Name: Göttingen
Alternative_Name: Gutingi; Guthingen; Guthinge; Gutinge; Gutingen; Guttingen; Gudingin; Gotinge; Gotingen; Ghotingen; Gothinge; Gottinghe; Gottingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a donation charter of Emperor Otto I to the monastery of St Maurice in Magdeburg.
Town_Description: It is unknown when exactly the town rights were acquired, probably in the early 13th century. First mention as "civitas" around 1230.
Toll_Description: Fee for safe conduct for commodities moved through town, owned by the Duke of Brunswick, and toll for all commodities sold and bought in Göttingen, except those intended for the nobility and clerics, perishables and retail. Already in 1380, the height of the toll was defined by the civic council. Extensive toll registers exist from the first half of the 15th century. The toll was levied at the town gates.
Fair_Description: In Göttingen trade regulations of the year 1398, four fairs are mentioned, taking place on St Walpurga, Corpus Christi, St James and St Simon and Juda. The Corpus Christi fair was founded in 1380.

Name: Northeim
Alternative_Name: Northeim; Nordheim; Northeheim; Northeimensi; Northeym; Northemensis; Norttem; Northem; Nortem; Northum; Nordtheimb; Northeimb
Settlement_Description: Northeim probably originated in Frankish times. It is first mentioned around 780-802.
Town_Description: The settlement acquired town privileges in 1252 from Duke Otto the Child. The town privileges of Göttingen were granted in 1266.
Toll_Description: The Benedictine monastery acquired toll privileges in 1141. In 1492, the town received permission from Duke Wilhelm of Brunswick to levy a road toll for 20 years to fund the improvement of the road to Hammenstedt. It was also levied at the other roads leading out of town and remained in existence after 20 years. In 1502, a ducal road toll was added by Duke Erich, which was levied at the town gates as well.
Fair_Description: Three three-day fairs are mentioned in Northeim in 1336, "as they have taken place since old times" on the Sundays after St John, St Bartholomew and St Andrew. It is unclear when these fairs were founded, but probably not later than the year the settlement received the Göttingen town privileges in 1266. After 1336, a fourth fair on Sunday after Estomihi was added.

Name: Nörten
Alternative_Name: Nörten-Hardenberg; Norhtunon; Norzunun; Northun; Northunun; Nortzun; Nortun; Northune; Norzun; Nortunensis; Nortuni; Nortene; Northene; Nortunis; Northunensi; Nortten; Nörthen
Settlement_Description: Nörten was the seat of the law court of the nearby castle Hardenberg, which belonged to the archbishop of Mainz.
Town_Description: Town, market and fortification privileges were granted in 1360, but from the late 15th century onwards, Nörten is usually referred to as borough ('flecken').
Toll_Description: A toll is first mentioned in 1357, then already existing for a while. In the town privileges of 1360, it is determined that the archbishop of Mainz had the right to levy a toll of 1 shilling in the Göttingen currency of each horse pulling a wagon or cart through town. In 1478, an additional road toll for the maintenance of the street is installed.

Name: Angerstein
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1082.
Toll_Description: Insignificant toll, first mentioned in 1394.

Name: Bovenden
Alternative_Name: Bobbenzunon; Bobbontenini; Bobentunon; Bobbentun; Bovendten; Bobbantun; Bouenten; Boventhen; Bovente; Boventen; Bobenczen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 949. In the 16th century the settlement became a borough ('Flecken').

Name: Weende
Alternative_Name: Uunide; Winithi; Winnithi; Winithe; Winethe; Winethen; Winede; Venede; Wenedhe; Winedhe; Wenede; Wende; Wenden; Wehnde; Wehende
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 966 as 'Uuinide'.
Toll_Description: A new toll station of the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg was installed in Weende in 1501, but destroyed by Göttingen citizens. Between 1504 and 1512, a toll was effectively levied in Weende.

Bridge_Description: The often wet valley of the Leine is relatively narrow south of Nörten, and was therefore often used as a river crossing point. A bridge is already mentioned in 1055.

Name: Parensen
Alternative_Name: Peranhuson; Perranhusun; Perranhus; Perhusun; Pernhusen; Perrenhusen; Parenhosen; Parhusin; Parnhusen; Parenhusen; Parnnhussenn; Parnhußen; Parhusen; Parnhaussen; Paarensen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 990.

Name: Harste
Alternative_Name: Hersithi; Heristi; Hersiti; Hiristi; Heriste; Herste; Hersthe; Harsta; Harst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 822 and 826. There existed a moated castle of the dukes of Brunswick here, which was first mentioned in 1294.
Toll_Description: In 1413, the duke of Brunswick leased the toll and safe conduct in Harste and Göttingen to Albrecht Lange.

Name: Barterode
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1093.

Name: Güntersen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1059.

Name: Imbsen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1093.

Name: Varlosen
Alternative_Name: Vereldehusen; Uereldehusen; Verldehosen; Verlidehosen; Ferlehosen; Ferlehusen; Verlehussenn; Varloisszen; Varlehusen; Varlhausen; Varlosen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1093.

Name: Bühren
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Gimte
Alternative_Name: Gemmet; Gimmeth; Gymmit; Gympt; Gemyt; Gimmette
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 970.

Bridge_Description: The Werra bridge in Münden is first mentioned in 1329. It was rebuilt in stone with seven arches in 1397-1402. A bridge toll was mentioned in the 15th century.

Name: Hann. Münden
Alternative_Name: Münden; Hannoversch Münden; Gemunden; Gemunde; Gimundi; Gmunden; Gemundin; Munden
Settlement_Description: The older settlement Altmünden west of the Fulda river is first mentioned around 800; the newer settlement on the opposite shore in 1049.
Town_Description: Possibly a planned town was founded around the middle of the 12th century at the confluence of the Werra and Fulda in the Weser river. It is first mentioned as the town Münden around 1182-85.
Staple_Description: The basis for the Münden staple was its location at the confluence of the Werra, Fulda and Weser rivers. Natural and man-made barriers in the river arms forced transshipment to other vessels for further transportation on one of the three rivers. The town was granted a staple privilege by the duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg in 1247, although the document is probably a falsification made during a conflict with Kassel in 1319 about the salt trade. The staple privilege was confirmed by emperor Rudolf II in 1597. The shipping regulations from 1653 mention the right of Münden skippers to sail past the town, whereas skippers from other towns were obliged to unload their cargo in Münden. Moreover, the Münden skippers sought to acquire a privilege for shipping between Münden and Kassel. The staple led to numerous conflicts, mostly with Kassel, in the 16th and 17th centuries. Although the staple privilege does not discern between river and land traffic, it seems that it was only applied to river traffic.

Bridge_Description: A box for collecting transit fees was placed on the bridge in the 15th century.

Name: Rosdorf
Alternative_Name: Rasthorp; Rastherpe; Rostorpe; Rostorph; Rostorff; Rostorppe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1004.

Name: Mengershausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Vorwerk Heißental
Alternative_Name: Heißenthal; Hesledale; Heslendal; Hesledal; Heysendal; Heistindal; Heistendal; Hesendal; Heyssendale; Heseldal; Heissindal; Hessendal; Hessintal; Hoitzkendale; Hoitzendale; Heistendal; Heitzendal; Heistindael; Heyttzendall; Heszendael; Heissendall; Heisendahl; Heißendal; Heissenthal
Settlement_Description: The folwark was built in the 17th century near the settlement of Heistendal, which had been abandoned in the 15th century and was first mentioned in 1251.

Name: Jühnde
Alternative_Name: Iuniun; June; Iunen; Juine; Junde; Juende
Settlement_Description: First mention of the settlement in 960. A castle is first mentioned in the 13th century, the St Martin's church in 1271.

Name: Meensen
Alternative_Name: Manisi; Mamese; Manese; Meinse; Menise; Gropenmeinse; Gropenmense; Meynse; Grobmense; Mense; Großmenße; Meynssen; Mensze; Mäensen; Meinsen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 990.

Name: Wiershausen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 990.

Name: Grone
Alternative_Name: Grona; Gronaa; Gruonaha; Gruona; Grune; Gronte; Oldingrone; Aldingrone; Veteri-Grone; Aldengrune; Oldengrona; Oldengrone; Olden Grone
Settlement_Description: Northeast of the current Göttingen quarter Grone on the street to Harste, there existed the royal palace Grone and a connected settlement named Burggrone, which are first mentioned in 915 and 1101 respectively. The castle was destroyed by Göttingen citizens in 1294 and again in 1387, after which Burggrone was abandoned. The later village and current quarter Grone developed from the farm Altgrone, which belonged to the palace and is first mentioned in 1118-1137.

Name: Olenhuser Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Göttingen, built on a hill north of the road. The road was closed off with a boom barrier.

Name: Settmarshausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1239.

Name: Klein Wiershausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1303.

Name: Varmissen
Alternative_Name: Vermelsen; Vermissen; Vermessen; Vermelsen; Farmesen; Varmißen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1311.

Name: Dransfeld
Alternative_Name: Trhenesfelde; Dransvelt; Thransfellensem; Triensvelt; Dransfelde; Transfeldun; Thransfelde; Drinsfelt; Transwelde; Dransveld; Transvelt; Dransvelde; Transfeldt; Dransfeldt
Settlement_Description: Perhaps a settlement developed around a church of St Martin, founded in the 9th century. Dransfeld was first mentioned in 960.
Town_Description: Traditionally, it is assumed that town privileges were acquired in or before 1305, but it is likely that the settlement was only a borough ('flecken') at that point. Full Münden town privileges were granted by Duke Otto of Brunswick in 1368.

Name: Wellersen
Alternative_Name: Walieressun; Wilredesheim; Weldersen; Wellerdessen; Wilredessen; Welersen; Wellerssen; Welryczen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1015 and 1036. In the Middle Ages a village, nowadays only a manor. It is unknown whether the village was only partially abandoned or that it disappeared completely with the manor being built later.

Name: Niederscheden
Alternative_Name: Scheden; Nederen Scheden; Inferiori Scheiden; Nieder Schneeden; Niederscheeden
Settlement_Description: The settlement Scheden, first mentioned in 1046, was divided into Niederscheden and Oberscheden, of which the former was first mentioned separately in 1317. In modern times, both settlements have grown together again.

Name: Volkmarshausen
Alternative_Name: Folcmareshusen; Uolcmereshuson; Volcmershusen; Volgmershusin; Folkmerssen; Folkmershusen; Volkmerssen; Volkmershausen; Volckmerßhausen; Volgmarshusen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between the 8th and the 9th century. In 1345, a boom barrier was built here as part of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Münden.

Name: Lenglern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 966.

Name: Holtensen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in the middle of the 13th century.

Name: Reinser Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Einbeck, close to the former village Reinsen, built in 1407. It was first mentioned in 1454. Demolished in 1800.
Toll_Description: A toll of the Amt Salzderhelden, which was levied at the Reinser Turm, was first mentioned in 1548.

Name: Strodthagen
Settlement_Description: At the Sülberg in Strodthagen there existed a regional law court, which was moved later into the settlement and is still mentioned in the 16th century as local court.
Toll_Description: The toll is mentioned in charters from 1394 and 1395 and was still levied in the 18th century.

Name: Buensen
Settlement_Description: First reference in 1120.

Name: Pilshäger Warte
Alternative_Name: Pilshager Warte; Pilshäger Turm; Pilshagen; Pyleshaghen; Pfeilshagen; Pylshagen; Pilshäger Thurm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower, erected by duke Otto I the Evil of Brunswick-Göttingen between 1383 and 1394.

Name: Moringen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1002-1003. There was a royal court here, and from 1158 a castle of the Dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg.
Town_Description: The date of acquisition of town rights is unclear. Already in the middle of the 14th century, there existed an urban community; Uslar town privileges are reiterated in 1384.
Toll_Description: A "new" toll in Moringen is pawned by duke Erich of Brunswick-Calenberg to Cord von Mandelsloh in 1514.
Fair_Description: Moringen acquired the right to hold a fair four times: in 1390 on St Margaret, founded by duke Otto I of Brunswick-Göttingen; in 1432 on St Michael, founded by Otto II; in 1582 on the Presentation of Mary, founded by duke Erich; and in 1684 on Sunday Judica, founded by duke Ernst August.

Name: Thüdinghausen
Alternative_Name: Thutiggehusen; Tudyngehusen; Tugingehußen; Tugehausen; Dudinghausenn; Tudhusen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1139.

Name: Gladebeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1015 and 1036. A castle of the dukes of Brunswick existed here possibly since 1318, first mentioned in 1447. It must have dilapidated in the late 16th century.

Name: Einbeck
Alternative_Name: Embecka; Einbike; Enbiche; Enbike; Enbeka; Einbeche; Embeke; Embike; Eimbike; Enbyke; Eymbecke; Eymbeke; Eimbecke; Eimbek
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the time of Emperor Conrad II (1024-1039) as "predium" (estate) of count Udo of Katlenburg. The monastery of St Alexander was founded before 1085. South of it, a market settlement developed in the late 12th century.
Town_Description: Einbeck was mentioned as "civitas" in 1203 und 1239. A council is first mentioned in 1252, a town wall in 1264, and a "new" market in 1266. Braunschweig town privileges were granted in 1279.
Toll_Description: The safe conduct in Einbeck was changed into a road and bridge fee in 1417.

Name: Geismar
Alternative_Name: Gesmaria; Geismare; Geismariam; Geysmaria; Geißmer; Geußmar
Settlement_Description: First mentioned 1055.

Name: Diemardener Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower ('warte') was part of the enclosure ('Landwehr') of Göttingen, built in 1409. It still exists today.

Name: Klein Lengden
Alternative_Name: Lengidi; Lengithi; Lengithe; Inferiori Lengede; Minori Lengede; Lutteken Lengede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 8th or 9th century as 'Lengidi'. At first there was only Lengden, since 1022 a distinction was made between Groß- and Klein Lengden.

Name: Wittmarshof
Alternative_Name: Wittmarsdorf; Witmereshusen; Witmershusen; Vintmarishusen; Wetmarishusen; Wetmershusen; Wethmarshusen; Withmarshusen; Witemershusen; Witmarstenhusen; Witmarshusen; Wettmarshausen; Wittmarshoff; Wetmarshausen; Withmershausen; Witmarshoff; Wettmarshof
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022. Originally called Wittmarshausen, it is mentioned to have been (partially?) abandoned in the 15th century. In the 16th century, the name Wittmarshof appears, which is probably related to its resettlement as folwark.

Name: Gelliehausen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in a forged document from the 12th century.

Name: Bischhausen (Eichsfeld)
Alternative_Name: Bischhausen; Bischoppeshusen; Biscopeshusen; Bissoueshusen; Byshusen; Bißhußen; Bischopshusen; Bishusen; Bishausen; Bischhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1189.

Name: Siemerode
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1055. In the 15th and 16th century the settlement was deserted, it is unclear when it was resettled. In 1693 the "parochia in Simeroda" is mentioned, which is probably means that it has been resettled in the meantime.

Name: Fegebankswarte
Alternative_Name: Beberberger Warte; Beber-Warte; Beverwarte; Vegebankswarte; Bebrawarte; Feygebankswarte; Vegebangkeswarthe; Feigebanckswarte; Fegebanks-Warte; Freyghebanks-Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower at the ditch ('Landwehr') surrounding Heiligenstadt. Plenary diets ('Landtag') of the Eichsfeld were held here. Demolished in the third decade of the 19th century.

Name: Heilbad Heiligenstadt
Settlement_Description: Heiligenstadt was founded as a missionary-centre and as a King's Court during the 9th and 10th century. Marketplace in the 11th century.
Town_Description: Archbishop Siegfried II. of Mainz gave town privileges in 1227.
Toll_Description: In 1294 the archepiscopal rights for tolls and safe conduct were moved from Beuren to Heiligenstadt.
Fair_Description: Heiligenstadt owned four fairs in 1460, two more were added later.

Name: Niedergandern
Alternative_Name: Gandera; Gadra; Gandera Inferioris; Nederen Gandera; Nederingandera; Neddergandra; Nederen Gandre; Nedderngander; Niddergandera; Nederengandere; Nedern Gandern; Nederen Gander; Nyderngander; Nedderngandera; Nieder Gandern; Niedergandra; Nieder Gander
Settlement_Description: The settlement Gandern, first mentioned in 1118-1137, was divided into the three parts Nieder-, Hohen- and Kirchgandern, of which Niedergandern is first mentioned separately in 1294.

Name: Hohengandern
Settlement_Description: Formerly part of the Eichsfeld of Mainz, it was pawned off to the family of Hanstein in the 14th century. The manor in Hohengandern was still in the property of the family of Hanstein in the early 20th century.
Toll_Description: Hohengandern was a main toll station since 1624. Safe conduct zones ended here.

Name: Arnstein
Settlement_Description: Local nobility is mentioned in 1248.

Name: 's-Heerenberg
Alternative_Name: de Berga; de Monte; de Berge; ’s Heerenberch; Burg; Berga; van den Berge; Herenbergensis; Graven Berge
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1122-1131.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted on 8 September 1379 by Willem I, count of Bergh and lord of Bylant, knight.

Name: Aachen
Alternative_Name: Aquis; Aquisgrani; Ahha; Ais em ma chapelle; Aix-la-Chapelle; Aken
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 769, Aachen was the primary residence of the Carolingians and place of coronation for over 30 German kings.
Town_Description: Aachen was granted town rights, as well as market and mint rights, as "caput civitatum" (head of towns) and as "caput et sedes regni Theutonici" (head and seat of the German kings) on 8 January 1166 by Emperor Frederick Barbarossa. The document became known as the "Karlsprivileg" and made the town to a free imperial city.

Name: Aijen
Alternative_Name: Oyen; Ayen; Aien; Aegen; Aeyen; Aaien
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1336.

Name: Aalborg
Settlement_Description: Archeological excavations have revealed a viking age seasonal market. Around 1000 AD a church was built, and Aalborg now seems to have been a permanent settlement with an urban character.
Town_Description: Around 1040 king Hardeknud (1035-1042) minted coins in Aalborg, which by now must be considered a town; described as “civitas” by Adam of Bremen c. 1075. Oldest town privileges are lost, by new privileges granted by king Valdemar IV (1340-1375) in 1342. An important royal castle, Aalborghus, is mentioned first in 1340, but presumably older. In 1232 a Franciscan convent was founded. Sometime before 1431 a town hall was built at the medieval town square. A new town hall was built shortly before 1499, but burned down in 1530, and was not rebuilt before after the Count's Feud (Danish: Grevens Fejde) 1534-1536.
Toll_Description: The origin of the toll is unclear. But at least from the middle of the 15th century onwards Aalborg was one of the most important royal tolls in Denmark. The first certain evidence of the toll is from 1447. During one of the Dano-Swedish wars, the Torstenson War 1643-1645, a toll building in Aalborg was destroyed, it was rebuilt in 1651.

Name: Aalst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 866, in a eigtheenth century copy. Next mention mention in 868, in a eigtheenth century copy. Next mention in 1088.

Name: Aane
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1232-1233.

Name: Aarschot
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1107.

Name: Aasbüttel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1576.

Name: Abbenrode
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1086.

Name: Abja
Settlement_Description: Manor that was first mentioned in 1551.

Name: Abteroda
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1015.

Name: Achim (Börßum)
Alternative_Name: Achim; Echeim; Achem; Acheim; Osterachem; Achum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as Echeim in 966.

Name: Achim (Weser)
Alternative_Name: Achim; Acheim; Achem; Achumb; Hachem; Haghem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1091.

Name: Ackendorf
Settlement_Description: In 1121 given as property to St. Lorenz' monastery near Schöningen. Probably of Slavic origin.

Name: Addenstorf
Alternative_Name: Addenstorff; Addunesthorp; Edelestorpe; Haddestorpe; Adestorpe; Adelstorpe; Addenstorpe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1004.

Name: Adelshausen
Alternative_Name: Odolvessen; Odolfshusen; Odolvishusin; Odolpheshusen; Odolfishusen; Odelshusen; Odelshausen; Adels Hausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1209. Referred to as 'villa' in 1318. At times desolate at the beginning of the 15th century.

Name: Aderstedt
Settlement_Description: The royal court in Aderstedt goes to the bishopric of Halberstadt in 1063 and becomes the property of Ilsenburg monastery in 1086.

Name: Adorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1120.

Name: Gaujiena
Settlement_Description: The castle was built in the 13th century. Later, there was also a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') nex to the castel.

Name: Aerzen
Alternative_Name: Artzen; Artelessen; Artlissen; Arteldessen; Arthesloin; Artldissen; Ertelsen, Ertsen; Artzelen; Artzen
Settlement_Description: Castle of the lords of Everstein, first mentioned around 1200. In 1293, we hear for the first time of a settlement ('oppidum') near the castle. It received borough ('flecken') privileges in 1589.
Toll_Description: Count Hermann of Everstein confirmed in 1385 that Hameln remained exempted from the toll in Aerzen as before.

Name: Afferde
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1042.

Name: Afferden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1293.

Name: Afsched
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1302.

Name: Agathenburg
Settlement_Description: The village was originally called Lieth, and first mentioned as such in 1199. The village was renamed Agathenburg when a manor house was built here with the same name in 1652.

Name: Ageri
Settlement_Description: Village and Manor were mentioned in 1447.

Name: Ahlen
Alternative_Name: in Alnon; de Alnen; Alnun; Alen
Town_Description: The settlement was mentioned in 1224 as a fortified place or town but was granted Munster town privileges in 1245.

Name: Ahlhorn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000.

Name: Aligse
Alternative_Name: Aldagessem; Aldesse; Aldaghesen; Aldessche; Aelße; Ahlse; Ahligse
Settlement_Description: Evidence for earlier mentions in 826-872 and 1022 is based on falsified documents.

Name: Ahnebeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1503.

Name: Ahrbeck
Settlement_Description: Because of the likeliness of confusion with nearby Arpke, of which the name shares the same onomastic origin, the first certain mention of Ahrbeck can only be attested in 1406.

Name: Ahrensbök
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1328. A Carthusian monastery was founded in 1397. Because of a statue of the Virgin Mary, it became a pilgrimage destination in the Middle Ages. The monastery was secularised in 1542, the settlement was abandoned and turned into a folwark in 1593.

Name: Ahrenswohlde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of the castle Bremervörde between 1498 and 1500. At the time, the settlement consisted of three farms and two cottages.

Name: Aidu (Viljandi)
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1583. A hamlet ('Hof') was built between 1638 and 1688.

Name: Aidu (Jõgeva)
Settlement_Description: The village and the Inn were first mentioned in 1583.

Name: Aken
Settlement_Description: First mentioned with the name Waltherus de Aken in 1219. The Ascanian electorate princes and the dukes of Saxony owned a residence in Aken. It was also an important centre for shipping on the Elbe.
Town_Description: First mention as town 1271.
Toll_Description:
A toll in Aken is first mentioned in 1295.
In 1447, the castle and the town of Aken are pawned off, including toll and ferry. In 1485, the burnt down town of Aken is granted excemption from toll and ferry fees.
In the 16th century, escorts ('Geleitsleute') are mentioned several times in the fiefdom ledgers ('Lehnsbücher') of the archbishops of Magdeburg.
Staple_Description: Aken loses its staple rights to Magdeburg

Name: Alansi
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241. In 1417, the village including the hamlet ('Hof') and mill were given to Jacob Ronne. Shortly after that the hamlet in Alansi lost its importance.

Name: Albachten
Alternative_Name: in Albagthon; et terram Albucten; Albatten; Albuthen; Albach

Name: Albersdorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1281. The village church dates from ca. 1230.

Name: Albersloh
Alternative_Name: Albrecteslo; Alberteslon; Albratteslo; Albrahteslo; Albrahtello; Alebragsteslo; Alberteslo; Albersloe

Name: Albsfelde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230.

Name: Aldekerk
Toll_Description: In 1436, the Duke of Geldern levied a land toll whose revenues are not preserved. The toll was later abolished due to a complaint by the town of Geldern.

Name: Aldenhoven
Settlement_Description: First mention in a possibly falsified document from the last quarter of the 11th century. The place was fortified at the end of the 14th century.
Toll_Description: The Duke of Jülich levied a road toll in 1501. It is known that the annual income in 1501 and 1510/11 was 3 Mark and 6 Shilling. The toll was probably leased.

Name: Aldrup
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 9th century.

Name: Alfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in ca. 1019-1022. The settlement developed at a ford at the Leine river, which was secured by a castle (first mentioned in 1358).
Town_Description: Acquired town privileges between 1220 and 1258 and became the second-most important town in the diocese of Hildesheim.
Fair_Description: In 1501, two two-day fairs were mentioned in Alfeld, which took place "according to old custom" on St Nicholas and Sunday Letare. These probably went back to the time that Alfeld became a town. In 1456 three additional fairs were added, on St Vitus, St Gallus and on Sunday before All Saints' Day. The Vitus and Gallus fairs were extended with three-day cattle markets in 1619.

Name: Alfhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 977. Around 1350 Alfhusen was called 'villa'.

Name: Algermissen
Alternative_Name: Algrimsen; Alegremishusun; de Alegrimessem; Groten Alghermissen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 980 and 982. The settlement consisted of the two parts Groß and Klein Algermissen until the modern period.

Name: Alavere
Settlement_Description: The Manor was mentioned in 1241.

Name: Allaži
Settlement_Description: In 1562 Heinrich von Dohna was assigned the area. Thereupon, a manor house and a village emerged.

Name: Druzhba
Settlement_Description: Prussian castle on the 'Zickelberg' has been reinforced in 1256 after being seized by the Teutonic Order, was destroyed again four years later and again rebuilt in 1272, afterwards a settlement grew
Town_Description: The Grandmaster of the Teutonic Order, Konrad von Jungingen grants the Magdeburg-Kulm town law, endorsed in 1663 by the Great Elector

Name: Allendorf (Dillenburg)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1362.

Name: Allendorf (Sauerland)
Alternative_Name: Allendorf; Aldendorp; Aldendorpp; Oldendorp; Aldendorff; Allentrop
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1269.

Name: Türi-Alliku
Settlement_Description: Hamlet ('Wirtschaftshof') of the Teutonic Order, which was mentioned in 1429.

Name: Olsztyn
Alternative_Name: Allenstein; Olsten; Allemsteyn; Allensteyn Nowemiasto; Olchsztyn; Olsthin; Olsztin; Olsztyn; Nova civitas
Settlement_Description: Castle of the diocesan chapter of Pomesania built before 1353, when there existed a mill and a settlement
Town_Description: Town probably existed before 1348, founding documents were granted in 1353 by the diocesan chapter of Pomesania, Kulm town law, mentioned as civitas seu opidu in 1353 and opidum in 1378

Name: Allerbüttel
Alternative_Name: Alersbutle; Allersbuttele; Allersbutle; Allersbuttel; Alersbüttel; Alersbuttel in dem poppedike; Allerßbuttel; Alrßbuttel; Alrsbuttel; Allersbuttle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1292/96.

Name: Alleringhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1332 and 1344.

Name: Allmenhausen
Settlement_Description: Mention in a gift certificate 1133 to Jechaburg monastary by Archbishop Adalbert I.

Name: Aluvere
Settlement_Description: The village was sold to the Teutonic Order in the 15th century and thus belonged to the manor of 'Sommerhusen'.

Name: Allstedt
Settlement_Description: Allstedt was a royal court since the 10th century. A market was founded between 1323 and 1330.
Town_Description: In 1425 Allstedt was granted town rights.

Name: Almelo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention from Almelo dates from 1157 (in a seventeenth century copy).
Town_Description: From 1346 onward, Almelo gradually grew into a place with town-like characteristics. Town privileges were probably granted by Evert van Heeckeren and Beatrix II, lord and lady of Almelo, before 3 July 1376, probably between ca. 1363 and 1376.

Name: Albu
Settlement_Description: The Manor was mentioned in 1282.

Name: Alphen
Alternative_Name: Alfheim; Alphem; Alfeim; Alpheym; Alfem; Alpheem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 709, in a copy dating from 1191. Next mention in the twelfth century.

Name: Alsemberg
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1219.

Name: Alsfeld
Alternative_Name: Adelsfelt; Adelsveld; Agilsvelt; Adelesfelt; Ailesuelt; Alsffeild; Alsfelt; Alsfeild; Alsveld; Alsvelt; Elsfeld; Alsfeylt; Aylsfeld

Name: Alsleben
Settlement_Description: A castle and a monastery were built in the 10th century. First mentioned in 961.
Town_Description: The year in which the town rights were granted is unknown. However, Alsleben was referred to as "town" in 1479.
Ferry_Description: There was an important Saale crossing in Alsleben since the Early Middle Ages, which was only replaced by a bridge in 1867.

Name: Alstätte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a confirmation charter of bishop Werner of Münster of 1151. Mentioned as belonging to Münster cathedral in 1176.

Name: Vecaduliena
Alternative_Name: Alt Adlehn; pagast Adolene; pagast Adelen
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1354 as 'pagast Adolene'.

Name: Hummuli
Settlement_Description: The area is mentioned in 1226, the manor was only built after 1470.

Name: Alt Mölln
Settlement_Description: "Mulne" was first mentioned in 1188. The original Slavic settlement was probably located at the mouth of the Delvenau in the Mölln lake, near the current street "Ohlendörp". It was moved to Altmölln before 1194, when it was first mentioned, already with the addition "old".

Name: Oer
Alternative_Name: Oer-Erkenschwick; Ora; Ure; Hure; Ore; Tore
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1160

Name: Alt-Wolfsburg
Settlement_Description: The castle Wolfsburg on a crossing of the Aller river is first mentioned in 1135, and expanded by the von Bartensleben family after 1300.

Name: Altastenberg
Alternative_Name: Lichtenscheid; Lichtenscheidt; Lechtenscheit; Lichtenschet; Astenbergk; Astenberg; Ostenberg; Alt-Astenberg; Alt Astenberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1533. After 1536 some huts were built on the Lichtenscheid, where a settlement formed.

Name: Dąbie
Alternative_Name: Altdamm; Badam; Dambe; Damm; Damme; Alten Damm
Settlement_Description: A settlement existed close to the hillfort Badam, which was destroyed by the Polish in 1121.The duke of Pomerania gifted it to the monastery of Kolbatz, but it became his fiefdom again in 1226
Town_Description: Duke Barnim I granted the Madgeburg town law in 1260, it was changed to Lübeck town law in 1293 but returned to the former one in 1297.

Name: Altefeld
Settlement_Description: Forst mentioned in 1326.

Name: Altena
Alternative_Name: de Altena; de Alzena; de Altina; Althena; Althenae

Name: Altenbauna
Alternative_Name: Bunon in pago Hessigowe; Bunun; Bunen; Altdenbune
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as Bunon in 1015. It was the seat of a landgrave's office and court.

Name: Altenboizen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1242.

Name: Altenbreitungen
Settlement_Description: Today, Alten-, Frauen- and Herrenbreitungen are merged into one village called Breitungen.
Bridge_Description: Bridge at Frauenbreitungen first mentioned in 1137.

Name: Altenbüren
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1338.

Name: Altenburg
Settlement_Description: From approximately 800 centre of the Slavic area called Plisni (Pleißenland). A castle and a rampart were referred to as the Altenburg. A small village called Pauritz settled close to the castle's rampart. From the 11th to the 13th century the castle was used as an imperial palace ('Kaiserpfalz') so that the village showed early urban structures in the 11th century.
Town_Description: From 1165 Altenburg consisted of an old and new town. In 1205 it was referred to as civitas. First record of town rights in 1256.
Toll_Description: The regulations of safe conducht ('Geleitsordnung') and bills of safe conduct ('Geleitsrechnungen') for Altenburg regulate the fees for several wares (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Bb 318, 1515, p. 3–4.).

Name: Vecpils
Settlement_Description: A manor was mentioned in 1387.

Name: Altencelle
Settlement_Description: A castle Celle is first mentioned before 1007, possibly in 983. The settlement acquired town privileges around 1249, but was moved 3 km downstream the Aller river in 1292, to the current location of Celle. Thereupon the original settlement became known as Altencelle ('old Celle').

Name: Altendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1206.

Name: Altenhagen
Alternative_Name: Hainanblic; Haianblik; Indago; Oldenhaghen; Oldenhagen; Hagene; Haghene; Aldenhagen; Old Hag
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 990.

Name: Altensalzwedel
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1375.

Name: Altenstaßfurt
Settlement_Description: Probably location of a moot of the Eastern Saxonians, called in by Charlemagne. 970 salines in Ostersalzhusen (district of Staßfurt) are given to Thankmarsfelde monastery by archbishop Gero of Cologne and his brother margrave Thietmar. Altstaßfurt thus gained market rights. 1035 the market is moved from Altstaßfurt to Nienburg

Name: Altenvers
Alternative_Name: Ferse; Verse; Virse; Aldenverse; Aldynvers; Altenfersa
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1130.

Name: Altenweddingen
Settlement_Description: Given to St. Moritz' monastery by Otto I. in 937. In 1338 it is mentioned as deserted, but a family of Weddinge is reported to reside here into the 16th century.

Name: Altenzaun
Settlement_Description: First secure mention in 1238; earlier mentions from 946 and 1150 can not clearly be referred to Altenzaun.
Ferry_Description: Altenzaun maintained a small passenger ferry.

Name: Altgandersheim
Alternative_Name: Gandesheim; Aldangandesheim; Aldengandersem; Antiquam Gandersem; Oldengandersem; Olden Gandersheim; Altengandersheim; Altengandersheimb
Settlement_Description: Originally, the settlement was called Gandersheim until the foundation of the monastery of Gandersheim (the current Bad Gandersheim) in 852, whereupon the old settlement became known as Alt ('old') Gandersheim.

Name: Altharen
Settlement_Description: Haren was sold to the bishop of Münster in 1076, who built a castle there. The name Haren was later transferred to the younger settlement on the river Ems, which developed in the 13th century. The old settlement thereupon came to be known as Alt-('old')haren.

Name: Altmörbitz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1280 as Merenvitz.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Altenburg.

Name: Altmorschen
Alternative_Name: Mursna; Mornaha; Mursine; Mursenaha; Mursina; Mursne; Aldenmorsene; Aldenmorsne; antiquo morsen; antiquo morsne; Alten Morschen; Altenmorßen; Altenmorsen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the first half of the 9th century.

Name: Hof Altona
Settlement_Description: Inn and farm, first mentioned in 1388.

Name: Altpenig
Settlement_Description: First mention of Altenpenig in 1400.

Name: Altruppin
Settlement_Description: In early German times, a castle was constructed already, which was never captured. It served as the seat of the counts of Lindow-Ruppin from the first third of the 13th century until their demise in 1524. The German settlement developed in the 13th century, but never gained town rights.

Name: Altwarmbüchen
Alternative_Name: Wermboke; Werenbeke; Warmboken; Oldewarmboken; Olderwarmbeek; Alten Warmboiken
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1196.

Name: Alverdissen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1151. A planned town was founded by the count of Sternberg around 1300, but it never received full town privileges. It is characterised as town in 1410, but only as borough ('weichbild') in 1464.

Name: Allzunah
Settlement_Description: Emerges from the foundation of a glassworks in 1691.

Name: Embūte
Settlement_Description: The Teutonic Order built the old castle between 1245-50. However, it may have been built later, in 1265. Until 1583 it was the domain of the bishop.

Name: Amelinghausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1236. From ca. 1300 seat of an administrative division ('vogtei'), later a law court is attested.

Name: Amelungsborn
Alternative_Name: Amelunxborn; Amelungesborne; Amelungesbrunne; Amelunxburne; Amelungesborn; Amelungesburne; Amelungisburne; Amelungsburnen; Amelungisborne; Amelungesbornen; Amelsborn; Amelinghesborne; Amelunghesbornn;
Settlement_Description: Cistercian monastery, founded between 1123 and 1135. According to the Annales Cistercienses, the monks moved in in 1135. The monastery became Lutheran in 1568.

Name: Amerongen
Alternative_Name: Amerungon; Amerunga; Amerungen; Amerunghe; Ameronge; Amerunge; Amerhunge
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1126, in a falsification which probably dates from the twelfth century.

Name: Amersfoort
Alternative_Name: Amersfoirde; Amersfoorde; Amersforden; Amervoirde; Amersfordia; Amersfort;
Settlement_Description: Amersfoort is first mentioned in 1028. It developed from a bishop's court that existed already in 1203.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted before 12 June 1259 by Henry I van Vianden, bishop of Utrecht.

Name: Ammensen
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1093.
Toll_Description: A toll of the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg in Ammensen is mentioned in 1412, 1502 and 1567.

Name: Ammern
Settlement_Description: First mention in 897. Archaeological finds indicate intensive settlement in Germanic and Frankish times, it possibly held some meaning as a manor.

Name: Amöneburg
Alternative_Name: Amelburg; Amanaburch; Hamanaburch; Ameneburc; Ameneburg; Amelburg; Omelburg; Amenburg; Amelbork; Omenburg; Amaeneburgk; Omeneburg
Settlement_Description: In 721 a monastery was founded by Boniface.
Town_Description: Town foundation probably at the beginning of the 13th century by the Archbishop of Mainz. Since 1260 'civitas' are mentioned.

Name: Ambla
Settlement_Description: The place with a church was built in the 13th century. It was mentioned for the first time in 1253. The church was probably built by the Danes in 1221-23.

Name: Amsterdam
Alternative_Name: Amstelledamme; Amstelredamme; Amstelodanum; Amestelredam; Amestelredamme; Aemstelredamme
Settlement_Description: Amsterdam is first mentioned in 1275.
Town_Description: Town privileges were officially granted after 21 May 1300 and before 5 August 1301. Extended town privileges were granted on 9 December 1342. The largest of six 'Kamers' (departments) of the VOC (Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie, the Dutch East India Company, founded in 1602) was located in Amsterdam.
Staple_Description: A decree of the town council forbade the trade in surrounding villages in 1548. Already in 1531, staple-like measures can be seen in the exclusive right of the trade with Hamburg beer.

Name: Anderlecht
Alternative_Name: Andreleth; Andrelech; Andarlech; Andrelet; Anderlecth; Anderleght
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1046.

Name: Andernach
Toll_Description: (1) The Archbishop of Cologne levied a river toll on the Rhine from 1147 to 1190, in 1235, from 1277 to 1282, from 1287 to 1302 and from 1306 to 1365. In 1365, the toll was relocated to Linz until it was reestablished in Andernach in 1475. Between 1475 and 1485, the annual return amounted to 3000 Gulden. The amount to pay for wine was relatively low, but salt, fish and grains are similar to the tariffs in Bonn. The tariffs can bee seen under the following source below. (2) In 1302 and from 1312, together with the river toll, an escort fee was levied by the Archbishop of Cologne. (3) This unknown toll, probably a transit toll, was levied from 1389 and concerned millstones. The tariff per millstone was 6 Pfennig/Denar. The annual yield amounted to 12 Mark in 1390-95 and 1433.

Name: Angermünde
Alternative_Name: Angermunde; Angermund; Angermundt; Nova Angermünde; Nigen Angermünde; Nuwen Angermünde; Newen Angermünde
Settlement_Description: small Ascanian fortress built on Wendish remains, probably during the acquisition of the Uckermarken by the Ascanians betweens 1232 and 1250, first documental mention from 1263
Town_Description: Founded by the Margraves Johann I. and Otto III., between 1230 and 1267, 1284 mentioned as a civitas, in 1286 the Angermünder town law was granted to Stolpe, in 1440 to Arnswalde

Name: Angenrod
Alternative_Name: Angerod; Ingerode; Engerode; Angerode; Angerrodt; Angenrodt; Engerodt; Angerod
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1272.

Name: Anholt
Settlement_Description: In the 12th century the lords of Zuylen built a castle near which the settlement grew. It was first mentioned in 1234.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted in 1349 by Dietrich of Zuylen.
Toll_Description: The Lord of Batenburg-Anholt levied a land toll from 1475. The exact localisation as well as revenues are not known.

Name: Anklam
Alternative_Name: Tanchlim; Tanchlym; Anclam; Tanglim; Tanclim; Anclim; Anclym; Tangelin; Danglyn; Anclam; Tanclem; Tanglym; Angklem; Ancklym; Anglam; Anglym; Angelheim
Settlement_Description: newly found around 1242-43, systematically built close to a river crossing
Town_Description: proof of Lübeck town law in 1292
Staple_Description: In 1579, Anklam acquired the right to force merchants to offer their commodities on the local markets for two hours; confirmed in 1679.

Name: Ankum
Alternative_Name: Ainghem; Anchem; Amghem; Tamchem; Anthem; Anchemmen; Anckumb
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned as 'locus' in 977. The fortified parish church is first attested in 1169. From the end of the 12th century often mentioned as 'villa'.
Fair_Description: A fair in Ankum is first clearly attested in 1580, but possibly goes back to the 13th century.

Name: Anloo
Alternative_Name: Anloe; Anlon; Anlo; Aenlo; Amloe; Andloe; Andelo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1139, in sixteenth century copy. The next mention is a copy from circa 1148.

Name: Annarode
Settlement_Description: First mention of the village in 1400.

Name: Emburga
Settlement_Description: In the 13th or 14th century, a castle was built probably by the Teutonic Order.

Name: Anikvere
Settlement_Description: Village that belongs to the Manor of Oberpahlen castle.

Name: Antwerpen
Alternative_Name: Andouerpenses; Andouerpis; Antwerpo; Andouerpis castro; Antwerpia; Antwerpensis; Antwerp; Anvers
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in eighth century in a tenth century copy. Next mention in 692-726, in a copy dating from 1191. Next mention 980. Next mention in 1124.
Staple_Description: Malines citizens were freed from staple obligations for fish, salt and oats in Antwerp in 1356, which led to decades of conflict between both cities, ended in favour of Antwerp in 1415. Staple of fatty products for Holland in 1358. 1407: Staple of English cloth merchants. 1409: Privileges of the Hanse, partial relocation of Hanseatic activities from Bruges to Antwerp. 1444 Staple of Middelburg trading guilds. 1452: Hanseatic staple of Rhenish wines, together with Dordrecht. 1491: Staple for alum from Tolfa. 1540: Agreement with Scotland for a staple of Scottish salt and fishes. An agreement with the Hanse made the city the principal Hanseatic residency in the Netherlands in 1563.
Fair_Description: Salt and fish market, which was moved to Malines. Emperor Henry VII moves it back to Antwerp in 1309, but moved to Malines again in 1369.

Name: Anzefahr
Alternative_Name: Ancevar, Anzenvar; Ancinvar; Antzphare; Anzenfahrt; Hansefahr
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1226. Referred to as 'villa' in 1277.

Name: Apeldoorn
Alternative_Name: Appoldro; Apeldern; Apeldorne; Apeldoren; Apeldoern; Appeldoren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 790-793, in a copy dating from 1170-1175. Next mention is in the beginning of the thirteenth century.
Toll_Description: A land toll owned by the landlord, the duke of Guelders, was levied near Apeldoorn.

Name: Apen
Settlement_Description: Around 1200, a castle existed in Apen, and from 1550 a fortress, which became an administrative and market centre.
Toll_Description: A butter toll in Apen is first mentioned in 1275, but possibly older. Additional tolls were levied on wagons and ships, as well as cattle driven through the village. The toll belonged to the Counts of Wildeshausen, later Oldenburg. Toll registers exist a.o. from 1428 and 1565.

Name: Aabenraa
Harbour_Description: A harbour in Aabenraa is mentioned in 1257.

Name: Aperloo
Alternative_Name: Apelderloe; Apeldorenloe; Apeldorlo; Apperloe; Aperloe; Apperloo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1313.

Name: Appels
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 707, in a copy dating from 941. Next mention in 1145.

Name: Appingedam
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1224, but probably Appingedam already existed around 1000.
Town_Description: Appingedam developed urban qualities in the 13th century with the establishment of a law court and market. With the privileges officially confirmed on 24 May 1327 in the 'buurbrief', Appingedam can be considered to have become a town.
Fair_Description: First mentioned in 1327, there were probably three fairs, held at the court days after the octave of Easter, after the Nativity of Mary and on the octave of Epiphany.

Name: Arbergen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230.

Name: Arcen
Alternative_Name: Arsnan; Arsen; Arsene; Aersen; Arssen; Aerssen; Aarcen; Aertsen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1100.

Name: Arendonk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1219.

Name: Arendsee
Settlement_Description: In 1184 a benedictine monastery was founded in close proximity to a village.
Town_Description: It is uncertain whether the place received any town rights. Though, the place was reffered to as 'oppidum' in 1289 and 1381. However, in 1445 the town is still mentioned as a 'Flecken'.
Fair_Description: In an official schedule from 1719, Osterburg, Arendsee and Bismark each held six fairs. It can be assumed that some of these had existed for a while to this point.

Name: Arendshorst
Alternative_Name: Aernshorst; Aernshorst; Arnshors; Arenshorst; Aerendshorst; Arendhorst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1381-1383.

Name: Kuressaare
Settlement_Description: In the second half of the 14th century the castle Arensburg was built, residence of the bishops of Ösel-Wiek. A fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built in the same century..
Town_Description: The settlement near the castle was granted Riga town rights in 1563.

Name: Arensburg
Settlement_Description: Around 1300, a castle was constructed to control the pass near Steinbergen, first mentioned in 1385. Possibly, the 12th-century castle Steinburg stood at the same location.

Name: Argenstein
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1332.

Name: Arneburg
Settlement_Description: In 925 Henry I. erected the castle (Arneburg) at the border to the Slavic area of settlement. In 978 a family of Arneburg is mentioned. The castle is destroyed at the end of the 10th century but rebuilt by Henry II in 1006.
Town_Description: First mention as 'civitas' in 1006, then again in 1338. In 1358 town like privileges are confirmed. In the 14th century there was a town council and court so that the place was called 'civitas'. A formal awarding of town rights has never taken place.
Toll_Description: The people of Stendal are granted exception from the toll of the castle as early as 1160. In 1345 excemption from tolls and safe conduct is granted to the citizens of Stendal, Salzwedel, Osterburg, Tangermünde, Seehausen, Werben, Havelberg and Arneburg. Further mentions of the toll during the pawning off of Arneburg in 1414 and 1416. In 1441 and 1452, Arneburg castle ist pawned off, which includes the land toll and the Elbe toll. In 1482 first mention of a wagon toll, further in 1487 as a road toll. In 1492 the toll is mentioned as belonging to the margrave.
Fair_Description: In 1672, fairs and cattle markets on Thursday and Friday after Quasimodogeniti and after Galli, as well as a fair on 27th June are mentioned in Arneburg. It can be assumed that some of these had existed for a while to this point. In 1379 three fairs are formally granted.

Name: Arnhem
Alternative_Name: Arnheim; Arneym; Arnem; Arnheym; Arem; Aerhem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 893.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted 13 July 1233 by Otto II, count of Guelders. He elevated Arnhem from oppidum to civitas.
Toll_Description: A land toll ('weggeld'), owned by the landlord, the duke of Guelders, was levied at all four mayor town gates: the Sabelspoort, Rijnpoort, Velperpoort, and Sint-Janspoort. The toll at the Rijnpoort (Rhine gate) linked up with the ferry, which stimulated trade-related traffic coming from the ferry to enter Arnhem. Most traffic used the Rijnpoort; profit from the Sint-Janspoort was quite low.
Staple_Description: Officially, Arnhem had no grain staple, but around the mid-fifteenth century, from 1437-1439 onward, the town de facto forced people to offer their load of grain for sale in Arnhem when passing by on the river Rhine. The grain market was located outside the Rhine gate, near the harbour.
Fair_Description: In 1294/95, Arnhem had three fairs. In 1459, and additional cattle fair was granted. Since the middle of the fourteenth century or even earlier, the dukes of Guelders had been pawning or leasing out the cashing of all three Arnhem fairs to private persons, and since 1372 to the town of Arnhem itself. Around the middle of the fourtheenth century, town accounts of Deventer mention a fair in Arnhem 'in festo Palmarum' or '(in) Palmis', which could refer to the Mid-Fast fair. Fairs took place on the 'Nieuwe Markt' (New Market), the present-day 'Korenmarkt', which was in function from the second quarter of the thirteenth century. Cloth was the most important commodity traded on the fairs in Arnhem, followed by wine and salt.

Name: Arnsbach
Alternative_Name: Arnesbach; Arnespack; Arnspach; Arnispach; Arinspach; Arnespach; Arnßpach; Arnßbach; Ahrnsbach; Ahrnspach
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1245. Called a 'villa' in 1314 and 1347.

Name: Arnsberg
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 1082, but goes back to the castle "Alte Burg", which is already named in 1060.
Town_Description: The duke Gottfried III. granted Arnsberg in 1237 the town privileges of Lippstadt and urban freedom. Additionally the town expanded.

Name: Arnsgereuth
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1337.

Name: Arnstadt
Settlement_Description: Before it was mentioned as a manor of the duke of Thuringia in 704, a ancient Thuringian settlement lay at the traffic route across the mountain range in direction of Main-Franconia.
Town_Description: In the 10th and 12th cenury, Arnstadt developed into a market and earned town rights in 1200, in 1220 it was referred to as civitas and a trading place.

Name: Arnstein
Settlement_Description: First secure mention of the castle in 1159, it has been the property of the counts of Mansfeld since 1387. The castle was already found ruinous in 1736.

Name: Choszczno
Alternative_Name: Arnswalde; Hoscno; Arneswolde; Chosczno alias Arnsberg; Arnszwald
Settlement_Description: Likely protohistoric settlement before it was first mentioned as Hoscno in 1234. Mentioned as place of issue of a margravial document in 1281. Began as a germanic or slavic settlment, a castle mound is mentioned in 1364, possibly built by germans.
Town_Description: Founded in 1284 by the Ascanians right after the Peace with Pomerania. Mentioned as civitas and burgenses in 1291, called nyeve stad in 1310. The Angermünde town law was confirmed in 1441.

Name: Arnum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 989.

Name: Arpke
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1166.

Name: Aruvalla
Settlement_Description: Village and Manor that were first mentioned in 1417.

Name: Artlenburg
Alternative_Name: Artlenborch; Erteneburg; Ertheneburg; Artenborch; Ardtlingborch; Artlenborch; Ertheneborch
Settlement_Description: The name goes back to the Ertheneburg, an early 9th-century castle erected on a crossing of the Elbe river, first mentioned in 1106. It was demolished in 1181 after the retreat of Henry the Lion of Saxony. The castle was succeeded by the settlement Artlenburg on the southern shore, although there has been much discussion about whether this was also the original location of the castle or whether it was located on the opposite shore of the river. Artlenburg is later mentioned as borough ('oppidum'); a ducal manor house was mentioned in 1414, which also served as inn for the ferry.
Toll_Description: A toll in Artlenburg is first mentioned in 1188, when Emperor Frederick I exempted Lübeck from tolls in the duchy of Saxony, except for Artlenburg, where each wagon had to pay 5 penny for crossing the river. This situation was confirmed in 1226. Although an agreement between the dukes of Lauenburg and the town of Lüneburg from 1335 states that the salt toll from Lauenburg was to be moved to Artlenburg because of a change in salt transport routes from Lüneburg, it seems that this change never took place, or only for a short time, and the toll in Artlenburg remained limited to a ferry toll.
Ferry_Description: The ferry is first mentioned in Arnold of Lübeck's Chronica Slavorum, who narrates that duke Bernhard of Saxony wanted to move the ferry to Lauenburg after the destruction of the Erthenburg, but after the wishes of Lübeck, the emperor decided that it should stay at the original location.

Name: Aruküla
Settlement_Description: Dorf that was mentioned in 1582.

Name: Asbach
Settlement_Description: First mentioned 1073.

Name: Aschendorf
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 849.
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Münster in Aschendorf is mentioned in 1576, when it was pawned. Annual revenues are known from the years 1591-1605. In 1645, a toll collector could not be found because of decreased revenues due to the Thirty Years' War.

Name: Aschenhütte
Settlement_Description: Glassworks, which came into existence at the middle of the 16th century.

Name: Aizkraukle
Settlement_Description: A castle of the Teutonic Order was built in 1213. A manor and a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk'), which was first mentioned in 1526, were built nearby.

Name: Aschersleben
Settlement_Description: In the 9th century mentioned as the property of Fulda monastery, given to the property of Ilsenburg monastery in the 1086 and since the 11th century property of the counts of Ballenstedt.
Town_Description: In 1266 the place received Halberstädt town rights that were given by Henry II. from Anhalt. The town was member of 'the Hanse' between 1426 and 1518.
Fair_Description: The exact dates of the fairs in Aschersleben are unknown.

Name: Aspach
Settlement_Description: First mention in 822.

Name: Asse
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1106-1110.

Name: Assebroek
Alternative_Name: Arsabroch; Arsbrouc; Arsbroc; Ersebrouch; Asebrouc; Assebroucq; Asse(n)broek; Assebrouck
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1187.

Name: Assen
Alternative_Name: Ascen; Azcen; Adzen; Asdzen; Aszen; Asscen; Hassen
Settlement_Description: The monastery Mariënkamp was moved from Coevorden to Assen around 1259. The monastery was abolished around 1600, after which Assen became a regional centre of government. Granted the rank of city by Royal Decree, 13 March 1809.

Name: Assinghausen
Alternative_Name: Assinchusen; Ascenkosen; Astinghausen; Assinghausen; Assinkhusen; Assenkhußen; Ascenkosen; Assingkhuißen; Aßinghaußen; Astinghausen; Astinckhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 14th/15th century.

Name: Asten
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1202-1212.

Name: Astenbeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1167.

Name: Astfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1153. Around 1448, Astfeld was abandoned. Resettlement of the area probably took place south of the medieval settlement.

Name: Athenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1219 as villa Atenstede.

Name: Lēči
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in either 1466 or 1507.

Name: Attendorn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1072, from the 9th century there was already a parish church. It lies at the crossroads of two old long-distance trade routes.
Town_Description: In 1222 Attendorn received town privileges of Soest.

Name: Atzendorf
Settlement_Description: Mention in a gift certificate by Otto I. to the monastary of St. Mauritius in Magdeburg (MGH DD O I, nr. 74, S. 153f.).

Name: Audru
Settlement_Description: Manor in episcopal possession.

Name: Audigast
Settlement_Description: Metioned as manor in 1330

Name: Auerstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in written sources in 1074 (MGH DH IV 268), the settlement probably already existed in the 9th century. In the 13th century, the village was property of a family which held the same name as the village and in the 14th century it became property of Pforta monastery.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Eckartsberga, the safe conduct ended at the end of the village.

Name: Aulhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1159.

Name: Auma
Settlement_Description: Auma had a castle and was a market place.
Town_Description: At the end of the 13th century the place got town privileges. In 1378 the term civitas was used.

Name: Aurich
Alternative_Name: Aurec; Awerichawe; Awreke; Awerkera; Aurike; Affrices; Afferen
Settlement_Description: Around 1150, the parish church of St Lambert was built, around which a market settlement developed. The settlement was first mentioned around 1250 in Frisian judicial sources.
Town_Description: Sometimes mentioned as town from 1491 onwards. The first town rights were granted in 1539 by Count Enno II of East Frisia.
Toll_Description: Toll on cattle, from which merchants from Groningen were temporarily exempted in 1427. The toll fee was raised from 1 to 5 Krumstert for each piece of cattle for foreign traders in 1548. In 1602, the count of Oldenburg complained about an increase in the toll fees at the Imperial Chamber Court. A document from 1641 attests that this toll was no longer levied for persons from Oldenburg at the time.
Fair_Description: The cattle and horse fairs in Aurich were important for merchants from the Netherlands and Westfalia in the 15th and 16th century. No less than 7 fairs are mentioned in the 16th century, although only the most important one is kwown with a date, the so-called "silent" market on Laetare.

Name: Baak
Alternative_Name: Baco; Baech; Bake; Baack; Baick; Baeck
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1190.

Name: Baarle
Alternative_Name: Baarle-Nassau; Baarle-Hertog; Barle; Barla; Baerle; Baerle onder Nassouwe; Baele Nassau; Baerle; Baarle
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of Baarle in 1237. After parts of the village were given to the lord of Breda by the duke of Brabant, the village was divided into two administrative units: Baarle "onder den Hertog" for the Brabant parts, and Baarle "onder Nassau" for the Breda parts. This division became a national border in the Treaty of Westfalia (1648) and exists until today.

Name: Baarlo
Alternative_Name: Barlo; Barle; Baerle; Baerlo; Baelre; Boirl; Baerloo; Baarloo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1219.

Name: Baarn
Settlement_Description: Baarn developed as a settlement in the eleventh century. Its first mentions in historical sources dates from 1308.
Town_Description: Baarn exists as a settlement since the 11th century. Town privileges granted between 21 October 1346 and 14 February 1390, by John ('Jan') of Arkel.

Name: Baasrode
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 821, in copy dating from circa 1300.

Name: Baben
Settlement_Description: First secure mention in 1281; possibly in 1215 within a name, even though it cannot be proven that the person actually came from Baben.

Name: Babenhausen
Settlement_Description: Founded in the 8th / 9th century at the latest.
Town_Description: In 1295 the settlement was granted Frankfurter town privileges.

Name: Babimost
Settlement_Description: One of the oldest settlements and parishes in the area, grew close to a castle that already existed in 1000, the village passed into the possession of the monastery Obra
Town_Description: Mentioned as oppidum in 1329, Wladislaw II. granted the Magdeburg town law before 1397, Sigismund I. granted more privileges in 1539, was established as a royal custom office in 1524

Name: Bacharach
Toll_Description: (1) From 1225/26 the Count Palatine levied a river toll on the Rhine. Only short interruptions of customs operations are to be assumed, f.e. 1269 to 1272 and 1317 to 1320. In 1360/80, the river toll was united with the "Ruderzoll" that was levied by the Archbishop of Cologne. The annual yield amounted to 7000 pound Heller in 1316/17. For exact tariffs see the source listed below. (2) Together with the river toll, an escort fee was levied by the Count Palatine.

Name: Buchwitz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1344.

Name: Baccum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000

Name: Badbergen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1175. In 1249, the settlement is called 'villa'.

Name: Baddeckenstedt
Settlement_Description: The main farm of the castle Wohldenberg was located in Baddeckenstedt.

Name: Baden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1012.

Name: Badenhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 968.

Name: Badingen
Settlement_Description: Became property of the bishopric of Brandenburg in 1270, but the settlement and a castle already existed in early German times. Referred to as little town (oppidulum; 'Städtchen') in 1459.

Name: Badra
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1157 (MGH DF I 187). Mentioned in a donation charter to Walkenried monastery in 1197.

Name: Baexem
Alternative_Name: Baxen; Baxem; Baex; Baxhen; Baxhem; Baexhem; Bazen; Baaksem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1244.

Name: Bahrenfeld
Alternative_Name: Bahrenueldesmor; Barenuelde; Barenveld; Barenvelde; Barenvelt; Barenfelde; Barenfelt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1256.

Name: Balen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1173.

Name: Bāliņi
Settlement_Description: A village called 'Balem' was first mentioned in 1560 and belonged to the Idwen ('Idus') Manor. Today, the single hamlet belongs to the village 'Vērsis'.

Name: Balloo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1298-1304.

Name: Ballstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 822.

Name: Balve
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 864.
Town_Description: The Cologne archbishop Dietrich II. von Mörs granted town privileges in 1430 based on the Arnsberg rights.

Name: Banteln
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 997.

Name: Bantorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1226.

Name: Barbis
Alternative_Name: Berves; Barwertß; Barwerße; Berbiß; Barbisse; Barfüß
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1384.

Name: Barchel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1340. There were 7 farms and one cottage in Barchel around 1500.

Name: Barchfeld
Settlement_Description: First mention in 933.

Name: Bardowick
Alternative_Name: Bardowiek; Barduwic; Bardenwih; Partunwich; Bardaenowic; Bardorum vicus; Bardunwih; Bardanwich; Bardonwich
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 785. Otto I granted the place market, mint and toll privileges in the 10th century. After the destruction of the town in 1189 at the latest, Bardowick lost its importance as trade centre to Lüneburg.

Name: Barenburg
Settlement_Description: A moated castle to guard a street crossing was presumably built in 1247 by the count of Hoya. A borough ('flecken') probably came into existence in the 15th century, and is first mentioned in 1530.

Name: Barendorf
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1158.

Name: Bargdorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252.

Name: Bargfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned ca. 1140.

Name: Bargloy
Settlement_Description: Mentioned around 1000 in a tax register of the monastery of Corvey.

Name: Bargteheide
Alternative_Name: Brektehegel; Brekteheyl; Berchteheyle; Berchteheyll; Barchteheyll; Berchteheide; Bargteheid
Settlement_Description: Parish village with regional market function, first mentioned in 1314.

Name: Barleben
Settlement_Description: Parish village, formerly close to the Elbe.

Name: Barlohe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1585.

Name: Barmbek
Alternative_Name: Bernebeke; Bernebek; Barnebeke; Barmbeck; Barmebegke; Barnbeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1271.

Name: Barneveld
Alternative_Name: Barnevelde; Bernevelde; Berneuelt; Barnevelt; Barnefelt; Barrevelt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1174 in a possibly falsified seventeenth-century copy. Barneveld is at least mentioned from 1307 onward.

Name: Barnstorf
Settlement_Description: The name of the settlement is first mentioned in an 890 tax register of the abbey of Werden, but the settlement is clearly older. Moreover, it had borough ('flecken') privileges, but it is unknown when these were granted.

Name: Barßel
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1330.

Name: Bartelsdorf
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1230.

Name: Barciany
Settlement_Description: In Old Prussian times a castle of the Barten county, later in 1357 a castle of the Teutonic Order, moved in 1325 and destroyed in 1455, close to the new castle a settlement grew, mentioned as Städtlein in 1473
Town_Description: Granted town right in 1628 by the elector Georg Wilhelm, population became citizens/burghers, Kulm town law, mentioned as a city in 1630

Name: Bartoszyce
Settlement_Description: Castle of the Teutonic Order built in 1241
Town_Description: First mentioned as a city in 1326, officially founded by Grand Master Luther of Braunschweig in 1332, Kulm town law

Name: Barth
Alternative_Name: Barta; Bart; Bardt; Barte; Bartte; Bahrtt; Boort; oppidum Bard
Settlement_Description: Grew out of the Old Fortress, first mentioned in 1159, in 1225 a mention of Petrus burchravius de Bart
Town_Description: Prince Jaromar II. of Rügen grants the Lübeck Town Law

Name: Bartolfelde
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1222.

Name: Bartshausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1400.

Name: Barum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252.

Name: Barum
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1140.

Name: Baruth
Settlement_Description: A castle existed in slavic times
Town_Description: Granted town law by the elector (Kurfürst) Johann Georg I. in 1616

Name: Barwice
Alternative_Name: Bärwalde; Barwitz; Berenwolde; Berenwalde; Berentwolde; Berwolde; Bernwolde; Berenwold; Bernwolde
Settlement_Description: Grew out of the civitas Barwitz around 1286 along the old saltroad to Kolberg. A church was built around 1300.
Town_Description: The town was mentioned as a see of Reimer Podewil and Hans Hechthausen in 1389. It was explicitely called a town with Lübeck town law in 1409. It belonged mainly to the house of Münchow in 1479 and jointly to the Houses Münchow, Glasenapp, Wolde and Zastrow in 1523.

Name: Mieszkowice
Alternative_Name: Bärwalde; Berenwalde; Berenwolde; Beerwolde; Bernwoldt; Berenwaldt; Bernwalde; Bernwolde
Town_Description: Founded by the Ascanian Albrecht III. without a former settlement, mentioned first in 1298 as civitas, Strausberg town law

Name: Basdahl
Settlement_Description: First named on October 11, 1297 as the place of the peace treaty between Archbishop Giselbert of Bremen and Duke Otto of Brunswick.

Name: Bassen
Settlement_Description: The stream Bicina, which allegedly gave Bassen its name, is possibly first mentioned in a description of the borders of the diocese of Bremen from 787. The settlement itself is first mentioned in 1259.

Name: Bassum
Alternative_Name: Birxinon; Birsina; Bircsinun; Birchisinun; Byrsen; Bersen; Bartzen; Barssen; Bashum; Bersene
Settlement_Description: A house of canonesses was founded between 846 and 850; mentioned as Benedictine nun monastery from 1207 onwards. The monastery was rewarded royal privileges shortly after its foundation and was the only landowner in Bassum. In 1542, the monastery became a Lutheran ladies' foundation ('damenstift'). The settlement belonging to the monastery acquired limited borough ('weichbild' or 'flecken') privileges in the 16th century.
Toll_Description: A toll in Bassum is first mentioned in 1380, which was leased to the lords of Diepholz in 1407. There is a likely connection with the acquisition of the county Altbruchhausen by the counts of Hoya in 1388, and the rebuilding of the castle Freudenberg in Bassum in 1379, at which occasion also minting took place, which is attested until the 17th century. It is unknown whether the toll was also levied during the same time frame.

Name: Bauerbach
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1238. Called 'villa' in 1297.

Name: Baumgarten (Altmark)
Settlement_Description: First mention of a noble family of Bomgarden in 1157.

Name: Bauska
Alternative_Name: Bauske; Bauskenburg; Bauschkenburg; Pawszke; Bawsenborg; Boske; Bowsenborch
Settlement_Description: In the 14th century a castle of the Teutonic Order was built, near which a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built.
Town_Description: Town rights were gained in 1609.

Name: Bautzen
Settlement_Description: A castle and the eldest church were probably founded in the 10th century. Before that, the area was inhabited by Slavs. In the northwest of the castle a 'suburbium' settled, which secured the ford crossing the river Spree.
Town_Description: In 1213 the town hall was erected. First mention of the town privileges in 1240. The town was situated along the Via Regia which favoured the economical developement.

Name: Bawinkel
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in the early 10th century. Consisting of four farms at that time, later two more were added.

Name: Bebra
Alternative_Name: Biberaho; Biberacha; Bibera; Biberaha; Biwera; Bybera; Bibra; Bybra; Beber
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the beginning of the 9th century in the Breviarium Sancti Lulli.

Name: Beckum (Werse)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1134.
Town_Description: Borough ('weichbild') privileges granted in 1220; characterised as "civitas" in 1224. Town privileges were possibly granted around 1231.

Name: Beek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in half of eleventh century, in a copy of the eigtheenth century.

Name: Beekbergen
Alternative_Name: Bekberge; Becberg; Bicberghen; Begberghen; Begbergen; Beeckberghe; Beeckbergen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1243.
Toll_Description: A land toll owned by the landlord, the duke of Guelders, was levied near Beekbergen.

Name: Beelitz
Settlement_Description: Burgward granted to the archbishopric Magdeburg by Otto III. in 997, however it is still unclear whether the mentioned Belizi refers to Beelitz or Belzig. A Wendish castle turned Ascanian after 1150, for some time see of a bailiff, the castle itself was mentioned in 1317, Gerhard von Belitz mentioned in 1204. Around 1210 the Slavic castle village was abandoned, in 1216 a burgward is mentioned and the newly founded townlike village is referred to as oppidum in 1247. It gained some meaning as a place of pilgrimage in the context of the legend of the Holy Blood.
Town_Description: First mention as civitas in 1307. Since 1321 Beelitz is alsways mentioned with the towns of the Mark, even though an explicit elevation to town cannot be proven. In 1341 town rights are confirmed for the first time. After 1350 the Ascanian castle was probably demolished when the town fortifications were constructed.
Toll_Description: Sovereign toll exists.
Fair_Description: In 1654 two free markets exist, which leads to believe they may have been granted earlier.

Name: Beerse
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1185.

Name: Beese
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1284; the stream of Beese is also mentioned early (1287). In 1420 and into the 16th century mention as little town ('Stedeken').

Name: Beeskow
Alternative_Name: Beskowe; Bezikow; Besikow; Besekowe; Betzkow; Bezkow; Beetzkow
Settlement_Description: old castle and a wendish fishing settlement opposite a few german villages and a german settlement surrounding a church
Town_Description: A knight mentioned in 1202, founders were also lords of the castle and lands, extended into a town around 1260 by a colonial scheme, Magdeburg town law granted in 1285, generally mentioned as a civitas
Staple_Description: In 1321 Beeskow was granted staple rights for rafted lumber on the Spree.

Name: Beetzendorf
Settlement_Description: The records which mention Beetzendorf in 1204 are lost today; the first remaining mention therefore occurs in 1304. In 1375 it is mentioned as a castle borough ('Burgflecken').

Name: Behlendorf
Settlement_Description: Village and the associated manor Klein Behlendorf, both first mentioned in 1194.

Name: Behrendorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1209.

Name: Behrensen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 993.

Name: Beilen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1139, in a sixteenth century copy.

Name: Beinum
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1209.

Name: Beisem
Alternative_Name: Bergecen; Berghecen; Berhsen; Berchsen; Bergschem; Berchseem; Veltem-Beisem; Beyssem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1117.

Name: Belecke
Alternative_Name: Badelecca; Badulikki; Patelecke; Batelecca; Bathalicha; Bedelike
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 938.
Town_Description: Town privileges under Soester rights were granted in 1296 by the Cologne archbishop Siegfried II.

Name: Białogard
Alternative_Name: Belgard; Belgrod; Belegarde; civitatem Albam; Belgard an der Persante; Belgarda; Belgart; Belgardem; Belgarden; Belgarth; Belgroensis Urbs; Belgrada; civitas alba; Balagardhs
Settlement_Description: A slavic castle mound from the 6th ct. was the basis of a town-like settlement in the 11th ct. and was was conquered by the polish duke Boleslaw III in 1102. The eldest surrounding settlement dates to the 10-13th ct. A ducal castle was built in 1315 on the castle mound and later became the see of a castellan.
Town_Description: The term ‘civitatem Albam’ appears in 1107. The pomeranian duke Bogislaw IV granted the german settlement the Lübeck town law in 1299.

Name: Belgern
Settlement_Description: There was probably a settlement before 900 which was situated around the church. Later, a castle to control the border was erected. The settlement developed into a market place.
Town_Description: Referral as 'oppidum' around 1300. However, the year of the founding is uncertain. In 1572 town statutes were confirmed.
Toll_Description:
In 983 emperor Otto I. gives the toll on the Elbe river in Belgern to the chapter of Meißen .
In the late Middle Ages secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wettin in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig.

Name: Bellingwolde
Alternative_Name: Billinge; Billinghewolde; Bellingewolde; Byllynckwolt; Bellinckwolt; Bellingwolde; Bellingewolde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1438, in a copy.

Name: Bellnhausen
Alternative_Name: Bedelnhusen; Badelogehusin; Badelingehusen; Bedelingehusen; Belnhusen; Bellenhusen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1254.

Name: Belm
Alternative_Name: Belhem; Bilehem; Bellm; Beleem; Bellehamen; Belheym; Beelhelme; Belhemb
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1150.

Name: Bad Belzig
Settlement_Description: It is still unknown whether the castle district center Belizi, mentioned in 997, refers to Beelitz or Belzig. In the 12th century, an Ascanian castle emerges there. The settlement of Belzig consists of two villages which are only merged in the 19th century: A rural suburbium "Sandberg", which alsready existed in early German times and a market settlement beyond the stream, which is already referred to as oppidum im 1269.
Town_Description: In 1506 a council is mentioned, when the town was first granted townrights is unknown. It was only granted full town rights in 1702.
Toll_Description: Northernmost Ernestinian main station of safe conduct.

Name: Bemelen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1096, in a fifteenth century copy. Next mention in circa 1170-1180 [1124].

Name: Bemmel
Alternative_Name: Benmele; Bemela; Benemele; Bemele; Benele; Bennemele; Bennemale; Bemle; Benemel; Benmeel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention end of the twelfth century. Mention in 1178 might be falsified. Another mention in 1189 in a copy of ca 1485.

Name: Bendeleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 817.

Name: Benkendorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1280.

Name: Benneckenstein
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a letter of enfeoffment in 1319. In 1344 count Henry IV. of Honstein erected castle Benneckenstein around which a village developed. Frederick the Great granted town rights in 1741.
Bridge_Description: Mention of a Benickenbrugge (Benicken bridge) across the Rappbode in 1250-1260.

Name: Benneveld
Alternative_Name: Bonavelda; Bonevelde; Bonnevelde; Bonvelde; Boenevelde; Bonneuelde; Bunneveld
