Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Bonavelde' in 1267-1288.

Name: Bennungen
Settlement_Description: First mention in an exchange certificate by Henry V. in 1112.

Name: Benstorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 826.

Name: Bentfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 1280s.

Name: Bad Bentheim
Settlement_Description: Settlement near a castle, first mentioned around 1050. In the 16th and 17th century, the village had town-like characteristics, but town privileges were only granted in 1865.

Name: Berbroek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1366.

Name: Berchem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1186, in a fourteenth century copy.

Name: Berga
Settlement_Description: Queen Adelheid gives the village of Berga to Quedlinburg monastery in 953 among others.

Name: Berge (Gardelegen)
Settlement_Description: In 1327 the homestead of Berghe is given to count Otto of Braunschweig. Mention as village in the 15th century.

Name: Bergedorf
Alternative_Name: Bergerdorp, Bergerdorpe; Bergherdorpe; Bergherstorp; Bergthorpe; Bergherstorp; Bergertorpe; Bergerdorp; Bergerthorp; Berierdorp; Bergerdhorp; Bercherdorpe; Bergherdorpe; Bargerdorpe; Bergerdorpe; Bergerdorff; Bargerdorf; Bergerdorff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1162 as a church town with the parish church of St Peter und Paul, but it already existed before as a parish of Hamburg. Bergedorf castle was first mentioned in 1212. It was acquired by Hamburg in 1420.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted in 1275 by Duke John I of Saxony-Lauenburg after the Mölln-Lübeck model.
Toll_Description: A toll of the duke of Saxony-Lauenburg on timber floated down the Bille and transported on wagons through Bergedorf was agreed upon in a 1410 agreement between the duke and Hamburg. It is likely that this was a general toll on wagons, which came to Hamburg when it acquired Bergedorf castle in 1420.
Harbour_Description: After the Schleusenkanal was dug in 1443/45, Bergedorf acquired a navigable waterway via the Dove Elbe with Hamburg. The waterway mainly served the transport of wood from the surrounding forests.

Name: Bergen an der Dumme
Alternative_Name: Bergen/Dumme; Monte; Bergen; Bargen up der Dumme; Berghe; Berghen; Barghen; Berge; Bergen Tyorska
Settlement_Description: Castle of the lords of Bergen, which came to the lords of Lüneburg around 1203. The corresponding settlement was characterised as borough ('blek', 'stadtlein').
Toll_Description: In 1435, the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg set the rate to be paid for safe conduct in Lüchow and Bodenteich for citizens of Salzwedel at the same height as that in Bergen. Between 1548 and 1574, the toll collector Herman Schradt is mentioned in Bergen. Toll tariffs are known from the 16th century (StAB).

Name: Bergen (Lüneburger Heide)
Alternative_Name: Bergen; Berge; Berghe; Bhergerwolt; Bercho; Bergen by dem Bergerwolde; Bergerwald; Bergerwolt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1197.

Name: Bergen (Maas)
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1230.

Name: Bergen op Zoom
Alternative_Name: Bergon; Berga; Bergen supra Zoom; Bergen super Zoem; Berghen super Zoem; Bergen vp den Zoem; Berghen anden Some; Berghen opten Zoem; Bergen op ten Zoom; Bergh... svper Zome
Settlement_Description: Bergen op Zoom is first mentioned in 966.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted between ca. 1198 and 25 February 1212 by Godfried II, lord of Breda and Schoten.
Staple_Description: Between 1388 and 1392, the Hanseatic wool staple was moved to Bergen op Zoom

Name: Bergfeine
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 872.

Name: Berggießhübel
Settlement_Description: Originally a small estate and knights estate. In the 15th century the place benefited from flourishing mining.
Town_Description: In 1554 town privileges were appointed.

Name: Bergheim
Toll_Description: (1) The Duke of Jülich levied a land toll from 1375, after public peace in the same year. In 1389, a horse fee and a fee for safe conduct was included into the land toll. The annual yield in 1389/93 amounted to 1864 Mark per year. In 1398/99 it was 1553 Mark, in 1434 it was 833 Mark and in 1500/01 it was 1565 Mark per year. Around 1500 the fee for safe conduct was collected by an escort servant. (2) Furthermore, a road toll was levied by the Duke of Jülich from 1434. The exact tariffs are not known. The yield taken over half a year amounted to 8 Mark and 9 Shilling in 1434/35. In 1500/01 it was 34 Mark and 6 Shilling per year.

Name: Bergholz
Settlement_Description: Former Slavic settlement, in 1228 an early German castle is constructed. The German settlement must have emerged around the same time, the village church can be proven since 1257. A manor lay nearby, its first lord can be proven in 1249.

Name: Bergstedt
Alternative_Name: Berchstede; Bericstede; Berichstede; Berghstede; Bergstede; Bargstede; Bargstett; Bergstett; Barchstede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1248.

Name: Bergzow
Alternative_Name: Berkczow; Berkso; Berso; Barchtzow; Beerkove; Berchzow
Settlement_Description: Mention around 1400 as Berkczow.

Name: Berka (Werra)
Settlement_Description: During the 9th century, the monasteries Fulda and Hersfeld had ownership in this village. In the beginning of the 16th century Berka was probably called "Marktflecken". Town rights were given in 1847.
Toll_Description: Station of safe conduct

Name: Berkhof
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1393.

Name: Berlin
Alternative_Name: Berlin-Kölln; Berlin-Cölln, Cölln, Kölln; Perlyn; Berlyn; Berlinum; Berlinensis; Berolinum
Settlement_Description: A Slavic settlement can be proven from the 6th to 8th century, but it isn't necessarily the immediate predecessor of the German settlement. In the 13th century, increased trade seems to have increased the meaning of the settlements of Berlin and Cölln at the Spree crossing. Further signs of settlement can then only be proven in the 12th and 13th century in the market area of St. Nikolai's church.
Town_Description: The first indication of Berlin is given in the mention of its provost in 1237, who was already mentioned as provost of Cölln in 1237. Since its first mention, Berlin can be seen as a town, it is referred to as civitas in 1251. The exact date of the awarding of town rights has not survived, as well as earlier mentions, which may have been destroyed during a town fire in 1380. In 1244, the provost of Berlin is first mentioned, who is also referred to as provost of Cölln in 1247, which may be seen as proof that both towns can be seen as twin towns at the time. Participation at the Hanseatic Diets 1359, 1430 and lastly 1443, in 1518 they were forced by their territorial lord to quit the alliance.
Toll_Description: Staple rights are confirmed in 1298, they therefore already existed earlier. The "Nedderlage" (entrepot), as they were referred to in the town rights, were tolls for merchants who traveled through the town; they were transferred to the prince electorate in 1448.
Staple_Description: A record, in which Berlin was granted staple rights in 1297, turned out to be a forgery. Especially the mention of the staple therein is insecure. The first secure confirmation of the staple right in Berlin is granted in 1337, even though a fee was probably already collected in the 13th century.
Fair_Description: The date of the awarding of the fairs in Berlin is not mentioned.

Name: Barlinek
Alternative_Name: Berlinchen; Nova Berlyn; Berlin; Neu-Berlin; Berliniken; Klein Berliniken
Town_Description: In 1278 the Margraves Albrecht III. and Otto V. commission the knight Heinrich Toyte to found a town with Magdeburg town law, it was intended as an Ascanian fortress against Pomerania,

Name: Berlstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 822.

Name: Bernau bei Berlin
Settlement_Description: Foundation of the city in the early 13th century.
Town_Description: Foundation of the city in the early 13th century. In 1296 referred to as civitas.

Name: Bernburg
Settlement_Description: Mention of a castle Brandanburg in a gift certificate by Otto I. to St. Mauritius monastary in Magdeburg in 961 (MGH DD OI, 231, S. 316f.). Archaeological evidence shows an early medieval ditch system on the castle hill of Bernburg.
Town_Description: First record of the town rights in 1278.
Toll_Description: In 1537 the toll from Neundorf (Anhalt) is moved to the district of Bernburg. A regulation of safe conduct of 1563 settles the bridge and road toll.

Name: Berndorf
Alternative_Name: Beranthorpe; Biredorphe; Berentorp; Berndorpe; Berenthorp; Berindorp; Berendorff; Berndorf; Berndorppe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Pełczyce
Settlement_Description: The castle mound close to a german settlement and a slavic village was destroyed in 1290
Town_Description: Mentioned as a civitas in 1290 and 1315, founding year did not survive, the town later became independent from the castle built after 1315

Name: Bersenbrück
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1221; in 1231 the settlement was called 'villa'. In the same year, a Cistercian nunnery was founded. The monastery was a large landowner until it was closed in 1787.

Name: Bērze
Settlement_Description: The Manor was first mentioned in 1599.

Name: Bērzaune
Alternative_Name: Bersohn; Bersen; Bersone; Berszen; Barson; Barsoon
Settlement_Description: The settlement was owned by the Tiesenhausen-Family in 1229. The first written reference can be dated back to the 14th century. A castle was built in 1382.

Name: Berßel
Settlement_Description: First mention as a villa in a gift certificate to Ilsenburg monastery in 1018.

Name: Berstadt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 802 and 817.

Name: Bertkow
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1225.

Name: Berwicke
Alternative_Name: Berewich; Berwich; Berewic; Berewyc; Berwik; Berwyk; Berwigk; Berwerck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1193-1205.

Name: Besenthal
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1230.

Name: Besse
Alternative_Name: Passahe; Bessehe; Bessen; Bessahe; Bessee; superiori Besse; Overen Besse; Ober Besse; Obernbesse; Beisse; Beß; Besße; Bessa; Beeß; Oberbesse
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 802 and 817.

Name: Bethen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1362. It is first mentioned as pilgrimage centre in 1448, because of a miraculous pietà image, although the first pilgrimages probably already took place at the time of creation of the image between 1380 and 1400.

Name: Pszczew
Alternative_Name: Betsche; etschen; Petschen; Pszczewo; Pczewo; Przewo; Petschew; Psechem
Settlement_Description: Used to be a Pomeranian castle with a moat, mentioned in 1259 as a german settlement belonging to the bishop of Poland, still mentioned as a village in 1350
Town_Description: Already a town in 1412, a bailiff mentioned in 1435, the only document remaining is the renewal of the founding privileges from 1508, signed by the bishop of Poland, Johannes Lubranski, after a fire

Name: Bettenhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1126.

Name: Bettmar (Hildesheim)
Alternative_Name: Bettmar; Bethmere; Bethmare; Bedmere; Betmer; Bethmar
Settlement_Description: A watchtower of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Hildesheim was built in Bettmar in the 15th century.

Name: Bettmar (Vechelde)
Alternative_Name: Bettmar; Betmer; Bethmare; Bethmere; Betmare; Betmere; Bethmer; Bethmar; Betthmar; Bettmer; Bedmer over den Langen wisch; Betmere vor der Langen Wisch; Betmer by der Langgewissche; Bethmar vor der Langen Wischen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1146.

Name: Betzendorf
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention from ca. 1300. According to a 1450 register, the village consisted of 9 half farms ('plog') and 5 cottages.

Name: Betziesdorf
Alternative_Name: Bezchindorph; Becingendorf; Bezcekendorph; Bezzichindorf; Betzgensdorf; Bettzendorff; Betzgesdorff; Betziesdorf; Betzdorf; Betzigsdorf; Betzienndorff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1254. Called 'villa' in 1259.

Name: Beugen
Alternative_Name: Boghene; Boghen; Bughene; Boegen; Beughem; Bueghen; Bueghem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1294.

Name: Beuren
Settlement_Description: The village of Beuren is first mentioned in 1128. Foundation of a monastery before 1200. In 1550 the monastery is abandoned, after it had suffered heavy damages during the Peasant's war.
Toll_Description: Toll and safe conduct are moved to Heiligenstadt in 1294.

Name: Beveren
Alternative_Name: Beuerne; Beuerna; Beuerne in Wassia; Beuere
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1112, in a copy dating from circa 1175.

Name: Bevergern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1366 and located near a castle built around 1350.
Town_Description: In 1366 town privileges granted by the dukes of Tecklenburg. Around 1400 it was called a town and the privileges got approved in 1471.

Name: Bevern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 822-826. The Renaissance country house ('schloss') of Bevern was constructed in 1603-1612.

Name: Beverst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1319.

Name: Bias
Toll_Description: Mentioned as a toll station and station of safe conduct in 1419, 1454 and 1479.

Name: Bicken
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1218.

Name: Bieber
Alternative_Name: Biberhahen; Biberaha; Biberah; Byberahe; Bybera; Bebera; Biberach; Bibera; Bebrau; Biebra; Bibra; Biberaw; Bieberauw; Biber
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 791. 868 called 'villa'.

Name: Biedenkopf
Alternative_Name: Biedenkaph; Bydenkapf; Biedencap; Biedenkap; Beidencap; Bydenkapf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1196.
Town_Description: First mentioned as a town in 1254. The exact year of the town charter is not known.

Name: Biederitz
Settlement_Description: The tithe of Bidrici is mentioned as given to St. Moritz' monastery in Magdeburg when the bishopric of Brandenburg was founded.

Name: Bielefeld
Alternative_Name: Bylanuelde; Beilfeldt; Biliuelde; Bileuelde; Bilivelde; Bylivelt; Bilenvelth; Beilfeldt; Bilevelde; Bilewelde; Bieleveld; Bilevelt; Bilenbelde; Billevelde; Bildevelde; Billevelde; Bielvelda; Bilveldia; Bilfelt; Beilfelt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 856 and 866 in the possession of the monastery Corvey.
Town_Description: Münster town privileges were probably granted in 1214 and confirmed in 1287 and 1326.
Toll_Description: In 1224 the counts of Ravensberg acquired the right to levy a toll in Bielefeld.
Fair_Description: Three fairs are attested in Bielefeld: on the day before and after St John's Day (1338), on the day before and after St Leonard (1485) and on the day before and after St Michael (16th century).

Name: Bielen
Settlement_Description: First mention in MGH DF 1211

Name: Biene
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000

Name: Bienenbüttel
Alternative_Name: Binebutle; Binebotle; Bynenbuttele; Bynenbuttel; Binnenbuttel; Bynnenbotel
Settlement_Description: The first certain mention of the settlement is dated to 1238. An earlier mention as Biangibudiburg from 1004 could belong to Buntenburg near Lüneburg.

Name: Bierbergen
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1151.

Name: Biesdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention of Biesdorf in 1375. It was a knightly residence until 1665.

Name: Bulduri
Settlement_Description: The manor existed in the 17th century.

Name: Bilderlahe
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1254.

Name: Billerbeck
Alternative_Name: Billurbeki; Billerbeke; Billarbeci; Billurbeki; Bilribechi; Byllerbeke; Bilrebeke; Billerbike; Bilderbeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned by name in 834. But a church was mentioned as early as 809.
Town_Description: In 1302 town privileges got granted and named as an 'oppidum' in 1312.

Name: Bilzen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1050, in a copy from the end of eleventh century.

Name: Binder
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1153.

Name: Bingen
Alternative_Name: Bingen am Rhein; Bingium; Bingum; Pinger marca; Bingam; castello Pinge; castello Pingua
Settlement_Description: A copy of the 11th century suggests a first mention of the settlement around 107. A castle called Klopp was built in the 13th century.
Toll_Description: There were two land tolls in Bingen owned by the Archbishop of Mainz: 1) A toll for cattle was probably levied from 1190 or 1194/98. In 1368 this was leased out for 200 guilders. 2) The 'Gaupfortenzoll' was first mentioned in 1247. In 1390, 50 pounds Heller were collected. In addition, a river toll was probably levied around 1250. A transit toll on the Rhine in the 14th and 15th centuries, however, can be ruled out. It was probably only a fee for the ferry.

Name: Birkenwerder
Settlement_Description: Founded probably around 1230 from a rampart nearby, which had been settled from the Bronze Age until the early German phase.

Name: Birkesdorf
Toll_Description: From 1289, the Count of Jülich levied a land toll, which was localised in Velden until 1274. In the 'landfrieden' of 1375, a certain tariff per horse was fixed. For more detailed information see source. In 1375 and 1389/93, an fee for save conduct and a 'landfrieden'-toll were levied in addition to the existing tolls. In 1350 the revenue amounted to about 120 marks. In 1398/99 about 1897 marks.

Name: Bischhausen (Wehre)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 800.

Name: Bischoffen
Alternative_Name: Bishofen; Bischoben; Bischobin; Bischoffen; Bißobin; Byschuuin; Nydern Biscoffin
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1299.

Name: Bischofferode
Alternative_Name: Bischovirode; Bissoverode; Bisschofferode; Bischoverode; Buschoffenrode; Bischofferod; Bischofferodt; Bischofferode
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1280.

Name: Biskupiec
Settlement_Description: Built before 1389 as a fortress against the Lithuanians, no older settlement found
Town_Description: Mentioned as 'civitas Bischofsburg'; Bishop Heinrich III. Sorbom of Ermland grants the Kulm town law in 1395 to the civitas

Name: Bischofshagen
Alternative_Name: Biscopeshagen; Indagine Episcopi; Bischopeshagen; Hesinghusen; Biscopeshaghen; Biscopingehaghen; Esinchusen; Bischopeshagen; Hessinchusen; Hesinckhusen; Byschopeshagen; Poggenhagen; Bischopshagen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1206.

Name: Bischofsmühle
Settlement_Description: Water mill near Schwerin, first mentioned in 1209.

Name: Bischofswerda
Town_Description: In 1361 Bischofswerda was referred to as 'town' for the first time. In 1416 referral as 'oppidum'.

Name: Bismark
Settlement_Description: Presumably a castle or a castle mound existed, which are not mentioned in the records. Town rights were never officially granted, despite being referred to as town in 1375 and having a town hall in 1413 - in the 15th/16th century the settlement was alternatly referred to as borough ('Flecken') or little town ('Stetlein').
Fair_Description: In an official schedule from 1719, Osterburg, Arendsee and Bismark each held six fairs. It can be assumed that some of these had existed for a while to this point.

Name: Bispingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1135.

Name: Bissendorf (Wedemark)
Alternative_Name: Biscopinctorpe; Biscopigdorpe; Bispinghedorpe; Bispendorpe; Bispingkdorp; Bissendorpe
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1285.

Name: Bissendorf (Osnabrück)
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1160.

Name: Bitterfeld
Settlement_Description: A former Slavic settlement probably existed.
Town_Description: According to Niemeyer, proven as town in the 14th century. In 1382 referred to as town; only 2007 the name Bitterfeld-Wolfen emerged through incorporation.
Toll_Description: The regulation of safe conduct of Bitterfeld is uncommonly exhaustive and contains numerous exemptions, which show the importance of long-distance trade here (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Bb 606, Jahresrechnung Amt Bitterfeld 1539/40, p. 1–5v.). It was especially important for cattle trade from Poland.
Fair_Description: In 1582 the council of Bitterfeld proclaims to establish two cattle markets, which would profit from traffic to Buttstedt. Permission is granted if surrounding markets give their consent. Leipzig's reaction is unclear, as well as whether the markets took place.

Name: Bladel
Alternative_Name: Pladella; Bladele; Bladela; Blade; Pladele; Blajel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1173-end of the thirteenth century

Name: Blankenbach
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1332. The settlement previously existed a little further to the north, it fell desolate and was then rebuilt in the 16th century on the current site.

Name: Blankenburg (Harz)
Settlement_Description: In 1123 Blankenburg is first mentioned. The settlement beneath the castle is mentioned as oppidum in 1195.
Town_Description: Since 1389 a council is proven in the town, in 1380 the village is granted Goslar rights, market- and coin privileges.

Name: Blankenese
Alternative_Name: blanke Ness; Blankinese; Blankenesen; Blankenneze; Blanckenneße; Blanckenese
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1301 and was built at a pier of the Elbe ferry.
Ferry_Description: Ferry to Buxtehude and Cranz. A landing pier for the ferry is first mentioned in 1301. It was also an important river crossing for oxen in the 15th and 16th century, although many merchants preferred the ferry in Zollenspieker because of the high prices of hay in Blankenese.

Name: Blankenham
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1420.

Name: Blankenhain
Settlement_Description: A castle is mentioned in 1279, in 1252 the village is first mentioned.
Town_Description: In 1424 Blankenhain is mentioned as town. During the 15ht century is is continuously mentioned as town and market.

Name: Blasheim
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 969 and 996.

Name: Blatzheim
Toll_Description: The land toll in the possession of the Archbishop of Cologne weas levied from 1425. In 1425, 285 guilders were recorded as revenue, although the period of the revenue is unclear.

Name: Bleckede
Settlement_Description: Duke Wilhelm of Lüneburg tried to develop the village Bleckede into the town Löwenstadt in 1209. The project failed, and in 1258, the settlement is mentioned under its old name Bleckede as borough ('flecken'). A castle is first mentioned in 1271.
Toll_Description: A land and water toll of the duke of Saxony-Lauenburg is attested from 1248. It was acquired by the duke of Lüneburg in 1308. The castle was often pawned without the toll, although the toll is mentioned in 1492 as belonging to the town council of Lüneburg. In the latter year, the toll fees are indicated as 4 Gulden, 1 loaf of bread and 2 buns for each ship. Toll registers exist from the year 1503 onwards.

Name: Bleckenstedt
Alternative_Name: Blikenstide; Blekenstede; Blikemstide; Blikkenstede; Blekenstede; Blekenstidde; Bleckenstete; Bleckensted Tam; Beckenstett; Plickstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1181.
Toll_Description: Road toll of the dukes of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel at the Damm (causeway) of Bleckenstedt, first mentioned in 1540/1.

Name: Blerick
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 365, in a thirteenth century copy. Next mention in probably 802-822, in a copy dating from 1150-1158. Next mention in 1213.
Toll_Description: The Duke of Guelders possibly levied a fee for safe conduct here from 1355/61. In the tariff of the toll in Venlo, Blerick and Kessel were mentioned as secondary toll stations.

Name: Bledzew
Settlement_Description: Originally a small slavic settlement, given to the Cistercian Abbey of Semmritz in 1312 by Margrave Waldemar of Brandenburg, new abbey was built in the early 15th ct., later the see of the abbott, the enitre convent moved to Blesen in 1578
Town_Description: The polish king Kasimir IV. grants the Magdeburg town law between 1458 and 1485 at the request of the abbott, renewal of the rights in 1565 and 1619

Name: Blexhaus
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1546, but goes back to the family name 'Blexen', which is already mentioned in 1506. Around 1570, an inn is mentioned here.

Name: Bliestorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1380.

Name: Westerblokker
Alternative_Name: Westerblocweere; Westerbloecwere; Westerbloc weer; Westerblocweer; Wester Bloicker; Wester Blocker; Wester blocker
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1289. In 1414, Westerblokker, Oosterblokker and Westwoud were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements became the ‘stede’ Westwoud. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments.

Name: Blokzijl
Alternative_Name: Groote Zijl; Groote Zyl by Blockes huis; Bluckzijl; Blocksijl; Bloxiel; Blockzijll; Blokzyl; Bluxiel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1375. Next mention in (1524.) Town-like privileges granted by prince Maurits from 1589 onwards. Town privileges were granted by prince William III, 19 October 1672. Contemporaries objected these privileges, and they were revoked within several years.

Name: Blomberg
Alternative_Name: Blomberghe; Blomenberg; Blomberch; Blumberg; Plumberg; Plombergk
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1230 and 1255. The settlement goes back to a castle built around 1200.
Town_Description: Around 1260 town privileges of Lippstadt and Lemgo got granted.

Name: Blumendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1314.

Name: Blumroda
Settlement_Description: First mention as Blumenrode in 1416.

Name: Bobbau
Toll_Description: The regulation of safe conduct of Bobbau states, that safe conduct in Bobbau is taken of those who travel from Dessau to Steinfurt or from Köthen to Bitterfeld and Delitsch or vice versa. Who was already promised safe conduct in Jeßnitz or Ragun may not gain it in Bobbau. Who travels to the fairs in Leipzig from Bobbau is given a permit, upon which he may pass free of payment if he returns via Bobbau. (LHASA, DE, Z 10, Nr. 27, Land Register über den Dessauischen Anteil 1547/49.)

Name: Boberg
Alternative_Name: Bocberge; Bober; Bucberghe; Bocberghe; Bocberghen; Boekberge; Bockbarge; Boberge; Bohberg; Bobergen; Bobarg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1197.

Name: Bocholt (Münsterland)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 779 but might be much older. Called 'villa' in 1142.
Town_Description: The settlement got 'Weichbildrechte' in 1201. In 1222 the bishop of Munster granted town privileges.

Name: Bocholt (Bree)
Settlement_Description: Ealiest mention in 1162.

Name: Bochum
Alternative_Name: Cofbuokheim; Bukhem; Aldanbochem; Buchem; Bochem; Buchheym; Bochheim; Bouchem; Boicheim; Boikem; Boikhem; Boickhum; Baucum; Boichemensis; Cofbuockheim; Bogchem; Bouchum; Boickem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1041. However, the oldest part of the city dates from the 9th century.
Town_Description: A charter from 1321, in which the settlement is called 'oppidum', has often been interpreted as a town privilege. However, Bochum remained a minor town or borough ('minderstadt') and seems to have acquired the status of a full town only in 1437.

Name: Bockelskamp
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1227-1266.

Name: Bockenem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 11th century.
Town_Description: Raised to a town by the counts of Woldenberg in 1300. The town was sold to the bishop of Hildesheim in 1314.

Name: Bocklemünd
Toll_Description: The Archbishop of Cologne levied a fee for save conduct and a land toll here from 1389. In 1396, 2 to 3 white pfennigs per horse had to be paid. An average of 837 Mark per year was collected through this toll. In 1455, Bocklemünd served as a secondary toll for Königsdorf.

Name: Böddensell
Settlement_Description: First mention around 1150 or 1160, after 1311 it was deserted, only to be re-settled in around 1500.

Name: Böddenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1197.

Name: Bodenburg
Settlement_Description: Settlement at a castle of the lords of Steinberg, after 1359 in possession of the dukes of Brunswick. Bodenburg is mentioned as borough ('flecken') in 1545.
Toll_Description: Around 1439 the bishop of Hildesheim started to levy a wine toll, like in Marienburg and Lamspringe.

Name: Bodenstedt
Alternative_Name: Bonstad; Bonstede; Bonstide; Bonenstidde; Bodenstidde; Bohnstedt; Bonstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1151.

Name: Bad Bodenteich
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1130. Since 1290 a castle is mentioned; in 1323 the place became a borough ('weichbild').
Toll_Description: Toll of the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg, first mentioned in 1323. In 1435, the rate for safe-conduct for citizens of Salzwedel in Bodenteich was set at the same height as that in Bergen. Toll tariffs are known from the 16th century (StAB).

Weser toll station, first mentioned in 1387. In lists of the Weser tolls in a 1584 Bremen complaint and a 1597 charter of the monastery Hardehausen, it is not mentioned anymore. The toll could have been related to the existence of a castle ('slot') in Bodenwerder, which is mentioned between 1399 and 1442.
Ferry_Description: When a bridge was not existing, the traffic was moved across the river by ferries.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Weser is mentioned already in 1289, but it was often destroyed by floods and drift ice, among others in 1573 and 1595.
Harbour_Description: According to the data from the Rinteln toll registers, Bodenwerder was the town most active in river transport between Minden and Hameln.

Name: Boechout
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 974. Next mention in 1003.

Name: Baesweiler
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1130.

Name: Boffzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876

Name: Bohlsen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1292.

Name: Böhmerwold
Alternative_Name: Beddinghem; Bedmawertha; Bedma hamryk; Bedamewalt; Bemerwolt; Bimerwoldt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Česká Lípa
Alternative_Name: Böhmisch Leipa; de Lipa; Leipen; lyppeho; Lip´y

Name: Bohmstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1445-1450.

Name: Boitzen
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 1306 when property of the monastery Zeven in Boitzen had been damaged.

Name: Boizenburg
Alternative_Name: Boizenburg/Elbe; Boyceneburg; Boyceneborch; Boitzenborch; Beutzenburg; Boysenborch; Boichenborch; Boichenenborch; Boycenburg
Settlement_Description: In wendish time centre of the terra Boizenburg, old fortress replaced in 1170 by a new German Fortress, 1241 mentioned as civitas
Town_Description: Lübeck town law granted by the dukes Guncelin and Helmold of Schwerin
Toll_Description: A toll of the lords of Schwerin, later the dukes of Mecklenburg, in Boizenburg is first mentioned in 1216. In 1241, Hamburg was exempted from payment of the river toll on the Elbe in Boizenburg, as well as citizens from the duchy of Saxony, Lauenburg, Artlenburg and Altengamme for transporting their own grain in 1260. In the 1360s, there were complaints of Lüneburg citizens that they had to pay tolls for herring, from which they claimed to be exempted. It was declared in 1369 that they were only due for toll payments for salt, and not for herring and other commodities which they transported from Lübeck. In the 15th century, a toll of 2 shilling was levied for each wispel (unit of volume). A toll register from 1470/71 has been analysed by Nissen.

Name: Vreschen-Bokel
Alternative_Name: Bokel; Bocklo; Vreschen Bokele; Botelen; Bokell; Bockel; Boeckholt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1260 and 1275. The addition 'Vreschen' appears for the first time in 1428 to distinguish the settlement from Bokel in the community of Wiefelstede.

Name: Bölhorst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1397. However, it is possible that the name of Hinrik Balhorst, who is listed in a 1381 town register of Minden, refers to a variant of the name of the settlement.

Name: Bölsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1375.

Name: Bolsward
Alternative_Name: Bodliswert; Boedelswaerd; Bodelswardia; Boalsert; Bodelswerde; Boelswert; Bolswert; Bodleswaerd
Settlement_Description: First mentioned 1038-1057.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted before 4 April 1331.
Harbour_Description: Regular barge ('trekvaart') services were offered on the route Leeuwarden-Bolsward-Workum from 1648 onwards.

Name: Bömenzien
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1319.

Name: Bommershoven
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1268.

Name: Bonames
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1039 as a 'locus'. 1292 called a 'ville'.

Name: Bonn
Alternative_Name: Bonnam; cum castris Bonnensibus; Bunna; Bonna; cisalpinae Veronae; Bunno; acta Verona
Settlement_Description: Before the Romans could establish their military camps, the Ubii settled in the area of today's Bonn. In the 1st century Bonn served as a legionary suburb, a so-called 'civil vicus' ('Zivilvicus'). Under Frankish rule, Bonn rose to become an important marketplace and after 1288 became the residence of the Cologne electors.
Toll_Description: Three tolls were levied in Bonn by the Archbishop of Cologne: 1) The river toll on the Rhine was levied 1244-1254, before 1282, 1293-1302 and from 1306. The tariff was 12 pfennigs in 1293. In 1367 the customs were leased for 4 years for 30600 guilders a year. In 1371/74 the revenues added up to an average of about 16839 guilders a year. In 1473, the toll was moved to Remagen for a few weeks. 2) From 1302 onwards, the escort fee was probably levied together with the Rhine toll. 3) A land toll was established before 1282, but was not attested again until the beginning of the 15th century. In 1454/60, 70 marks were estimated for the cattle fee.

Name: Bönnien
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1143.

Name: Bookholt
Settlement_Description: Hamlet ('bauerschaft'), first mentioned in 1465.

Name: Boortmeerbeek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1290.

Name: Boostedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1200.

Name: Boppard
Settlement_Description: Niemeyer speaks here of a settlement originating at the end of the 3rd century.
Town_Description: In 1216, the town received its first town seal.
Toll_Description: An identification of the toll in the year 991 is not certain, which is why the first mention is in 1074. It was a river toll on the Rhine in the possession of the empire. From 1282, the toll was pledged to the Counts of Katzenelnbogen. In 1344 there was also a toll by Kurtrier. In the 14th and 15th centuries, the customs changed hands frequently. The tariff for the Rhine toll was 2½ pfennigs per ship in 1212. In 1282, there was a temporary surcharge of 6 pfennigs per foder of wine. In 1314 the tariff for the Kurtrier toll was 4 Turnosgroschen per foder of wine. In 1413 about 7340 guilders could be collected, in 1422/23 about 5193 guilders. For more detailed information, see source.

Name: Borculo
Alternative_Name: Burkelo; Burglo; Burchlo; Burclo; Borcloe; Borkelo; Borkeloo; Borkulo; Borculoensis
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1190.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted on 1 May 1375, by Gijsbert of Bronkhorst and Borculo, and his wife Henrica of Borculo-Dodinkweerde.

Name: Bordesholm
Settlement_Description: The monastery of Augustinian Canons in Neumünster was moved to an island ('holm') in the lake near the village Eiderstede before 1327/28. The monastery was secularised in 1565/66.

Name: Borg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1273.

Name: Borgeln
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1021.

Name: Borger
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1327, in a copy dating from 1471.

Name: Borghorst
Alternative_Name: Steinfurt-Borghorst; Borchorst; Burchurst; Burghurst; Burghorst; Borichorst; Burchorst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 935. Sometimes mentioned as 'Wigbold' around 1512.

Name: Borgloon
Alternative_Name: Lon; Los; Loen; Borchloen; Loon; Looz
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1078, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Borken
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 9th or 10th century. 1201 to 1203 called 'villa'.
Town_Description: Between 1222 and 1226, the place was granted town privileges of Munster.

Name: Born
Settlement_Description: The alleged first mention in the records in 1187 by Hermes and Weigelt seems to have nothing to do with the settlement Born. This settlement was founded as an outlying estate ('Vorwerk') in 1745. The inn mentioned by Bruns-Weczerka can only be assumed by the end of the 18th century.

Name: Borna
Settlement_Description: Originally Slavic settlement that was re-founded and expanded in the course of the German east expansion in the 12th century.
Town_Description: In 1264 first mentioned as 'town' although the founding of the town could be situated in the beginning of the 13th century.
Toll_Description: Important ernestinian station of safe conduct south of Leipzig.
Fair_Description:
In 1637 Borna owns at least one fair. In 1544 it had applied for another fair, which as not explicitly denied, despite protest from Leipzig. If this is the same fair is unclear.
In 1677 Borna moves a fair from Sunday after St. Margaret's day to Monday after the first Sunday after Trinitatis.

Name: Borne (Twente)
Alternative_Name: Borne; Burgunde; Bornden; Borgonden; Borghenden; Borngonde; Borgeden; Boerne; Borgen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1206, in a fifteenth-century copy.

Name: Bornhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 973.

Name: Bornhöved
Alternative_Name: Burnhovede; Burnhavede; Bornehouede; Burnehovede; Bornhovede; Bornehovede; Bornhovet; Bornhouet
Settlement_Description: The village was founded in the second half of the 12th century. It was a meeting place for regional diets until 1480.

Name: Bornsen
Settlement_Description: The first certain mention dates from 1309. An earlier uncertain mention dates from ca. 1252.

Name: Borntosten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1565.

Name: Bornum am Elm
Alternative_Name: Bornum; Bornnem iuxta Luttere; Bornem apud Luttere; Borne; Bornem bi Luttere; Bornem, dat by Luttere lecht; Bornum prope Elmonem; Bornum vor dem Melme; Bornem; Bornum vor dem Elme; Born
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1135.

Name: Bornum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1189.

Name: Bornum am Harz
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1132.

Name: Bornum (Hannover)
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1304.

Name: Börry
Alternative_Name: Burgiun; Burige; Barigi; Borie; Boria; Burien; Borige; Borye; Borien; Borge; Börrie; Borye; Boryge; Boreye; Borighe; Borry; Borrige; Börri; Barrie
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 968.

Name: Borßum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Borstel (Stendal)
Settlement_Description: In 1150 the tithe in Borstel was given to the bishopric of Halberstadt.

Name: Borstel (Winsen)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1117. According to 17th-century registers, the village consisted of 5 farms ('plog') or 4 farms and a half farm.

Name: Borstel (Achim)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1384.

Name: Borstorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230.

Name: Borxleben
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Breviarium sancti Lulli in the 8th/9th century.

Name: Bösdorf
Settlement_Description: Mention in the beer-privilege of Oebisfelde as property of Oebisfelde.

Name: Bösdorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1433.

Name: Bösel
Alternative_Name: Bosele; Bozele; Bosel; Bossele; Bosell; Boesell; Boesehl; Böesell; Bozel; Boisel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330/52. The village consisted of 13 farms in 1450.

Name: Bosseborn
Alternative_Name: Boffesburiun; Bossesbire; Boffesberen; Boffzebexen; Botzeborn; Bosszeborn; Bofzeborn; Bußbohrn; Boffseborn; Boßeborn

Name: Bostel
Alternative_Name: Liauildindburstal; Berstolde; Borstelde; Borstle; Borstele; Borstel; Borstall
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 826-876.

Name: Bothfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1274.

Name: Bourtange
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1573. Located on the only passage through the extensive Bourtange moor, a fortress ('vesting') was constructed here between 1580 and 1593 to control the traffic.
Toll_Description: According to documents pertaining to the toll in Leerort, a road toll was levied in Bourtange.

Name: Boutersem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1129.

Name: Bovenkarspel
Alternative_Name: Bovenkerspel; Boevenkerspel; Bouekerspel; Boue kerspel; Boeck Carspel
Settlement_Description: Bovenkarspel is first mentioned c1312. Bovenkarspel, together with Grootebroek, was granted town privileges on 2 August 1364 by Albert ('Albrecht'), governor ('ruwaard') of Holland. Bovenkarspel and Grootebroek combined formed the 'stede' Broek. The settlements Lutjebroek and Hoogkarspel were added to this 'stede' in 1402 and 1403, respectively. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The 'stede' lost its privileges in 1426, but these were partly regranted in 1429, and fully restored in 1436.

Name: Boxmeer
Alternative_Name: Buch de Mere; Bucch de Mere; Boxmere; in Meer; Boxmer
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1271.

Name: Braak
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1256.

Name: Bracht
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1306.

Name: Brackrade
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 1280s.

Name: Brackwede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1029.

Name: Brahmkamp
Settlement_Description: Hamlet ('häusergruppe'), first mentioned in 1583.

Name: Brake
Settlement_Description: A castle, next to which the settlement developed, was first mentioned in 1306, but it is archaeologically dated back to the end of the 10th century.

Name: Brakel
Alternative_Name: Brechal; Brecal; Brakelo; Bracle; Brakele; Brackele; Brokel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 836.
Town_Description: Around 1200 Brakel was raised to a town. Called 'civitas' in 1229 and 1244. In 1383 mentioned as 'novum oppidum'.

Name: Bramfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1271.

Name: Bramsche
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1097. The village developed to a borough ('flecken') until the 16th century.
Toll_Description: In an agreement between the town of Osnabrück and the cathedral chapter from 1532, the "new toll" in Bramsche and Venne was cancelled. Probably, the toll had been installed by the recently deceased bishop Erich von Braunschweig-Grubenhagen (1508-1532), whose financial politics had led to complaints and revolts in Osnabrück in 1524/5.

Name: Bad Bramstedt
Alternative_Name: Bramstedt; Bramstede; Bramstedium; Brambstette; Brahmstette; Bramzsthede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as "villa Bramstede" in the 13th century; the settlement was characterised as borough ('flecken') since 1448.
Toll_Description: In 1487, the council of Lübeck complained to the Danish queen Dorothea about the levying of a toll in Bramstedt, which had not been levied before.

Name: Brandenbaum
Alternative_Name: nova villa; Niegenthorpe; Nyndorpe ad arborem; to dem Bome; Brandenbom; Nyendorpe bi dem Brandenbome
Settlement_Description: Border crossing in the Lübeck enclosure ('landwehr'). There was a draw bridge and a boom barrier, first mentioned in 1256, as well as a village, which was "founded recently". In 1410, an inn is mentioned as well.
Bridge_Description: A draw bridge over the enclosure ('landwehr') ditch is first mentioned in 1256.

Name: Brandenburg (Havel)
Alternative_Name: Brandenburg an der Havel; Brendanburg; Brennaburg; Brandenborch; Brandenborg; Brandenburgensis; Brandeneburg; Pardiun; Parduwin; Brennabor
Settlement_Description: Episcopal foundation under Otto I., before a Slawic settlement. In 983 the episcopal seat is lost to the Wends, and is regained and lost again in the following decades. It is finally reconquered in 1157 by the margrave of Brandenburg and the archbishop of Magdeburg. They resided on the castle on today's cathedral isle, while Premonstratensian Canons had settled in the nearby village of Parduin around 1147, which became the old city later in 1160. A new city follows around 1170, it is first mentioned in 1197. In the first half of the 13th century, construction on the cathedral was finished.
Town_Description: Brandenburg is already a coin mint in Slavic times (before 1150), toll privileges follow in 1170 for the 'cives nostri Brandenburgensis'. probably for the civitas of Pardiun. In 1166 Pardiun (the old town) is referred to as villa, the new town has always been called (nova) civitas since 1196. In the middle of the 13th century, Brandenburg (basically Magdeburg) rights are already known. In 1263 council members are mentioned in old and new town. Brandenburg's old and new town can be seen as twin towns with seperate town lords and administratoins until they were merged in 1718.
Staple_Description: In a treaty of the Elector Frederick with the Neustadt in Brandenburg, a three-day staple is mentioned for merchants who wanted to travel through the "Arche". Since 1564 there was also an entrepot in the old town.
Fair_Description: At the end of the 15th century two fairs in old and new town, one additional fair in the new town. At the end of the 16th century 6 fairs in the old town and 5 in the new town.

Name: Brandlecht
Settlement_Description: Castle of the counts of Bentheim, first mentioned in 1313. It was destroyed by troops from Münster in 1360 and rebuilt afterwards.

Name: Brasschaat
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1267, in a fifteenth century copy.

Name: Brójce
Alternative_Name: Brätz; Breditz, Bröditz; Brötz; Bretz; Brojec; Bröyce; Broyca; Brojce
Town_Description: In 1428, Wladislaw II. granted Petrus Rorczbok the right to found a town with Magdeburg town law in the forest Brodcza, however as he couldn't find settlers, it still wasn't a town in 1458, the founding privileges were reinstated in 1603 by Sigismund III.

Name: Brauerschwend
Alternative_Name: Brauerschwein; Brunwardischgeschwende; Bruwertswende; Bruwirswende; Bruerswende; Brauerschwenger; Brawerschwein
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1273. In 1320 a 'Vorwerk' is named.

Name: Braunlage
Settlement_Description: Braunlage is mentioned in 1518 as forestry settlement, and in 1531 with ironworks. It developed into a market borough ('marktflecken') in the 17th century.

Name: Braniewo
Settlement_Description: Most likely used to be an old prussic settlement, a castle of the Teutonic Order was built in 1240 and destroyed by the Old Prussians in 1242, a new german settlement was founded in 1250 and destroyed in 1260, what is now known as the historic district was built in 1276
Town_Description: Town law was granted in 1254 by the first Warmian Bishop, Anselm, the now historic town district was granted a handfast of Lübeck town law in 1284 by Bishop Heinrich Fleming from Lübeck, the new town district was founded on Lübeck town law in 1342 by Bishop Hermann of Prag

Name: Braunschweig
Alternative_Name: Brunswick; Brunesguik; Brunswik; Brunswijk; Brunßwig; Brunßwik; Brunßwigk
Settlement_Description: Braunschweig is first mentioned in the dedication charter of the St Magnus church from 1031.
Town_Description: The town consisted of the five initially independent boroughs ('weichbilde') Altstadt, Hagen, Neustadt, Altewiek and Sack, which merged with each other and appeared as the single town Braunschweig in the course of the 14th century. The oldest town rights of Altstadt were granted in 1204.
Toll_Description: A toll of the town Braunschweig was levied for foreign merchants on commodities sold in town. If the commodities were transported through town without halt, the merchant did not have to pay; if he stopped and rested only half of the toll. The tariffs were specified in the toll regulations around 1300, changed at the end of the century and entered into the town law in 1403.
Fair_Description: The three most important fairs in Braunschweig, on St Walpurga, New Year's Day and St Giles, were first attested in 1385. Three smaller fairs are attested in 1439, on Sunday Jubilate (the dedication day of the church of the Paulinian fathers), Sunday Rogate (dedication day of the Franciscans) and the day of St John. In the late 15th century, the town tried to raise its markets to large international fairs after the example of Leipzig. A privilege was granted in 1497; the New Year's market was moved to the period between 9 and 19 December and the Walpurga market to Friday after Ascension Day. Further extensions came with the market privilege of emperor Maximilian in 1505, when both fairs were extended to 10 days and the New Year's market moved to the day after the Immaculate Conception. However, the great ambitions were never realised, and the three large fairs were reduced to 6 days again in 1521, with the Ascension Day market being moved to two weeks after Easter.

Name: Braunsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1290.

Name: Brauweiler
Toll_Description: From 1389, the Archbishop of Cologne levied a fee for save conduct and a land toll here. Fees for horses and save conduct were collected. The tariff in 1396 was 2 to 3 white pfennigs ('Weißpfennige') per horse, depending on the load. The annual amount added up to an average of 117 marks in 1389/93.

Name: Brecht
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1173.

Name: Breckerfeld
Toll_Description: The count of Breckerfeld charged road toll in 1499. The tariff was fixed at 1 Heller per carriage. The annual revenue in 1499 was 20 guilders, which was to be used to repair the roads.

Name: Breda
Settlement_Description: Breda is first mentioned in a sixteenth-century copy of a document dated 1152.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted ca. 1198-before 25 February 1212 by Godfried II, lord of Breda and Schoten.

Name: Bredelar
Alternative_Name: Breydelare; Breidelare; Bredelare; Breydelar; Breideler; Breidelar; Breydeler; Bredeler; Breitlar; Breideler; Breidelar; Braidelar; Breyler; Breitlar
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1170.

Name: Bree
Alternative_Name: Britte; Bride; Brida; Bridde; Brede; Brée
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1077.

Name: Breese
Alternative_Name: Breese am Seißelberge; Brasen; Brese; Bresen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1450.

Name: Brehna
Settlement_Description: The settlement probably derives from a Slavic-Sorbic settlement with a castle. A village, which held a convent since 1201, developed near the castle.
Town_Description: An exact date of the awarding of town rights in unknown, however, the village is referred to as town since 1274 and is fortified and expanded.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of the department of Bitterfeld
Fair_Description: From 1624-28 Leipzig and Brehna argued over the requested fairs in Brehna; only when Brehna promised to only hold rural fairs ('Landjahrmarkt') and to never establish a staple or depot, the quarrel ended.

Name: Breitau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1260.

Name: Breitenbach am Herzberg
Alternative_Name: Breitenbach; Breitenbach unter den Herzberg; Breitinbach; Breydenbach apud stratam (bi dem Herczisberge); Nidern Breydenbach; Breytenbach
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1294.

Name: Breitenbach
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1408.

Name: Breitenfeld
Alternative_Name: Breitenfelde; Bredeuelt; Bredenfelde; Birdenfelde; Bredefeld; Breydenfeldt; Breittenfeld
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1258.

Name: Breitenworbis
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1238.

Name: Bremen
Alternative_Name: Brema; Bremia; Bremae; Bremun; Bremon; Bremin; Bremenn; Brehmen;
Settlement_Description: Around 780, there existed a settlement at the riverfront at the current street Tiefer at the shore of the Weser river, as well as a religious (episcopal) centre on a river dune.
Town_Description: The settlement acquired market, justice and mint privileges in 965. The first city wall was built after 1030 and a council is first mentioned in 1225. Older town privileges were confirmed by archbishop Gerhard I in 1217.
Toll_Description:
Various tolls were levied in the city of Bremen, of which the oldest have their roots in the toll rights of the archbishop from 888. The town levied tolls at each town gate, which were leased to Johan Cruse in 1373, who in return had to maintain the stone road from St Ansgar's bridge to St John's chapel. (Bremer UB III:431). Excluded was the toll on the Weser bridge, which was owned by the count of Hoya.
The Akzise, import and export duties, accounted for about 86% for the entire income of the city in 1600. Moreover, from 1426 onwards a buoy toll ('tonnengeld') for maintenance of the traffic signs on the lower Weser river, a tidal area, was levied for each incoming and outgoing ship. Responsible for the levying of the latter toll were the eldermen of the common merchant. Akzise and Tonnengeld registers are extant from the year 1532 onwards (StAB, 2-R.2.A.o.2.b.).
Staple_Description:
First signs of a staple can be found in the town rights of 1303/8, but only in 1360, a request from Lübeck shows that Bremen had installed a corn staple. In 1376, citizens of Hannover were allowed to ship all commodities freely, except corn, of which a third part had to be sold in Bremen. The town laws of the "Kundige Rolle" (1450, 1498) contain a three-day staple obligation for commodities coming from the sea and wood coming down the Weser, as well as a prohibition of the trade between non-citizens.
Complaints from Minden on the Hanseatic Diets in 1506, 1507 and 1511 show that the staple could not be fully enforced. In 1541, the emperor confirmed the staple obligations, but revoked the charter in the same year. Minden citizens were exempted from the Bremen staple in 1552, but from 1611 there were renewed attempts to enforce the staple towards Minden merchants. The "Weddeordnung" of 1612 prohibited merchants from neighbouring towns to transport herring, butter, fish, tar, fish oil, tallow, corn, wine, beer and other commodities through Bremen. The staple was abolished with the "Weserschifffahrtsakte" of 1823.
Fair_Description: The fairs in Bremen went back at least to the market privileges of 965, probably even into the 9th century. The oldest fair took place in Autumn, to which a second Spring fair was added in a privilege of 1035. These two fairs both lasted a week and remained in place - with various alterations in the dates throughout the years - until 1638. In that year, the Spring fair was replaced by two three-day fairs, on Quasimodogeniti and Ascension Day; the Autumn market was prolonged to nine days. In the same 1638 privilege, four new horse fairs were installed.

Name: Bremervörde
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed next to a 12th-century moated castle that was built by duke Lothar of Saxony at a ford in the Oste river. After 1219 it became the main castle of the archbishops of Bremen. The settlement acquired borough ('weichbild') privileges after Hamburg model in the 14th century.
Toll_Description: A toll of the archbishop of Bremen is first mentioned in 1225, when citizens of the town Bremen were exempted from the toll. In the 15th and 16th century, there were conflicts with Bremen citizens, who misused their exemption to drive cattle through Bremervörde for foreigners. In this time, it is mostly mentioned as toll and safe conduct for oxen.
Fair_Description: A fair on Ascension Day was moved from Bevern to Bremervörde in 1582. Merchants were offered two days of safe conduct after the fair.

Name: Bremke
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1313.

Name: Bremscheid
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1280.

Name: Wrocław
Staple_Description: In 1274, Henry IV of Silesia limited the staple for entire Silesia to Breslau; confirmed 1409. However, most of the times the staple was difficult to enforce due to conflicts with Poland. An agreement between Frankfurt (Oder) was made in 1490, that merchants were only allowed to cross the Oder at Frankfurt or Breslau. The Enforcement of this agreement was complicated by counter-measures of the Polish king. Merchants from Poland, Russia, Prussia, Lithuania and Masovia were prohibited to trade further than Frankfurt and Breslau in 1507. The staple of Breslau was confirmed by the Emperor 1510, but the following Polish trade boycott forced the city to refrain from its staple rights between 1515 and 1530. The staple disappeared at the end of the 18th century.

Name: Breukelen
Alternative_Name: Bruklede; Broclede; Broeclede; Broicleede; Broeckelen; Brueckelen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1130-1161, in a copy probably from circa 1420. Next mention in 1139.

Name: Brickwedde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned at the end of the 12th century. The settlement was possibly founded in Frankish times.

Name: Brielle
Settlement_Description: Brielle is first mentioned in 1257.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted 30 November 1330 by Gerard, lord of Voorne, but at least from 1306 onward already indicated as a city.

Name: Brietlingen
Alternative_Name: Britlingi; Brithlinghe; Brittlinghe; Britlinge; Britling; Brithlingen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1004.

Name: Brilon
Alternative_Name: Brilo; Brylon; Bruilen; Bräylen; Brilon; Brielon; Brylan; Brilen; Briilon; Brilohn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 973.
Town_Description: Raised to a town in 1220 and granted Soester rights.

Name: Brink
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1315.

Name: Brinkum
Alternative_Name: Brinken; Brinkem; Brinckem; Brynchem; Brinkheim; Brynghen; Brynchen
Settlement_Description: The place was mentioned for the first time in 1158.
Toll_Description: A toll of the counts of Hoya is first mentioned around 1380. It is still mentioned in a charter from 1562, in which the count of Hoya lowers the fares for the citizens of Arsten and Habenhausen (in Bremen territory) to dig peat around Brinkum, and obliges them to pay these fares at the comital toll house in Brinkum and to use only the toll road through the Kattenturm to get there. Further details of the toll are only known from the late 17th century onwards (Niedersächsisches Landesarchiv Hannover).

Name: Britz
Settlement_Description: First mention at the end of the 12th century.

Name: Brockel
Settlement_Description: A priest from Brockel is mentioned as owner of a part in the Lüneburg saltworks in a register of 1379-1381.

Name: Bröckel
Alternative_Name: Broclede; Brocledhe; Brokede; Brokel; Brokelde; Brokilde; Bruckelde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1215.

Name: Brockensen
Alternative_Name: Brokhusen; Brochusen; Brechusen; Brukensen; Brokensen; Bruchhausen; Brokenen
Settlement_Description: A first mention in the 10th century is uncertain.

Name: Broich
Toll_Description: In 1389, the Duke of Jülich levied a lfee for save conduct and a land toll here. Fees for horses and save conduct were collected here. Depending on the load, the tariff was 2 to 3 white pfennigs ('Weißpfennige') per horse. The annual revenue in 1389/93 was on average 79 marks per year, in 1510/1511: 375 marks.

Name: Broitzem
Alternative_Name: Brochem; Brothsem; Brotzem; Brutzem; Brotcem; Broszzem; Brotzhum; Broczem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1160.

Name: Brome
Settlement_Description: The castle and settlement were first mentioned around 1202/3. The settlement was usually characterised as borough ('flecken').
Toll_Description: A toll of the dukes of Brunswick is first mentioned in 1321, and again in 1409.

Name: Bromskirchen
Alternative_Name: Fromolskirke; Fromoldeskirchen; Vromoldeskirchen; Fruboldeskirchen; Hrumboldeskirchen; Fromißkirchen; Brommelskirchen; Formskirchen; Brumskirchen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1238.

Name: Bronkhorst
Settlement_Description: Earlierst mention dates from 1128-1139.
Town_Description: Earliest mention as 'stedeke' in a charter of 1371. Town privileges granted on 13 March 1482, by Gijsbert VII of Bronkhorst and Borculo.

Name: Brual
Settlement_Description: First mentioned when a castle was destroyed here in 1345.

Name: Bruchwedel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1391.

Name: Brück
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in Brück in 1411. Tariffs and revenues are not known. Established in 1411 as a secondary land toll by Mühlheim, in 1487 by Dünnwald.

Name: Brücken
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Breviarium sancti Lulli (Trizzebruccun) in the 8th/9th century. Is granted market rights in 1518.

Name: Brüel
Settlement_Description: mentioned as a settlement, close to a castle complex from the 13th ct. belonging to the noble house Plessen
Town_Description: Reimar von Plessen raised the settlement to be a 'Stedeken', most likely with the Parchim town law

Name: Brugge
Alternative_Name: Brvggas; Brvccia; Bruggis; Bricge; Brycge; in Brugghen; bi Brigghe; Bruges; Brügge
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 840-875. Next mention in 1012.
Staple_Description: First privileges of the low German merchants in Bruges date from 1252. The ordinance of the aldermen from 1285 forces citizens to bring all cloth from within a range of 3 miles around the city to Bruges. 1309: Staple for wax, furs, copper and other commodities. The general staple was confirmed by Count Louis II in 1323, with the exception of dried fish, corn, salt, pitch, tar and shipbuilding materials, which are also allowed to be unloaded in Damme, Houcke and Monikerede. Exclusive staple for English wool in 1340-1353. A Hanseatic residence ("Kontor") was established in 1347. During conflicts, the Hanseatic staple was moved to Dordrecht in 1358-1359 and 1388-1392, and to Bergen op Zoom (for wool) in 1388-1392. In the 14th century, Bruges had growing problems in enforcing the staple, in favour of the cities Sluis, Antwerp, Middelburg, Utrecht and Amsterdam. In 1530, the Hanseatic Kontor was finally moved to Antwerp, leaving only a staple for Spanish wool (established in 1490, confirmed in 1531 and 1540) in Bruges.

Name: Brumby
Toll_Description: Proof of a station of safe conduct in 1486.

Name: Brummen
Alternative_Name: Brimnum; Bremmenen; Brimmen; Brijmmen; Brommen; Brymen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 794, in a tenth century copy.

Name: Bründeln
Alternative_Name: Brundelem; Brundelen; Brundelheimb; Bründelem; Brundelemb; Bründelumb
Settlement_Description: The year of first mention was 1191.

Name: Brungershausen
Alternative_Name: Brungozeshusun; Brungozhusen; Brungodeshusen; Brungozishusen; Brungeshusen; Brungershusen; Brungerchusen; Brungirchusin; Brumerßhußen; Brengershusen; Brommershausen; Brungerßhaußen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1130.

Name: Brünn
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1330.

Name: Brunsen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1148.

Name: Brunshausen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 852, when a house of canonesses was founded. After the canonesses had moved to Gandersheim in 881, a new Benedictine monastery was founded before 1106/11, which became a nunnery between 1192 and 1206. In 1655 the monastery became Lutheran, and was abolished in 1810.

Name: Bruxelles - Brussel
Alternative_Name: Bruocsella; Brosella; Brucsella; Brussel; Brussels; Brüssel; Bruxelles
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 966, in a fifteenth century copy.

Name: Brüssow
Settlement_Description: A castle existed in slavic times, a small german settlement with a church is mentioned as a plebanus in 1259
Town_Description: The knight Heinrich von Stegelitz was granted the right to built a courtroom and a market toll in 1259, later the town law of Prenzlau and Magdeburg was granted, in 1299 the village was merged with Alt-Borstow and subsequently called a civitas

Name: Most
Staple_Description: The staple privilege contained obligations to use specific routes only. Corn staple for the surrounding countryside.

Name: Bubendorf
Settlement_Description: First mention as Bovendorf in 1378.

Name: Büchen
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1230.

Name: Buchenau
Alternative_Name: Bechenowe; Bochenowe; Buchinowe; Buchenauwe; Büchenowe; Buchenaw
Settlement_Description: The settlement 'Bechenowe' is first mentioned in 1238 but possibly goes back to a deserted settlement.

Name: Buchladen
Settlement_Description: A law court with the name Bocla is first mentioned in 1213. The name of the forester's lodge Buchladen is first mentioned in 1823. It is questionable whether there already existed a settlement in the Middle Ages

Name: Buckau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 937 in a gift certificate by Otto I. to the monastary of St. Moritz in Magdeburg (MGH DD OI, nr. 16, S. 103 - 105).

Name: Bückeburg
Settlement_Description: Around 1300, a moated castle was built by the counts of Schaumburg, which was first mentioned in 1304. The attached settlement acquired Stadthagen borough ('flecken') privileges from count Adolf VII of Schaumburg in 1365.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted in 1609 by count Ernst of Schaumburg.

Name: Buckow
Settlement_Description: Since there are no rights of the Mark in Buckow, it can be assumed that the village was founded before it became territory of the margraves in the Teltow-war 1239 - 1245.

Name: Buddemühlen
Settlement_Description: Originally a farmyard, became a manor in the late 15th century.

Name: Büderich
Toll_Description: 1) The Count of Cleves levied a Rhine toll here between 1288-1472, 1485-1495 and from 1500 a river toll on the Rhine was levied. Tolls were mainly levied on wine, so a tariff of 2 shillings per barrel applied in 1290. For more information on tariffs and revenues, see source. This toll was probably established as the successor to the Orsoy toll. From 1352, Duisburg customs were also levied in Büderich. From about 1438 onwards, customs tariffs were differentiated according to whether the goods took the Rhine or the Waal route. 2) During the Soest feud (1444-1450), a fee for save conduct on the river was also levied. This is documented in 1445, but was not continued thereafter. 3) In 1417/1446, a land toll was levied. Tariffs are not known. First evidence from 1446, but probably already established in 1417.

Name: Buggenum
Alternative_Name: Bugnem; Buchnem; Bugenheijm; Buggenheym; Buggenom; Bugghenhem; Bogghenum; Buggem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1230.

Name: Bühne
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1324.

Name: Buitenpost
Alternative_Name: Bûtenpost; Post; Uetpost; Butapost; Buta post; Butenpost; Butenbast
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1388.

Name: Buke
Settlement_Description: A church called 'Buke' was first mentioned in 1231.

Name: Buļļuciems
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1450. A little further west there was probably a ferry with which you could cross the river Aa.

Name: Bülstringen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1121.

Name: Bümmerstede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1310. Münster troops from Vechta burned the village to the ground in 1454.

Name: Bunde
Alternative_Name: Bunda; Hogenbonne; Hogenbunde; Hoogen Bunde; Hohebonde
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 1428, but the village church dates from between 1230 and 1280. The settlement developed into a borough ('flecken') in the 15th century.

Name: Bündorf
Alternative_Name: Boian villa; Bojandorf; Boiondorff; Bugindorph; Boyndorph
Settlement_Description: Probably developed during the Frakisch colonization, first written mention in 1012, when Henry II. confirms the possession of Boian villa (Bojandorf) to the church of Merseburg. Mention of a castrum in 1266.

Name: Bunschoten
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1249. Around 1200 an agrarian settlement had developed, after the region was cultivated ('ontgonnen') in the twelfth century.
Town_Description: Bunschoten was granted town rights sometime between 1336 and 1355, by John ('Jan') of Arkel.

Name: Bünzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned ca. 1140.

Name: Büren
Alternative_Name: Burenan; Burgnan; Buren; Buronon; Burin; Buiren; Beuren
Town_Description: The city was probably founded before 1194 by the noblemen of Büren near their castle, which was built from 1150; until 1220, the city was expanded based on the Lippstadt model with a market and minting; before 1252 a second new town was founded.

Name: Burg (Bremen)
Settlement_Description: A castle likely existed on the crossing of the river Lesum in the 13th century, next to which a settlement developed. The castle was reconstructed in 1350.

Name: Burg (bei Magdeburg)
Settlement_Description: The origin of the place lies in an early medieval settlement, probably from the time of Henry I. In the 10th century there was a castle guard and a settlement in close proximity. First written mention in the foundation of the bishopric of Brandenburg, when its tithe mentioned as belonging to St. Moritz' monastery in Magdeburg.
Town_Description: Town hall and marketplace point towards a trading enclosure, which probably held town rights from the beginning. Dating based on the emergence of the "jus Burgense" in the middle of the 13th century. Revisions of the town rights e.g. 1474, 1558, 1576 and 1598. Since 1262 Burg had purchased a freedom of tax and trade in Magdeburg.
Toll_Description: In 1489 the town of Magdeburg complains with the escort ('Geleitsmann') of Burg that safe conduct fees have been collected from two citizens, even though they were supposed to be excempt from such payments.
Fair_Description: The first market privilege was given in 1562.

Name: Burgdamm
Settlement_Description: Between 1388 and 1390, a causeway ('damm') was constructed to cross the marshes of the Lesum river between the newly erected Lesum bridge in Burg and the dry sandy moraine north of it. A settlement developed on the north end of the causeway and took over its name.

Name: Burgdorf
Alternative_Name: Burtorf; Borgdorpe; Borchdorpe; Borchtorpe; Borchtorp; Borchtorff; Burchtorf; Burdolf
Settlement_Description: A castle of the bishop of Hildesheim with a connected settlement was mentioned between 1260 and 1279.
Town_Description: The settlement developed into a borough ('flecken') or town without acquiring town rights. A council and seal is first mentioned in 1398.
Toll_Description: In 1354, the bishop of Hildesheim cancelled the toll and fees for safe conduct in Burgdorf. In the early 16th century, citizens from Braunschweig transshipped their commodities intended for Bremen on ships in Essel, thereby circumventing the toll in Celle. For this reason, the duke of Brunswick raised the toll tariff in Burgdorf, which led to Bremen complaints in 1526-1529.
Fair_Description: Before 1578, two fairs existed in Burgdorf. It is unknown since when these existed, possibly since the moment the settlement became a town or borough ('flecken') around 1400. A third fair was added in 1578, and a fourth carnival fair in 1614. In 1619, the dates and locations are specified: the fairs on Carnival and St Gallus took place in front of the Uetzen and Celle gates east of the town, and the fairs of St George and St Vitus in front of the Hannover gate west of the town.

Name: Werlaburgdorf
Settlement_Description: A family of Burgdorf is first mentioned in 1142, the village itself in 1147. The name Werlaburgdorf - after the early medieval royal palace Werla, which was located in the vicinity - was only adopted as late as 1958.
Toll_Description: A toll in Werlaburgdorf is mentioned in 1301 and 1354.

Name: Burgsteinfurt
Alternative_Name: Stenvorde; Steinvorde; Stenverde; Stenvordia; Steinvordia; Borchstenvorde; Castrum Stenvorde; Stenwert; Stemmert
Settlement_Description: The castle Stenvorde was first mentioned in 1129, next to which the settlement developed. Which was first named in 1222.
Town_Description: An exact year in which the first city rights were granted is not known, but must have been before 1299. From 1310 to 1337 the place is run as an 'oppidum'. In 1347 it was granted town rights of Munster.

Name: Burguffeln
Alternative_Name: Ufelohun; Ufloun; Uflon; Uflahun; Ufflan; Astuflon; Uffeln; Ostuffelen; Borckuffeln; Oistuffeln das man auch Burguffeln nennet; Burg-Uffeln
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 965 and located near a castle.

Name: Burgwalde
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1318. In the 15th century it was deserted for a time but it must have been inhabited again by the middle of the 16th century.

Name: Burlage
Settlement_Description: Around 1140 a Benedictine monastery was founded. The drainage of the surrounding moors in the 14th century favoured its economic situation to a certain extent, but the monastery did not own many lands or tithes. After it had become Lutheran in 1543, monastic life in Burlage ended in 1672.

Name: Burtnieki
Settlement_Description: The year of first reference is unclear, but is dated between 1306 and 1366. A castle was built on the southern shore of the lake, which the Russians burned down in 1560.

Name: Busch
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1441.

Name: Bussum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1306.

Name: Buttelstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 9th century. There were a castle, that is mentioned in 1281, and a market.
Town_Description: The landgraves of Thuringia granted Buttelstedt town status most probably before 1334. In 1454, the town was ruled under the constitution of Weißensee. The town is situated at a crossing of the via regia, which moves from West to East, and the salt road, which moves from North to South. This fact made the town gain some importance and facilities such as a court square, the escort building or the hospital.
Toll_Description: In 1403 the safe conduct of Buttelstädt was sold for one year. It was a station of safe conduct for Erfurt, as shown in the registry of safe conduct from 1533. It's the Easternmost Ernestinian safe conduct and the only station of safe conduct in between Erfurt and Leipzig. (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Cc 555 (1533); ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Bb 171 (1535/36).)

Name: Butzbach
Alternative_Name: Botisphaden; Buodesbach; Butespachere; Botinesbach; Butspach; Bodespach
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 773.
Town_Description: Was granted town privileges in 1321.

Name: Bützow
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 1171 as terra Butissowe, where a Slavic fortress existed.
Town_Description: A town must have come into existence in the early 13th century, and is first mentioned in 1229. Town privileges (presumably of Schwerin) were granted in 1236 and confirmed in 1371, 1449 and 1603.

Name: Buxtehude
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a donation charter of Otto I to the monastery of St Maurice in Magdeburg in 959. The original settlement was located in the vicinity of the Altkloster (old monastery), which was founded in 1196.
Town_Description: Archbishop Giselbert of Bremen founded the Neustadt ('new town') north of the original settlements in the 1280s; the town acquired Stade town privileges in 1328. The name of the original settlement was transferred to the new town in the mid-15th century.
Toll_Description: A toll of the archbishop of Bremen in Buxtehude is first mentioned in 1376. In 1385, after complaints about exceptional levying of toll on the Elbe, it is guaranteed that no toll shall be levied on shipping on the Elbe. It is therefore likely that the toll in Buxtehude was a fee on local im- and exports. Moreover, a pound toll for the fight against piracy was levied in Buxtehude in the 1360s, like in Hamburg and Stade.
Fair_Description: The oldest fair in Buxtehude, on St Lawrence's day, took place since 1287. A fair on St Martin's day appears in 1420. A horse market was founded in 1474, which often took place in combination with a fair on St Peter and Paul's day. In 1511, the horse market was moved to Wednesday before Palm Sunday, while the fair on St Peter and Paul remained in existence until 1573. In 1531, a fair was added on Thursday and Friday before Palm Sunday, which was moved to the week after Judica in 1583. A Pentecost fair is mentioned in 1559. In the 16th century, the fairs had a duration of at least 3 days, with the horse market one week and the St Martin's fair 14 days.

Name: Calau
Alternative_Name: Calowe; Kalow; Calawe; Kalo; Calovia; Calensis
Settlement_Description: Grew close to an old wendish settlement, protected by a german castle
Town_Description: Mentioned in 1279 as civitas, the town law has probably been granted earlier by Margrave Dietrich (1210-1221) or Heinrich von Meißen (1221-1288), Magdeburg town law was certified in the 15th ct.

Name: Calbe
Alternative_Name: Calvo; Caluo; Calven; Kalbe; Calbe an der Saale
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 936 in a gift certificate to Quedlinburg monastary (MGH DD OI, nr. 1, S. 89). Near a castle from 961 that was situated at a river crossing by the Magdeburg-Halle long-distance road. Around 965 a royal court was established and since 968 it belongs to the archbishopric of Magdeburg.
Town_Description: Given market- and town rights since the 12th century. Mostly wool weaving and fabric trade. Salt mined in Staßfurt was transported from Calbe via the Saale. In 1179 the royal court is destroyed by Henry the Lion and is replaced by a new castle. In 1361 this castle is refurbished and modernised by archbishop Dietrich. In 1289 councilmen are mentioned as well as jurymen, which means that there has to be a fully developed town constitution.
Toll_Description: In 1362 the achepiscopal steward of Kalbe demands a fee from the boatmen on the Saale river. The toll is proven by several conflicts with the citizens of Magdeburg on the toll excemption in 1432, 1486 and 1487. Complaint in the course of the 16th century, that the toll stations of Oebisfelde, Neuhaldensleben, Wolmirstedt, Dreileben, Wanzleben and Calbe earned less money because of the toll excemption of the citizens of Magdeburg. A toll regulation from the 16th century is recorded.

Name: Calberlah
Alternative_Name: Kalverlage; Kalverleghe; Calverla; Kalverla; Calwerlager; Calverlage; Kalverlage; Kalberlah; Kelberla; Calverla; Calverlag
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1311.

Name: Kalefeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 889.
Toll_Description: A toll is first mentioned in 1318.

Name: Calvörde
Settlement_Description: A former location at a ford is derived from the name Calvörde. The settlement's castle lay on a rise within the Ohre valley. First mention in 1196.
Town_Description: Mention as a borough ('Flecken') in the 13th century, referred to as town in 1345.
Toll_Description: In 1621/22, Gardelegen felt wronged by the new tolls of Braunschweig in Calvörde.

Name: Bad Camberg
