Alternative_Name: Camberg; Cagenberg; Kaymberg; Caimberg; Caenberg; Kaemburg; Kahenberg; Kanberc; Kaynberg; Kainberg; Kaymberg; Kaenberch
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000.
Town_Description: In 1281 town rights were granted.

Name: Camburg
Settlement_Description: Camburg was probably already an Karolingian castle. Since the 10th century it became a count's manor with an adjoining castle village, which developed into a castle market. It lay at the old road from Nuremberg to Naumburg, which led through Jena. In the 12th century, Camburg was given a chapter of canons.
Town_Description: After the town was planned in the first half of the 12th cenutry, it was referred to as cives in 1149, and since 1349 as oppidum. In 1373 Camburg was subject to Naumburg rights.
Toll_Description: Since 1259 a toll station for rafting is known on the Saale.
Fair_Description: Since the 13th century a fair on St. Laurentius' day (8th August) is known in Camburg.

Name: Karsdorf
Settlement_Description: The settlement was founded at a convenient Unstrut crossing and settlement can be proven since the Stone Ages. Several monasteries earned property in Karsdorf in the middle ages.
Toll_Description: A bridge escort is collected in Karsdorf. Since 1621 secondary station of safe conduct of Freyburg.

Name: Kassinurme
Settlement_Description: Village and manor were first mentioned in 1560.

Name: Castrop
Settlement_Description: Castrop was originally a farm, which in 1236 became the property of the counts and later dukes of Kleve. In 1484 the settlement around the courtyard received a freedom privilege for court and parish.
Town_Description: The settlement got town privileges in 1470.

Name: Celle
Settlement_Description: Mentioned at the old location Altencelle as early as 983. The town was moved to the present location in 1292.
Town_Description: Celle was moved from its previous location at Altencelle ('old Celle') in 1292, and received the Lüneburg town privileges; in 1301 those of Braunschweig. Celle was the principal residence of the Dukes of Lüneburg between 1433 and 1705.
Toll_Description: Land and water toll and safe conduct of the dukes of Brunswick--Lüneburg. The toll in Celle is already mentioned in the town privileges of the Braunschweig borough ('weichbild') Hagen in the early 13th century as the only toll at the waterway between Braunschweig and Bremen. Toll registers are available from 1379, see Peters 1913. In the years 1455-58, we first hear from different toll fees for commodities transported by Celle and Braunschweig citizens; the latter have to pay the double toll amount. The oldest known tariff dates from ca. 1560.
Staple_Description: The town of Braunschweig received freedom of shipping on the Aller and Oker rivers in 1459, but the Dukes of Lüneburg owned the pre-emptive right on a third of the corn shipped through Celle. Moreover, skippers were forced to offer the corn on the market for a while. The town attempted to expand the staple towards to include other commodities in the second half of the 16th century. In 1618, Bremen citizens acquired the right to buy corn up- and downstream from Celle, which effectively ended the staple.
Fair_Description: In 1353, three three-day fairs are mentioned in Celle: on Sunday before St Walpurga, St Maurice and Sunday before St Martin. The fair of St Maurice is moved to the Sunday after the Ascension of Mary in 1412.

Name: Cheine
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1270, when the village was acquired by the monastery Neuendorf.

Name: Chemnitz
Toll_Description: A regulation of safe conduct from 1551 is recorded (SHStA Dresden, Loc. 37864, Augustusburg Nr. 5, Erbbuch des Amtes Schellenberg 1551, p. 588–596b.)

Name: Dzierzgoń
Settlement_Description: A castle of the Teutonic Order wa sbuilt in 1248 and a settlement grew close to it, it was mentioned as oidum in 1254, but destroyed between 1260 and 1273
Town_Description: Founding documents were grantes by the Komtur Helwig von Goldbach in 1288, but it was already mentioned as a civitas between 1260 and 1273, documents were endorsed and expanded in 1290 by the landmaster of the Order, Meinhard von Querfurt, the handfast was renewed in 1451 by the Grand master Ludwig von Erlichshausen with Kulm town law

Name: Chüttlitz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1340. The village apparently was deserted by 1420 but resettled in 1503.

Name: Clauen
Alternative_Name: Cleun; Clowen; Clowin; Clauwen; Klauen; Clawen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1151.

Name: Clausthal
Alternative_Name: Clausthal-Zellerfeld; Bergstadt auf dem Clausberge; Klausthall; Clußdale; Kluvigesdale; Nicolaivallensis
Settlement_Description: Around 1530, mining activities in Clausthal were started (again).
Town_Description: Clausthal is first mentioned as mining town ('freie Bergstadt') in 1554. It was merged with nearby Zellerfeld in 1924.

Name: Cloppenburg
Settlement_Description: Before 1297, the castle Cloppenburg was built by the counts of Tecklenburg near the village Krapendorf.
Town_Description: Cloppenburg first received borough ('weichbild') privileges in 1411, and in 1435 the town privileges of Haselünne.
Toll_Description: In a Cloppenburg register from 1474/5, the income from the toll in Cloppenburg is listed as 46 Mark 5 Shilling. Probably, this was a road toll on the "flämische Straße" (Flemish street) from Bremen to Flandern. It is unclear when it was first levied.
Fair_Description: A fair in Cloppenburg is first mentioned in 1535.

Name: Coburg
Settlement_Description: Systematically founded around the beginning of the 11th century, Coburg lies at an old road from Bamberg to Frankfurt and was first mentioned in 1056 in a gift certificate, where it serves as the founding property of a chapter of canons. Around 1200 a new castle was constructed, which served as a royal manor until 1549.
Town_Description: In 1331 Coburg was granted Schweinfurt rights and an own jursidiction. Since 1540 residence town of Wettin.
Toll_Description: The regulations of safe conduct describe the extent of the safe conduct in Coburg as well as the fees that were due.

Name: Coesfeld
Alternative_Name: Coasfeld; Cosuelda; Koesfeld; Kosfelt; Cosvelda; Cusvelda
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 809.
Town_Description: Bishop Hermann II. granted town privileges like Munster in 1197.

Name: Coevorden
Alternative_Name: Koiforde; Cuvorde; Covordiae; Koevorden; Covorde; Coverden; Cuuorde; Cuforde; Koevorde; Coeverden; Covorden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1141 as part of a name ('Fredericus de Cuvorde'). Coevorden is located on a sand ridge ('zandrug') in the Bourtange Moor. This made it not only into a military strategic location, but also into an important trading point, as every traveller from Groningen to Munster needed to pass through Coevorden.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted at 31 December 1407 by Frederick of Blankenheim, bishop of Utrecht. Town privileges may have been granted earlier (before 1395); however, by 1407 the document that proofed this had been lost.
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Utrecht is first mentioned in a conflict with count Otto of Bentheim in 1187.

Name: Colditz
Toll_Description: The regulations of safe conduct settle the fees due in the town as well as on the Mulde river when it is high enough to use as a waterway.
Bridge_Description: In the regulations of safe conduct of Colditz, a bridge fee is mentioned. The station of safe conduct is especially important for cattle trade from Poland; every year toll was paid on thousands of cows and oxen.

Name: Connewitz
Alternative_Name: Kunawiz; Konenvicz; Kanewicz; Gonewicz; Konnewitz; Canwitz; Conewitz
Settlement_Description: First mention in the name Borzlaus de Kunawiz.

Name: Coppenbrügge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century. Around 1300, a castle was built here, whereupon the settlement developed into a borough ('burgflecken').

Name: Coswig (Anhalt)
Settlement_Description: The settlement lay at a castle district and later developed into a Anhaltinian coutry town. It was temporarily an important widow's seat and burial place.
Town_Description: In 1215 the town is referred to as oppidum. In 1315 town rights, which were probably based on Magdeburg rights, can be determined.
Toll_Description: The regulations of safe conduct mention 2 land- and road tolls as well as safe conduct. They also regulate the toll on the water.
Staple_Description: The regulations of safe conduct state that rafters had to offer their wares for three days in Coswig, unless they paid the toll right away.

Name: Cottbus
Settlement_Description: A burgward against the Wendish was built in the late 10th ct., a market settlement grew close to it
Town_Description: Exact date of foundation unclear, first mentioned as a town in 1156, formal adoption of the Magdeburg town law in 1409

Name: Cranz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1341.
Ferry_Description: Around 1400, Cranz replaced Urenfleth as landing place for the ferry across the Elbe river. The latter settlement was flooded, its location unknown.

Name: Crawinkel
Toll_Description: The Knights of St. John werre allowed to maintain a toll station and an inn in Crawinkel, which they sold to the counts of Gleichen in 1470.

Name: Cremlingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1296. In the vicinity of the church, shards from the 3rd-7th centuries were found, which indicate earlier habitation with an urn cemetery.

Name: Creuzburg
Settlement_Description: First mention of the Creuzburg at the Werraford in 973, together with the villages of East- and West-Milingen, which were later assimilated into Creuzburg.
Town_Description: Eleveated to town bei either Ludwig II. or Ludwig III. (between 1170 and 1189). This probably happened during the construction of the town wall and the fortification of town and castle. The term "civitas" can be found before 1189. Town rights could be based on the rights of the Hessian-Thuringian towns at the Werra, Eisenach or Gotha.
Toll_Description: The fees for the safe conduct in Creuzburg are listed in the regulations for safe conduct ('Geleitsordnung') for Creuzburg from 1535/36. (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Bb 171, Capitalrechnungen der Ämter zu Thüringen, Vogtland und Franken 1535/36.)
Fair_Description: In the regulations of safe conduct ('Geleitsordnung') for Creuzburg two fairs are mentioned. There is no indication of their lenghth. (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Bb 171, Capitalrechnungen der Ämter zu Thüringen, Vogtland und Franken 1535/36.)
Bridge_Description: Built by landgrave Ludwig, oldest preserved stone bridge north of the Main.

Name: Cröbern
Settlement_Description: In 1350 referred to as curia, abandoned in 1982 for a lignite open-cast mine.

Name: Krosno Odrzańskie
Alternative_Name: Crossen an der Oder;Crosno; Crosni; Crosna; Crozna; Krosyn; Krosne
Settlement_Description: A polish castle is mentioned in 1005 during the battles between Heinrich II. and Boleslaw I., a church existed in 1065, later mentions of silesian viticulture by german immigrants since 1154, a slavic fishing settlement existed between the church and the river, later there was also a german market settlement close to the castle
Town_Description: The town was founded in the beginning of the 13th ct. by silesian dukes, most likely Heinrich I (1201-1221), mentioned as civitas in 1249, possessed Magdeburg town since 1317

Name: Croya
Alternative_Name: Croye; Croge; Kroye; Kroyge; Croyge; Kroien; Croigen; Kroyen; Krüge; Kroy
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1310.

Name: Cuijk
Alternative_Name: Ceuclum; Kuik; Chuc; Kuc; Cuc; Cuich; Kuic; Kuck; Kuyc; Kuuck; Kuyck; Keyuk; Cuijck; Kuyk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 365 in a thirteenth century copy. Cuijk is mentioned as 'Kuik' around 1050 in an eleventh century copy.

Name: Kuringen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1076, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Curslack
Alternative_Name: Cureslake; Cuwerslake; Kureslake; Cursclake; Kurslake; Kurslacke; Korslake; Curslaken; Koslake; Kurse Lacken; Corslacke; Curslak
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1217.

Name: Dachrieden
Settlement_Description: First mention in 866.

Name: Dahlen
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Oschatz.

Name: Dahlenburg
Settlement_Description: According to a Slavic chronicle from the 13th century, this was a Slavic castle, erected between 860 and 900. The settlement is first mentioned in a charter in 1172.
Town_Description: Lüneburg town privileges granted in 1289.

Name: Dahlinghausen
Alternative_Name: Delinchusun; Dalichusen; Halinchusen; Dalynchuzen; Dolinchusen; Dallinkhusen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in the 12th century.

Name: Dahlwitz
Settlement_Description: First mention of Dahlwitz in 1370.

Name: Dahme
Alternative_Name: Dahme/ Mark; Dame; Damme; Dhame; Thame; Dahma; Damis
Settlement_Description: A german castle built on slavic remains, the earlier settlement was called Altstadt, german market settlement grew close to it
Town_Description: The town was likely founded by the lord of the castle, first mentioned as a civitas in 1265

Name: Dalchau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1170.
Ferry_Description: In 1486 a ferry in Dalchau is mentioned.

Name: Dalem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1343.

Name: Dalen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in probably twelfth century.

Name: Dalfsen
Alternative_Name: Dalsen; Dalfese; Dalvesem; Dalvsen; Dalvvashem; Dalvveshem; Dalfsem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in copies in 1241. Next mention in 1318.

Name: Dallahn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1289.

Name: Dalldorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1204.

Name: Dalle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned before 1007.

Name: Dalum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000

Name: Damgarten
Settlement_Description: Used to be a wendish settlement, probably close to a cultic site on the temple mountain.
Town_Description: Prince Jaromar II. granted the Lübeck town law, so to act as a barrier to Mecklenburg

Name: Damme (Osnabrück)
Settlement_Description: First reference from 1180.
Fair_Description: A fair in Damme is first mentioned in 1435, when it was the scene of a violent conflict between visitors from Osnabrück and Münster. It is mentioned again in 1580.

Name: Damnatz
Alternative_Name: Domnitze; Domnatze; Domenatze; Damnatze; Dampnatze; Damnaz; Damnaze; Damatz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330/52. In 1450, the village consisted of 12 farms and 8 half farms.

Name: Dankmarshausen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 842.

Name: Danndorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1150. The settlement was partially abandoned in the 14th century, destroyed in 1464 and resettled in 1539.

Name: Dannenberg
Alternative_Name: Dannenberg (Elbe); Danneberge; Dannenberch; Dannenberge; Dannenberghe; Danneberghe; Dannenbergk
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed next to a castle, which was possibly constructed around 800. The castle is first mentioned in 1162, when a count Volrad of Dannenberg as vassal of duke Henry the Lion appears in the sources.
Town_Description: The settlement is first mentioned as 'urbs' in 1202. In 1293 at the latest, Dannenberg owned town privileges. The Lüneburg town law was granted in the 16th century.
Toll_Description: Land and water toll of the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg, pawned to the Bülow family. It was first mentioned in an agreement between Friedrich von Bülow and Salzwedel in 1474. Toll fees are known from the 16th century (StAB).
Fair_Description: In 1293 at the latest, a three-day fair was held in Dannenberg. More details are mentioned in 1365, when a fair in the week after Easter was granted, next to an already existing fair on the Birth of Mary.
Harbour_Description: Dannenberg was an important skipper's town for the river traffic on the Jeetzel.

Name: Gdańsk
Alternative_Name: Danzig; Dantzig; Gothiscandza; Gyddanycz; Kdanzc; deutsch Danzk; Dancek; Danczik; Gedanum; Dantiscum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 997 as fishing village and castle of the princes of Danzig. The castrum Gdansk was mentioned in 1148 as a settlement belonging to the castle; a market settlement of German merchants is attested in 1178.
Town_Description: Prince Swantopolk (1220-1266) granted the German town law to the market settlement in 1224. Lübeck town law was granted in 1263, Magdeburg town law in 1295, Kulm town law in 1343. The settlement was first mentioned as a "civitas" in 1236.
Staple_Description: The origins of the Danzig staple are unclear, but in 1411, the staple was moved temporarily to Elbing by Grand master Heinrich von Plauen (HR I, 6 n 12). Apparently, the staple system of Elbing collapsed in favour of Danzig around 1400. In 1425, Danzig declared that it wanted to construct a building where guests could offer clothing. From 1441, there are clear attempts to force merchants to offer their commodities on the market, and in 1451 and 1482, Polish and Lithuanian merchants complained about the prohibition of trading between non-citizens. After Danzig was confiscated by Poland (1454), King Casimir confirmed the prohibition to travel between the sea and the hinterland without a stop in Danzig. In 1584, the staple for English cloth was moved to Elbing; in 1628, Danzig regained the exclusive import rights on foreign cloth.

Name: Dardesheim
Alternative_Name: Dardessem; Dardiß; Derdessem; Derdesseim; Derdensem; Derdesum; Dörsen
Settlement_Description: Probably a Frankish settlement from the 8th century, that developed into a market borough ('Marktflecken') during the 13th and 14th century. Town rights were granted much later, only in the 18th century.

Name: Dassel
Alternative_Name: Dassila; Daschalon; Daschalen; Daschala; Dassela; Dassele; Dasla; Dasle; Dassle; Dassell
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 877. A church is mentioned around 1022.
Town_Description: The settlement is characterised as borough ('weichbild') in 1310. It received Alfeld town privileges in 1315.

Name: Dassendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1334.

Name: Datterode
Toll_Description: The toll from Ulfen is moved here in 1583 when it is discovered that wagoners avoided the toll in Ulfen via Datterode.

Name: Datum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1588.

Name: De Bilt
Alternative_Name: Op die Bilt; Bilten wert; Bilten-waert; Bylt; Bildt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1307.

Name: De Ginkel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1360.

Name: De Meern
Alternative_Name: Marne; Maren; beneden der Maerne; de Meren; die Maern; Maren; De Meren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention is from a copy dating 1217.

Name: Werven
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1328.

Name: De Wijk
Alternative_Name: van der Wijc; die Wyc; in der Wijck
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1383.

Name: Deelen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from the end of the thirteenth century.

Name: Deetz
Settlement_Description: Until 1238 the settlement was owned by the counts of Osterburg, which means that it has existed before.

Name: Dehnsen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1146.

Name: Deinum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1397.

Name: Deisel
Alternative_Name: Disele; Thesli; Desli; Cesle; Thesle; Thiesle; Desla; Teysile; Deissell; Deyshell
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 9th century.

Name: Delbrück
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1219. Never grew beyond a settlement, but had market- and duty free. This was confirmed in 1591.

Name: Dellbrück
Settlement_Description: The name is derived from a bridge across a canal ('delf').

Name: Delden
Alternative_Name: Dhelden; Thelden; Deylden; Deelden; Theldun; d'Helden; Nye Delden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1036 (in a copy from the second half of the fourteenth century). In 1322, New Delden was officially being founded as a replacement of Old Delden, which was located more to the north. The inhabitants of the old place moved towards the new, walled, and moated location for safety reasons.
Town_Description: In 1322, it is mentioned that the town privileges of the inhabitants of Old Delden would remain valid after their movement to New Delden. In 1333, Jan III of Diest, bishop of Utrecht, grants the town privileges of Oldenzaal to Delden.

Name: Delfstrahuizen
Alternative_Name: Dolsterhuzen; Nye Delfsterhuisen; Olde Delfsterhuisen; Delffsterhuijssen; Delstra-Huysen; Delsterhuysen; Delsterhwysen; Delfterhuys
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1408.

Name: Delft
Settlement_Description: Delft is first mentioned in a the 1420 copy of a document from the period 1130-1157. It originated near the court of a count.
Town_Description: Delft was granted town privileges on 15 April 1246 by William II of Holland. Cox argues that Delft already was a town-like community before that time, as the grant is the result of an initiative by towndwellers. One of the smaller ‘Kamers’ (departments) of the VOC (Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie, Dutch East India Company, founded in 1602) was located in Delft.

Name: Delfzijl
Alternative_Name: Delfzilen; Delsilum; Delfsiel; Delfsijl; Delf Zyl; Delfsyl
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1303. Delfzijl originated near three locks built in 1272. The settlement was granted town rights at 7 May 1819 by William I of the Netherlands.
Harbour_Description: Delfzijl functioned as the sea harbour for the town Groningen, especially after the Damsterdiep canal connected both places with a waterway in 1424.

Name: Delitz am Berge
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Hersfeld Zehntverzeichnis (No. 122). Seat of a ministerial family in the 14th century.

Name: Delitzsch
Alternative_Name: Delce; Dielitz; Delz; Delschs; Deltz; Delczsch
Settlement_Description: The German Settlement probably had a Slavic predecessor. First written mention in 1200 in the name "Hermannus in Delicz". In 1207 a rural assisze town ('Gerichtsstätte') is mentioned.
Town_Description: Delitzsch became a town not before the second half of the 13th century, market- and town rights were probably granted around the same time. It is first referred to as town in 1306. In 1376 a (new?) town hall was constructed.
Toll_Description: The surviving regulations of safe conduct in Delitzsch are copies from 1668, but they were written in the 16th century.

Name: Delligsen
Alternative_Name: Dysieldeshusen; Diseldashusen; Disaldeshusen; Dysileshusun; Dislessem; Diselisseim; Diseldeshem; Disildesheim; Deselitz; Deselitzen; Deseldissen; Desseldissen; Diseldesem; Diseldissem
Settlement_Description: An inn is mentioned in Delligsen in 1567.
Toll_Description: A "minor" toll in Delligsen on the street between Alfeld and Höxter/Uslar is mentioned in 1548, where it is specified that it is levied only on hops (4 pounds for each wagonload), pikes brought from Uslar to Hildesheim (1/2 pound per bundle) and on horses bought on the market (2 pounds each). The total revenues are estimated at 8 or 9 guilders in good years. The toll is reiterated in 1567 and 1587.

Name: Delmenhorst
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed in the 13th century next to a castle of the counts of Oldenburg. The castle is first mentioned in 1254, the settlement in 1285.
Town_Description: Acquisition of Bremen town privileges in 1371. However, until the 17th century, the settlement is often characterised as borough ('flecken').
Toll_Description: The toll in Delmenhorst is first mentioned in the town privileges of 1371. The count of Oldenburg ceded the toll to the town of Bremen in 1380. Bremen citizens were exempted from the toll in 1461.

Name: Demmin
Town_Description: founded, Lübeck town law ratified in 1292 and 1681

Name: Den Hoorn
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1611.

Name: Den Hout
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1311.

Name: Dendermonde
Alternative_Name: Thenremonde; Thenremunde; Tenremont; Teneramunda; Tenremonde; Denremunde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1088.

Name: Denekamp
Alternative_Name: Daginghem; Danigheim; Degheninchem: Degeningen; Dechnykem; Degenikken; Denecham; Degenkamp
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the late tenth century, another mention in the twelfth century.

Name: Denklingen
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll here in 1435. More precise tariffs or revenues have not been preserved.

Name: Dennewitz
Settlement_Description: The settlement is known since 1174 and was part of the initial property of Zinna monastery.

Name: Denstorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022.

Name: Depekolk
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1319.

Name: Derben
Settlement_Description: Mention as Derwen at the end of the 14th century.

Name: Derenburg
Alternative_Name: Thaeremburch; Turneburc; Tarneburg; Darneburg; Deherneburc; Derrenburk
Settlement_Description: In the 10th and 12th century, a castle (Derenburg), which was erected in 925 by Henry I., constituted the centre of the settlement. The castle was destroyed in 1126 and the following village settled in its place.
Town_Description: A year or date of the awarding of town rights is unknown. The village is referred to as civitas in 1289, however.

Name: Dersum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000.

Name: Dessau
Settlement_Description: In the Early Middle Ages Dessau probably was a Wendish fishing village. First mention in a record in 1213. Dessau was a market place in the 12th century.
Town_Description: Since 1382 Dessau was referred to as town and was granted Magdeburg rights. An exact date of the awarding of the town rights is not known.
Toll_Description: The safe conduct was calculated by the horses that pulled a wagon. If someone had loaded herrings and crossed the Mulde river, this person had to pay an additional fee per ton of herring. In 1549 four road tolls and safe conducts are mentioned and the former method of raising fees confirmed.
Staple_Description: Each raft loaded with lumber or planks had to anchor on the Elbe river at Dessau for "three sunshines". In 1549 this staple right is mentioned again in the regulations of safe conduct.
Fair_Description: A third fair is prevented in the town of Dessau in 1573 due to protests of Leipzig.

Name: Destelbergen
Alternative_Name: Thesle; Thisla; Texla; Descelberge; Dessle; Descelberghe; Desselberge
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention probably 962, in middle eleventh century copy. Next mention in 964. Next mention 1119, in a first kwart of the thirteenth century copy.

Name: Detern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1409. The settlement is characterised as borough ('flecken') in the late 16th century.
Toll_Description: Around 1599, the count of East Frisia introduced a toll connected to the fair in Detern. This led to complaints from Oldenburg in 1602, after which the Imperial Chamber Court ruled that the toll was to be discontinued. After repeated complaints, a document from 1641 attest the discontinuation of the toll.
Fair_Description: In ca. 1596, count Edzard of East Frisia granted a fair in Detern. A date is not mentioned.

Name: Detfurth
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 12th century.

Name: Detmold
Alternative_Name: Theotmalli; Theotmelli; Thiotmellie; Teotmola; Thietmalli; Thiatmelli; Tietmelle; Thiadmelli; Detmele; Detmule; Depmolde; Dytmolde; Deiphmolte; Dethmeldia; Deithmolth; Dithmal; Dittmolden
Settlement_Description: Around 783 mentioned as a court place or 'locus'. The settlement is first named around 1263.
Town_Description: The city was founded around 1265 by the noblemen zur Lippe, accordingly, it received the Lippstadt city law. From 1357 it is listed as a city.

Name: Deuna
Settlement_Description: First mention 1162.

Name: Deurningen
Alternative_Name: Thornengen; Dorninge; Doerninghe; Doerningen; Doerninghe; Dornige; Doirningen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Thornengen' in 1295.

Name: Iława
Alternative_Name: Deutsch Eylau; Ylavia; Ylaw; Ilow theutonicalis
Settlement_Description: There are traces of pre-Teutonic Order settlements close to the town
Town_Description: Founded in 1305 by Sieghard von Schwarzburg, the komtur of Christburg, new handfast granted in 1317 by Luther von Braunschweig, the Komtur of Christburg, the founding documents were expanded in 1333 by Günther von Schwarzburg, Kulm town law was granted

Name: Wałcz
Alternative_Name: Deutsch Krone; Areskrone; Theutsche Krone; Chrone; Walcia; Arnscrone; Theutzsche Krone; Crone; Wolcz; Welcz
Settlement_Description: Originally a slavic fishing town (Walcz) with the castle of a starost.
Town_Description: Founding documents were given in 1303 by the ascanian margraves Otto, Konrad, Johann und Waldemar von Brandenburg. The locators were the knights Ulrich Schöning and Rudolf Liebenthal. The documents were endorsed multiple times by the polish kings.

Name: Deutz
Toll_Description: In 1386, the Archbishop of Cologne levied a transhipment toll on goods unloaded from the ship. A fee of 4 pfennigs was charged for a barrel of wine or per wagon. Unfortunately, annual revenues have not been preserved.

Name: Deventer
Alternative_Name: Dauentre; Deuentre; Dauentria; Davantria; Devendre; Daventre
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 840-849 (in a copy from around 1000). Next mention is a copy from 1222 of document from 893
Town_Description: In 956, Deventer is called a town ('urbs'); in 960 Deventer is called a 'civitas'. In 1123, Holy Roman Emperor Henry V granted a privilege to the town ('stad') of Deventer. Successive bishops of Utrecht will probably have granted additional town privileges which resulted in the town privileges granted to Zwolle in 1230.

Name: Dibbesdorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned ca. 1226

Name: Dieckhorst
Alternative_Name: Dichhorst; Dykhorst; Dickhorst; Dighorst; Diickhorst; Dyckhorst; Dichorst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1433. A castle (first mentioned in 1479), later a manor, was located on the left shore of the Aller. On the opposite shore a settlement developed.

Name: Diedenshausen
Alternative_Name: Didinshusen; Dudinshusen; Didenshusen; Diedentzhußen; Dientshausen; Dietenshausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1237.

Name: Diekholzen
Settlement_Description: The first mention dates back to the 11th century.

Name: Meinbecker Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower, erected in 1479 as part of the "Neue Landwehr" (new defensive line) east of Lüneburg. The tower guarded the place where the road crossed the little creek Dieksbeck with a little bridge or ford. The road was barred by a chain and would only have been opened by the guard. There was a well between two houses. The whole area was protected by palisades. Probably given up before 1580. In 1774, the place is still marked as "alte Thurm" (old tower) on the map of the Kurhannoversche Landesaufnahme.

Name: Diemarden
Alternative_Name: Timertha; Dimerthan; Thimarda; Dimerthin; Dimerda; Dymerden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022.

Name: Diepenheim
Alternative_Name: Dipenhem; Deepnaham; Difenhem; Depenhem; Depenham; Deepnem; Dypenem; Dijepenhem; Diepenem; Diepenum; Diepenhem; Dyepenhem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1134.
Town_Description: Earliest mention of Diepenheim as a town on 14 June 1379. Town privileges were possibly granted by the bishop of Utrecht as lord of Diepenheim between circa 1340 and 1379.

Name: Diepholz
Alternative_Name: Thifholt; Thyefholt; Depholte; Defholte; Diepholt; Deipholt; Deipholte; Deypholte; Diepholtz
Settlement_Description: Between 1120 und 1160, the castle Diepholz was built, which protected the settlement next to it and gave it its name. The settlement is characterised as "oppidum" in 1356.
Town_Description: Town privileges of Osnabrück were granted by lord Johann of Diepholz in 1380. They were only partially confirmed in 1655 by the Duchy of Brunswick-Lüneburg, whereupon Diepholz was degraded to the status of borough ('flecken').
Fair_Description: Diepholz acquired the right to hold two fairs in 1525, on three days before and after St Dionysius and Our Lady. In 1577, they were replaced by two new cattle fairs, on Monday after Palm Sunday and the day after St Matthew. In 1614, only the fair on St Matthew still existed.

Name: Dieren
Alternative_Name: Theothorne; Diederne; Thiedere; Diderin; Diedirn; Thederen; Dideren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 838, in a eleventh century copy.

Name: Diermen
Alternative_Name: Diramme; Dirhamme; Direm; Dyrmen; Dirm; Dyermen
Settlement_Description: Dispersed settlement ('buurschap'), first mentioned around 1250.

Name: Diersbüttel
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1302.

Name: Diesdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1112; in 1161 foundation of a monastery of Augustinians, which is converted into a worldly chapter of nuns in 1551.

Name: Dieskau
Settlement_Description: The lords of Dieskau gain Dieskau as a fiefdom around 1200.

Name: Diest
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 837. Next mention in 900, in a thirteenth-century copy. The following mention in 1114, in a copy from the mid-twelfth century..

Name: Dieteren
Alternative_Name: Dithirn; Ditheren; Dithern; Diethern; Ditren; Dytheren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1213.

Name: Dietkirchen
Settlement_Description: The settlement probably goes back to a Bronze Age settlement, which was probably already fortified. In the 6th century a monastery and a church developed. The collegiate monastery St. Lubentius is mentioned for the first time in 841.
Toll_Description: The Count of Katzenelnbogen levied a toll here in 1445. It is not precisely recorded whether it was really a land toll - but it is probable. Tariffs are not known. The annual revenue in 1445/46 was ½ gulden and 13½ heller.

Name: Dillenburg
Alternative_Name: Dillenberg; Tyllinberg; Diellinberg; Dillemburch; Dylnberg; Tylnberg; Dillemburg; Dilleburg; Dillemerk; Dellmerig; Dilleburk
Settlement_Description: The place was based around the castle founded in 1240, which was on the long-distance trade route Frankfurt-Siegen-Cologne
Town_Description: Was granted town privileges in 1344.

Name: Dilschhausen
Alternative_Name: Tulheshusen; Dileshusen; superior Dylshvsen; Tyleshusen; Oberndielszhusen; Dielshausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 780 and 802. In 1259 called 'villa'.

Name: Dingelstädt
Settlement_Description: The first mention of the settlement can be placed at the beginning of the 9th century, which is preserved in a copy of a record from 1150. Since 1309 place of trial ('Gerichtsort'). In the Late Middle Ages market borough ('Marktflecken'). Lifted to the status of town only in 1859.
Fair_Description: The privilege for two fairs is granted in 1607 by emperor Rudolf II, after Dingelstädt had requested market privileges since 1560. In 1662 Dingelstädt is granted a third and fourth fair, after the economy had been completely destroyed during the 30-year war.

Name: Dingeringhausen
Alternative_Name: Thincherdinchusun; Dingerindinghusen; Dincernchusen; Dingrikusin; dingerinchosen; Dingerchusen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1028 and 1036.

Name: Dingstede
Settlement_Description: The settlement was mentioned in 1249.

Name: Dinklar
Alternative_Name: Dinklere; Thinkelar; Thinkelere; Thynkelere; Thinglare; Dhinkelere; Dinghler; Dynckelere
Settlement_Description: Probably first mentioned in 924.

Name: Dinslaken
Toll_Description: The Count of the Mark levied a land toll in 1397. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Dissen
Alternative_Name: Dissen am Teutoburger Wald; Tissene; Dissene; Disnam; Dissine
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 895. The settlement is characterised as 'oppidum' in 1284, 1556 as borough ('wigbold').

Name: Ditterke
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1208.

Name: Ditzum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Döbeln
Fair_Description: In the 16th century, there was a cattle market in Döbeln, which held some meaning for the Middle German region as well as the Erzgebirge. In the middle of the 16th century, tolls were raised in the electorate of Saxony and the Habsburg area and the electorate of Saxony was avoided by cattle traders, which led to concerns that the fair might decline.

Name: Bad Doberan
Alternative_Name: Tabrahn; Doberan; Dobrum; Dobbran; DubbraanDoberam; Dobran; Dobrane

Name: Dobele
Settlement_Description: The 'Semgallenburg' (castle) was conquered by the Teutonic Order in 1289. The order built a new castle in 1335. In 1444 a fortfied borough ('Hakelwerk') was mentioned.

Name: Dobra
Alternative_Name: Dabern; Dobern; Dasdra; Taber; Daberr; Doberen
Settlement_Description: The castle Daber is built on top of a 10-12 ct. castle mound. The settlement is first mentioned as castrum in 1295.
Town_Description: The exact date of the founding with Lübeck town law is unknown, it was first mentioned as a town in 1331 and in 1336 as a villa. The founding was confirmed in 1461.

Name: Doberlug
Alternative_Name: Dobrilugk; Dobraluh; Dobralug; Doberluch; Dobriluh; Dobirlug; Doberlugk
Settlement_Description: Rally-point of King Henry's II. troops against the Polish in 1005. In 1165 a Cistercian monastery is founded. In 1624 the monastery is mostly decayed and it is reconstructed into a castle.

Name: Dodendorf
Settlement_Description: Mention in a record by Otto II. in which estates are exchanged between the monastery of Fulda and the archbishop Adalbert of Magdeburg (MGH DD OII, nr. 64, S. 74-77).

Name: Doesburg
Alternative_Name: Dusburg; Dosburg; Doesborg; Doysburg; Doesborch; Doesborch
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1025.
Town_Description: Earliest mention as oppidum probably in 1204 or 1230. Granting of town privileges on 19 September 1237 by Otto II, count of Guelders.
Fair_Description: Between 1294/95 and at least 1543, Doesburg had two fairs.

Name: Doetinchem
Alternative_Name: Ductinghem; Duttinghem; Duttencheim;Dutthinchem; Duttinchem; Duttincheim; Duttinghem; Dutthekem; Doetekem; Dotechem; Deutekom; Dutinghem; Doetekum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 838.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted after 22 October 1229 and before 11 November 1231, by Otto II, count of Guelders and Zutphen.
Fair_Description: Doetinchem had at least since 1294/95 a fair on St. Catharine’s Day (25 November). The duration of this fair is unknown.

Name: Döhle
Alternative_Name: Tole; Dolethe; Dolede; Dolde; Dole; Doelde; Doll; Doel; Döle; Doehle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1135.

Name: Dohna
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Pirna.

Name: Döhren
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1042.

Name: Döhren
Alternative_Name: Thurnithi; Thornithe; Dornede; Dorrenten; Dornede; Dornde
Settlement_Description: Year of first mention was 990.

Name: Döhren
Settlement_Description: First mention in the 13th century.

Name: Dokkum
Alternative_Name: Dockinga; Docken; Dockum; Tochingen; Dockingam; Tochkingen; Doccinga; Dockinge; Dochem; Docking; Doccum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as a settlement existing in 754 in a fourteenth-century copy of an early ninth century document.
Town_Description: First mentioned as a town on 8 March 1298.

Name: Dölitz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as manor, since 1451 knightly manor.

Name: Dollern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in possession of the monastery Katlenburg in a charter from 1105. Earlier settlement since before 800 can be assumed.

Name: Dömitz
Alternative_Name: Dumeliz; Domeliz; Domelitz; Domaliz; Domenitz; Dömnitz; Domptz; Domptze; Dämz; Dömitz; Dömiz; Döms
Settlement_Description: Originally a Slavic castle and settlement, known from the end of the 12th century. A priest is first mentioned in Dömitz in 1230.
Town_Description: Dömitz is first characterised as civitas in 1259. The Lübeck town law was granted by the dukes of Dannenberg and confirmed in 1505. The town was reconstructed as a fortress in 1559-65.
Toll_Description: A toll in Dömitz is first mentioned in 1237. A toll on the Elbe of the dukes of Lüneburg in Dömitz and nearby Wehningen is clearly mentioned in 1372, when they were transferred to the duke of Mecklenburg. The river toll was specified at 4 Gulden, 1 rye bread, 1 loaf of bread and 2 buns for each passing ship in 1492. Toll registers exist for many years from 1431 onwards; these have been analysed by Nissen. A road toll was levied as well, as becomes clear from a report from 1688, in which it is stated that the road toll was levied at the mill Findenwirunshier when the road to Dömitz was flooded, which happened regularly.

Name: Dommelen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1297, in a eighteenth century copy.

Name: Dommitzsch
Alternative_Name: Dumoz; Domuki; Thumvuz; Domuts; Domeniz; Damucz
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wettin in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig.

Name: Domnovo
Settlement_Description: A castle of the Teutonic Order was mentioned in 1324, a settlement grew close to the castle hill, but the castle itself was destroyed in 1460
Town_Description: First granted town law in 1400, mentioned as a town for the first time in 1427, the handfast was renewed by Konrad von Egloffstein in 1480 with Kulm town law

Name: Domnitz
Settlement_Description: In 1137 a monastery farmyard ('Klosterhof') was founded in Domnitz, showing that the settlement already existed earlier.

Name: Dongen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1288, in a copy dating from 1349.

Name: Dönges
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1222.

Name: Dodewaard
Alternative_Name: Doordewaard; Dodeuuero; Dodewero; Dudenwert; Dondenwerhe; Dudenwerthe; Dudenwerde; Doodewaardt; Doywaert
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from the late eleventh century.

Name: Doorn
Alternative_Name: Thorhem; Thornen; Darnen; Dornen; Doerne; Dorne; Doern; Doren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 918-948, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1126, in a falsification which probably dates from the twelfth century.

Name: Doornspijk
Alternative_Name: Thornspiic; Thornspic; Dorenspic; Dorenspiic; Dornspijck; Doerspyck; Doornspijc; Doorspeet; Doorspeeth
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 796, in a tenth century copy.

Name: Dordrecht
Alternative_Name: Thuredrith; Thuredrit; Thuredrech; Durthric; Thurdrecht; Durdreth; Dordreth; Dordreecht; Dojrdre
Settlement_Description: The first mention of Dordrecht dates from 1064, in a falsified copy from the first quarter of the twelfth century. The next mention dates from about 1151-1155.
Town_Description: Dordrecht was granted town rights in July 1220 by William I, count of Holland. However, it is probable that Dordrecht already held town(-like) privileges before 1200. In 1200, Dordrecht is mentioned as 'oppidum' and as 'stede'.
Toll_Description: Exemption from tolls for Easterlings in 1313 who brought their wares directly to Dordrecht (HUB 2:232); preferable tariffs for Hanse merchants in 1358 and between 1388-1392 while the Kontor in Bruges was displaced.
Staple_Description: Count John of Holland established a staple market for oats in 1298, which was extended to all commodities on Merwede and Lek in 1299, confirmed in 1304. From 1388 compulsory market for all ships coming from the east to the Maas. Staple for Rhine whine of eight days in 1324, which became a general wine staple in 1401. The staple obligations became hard to enforce after the St Elizabeth's flood (1421), after which Dordrecht became located on an island, making it easier to bypass the city. In 1441, commodities coming downstream with destinations elsewhere had to be transferred to other ships, but did not have to be offered for sale any more. Hanseatic staple for Rhenish wines in 1452, together with Antwerp. Staple for wine and salt for Holland and Friesland in 1453. In the 16th century, there were growing conflicts with other cities about the staple, which led to Middelburg being freed from staple obligations in Dordrecht in 1533. The staple was still confirmed by the emperor in 1540, but restricted in the following year: only corn, legumes, salt, wine, lime, coal, millstones and iron transported on Lek, Merwede and Maas had to be brought to Dordrecht. Despite ever growing conflicts and violations of the staple, it remained in place until 1670.

Name: Dorfmark
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1006.

Name: Dormagen
Settlement_Description: The settlement has been documented since Roman times.
Toll_Description: 1) The Duke of Jülich levied land toll and fee for save land conduct here from 1389. The escort money was collected by a special servant in the 15th century, so that toll and escort money existed independently of each other. Depending on the load, 2 to 3 white pfennigs per horse were collected as fee for save conduct. In 1389/93, an average of about 623 marks per year was collected. In 1398/99 it was about 420 marks. 2) In addition, the duke levied road toll in 1434, which was collected by a publican. In 1495, the tariff was 1 light shilling per wagon.

Name: Dornburg
Settlement_Description: Settlement grows out of a Karolingian castle at the border to Slawia in the 9th century. In the 10th/11th century royal court with village.
Town_Description: In the course of the 13th century, Dornburg developed into a town with Saxonian rights. Referred to as town ('stat') in 1343.

Name: Dörnhagen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1253, in 1303 called a 'villa'. 1346 probably desolate.

Name: Dörnholthausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1272.

Name: Dörnigheim
Alternative_Name: Turincheim; Turingeheim; Thurincheim; Dorenheim; Durnkeim; Durinkeym; Duringheim; Dörnigheim

Name: Dornitz
Settlement_Description: In 1484 Dornitz is sold to the lords of Ammendorf by the archbishopric of Magdeburg. Before it was owned by the counts of Alsleben.

Name: Tartu
Settlement_Description: The Russians conquered the Estonian settlement in 1030. The castle was then expanded. In 1224-34 the German conquerors built a new castle that served as the centre of the diocese.
Town_Description: In 1248 the town received Riga town rights and also became a member of the Hanseatic League.
Staple_Description: A privilege of King Sigismund III obliged every Russian travelling on his way to Livonian ports to offer his wares for sale in Dorpat for four days. Foreing merchants wishing to trade in Russia obliged to travel via Dorpat.

Name: Dörpen
Alternative_Name: Dorpun; Thorpun; Dorpen; Dorbun; Drope; Drop
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 890.
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Münster in Dörpen is mentioned in 1576, when it could not be leased. Likewise, in 1645 a toll collector could not be found as revenues had decreased due to the Thirty Years' War.

Name: Dorstadt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1110.

Name: Dorste
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1015.

Name: Dorsten
Alternative_Name: Durstinon; Durstina; Dorstene; Durstene; Durstine; Dorstenium
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 889/890.
Town_Description: The Cologne archbishop Konrad von Hochstaden awarded Dorsten the town privileges of Dortmund on June 1, 1251
Toll_Description: 1) The archbishop of Cologne confirmed the river toll in Dorsten that his predecessor had introduced in 1332. The toll was divided into two parts in 1334: one part belonged to the archbishop, the other part to the town. The toll was raised from 1 Rader albus to 1/2 Taler in 1557, despite many protests. Citizens from Dorsten only had to pay the old fee of 1 Rader albus after 1577. More exact toll tariffs are known from 1625. 2) The Archbishop of Cologne also levied a bridge toll in 1371.

Name: Dortmund
Alternative_Name: Throtmanni; Trutmania; Thortmanni; Trutmenni; Drudmunde; Drotmanni; Throtmennia; Thrutminensis; Drutmunne; Drodminne; Trotmenni; Trutmundi; Trutmonia; Thertmanni; Therotmanni; Thertamanni; Trotmannin; Drodmannia; Drotmannia; Dredmonna; Trutimanni; Trytemanni; Trytemanne; Trutemanne; Trudimonia; Trotmanni; Thrutmannia; Trutmannin; Trotmannii; Drutmunne; Tremunge; Tramonia; Tremoigne; Dritmunden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 880 and 890. The origins of the settlement are unknown. 939 it is called 'urbs' and in 979 'oppidum'.
Town_Description: The exact date when the town was established is unknown. But the earliest recods of granted privileges were between 1138 and 1152. Dortmund was an imperial town.
Toll_Description: Both the county of Dortmund and the city of Dortmund levied a land toll in 1074. In 1241, half of the fees and the county itself, then in 1431 completely, fell to the town of Dortmund. According to the tariffs of 1330/40, fees were only levied in February and from the end of March to the end of April. 1330/40 resulted in a tariff of 4 pfennigs per wine carriage (detailed tariff: RÜBEL, Urkundenbuch II, no. 456). In 1390 an annual yield of 9 marks 10 shillings, in 1391 one of 10 marks and 7½ shillings and in 1392 one of 11 marks and 12 pfennigs could be achieved. For further yields see source.

Name: Dösen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1305 as Dosene (PL).

Name: Drawsko Pomorskie
Alternative_Name: Dramburg; Drawnborch, Dravinburg; Drauenburg; Drahenburg; Dramborch; Dramborgh; Dramburch
Settlement_Description: A settlement grew around the old wendish castle mound.
Town_Description: The Margraves of Brandenburg, Otto IV, Konrad and his children, granted the right to occupy the hamlet to the knight Arnold von Goltzen and his brothers in 1297

Name: Dranse
Settlement_Description: In 1233 property in Dranse is given to Amerlunxborn monastery. The monastery sells its property in 1430.

Name: Drantum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 11th century.

Name: Draschwitz
Settlement_Description: First mention as Droschenitz.

Name: Drebkau
Settlement_Description: Probably first mention as Trebetz in 1301, first secure mention as Drebekowe in 1353.

Name: Dreeßel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1366.

Name: Dreilingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1296 and 1297.

Name: Drelsdorf
Alternative_Name: Trelstorp; Trelstrup; Trölstrup; Threlstrup; Drelstorpp; Trelstorp; Drelstorp; Drelstorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1352.

Name: Drempt
Alternative_Name: Thremete; Thremethe; Thrimethe; Drimethe; Dremethe; Dromthe; Dreemt; Dremp; Dremt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention 1122.

Name: Drensteinfurt
Alternative_Name: Stenvorde in regione Dreni; Stenforda; Steinuorde; Stenvordia super Drenum; Drenstenvorde; Dreynstenvorde

Name: Dresden
Settlement_Description: The town developed from a Sorbian port settlement; by c. 1150 there was fortress with a settlement.
Town_Description: Niemeyer dates the town’s foundation to 1200/1210; town fortifications existed in 1216. Today’s Dresden-Neustadt to the north was buit in the 17th century.
Toll_Description: The regulations of safe conduct recorded in 1716 are a copy of the regulations from 1547. They also include land and water safe conduct regulations from 1630.
Staple_Description: In 1455, Elector Frederick II of Saxony moved the staple right of Brüx (Most), which had been conquered by Bohemia, to Dresden. Salt, fish, honey and other commodities which were transported through Saxony to Bohemia, had to be offered for sale in Dresden. However, enforcing merchants to travel through Dresden proved to be difficult, and the road via Freiberg was still often used. The staple was confirmed in 1603, with special mention of corn and wood for the supply of the town.

Name: Bad Driburg
Alternative_Name: Driburg; Driburch; Triborg; Triborch; Dreyburgh; Iburg
Settlement_Description: Bishop Simon I. zur Lippe of Paderborn founded the settlement in the middle of the 13th century.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted in 1290. 1345 they got approved.

Name: Driebergen
Alternative_Name: Driebergen-Rijsenburg; Thriberge; Thribergen; Drieberghen; Drij bergen; Risenborch; Risenborgh; Rysenborch, Rysenburgh; Rijsenburch
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Thriberge(n)' in 1159, in a falsification which probably dates from the fourteenth century. Near the village stood the castle Rijsenburg, first mentioned in 1270. After the castle was demolished in 1809, a new village with the name Rijsenburg was founded, which was merged with Driebergen in 1931.

Name: Driehausen
Alternative_Name: Thrihusen; tribus domibus; Driyhusen; Drighusen; Dreyhuis; Dreihausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1182 as separate settlement. From the 16th century, it was considered a part of Schwagstorf.

Name: Drezdenko
Alternative_Name: Driesen; Drdzn; Drzn; Dssinia, Drisen; Drizina; Drecen; Dreden; Driessen; Dersen; Droczen; Dirzen; Drezen; Dirczen; Driesen; Drysen; Drieczen; Drysden; Drezdenko; Ossina
Settlement_Description: The castrum Drzn was first mentioned as a polish castle complex in 1092, it later belonged to the castellan, the surrounding area was settled by Slavs.
Town_Description: Was first mentioned as a town in letters from 1317, later in 1373 it was called castrum et oppidum Drisen and in 1526 was mentioned as Stad and Stedichen.

Name: Ośno Lubuskie
Settlement_Description: the basis was an old settlement, later a german market settlement, a subsequent addition eastwards with two markets was made
Town_Description: Founded in 1252 by the bishop of Lebus, was a long standing civitas forensis and a market town

Name: Drouwen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1381-1383.

Name: Drüber
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1235.

Name: Drögenbostel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1275.

Name: Dzelda
Settlement_Description: In 1253 the Celde manor belonged to the bishop.

Name: Bad Düben
Settlement_Description: In Asorbic times a fishing and boatmen's village; in the 10th century castle and castle district ('Burgward') of the margraves and corresponding castle borough ('Burgflecken'); after 1200 construction and extension of the town (end of the 15th century).
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct in between Wittenberg and Leipzig.

Name: Düderode
Settlement_Description: A falsified charter from the 16th century contains a first mention for the year 935.

Name: Duderstadt
Settlement_Description: King Henry II donated property in Duderstadt to his wife Mathilde in 927 and 929. This royal farm - later mentioned as ducal farm - was located around the current St Servatius's church. East of it, around the current Gropenmarkt, a market settlement developed.
Town_Description: First privileges are attested in 1247; the first town seal in 1255. The Brunswick town privileges were confirmed by duke Henry the Admirable of Brunswick-Grubenhagen in 1279.
Fair_Description: Duderstadt had 4 fairs, the dates of which are unknown. In 1638, they were extended with horse and cattle fairs.

Name: Duisburg
Settlement_Description: The settlement dates back to Roman times. Later it was a Frankish royal residence, which was first mentioned when it was plundered by Vikings in 883. It was enlarged to a royal palace in the 10th century.
Town_Description: Due to its location on the Rhine, Duisburg developed rapidly into a merchant centre that assumed an urban character around 1100. The town wall dates from 1129. After the Rhine changed its course after 1200 and the Rhine arm on which Duisburg was located silted up, the town gradually lost its position as primary trade centre.
Toll_Description: 1) A river toll on the Rhine was levied here from 1184 to 1348/52. The toll changed hands frequently. Until 1248 it was held by the Empire, from 1248 to 1280 by Duke Walram of Limburg, from 1280 to 1288 by Count Renald of Geldern and from 1290 by the Count of Kleve. In addition, a (fair) market toll, which also applied to ships, has been documented since 1065. The Rhine toll was transferred to Kaiserwerth in 1348 by Count Gerhard von Berg. At the same time, the Count of Kleve continued to levy toll until he moved it to Büderich in 1352. The tariff in 1348 was 6 Turnosgroschen. 2) A land toll was also levied from 1280 onwards.
Staple_Description: Uncertain: a "jus stapulae" in Duisburg is first mentioned only in 1708, when it is moved to Wesel because of changes in the course of the Rhine. A charter of Duke Walram IV of Limburg from 1273 allows citizens of Cologne to transport their commodities unhindered through Duisburg, indicating that the town already claimed some kind of staple privileges in that period.

Name: Duiven
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 838, in an eleventh century copy.

Name: Dülken
Toll_Description: The Duke of Jülich levied a road toll in 1387. In 1517 the annual revenue was 5 marks.

Name: Dülmen
Alternative_Name: Dulmenni; Dulmene; Dulmen; Dulminni; Dulmine; Dulmannia; Dulmoniensis; Dullmene; Sutdulmene
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 889.
Town_Description: In 1311 the settlement got granted town privileges of Munster.

Name: Düna
Alternative_Name: Dunede; Donde; Dune; Duena; Dunaw; Duhna
Settlement_Description: Abandoned between 1337 and 1372, with the exception of a manor; resettled in 1935.

Name: Daugavpils
Settlement_Description: Daugavpils was founded by the Russians in 1577, after they had destroyed the old castle and town of Dünaburg, 20 km upstream.

Name: Vecdaugava
Settlement_Description: Bishop Albert founded a Cistercian monastery on the right bank of the Düna in 1202. This was built in 1205-1208. Over time it was expanded into a fortress. In 1305 the Teutonic Order bought it.

Name: Dünebroek
Settlement_Description: Monastery of the Knights Hospitaller, founded before 1319. It was abolished in 1529, although the first Protestant service in the church only took place around 1550; the former monastic property was leased in 1580. The buildings were still extant in a dilapidated state in the 17th century; they were demolished in 1810.

Name: Dungelbeck
Alternative_Name: Dvngerbichi; Dungerbeke; Dungerbeche; Dunkerbeke; Dungelbeke; Dinghewecke; Dingelbecke
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1053.

Name: Dunkelforth
Toll_Description: Hunting lodge and toll station

Name: Dünnwald
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in 1487. The tariff was 3 white pfennigs per ohm of wine or per horse with dry goods.

Name: Durbe
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1230 and fell under control of the Teutonic Order in 1253. In the 15th century a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built, which burned down in 1435.

Name: Düshop
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1383.

Name: Düshorn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1227.

Name: Düsseldorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1135
Town_Description: Town privileges granted by the counts of Berg in 1288.
Toll_Description: 1) The Duke of Berg levied a river toll on the Rhine in 1374/77. In 1380, 6 turnosgroschen were collected per foder of wine. In 1386, it was 12 Turnosgroschen per foder of wine. For more detailed tariffs and yields, see source. In 1427 the annual yield was about 6782 gulden, in 1428 about 4810 gulden and in 1429 5507 gulden. 2) In 1398/99 the Duke of Berg levied a fee for free conduct on the river. Rates and revenues have not been preserved. 3) The duke also levied a land toll in 1476. 4) In 1395 he levied a road toll. One shilling had to be paid per carriage with heavy goods such as wine, fish or cloth.

Name: Dützen
Settlement_Description: Probably first mentioned between 1080/1085 and 1095.

Name: Ebeleben
Settlement_Description: In 1198 a noble family of Ebeleben is mentioned. It is only later mentioned as a settlement. The village only became a town in 1928.

Name: Ebendorf
Settlement_Description: Mentions in 950 and 965 when the tithe in Ebendorf is given to St. Moritz' monastery in Magdeburg. Since 1363 the counts of Falkenstein hold some of their judgement days ('Dingtage') in Ebendorf.

Name: Eberswalde
Alternative_Name: Neustadt a.d. Finow; Everswolde; Euersvolde; Neustadt-Eberswalde; Everswalde; Neustadt Everswalde; Nystadt; Newenstade; Nuwenstad Eberswald; Nyenstad alias Ewerswald; Ewerswalde; seu nova civitas
Settlement_Description: Many stone and bronze age findings as well as a wendish castle mound, a german margravial castle was mentioned in 1261 and a german settlement close to it that later became a part of a market settlement, it was first mentioned in 1276, a church was mentioned in 1294 and a merchant house in 1300
Town_Description: Margrave Albrecht III. sets dues and taxes for the then called civitas in 1300, it was probably made a town shortly before that

Name: Ebstorf
Alternative_Name: Ebbikesdorp; Ebbekestorp; Ebbekesthorpe; Ebekisdorp; Ebechestorp; Ebbikistorp; Hebbicstorpe; Nyenebbekestorpe; Ebkestorpe; Ebbstorp; Ebstorp
Settlement_Description: Around 1160 the first founding of a Premonstratensian monastery in Ebstorf is presumed. A second foundation probably took place in 1190, when Benedictine nuns from Walsrode moved to Ebstorf. The monastery owned land in the surrounding villages and parts of the saltworks in Lüneburg (mentioned in 1224). In 1565 the monastery became Protestant.

Name: Echt
Alternative_Name: Ehti; Eitha; Ehtá; Ehta; Eichta; Echte; Egth; Egthe
Settlement_Description: The first mention of Echt dates from 950. This document, however, is a forgery (possibly from the tenth century). The subsequent mention dates from 1050.
Town_Description: No official town right charter for Echt is known to exist (or have existed). However, by 18 August 1494, Echt is mention as a town. If town rights were granted officially, this was possibly done by Charles II, duke of Guelders (from the House of Egmond).

Name: Echte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 8th or 9th century.

Name: Echten
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1245, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Eckartsberga
Settlement_Description: In the 10th century a castle was erected on the Sachsenberg which had a village attached that developed into a borough ('Flecken') in the 12th and 13th century. At the end of the 12th century, the "castrum Eckchardesberc" is first mentioned.
Town_Description: Probably between 1265 and 1292 Eckartsberga gained town rights, possibly in 1288 as reimbursment for resigning its church to the monastery of St. Moritz.
Toll_Description: A safe conduct is known since 1291. Toll station for the main safe conduct by Sachsenburg. One of the oldest stations of safe conduct on the via regia, sources that show the income of safe conduct end in 1485. Regulations of safe conduct from 1550 have survived.
Fair_Description: Since 1431 two fairs are known. In the regulations of safe conduct of 1550, two fairs are mentioned. They were moved to Easter and St. Michael's day later.

Name: Eckendorf
Toll_Description: A land toll was levied here in 1194. The Count of Are/Neuenahr was initially the owner. From 1446/47 it was the Archbishop of Cologne. The annual yield was approx. 6 gulden in 1446/47.

Name: Viesīte
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1526.

Name: Eckernförde
Alternative_Name: Ekerenvorde; Ekelenbergh; Ekelenforde; Egernførde; Ekenevorde; Eckerneuorde; Ekorenvorde; Eklenforde; Ekellenforde; Eckelnfordenn; Eckelnförde
Settlement_Description: Grew out of a fishermens settlement on a sand reef. In the first few years mentioned in the context of the castle Ykaerneburg belonging to "Godescalcus de Ekerenvorde", and "Nikolaus de Ekerenvorde".
Town_Description: Systematically planned town of the 13th century, first mentioned as a town in 1302. King Christian III of Denmark confirmed the Schleswig town privileges in 1543.

Name: Eckhorst
Settlement_Description: Manor in posession of Lübeck citizens. An inn is mentioned in 1447.

Name: Eddelstorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1160.

Name: Edersleben
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Breviarium sancti Lulli in the 8th/9th century.

Name: Eeklo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1220, in a seventeenth century kopie.

Name: Eersel
Alternative_Name: Eresloch; Ereslohc; Ersele; Erslo; Ersle; Irsele; Eersele; Yerssele; Eerssele; Yerssel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 712- 713, in a copy dating from 1191. Next mention in 1102-1105, in a twelfth century copy.

Name: Eext
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1309.

Name: Egeln
Settlement_Description: In the 9th century a castle was constructed by Henry I. which was the centre of a burgward settlement in the 10th century. Thanks to a crossing of two roads in Egeln a road market developed early. In the 12th/13th century a market borough ('Marktflecken') developed.
Town_Description: First mention as civitas in 1251. Town rights can be proven for 1365. The town probably earned town privileges earlier (possibly when market rights were granted in 1250).
Toll_Description: An escort ('Geleitsmann') can be proven in 1494-1497 in Egeln.
Fair_Description: In 1550 two fairs are known.

Name: Eggenstedt
Settlement_Description: Mention of Eggenstedt 1143 as the property of Gottesgnaden monastery near Calbe. In 1563 the number of inhabitants of Eggenstedt had shrunk to 10-12, the settlement decayed during the 30-year-war.

Name: Eggershausen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1323.

Name: Egstedt
Settlement_Description: Originally property of the family of Egstedt, which is still mentioned in 1308, in the course of the 14th century it becomes property of the town of Erfurt.

Name: Ehndorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned before 1207.

Name: Ehrenburg
Settlement_Description: Castle of the counts of Hoya, first mentioned in 1427. The related settlement was characterised as borough ('flecken').
Toll_Description: The toll in Ehrenburg was pawned in 1525.

Name: Ehringen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1018 and still called a village in 1438.

Name: Ehrsten
Alternative_Name: Heristi; Herste; Hêrsten; Erstin; Erste; Ehrsten; Horstete
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 952.

Name: Eichenbarleben
Settlement_Description: In 1140 mention in a buying record, mention of a ministerial family in 1283, which had a manor here.

Name: Eichrodt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1301.

Name: Eickeloh
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1237.

Name: Eickenrode
Alternative_Name: Roden; Eykenrode; Ekenrode; Rothe; Eckenrode; Eickenroda; Aikenrode
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1295.

Name: Eickhorst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the second half of the 13th century.

Name: Eidapere
Settlement_Description: Manor that was first mentioned in 1530.

Name: Eidelstedt
Alternative_Name: Eilenstede; Eylstede; Eilstede; Eygelstede; Eilstette; Eiellstedte; Eillstedte; Eilenstede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1256.

Name: Eidinghausen
Alternative_Name: Edighusen; Edekehuson; Edinhusen; Eydinghusen; Eydinchosen; Eydinghus; Eydinkhusen; Eygdinchusenn; Oidinghausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1126.

Name: Eigenrieden
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1246.

Name: Eigenrode
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1296.

Name: Eilenburg
Alternative_Name: Hilburg; Ihleburg; Ileburgh; Ilburch; Ilberc; Illeburck
Settlement_Description: In the 10th century a castle was built that was mostly destroyed during the uprising of the Wends ('Wendenaufstand'). The settlement at the castle, however, remained. It is already referred to as town (urbs) in 981.
Town_Description: The awarding of town rights probably occurred at the beginning of the 13th century.
Toll_Description: An uncommonly exhaustive regulation of safe conduct lists the toll on the shipment of several wares (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Cc 676, Geleitsrechnung Eilenburg 1524/25, p. 2–6.).
Fair_Description: Over decades the town of Eilenburg requests a second fair, but always fails due to the resistance of Leipzig. The date of the first fair is unknown.

Name: Eilensen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1118.

Name: Eilum
Alternative_Name: Udenhem; Oudenheim; Udenem; Odhenem; Odenum; Addelem; Eylem
Settlement_Description: A first mention from 888 is debatable; the next mention of the settlement dates from 1121. Urn graves north of the current village hint at earlier habitation around 400/500.

Name: Eilvese
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1281.

Name: Eime
Alternative_Name: Einem; Eynem; Egem; Heiem; Eiem; Eym; Eygem
Settlement_Description: A first mention in the second half of the 10th century is uncertain. The settlement is attested as borough ('flecken') in 1550.

Name: Eimen
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1183.

Name: Eimersleben
Settlement_Description: First mention probably in 1043, next secure mention around 1150.

Name: Eindhoven
Alternative_Name: Endehouen; tEndouen; Eyndoven; Endoven; Eyndhoven; Endehoven
Settlement_Description: Assumably, Eindhoven was founded between 1212 and 1232. The first mention of Eindhoven can be found in a sixteenth-century copy of a document dated 1232.
Town_Description: Eindhoven was granted town rights in 1232 by Henry I, duke of Brabant. Eindhoven was surrounded by a stone wall and had a moat.

Name: Einhaus
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1194.

Name: Einsiedel
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1307.

Name: Einum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 8th or 9th century in a register of possessions of the monastery Corvey.

Name: Eys
Alternative_Name: Hanzon; Heyse; Eyse; Eyze; Hyze; Eysch; Eeys; Eis
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1193. Earliest mention of 'Eyse' in 1287.

Name: Eisdorf
Alternative_Name: Eisdorf am Harz; Agesthorp; Eysdorp; Eistorp; Egistorp
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 953.

Name: Eisenach
Settlement_Description: Eisenach develops from a market village which lay at the roads called the "Long Hessians".
Toll_Description: In Eisenach, a toll and a fee for overland safe conduct ('Feldgeleit') was due, which was determined by the mode of transport and the amount of the load. (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Bb 1237, Rechnung des Amtes Eisenach 1517/18, p. 1–7.)
Fair_Description: Around 1300, there were three fairs in Eisenach, although it can be assumed that the fairs were established earlier. In the regulations of safe conduct of 1517/18 four fairs are mentioned.

Name: Eisfeld
Settlement_Description: Frankish counts founded the village with six guarding farmyards and a manor in the valley of the Werra. Mention as a market village (oppidum) in 1319.
Town_Description: In 1323 king Ludwig the Bavarian gave permission to construct a town wall and excise consuption tax ('Ungeld'). Since 1342 Schweinfurt or Frankisch town rights and referred to as civitas.

Name: Lutherstadt Eisleben
Alternative_Name: Eisleben; Isileiben; Islebe; Islevo; Ysleiben; Eißleben
Settlement_Description: First mention between 780 and 802. In 994 the market borough ('Marktflecken') earned market-, coin- and tollrights.
Town_Description: Around 1180 mentioned as civitas. In 1286 the town wall is mentioned in a record. Around 1500 a new town is established.
Toll_Description: Station of safe conduct of the counts of Mansfeld
Fair_Description: In 1522 Leipzig complained about the fairs ein Eisleben, who claimed that the fairs there would benefit Leipzig, since wares in Eisleben had to pass through Leipzig first. They had also owned their fairs since 100 years already. In 1690 the fairs on the Sundays Reminiscere, after St. Viti, St. Gallus and St. Mauritius were moved to the following tuesdays.

Name: Eitze
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the year 860 in the wonders at the grave of bishop Willehad in Bremen. First mention in a charter in 1220.

Name: Ekeren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1157.

Name: Elberfeld
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll, possibly already before 1496.

Name: Elbergen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 890.

Name: Elbląg
Alternative_Name: Elbing; Elbinc; Elbingo; Elblaga; Elbiagowi; Ilfing; Elvigge; Zum Elbinge; Elbinge; Elbingum; Melvingen; Elbinga; Elbingen
Settlement_Description: There are relics of germanic settlements in pre-roman Iron Age, the imperial era as well as prussian-viking time, signs of a prussian trading post from 890 may have been a pre-settlement. The Teutonic Order founded the place on the mouth of the Elbing on the Vistula Lagoon in 1236 or 1237
Town_Description: A town was founded by the Teutonic order in 1237, Lübeck merchants settled there, the town was granted Lübeck town law by Wilhelm von Modena in 1240, but the documents do not survive, the eldest copies are from between 1263 and 1267, a handfast from 1246 granted restricted Lübeck town law, but it was extended in 1288, 1339 and 1343, the municipal ordinance made it an official town in 1808 and again later in 1853
Staple_Description: The staple existed already in 1388, when it was confirmed that the town was the only import harbour for english cloth; English merchants were only allowed to buy corn and wood from Prussia and Poland in Elbing. The staple was expanded in 1393 to include the export of corn, malt, tar, pitch, ash, tin, lead, timber and wood from the entire region between the Vistula and the Curonian Lagoon. Soon after, the entire system must have collapsed in favour of Danzig: in 1411 the Grand Master of the Teutonic Order moved the staple of Danzig temporarily to Elbing. A request of Elbing to instate a staple on the Diet of Prussian estates in 1440 shows that by that time, nothing was left of the Elbing staple.

Name: Elbingerode
Settlement_Description: Resting place at the route between Wernigerode an Nordhausen, since 1220 mentioned as village. 1298 first mention of a castle in Elbingerode. Rastplatz auf der Strecke zwischen Wernigerode und Nordhausen, seit 1220 als Dorf erwähtn. 1298 erste Erwähnug einer Burg in Elbingerode.

Name: Elburg
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1190.
Town_Description: It is generally assumed that town privileges were granted to Elburg between 1220 and 1271, probably by Otto II, count of Guelders; possibly around 1233. In 1392, duke William of Guelders ordered to move te city. The new town was being build from 1393 onwards, and walled in 1396. In 1397, the bishop of Utrecht grants permission to pull down the church and rebuild it within the town walls.
Fair_Description: In 1397, Duke William I of Guelders granted two fairs, each lasting 8 days before to 8 days after the fair date. Its ‘market freedom’ was based on the example of Arnhem.

Name: Elden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 855 in a copy dated around 900.

Name: Elfsen
Alternative_Name: Eueldenchusen; Elfendehusen; Elfeldehusen; Elfindehusen; Elfessen; Elffhuissen

Name: Elgershausen
Alternative_Name: Edelgershusun; Elgershusen; Helgershusen; Elichershusen; Heiligershusen; Eylgershausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1145.

Name: Elkeringhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1345.

Name: Ellamaa
Settlement_Description: Originally a village near the Soinitz manor. In 1515 the estate was called "Hellenbeke". From 1580, however, it is referred to as a village again.

Name: Ellamaa
Settlement_Description: Around 1500 there was a little estate.

Name: Ellecom
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1128-1139. Archaeological research shows that around 1100, a wooden chapel arose on the location of the Saint Nicholas Church (Nicolaaskerk).

Name: Ellerhoop
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1588.

Name: Ellrich
Settlement_Description: The oldest part of the settlement is probably to be found in the North of the village, where a church was built in the 9th century and remains of fortifications can be found. In the East the current town developed. The first written mention of the town remains from 1229 in the record book of Walkenried monastery.
Town_Description: In the 13th cenutry the settlement by the church in the East of the village was probably fortified and had a town-like character. In 1315 it is described as walled.

Name: Elm
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a donation charter between 1111 and 1116.

Name: Elmenhorst (Stormarn)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1470.

Name: Elmschenhagen
Settlement_Description: Founded after 1233, first mentioned in 1276.

Name: Elmshorn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1141 as 'Villa Elmeshorne'.

Name: Elspeet
Settlement_Description: Veen et. al. (2016) presume permanent habitation of Elspeet from ca. 1250 onwards. Neefjes and Bleumink (2015) consider earlier habitation a possiblity, possibly from the tenth century onwards. There is consensus that habitation and cultivation of land intensified during the thirteenth century in this area. From the thirteenth century onwards, habitation centered around a church dedicated to St. Paul. Nowadays, this is the ‘Hervormde Kerk’ located at Nunspeterweg 3.

Name: Elst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 726 in an eleventh century copy.
Fair_Description: Elst had one fair from at least 1294/95 onward, on the Day of the Assumption of Mary. At least in the sixteenth century, this was a horse fair.

Name: Elster
Settlement_Description: In 1428 mentioned as market. Referred to since as little town ('Städtchen') and borough ('Flecken').
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wittenberg in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig. Regulations of safe conduct remain from 1513.
Ferry_Description: Elster had a ferry since olden times.

Name: Elstertrebnitz
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as early manor in 1079, then again as a knightly manor in 1548.

Name: Eltze
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1240.

Name: Elze
Alternative_Name: Aulica villa; Alicga; Alitse; Alison; Ellessem; Eletse
Settlement_Description: Founded as Carolingian missionary centre. First mentioned between 826 and 876, characterised as village in 1190 and developed into a borough ('flecken') in the 14th century.
Town_Description: Already in 1360, a council and seal are mentioned. A town hall was built in 1546, town privileges acquired in 1579.

Name: Emden
Alternative_Name: Emathae; Amatha; Amuthon; Amethis; Emethen; Emutha
Settlement_Description: Emden arose from a Frisian trading settlement, where a Carolingian missionary church was erected around 800.
Town_Description: While Emden was occupied by Hamburg in 1433-1439 and 1448-1453, the settlement acquired urban character and institutions. However, town privileges were never granted.
Toll_Description:
- Toll on the river Ems, first mentioned in 1224. Toll reductions were introduced in 1457 for citizens of Groningen, who were freed from staple and toll obligations in Emden; in 1493 for Hamburg beer; and in 1497, reduced toll rates are mentioned for merchants from Münster. East Frisians were exempted from the Ems toll as well. The toll rates were doubled in 1541.
- The 1494 staple privileges contained a so-called 'ruderzoll' for large see-going vessels that entered the harbour of Emden in cases of emergency, but were not obliged to stay in the town for a certain time.
- New tolls were introduced in 1595 for imported commodities belonging to East Frisians, or being transported further to East Frisia. They were cancelled between 1603 and 1605. Citizens from Emden were exempted from these tolls in 1610.
