Staple_Description: The staple right was officially granted in 1494, but already practised in times that the town was controlled by Hamburg (1433-1439, 1448-1453). Merchants from Groningen were initially freed from staple obligations in Emden, but the 1483 prohibition to export corn, butter and cheese from East Frisia was also strictly implemented towards Groningen. Under Count Edzard of East Frisia in 1506-1514, Groningen merchants were privileged again. Emperor Charles V removed the Emden staple in favour of Groningen in 1548, but it was still practised, and his successor Ferdinand I declared Charles's decree invalid in 1558. In the following years, Emden's staple was acknowledged by Hamburg, Osnabrück and Münster. Emden was staple port of the English Merchant Adventurers in 1560-1564, 1580-1587 and 1599-1602. The staple was practised without many conflicts until the 1680s, afterwards often restricted and finally abolished in 1765.
Fair_Description: In 1440, it is first mentioned that fairs were organised in Emden. In 1497 they were specified as two eight-day fairs, taking place eight days before Laetare Sunday and eight days after St Michael.

Name: Emmen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1139, in a 16th-century copy.

Name: Emmerich
Alternative_Name: Emmerich am Rhein; Embrici; Emberic; Eymerich; Emmerik; Emmerick; Emericke
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 828.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted in 1233.
Toll_Description: The monastery of St. Maria in Utrecht levied a river toll on the Rhine here in 1318. A toll was mentioned for the first time as early as 1142. This was probably a market fee. Fees on river and land traffic, documented in 1233, were also market-related. In 1324, a preferential tariff of 4 pfennigs per foder of wine applied to people from Duisburg. In 1436/37 the annual yield was about 650 gulden, in 1489/90 579 gulden. For more detailed tariffs and yields, see source.

Name: Eemnes-Binnen
Alternative_Name: Eemnes Binnen; Eemnes; Eemnes-Binnendijks; Emnesse; Emmenesse; binnen dycx op Emmenesse; Emenesse; Emenesse bynnen dyck; Emenes; Ymenesse; Ymeness; Ymenes binnen dijcx; Ymenes binne dijcks; Emmenes; Emmenes binne Dyk
Settlement_Description: Cultivation of land west of Ter Eem/Eembrugge resulted in the settlements Eemnes-Binnen en Eemnes-Buiten. Earliest mention of 'Emnesse' dates from 1269. Especially after ca. 1300, people settled here. Both places and the area west of the river Eem fell under the jurisdiction of Ter Eem. In 1439, Eemnes-Binnen became independent of Ter Eem.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted in 1439 by Rudolf of Diepholt, bishop of Utrecht.

Name: Eemnes
Alternative_Name: Eemnes Buiten; Eemnes-Buiten; Eemnes-Buitendijks; Emenesse; Emnesse; Emmenesse; Emenesse buten dyck; Emenes; Emenes buyten sdycx; Ymenesse; Ymeness; Ymenes bytten dijcx; Ymenes buyte dijcks; Emmenes
Settlement_Description: Cultivation of land west of Ter Eem/Eembrugge resulted in the settlements Eemnes-Binnen en Eemnes-Buiten. Earliest mention of 'Emnesse' dates from 1269. Especially after ca. 1300, people settled here. Both places and the area west of the river Eem fell under the jurisdiction of Ter Eem. In 1352, the northern part of the area west of the river Eem, was split off Ter Eem: Eemnes-Buiten became independent.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted by John ('Jan') of Arkel, bishop of Utrecht, in 1352. In 1356, Eemnes-Buiten became part of Holland.

Name: Empelde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 826.

Name: Emsbüren
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as Buren in 1151, although the settlement is der Ort ist probably older and contained one of the manors donated to the holy Liudger before 849. Market borough ('marktflecken') since the 14th century. The connection with the river Ems in the name is first attested around 1490.

Name: Emsdetten
Settlement_Description: The settlement originated in the 9th / 10th century near a church and was first mentioned by name in 1178.

Name: Emstek
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in a charter of king Otto I from 947.

Name: Endorf
Settlement_Description: Already mentioned in the records as 934 as Emmundorp.

Name: Äntu
Settlement_Description: A manor was first mentioned in 1277. In 1558 it was occupied by the Russians.

Name: Enge
Alternative_Name: Enge-Sande; Klyntrynengi; Klintringenge; Clintring engi; Enghe; Klyntrinengy

Name: Engensen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1278.

Name: Enger
Alternative_Name: Angeri; Angare; Angerin; Engern; Angaram; Angre; Angeri; Aggeri; Engari; Engerensis; Angarie; Angera; Enghere; Eyngere; Engerenn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 948. The settlement acquired borough ('weichbild') rights in the late Middle Ages.

Name: Engter
Alternative_Name: Engethere; Enketer; Eggetere; Engetare; Engherten; Enkede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1147.

Name: Enkhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1173.

Name: Enkhuizen
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of Enkhuizen dates from 1305.
Town_Description: Enkhuizen was granted town rights on 27 January 1356 by William V (duke of Bavaria and count of Holland). One of the smaller ‘Kamers’ (departments) of the VOC (Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie, Dutch East India Company, founded in 1602) was located in Enkhuizen.

Name: Enschede
Alternative_Name: Aneschedhe; Anneschethe; Enscede; Entscede; Endschede; Endscheide; Enskedee
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1118 (in a thirteenth century copy, possibly a falsification). Earliest mention in a charter in 1316.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted by Jan III of Diest, bishop of Utrecht, on 15 December 1325.

Name: Ensen
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in 1487. Since Ensen was a secondary toll station of Dünnwald, the same tariffs applied as there. In 1488, the annual revenue was 316 marks 10 shillings.

Name: Entrup
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1151.

Name: Epe (Westfalen)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1188.

Name: Epe (Veluwe)
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1176.

Name: Eppegem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 966, in a fifteenth century copy. Next mention in 1146-1152, in a copy dating from circa 1265.

Name: Eppendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1140. The village church, mentioned in a document from 1267, is said to have existed since 840.

Name: Epse
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1195.

Name: Erfurt
Settlement_Description: The area was settled in since the Early Stone Ages. In the 8th century centre of the Catholic bishopric, as well as karolingian royal court ('Pfalzort').
Town_Description: The village was expanded to town since the early 12th century; in 1167 it is referred to as civitas.
Toll_Description:
Merchants from outside Thuringia hat do pay a fee of 4 pennies for wagons and 2 pennies for carts for entrepot ('Niederlagegeld') in Erfurt. They had to pay the same fee when they loaded their wares again. The transit fee ('Durchfahrtszoll') was probably higher.
Around 1495 this fee of entrepot had been changed to a fee of 6 pennies for every entrepot and wagonload of every foreign trader.
The toll was paid in the toll station on the cathedral plaza.
Regulations of safe conduct from 1315 and 1441 (as a copy from 1533) remain.
Staple_Description: The town legitimised its staple policy by the capitulary of Charlemagne of 805. It exercised a toll policy with staple characteristics in the law ('weistum') of 1289, to which later prescribed roads for the East-West-traffic between the Thuringian Forest and the Harz were added. The staple was abolished with the instalment of a staple in Leipzig in 1507, which led to resistance in Erfurt. The town tried to regain its staple in vain until the 17th century. Weight ordinances from 1631 and 1738 show that the town exercised a limited staple policy, in the sense of a pre-emptive right by its citizens.
Fair_Description: In addition to the privileged fairs that lasted several weeks, Erfurt held several free markets which were less prestigious than the large fairs.

Name: Ērgļi
Settlement_Description: Settlement existed since the middle of the 14th century. A castle called 'Erlaa' was built in 1397.

Name: Ermelo
Alternative_Name: Irminlo; Yrmilon; Hermelo; Ermello; Ermela; Ermele
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 855 in a copy made around 900. Earliest mention of the Oude Kerk (Old Church) in 1006.

Name: Ērģeme
Alternative_Name: Ermes; Argemis; Ergemis; Ergamis; Ermis; Ermiss; Armus; Ergemes; Ergeme
Settlement_Description: The castle was first mentioned in 1323.

Name: Ermsleben
Settlement_Description: A castle near a prehistorical settlement was constructed at the end of the 12th or at the beginning of the 13th century. The village developed into a market borough ('Marktflecken').
Town_Description: In 1298 the village is already referred to as oppidum, but there are no further mentions concerning the town rights. In 1530 Karl V. grants market rights.
Fair_Description: In 1530 emperor Karl V. grants two fairs to Ermsleben, which didn't help the citiy's economy at all and could not prevent its dwindeling population.

Name: Erpe
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 972, in copy from the middle of the eleventh century. Next mention in 1088.

Name: Ertvelde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a twelfth-century copy from a document from 1167.

Name: Erwitte
Alternative_Name: Arwitti; Atueite; Arueite; Arvite; Aruitdi; Arvita; Arviti; Ervete; Eruete; Erwete
Settlement_Description: The place was at the crossroads of two long-distance trade routes; it was a parish with a royal court. First mentioned in 822.

Name: Erxleben (Magdeburg)
Settlement_Description: First mention at the end of the 10th or beginning of the 11th century; further mention in 1021. In 1170 a noble family which carried the name of Erxleben emerges in the records, probably in connection with the castle that is first mentioned in 1273, but probably existed before. A settlement existed alongside the castle and was closely tied to its events. The castle held garrisons from Magdeburg and Braunschweig; served as waypoint and station between Helmstedt and Magdeburg.

Name: Erxleben (Altmark)
Settlement_Description: First secure mention in 1200; possibly already in 1145.

Name: Esch
Toll_Description: The Count of Blankenheim-Gerolstein levied a land toll in 1490.

Name: Escharen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from the beginning of the thirteenth century.

Name: Escheburg
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1319.

Name: Eschede
Alternative_Name: Esge; Esche; Eschete; Essche; Esghe; Eske
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1197.

Name: Eschenrode
Settlement_Description: First mention as Haskenroht as the property of Marienthal monastery.

Name: Eschershausen
Alternative_Name: Assiereshusun; Ascgereshuson; Aschereshusen; Eschereshusen; Eschershusen; Escherinchusin; Herschereshusen; Heskerhusen; Escherhusen; Esschereshusen; Eskershusen; Eszershusen; Esscershusen; Esschirßhus
Settlement_Description: The settlement probably already existed in the 8th century. In the second half of the 14th century the settlement became a borough ('flecken'). Town rights were granted in 1833.
Toll_Description: A toll station of the lords of Homburg in Eschershausen is first mentioned in 1384; it is included in a 1587 list of tolls in the duchy of Brunswick as well.

Name: Eschwege
Alternative_Name: Eskiniwach; Eskinewag; Iskinwege; Heschenewege; Askinewage; Eschenwege; Iskiniwege; Eschenwehe; Eschvia; Eschwega; Eischwiga; Eschenwegensis; Aschewai; Aschewä
Settlement_Description: In 974 Emperor Otto II gave the royal court of Eschwege, which was on the southern bank of the Werra, to his wife; The imperial abbey was probably founded in the 10th century; Development into a city from the middle of the 13th century

Name: Ezemaal
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1066, in an eighteenth century copy.

Name: Espenhain
Settlement_Description: First mention as Hespenhayen in 1322.

Name: Esperstedt
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Breviarium sacti Lulli, Tab. II.

Name: Essel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1251.
Toll_Description: Land and water toll. In 1389 the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg proclaimed that the same toll shall be levied on the Leine river in Neustadt that is levied on the Aller in Essel, namely for each fuder corn, flour or beer one Hannover shilling. According to a Hildesheim complaint from 1456, the fare for the land toll was doubled from one to two pennies. A 1507 agreement between Hannover and Celle regulated the fares for toll and safe conduct in Essel. Probably, this regulation concerned the toll in Neustadt, as Essel is not located at the Leine.

Name: Essen
Settlement_Description: A first mentioned around 870 is debatable. Around the middle of the 9th century, bishop Altfrid of Hildesheim founded a women's monastery, around which the settlement developed.
Town_Description: A civic community appears in a charter from 1244, which received permission to fortify the town. However, the town never became completely independent from the monastery.
Fair_Description: In 1041, abbess Theophanu of the Essen monastery received the right to hold a fair on the feast of St Cosmas and Damian.

Name: Bad Essen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1074.

Name: Essen (Oldenburg)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 968 and 978. There is said to have been a law court here at times, which suggests that the settlement had the character of a borough ('flecken' or 'weichbild').

Name: Essentho
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 826.

Name: Eßhoff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1580.

Name: Estebrügge
Alternative_Name: Eschedebrugge; Eschete; Eschedam; Eskete; Eschede; Este
Settlement_Description: The settlement goes back to the settlement Eschete, which developed on both sides of the river Este during the cultivation of the region Altes Land in the 12th century. The church is first mentioned in 1200. Estebrügge proper is named after the bridge over the Este, which is first mentioned in 1335 and was the only fixed river crossing until 1875.
Fair_Description: A fair in Estebrügge is first mentioned in 1595 and took place in September.

Name: Estedt
Settlement_Description: First mention as the property of Calbe monastery, which is given to St. Lorenz' monastery.

Name: Etelsen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1236.

Name: Etersheim
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1277.

Name: Etingen
Settlement_Description: In 961 Otto I. gives Adinga to the archbishopric of Magdeburg.

Name: Etterwinden
Settlement_Description: Uncertain mention in 958, first certain mention in 1292.

Name: Etzelbach
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1140.

Name: Eula
Settlement_Description: 1090 referred to as villa, in 1206 mentioned as manor

Name: Eutritzsch
Alternative_Name: Udericz; Vderisch; Uderitz; Ewderitzsch; Euderitzsch; Eyderitz; Euteritzsch
Settlement_Description: First written reconrd of the settlement in 1335 as Udericz, in 1378 mention as part of the administrational district of Leipzig. In 1890 the independent municipal was incorporated into the town of Leipzig.

Name: Evere
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a end thirteenth-century copy from a document from 1120.

Name: Everloh
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1016.

Name: Evessen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 965. The settlement might originally have consisted of two parts, the Osten- and Westendorf.

Name: Eyendorf
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in a register of the diocese of Verden of ca. 1252.

Name: Eystrup
Settlement_Description: A Saxon settlement already existed before the 9th century.

Name: Eythra
Settlement_Description: Emperor Otto II. gave Eythra to the prince-bishopric ('Hochstift') of Merseburg, since it had had been illegaly revoked by margrave Thietmar. The village had to move to a brown coal opencast mine in 1982 and after operations were ended, was flooded.

Name: Fahrenhorst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1530.

Name: Väo
Settlement_Description: Originally a village and town estate east of Reval. In 1402, Väo was bought by Reval.

Name: Kärkna
Settlement_Description: The monastery was built before 1234. It was a Cistercian monastery. In 1558 it was conquered and destroyed by the Russians.

Name: Złocieniec
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1311, a castle is mentioned in 1317. It was most likely a hamlet before 1333.
Town_Description: The Brandenburg town law was granted in 1333 by Lüdeke and Hasse von Wedel. It was mentioned as a Stad in 1374, as stat in 1503 and Stetichen in 1505.

Name: Falkenhagen (Mark)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1313, in the 14th century referred to as oppidum, once as town in 1369, after that as little town ('Städtlein') and borough ('Flecken').

Name: Falkensee
Settlement_Description: Around 1200 the two villages Falkenhagen and Seegefeld, which are merged into Falkensee in 1923, are founded and are property of the convent in Spandau. The village gains town rights only in 1961.

Name: Fallersleben
Alternative_Name: Valareslebo; Walresleba; Feleresleva; Valersleve; Waleresleve; Valirslive; Vallersleue; Vallerslebe; Vallersleve; Vallersseleve; Vallersleben; Vallerssleben; Fallersleuenn; Vallerschleben
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 942, then already with a church. The village was characterised as borough ('weichbild'; later 'flecken') from 1344.
Toll_Description: A toll of the Duke of Brunswick is mentioned in 1409.
Fair_Description: Three fairs were granted to Fallersleben in 1573: on Misericordia Sunday, Sunday after St Lawrence and 14 days after St Martin.

Name: Bad Fallingbostel
Alternative_Name: Fallingbostel; Vastulingaburstalle; Valigeburstolde; Vastëllingeburstel; Vallingborstele; Valingborstel; Valergeborstel; Vallingborstel; Fallingbostell
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 990. A church in Fallingbostel existed in 1239.

Name: Farmsen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1151.

Name: Farnstädt
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis.

Name: Farsleben
Settlement_Description: In 1197 Ammensleben monastery held a third of the village. Unsure, if it is the same settlement that is mentioned in a record in 946 as being given to Quedlinburg monastery as a gift, since it is not mentioned again.

Name: Fegetasche
Alternative_Name: Fegetasch; Holstenbrücke; Holstenbrugge; Zollkrug; Fegetascher Krug
Settlement_Description: The charterhouse of Ahrensbök acquired an eel weir at the Holsten bridge in 1429 and erected an hermitage with a chapel of St Anthony, which was enlarged in 1485. At the other side of the bridge, an inn at the toll station is first mentioned in 1596. The later name of the inn, "Fegetasche", first mentioned in 1649, probably does not refer to the toll payment, as is often suggested.
Toll_Description: Toll station of the counts of Holstein, connected to Plön. As the town Plön is not directly located on the main street, the toll was levied at the Holsten bridge on the border of the town area. The beginnings of the toll are unknown; a 1390 charter that guaranteed the freedom to use the streets for citizens from Plön has been interpreted to suggest exemption from toll payments. The fees to be paid were raised in line with other tolls in Holstein in 1474, but in comparison to the other toll stations, the Plön toll had only modest revenues. Lübeck citizens were exempted from toll payments. Toll registers are available for the years 1490-1518. Levying of the toll was discontinued in 1838.
Bridge_Description: The "Holsten" bridge, mentioned in the town privileges of Plön of 1236, crossed the Schwentine near the later inn Fegetasche. It formed the eastern border of the town area of Plön.

Name: Kiviloo
Alternative_Name: Burg Fegfeuer; Fegefeuer; Vegevur; Fegefur; Fegefüer
Settlement_Description: The manor ('Hof') was first mentioned in 1322. It was situated near Kiviloo (1241: Kiulo). The castle 'Fegefeuer' was not completely built in 1474, but was already mentioned.

Name: Fehrbellin
Alternative_Name: Bellin; Bellyn; Pellin uff der fehr; Bellin an dem Rhin; Belin
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1216, started as a small settlement close to the castle, that was first mentioned in 1305, the family Bellin, which was first names in 1260, was most likely from here
Town_Description: First mentioned as civitas in 1294, then later in 1471 called opidum

Name: Fehrenbötel
Alternative_Name: Botele; Westerbøtle; Verne botel; Verenbotel; Ferrnbötel

Name: Vestiena
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1452.

Name: Felbecke
Alternative_Name: Veltbike; Velbeke; Velbecke; Ffelbicke; Velmicke; Welbick

Name: Feldbergen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1218.

Name: Viljandi
Settlement_Description: The castle of the Livonian Brothers of the Sword was built in 1224 after they had conquered the Estonian castle 'Viliende'. A town developed next to the castle.
Town_Description: In the 13th century the city received toen rights by Riga and later became a member of the Hanseatic League.

Name: Fermersleben
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 937 in a gift certificate by Otto I. to the monastary of St. Moritz in Magdeburg (MGH DD OI, nr. 16, S. 103 - 105). Until the 10th century, Fermersleben should have been situated on the bank of the Elbe until it changed its course. Until the 18th century, the cut-off meander would have carried water.
Ferry_Description: In 1150 the ferry in Fermersleben is given to Berge monastery.

Name: Fettehenne
Toll_Description: Countess Margarethe von Berg levied a land toll in 1377. A fee of ½ Weißpfennig per horse had to be paid.

Name: Kivi-Vigala
Settlement_Description: A church was built in the 14th century. The Castle of Fickel was probably built around 1400, but was first mentioned in 1453. A Borough ('Flecken') around the church did not appear until the 20th century.

Name: Finsterwalde
Alternative_Name: Vynsterwalde; Dinsterwlde; Vinsterwalde; Finsterwald; Wynsterwalde; Duisterwalde; Fynsterwalde; Finsterwaldau; Finsterwalda; Dusterbusch

Name: Fischbach
Settlement_Description: First mention in 819.

Name: Fischbeck (Weser)
Alternative_Name: Fischbeck; Uisbecchae; Uisbeke; Vysbeke; Viscbiki; Uisbeki; Fiscbah; Visbeck; Visbike; Visbech; Visbick; Visbicke; Visebacho; Visbecc; Visbeke; Vysbeke; Bisbegk; Vischbeke; Visbeeke; Vissbeck
Settlement_Description: A monastery of canonesses was founded in Fischbeck in 955. After the Reformation it was converted into a Lutheran ladies' house in the 1560s, and recatholicised during the Thirty Years' War in 1629-1633.

Name: Fischbeck (Elbe)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1172. Probably part of the castle district of Kabelitz, since 1337 property of the bishop of Havelberg, since 1562 of the lords of Bismark.

Name: Fischbek
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a Kiel town register of 1264-1289.

Name: Primorsk
Alternative_Name: Fischhausen; Приморск; Vyschuzin; Bischoveshusen; Vischhawsen; Fischhaußen
Settlement_Description: Heinrich von Strittberg, the bishop of Samland, was given a village by the Teutonic Order in 1264, he built a fortified bishop's see and gave land to settlers in 1268, the first attempt of a town founding in 1299 was not successdul
Town_Description: Bishop Siegfried took over the town's founding in 1305, granted Kulm town law, the founding documents were endorsed in 1475 by elector Johann Sigismund

Name: Flatow
Alternative_Name: Vulchovum; Vulutovum; Welatowo; Zlotane; Flotho; Flatto; Flatho; Flatow; Flatau; Zlotowo
Settlement_Description: Stone Age finds, a pomeranian castle mound with a wooden fortification dates back to 700. Later the pomeralian dukes built a castle complex with a suburbium.
Town_Description: Has already been a town in 1370, the founding documents are lost. It was the centre of a domain in the middle of the 14th ct. The eldest surviving privilege with Magdeburg town law, which refers back to the original, dates back to 1665 and was issued by Andreas Karl von Grudzinski.

Name: Flechtdorf
Alternative_Name: Fliathorpe; Flahtthorpe; Fliahtthorpe; Flietorp; Fletorp; Flicztorp; Flictorp; Flietorp; Fleitorp; Flechtorff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Flechtorf
Alternative_Name: Flehtthorp; Flegthorp; Flehttorpa; Ulechthorp; Vlechtorp; Wlecdorp; Flectorpe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022.

Name: Flemhude
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the Kiel town register of 1264-1289; the church was built around 1242. The village name signifies a landing place of Flemish traders on the Eider river.
Harbour_Description: The Eider was navigable until Flemhude, which made the settlement an important transshipment port between the North and Baltic Sea in the High Middle Ages.

Name: Flensburg
Alternative_Name: Flensborg; Flensborgh; Flensaburgh; Flensaaburgh; Vlensborch; Flenßburg
Settlement_Description: Founded close to the St. John Church of the 12th Ct.
Town_Description: Flensburg was founded in the 12th century, probably around 1150. Around 1190 a St. Canute Guild (Danish: Skt. Knuds Gilde) based in Flensburg was taken under royal protection. In 1263 a Franciscan convent was established, and a town law was in place from 1284, granted by Duke Waldemar IV., Duke Erich II. acknowledges this in 1314

Name: Kleparz
Alternative_Name: Florenz; Florencja; Florencia; Florentia; Clepardia; Clapers; Klepars;Alta civitas

Name: Fölziehausen
Alternative_Name: Folcringehuse; Falssigehusenn; Folsigehusen; Voltziehausen; Föltzighaussen; Voltzinghasuen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1409.

Name: Forst
Alternative_Name: Forst (Lausitz); Vorst; die veste Forst; zum Forst; Forsta; Forste; Forschte
Town_Description: The town was founded by the landowner, protected by the water castle, first mentioned in 1346, see of the archpriest of 15 parish churches, renewal of Magdeburg town law in 1428, mentioned as civitas in 1595, after the privileges burnt in 1645, they were often cut down by the landowners

Name: Förtha
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1239.

Name: Sint-Martens-Voeren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 879. Next mention in 966. Following mention in 1084.

Name: Frankhuis
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1396.

Name: Franeker
Alternative_Name: Frentsjer; Fronakre; Fronacker; Froneckere; Vroenackere; Vranekere;
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1085. This document, however, is a falsification dating from around 1200. Another early mention dates from 1216.
Town_Description: A document from 25 July 1417 notes several town-like features; however, town rights are not mentioned. According to Cox, town privileges gradually developed between the late fourteenth century and 1474.

Name: Frankenberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1243. The castle was built in 1233/34.
Town_Description: Receipt of town charter before 1243; In 1335 a new town was founded, which in 1556 was merged with the original town of Frankenberg.

Name: Frankfurt am Main
Alternative_Name: Franconofurd; Franchonofurt; Franchenvurt; Frankfort; Franckforde; Franconevurt; Franchennevort; Franchenvurt; Franchenfurt; Frankenvurt; Frankenfort; Frankenvort; Frankinfort; Frankefort; Frankfort
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 794 in a document of Charlemagne. 815 Royal Palace of the German Carolingians. A Celtic settlement is said to have existed way before the Franconian royal court, which was conquered by Teutons and was inhabited by the Romans in Augustan times.
Fair_Description: The fairs in Frankfurt are first mentioned in 1227. They became large international fairs, attracting visitors from as far as France, Flanders, northern Italy and northern Germany. In 1240, Emperor Frederick II granted safe conduct for visitors of the fairs. The exact dates of the fairs were first mentioned in 1349. The oldest one was the Our Lady's or autumn fair ('Frauenmesse'); in 1330 a Lent fair was added.

Name: Frankfurt (Oder)
Alternative_Name: Frankfurt a.d. Oder; Vrankenuorde; Frankinfurd; Frankenuorde uff der Odir; Frankenfordt; Frankenforde; Franckfurth
Settlement_Description: A marketplace existed (perhaps from 1226) in the vicinity of the Church of St Nicholas before the settlement’s foundation as a town in 1253
Town_Description: Town foundation and provision of town rights by John I of Brandenburg
Staple_Description: The mention of the staple in the foundation charter of the town from 1253 is probably a later addition. A privilege by the Margrave of Brandenburg from 1351 limited the land and river traffic to routes through Frankfurt; other river crossings were prohibited. The 1379 edict about the freedom of shipping on the Oder limited the possibilities to enforce the staple, but it was still mentioned in the town privileges from 1473. A treaty with Breslau from 1490 limited the crossing of the Oder by merchants to Breslau and Frankfurt, but proved difficult to enforce because of Polish counter-measures. In 1507, merchants from Poland, Russia, Lithuania, Masovia and Prussia were prohibited to trade further than Frankfurt and Breslau. The staple privileges were confirmed in 1510 and 1512, but could not be reinforced in the wake of the collapse of the staple of Breslau in 1515. However, both staples were reinstated in 1530 and confirmed in 1555, 1624 and 1643. The street via Landsberg was not allowed to be used by transit traffic. The prohibition of shipping on the Oder South of Frankfurt from 1459 was cancelled in 1555 for salt transports; all other commodities had to be transported on the land route. When the Spree was made navigable by the construction of a lock in Fürstenwald in 1588, Frankfurt constructed a storage house there for transshipment to the Frankfurt staple. The staple was abolished in 1752, having been reduced to a monopoly on the linseed trade.

Name: Franzhagen
Settlement_Description: The settlement Lalkau is mentioned in 1230, and abandoned in the 15th century. Between 1572 and 1592, a manor was built by the wife of Duke Franz I of Lauenburg, called Franzhagen.

Name: Frombork
Alternative_Name: Frauenburg; castrum Dominae nostrae; Warmiensis; Frowenburg; Vrowenburch; unser vrowen burk; Wrounburc
Settlement_Description: Around 1270 a castle was built on the remains of an old prussian settlement, it was first mentioned in 1278, there were soon settlers along the castle hill
Town_Description: Originally planned as a town, councilmen and citizens mentioned in 1287, a village major in 1304, soon the Warmian cathedral and the cathedral chapter were resettled from Braunsberg to Frauenburg, a handfast and the Lübeck town law were granted by the Warmian liege bishop Eberhard von Neiße in 1310

Name: Saldus
Settlement_Description: The area was already populated from the 9th to the 13th century. In 1253 it was assigned to the Teutonic Order, that built a castle in the 1370s. A fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') existed in the 16th century.

Name: Frauenwald
Settlement_Description: Veßra monastery has some Premonsaterian Sisters settle in a chapel to St. Nicholas in the Heights of the Thuringian Forest. The monastery "To the ladies in the Wood" ('Zu den Frauen auf dem Wald') forms.
Toll_Description: A toll registry shows the toll that had to be paid on the way across the Thuringian Forest. (LHASA, MD, A 33, O Nr. 77, Erbbuch des Amtes Schleusingen, p. 125, undated; also LHASA, MD, A 33, S I Nr. 3, 1529/30, income toll.)

Name: Freckenhorst
Settlement_Description: The settlement emerges west of the Freckenhorst Abbey; a 'Wigbold' in the late Middle Ages. First mentioned 851.

Name: Fredeburg
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the Mölln enclosure ('landwehr') of the town of Lübeck, which was constructed around 1350. Fredeburg consisted after a drawing from 1594 of a tower guarded with a palisade, and three boom barriers - two from Lübeck and one from Mecklenburg.

Name: Vreren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1078, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Freiberg
Settlement_Description: The place grew out of the village of Christiansdorf; after the laying down of old town in 1170, the town developed into an important trading and mining town in the high medieval period.
Town_Description: The old town probably received its market, town and mining rights when it was founded in 1170; rights renewed at the end of the 13th century and 1433. From 1223 the term ‘civitas’ is used.
Staple_Description: The staple of Freiberg is first mentioned in 1381. The foundation of the Dresden staple led to conflicts with Freiberg about bypassing Freiberg (1466). The staple was confirmed by the Elector of Saxony in 1470.

Name: Bad Freienwalde
Alternative_Name: Bad Freienwalde (Oder); Vrienwolde; Vrienwalde; Frienwalde; Fryenwalde; Freyenwalde
Settlement_Description: Started as a german settlement in between two wendish fishing villages, probably belonging to Pomerania in the late 12th ct., first mentioned in 1316
Town_Description: Exact date of founding is unknown, it was confirmed as a so called 'offene Stad' with a fair in 1364, mentioned as oppidum in 1373 and as civitas in 1375, called a 'stedeken' in 1477

Name: Frenswegen
Settlement_Description: The Augustinian Monastery was founded in 1394 by several distinguished counts and benefactors. Due to its numerous possessions, including farms and from 1578 even the castle in Nordhorn, the monastery received great prestige and grew to be an institution of economic importance. It was closed in 1809.

Name: Freren
Alternative_Name: Friduren; Vrideren; Friderun; Fridderun; Wrederen; Vrederen; Fredderen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a donation charter of the monastery of Corvey. The settlement possibly goes back to a missionary centre founded by the holy Liudger.

Name: Fretzdorf
Settlement_Description: In the second half of the 13th century, Fretzdorf fell into the property of the margraves.

Name: Freudenberg
Alternative_Name: Freudenberghe; Vroethdenberch; Freudenburg; Fraudenberge; Freudenbergk; Freidenberg; Freutenberg
Settlement_Description: The place originated near a castle which was first mentioned in 1389.

Name: Freyburg (Unstrut)
Town_Description: Die town is first mentioned by name in 1203. It is erected in the shadow of the Neuenburg, built around 1076. Its foundation was probably planned. It is referred to as a town several times during the 13th century, even though there is no evidence that town rights were ever granted. First mention of a council in 1410, fist mention of a town constitution in 1446.
Toll_Description: Until 1459 station of safe conduct in the vicinity of Naumburg. Twin safe conduct ('Doppelgeleit') of Markröhlitz. Since 1621 the department had its own regulations of safe conduct and secondary stations.
Fair_Description: Since 1553 two fairs are known.

Name: Freyenstein
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1263, originally an old settlement close to the former castle mound, Altstadt was destroyed during border wars between Werle and Brandenburg
Town_Description: Margrave Johann founded the town in 1278 with Brandenburg town law and the exemption from taxes, returned to the state of a hamlet for a while by the aristocratic rule, fight for the re-establishing of former rights in the 18th ct.

Name: Kożuchów
Settlement_Description: The area was given to the knight Dietrich Stang in 1285 by the Pomesanian diocesan chapter with the right to found a town
Town_Description: The town was founded by the knight Dietrich Stange, so it had to have happened before 1320, the oldest handfast, with Kulm town law, is dated 1331

Name: Friedberg
Settlement_Description: Around 1170 a castle is mentioned, where the town is planned to be laid out until 1200 and was first mentioned in 1216.
Town_Description: For 1216 'Burggravius ​​et castrenses' are mentioned. 1219 'cives' and 1220 'civitas'. The town has had royal charter since 1232.

Name: Strzelce Krajeńskie
Alternative_Name: Friedeberg; Vredeberge; Fredeberg; Vredebrech; Vredberch; Vredeberg; Ffredeberghe; Vrideberg; Friedebergk; Fridenbergk
Settlement_Description: Originally a small slavic settlement in villa Strzelcze
Town_Description: Was built between 1260 and 1270 by the Margrave Konrad of Brandenburg as a fortress against Poland. It was destroyed in 1272 and rebuilt, it was mentioned as a civitas in 1286.

Name: Friedland
Alternative_Name: Vredelant; Vredheland; Fredelande; Fridelan; Vredeburch; Fridlandt
Settlement_Description: Was based on a slavic pre-settlement and was systematically founded in 1244

Name: Altfriedland
Settlement_Description: Mention of a Cistercian convent in 1271, in a record from 1300 an oppidum Vredeland is mentioned. Referred to as little town ('Städtchen') until 1565, but never overcame its status as village.
Toll_Description: Toll station mentioned in 1327.

Name: Friedrichsfelde
Settlement_Description: In 1288 Rosenfelde is first mentioned in the records. In 1319 it becomes property of the town of Berlin, which consigns it to the family of Ryke, who resides there until 1601/02. It is renamed to Friedrichsfelde only in 1699.

Name: Frielingen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1357.

Name: Friens
Alternative_Name: Frenigge; Frenze; Freentze; Friense; Freenze; Freens
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the thirteenth century.

Name: Friesack
Settlement_Description: Early ascanian castle existed in 1216, passed into the possession of a part of the madgeburg ministry official lineage of Jerichow in 1256, a settlement grew close to the castle, mentioned as a plebanus in 1290 and as hus und stat in 1327
Town_Description: The town regulations were passed in 1571 and 1616 by the aristocratic rulers

Name: Friesoythe
Alternative_Name: Oythe; Oyte; Fries Oite; Vrisoyte; Vrysoyte; Vrisuyt; Freyseten
Settlement_Description: A castle of the counts of Tecklenburg was built in the 13th century. At the end of the century, a market settlement is attested, which is mentioned as "oppidum" in 1308.
Town_Description: Friesoythe was fortified after 1338 and had a council constitution in 1366/67 at the latest. Probably the town had town privileges of Osnabrück, from the 17th century of Lemgo.
Toll_Description: A wagon toll of the bishops of Münster, which was levied at the town gates, as well as a shipping toll are mentioned in the 15th century. In 1573 and 1592, there were problems finding a person interested in leasing the toll. This suggests that the toll revenues were limited.
Fair_Description: In the first half of the 14th century, various fairs are mentioned in Friesoyte, on many different days. For these fairs, letters of safe conduct are issued for merchants from Osnabrück. However, it is unclear how long these were organised. In 1369, a fair is still mentioned on Thursday after St John, but in an overview of fairs in Friesoythe from 1497, none of the 14th-century fairs is still mentioned. In their place there are two eight-day fairs, on St Giles and on the day of the Eleven Thousand Virgins. These must have disappeared in the course of the 16th century as well, and two new fairs are founded in 1565, on St Matthew and on the day of the Ten Thousand Martyrs. The importance of these markets was probably limited.
Harbour_Description: The river Soeste was navigable up to Friesoythe.

Name: Frohburg
Settlement_Description: Around 1150 Frohburg was already a castle village, which had town-like character around 1200.

Name: Frohse
Settlement_Description: First settlement was inhabited by Slavs. First mention 936 in a gift certificate to the monastery of Quedlinburg (MGH DD OI, nr. 1, S. 89). Later royal place of residency.
Town_Description: Settlement has own town hall, constitution and administrative bodies, but always stays under the jurisdiction of the archiepiscopal lesser judge ("Möllenvogt"). 1202 is the year of the construction of the two parish churches in the "Old new town". A town council is mentioned in 1396.
Toll_Description: Dean of the cathedral ('Domprobst') Hermann enfeoffs ('belehnt') the vicars in the cathedral with the toll on the Elbe river in the Walwitz in Frohse. In the 15th century (last mention in 1490), there is regular mention of the little toll of Frohse on the Elbe in the Walwitz.

Name: Fuchshain
Settlement_Description: Fist mention as Wuchshol in 1267.

Name: Füchtorf
Alternative_Name: Fiehttharpa; Viehtorpe; Vectorp; Vuchtorpe; Vugthorpe; Voogdorpe; Wuchdorpe; Fuchtruppe
Settlement_Description: The first reference can be dated back to the 11th century.

Name: Fuestrup
Settlement_Description: The village was probably first mentioned around 1050.

Name: Fuhlsbüttel
Alternative_Name: Fulesbutle; Vulesbutle; Wulesbutle; Vulsbyttel; Vulsbuttele; Fulenbuttell; Faulsbuttell; Fulsbuttel; Faulsbüttelschen; Fulesbüttel; Fuelsbüttell
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1283.
Harbour_Description: Harbour on the Alster river. It is known that Hamburg ships sailed to Fuhlsbüttel, where goods were transshipped to land transport, in 1584. In 1618, the Lübeck council was informed that due to closure of the Steindamm, travellers to Hamburg should use the waterway between Bergstedt and Poppenbüttel or Fuhlsbüttel.
Lock_Description: A lock in the Alster river was constructed in 1527 as part of the construction works for the Alster-Trave canal.

Name: Fulda
Alternative_Name: Fulta; Uulda; Fultta; Wldae; Volda; Fulde; Ffulde; Foll
Settlement_Description: A Benedictine monastery was founded in 744. The settlement at the monastery mentioned around 852.
Town_Description: Receipt of town charter under Abbot Marquard I (1150-1165); In 1019 Fulda was given market, customs and minting rights.

Name: Fürstenau
Alternative_Name: Vorstenowe; Vorstenouwe; Verstenouwe; Verstenowe; Forstenauwe; Forstenoe; Vastenowe; Furstenaw; Forstenowe; Vastenouwe; Furstenouw
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed near the castle that was erected in 1344 by Gottfried von Arnsberg, bishop of Osnabrück. It was built as a planned town with limited borough ('weichbild') privileges, which were reiterated in 1402 by bishop Heinrich von Holstein.
Town_Description: Fürstenau acquired Osnabrück town privileges in 1642.
Toll_Description: According to the privileges of 1402, half of the toll in Fürstenau belonged to the bishop of Osnabrück, the other half to the settlement. The toll probably goes back to the time that the castle was built, around 1350. The situation of 1402 was reiterated in 1516 and 1620. The toll was levied predominantly on cattle that was bought in the settlement and its surroundings.

Name: Fürstenberg (Havel)
Alternative_Name: Fürstenberg an der Havel; Fürstenberg/Havel; Vorstenberghe
Settlement_Description: first mentioned in 1278 as a settlement close to a castle
Town_Description: first mentioned as civitas, the first town privilege survives from 1532, most likely a reinstation.

Name: Fürstenberg (Oder)
Settlement_Description: There has most likely been a slavic and later a german castle, the area was named Vorstenbergh in the 13th ct. based on the castle, a slavic settlement is evidenced in 1411
Town_Description: The town was founded late in the 13th ct., it was mentioned as civitas in 1293 and 1300, however it was mentioned as oppidum in 1316, the Magdeburg town law was approved with small changes in 1331 and endored in 1335 and 1371

Name: Fürstenberg (Weser)
Settlement_Description: The castle Fürstenberg is first mentioned as a fief of the Duchy of Brunswick in the middle of the 14th century.
Toll_Description: A toll in Fürstenberg is mentioned in registers from the years 1539, 1541, 1544, 1546 and 1587.

Name: Boleszkowice
Settlement_Description: A german village was founded after 1252, mentioned as oppidum in 1337

Name: Fürstenwald
Settlement_Description: First mentioned 1332.

Name: Fürstenwalde
Alternative_Name: Furstenwald; Furstenwalde; Vurstenwalde; Vuorstenwalde; Vursteinwald; Vursteinwalde
Settlement_Description: Founded just after the middle of the 13th century.
Town_Description: Founded between 1252 and 1258 by the Margraves Johann I. and Otto III., town rights are confirmed in 1285.

Name: Gaarden
Alternative_Name: Gaarden-Ost; Hemminghestorpe; Wulvesbrooke; Villa Ghardin; Gharden; Garden
Settlement_Description: The settlement Gaarden developed from the villages Hemminghestorpe (first mentioned in 1232) and Wulvesbrooke. In 1286, there were 10 farms, 4 cottages and a mill. The name Gaarden for the entire settlement is first attested in 1389.

Name: Gadebusch
Alternative_Name: Godebuz; Ghodebusse; oppidum Gadebusc; Ghotebuz; Ghodebusk; Gadebuz; Godebutz

Name: Gadesbünden
Settlement_Description: The name Gadesbünden is probably derived from "godesbunde", which suggests that the settlement developed from a monastic grange of the monastery of Bassum.
Toll_Description: In 1377, the count of Hoya installed a toll in Gadesbünden of one Turnosgroschen for each horse. In 1380, the toll station is moved to "Stotebrucke" (UB Lüneburg II:945), which however is called "Scotemburge" in a 1382 charter (Hoyer UB I:256); the latter is confirmed in 1583. This location cannot be identified with certainty. In Stöcken near Rethem on the same street, there exists a side street called "Stoßbrücke", but it is not located in the former county of Hoya. "Scotemburge" is identified by Erler as Stoltenburg, a former island in the Weser near Drakenburg, but this identification is rather uncertain as well. Moreover, in the latter case, the toll would have been transformed into a water toll on the Weser river, but it does not appear in any of the Weser toll lists from the 16th century.

Name: Gailhof
Settlement_Description: Year of first mention was 1381.

Name: Gamsen
Alternative_Name: Gamenhusen; Gamenhusin; Gammenhusen; Gamensen; Gammensen; Ghamesen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1214.

Name: Gamstädt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1275.

Name: Ganderkesee
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 860 in the Vita St Willehadi. Bishop Adalbert of Bremen founded a church with a law court ('sendkirche') here in 1050. The settlement developed into an important market place in the Middle Ages.

Name: Bad Gandersheim
Alternative_Name: Gandersheim; Gandersen; Gandesheim; Gandeshemense; Gantheresheim; Gandertzen
Settlement_Description: Originally a small village to the northwest of the later town. The monastery of canonesses, founded in 852 in nearby Brunshausen, moved to Gandersheim in 881. The monastery settlement acquired market privileges around 990.
Town_Description: Gandersheim acquired town privileges in the 13th century; these were reiterated in 1330.
Toll_Description: The monastery Gandersheim acquired the right to levy a transit toll for merchants travelling between the Rhine and Elbe and Saale rivers in 877. According to an overview of tolls in the duchy of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel from 1582, the toll in Gandersheim was calculated by weight of the cargo.

Name: Gangelt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 828, when the place was in the possession of the king.
Town_Description: In the 14th century, the town was referred to as an 'oppidum'.
Toll_Description: The Duke of Brabant-Limburg levied a land toll in 1396. Around 1400, the toll was pledged several times. In 1420 the toll passed to the Lord of Heinsberg, in 1483 to the Duke of Jülich. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Gangloffsömmern
Settlement_Description: First mention 802.

Name: Garbolzum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 12th century.

Name: Gardelegen
Settlement_Description: In the Early Middle Ages Gardelegen already was a village with a castle from the 10th century. First secure mention occurs in 1121. In 1196 it is given to the archbishop of Magdeburg. Expanded to a town at the end of the 12th century.
Town_Description: Referred to as civitas in 1241. Magdeburg town rights can be proven for around 1290; since 1358 member of the Hanse.
Toll_Description:
In 1483 the town of Gardelegen is granted a dam- and road fee from loaded wagons and half the fee from unloaded wagons in order to maintain the roads.
In 1533 a secondary station of safe conduct of the toll in Gardelegen is established in Wegenstedt, so travellers could choose between the routes via Oebisfelde or Gardelegen.
Fair_Description: In 1579 the privileges for Gardelegen's four fairs are renewed. The Mid-lent-fair is cancelled and a new fair on Monday after Michaelis is established. Each fair lasted four days, with a cattle market at the beginning of the fair.

Name: Garderen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1245.

Name: Garmerwolde
Alternative_Name: Germerwolt; Germerwalda; Gedmerawalda; Gedmawalda; Germerawalda; Garmerwolde; Garmarwolde; Germerwolde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1288, in a sixteenth- seventeenth century copy.

Name: Gardeja
Settlement_Description: A settlement on old-Prussian remains belonging to the knight Dietrich Stange before 1285, the Cistercian Order of Pelplin unsuccessfully planned a new monastery in 1285, mentioned as a village in 1323
Town_Description: Founded by the bishop of Pomesania in 1328, the founding documents are lost, the oldest handfast survives from 1334 with Kulm town law, after being destroyed by a fire in 1554 it was rebuilt in 1559

Name: Garrel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1408.

Name: Garrelsweer
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1057, in a copy dating from fourteenth century.

Name: Garoza
Settlement_Description: The manor was given as fief in 1556.

Name: Garsena
Settlement_Description: Mention of lords of Corzene in 1286.

Name: Garßen
Alternative_Name: Garssen; Gadereshusun; Gatheradeshusen; Gerswide; Gerswede; Gerstwede; Gersnede; Gersnethe; Ghersene; Gersne; Gertzen; Gherssen; Gerssen; Gherdessen; Garsen; Garszen; Garsszen; Gerssen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 986-988.

Name: Gartow
Alternative_Name: Garttowe; Chartowe; Gartowe; Ghartowe; Ghartow; Gartou; Gartaw
Settlement_Description: A castle of the lords of Gartow is first mentioned in 1225. The adjoining settlement was referred to as a minor town or borough ('stedeken') from 1360; between 1360 and 1438 there was a monastery of the Knights Hospitaller in Gartow.

Name: Gartz
Settlement_Description: Site of a slawic fortress, later the see of a castellan in 1236, market settlement
Town_Description: Duke Barnim I. of Pomerania granted the Magdeburg town law
Staple_Description: Duke Barnim proclaimed in 1271 that only citizens of Gartz were allowed to buy corn in Stettin, and limited the right to ship corn outside the town. In 1325 and 1328, Gartz acquired the right to hold back commodities intended for Stettin, if cargoes destined for Gartz were held back in Stettin, and merchants travelling between Stettin and Schwedt had to use the road through Gartz. A full staple privilege with a compulsory duration of one day for corn, beer, venison, butter and cattle was granted in 1397; a three-day staple for beer and wine followed in 1464.

Name: Garz
Settlement_Description: Former Slavic settlement; in the first decade of the 13th century the German village was founded.

Name: Garze
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1368/1369.

Name: Gassel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1306.

Name: Gasselte
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1302.

Name: Gasthuis
Alternative_Name: Gasthuyis; Gasthuys; Opgasthuis; Out Gasthuys; ’t Gasthuis; Gasthaus
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1450.

Name: Gautzsch
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as manor in 1216

Name: Gebesee
Settlement_Description: Karoloingian royal court. Market rights were granted in 1334. Referred to as borough ('Flecken') since 1465.
Town_Description: Johann Georg of Saxony granted town rights in 1638, even though the town was called borough ('Flecken') until 1816.

Name: Geel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a copy dating circa 1243 from a document dating circa 1155.

Name: Geertruidenberg
Alternative_Name: Montem Sancte Gertrudis; Monte Sancte Gertrudis; Sinte Gheerdenbergen; Sente Gherdene Bergh; Sinte Gheertruden Berghe; tsente Geertruydenberghe; Mons Sancte Gertrudis
Settlement_Description: Geertruidenberg is first mentioned in written records in 1213. However, a trade settlement existed at the place long before 1213.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted on 21 September 1213 by William I, count of Holland. Between 1323-1325 a castle is built near Geertruidenberg and stone wall may have been added to the town in 1319 (although it is possible that Geertruidenberg was already walled before that year).

Name: Geeste
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 890.

Name: Geesthacht
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1216. The village belonged to Hamburg and Lübeck jointly between 1420 and 1867.
Toll_Description: In 1216, Hamburg was exempted from the toll in Geesthacht. Likely, this was an im- and export toll for commodities like wood and salt that where shipped on the Elbe river. The toll is once again mentioned when Geesthacht was pawned to Lübeck in 1370.

Name: Gefell
Settlement_Description: The settlement was probably founded in the 11th century by Kirchberg castle. Referred to as borough ('Flecken') in 1416. If the village owned town rights is unclear. A town constitution remains from the 15th century.

Name: Geffen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1246, in a fifteenth century copy.

Name: Gehlenbeck
Settlement_Description: A farm in Gehlenbeck is mentioned in ca. 1100.

Name: Gehren (Ilmenau)
Settlement_Description: Church village with knightly manor in the 13th and 14th century. Market- and town borough ('Markt- und Stadtflecken') in the 16th century. Since Gehren owned town-like rights and facilities, it was granted town status in 1855.
Toll_Description: Regulations of safe conduct remain for the district of Gehren from the 16th century (ThStA Rudolstadt, Kanzlei Arnstadt 1129, p. 93).

Name: Gehrenrode
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1228.

Name: Geisleden
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1022, when property in Geisleden is given to the monastery in Heiligenstadt. A noble family of Geisleden is proven.

Name: Geismar
Settlement_Description: A knightly manor ist known in Geismar.

Name: Geldern
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in the 10th century.
Town_Description: In the 13th century, the place was confirmed as a town.
Toll_Description: 1) The Duke of Guelders levied a land toll here in 1393/94. Tariffs are not known. In 1397 the annual revenue was 26 gulden and 14 groschen.1469/70 this was leased out for 12 gulden. 2) In 1462, the duke levied a fee for save conduct on land. The annual yield in 1462/63 was 2 marks and 6 shillings. 3) In 1386, the duke also levied a road toll. The average annual yield from 1386 to 1399 was about 48 marks 3 shillings and 7 pfennige.
Fair_Description: It is unclear when the fairs in Geldern were first granted, they are first mentioned in 1343/44

Name: Geldrop
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1302.

Name: Gelnhausen
Alternative_Name: Barbarossastadt Gelnhausen; Geilenhusen; Geilnhusen; Gelenhusen; Geilinhusin; Geylnhusen; Gellhause
Settlement_Description: Presumably the place comes from a Carolingian settlement; in the High Middle Ages the political and economic boom took place.
Town_Description: Barbarossa founded the imperial town with a palatinate.

Name: Gendringen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention circa 1100.

Name: Genemuiden
Alternative_Name: Genemuden; Geynmuden; Genemuyde; Genemuden; Ghenemuden; Gelemuiden; Geelmuyen; Genemuyden; Gellemuden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 14 January 1275, when town privileges are granted to Genemuiden.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted by Jan I of Nassau, bishop of Utrecht, on 14 January 1275.

Name: Gennep
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 949.
Town_Description: On 6 January 1371, town privileges are being confirmed by Reginald (Reinoud) of Brederode, lord of Gennep, and Joanna (Johanna) of Gennep. Town privileges have thus been granted before 1371.

Name: Gent
Alternative_Name: Gandensis; Ganda; Gandauum; Ganth; Gend; Ghent; Gand;
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in first kwart of the eighth century in a tenth century copy. Next mention in 819. Next mention in 819-840 , in a eleventh- twelfth century copy.
Staple_Description: In 1251, a staple between Aardenburg and Ghent was prohibited. It was prohibited to manufacture cloth within five miles of Ghent in 1314; in 1338 to trade woad within the same area, and yarn within three miles. A corn staple was introduced in 1343, whereby half of the corn from the region around the city had to be stored within the town. Conflicts with Ypres because of the corn staple were solved in favour of Ghent in 1424, and it was further enforced in 1484. Further fixation of the grain stapel in 1484: a quarter of the corn shipped through the city and all corn grown in Flanders had to be offered to the local population for 8-14 days. In 1486 and 1514, the staple was reiterated. The forced offering of commodities for sale was abolished in 1540, but in in its place came a forced transshipment between Scheldt and Leie, and in 1547 for the Sassevaart. The staple was reinstated in 1587, with the exception of all commodities intended for personal use of the merchants.

Name: Genthin
Settlement_Description: The village emerges from a Slavic settlement named Plote, which today is a part of Genthin; after that German knightly manor with water castle; in 1160 establishment of a market; Market village ('Marktflecken') since 1413.
Town_Description: Referred to as oppidum, since 1562 borough ('Flecken').
Toll_Description: Mention of Plote as a toll station in the context of Jerichow in 1432. Possibly confused with Klietznick in the mention, however it is mentioned as a toll station in other places as well.
Fair_Description: Since 1539 markets privileged by cardinal Albrecht took place in Genthin.

Name: Gera
Settlement_Description: In Slavic times there already was a castle; in the 12th century it was expanded to a town-like settlement. Proof of a coin mint in 1180.
Town_Description: Referred to as oppidum and cives. The mentioned town rights from 1292 point towards Magdeburg rights. First remaining town rights from 1487.

Name: Jersika
Settlement_Description: In 1209 the area was conquered by the Teutonic Order. The castle was destroyed in 1239.

Name: Gerdau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1004.

Name: Zheleznodorozhnyy
Settlement_Description: A castle of the Teutonic Order was built in 1325 to replace the Prussian castle, a settlement grew close to it
Town_Description: The Grand Master Konrad von Jungingen elevates the place to a town with Kulm town law in 1398

Name: Gernrode
Alternative_Name: Rode; Gerenrode; Geronisroth; Geronrod; Gerenrodun; Gerenroht
Settlement_Description: First mention in 961; In 960 margrave Leo endowed a convent, near which a settlement grew (it is mentioned in the records in 1136). Borough ('Weichbild') in 1416.
Town_Description: Town rights in 1519 by abess Anna of Plauen.

Name: Gerzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Geseke
Alternative_Name: Geiske; Gescen; Gesiki; Gisici; Gesize; Gieseke; Geseche; Gesici; Gession; Gesecho; Geseca; Gysike; Geyseke; Gesicke; Geiseke; Geysecke
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 833.
Town_Description: A town founded by Cologne around 1220 with Rüthener rights. An urban seal has been preserved from 1237.

Name: Gesmold
Alternative_Name: Gesmeri; Gesmele; Geyzmele; Gesmello; Gesmen; Gismel;
Settlement_Description: A first mention between 1027 and 1037 is uncertain. The settlement is first mentioned reliably in 1160.

Name: Gestel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1173.

Name: Gevelsberg
Alternative_Name: Gyevilberch; Givelberg; Givelberch; Gyvelberc; Gevelsberch; Gevelberg
Settlement_Description: First mention of the Cistercian monastery there in 1225. Then pilgrimage site.

Name: Giebichenstein
Settlement_Description: Early mention of a "civitas" or "urbs" Giebichenstein in connection with Halle (Saale). Halle itself is only mentioned in 1064 in wirtten records, which leads to believe that Giebichenstein was the administrative center of Halle (Saale). In 937, Otto III gave the rights of toll, ban and coin in Giebichenstein to the monastary of St. Mauritius in Magdeburg (MGH DD OIII no. 34, S. 433f.).
Toll_Description: The archbishop of Magdeburg pawned the toll and road toll of Burg Giebichenstein to the council of Halle in 1281, in order to regain posession of the castle.

Name: Gieboldehausen
Alternative_Name: Gebehildehusen; Ghevoldehusen; Geuoldehusen; Geueldehusen; Giebeldehusin; Gebeldehaussen; Gibeldehausen; Gieboldshausen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1003. A castle of the dukes of Brunswick was pawned to the archbishop of Mainz in the 14th century. The settlement is mentioned as borough ('flecken') since 1450.
Toll_Description: The toll in Gieboldehausen, belonging to the dukes of Brunswick, was acquired by the lords of Minnigerode in 1518. Around 1600, the duke tried to acquire the toll again. A toll house in the village is mentioned in 1596.
Fair_Description: The privilege for two fairs is granted in 1607 by emperor Rudolf II.

Name: Giehle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1187

Name: Giershagen
Alternative_Name: Upspringun; Obsprinchen; Opspringe; Upspringe; Gyrshagen; Girshagen; Gierßhagen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 949. In the 16th century the original place name "Upsprunge" was replaced.

Name: Giesenslage
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1200.

Name: Gießen
Alternative_Name: Giezzen; Giezin; Gizen; Gyzen; Giezen; Gizzen; Gyssin; Giessen; Gezin; Gysind; Gyßen; Gieße; Gyßheym
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1197. A castle was built in 1150.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted in 1248.

Name: Giessendam
Alternative_Name: Hardinxveld-Giessendam; Gysendam; dore den dam van Oltghiesen in die Merwede; den dammen van Giessen; de halvendamme sterven in die Ghiessen leghet; Ghiesendamme; Gyessendamme; Giesendam Giesendam
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1230.

Name: Gietelo
Alternative_Name: Getlo; Gietel; Gheetlo; Getele; Geitlo; Ghytelo; Geetlo; Gyetelo; Ghietelo; Geetelo
Settlement_Description: Earliest undoubted mention in 1299. In 1050, 'Getlo' is named as a place close to Deventer. Probably, Gietelo is meant here.

Name: Gieten
Alternative_Name: Geten; Gheyten; Gheten; Ghethen; Geyten; Gheeten
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1223.

Name: Gifhorn
Settlement_Description: Gifhorn came into existence at an important crossing of the Aller river, where a castle is first mentioned in 1196. The settlement next to the castle was granted market privileges by duke Johann of Lüneburg in 1275. Mentioned as "oppidum" in 1332; borough ('weichbild') rights were granted in 1364; characterised as borough ('flecken') in 1544-1640.
Toll_Description: A toll station of the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg in Gifhorn is first mentioned in 1303/1330. Toll tariffs are known from the 16th century (StAB).

Name: Gifkendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1283.

Name: Gildehaus
Settlement_Description: The settlement was called Nyenkerken until the 14th century, after the local church of St Anne. Between the 13th and the 19th century, the settlement was an exporter of the local sandstone.

Name: Dąbrówno
Settlement_Description: In 1316 the castle Ilien was the see of an 'Ordenspfleger' and it was close to three Prussian castle mounds
Town_Description: The komtur of Christburg, duke Luther von Braunschweig founded the town in 1326

Name: Gispersleben
Alternative_Name: Gispersleben Kiliani; Gispotisleyben; Gispesleuben; Gispotisleben; Kisperslebe; Gispersleibin
Settlement_Description: Mention in a record from 1143 as Gispotisleyben, it probably existed in prehistoric times. Later half of the village was property of the counts of Gleichen.

Name: Gittelde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 965, at which time there already existed a market, toll and a royal mint. The settlement is mentioned as borough ('flecken') in 1496.

Name: Gitter
Alternative_Name: Gitter auf dem Berge; Geizheres; Gaeteri; Iehthere; Jaitterem; Geter; Gythere; Gitere
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 8th or 9th century. After the saltworks in nearby Salzgitter were developed around 1300, the original village Gitter acquired the addition "auf dem Berge".

Name: Glandorf
Alternative_Name: Glanathorpe; Glandorpe; Clandorpe; Oistendorffer; Glaendorp; Dörpffer; Dorff
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1074.

Name: Glane
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1088.

Name: Glasau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1304.

Name: Gleidingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 990.

Name: Gliesmarode
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1031. In Gliesmarode, there stood a watch tower of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Braunschweig, for which the oldest evidence dates from 1387.

Name: Glimmen
Alternative_Name: Glemmene; Glimine; Glumme; Glumne; Glemne; Glymmen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in twelfth century.

Name: Glinde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1229.

Name: Głogów
Staple_Description: Staple for fish, salt and mill stones, confirmed in 1477 and 1511. The staple was under constant pressure from Frankfurt and Breslau, which tried to limit all traffic crossing the Oder river to both towns.

Name: Gloine
Settlement_Description: Mentioned 1187 as the property of Leitzkau monastery. Later property of the archbishopric of Magdeburg and later the district of Loburg. In 1645 reported thoroughly deserted. Bought in 1898 by the German military for the establishment of a military training area.

Name: Gnandstein
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as manor, around 1402 mentioned as knightly manor.

Name: Gniezno
Staple_Description: Around 1440, the town started to force merchants to offer their commodities for sale on the market.

Name: Gnoien
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1258, the bailiff had his see there.
Town_Description: Mentioned as civitas in 1290, confirmation of the Rostocker and Lübecker town law, privileges have been renewed multiple times, mentioned as 'Städtlein' and town in 1353.

Name: Goch
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the second half of the 11th century.
Town_Description: Referred to as a town from 1261.
Toll_Description: The Duke of Geldern and the town of Goch levied a road toll before 1372. Tariffs and revenues have not been handed down.

Name: Bad Godesberg
Toll_Description: The Archbishop of Cologne levied a land toll in 1331. This included road toll and carriage toll ('Karrenzoll'). In 1470, 4 denarii per ox had to be paid. In 1381/82, an annual average of 156 mark 4 shillings in road toll was collected. In 1382/83 it was 85 mark 2 shillings. In 1381/82, 206 mark were collected per year, in 1382/83 209 mark per carriage. In the 15th century, there was no longer a distinction between road toll and carriage toll.

Name: Gohfeld
Alternative_Name: Gouelde; Govelde; Ghofelde: Goveldo; Ghouelde; Gofeld; Goefelde; Coofeldt; Coveldt; Gofeldt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1224.

Name: Goingarijp
Alternative_Name: Goaiïngaryp; Godinriip; Goyngrip; Gohimriip; Goyngriip; Goynghryp
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the thirteenth century.

Name: Gokels
Alternative_Name: Ghekelse; Ghekelsse; Gokelße; Gogelße; Gokelse; Gockels

Name: Gołdap
Settlement_Description: House and yard of a ducal private (Wildschütze) in 1551, ducal sheep farm with adjoining village
Town_Description: The founding was planned for 1565, founded between 1566 and 1570 along the remains of two villages, organised by a locator and the ducal councilman Kaspar von Nositz, Duke Albrecht Friedrich signed the documents in 1570 and granted Kulm town law

Name: Kullamaa
Settlement_Description: The parish of Goldenbeck is mentioned in 1364.

Name: Goldenstedt
Settlement_Description: The first mention of 1080 is recorded in a 14th-century copy.

Name: Kuldīga
Settlement_Description: Between 1242 and 1245 a castle was built, which was named Jesusborg.
Town_Description: The fortified borough ('Hakelwerk'), which originated in the 14th century, received town rights of Riga in 1347. It was Hanseatic town since 1368. In the Middle Ages, the town was an important transshipment point from water to land vehicles.

Name: Gollensdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1319.

Name: Gollmenz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1350, mention as knightly manor in 1445/47.

Name: Goleniów
Alternative_Name: Gollnow; Golinog; Golenoge; Golnow; Gollenog; Vredeheyde
Settlement_Description: There has most likely been a wendish settlement but a castrum hasn't been proven. It was mentioned as a settlement in 1255.
Town_Description: Founded with Magdeburg town law in 1268 by Duke Barnim I of Pomerania. Lübeck town law was later granted in 1314 by Duke Otto I.

Name: Golßen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1276 as Golsyn. In 1301 a castle is mentioned.
Town_Description: The settlement gained the character and rights of a town in the course of the 14th century, as well as a town constitution in 1372. It only held mediocre meaning though.

Name: Golzow
Settlement_Description: A castle probably existed since the 2nd half of the 12th century. Mentions of Golzow as a castle since 1219. The village of Golzow is referred to as little town ('Stadechen') in 1335 and 1451, but never earned town rights.
Toll_Description: Already mentioned in 1335 as a toll station, again in 1525.

Name: Gommern
Settlement_Description: Since 948 a German settlement with castle district ('Burgward'), before a Slavic settlement; gained borough rights ('Marktfleckenrecht') in the 16th century.

Name: Goor
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1027-1054 (in a copy from the second half of the twelfth century).
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted by Henry (Hendrik) van Vianden, bishop of Utrecht on 16 September 1263.

Name: Gordemitz
Settlement_Description: First mention as Gurdunewice in 1156.
Bridge_Description: Maintenance of the bridge had to be undertaken by the town of Leipzig.

Name: Gorinchem
Alternative_Name: Gornichem; Gurinchem; Gorichem; Ghorchem; Gorckum; Gorchvm; Gorcom; Gorkum; Ghorinchem; Goerinchem
Settlement_Description: Gorinchem is first mention about 1200 (document is fourteenth-century copy). In the thirteenth century, it was a trade settlement near a castle.
Town_Description: Dordrecht was granted town privileges on 11 November 1382 by Otto, lord of Arkel. During the reign of William VI, count of Holland (r. 1404-1417), the castle near Gorinchem was demolished and a smaller castle was built in the town itself.

Name: Górzyca
Settlement_Description: Slavic settlement was mentioned in 1405 as well as a castle with strong slavic fortification, mentioned as a hamlet in 1258 and an oppidum in 1317

Name: Görlitz
Alternative_Name: Goreliz; Yzhorelik; Gorliz; Zgorliz; Gorlizc; Zhorjelc
Settlement_Description: By the 11/12th century there were boroughs with a Bohemian castle. Previously settled by Slavs, it was an important junction for long distance trade.
Town_Description: The old town was laid out around 1200, and expanded with the addition of a new town around 1250.
Staple_Description: A staple for woad was granted in 1339 and confirmed in the Golden Bull of 1356, but was probably enjoyed earlier. Woad traders in the Margraviate of Bautzen needed to travel through Görlitz and were not allowed to bypass the city. In a settlement of 1340 the length of the staple right was set at four weeks.

Name: Görsbach
Settlement_Description: First mention in the record book of Fulda monastery.

Name: Gorssel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1275.

Name: Gortel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the fourteenth century.

Name: Görzke
Settlement_Description: A castle with a castle district were probably the origins of this settlement.
Town_Description: In 1283 the term civitas can be found, the systematic foundation of the town by the margraves of Brandenburg probably occurred around 1250. Mention of a council in 1355, in 1378 a mayor and a council are mentioned. During the 30-year war the place was mostly destroyed and lost its town privileges.
Toll_Description: Electoral Brandeburg gains the rights of safe conduct.

Name: Göschwitz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1425.

Name: Goslar
Alternative_Name: Gosleri; Gosilare; Goslaria; Gozlare; Gosler; Gosseler; Goselare; Goslarie; Goßlar
Settlement_Description: Founded by king Henry I around 922; first mentioned in 1005.
Town_Description: The development of the market town Goslar was driven by the exploitation of the Rammelsberg mines. Goslar already had town-like characteristics in the 11th century. Official representatives of the market settlement are mentioned in 1108, and it was characterised as "civitas" in 1131. The first town right exists from 1320, which codified the privileges granted by Emperor Frederick II in 1219. Goslar became Free Imperial City in the first half of the 14th century.
Fair_Description: Dates for fairs in Goslar are not known.

Name: Gößnitz
Settlement_Description: The advantageous position in the network of long-distance trade led to a economical boost of the village in the 15th century. The village only gained town rights in 1718.

Name: Gotha
Settlement_Description: The existing settlement became a royal court in the 8th/9th century, which owned a castle in the 11th centruy; because of its advantageous position in the traffic network the settlement developed into a market village, which mostly traded grain in the 16th century.
Town_Description: Around 1168 Gotha was owned by the landgraves of Thuringia, who promoted road construction. Awarding of town rights probably around the end of the 12th century (1180/1189). Gotha had Gotha Eisenach town rights.
Toll_Description: Toll- and regulations of safe conduct remain for the town of Gotha from the 16th century (ThStA Gotha, Kammer Stadt Gotha 66 Nr. 222).
Fair_Description: The toll- and regulations of safe conduct from the 16th century mention fairs in Gotha, during which the toll is doubled.

Name: Gottorf
Settlement_Description: A castle was built by the bishop of Schleswig after 1161; owned by the dukes of Schleswig since 1268.
Toll_Description: The royal Danish toll station at Gottorf was one of the transit tolls with the highest revenues. Total revenues for 1485 amounted to 2352 Lübeck mark; in 1491 2813 Lübeck mark and in 1519 4154 Lübeck mark. Detailed toll registers are available for the years 1484-1704, with lacunae for some years (Landesarchiv Schleswig-Holstein, Schleswig and Rigsarkivet, Copenhagen). For the period 1484-1519, these have been analysed by Schwetlik, and by Wiese for the oxen transports.

Name: Gouda
Settlement_Description: Gouda was first mention in a (+/-) 1420 copy from a text dated 1143. It originated from a castle. In the eleventh and twelfth century, cultivations ('ontginningen') took place on the banks of the River Gouwe close to this castle. A port was constructed in 1225, after which Gouda grew into an important trade settlement.
Town_Description: Gouda was granted town rights on 19 July 1272 by Floris V, count of Holland. In the 1350s, fortifications were added to the town.

Name: Govelin
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1360. The settlement consisted of 3 farms.

Name: Göxe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1260

Name: Grabow (Elde)
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed out of a 12th-century Slavic castle. A german castle was first mentioned in 1186, a parish in 1230-1235.
Town_Description: Founded by the Duke of Dannenberg for military reasons. The founding privilege from 1252 is a forgery, but the privileges are confirmed in 1317. The town is mentioned as a civitas with Lübeck town law in 1354, and as oppidum in 1355.

Name: Grabow (Wendland)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330/52. In 1450, the village consisted of 11 farms, which were later turned into two noble manors (the Ober- and Untergut) and a folwark.

Name: Gräfenhainichen
Alternative_Name: domino Burchardo de Indagine; mit deme Hayn; Gravinalbrechtishayn; Grefinheynchin
Settlement_Description: Foundation of the settlement in the High Middle Ages, formerly under Anhaltinian suzerainty ('Lehnshoheit').
Town_Description: The year of the awarding of town rights is unknown. However, in 1454 existing town rights were confrimed, which leads to assume that privileges were granted at the beginning of the 14th century.
Toll_Description: A regulation of safe conduct remains from 1550 (LHASA, MD, d. 16, Nr. 17 1a, Erbbuch des Amtes Gräfenhainichen 1550).

Name: Gräfenthal
Settlement_Description: The counts of Orlamünde owned a castle in Gräfenthal. They granted the place bylaws in 1412. In 1462 finalisation of the mining station ('Saigerhütte') in Gräfenthal, which confirms its meaning at the copper road ('Kupferweg').
Toll_Description:
Toll station at the route of safe conduct Coburg - Saalfeld, proven since 1446.
The regulations of safe conduct for Saalfeld from 1728, which were also valid fof Gräfenthal, explicitly state that a road toll had to be paid together with the fees of safe conduct.

Name: Gräfentonna
Settlement_Description: First mention in 845 as the property of Fulda monastery, the whole area of Gräfentonna has been settled since the Stone Ages, however. It served as the residence of the counts of Tonna, later the counts of Gleichen. It was only granted market rights 1785.

Name: Grafhorst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1277.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted by Jan III of Diest, bishop of Utrecht, on 20 April 1333.

Name: Gräfinau
Settlement_Description: First mention of Gräfinau in 1282; First mention of Angstedt possibly as early as 869 - 891.
Toll_Description: Toll regulations from 1566 settle the fees that had to be paid in Angstedt.

Name: Gräfinghausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in ca. 1260. The settlement probably already existed before the 9th century.

Name: Grambke
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1200.

Name: Gramsbergen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1227.
Town_Description: Gramsbergen is mentioned as a town ('stedeken') in a charter of 13 August 1442. The small town was closely related to the lord of Gramsbegen, who hold the right to inn taxes from its inhabitants, and who appointed the members of the town government.

Name: Gramzow
Town_Description: First mentioned as a town in 1288, in 1586 it is merely referred to as borough ('Flecken').
Toll_Description: There's a large and small toll in the town.
Fair_Description: The fair in Gramzow is moved to Vierraden in 1733.

Name: Grande
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1248.

Name: Gransee
Alternative_Name: Stad Gransoyge; Granzoge; Gransowe; Cransehe; Gransoyge; Granzoye; Gransoy
Town_Description: Margrave Johann I. of Brandenburg granted the Brandenburg (Magdeburg) town law in 1262

Name: Grasdorf (Leine)
Alternative_Name: Grasdorf; Gravestorp; Gravestorpe; Grastorpp; Graßtorff; Graustorff; Graßdorff
