Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1235.

Name: Grasdorf (Innerste)
Alternative_Name: Grasdorf; Gravestorp; Gravesthorp; Grasthorp; Gravesdorp; Gravestorpe; Graßdorff; Großdorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1131.
Toll_Description: In the town accounts of Hildesheim from 1444, there are records of toll being paid in Grasdorf.

Name: Grathem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1116, in a sixteenth century copy.

Name: Graudupes
Settlement_Description: Private property of the Teuring family from Goldingen, which was first mentioned in 1616.

Name: Grave
Settlement_Description: Grave presumably originates from 1133 or later, as an allodium of the lords of Cuijk (Van Kuyc). Earliest mention dates from 1214.
Town_Description: Town privileges presumably granted before 1279, by John I of Cuijk. In 1323, Otto of Cuijk grants Grave in fee to the duke of Brabant. On 15 December 1400, the city acknowledges duke William I of Guelders as its lord.
Fair_Description: All fairs in Grave were specialized markets. On the two fairs which already existed in 1456, horses and cloth were traded. The two new ones instituted in 1456 by Arnold, duke of Guelders, on the request of the town council, were meant specifically for cattle and horse trading.

Name: Grebehna
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1219.
Toll_Description: Zwochau was a secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Delitzsch.

Name: Grebenstein
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1272 in the context of a castle at Grebenstein.
Town_Description: Was granted town privileges in 1324. The new town was founded in 1356 and united with the old town in 1370.

Name: Greene
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 980.

Name: Gryfice
Alternative_Name: Greifenberg; Griphenberch super Regam; Gryphimontani; Greiffenberg; nova civitas super Regam
Town_Description: The town was founded without a prior settlement with Lübeck town law before 1262 by duke Wartislaw III. The locator was Jakob von Treptow. The founding was endorsed in 1264 by Barnim I.

Name: Gryfino
Settlement_Description: A slavic settlement with agricultural character and a market, a german merchant settlement grew close by.
Town_Description: Duke Barnim I granted the Madgeburg (later the Lübeck) town law in 1254. Rudolph von Belekow and his sons served as locators.

Name: Greifswald
Alternative_Name: Grifeswold; Gripeswold; Gripheswald; Gripeswald; Grifeswolde; Gripeswalt; Gripeswald
Settlement_Description: settlement affiliated with the saltworks first mentioned in 1193, since 1209 owned by the Cistercian monastery Eldena, marketsettlement since 1241, mentioned in 1248 as 'oppidum'
Town_Description: Wartislaw III. of Pomerania grants the Lübeck town law and constitution

Name: Grembergen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1019-1030.

Name: Greußen
Settlement_Description: First mention in the record book of Fulda monastery.
Town_Description: The oldest bylaws are known from 1556, however in the same instance older bylaws are mentioned. Keyser assumes that those are the bylaws of Clingen from 1353. Since Greußen was referred to as villa in 1268, the bestowal of town rights must have taken place afterward.
Toll_Description: In 1389, the council of Greußen raises the toll on woad from Mühlhausen.

Name: Greven (Ems)
Settlement_Description: The place is a Franconian settlement and 'Kirchdorf', which was first mentioned around 890. At the beginning of the 13th century there was a market.

Name: Grevenbroich
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 962.
Town_Description: The place was given town rights around 1300.
Toll_Description: The Count of Kessel levied a land toll here in 1273. From the beginning of the 14th century, the place came into the possession of the Count of Jülich. It is therefore unclear whether the toll continued to exist. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Grevenkrug
Settlement_Description: The settlement is not named after an inn ('krug').

Name: Grevesmühlen
Alternative_Name: Gnewesmulne; Gnewismulne; Gneuesmholen; Greuiszmhulenn; Grevismühlen; Gnewismolen; Grevesmolen; Gevismühlen
Settlement_Description: Founding of a German village in the Land of Bresen in 1230, previously inhabited by Slavs. The village became the seat of the local administrative unit ('vogtei') Gnewesmolen before 1242.

Name: Grießem
Alternative_Name: Grismere; Gryszem; Gosme; Grysme; Grißme; Grießheim
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 12th century.

Name: Grijpskerk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1500.

Name: Grimlinghausen
Toll_Description: The Archbishop of Cologne levied a land toll here from 1386. Exact tariffs are not known. Presumably 4 white pennies ('Weißpfennige'/Albus) had to be paid for every horse. Revenues were 20 mark in 1386/87, 22 in 1392/93, 80 in 1442/43 and in 1444/45. Additionally, in 1479 Grimlingshausen was mentioned as a secondary toll station of Neuss. Accounts from 1583-4 show that the revenue was very low; presumably it was abandoned afterwards because of insignificance. In 1630, the toll is no longer mentioned.

Name: Grimma
Toll_Description: Toll- and safe conduct regulations remain from 1390, 1524/25 and 1621.
Fair_Description: The regulations of safe conduct from 1390 also come with the privilege for two fairs.

Name: Grimmen
Settlement_Description: settlement of the late Iron Age close to one of the most important trade routes, probably wendish settlement close to where the fortress of the Dukes of Rügen stood in the 14th. Ct.
Town_Description: Founding year of the town unknown, first mentioned in 1267, Lübeck town law, town council mentioned in 1306

Name: Joachimsthal
Settlement_Description: A glassmaker's settlement existed since 1577, which was revived in 1601.
Town_Description: Town foundation in 1603

Name: Grobina
Settlement_Description: An important sea trading centre in the early Middle Ages. In 1245 there was a castle, which was destroyed in 1262. In 1464 the already existing fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was expanded.

Name: Gröblingen
Alternative_Name: Grupilingi; Grupilinga; Gropelinge; Gropelinc; Groppelingen; Gropelinghen; Gropling
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1001.

Name: Groenlo
Alternative_Name: Gronlo; Grunlo; Groenloe; Grolloe; Grol; Grolle
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1188.
Town_Description: Mentioned as 'cives de Gronlo' in 1251. Earliest mention as a town in 1273. Town privileges received on 1 December 1277 by Reginald I, count of Guelders.
Fair_Description: Around 1440, a market took place in Groenlo of which it is unknown how old it was, and whether it concerned a daily or weekly market, or a fair. The market had a local function: it was visited by inhabitants of the neighbouring small principality of Borculo.

Name: Groesbeek
Alternative_Name: Gronspech; Gronesbeke; Grunsbek; Groesbeke; Grosebecke; Grunzebeke; Grunzenbeke; Grusbeke; Groisbeeck
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1040.

Name: Grolloo
Alternative_Name: Grunlo; Groenlo; Grolle; Groelle; Grollo; Grolloe
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention probably in twelfth century. Next mention dates from 1298-1304.

Name: Gronau (Westfalen)
Settlement_Description: The castle Bocholte at the bridge across the Dinkel near Spechtholte was first mentioned 1365. The name Gronau for the accompanying settlement first appears in 1371. It developed into a town-like settlement or borough ('wibbolde'), as it is first attested in 1487.

Name: Grönebach
Alternative_Name: Grunebeke; Grunebek; Grummenbach; Groinbeck; Gronebecke; Grvnbec
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1250.

Name: Gronenberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1201.

Name: Groningen
Alternative_Name: Groningi; Groniggea; Groninga; Groningon; Grvoningen; Villa Cruoninga; Groninghe; Groninge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1040.
Town_Description: Groningen was never officially granted town rights by a land lord. However, Groningen had several town-like features and developed into a town between the eleventh and thirteenth century. By the thirteenth century the town was already walled ('ommuurd'). The earliest document from a city government dates from 14 November 1245.
Staple_Description: From 1430 onwards, the town attempted to dominate the economy of the Frisian coastal area between Ems and Lauwers. It acquired full staple privileged for all commodities from the Ommelanden and a beer monopoly in 1500. This led to conflicts with Emden and Appingedam, which organised fairs. The States General recognized the forced offering of commodities for sale on the market in 1559, but the duration was limited to one or two hours. In 1599, all foreign commodities except horses and cattle were exempted from staple obligations. For domestic commodities, the staple obligations existed mainly for corn, butter and cheese. The staple is still mentioned in 1649, but seems to have collapsed shortly afterwards.

Name: Gröningen
Alternative_Name: Groninga; Grouninga; Groningen; Gronigge; Gruninge; Gronig
Settlement_Description: In 936 a court (curtis) is mentioned. In 1371 the settlement is granted borough rights ('Weichbildrechte'). From 1369 to 1648 it served as a residence to the bishops of Halberstadt, the bishopric's seat remained in Halberstadt. In the Middle Ages, the settlement split into Wester-/Klostergröningen, Südgröningen (Sudendorf) and Nordgröningen. Since the sources usually only refert to Gröningen, a distinction remains difficult. Since the 16th cenutry, the village owned a council constitution, but it was nevertheless referred to as borough ('Flecken') up into the 17th century.
Fair_Description: In 1641 Gröningen is granted two fairs.

Name: Groot-Ammers
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1280-1287.

Name: Groß Ammensleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 950. 1087 first mention of a lord of Groß Ammensleben. Foundation of an abbey in 1120, which was converted into a benedictine monastery in 1129. It never seems to have gained much influence.

Name: Lielauce
Settlement_Description: The manor was mentioned in 1561 and was given as a fief.

Name: Groß Berkel
Alternative_Name: Berkolo; Bercle; Berkele; Bercke; Barkel; Berckele; Berkle; Barckele; Barkel; Barkell; Großen Barckel; Groß Bergkel; Großenberkel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1066-1081, initially only as Berkel. To make a distinction with nearby Klein Berkel (first mentioned in 1241), the settlement became known as Groß Berkel in the 16th century.

Name: Groß Beuster
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1246 as part of a noble family.

Name: Groß Borstel
Alternative_Name: Kalen-Borstel; Borstle; Burstelde; Kale Borstelt; Calebostel; Borstelde; Bostel; Borstell; Groß-Borstel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1247.

Name: Burlo
Alternative_Name: Groß Burlo; Burloe; Burloh; Buerloe; Borlo

Name: Groß Dahlum
Alternative_Name: Daleheim; Dalem; Dalehem; Dalum; Vogedesdalem; Dahlem; Groten Dalim; Vogts Dalem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022. A castle mentioned in 1191 could not be reliably located.

Name: Groß Denkte
Alternative_Name: Dencthi; Dengdi; Denghte; Deghcte; Denchte; Denkede; Denckte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 947. However, a settlement already existed in the neolithic and Roman period.

Name: Groß Döhren
Settlement_Description: First mentioned "in villa Durnede" around 1000.

Name: Groß Düngen
Alternative_Name: Dunge; Dungen; Duggem; Dungedhe; Dunghem; Dunchem; Dunhem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1146.

Name: Großebersdorf
Toll_Description: Transit on the road to Leipzig continually rose since 1497, even though the road had been forbidden by the Ernestinians in 1470. Nevertheless, this station of safe conduct was no competition for other roads into Upper Germany.

Name: Iecava
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1272.

Name: Groß Eicklingen
Alternative_Name: Eicklingen; Eklethe; Eklege; Ekleghe; Nortecledhe; Ecleghe; Hecleghe; Eklaghen; Maiori Eklagen; Propiori Eclaghe; Negheren Ekelege; Smedd-Eikeln; Smedt Ekelingen; Ekelinghen; Ekelege; Grossen Eichlingen; Schmedt Eckling; Groten Ekelinghen; Grossen Eichlingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned before 1196-1197.

Name: Groß Ellingen
Settlement_Description: First secure mention in 1320.

Name: Großflintbek
Alternative_Name: Groß Flintbek; Flintbek; Vlintbeke; Vlintbeke maiorem
Settlement_Description: The village Flintbek - first mentioned in 1223 - was divided into Groß and Klein Flintbek, of which the former is first mentioned separately in 1328.

Name: Groß Förste
Alternative_Name: Vorsete; Vorsathe; Forsaten; Vorsethe; Vorsede; Vorstede; Vorsato; Vorsate; Vorsethe maius; Vorste; Vorsethe maiori; maiori Vorste; Groten Vorste
Settlement_Description: The settlement Förste was first mentioned in the beginning of the 12th century. It consisted of two parts, Groß and Klein Förste, of which the former was first mentioned separately in 1283.

Name: Freden
Alternative_Name: Groß Freden; Freden (Leine); Vreden; Fredenon; Freten; Friethen; Frethen; Vrethe; Freyden; Fredensem; Fredhen; Vredene; Vreyden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 12th century. The parish church of St George is mentioned in 1068. A castle is first mentioned in 1158, later it is presumed that there was a fortification of the bishop of Hildesheim near the church, to guard the river crossing.

Name: Groß Fullen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000 in plural, which indicates that already at that time, Fullen encompassed two distinct settlements, which developed into Groß and Klein Fullen.
Toll_Description: A road toll ('wegegeld') of the bishop of Münster was mentioned in Fullen in 1576, when it could not be leased. In the 17th century, half of the toll was owned by the town Meppen.

Name: Gramzda
Alternative_Name: Groß Gramsden; Gradtsen; Granzen; Gros Gram

Name: Groß Grönau
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in the tithe register of Ratzeburg from 1230. The St Willehad church dates from the 13th/14th century.

Name: Groß Haltern
Alternative_Name: Haltern; Magnum Halethere; Groten Halteren; Rodenhalteren; Magna Haltern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1240.

Name: Groß Hesepe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000, where a distinction between Groß and Klein Hesepe is not yet made.

Name: Jarßum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Dzelmes
Alternative_Name: Groß Jungfernhof; Lieljumprava; Jumprava; Pepholt; Peppelholt; Pargenhof
Settlement_Description: 'Villa Pepholt' is mentioned as the original name of the settlement in 1257.

Name: Klitschmar
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1350.

Name: Kõpu
Settlement_Description: Manor, that was mentioned in 1560.

Name: Groß Lafferde
Alternative_Name: Loferdi; Loffurdi; Lacfurdi; Laffordi; Lafforde; Latforde; Lachvorde; Maiori Lafforde; Laffordhe; Groten Lafferde; Westerlafforde; Magno Lafferde; Groß Laferde; Großen Laffert; Grosslafferde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 822 and 826.

Name: Möringen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1200; mention of an inn in 1375 and 1472.

Name: Groß Niendorf
Alternative_Name: Niendorp; Niendorpe; Nigendorppe bii Letzinge; Nyendorpe; Niendorpp

Name: Groß Oesingen
Alternative_Name: Hosenge; Osinghe; Osynghe; Osinge; Ossingen; Osinghen; Groten Oßinghe; Groten Osing; Osingen; Groten Ozinghe; Groten Osyngenn; Ossinge
Settlement_Description: Originally named Oesingen. The addition "Groß" ('large'), to distinguish the settlement from Klein ('little') Oesingen, is attested since the end of the 15th century.

Name: Ottersleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in a gift certificate in 937, further mention in a gift certificate by Otto I. to the monastary of St. Mauritius in Magdeburg in 941 (MGH DD O I, nr. 37, S. 123).

Name: Groß Rheide
Alternative_Name: Store Rejde; Reyde; Groten Reyde; Grotereide; Große Reide; Groß-Reide
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in ca. 1512.

Name: Groß Ringmar
Alternative_Name: Rigmare; Rigmere; Ringmere; Rigmore; Groten Ringmere;
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in the list of contributors to the construction of the Weser bridge in Bremen, ca. 1250.

Name: Bad Salzelmen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1124. Originally two settlements: Elmen and Schadeleben. Important saltworks, which were first mentioned in 1170.
Town_Description: A register of the council ('Rathandelsbuch') of 1291 suggests that Salzelmen was referred to as town at the time and had Magdeburg town rights.
Toll_Description: Construction of a castle in Schadeleben near Groß Salze between 1310 and 1313 in order to levy a salt toll. The castle was pawned several times later.

Name: Suure-Jaani
Settlement_Description: Around 1200 a parish was established.

Name: Groß Sarau
Alternative_Name: Sarowe; Groten Zarow; maiore Zarouwe; Groten Zarowe; Groten Sarouw
Settlement_Description: Already when it is first mentioned in 1230, a division of the settlement between 'Sarowe' and 'Slavicum Sarowe' is made, which points at a German and a Slavic settlement. An inn is attested here in 1466.

Name: Groß Schierstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in the Codex Diplomaticus Anhaltinus in 1010.

Name: Groß Schwechten
Settlement_Description: First mention of the church in Schwechten in 1200.

Name: Groß Sehlingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1437.

Name: Sottrum
Alternative_Name: Groß Sottrum; Suthrem; Sutherhem; Sutherem; Sutherum; Suterem; Sutterum; Sottmar; Sotterem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1205.

Name: Groß Stavern
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 890.

Name: Groß Stöckheim
Alternative_Name: Stochheim; Stockim; Stokkem; Stöcken; Stochem; Magno Sthockem; Groten Stockem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1051. Traces from habitation from the Roman imperial period have been found.

Name: Groß Timmendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1260.

Name: Großbeeren
Settlement_Description: Probably founded in the context of the colonisation of the Teltow by the Ascanians since the Middle of the 13th century. Mention as Berne in 1297. In 1344 the settlement was given to the family of Berne, who stayed in possession of the settlement until their demise at the beginning of the 19th century.

Name: Groß Berkenthin
Alternative_Name: Parketin; Parkentin; Barkenthyn; Berkenthin; Barkentin; Berkentin; Großen Berkentien; Perkentin; Parkentyn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230.

Name: Großenlinden
Alternative_Name: Großen Linden; Lindun; maior Linden; Grozinlindin
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 790 as a 'villa'.
Town_Description: Town privileges confirmed in 1605.

Name: Großenaspe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1200.

Name: Großenbehringen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 932.

Name: Großengottern
Settlement_Description: In 802/17 one of the villages of Gottern is referred to as 'in Thuringia' and mentioned as the property of a count Erpfol. The prefix "Bischofs-", which refers to the current Großengottern, comes up quite late in the records. In the 8th/9th century, Großengottern is counted to the Westergau or Natergau (DH 1 32, DH 11 376). The first referral to Großengottern explicitly can be found in 1189/90.
Toll_Description: Complaint of Mühlhausen traders that they had to pay toll in Weberstedt, even though they had already paid it in Gottern. Wares from the area of the Weser had to pay toll in Großgottern but were then excempt from the safe conduct in Erfurt, as long as the corresponding lead marks were shown in the area of Erfurt's safe conduct "during daylight". There are regulations of safe conduct ('Geleitsordnung') from 1516, in which the safe conduct of Langensalza is also regulated.

Name: Großenhain
Alternative_Name: Ozzec; Hagen; Indago; Hayn; Hayn ober Elbe; Großen Hayn
Settlement_Description: Slavic fortress and settlement in place before its foundation in the 12th century as a fortress of the margraves of Meißen.
Town_Description: Town foundations laid down around 1200; development into an important weaving town by the 15th and 16th centuries. Town privileges confirmed in 1464.
Toll_Description: Extensive regulations of safe conduct remain from 1547 (SHStA Dresden, Loc. 40 085, Hain Nr. 116 b, Erbbuch des Amtes Großenhain 1547, p. 731–780v).
Staple_Description: Staple for woad in the duchy of Saxony granted in 1477. Their rival Görlitz succeeded in repressing the staple rights for ten years, but staple back in place from 1490. Only woad that was unsold after four weeks could be taken onwards to Görlitz. Görlitz remained an important centre of the woad trade; in 1523 the council of Großenhain decided that only one quarter of the woad should be offered for sale in their town; intensified in 1592 and 1607.
Fair_Description: In 1545 Leipzig protests against a new fair in Großenhain. The town's council answers that it wasn't aware of a new fair and the other fairs had been held since the olden times.

Name: Suuremõisa
Settlement_Description: In the Medieval times there was an estate of the Teutonic Order ('Deutscher Orden') north of today's settlement. The farmers settled further south in 1626, where the former fields of the estate were. After the Teutonic period, it first became a Danish, then a Swedish and later a Russian domain.

Name: Großenlupnitz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1304.

Name: Großenritte
Alternative_Name: Rittahe; Rittehessis; Ritdi; Ritte; major Ritte; Grozme Rytte; Kirchritte; Großen-Ritte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 775 and 786.

Name: Großensee
Alternative_Name: Grotense; Magnum Stagnum; Magno Stagno; Groten Zee; Grotensehe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1248.

Name: Großensee
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1402.

Name: Großeutersdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1084.

Name: Großfahner
Settlement_Description: Already settled in prehistory, archaeological finds suggest beginnings in the early Stone Age. First written mention in 876.

Name: Großgrabe
Settlement_Description: Mention in a gift certificate to St. Victor monastary in Mainz by Otto III. (MGH DD OIII. Nr. 251, S. 667f.).

Name: Königsdorf
Toll_Description: 1) Even before 1314, Dietrich Luf of Cleves levied a land toll. From 1314 this was in the possession of the Archbishop of Cologne. In 1396, 2 to 3 alb. per horse had to be paid, depending on the load. In 1430, 4 shillings per horse had to be paid. In 1314 the annual income was about 5 mark. In 1395 only the road toll was collected. In 1455 Blatzheim, Bocklemünd, Brüggen (Erft), Lövenich, Mehlem, Merheim and Widdersdorf were secondary toll stations. 2) In 1395, the Archbishop of Cologne levied a road toll. In the same year, a tariff of 2 heller per wagon had to be paid. In 1454/60, 40 mark per year could be collected.

Name: Großmühlingen
Settlement_Description: In 936 property in Großmühlingen is given to Quedlinburg monastery. A castle is first mentioned in 1318. Independent county until 1659.

Name: Großörner
Alternative_Name: Örner; Arnare; Ornare; Ornere; Hornaria; Orner; Alten-Örner
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 973 in an exchange of estates between Fulda monastery and the archbishopric of Magdeburg. In 1337 Großörner is referred to as Alten-Örner, but the name did not establish itself.

Name: Großräschen
Alternative_Name: Grosen Redschin; Redschin ambo; Grossen Retschen; Groß Reschen

Name: Großringe
Settlement_Description: The settlement Ringe is first mentioned in 1329, both parts Groß- and Kleinringe separately in 1456.

Name: Großtöpfer
Settlement_Description: The village was property of castle Stein (Bischofsstein) since olden times and home to a knight family which named itself after it.

Name: Großwechsungen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1155 in an exchange of property between Fulda and Walkenried monasteries.

Name: Großwudicke
Settlement_Description: First mention possibly in 1397 as Weddig.

Name: Großzöbern
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Gräfenhainichen (LHASA, MD, d. 16, Nr. 17 1a, Erbbuch des Amtes Gräfenhainichen 1550).

Name: Grote Brogel
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1222.

Name: Grumbach
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1137.
Toll_Description: In 1547 the counts of Henneberg erected a block house and a tollbar in Grumbach.

Name: Gruna
Settlement_Description:
First mention of Gruna in 1456.
In 1980 Magdeborn and its district Gruna had to be deserted due to a brown coal opencast mine, after the end of operations the remains are filled with water and form the current Störmthaler lake.

Name: Grünberg
Settlement_Description: A castle was built in 1180, where a settlement formed immediately.
Town_Description: Mentioned in 1186 as a castle suburb, unclear whether city rights exist. Listed as a 'Flecken' in 1195, named as 'civitas' in 1222.

Name: Grundzāle
Settlement_Description: Until 1489, the manor belonged to the 'Grundeis'-Family.

Name: Grünenwulsch
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1375.

Name: Grünhagen
Alternative_Name: Boythelenthorpe; Gronenhagen; Gronehaghen; Grönehaghene; Godestede; Grünenhagen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252. The settlement was called Boytelendorp before the 14th century.

Name: Grünhof
Settlement_Description: Folwark, which was constructed not long after 1557.

Name: Zaļenieki
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1566.

Name: Gubin
Settlement_Description: Findings of old settlements from 1400 BC to 200 AC, first mentioned in 1211
Town_Description: Heinrich, Margrave of Meisen and Ostmark (1221-1288) granted the Madgeburg town law to the oppidum in 1235, mentioned as civitas since 1286
Harbour_Description: Guben was an important place of transshipment for transport on land to the Neiße and down the Oder. The first mention of shipping via Guben occurs in 1211when duke Henry I. grants Lebus monastery toll-free passage on the Oder to Guben.

Name: Gudensberg
Alternative_Name: Gůdenesberch; Ůdenesberc; Wothenesberc; Wuodesnberg; Gvtenburg; Wotensberg; Guttensberg; Gudinsberc; Gudinburg; Gudinsburg; Godensberg; Gudensberc; Godenspergh; Gotesberg; Gotensberg; Ghodensperg; Gudinborg; Gudensperg; Guttensbergk; Gudensperg
Settlement_Description: The settlement goes back to a court mentioned in the 10th century. A castle of the Counts of Gudensberg is attested from 1121, besides the place developed.
Town_Description: The exact development of the town is unknown as there is no document. However, the place might be fortified at the end of the 12th century and is mentioned in 1254 as 'oppidum'.

Name: Gudersleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 822.

Name: Häädemeeste
Settlement_Description: In the 16th century, a harbour was built. A village settled around this harbour. At the same time, a hamlet ('Hof') was built, which was owned by the Mayor of Pernau in 1624.

Name: Gulpen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1161, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Gusev
Settlement_Description: The church village Pifferkeim grew out of the Kulligkehmen around 1554 and later became Gusev

Name: Gumpelstadt
Settlement_Description: First uncertain mention in 907, first certain mention in 1015.

Name: Gudersleben
Settlement_Description: Mention in the record book of Fulda monastery. Further mention in 927 in a gift certificate by Henry I.

Name: Güntersberge
Settlement_Description: In 1326 a castle was mentioned. During the 14th century the settlement was referred to as borough ('Flecken'), which requested a confirmation of its rights and privileges in 1531.
Town_Description: In 1539 privileges, that are similar to those that existed in Harzgerode, were given. However, the term 'borough' ('Flecken') was still used after that.

Name: Günzerode
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1188.

Name: Güssefeld
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1324.

Name: Güstrow
Settlement_Description: Was part of the terra Bisdede in wendish times, a castle is mentioned in 1226, the settlement grew out of a collegiate chapter that was established close to the castle
Town_Description: Founded by Heinrich von Rostock (1219-1226) with Schwerin town law, only mentioned as civitas in 1228

Name: Gütersloh
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1110 as a parish ('Kirchspiel'). But a settlement seems to have existed before 1000.

Name: Dobre Miasto
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1325, the settlement was founded by the locator Wilhelm von Wormitt on the order of the Warmian bishop Eberhard von Neiße
Town_Description: Bishop Heinrich von Wogenap grants a handfast with Kulm town law to the civitas in 1329

Name: Haacht
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1142.

Name: Den Haag
Alternative_Name: Haag; 's-Gravenhage; The Hague; Haghe; Die Haga; Hagen; Die Haghe; Haga; 's Graven-Hage; 's Gravenhage
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of 's-Gravenhage dates from a 1390-copy of a 1242 document. The settlement orginated in the vicinity of the court of a count. Although the government of the settlement has town-like features and 's-Gravenhage is sometimes even considered a town by contemporaries, it is only elevated to town rank on 25 November 1806 by Louis Bonaparte, king of Holland.

Name: Haaksbergen
Alternative_Name: Hockesberghe; Huckesberghe; Houckesberghe; Hakesberg; Hokesberghe; Hoekesberghe; Haxberghe; Haaxbergen; Haxberghen; Haexbergen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1188, inserted in the end of thirteenth century.

Name: Haarlem
Alternative_Name: Haralem; Harleim; Harlem; Herlehe[m]; Harlehem; Harlhem
Settlement_Description: Haarlem is first mentioned in an eleventh-century copy of a document dated 918-948. Haarlem became situated at the crossroad of several trade routes and gained importance as an military-strategic location.
Town_Description: Haarlem was granted town rights on 23 November 1245 by William II, count of Holland.

Name: Habaja
Settlement_Description: Manor and village that was first mentioned in 1417.

Name: Habbrügge
Settlement_Description: The name of the settlement indicates a plastered ford.

Name: Haabersti
Settlement_Description: In 1265 it was referred to as a village in the borderland of Reval. In the 16th/17th century the village became property of Reval.

Name: Habighorst
Alternative_Name: Havichorst; Havechorst; Hauekost; Hauekhorst; Hauechorst; Havekhorst; Havichorst; Haveckhorst; Havyckhorsth; Havickhorst; Havekost; Havecost
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1291.

Name: Hachen
Alternative_Name: Hacchene; Hagnen; Hage; Hachene; Hachnen; Hachenen; Hachgene; Hacnen; Hagnere; Hacghem; Hachgen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1100.

Name: Hachenburg
Toll_Description: The Count of Sayn levied a land toll here before 1327. In the following decades, the toll rights were further granted: among others, Reinhard von Westerburg held them from 1340 and Heinrich Beyer von Boppard from 1372. Under Beyer of Boppard in 1372 and 1402, ½ gulden per carriage was paid. Under Westerburg in 1402, 1 guilder per carriage. In 1511, the Sayner customs were leased out for 150 gulden.

Name: Hachmühlen
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1217.

Name: Hadamar
Alternative_Name: In Hatimero marca; Superior Hademar; Obernhadamar; Münchhadamar; Hademar; Hatmar; Horemer
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 832. In 1190 a curia is mentioned. The settlement is named as 'villa' in 1231 and 1287.
Town_Description: Was granted town privileges in 1324.
Toll_Description: The Count of Katzenelnbogen levied a gate toll in 1453. Accounts from 1430 and 1431 still mention a fair/market toll. Tariffs are not known. In 1453, 5 Turnosgroschen were collected in the year.

Name: Haddenhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1033.

Name: Hademstorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1296.

Name: Hadenfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned before 1500.

Name: Haderslev
Town_Description: In 1292 Haderslev was given a town law by duke Valdemar IV.

Name: Hadmersleben
Settlement_Description: 961 Otto II. confirms the foundation of Hadmersleben monastary (MGH DD OII nr. 2, S. 11f.). First mention of the castle in 1144.
Town_Description: One of the settlements of Hadmersleben is referred to as civitas in 1399.
Fair_Description: In 1565, two fairs were granted by archbishop Sigismund.

Name: Hagen
Settlement_Description: Mentioned at the end of the 11th century, but possibly much older.

Name: Hagen (Altmark)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1329/30. There is a mention in 1215, but this may only refer to a field name. Until 1542 property of Dambeck monastery.

Name: Hagenah
Settlement_Description: First mentioned when count palatinate Frederick II donated 3 farms in Hagenah to the monastery of St George in Stade before 1132. In a register from 1535, 4 farms and a cottage are mentioned.

Name: Hagenohsen
Alternative_Name: Nordohsen; Nort Osen; North Osen; Nortosen; Hosen; Ozen
Settlement_Description: Came into existence as settlement near the castle Ohsen on the right shore of the Weser. The settlement was first known as Nordohsen, later as Hagenohsen.

Name: Hagenow
Settlement_Description: A village existed since wendish times and a german village grew close to it, 1190-1195 a parson and knights are mentioned, proven as a settlement from 1230-1327
Town_Description: Became a town when the land was given to Mecklenburg in 1358, mentioned as oppidum in 1370, mentioned as a town in 1420

Name: Hagstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000.

Name: Hahausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1021.

Name: Haiger
Alternative_Name: Haigrahe; Heigrehe; Heigera; Heigere; Heigerin; Heigre; Heigeren; Heger; Heygere; Heygirn; Heigir; Heiger; Häger; Häajer
Settlement_Description: First attested in 778. Around 900 there was a Frankish royal court.
Town_Description: It is unclear exactly when the settlement was raised to town. In 1357 still referred to as a village, but in 1400 as a city. A document about the city rights is missing.

Name: Heyen
Alternative_Name: Hajen; Hegen; Heigen; Hoyen; Eygen; Eyhem; Heyghen; Heygen; Heyne; Haien; Haye
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1004.

Name: Hakenberg
Settlement_Description: First mention in the records in 1200.

Name: Hakendover
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1138, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Halle (Zenne)
Alternative_Name: Hallensis; Halla; Hal; Halle; Hal; Haulx
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1152.

Name: Halberstadt
Settlement_Description: Halberstadt is the name of a settlement that already existed around 800 and that was first mentioned 781. The bishoprick of Halberstadt gained independence in 827. In 989, market and toll rights were given.
Town_Description: In 1105, the bishop confirmed the "iura et statua civilia". Court, police and administration emerged during the following years. In 1184 Halberstadt already adapted the town rights of Goslar. In the first third of the 13th century the first council forms after several conflicts with the episcopal town lord. 1241 a town hall is mentioned for the first time.
Fair_Description: In 989 emperor Otto III. grants market privileges to the settlement.

Name: Halchter
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1149.

Name: Haldensleben
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in a document during Otto I. regency in 966. Althaldensleben was the original settlement. After 1150 Neuhaldensleben was built to the north. Both places were united in 1938.
Town_Description: Magdeburg town rights granted in a foundation record in 1223.
Toll_Description: Awarding of a road toll for the town by archbishop Wilbrand in 1249, with which the town was supposed to fund road construction, the expansion of the gates and the erection of wall towers. The toll in Haldensleben is further mentioned in the 16th century, when a complaint is filed that the toll stations of Oebisfelde, Neuhaldensleben, Wolmirstedt, Dreileben, Wanzleben and Calbe collect less toll because of Magdeburg's toll excemption. In 1549 a listing of the yearly income from the safe conduct of the district of Haldensleben remains.

Name: Haldern
Toll_Description: The Archbishop of Cologne probably levied a land toll before 1299. From 1392 onwards, there is no longer any mention of a toll in Haldern. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Halen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 741, in an eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1107, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Halfweg
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention 1680, in a reprint in 1745.
Harbour_Description: Due to the existence of three sluices between the Haarlem Lake and the IJ, the tow canal ('trekvaart') between Amsterdam and Haarlem, which was built in 1631, was interrupted in Halfweg. Passengers had to change barges here.

Name: Halle (Saale)
Alternative_Name: Halle a.d. Saale; Halle an der Saale; Halle/Saale; Hall in Sachsen; Halla
Settlement_Description: Numerous prehistorical finds are witness to an early settlement and attractiveness of the region. Mention of castle "Halla" on the Eastern bank of the Saale in 806. Its location is not known. First explicit mention of Halle as a location in 1064, before, Giebichenstein was referred to. However, the area of the Old Market used to be an early traffic junction, which was surrounded by a wall in the 11th century. Around 1000 salt production started in the area of the old market, which led to an economic boom for the blooming town.
Town_Description: First explicit referral to the place as a town in 1177. Even though Halle already had an own jurisdiction after the fashion of the Magdeburg law in the 12th century, it only received a fully autonomous town status in 1310. 1280 it joined the Hanse.
Toll_Description: In 1067 the archepiscopal coin and toll were moved from Giebichenstein to Halle.

Name: Halle (Bodenwerder)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 997.

Name: Halle (Westfalen)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1146. In 1346 the settlement got granted 'Weichbildrechte' and was called a free 'Wigbold' in 1488.

Name: Hallenberg
Alternative_Name: Merklinghausen; curtim in Nona; Merclinchusen; Merkelinchusen; Merckelinchusen; Mercklinghusen; Hallinberg; Halenbergh; Hollnberg; Hallenberk; Hallenberch
Settlement_Description: The settlement Merklinghausen in the Nuhne valley was first mentioned in 1147, but possibly belonged to the abbey of Deutz since its foundation in 1002. Between 1248 and 1253, the castle and town Hallenberg were founded on an elevation next to the village by Arnold von Hochstaden; it was first mentioned in 1259.
Town_Description: Town privileges were confirmed in 1338 and extended in 1354 by the town right of Rüthen-Brilon.

Name: Hallerburg
Settlement_Description: A castle in Hallerburg was built around 1350; a settlement developed next to it. The castle was destroyed in 1519.
Toll_Description: A toll in Hallerburg is mentioned in 1455.

Name: Haljala
Settlement_Description: In the 13th century, the village belonged to the church.

Name: Halmaal
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1065.

Name: Haltern am See
Alternative_Name: Haltern; Halahtra; Halostron; Halatra; Halahtram; Alteren; Halteren
Settlement_Description: The settlement itself is first mentioned in 1017, but goes back to roman colonization.
Town_Description: In 1288 the settlement was given 'Wigboldsrechte' by Bishop Everhard von Munster.
Toll_Description: The toll in Haltern was divided into two parts: one for the bishop of Münster and one for the town. In 1557, the tariff was raised from 1 Rader albus to 1/2 Taler, but the old tariff was restored after complaints from towns on the Rhine.

Name: Hamburg
Alternative_Name: Hammaburg; Hammenburg; Hamborch; Hamburgum; Hammonis castrum; Hammonia; Hamborg
Settlement_Description: Precarolingian refuge fort of the Saxons north of the Elbe, bishopric since 831, archbishopric since 834. A market settlement outside of the fortress is first attested in 845.
Town_Description: The archiepiscopal old town (Altstadt) became a town no later than the mid-12th century. The new town (Neustadt) was founded by Duke Adolf III of Schauenburg and received Lübeck town privileges in 1188. Both parts were united around 1215.
Toll_Description:
Four tolls existed in Hamburg:
1) the Count, Priest or Schaumburg toll of the territorial lords was first mentioned in 1188 and in 1460 half went to the Danish royal house and from 1640 in its entirety. The levying of the toll was, however, in the hands of the town, to whom it was regularly pawned. Payment of the toll was handled at the town gates and at the harbour entrance; merchants from Bremen, Brandenburg, Meißen, Magdeburg, Braunschweig and Saxony were exempted.
2) The Werkzoll, first mentioned in 1309, was raised by the council of Hamburg to finance navigation beacons for the isle of Neuwerk and the Lower Elbe; it was privileged by the Emperor in 1628.
3) A toll for securing the sea lanes from pirates and robbers was raised as a pound toll first in 1362, then from 1424 with some breaks until 1528. From 1541 the toll was raised in cooperation with Lübeck; in 1552 the toll was imposed unilaterally by Hamburg and converted into a grain toll after complaints from Lübeck in 1557. After the foundation of the Admiralty in 1623 a new toll for the defence of the sea lanes was raised.
4) The Land and Elbe toll for trade heading inland by both water and land; toll records are edited by Pitz. Registers from the Land and Elbe toll and the Admiralty toll have survived from the 17th century; they were partly assessed by Reißmann. Pound toll records from 1485-6 have also been edited.
Staple_Description: First attempts to establish a staple can be seen in the toll tariffs of 1236, where it is recorded that merchants were exempted from toll payment when they offered their commodities for sale on the market in Hamburg. In the following centuries, ever more trade limitations were taken; the town law of 1458 first contained an obligation for merchants to offer butter, cheese, fish and corn for sale on the local market for three days. The staple was confirmed by king Christian I of Denmark in 1480 and by the emperor in 1482. Merchants from Brandenburg were exempted from the staple between 1518 and 1555, but had to sell 2/3 of their grain in Hamburg afterwards. A threat for the staple was posed by the possible circumvention of town via the southern Elbe arm, which Hamburg tried to prevent from the 14th century. This led to conflicts with Brunswick-Lüneburg, Stade and Buxtehude in the 16th and 17th centuries. Despite a verdict of the imperial chamber court from 1619 that traffic on the southern Elbe should be free, the emperor confimed the staple privileges in 1621, and in 1628 Hamburg's control over the southern Elbe as well. After the mid-17th century, the staple was ever more difficult to enforce and finally abolished in 1748.
Harbour_Description: Until the cosntruction of a new crane on the inner harbour in the 16th century, the only crane was that on the square adjacent to the town hall. Lighter boats transported commodities to here from the larger sea-going ships in the lower and inner harbours.

Name: Hameln
Alternative_Name: Hamelo; Hamelon; Hamala; Hamalam; Hamelensibus; Hamelensis; Hamele; Hamela; Hamelen; Hamelenses; Hameluncus; Hammelen; Hamelin; Hamlen; Hamelowe
Settlement_Description: Hameln, which consisted of more than one settlement, is first mentioned in the 9th century, but was considerably older.
Town_Description: A planned town with Minden town privileges was founded around 1200.
Staple_Description: In practice, there existed a forced transshipment in Hameln for a long time because of the barrier of the Hamelner Loch (see harbour). A formal staple right, however, is first attested in 1627, and it is uncertain whether it was ever really enforced.
Fair_Description: Fairs in Hameln are first mentioned around 1240, among others on St Peter and Paul's Day. In the oldest town register from ca. 1350, three fairs are mentioned: on St Boniface, St Michael and "tho der hoighen kerkemisse", probably on All Saints' Day. The dates were changed in 1556: the St Michael and All Saints fair took place on Monday after the feast days, and the fair on St Boniface was replaced by two new ones, on Monday after Letare Sunday and on the second Monday after Trinity Sunday.

Name: Hämerten
Settlement_Description: First mention around 1150.
Ferry_Description: Hämerten maintained a small passenger ferry.

Name: Hamfelde
Alternative_Name: Hamfelde (Stormarn); Honuelde; Haneuelde; Honvelde; Handvelde; Hanueld
Settlement_Description: The settlement Hamfelde, first mentioned in 1230, developed on both shores of the Bille. Because this became the border between Lauenburg and Stormarn, it was divided into two administrative units.

Name: Hamm (Lippe)
Settlement_Description: After the nearby castle and town of Nienbrügge were destroyed, Count Adolf von der Mark founded a settlement in "Hamm" in 1226.
Town_Description: Since its foundation, the settlement has been mentioned as an 'oppidum' and 'civitas' and got Lippstadt rights approved in 1279.
Toll_Description: The Count of the Mark probably levied a land toll in 1347/91. From 1456, half of the yields fell to the town of Hamm. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Hamm (Hamburg)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1212. A boom barrier is mentioned here in 1465.

Name: Hammenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 8th or 9th century.

Name: Hammer (Kiel)
Settlement_Description: The settlement of five farms probably goes back to Malugesdorf, which is mentioned in the 13th century. In 1288, the name Hammer appears for the first time.

Name: Czarne
Settlement_Description: A border castle (Wildhaus) of the Teutonic Order was relocated here in the 14th ct., a settlement grew close by.
Town_Description: A handfast granting the Kulm town law was given in 1395 by grandmaster Konrad von Jungingen. It was endorsed in 1411.

Name: Hanau
Alternative_Name: Hagenowa; Hagenowe; Hagenha; Hanowe; Haynowe; Hanouwe; Hanauwe; Henauwe; Hanauw; Hanaw
Settlement_Description: The name appears as early as 1143. A castle probably existed before that, but it is first mentioned in 1234. At the beginning of the 13th century, a settlement was built south of this castle.
Town_Description: The settlement is only mentioned by name in the course of its city charter in 1303. Before that it is called 'oppidum'.

Name: Hanerau
Alternative_Name: Hanrouwe; Hanrowe; Hanerowe; Hanrow; Hanrouw; Hannerouw; Hanrou; Hannraw; Hannrauwe; Hannerow
Settlement_Description: Around 1180, a castle was built by count Adolf III of Holstein as border defense against Dithmarschen.
Toll_Description: A toll in Hanerau is levied from the mid-15th century, first mentioned in 1461, but then already existing for some years. In 1474, the toll in Hanerau is confirmed and set at the same level as the other tolls in Holstein. The toll was also levied at other streets to Dithmarschen, at the castle Lindhorst (Keller) and since 1601 in Hohenhörn.

Name: Hankenberge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1317.

Name: Hankensbüttel
Alternative_Name: Honengesbuthele; Hunekesbotle; Honekkesbuthle; Honickesbotele; Honekesbutle; Hankesbuttell; Honekesbuthle; Honekesbuttele; Honkesbutle; Hannekesbuttel; Honnekesbuttel; Honkesbüttel; Honekesbüttel; Horckenbuttel; Hannekeszbuttell; Hannekensbuttell; Hannikesbüttel; Hanckensbüttel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1051.

Name: Hannover
Alternative_Name: Hanabruinborgar; Hanofra; Hanovere; Honovere; Honnovere; Honouir; Honover; Hanover; Hoenover; Hannouer
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1150; there are traces of permanent settlement from ca. 1000. The settlement was fortified in the second half of the 12th century.
Town_Description: Hannover developed into a town in the 1230s; the Minden town privileges were confirmed in 1241.
Toll_Description: Next to a market toll, which was levied by the duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg, there existed a transit toll for the town area. This belonged to the duke as well, but in practice it was levied by the town authorities since 1293, who in return acquired part of the revenues. In the middle of the 15th century, the toll was acquired by the town; customs for many commodities were raised around the same time.
Fair_Description: Fairs in Hannover are first mentioned in 1399, taking place on the feast of St James and Maundy Thursday. According to a 1444 letter from Hildesheim, there also existed a fair of St Simon and Jude at the time, which was to be replaced by a fair on St Walpurga and the day before and after, with the addition that no other free fair was to take place in Hannover. St Walpurga's fair is mentioned again in 1453, when Hildesheim complained about hindrance of their citizens during the said fair. However, in 1445 there is also mention of a fair of St Giles in Hannover.

Name: Hamberge
Alternative_Name: Hogenberghe; Homberge; Honberge; Homberghe; Hoenberge; Hamberghe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1231. The local church is mentioned in 1340.

Name: Haapsalu
Settlement_Description: A bishop's castle in Hapsal was the residence of the bishops of Oesel-Wiek from 1265/66 until the middle of the 14th century. The Fortified Borough ('Hakelwerk') was built in the 13th century next to the castle.
Town_Description: The Fortified Bourough received town rights in 1279. The town rights of Riga were granted in 1294. Later, in 1581, town rights of Reval were granted.

Name: Harburg
Alternative_Name: Horeborg; Horborch; Horeburg; Horeburgh; Horborch; Horborgh; Horborg; Harborch; Hareborgh; Hareborg; Harborg; Harburgk; Haerborg
Settlement_Description: Moated castle of the archbishop of Bremen, first mentioned in 1133-1137. In the following time, the castle was often destroyed and changed hands. A settlement at the castle was first mentioned when it received borough ('weichbild') privileges in 1288.
Town_Description: The settlement acquired borough ('weichbild') privileges in 1288, and Lüneburg town privileges in 1297, which were confirmed in 1458. However, the settlement was characterised only as borough ('flecken') for a long time.
Toll_Description: A toll in Harburg was mentioned when the castle was pawned to Lüneburg in 1369, and to Lüneburg, Hamburg, Lübeck and Hannover in 1397. It was most likely a fee on exports of grain and wood on the Elbe.

Name: Hurdegaryp
Alternative_Name: Hardegarijp; Herdegaryp; Herdgarijpera; Hardarijp; Hertgerijp; Hardgarijp
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1401.

Name: Hardehausen
Alternative_Name: Harderhusen; Hirisuuithuhuson; Herswithehusen; Hersindehusen; Hersvithehusen; Hersuithehusen; Hersuithehusensis; Hersvidenhusen; Hersuithehusen; Hersethehusen; Hersuitheh; Herdehusen; Hersvethehusen; Hersvithehusen; Herswithehusen; Hersedehusin; Hersedehusin; Hersuedehusen; Hersuidehusen; Herdehusen; Hardehusenn; Hardehaußen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1036.

Name: Hardenberg
Alternative_Name: Herdenborg; Hardenborg; Harberge; Hardenberge; Herdenberch; Hardenberghe; Hardenborch; Hardenberch
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1229-1230. Hardenberg came into being near by a castle which had been established around 1227. Inhabitants of near by Nijenstede, a place with limited town privileges, moved to Hardenberg over time.
Town_Description: On 18 September 1362, Jan IV of Arkel, bishop of Utrecht, renews the town privileges of Nijenstede, and moves them to Hardenberg. He grants additional town privileges, including the same rights as people of the town of Zwolle.
Toll_Description: Toll station of the bishop of Utrecht, who exempted his servants in Twente from toll payments in Hardenberg and Nieuwebrug in 1391.

Name: Schloß Hardenberg
Toll_Description: The Lord of Hardenberg levied a land toll in the village of Hardenberg, presumably in 1487. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Harderwijk
Alternative_Name: Harderewich; Herderewich; Harderwyc; Herderwick; Harderwike; Herderwich; Herderwig; Harderwyck
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1231.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted 11 June 1231, by Otto II, count of Guelders and Zutphen.
Fair_Description: In 1294/95, Harderwijk had one fair; in 1424, it received a second fair. A municipal degree ordained the merchandise in this fair to be toll-free. At least around 1524, there was an additional oxen fair.

Name: Boven-Hardinxveld
Alternative_Name: Herdingfelde; Hardingfelde; Hardinvelt; Herdinxfelt; Hardicvelt; Herdichfeldt; Boven-Hardingsveld
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1105. Earliest mention of 'Boven-Hardingsveld' in 1899.

Name: Haren (Zenne)
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1050.

Name: Haren (Groningen)
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1249, in a copy from circa 1789. The next mention dates from 1323.

Name: Harku
Settlement_Description: Manor and village that were first mentioned in 1241.

Name: Harkebrügge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330.

Name: Harkotten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1309.

Name: Harksheide
Alternative_Name: Norderstedt-Harksheide; Herkesheyde; Herkestheide; Harkeszheide; Harkesheyde; Harxheide; Harckes Heyde
Settlement_Description: Dispersed settlement, first mentioned in 1374.

Name: Harlingen
Alternative_Name: Harns; Herlinge; Harlinghen; Harlinge; Herlenze; Harnze; Harlingae
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1228.
Town_Description: According to Cox, the earliest mention as a town dates from 1317. Van Berkel & Samplonius claim that Harlingen was granted town privileges in 1234.

Name: Harmstorf
Toll_Description: A Lüneburg toll in Harmstorf is mentioned in 1441, and in 1495 together with nearby Jesteburg.

Name: Harmöle
Settlement_Description: Mill, first mentioned in a late 13th-century addition to a document from 1188.

Name: Harpendorf
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1178.

Name: Harrislee
Alternative_Name: Harreslev; Haringslof; Harrislof; Harrithsleve; Harrisleve; Harrisle

Name: Harsewinkel
Alternative_Name: Hosewinkel; Haswinkila; Hasuinkla; Hoswincla; Hoswinkele; Hoswingel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1050 and grown near a church. In 1592 called a 'Wigbold'.

Name: Harskamp
Alternative_Name: Hoerscampe; Heerscamp; Herscamp(e); Harscamp; HartzCamp; Harts kamp; Hartskamp
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1333.

Name: Harsleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in the records at the end of the 11th century. A castle referred to as old castle ('Alte Burg') is known.

Name: Hartmannshausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned at the end of the 14th century.

Name: Harvesse
Alternative_Name: Herwardessen; Harwardissen; Herwordessen; Herwessze; Harpse; Hervesse; Herbst; Herbiß; Harweße; Harbis; Harvessen; Harvese; Harveße
Settlement_Description: First referred to in 1160.

Name: Bad Harzburg
Alternative_Name: Harzburg; Nyestat unter der Hartesburg; Nigestad; Newenstadt; Nienstedt
Settlement_Description: A settlement below the castle Harzburg is first mentioned in 1338 as "Neustadt unter der Harzburg".

Name: Užava
Settlement_Description: In 1253, the area fell to the Teutonic Order. A manor that was built by the Teutonic Order was mentioned in 1443.

Name: Hasbergen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 836 and 891.

Name: Hasede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1100 and 1200.

Name: Haselünne
Settlement_Description: A farm owned by the monastery of Corvey is mentioned in 1107. An earlier mention in the 11th century is questionable. The church was possibly erected around 800.
Town_Description: In 1271, the bishop of Münster confirmed the town privileges that were originally granted by the Counts Hermann and Otto of Ravensberg before 1220.
Toll_Description: The toll probably came into existence at the end of the 12th century, and was owned by the counts of Ravensberg in the 13th century. Later it belonged to the bishop of Münster. In 1569, the towns of Deventer, Kampen and Zwolle complained that a bridge toll was levied against all customs and rights. The lease of the toll is known from the same year and 1578. In 1594, 1626 and 1645, there were complaints about decreased revenues because no oxen were transported through Haselünne anymore, among others due to wars.
Fair_Description: Various fairs are mentioned in Haselünne in the early 14th century: on Sunday Laetare and 1 August (1307), 11 March (1319), and Petri ad Vincula (1324). These were mainly visited by merchants from Osnabrück. It is unclear how long these existed; in 1497, only one fair is still mentioned, the eight-day fair on Laetare, which possibly goes back to the 1271 town privileges.

Name: Hasenburg
Settlement_Description: The Hasenburg was the first and most important watchtower of the Lüneburg enclosure ('landwehr'), built in 1397 on the road to Munster and Soltau. The road crossed the Mühlenbach with a bridge, which could be closed with a barrier. The tower was renewed in 1484. The guard of the tower also checked the payment of excises for foreign beer. An inn at the tower is mentioned in 1562.

Name: Aizpute
Settlement_Description: The original castle of Hasenpoth fell to the Teutonic Order in 1245, after which a new castle was built on the left bank in 1249.
Town_Description: In 1378 the founding charter was issued. The town received Rigian town rights as well as mayor and council.

Name: Häsewig
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1183.

Name: Hasport
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1637 as a farm on the "Annen-Heyde".

Name: Haßbergen
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1025.

Name: Hassel
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1208.

Name: Hassel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1091.

Name: Hasselfelde
Settlement_Description: In 1043 and 1052 King Henry III. set up records in Hasselfelde, however, a proper village probably didn't exist at that point. Only in 1209/27 three villages named Hasselfelde are mentioned, most probably today's districts Hagen, Middle- and Easthasselfelde. In 1346 the village is once referred to as town, otherwise mostly as borough ('Flecken').

Name: Hasselt (Zwolle)
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 22 July 1227. The settlement came into being around 1180.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted by Henry (Hendrik) I of Vianden, bishop of Utrecht, in 1252.

Name: Hasselt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1165.

Name: Hassendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1215.

Name: Hassenhausen
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis.

Name: Haßleben
Settlement_Description: Burial sites found suggest the settlement of an early Thuringian noble family. First mention in a written record in the record book of Fulda monastery from 780-801.

Name: Haster Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the enclosure ('landwehr') of Osnabrück next to a bridge over the river Nette, first mentioned as "turris in Harst" in 1383.

Name: Hastedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1226.

Name: Hattem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from ca. 800.
Town_Description: Charter of town privileges has not been preserved. Generally, one assumes the granting of town privileges between 25 September and 31 October 1299, by Reginald I, Count of Guelders.
Fair_Description: In 1353, Duchess Alianora (second wife of Reinald (Reginald) II), Lady of the Veluwe, granted two fairs to Hattem.

Name: Hattorf
Alternative_Name: Hattorf am Harz; Hattorpp; Hattorph; Haldorp; Haddorpe; Hatdorp
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 952.

Name: Howiek
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned between 1260 and 1270.

Name: Havelberg
Settlement_Description: Settlement of Slavic origin; German foundation in 948 by Otto I. In the course of the Great Slav rising in 983 it went back under Slavic sovereignty. It was probably re-conquered in 1136/37.
Town_Description: The founding of the town was endorsed by Friedrich I. in 1179
Toll_Description: A toll in Havelberg is first mentioned when it was pawned by margrave Ludwig in 1335. A toll collector is mentioned in 1473. In 1570 or 1580 the episcopal toll on the Havel is moved from Nitzow to Havelberg.

Name: Heede
Alternative_Name: Heede, Ems; Heythe; Heyde; Hethe; Hede; Heda
Settlement_Description: Although first mentioned in 1212, the settlement is probably much older. It is traditionally believed that St Liudger founded a chapel here.
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Münster in Heede is mentioned in 1576, when it could not be pawned. Similarly in 1645, no toll collector could be found because the revenues had become very low due to the Thirty Years' War. A list of annual revenues is known from the years 1591-1604.
Fair_Description: Reyner von den Bele is mentioned in 1378 as owning a quarter of the market toll in Heede; other quarters are mentioned in 1420 and 1426. The fair in Heede is mentioned in 1482 as one of the free fairs in Emsland (next to Meppen, Haselünne and Haren). A date, however, is not known.

Name: Heemse
Alternative_Name: Heymiss; Hemis; Hemisse; Hemys; Hemysse; Hemissen; Heemsche; Heemsse
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1240.

Name: Heer
Alternative_Name: Heere; Here; Hyere juxta Trajectum; Her
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1176, in a eighteenth century copy.

Name: Heerde
Alternative_Name: Herodna; Herghe; Herdhe; Herda; Herthen; Herde; Heerd
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 838, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention dates from 1176, in a seventh century copy.

Name: Heerlen
Alternative_Name: Coriouallum; Corioualum; Coriouallio; Herla; Herle; Herlo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 300, in a eighth and tenth century copy. Next mention in 365, in a thirteenth century copy. Next mention in 1050 in a eleventh century copy.

Name: Heesch
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1191.

Name: Heeslingen
Settlement_Description: Heeslingen is first mentioned when a monastery of canonesses was founded around 961. The monastery was moved to Zeven in 1141.

Name: Heeten
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1300.

Name: Finow
Settlement_Description: First mention of the farm, mill and inn in "Hegermole" in 1294. The name suggests that it was a fortification at a Finow crossing.

Name: Heide
Alternative_Name: Vppe der Heide; Vpp der Heyde; Upp der Heyde; tor Heyde; to der Heide
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1434. Between 1447 and 1559, the settlement was the chief village of the peasant's republic Dithmarschen.

Name: Heijen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1271.

Name: Heikethalwarte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower, erected around 1280, destroyed in 1425, re-erected in 1452. According to Schmidt (1891) erected in 1454.

Name: Mamonovo
Alternative_Name: Heiligenbeil; Мамоново; Swentomest; Heylgenstat; Heiligenbil; Heiligenpeyel; Heiligenbuel; Helgebeil; zum Heiligenbeil; sancta civitas; Hieropolis
Settlement_Description: There used to be an Old-Prussian sacrificial altar where the city stands today, probably alongside a castle and a castle mound, the first german settlement later grew into a village, but was destroyed during the uprising of the old Prussians in 1260, the Old Prussian fortress was captured and destroyed in 1272 by the Counts Günter and Dietrich von Regenstein, the german settlement was rebuilt in the 14th ct.
Town_Description: The handfast is lost but the town was likely founded in 1301 with Kulm town law, it was mentioned as a civitas in 1330, new privileges were granted in 1522 and 1560

Name: Heiligenhafen
Settlement_Description: A planned town was established shortly after 1250.
Town_Description: First mentioned as a town in 1262; Lübeck town privileges were probably granted by Adolf IV, confirmed by Gerhard II in 1305.
Toll_Description: A transit toll of the count of Holstein is first mentioned in 1448.

Name: Heiligenkirchen
Alternative_Name: Halogokircan; Helagankyrcan; Heligenkerken; Hilgenekerken; Helghenkerken; Hylgenkerken; Hillighenkerken

Name: Heiligenloh
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252.

Name: Heiligenroda
Settlement_Description: Fist mention in 1184, deserted in 1970.

Name: Heiligenrode
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1123.

Name: Heiligenstedten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned by Adam von Bremen in the late 11th century, who described the foundation of a church around 830.

Name: Lidzbark Warmiński
Alternative_Name: Heilsberg; Heilesperch; Helisbergk; Heilisberc; Helsberg; Hilsberg; Helsperk; Helsperg; Höllsbeck; Elfzberk
Settlement_Description: Originally an old Prussian castle and settlement, a castle of the Teutonic Order is mentioned in 1241 but was destroyed by the Old Prussians in 1242, it was rebuilt in 1260 as the castle of a bishop, as such it was captured by the Old Prussians during their riot and remained in their possession until 1273
Town_Description: Eberhard von Neiße, the bishop of Warmia, grants the Kulm town law to the village next to the Bishop's castle in 1308

Name: Heinsberg
Toll_Description: The lord of Heinsberg levied a land toll in 1241. In addition to the land toll, safe conduct was also provided. In 1422 the toll rights were confirmed. Since 1483, the Lordship of Heinsberg was purchased by Jülich, with which the rights fell to the Duke of Jülich.

Name: Heisede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876. Since the evidence for Heisede could also apply to a homonymous place near Gronau, it is not always clear to which place it pertains.

Name: Heist
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1292.

Name: Helfta
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis, a castle from the 9th century is known, it was used as a royal court in the Early Middle Ages. 1229 a Cistercian convent is instituted in Mansfeld, that is moved to Helfta in 1259. It held some meaning until the Peasant's War in 1525.

Name: Hellefeld
Alternative_Name: Heliueldun; Heliueldon; Hileualden; Helivelde; Helvelde; Heleuelden; Heleuelde; Hieluelde; Helevelde; Heluelde; Kyrcheluelde; Heluelden; Kerckheluelde; Helfellen; Kirchhellefelder; Kirchhellefeldt; Hellefeldt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000.

Name: Hellendoorn
Alternative_Name: Hellender; Hellendorn; Helendorn; Helendoren; Helendoern; Hellendoern; Hellendoren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1275-1280.

Name: Hellendorf (Hannover)
Alternative_Name: Hellendorf; Helinghedorpe; Hellingdorppe; Hellengendorff; Hilgendorf; Helgenndorff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1360.

Name: Hellern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 13th century.

Name: Helme
Settlement_Description: At the beginning of the 14th century a castle was built. A settlement developed around it during medieval times. The castle was destroyed in 1658. A manor was built around the same time as the castle.

Name: Helmstedt
Settlement_Description: A missionary church was founded around 800 near the village Helmonstedi (first mentioned in 802), which developed into the Benedictine St Ludger monastery. The later town developed around the current market place in the 12th century. West of it, the monastery of Augustinian Canonesses Marienberg was founded in 1176. Between the monastery and the walled town, the planned suburb Neumark was located, which is first mentioned in 1249.
Town_Description: Helmstedt is first mentioned as "civitas" in 1228. Town privileges were confirmed in 1247.

Name: Helvoirt
Alternative_Name: Hellevorth; Helleuoirt; Helleuort; Helvorde; Helvort; Helvoert
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1192.

Name: Hemdingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1564.

Name: Hemelingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1238.

Name: Hemmelte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 11th century.

Name: Hemmendorf
Alternative_Name: Hemmonthorp; Hemmonthorpe; Hemmentorpe; Hemmendorp; Hymmentorp; Hemmondorp; Hemmendorp
Settlement_Description: When it was first mentioned in 822, Hemmendorf was in possession of Corvey. Later, the settlement developed into a borough ('flecken').
Toll_Description: Hemmendorf is first mentioned as toll station of the lords of Homburg in 1384.

Name: Hemslingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1320.

Name: Hendrieken
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1079, in a circa seventeenth century copy.

Name: Hengelo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1381-1383.

Name: Hengsterholz
Alternative_Name: Langenhenstede; Hunsterholt; Hesterholte; Hengsterholtz; Hensteder holte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as "Langenhenstede" in 1213.

Name: Herbaijum
Alternative_Name: Hjerbeam; Herbadingum; Heerbadigim; Herbaynghum; Herbadeghum; Herbaeyum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in thirteenth century.

Name: Herbern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 9th century.

Name: Herbern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 900.

Name: Herborn
Alternative_Name: Herbore; Herberen; Herberin; Herbere; Herbern; Herwern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1251 as 'villa'. Perhaps there was a seat of a royal court here.
Town_Description: In 1251 the settlement received the right to fortification and a market. The sovereign is used as the town lord. Mentioned 'civitas' in 1296, referred to as 'oppidum' in 1329 and as a city in 1332.

Name: Herk-de-Stad
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1107, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Herda
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1244.

Name: Herdecke
Alternative_Name: Herrche; Herreke; Nunherrike; Herrike; Herdecke; Herdicke; Heirtgen; Heriche; Heriko; Heryche
Settlement_Description: The settlement was built next to an abbey founded in 810. In 1355 the settlement received market privilege.
Toll_Description: The Count of the Mark and the Hospital of Herdecke levied bridge fee in 1392. In 1421 those rights were confirmed.

Name: Herderen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1096.

Name: Herent
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1140.

Name: Herentals
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1181.

Name: Herford
Alternative_Name: Herivurth; Herifurd; Heriford; Herivord; Hervordi; Herivort; Herifort; Herevorde; Herfurden; Hervord; Herivordense; Herivurdense; Hefordense; Herifurdense; Hervordia
Settlement_Description: The imperial abbey Herford was founded in 789.
Town_Description: The old town received town rights around 1170. A judge and leader of the community are mentioned in 1191. The characterisation 'civitas' appears between 1219 and 1226. The new town was founded around 1224 and remained independent until 1634.

Name: Hermannsburg
Alternative_Name: Heremannesburc; Hermannesburch; Hirminnesburch; Hermenborch; Hermensborch; Hermannesborch; Hermansborch; Hermensborg; Hermensburg; Helmersburg; Hermelsburg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1059.

Name: Herne
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as 'Kirchdorf' in the 9th century at the intersection of old trade routes.

Name: Herrenbreitungen
Settlement_Description: Today, Alten-, Frauen- and Herrenbreitungen are merged in one village called Breitungen.
Town_Description: Referred to as civitas in 1189
Toll_Description: Toll regulations from the 16th century settle the fees that had to be paid in (Herren-)Breitungen.

Name: Herrhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 947.

Name: Bad Hersfeld
Alternative_Name: Hersfeld; Hirschfeld; Haerulfisfelt; Herolvesfeld; Herveld; Herveldia; Heresfeld; Heristfeld; Herollosvelt; Herosfeld; Hiersfelt; Hyersfeldt; Herschfeld; Herocampia
Settlement_Description: Originally a student of Boniface founded a hermitage here in 736/743, but it had to be given up again in 744. Benedictine abbey founded between 769 and 775, near which a settlement was built.

Name: Herselt
Alternative_Name: Harsele; Herselo; Harsele; Harselo; Hersele; Hersselt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1139.

Name: Herstelle
Alternative_Name: Hiristalli; Heristelli; Haristalli; Haristallio; Herstelli; Harstelle
Settlement_Description: The settlement possibly goes back to a Carolingian fortification near an important river crossing; it was first mentioned in 1036. A castle of the bishop of Paderborn was first mentioned in 1163. The settlement near the castle acquired a market in 1171, and was mentioned in 1399 as town.
Toll_Description: Herstelle was listed as a toll station on the Weser river in a complaint from Bremen from 1584.
Ferry_Description: River crossing between Herstelle and Würgassen. It cannot be determined whether this was a ford or a ferry. According to Herbst (1926), the crossing had the character of a ford, as there existed a settlement on both sides of the crossing, since wagoners had to wait here for a while during floods before they could cross the river.

Name: Herten (Recklinghausen)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned 1117.

Name: Herten (Roermond)
Alternative_Name: Herten; Hercena; Hertra; Herta; Hertam; Herthenam; Herthen; Hertene; Hertthen; Ruerharten; Hartten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 968.

Name: Herwijnen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 850 in a eleventh-century copy.

Name: Herxen
Alternative_Name: Herxze; Hercsem; Herxe; Herchse; Harxen; Hercxen; Herkzen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1310.

Name: Herzberg (Elster)
Toll_Description:
Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wettin in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig.
The regulations of safe conduct show that long-distance trade goods passed through here.
Fair_Description: The regulations of safe conduct for Dobra and Nauendorf state that the fee is only due when it is fair day in Herzberg and Kirchhain.

Name: Herzberg am Harz
Alternative_Name: Herzberg; Hirzberg; Hirschberg; Hirtzberch; Hirzisberch; Hertsberg; Hartesbergk; Hirßperg; Hirzesberc; Hirceberch
Settlement_Description: Count Werner of Lutterberg built a hunting house in 1029, below which a settlement developed. In the second half of the 16th or the first half of the 17th century, Herzberg acquired borough ('flecken') privileges, an exact year is unknown.
Toll_Description: A toll in Herzberg is first mentioned shortly after 1421, but probably existed already in 1315.

Name: Herzfeld
Alternative_Name: Hirutfelt; Hirutfeldienses; Hyrutueldun; Hyrutuelde; Hirutveldun; Hirutfelda; Heretvelde; Hertuelde; Hirutfeldon; Hertvelde

Name: Herzford
Settlement_Description: A first mention as Hriasforda in 890 is very uncertain.

Name: 's-Hertogenbosch
Alternative_Name: Herzogenbusch; Den Bosch; nouo opido super siluam juxta Orten; noua civitate apud Siluam; silua iuxta Orten; Orten que nunc Silua dicitur; Busco ducis; Boscho ducis; sHertoghen bosche; super Silvam juxta Orthen; de Orthen cum Buscho; van Ordunen, dat men nu seegt Bossche
Settlement_Description: 's-Hertogenbosch is first mentioned in 1185.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted in May 1195 by Henry I, duke of Brabant.

Name: Herzogenrath
Toll_Description: 1) The Duke of Limburg levied a land toll in 1161. In 1389, 2 groschen per wine cart with two horses had to be paid, 4½ groschen per wine cart with 4 horses. In 1356/57 1188 cologne mark 8 denarii were collected, in 1374/75 2866 cologne mark and in 1377/78 1951 cologne marks. For further annual revenues see source. 2) The Duke of Limburg also levied a fee for safe conduct in 1249. For Flemings, a tariff of 27 denarii per barrel of wine applied in 1249. After the Land Peace of 1375, 2 to 3 white pennies ('Weißpfennig/Albus) per horse were paid, depending on the load. Horse fee and land toll merged with each other over time.

Name: Hessen
Alternative_Name: Hessenheim; Haessenhem; Hessenem; Heissenhem; Hesnem; Hessem; Hesnum; Heßem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 966. Since 1129 the lords of Hessen are mentioned as the owners of the castle and the village.

Name: Hesserode
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1230.

Name: Hessisch Oldendorf
Alternative_Name: Oldendorf; Hess. Oldendorf; Oldendorpe; Aldenthorpe; Aldendorpe; Hessen-Oldendorf
Settlement_Description: A first mention around 1160/70 is uncertain; first certainly mentioned around 1247. The planned town was probably founded in the 1230s.
Town_Description: Lippstadt town privileges were granted in 1405.
Toll_Description: The toll levied on land and river traffic was moved from Großenwieden to Oldendorf in 1588. Because the old river arm on which Oldendorf is located was closed in 1616, the toll was moved to Rumbeck, but it came back to Oldendorf in 1638 at the latest during the 30-Years' War. Toll registers exist in NLA Bückeburg, L1 Nr. 6372-6379, 6386-6390.
Fair_Description: In 1462, older market privileges in Oldendorf were confirmed. This concerned the large seven-day fair on Monday before St Michael. In 1563, two other fairs were granted on the Mondays after Oculi and after Exaudi, for which the timeframe was set to three days before and after the said days.

Name: Heelsum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1160.

Name: Hettstedt
Settlement_Description: 1046 Mention in a gift certificate by Henry III. to Meißen monastery (MGH DD H III, nr. 157, S. 198f.). The mining industry facilitates building a castle in Hettstedt, which is desterted again around 1575.
Town_Description: Reference to the settlement as "civitas" in 1283, later as "stad" in 1334. First mention of a council in Hettstedt in 1385.
Fair_Description: In 1453 two fairs were known, additional fairs were granted in 1679 and 1697.

Name: Heubach
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1311.

Name: Heuckewalde
Settlement_Description: Mention of an official of Heuckewalde in records since 1153.

Name: Heumen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dated in 1188, but it is uncertain whether this year is correct. Knights of Heumen are mentioned multiple times in the thirteenth century.

Name: Diets-Heur
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1385.

Name: Hever
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1150.

Name: Heythuysen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1383.

Name: Hien
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention probably dates from the second half of the ninth century, in a copy dated between 1150 and 1158. Mentioned as 'apud Hian' at the end of the eleventh century.

Name: Hierden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1331.

Name: Hilchenbach
Settlement_Description: First mentioned 1292 as a village.

Name: Iļķene
Settlement_Description: In 1463, the land with the ferry, inn and fishing was given as a fief. David Hilchen bought the land in 1599.

Name: Hildburghausen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1234.
Town_Description: Awarding of Coburg town rights in 1314, which is revoked temporarily in 1334.
Toll_Description: Toll station of the district of Heldburg. A toll- and regulation of safe conduct remains from 1570.

Name: Hildernisse
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1094-1095, in a fifteenth century copy. This village drowned in 1570.

Name: Hildesheim
Alternative_Name: Hildenisheim; Hiltineshimensi; Hildinemensem; Hildinensem; Hildensem; Hildenshem; Hilmsen
Settlement_Description: Emperor Louis the Pious founded the diocese of Hildesheim near a merchant settlement in 815. The settlement received market privileges around 1000.
