Town_Description: Around 1146, Hildesheim is already characterised as 'civitas'. A town hall is first mentioned in 1217, and in 1300 the old town granted itself town rights. The new town, which was founded around 1220, formed a union with the old town since 1583, but both parts were only formally united in 1803.
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Hildesheim is first mentioned in 1382, when it was pawned to Aschwin von Meienberg. In 1389 it was pawned to Gunzel von Lutter.
Fair_Description: The town rights of 1300 mention three fairs, on the Annunciation, the Ascension of the Virgin Mary, and on St Michael's day. According to the stand fees in the town accounts from 1379 onwards, the Annunciation fair was the most visited of the Hildesheim fairs. A fourth fair on St Gotthard is mentioned in 1310. In 1460, the old fairs were replace by two six-day fairs, for a trial period of four years: the fair of St Michael remained, and a new fair took place on Misericordia Sunday. Apparently the trial was a success, because in 1476, the two fairs were reiterated for the period of 12 years with slight modifications. After that period and before 1523, the situation must have changed again, since it is mentioned in the latter year that there were four three-day fairs in the town, which had been held since times of old: next to the fairs of St Michael and Misericordia Sunday, the Annunciation fair had been revived and a new fair on Wednesday after Pentecost was added.

Name: Hillegom
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1248.

Name: Hilleshagen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1227.

Name: Hilter am Teutoburger Wald
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1171.

Name: Hiltrup
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1218 and 1226.

Name: Hilversum
Alternative_Name: Hilfercem; Hilfersem; Hilferssom; Hilferssen; Hilfertsem; Hilfersum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1305.

Name: Himmelpforten
Alternative_Name: Hymelporte; Himilporte; Hymelporthen; Portam Celi; Hemelpforten; Hemelportzen; Himmelparten

Name: Hindeloopen
Alternative_Name: Hylpen; Hitinkufe; Hindelopis; Hindelopen; Hindeloep; Hintinlvofe; Hindahlop; Hindelepum; Hinlopen; Hindelepen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 822 and circa 825.
Town_Description: First mentioned as a town on 25 July 1368.

Name: Hindenburg
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1208.
Toll_Description: Mention of a toll station.

Name: Hinte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Hinderdam
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1317.

Name: Hinternah
Settlement_Description: First mention 1178.

Name: Hintham
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1300.

Name: Inčukalns
Settlement_Description: The manor and the surrounding land were mentioned as fiefs in 1436.

Name: Hirschberg
Settlement_Description: The place grew under the protection of the castle of the Counts of Arnsberg, which was built in the 12th century. The settlement was first mentioned in 1308.
Town_Description: In 1308 the town was given town privileges of Eversberg by Count Wilhelm von Arnsberg, which were confirmed in 1364.

Name: Hochheim
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 754 during the transfer of Bonitafius's remains from Mainz to Fulda.

Name: Höchst
Alternative_Name: Frankfurt-Höchst; Hostat; Hosteden; Hochstedin; Hosten; Hosti; Hoeste; Hoest; Hoegst; Hoechst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 790. In the area of ​​the old town there was an earth fort built in Augustan times.
Town_Description: In 1355, Karl IV authorizes the Archbishop of Mainz to fortify his villages and make them towns under Frankfurt law.

Name: Höckelheim
Settlement_Description: First reference in 1016.

Name: Hoevelaken
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention at least in 1286.

Name: Hoevenen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1329.

Name: Hofgeismar
Alternative_Name: Hovegeismari; Geismare; Chiesmare; Chesmarie; Geismar; Hovegesmar; Geysmar; Hovengeismar; Geismaria; Geismarienses
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as 'curtis' 1082.
Town_Description: The place was granted town privileges between 1220 and 1230, which were confirmed several times between 1354 and 1646. A 'nova civitas' is mentioned in 1234 and a mint master in 1210.

Name: Hofheim
Settlement_Description: The settlement was mentioned in 1294, in the vicinity there are Roman remains of a stone fort built in 83 AD.
Town_Description: In 1352 Philipp von Falkenstein was allowed by Charles V to convert the village, called a 'villa' since 1294, into a town.

Name: Hohenbostel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1321.

Name: Hoheneggelsen
Alternative_Name: Eggensem; Eggelsim; Eggeleshim; Eckelesheim; Ekkelsem; Honnegkelsen; Honekkelsem; Honeckelsum; Honeggelsem; Egkelsem; Hoen Egelsehn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1044.

Name: Hoheneiche
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1337.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct of Saalfeld (1728).

Name: Hohenfinow
Settlement_Description: First mention of castle Vinow in 1258. Due to its location at trading routes between Berlin and Frankfurt/Oder it developed quickly, but this development came to a sudden end when the trade route was moved to Eberswalde in 1317. Hohenfinow was last referred to as little town in 1547. The village detereorated in the 30-year-war and only recovered around 1666.
Toll_Description: A toll and a entrepot in the 13th/14th century.

Name: Hohengöhren
Alternative_Name: Hohengören; Gorony; Goren; Hoghengörne; Hoen Gohren; Hohengarne
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1337, mention of a knightly manor.

Name: Hohenhameln
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1146. The settlement was the seat of a regional court ('gogericht'). Next to the village, a market borough ('marktflecken') was founded in the 14th century.
Fair_Description: Fairs in Hohenhameln were probably held since the founding of a market borough in the 14th century. Dates are not known before 1695, when three two-day fairs were granted.

Name: Hohenheida
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1399 as Windysche Heide.

Name: Hohenhörn
Toll_Description: After the construction of the "new road" to Dithmarschen, the toll of Hanerau was also levied in Hohenhörn since 1601.

Name: Hohenossig
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1350 as Osek.

Name: Hohenseeden
Alternative_Name: Sadun; Sodin; Soden; Seden; Hoen Seeden
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1144 as property of Berge monastery.

Name: Olsztynek
Settlement_Description: A castle of the Teutonic Order was built around 1350 alongside a village from 1343
Town_Description: The Grand Master Winrich von Kniprode grants founded the town in 1359 with Kulm town law

Name: Hohenthurm
Settlement_Description: In 1244 a noble family is mentioned. In 1347 Hohenthurm goes to Magdeburg.

Name: Hohenweddrien
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1368.

Name: Hohenwepel
Alternative_Name: Weplide; Vuepplithi; Weplithi; Wepletha; Weplethe; Weplede; Wepletha; Veplethe; Wepelde; Hogenwepelde; Wepeldte; Wepel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000.

Name: Hohenwestedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1217. A church was founded in the 12th century.

Name: Hohenzethen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1289.

Name: Hohenziatz
Alternative_Name: Zojas; Cyas; Czyas; Hohen Zeyass; Hohen Zigahtz
Settlement_Description: 992 mentioned in a record by Otto III. In 1187 part of the castle district ('Burgward') of Loburg, after that property of the archbishopric of Brandenburg and later the seat in Ziesar.
Toll_Description: Toll station of Magdeburg on the road to Brandenburg.

Name: Hohnsen
Settlement_Description: It is uncertain whether the Hainanhusen mentioned in 955 refers to Hohnsen; first mentioned with certainty as Hodenhusen in 1185/87.

Name: Höingen
Alternative_Name: Hoingi; Honge; Hoange; Hoingen; Huingke; Hoyngen; Hoyginc; Hoynch; Overen-Hoginge; Overhoyngen; Hoedingenn; Hoengen; Hywinkcke

Name: Hoisbüttel
Alternative_Name: Hoyersbutle; Hoygersbutle; Hoygersbuttel; Hogersbuttel; Hoyelsbuttell; Hoyeßbüttel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1262.

Name: Holbach
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1152.

Name: Holdenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1060.

Name: Hollage
Settlement_Description: First mentioned ca. 1245.

Name: Holle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1146.

Name: Holleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis fom the end of the 9th century. In 1091 central castle district ('Burgward-Hauptort'). The settlement developed into a borough-like village with a market and town hall, among others due to its Jew toll and rights to a ferry during the Middle Ages. The 30-year war and the plague terminated the flourishing times of the village.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Lauchstädt.

Name: Hollenbek
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1323.

Name: Hollenstedt
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 947.

Name: Hollingstedt
Alternative_Name: Hollingsted; Hylingstaða; Huchlstiæth; Huhelstath; Huglæstath; Hwelstath
Settlement_Description: Hollingstedt is mentioned in the Schleswig town law of ca. 1200 as North Sea harbour of Schleswig at the Treene. Archaeological finds show that there was a transshipment point here since the 11th century.

Name: Holm (Holstein)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1255.

Name: Holstre
Settlement_Description: Hamlet ('Hof') owned by the Teutonic Order.

Name: Waardenborg
Toll_Description: Road toll of the bishop of Utrecht at Waardenborg castle, first mentioned in 1383 when the toll fees were set for inhabitants from Twente. From 1444 to 1487 the toll was pledged to the town of Deventer. In 1528 Charles V, the Holy Roman Emperor took over the power of the bishop of Utrecht. He decided to demolish the castle as happened in the following years.

Name: Höltenklinken
Alternative_Name: Klein-Rümpel; Lutteken Rumpnigh; Klinken; Höltenklinke; Holtenklincken; Holtzen Klincken; Höltzernklincken; Klincken; Holtzernklincken; Hölzernklincken
Settlement_Description: Originally the settlement Klein-Rümpel, mentioned in 1420. It was succeeded in the 16th century by the manor Klinken and the associated village Höltenklinken.

Name: Holtorf (Nienburg)
Settlement_Description: A settlement probably already existed before the 9th century.

Name: Holtorf (Schnackenburg)
Alternative_Name: Holtorf; Holtdorpe; Holttorppe; Holtorp; Holtorpe; Holtorff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1334.

Name: Holtrup
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 865 and 868/72.

Name: Holtsee
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a Kiel town register of 1264-89.

Name: Holxen
Alternative_Name: Holekessen; Holekesne; Holleckessen; Holzele; Holcsen, Holten; Holtensen; Holtzing; Hollexen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252.

Name: Holzen
Alternative_Name: Holthusen; Holthosen; Holtensen; Holzem; Holtzhausen; Holtenßen; Holtzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1184.

Name: Holzhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1031.

Name: Holzhausen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1289.

Name: Bad Holzhausen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1033.

Name: Holzminden
Alternative_Name: Holtesmeni; Holtesmynne; Holtisminni; Holtesminnen; Holtesminne; Holttesminne; Holtisminne; Holzesminden; Holtesminde; Holtsmynne; Holtesmunde; Holteßmynne; Holtzmynne; Holtzmyn; Holtzminda; Holtzmind
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 826. The original settlement was possibly located in Altendorf, because in the 11th century, both Altendorf ("Aldenthorpe") and two settlements named Holzminden ("Holtisminni duo") appear in the sources. Altendorf was merged with Holzminden in 1922.
Town_Description: A town was founded around 1200 by the counts of Everstein; it received town privileges in 1245.
Toll_Description: A toll of the duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel in Holzminden is first mentioned in 1539. It was levied on land and river traffic, of which the latter was far more significant. According to a note in 1584, those who already paid toll in Holzminden were exempted from the toll in Fürstenberg. The earliest toll registers date from 1601/1602, which were analysed by Rothe.
Fair_Description: Duke Julius of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel granted Holzminden in 1588 the right to hold 3 fairs. These took place on St Martin's Day, Cathedra Petri, and Pentecost.

Name: Holzweißig
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of the department of Bitterfeld.

Name: Homberg
Alternative_Name: Homberg (Efze); Hohenberc; Hoinberg; Hohenberg; Hoenberg; Hoenbergk; Homberk
Settlement_Description: A castle is mentioned for the first time in 1162.
Town_Description: The city was founded in 1231 at the latest. 'Villicitatio et burgenses' mentioned in 1254.

Name: Bad Homburg vor der Höhe
Alternative_Name: Homburg; Tidenheim; Ditincheim; Tittingesheim; Diedeckem; Dydeckheym; Diedigheim; Diedicomb; Hohenberch; Hoenberch; Hohinberch; Hoinberch; Hoemburg; Homberg
Settlement_Description: The place goes back to the Dietigheim settlement, which was first mentioned between 769 and 782. The reason for the settlement was probably the nearby salt springs, which were already used in Roman and Franconian times. At the end of the 12th century a castle was built over the village.
Town_Description: The elevation to a town is set between 1318 and 1335. In 1361 it was first called a town.

Name: Honerdingen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1382.

Name: Höngeda
Settlement_Description: First mention in 876.

Name: Hoof
Alternative_Name: Hobe; Hoff; daz nuwe hus; im Hobe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1315 and 1318.

Name: Hoog-Soeren
Alternative_Name: Suornom; Sorna; Hosoren; Hoogsoeren; Hoge Suren; Hoog Souren; Hoog Soeren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 814-815, in a copy dating from 1170-1175. Next mention in 1025, in an eighteenth century copy.

Name: Hoogeveen
Alternative_Name: Nie Echten; `t Hooge Veen; Hoog Echten; Hogeveen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Nie Echten' in 1634. Earliest mention of 'Hoogeveen' in 1648,

Name: Hooghalen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in a copy dating from 1217. Next mention dates from 1334.

Name: Hoogkarspel
Alternative_Name: Hoghekerspel; Hooghkarspel; Hooge kerspel; Hoogh Carspel
Settlement_Description: Hoogkarspel is first mentioned probably circa 1312. On 20 April 1403, Hoogkarspel was added to the ‘stede’ Broek, which already consisted of Grootebroek, Bovenkarspel and Lutjebroek. Grootebroek and Bovenkarspel had been granted town privileges on 2 August 1364 by Albert ('Albrecht'), governor ('ruwaard') of Holland. In 1402, Hoogkarspel had been added to this ‘stede’. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The 'stede' lost its privileges in 1426, but these were partly regranted in 1429, and fully restored in 1436.

Name: Hoog-Keppel
Alternative_Name: Hoogkeppel; Hoog Keppel; Kepple; Keppele; Capelle; Cappele; Kepple; Keppele; Capele; Kepele; Olden-Keppel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the mid-12th century. The addition "Hoog-" or "Olden-" appears later to discern the village from Laag-Keppel near the castle Keppel.

Name: Hoogstraten
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1256.

Name: Hoopte
Ferry_Description: Ferry to Zollenspieker, moved here in the 16th century due to the relocation of the Ilmenau estuary.

Name: Hoorn
Alternative_Name: Hoern; Horne; Hoirne; Hoirn; Hoerne; Horn
Settlement_Description: According to Cox, Hoorn is first mentioned in 1298. Van Berkel & Samplonius, however, state that the 1298 mention is a forgery dating from 1424. The following mention they note, dates from 1312.
Town_Description: Hoorn was granted town rights on 27 March 1356 by William V, count of Holland. One of the smaller ‘Kamers’ (departments) of the VOC (Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie, Dutch East India Company, founded in 1602) was located in Hoorn.

Name: Hoppenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1249.

Name: Hördinghausen
Alternative_Name: Ordinchusen; Hurdinchusen; Hordinchusen; Horthinchusen; Hordighusen; Wrdinchusen; Wurdighusen; Wordinchusen; Wurthinchusen; Wordingehusen; Hardinc; Hörminghausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 969 and 996.

Name: Höringhausen
Alternative_Name: Hogerinchusen; Hoyrynchusen; Horinchusen; Hoyerichusen; Hovenchusen; Hornighausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1264.

Name: Horn (Bad Meinberg)
Alternative_Name: Horn; Horne; Hornon; Hornum; Hanrne; Hurn; Hornne; Horen; Hornouwe; Hornan; Hornsche
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1031 and 1128.
Town_Description: Between 1230 and 1248 town privileges after Lippstädter rights were granted.

Name: Horn (Maas)
Alternative_Name: Hurne; Hurnen; Hornin; Horne; Huerne; Hoern; Hoorn
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1102

Name: Horn (Hamburg)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1309. A boom barrier is mentioned here in 1465.

Name: Hornbek
Alternative_Name: Horneburg; Hornebeck; Horgenbeke; Horchenbici; Horghenbeke; Harghenbeke; Hornigbecke
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 9th century

Name: Hornburg
Settlement_Description: A settlement Hornberc is already mentioned in 890 in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis. The foundation of a monastery occurrs at the beginning or the middle of the 12th century, in 1535 it is secularized.

Name: Stadt Hornburg
Alternative_Name: Hornburg; Hornaburch; Hohenborc; Horneborgh; Horneborgk; Honaburhc; Horneburch; Horneburg
Settlement_Description: A castle is first mentioned in 994, but possibly goes back to Frankish times. Next to it, a settlement developed.
Town_Description: The exact date on which town privileges were granted is unknown, possibly in 1525. After 1378, the settlement is characterised as borough ('flecken'), and as town from 1552.
Fair_Description: The bishop of Halberstadt granted two free fairs in 1552, on the day of St Walpurga and on Sunday before St Martin.

Name: Horndorf
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1299.

Name: Horneburg (Altes Land)
Settlement_Description: A castle was built by the archbishop of Bremen in 1255. Next to the castle a settlement developed.

Name: Hörsingen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1112.

Name: Horst (Holstein)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in ca. 1234.

Name: Horstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1212/1213.

Name: Branti
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1424.

Name: Horstmar
Settlement_Description: First mentioned at the beginning of the 11th century.
Town_Description: In the second half of the 13th century, town privileges were awarded by the Bishop of Münster. Called 'oppidum' in 1297.

Name: Hösseringen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1239.

Name: Hötensleben
Settlement_Description: Can be proven as early as the 9th century. In 1251 a castle can be proven.

Name: Hötzum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1031.

Name: Walshoutem
Alternative_Name: Holtheim; Holtheym; Houthem; Huten; Houtaing le Vesque; Wals-Houtem; Bisschops Houthem; Houtain-l'Évêque
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1118.

Name: Höver
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1254.

Name: Höveringhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1169.

Name: Hovestadt
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1231.
Toll_Description: The Archbishop of Cologne levied a toll in 1438. This was probably a land toll.

Name: Höxter
Alternative_Name: Huxeri; Hucxori; Huxori; Huxeli; Hugseli; Huxarientes; Huxere; Huxera; Huxara; Huxariam; Huxarie; Huxaria; Huxar; Hoxer; Hoxere; Hoxser; Höxer; Höxar; Hüxer
Settlement_Description: Höxter came into existence as a settlement on the crossing of the river Weser on the east-west trading route from Westfalia near the monastery of Corvey.
Town_Description: Date of acquisition of town privileges unclear. A market is mentioned near the Weser bridge in 1115, which acquired fortification privileges in 1152. The first council ordinances are known from 1225, and the town must have acquired Dortmund town privileges after 1256.
Fair_Description: The fair on the holiday of Simon and Jude, which was granted before or around 1300 by the abbot of Corvey, was the most important fair in Höxter. Two other fairs are known as well, on Cathedra Petri and Cantate Sunday. In 1514, it was ordained that all commodities had to be offered for salevon the market for three days before they were allowed to be sold elsewhere in town.

Name: Kirchhuchting
Alternative_Name: Huchting; Huhthinge; Huginke; Huchtinge; Huchtingen; Hoychtiggen; Huchtigen; Huchtyghe; Huctinge; Kerchoytiggen; Kerkhuchtiggen; Kerchhuchtinge; Kerchuchtingen; Kerchutinghen; Kerchuctinge; Kerchuchtinghe
Settlement_Description: The settlement Huchting was divided in three parts: Kirch-, Mittels- and Brokhuchting, of which the former two are the oldest parts. In Kirchhuchting, the church was located, which was probably founded in the 12th century. It is first mentioned separately in 1288.

Name: Huckingen
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in 1471. Tariffs and revenues have not been handed down.

Name: Hudemühlen
Settlement_Description: The castle Hodenhagen was destroyed in 1289. A new castle was built in nearby Hudemühlen.

Name: Hühnerbusch
Lock_Description: The map of Mecklenburg included in the atlas of Janssonius from 1622 shows a lock north of Blücher in the Schaale canal, which was built in 1564. Probably this was a lock in the mill weir of Hühnerbusch.

Toll_Description:
This was a toll for sailing transport on river Rhine and a continuation of the toll of Angeren. In 1656 the levying of the toll moved to Emmerich.
    In 1751 a new "Lizent zu Huissen" was founded for the sailing traffic that came from Nijmegen via river Waal to Arnhem. This ended in 1816 as the Huissen and Malburgen area were incorporated into the Netherlands. Scholz-Babisch, 1971, p. 363-373, presents an extract of the toll registration for the years 1578 - 1580 and (p. 438, 726) a tariff list from 1596/7.

Name: Huizen
Alternative_Name: Husen; Huyssem; Huzen; Huessen; Huysen; Huyssen; Hyussem; Huijsen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1381-1382.

Name: Hulja
Settlement_Description: The manor was built in the 13th or 14th century. A village developed next to it.

Name: Hüls
Toll_Description: The Archbishop of Cologne levied a land toll in 1364.

Name: Hümme
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Hummeldorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of the monastery of Werden from ca. 890.

Name: Hummelo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 828, in a eleventh century copy.

Name: Hünfeld
Alternative_Name: Unofelt; Hunifelt; Hunefelt; Hunnenfelt; Huenfeld; Hunevelt; Huneveld; Honevelt; Hunefeld; Heunfeld; Hunfelt; Haunfeld; Hunfeldt; Heuneveld; Heunefeld; Huniofelt; Hünenfeld; Hünfelt; campus hunae; Hunerendensis; Heunfeldensis
Settlement_Description: Charlemagne donated the 'campus hunae' in 781 to the Fulda monastery. A 'Hörigensiedlung' is first mentioned in 1049.
Town_Description: Called 'civis' in 1295 and 1308, 'oppidum' in 1299 at the latest. In 1310 King Heinrich VII granted Gelnhausen town rights.

Name: Hungen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 782 in a deed of gift. Maybe goes back to a Roman settlement.
Town_Description: In 1361 town privileges were granted. Then called town in 1403.

Name: Hünighausen
Alternative_Name: Hüninghausen; Huninghusun; Huneckhusen; Huninchusen; Hunenchus; Hünenchussen; Hünekussen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1107 and 1128.

Name: Hunsel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1400.

Name: Hunteburg
Settlement_Description: Castle, built by bishop Gottfried of Osnabrück in 1324, next to which a settlement developed successively.
Toll_Description: Toll station of the bishop of Osnabrück after 1334. An agreement with Diepholz in 1388 concerns the toll on fish caught in the Dümmer lake, furthermore the fish carts were exempted from toll.

Name: Hüpstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1124.

Name: Hüsby
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1196.

Name: Hüselitz
Settlement_Description: First mention in a name in 1251. Further mention in records from 1345.

Name: Hüsten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 802, in connection with the Werden monastery.
Town_Description: In 1360 the majority of Hüsten was liberated and granted Arnsberg rights.

Name: Husum
Settlement_Description: The bridge Husembro is first mentioned in 1252. After the "Mandränke" flood of 1362, a navigable connection with the sea was created, where the harbour settlement Husum existed in 1372; in 1398 divided into Oster- and Westerhusum.
Town_Description: Market privileges were granted to the borough ('blek') Husum in 1465, and it acquired its own jurisdiction in 1472. Town privileges were granted in 1608.
Fair_Description: Husum was an important market for oxen driven from Jutland. Markets are first attested in 1493 and took place each Thursday in May and April, with the main fairs taking place on the last Thursday in April and the first Thursday in May. In autumn, there was an oxen fair on St Simon and Jude. In 1607, two three-day cattle markets were granted in spring and autumn.

Name: Hützel
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1267.

Name: Ibbenbüren
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1146/47.

Name: Bad Iburg
Alternative_Name: Iburg; Iuberg; Iuburg; Uiberg; Wiburg; Yburg; Yburch; Iborg
Settlement_Description: Possibly goes back to the Merovingian period. In the 11th century, there was a castle and a monastery, under which a settlement developed. A Benedictine monastery was founded around 1080/81, flourished economically at the end of the 15th century and was closed in 1803. The settlement was first mentioned as 'villa' between 1219 and 1237.
Town_Description: Listed as 'oppidum' with civic rights in 1254. From 1359, parts of the town law were based on those of Osnabrück.

Name: Ichtershausen
Settlement_Description: Foundation of a proprietary church in 1133, which is transformed into a Cistercian convent in 1147.

Name: Ickhorst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1438.

Name: Idegem
Alternative_Name: Idingehem; Hedegen; Idenghem; Idengem; Ydenghem; Itegem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 964 . Next mention in 1147.

Name: Iden
Settlement_Description: First mention in a name in 1308; mention of the village in 1334.

Name: Idstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1196.

Name: Ifta
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1260.

Name: Igavere
Settlement_Description: The village that belonged to the Manor of Ellistfer was mentioned in 1220.

Name: Ihleburg
Settlement_Description: Given to Berge monastery in 1117, in 1300 a family of Ilborch is mentioned.

Name: Īle
Settlement_Description: The manor was probably built shortly after 1530.

Name: IJlst
Alternative_Name: Drylts; Jleke; Yleke; Ylike; Yhlike; Dorylse; Yilse; Trils; Yltze; Ylst; Ilst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1268.
Town_Description: The earliest possible year that IJlst was granted town privileges is 1268. Cox states that IJlst is first mentioned as 'oppidum' in 1315.

Name: IJsselmuiden
Alternative_Name: Islemuthen; Islemunde; Yselmueden; Yselmude; IJselmueden; IJselmude; Yselmuden; IJselmuden; Ysselmuiden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1133. The medieval church (located at Dorpsweg 53) has probably been built around 1200.

Name: IJsselstein
Alternative_Name: Yselsteyne; Iselsteine; Yselsteine; Ycelsteyne; Steyne; Yselsteyn
Settlement_Description: IJsselstein is first mentioned in 1279.
Town_Description: IJsselstein developed several city-like features in the period 1279 - 1363. It was officially granted town rights on 23 June 1363 by Guyote van IJsselstein.

Name: IJzendoorn
Alternative_Name: Maandra; Isaandra; Isendra; Ysender; Ysendoren; Yseldorn
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 850-865 (possibly 855) in a copy dated between 1170 and 1175.

Name: Ildehausen
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1147.

Name: Illeber Brücke
Toll_Description: The Illeben bridge constituted the border of the Erfurt escort area.

Name: Ilmenau
Settlement_Description: The water castle and the corresponding place of the castle lay at the long-range traffirc route Erfurt-Nuremburg.
Town_Description: Mention as town ('stet'). Granted town rights in 1341.
Toll_Description: A toll regulation remains from 1642 (ThStA Rudolstadt, Kanzlei Arnstadt 1129, 1642).

Name: Ilmjärve
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1510.

Name: Imbshausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 966.

Name: Immekath
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1289.

Name: Immendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1175.

Name: Immenhausen
Settlement_Description: Nobles von Immenhausen mentioned since 1143. The town itself is mentioned as a subject of dispute in 1282.
Town_Description: Town privileges can be proven from 1298. The town is mentioned as an 'oppidum' in 1303 and 1331.

Name: Immenrode
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1086.

Name: Immensen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 822-826.

Name: Immighausen
Alternative_Name: Ymminchusen; Imminghusun; Immynchusen; Imminchusen; Imickhusen; Immichusen; Ymenchusen; Jminchusen; Imminckhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Chernyakhovsk
Settlement_Description: Grew out of the castle of the Teutonic Order and multiple settlements that have existed before 1336
Town_Description: In 1583, Margrave George Friedrich von Anspach, de duke of Prussia, grants the German town law based on the Kulm town law, to the market settlement

Name: Inciems
Settlement_Description: The Inzeem manor was mentioned in 1625 as property of the Treyden castle.

Name: Ippinghausen
Alternative_Name: Ypponhuson; Ippinghusen; Eppenghusen; Yppekusen; Eppenkusen; Ippinghausen; Ipinghausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1120. Deserted in the 15th and early 16th centuries. However, settled again in the first half of the 16th century.

Name: Iprump
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in the 14th century as a dispersed settlement.

Name: Ipse
Alternative_Name: Ipisze; Ips; jptz; ypcz; Yptz; Iptze; Ipze
Settlement_Description: First written record in 1238.

Name: Jirnsum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1399-1401.

Name: Irxleben
Settlement_Description: First secure mentions in the 14th century; before there were older mentions but Irxleben can't be clearly distinguished from other settlements in the surroundings.

Name: Isenbüttel
Alternative_Name: Ysenebutle; Ysinibutle; Isenebutle; Ysennebutle; Eysenebutle; Isenbutle; Isenbuttel; Ysenbutle; Ysenebuthle; Yselnbutle; Ysenbuttele; Ysembotle; Ysenbotel; Isenebuttele; Isenbuttele; Ysenbuttel; Issenbuttel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned before 1196/97.

Name: Tönnishäuschen
Alternative_Name: Isendorf; Isingtharpa; Ysengtorpe; Isincdorpe; Ysinchtorpe; Ysendorp; Isincktorp; sunte Anthonii; Thonyes huseken; Tonieshuseken; sunte Anthonies Klusen; Tonieshauß; S. Antonii capellen; Tonnieshauß; Tonigeshausken; Tonnießheußker; St. Anthonii Capellen; Tonniesheusken; Thönieshauses; Tonnishause; Tunshäuschen
Settlement_Description: The dispersed settlement ('bauernschaft') Isendorf is first mentioned in the 11th century. After a chapel of St Anthony was built on a crossroads in the settlement (first mentioned in 1499), this part of Isendorf became known as Tönnishäuschen.

Name: IJzeren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1330.

Name: Iserlohn
Alternative_Name: Loon; Iserlo; Yslo; Isrlon; Iserenlon; Yserenlohn; Yserenloyn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as a mint between 1030 and 1050.
Town_Description: In 1278, town privileges were confirmed after Dortmund law. However, the first awarding of town privileges can no longer be verified. Called 'oppidum' around 1232.

Name: Itterbeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1259.

Name: Itzehoe
Alternative_Name: Ekeho; Etzeho; Ezeho; Ezieho; Itzeho; Eziho; Itceho; Etseho; Etceho; Etkeho; Echeho
Settlement_Description: A fortification was built at a bend in the Stör river by the Saxon duke Magnus Billung around 1000. A merchant settlement developed on the opposite shore, the St Lawrence chuch was probably dedicated in the 11th century.
Town_Description: Adolf IV of Schauenburg granted Lübeck town privileges in 1238 and built a planned new merchants' town (Neustadt) on a peninsula, which was joined with the old town in 1303.
Toll_Description: A transit toll is first mentioned in 1492. In the 16th and 17th century, Lübeck claimed the right to be exempted from the toll for the import of cloth from Emden through Itzehoe.
Staple_Description:
In 1260, counts Johann and Gerhard of Holstein obliged all skippers sailing on the Stör to offer their commodities for sale on the market in Itzehoe. The staple was enforced by a barrier in the Stör ("Störbaum"), first attested in 1572, which prohibited sailing past town.
Citizens of Krempe were exempted from staple obligations for salt, corn and timber in 1271, but the enforcement of the staple often led to conflicts between both towns in the following centuries. The staple privileges were confirmed against Krempe interests in 1496, but Krempe was exempted from the staple for beer and timber transports in 1540. Further exemptions were introduced in 1575 for the noble Rantzau family, in 1607 and 1609 for timber and cheese transported from and to Wilster, and in 1627 for timber from Glückstadt. In 1638, a prohibition for foreigners to trade with each other was introduced.
Fair_Description: It is not known how old the fairs in Itzehoe are. A "new market" on Monday after Epiphany was first mentioned in 1400. Other presumably older late medieval fairs were the fair on "Bürgertag" (citizen's day) on 7 or 8 September, to which a horse fair was connected, and the oxen fair on St Gallus. The latter was one of the most important markets for oxen driven from Jutland, which was held on the premises of the monastery. The oxen fair on St Gallus and the horse fair on Bürgertag were extended to 8 days in 1655. In 1489, five fairs were added: 3 weeks before Carnival, 8 days before Carnival, Sunday before Reminiscere, Thursday before Palm Sunday, and 8 days before St James, the latter being also the day the regional court took place in Itzehoe. A second horse fair in the early modern period took place 3 days before Sunday Letare.

Name: Itzstedt
Alternative_Name: Iddesten; Yddeste; Iddest; Ydestede; Iddestede; Itzstede

Name: Itzum
Alternative_Name: Ysnum; Iuzem; Hisnem; Isnem; Yssenem; Itzheim
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 12th century. A watchtower of the Hildesheim enclosure ('landwehr') was built in Itzum in 1442.

Name: Ivangorod
Settlement_Description: In 1492, Ivan III built a castle called Ivangorod on the right bank of the river. Since then, it was distinguished between the Russian and Estonian part of the town.

Name: Ivendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1243.

Name: Jackerath
Toll_Description: In 1389, the Duke of Jülich levied a land toll and a fee for save conduct. At first there was only a fee for save conduct mentioned, later only land toll. Depending on the load, 2 to 3 white pfennigs ('Weißpfennig'/Albus) per horse had to be paid as escort fee in 1389/93. Further tariffs are not known. The annual yield in 1389/93 averaged 139 mark, in 1398/99 113½ mark.

Name: Jakobidrebber
Alternative_Name: Jacobidrebber; Drebber; Thriburi; Driburi; Triburi; Drebbere; Drebber orientalis; Ostdrebber; Osterdrebber
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 980 as "Thriburi", which refers to three farms. In 1281, separate parts of the settlement east and west of the Hunte river are mentioned. From the 16th century, the eastern part is known after the patron saint of the local church, St James.

Name: Jagel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned at the end of the 12th century.

Name: Jēkabpils
Settlement_Description: The settlement originated in the 17th century and only received town rights by Magdeburg in 1670. The place already had a pier which was a transhipment point from water to land in the 16th century.

Name: Jameln
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1360. In 1450, the village consisted of 4 farms, a cottage and a farm with a mill.

Name: Jarchau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1238.

Name: Jastorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252.

Name: Jastrowie
Settlement_Description: Originally a slavic settlement, but mentioned as a royal village in 1363
Town_Description: The town privileges and the Magdeburg town law were grantes in 1602 by Peter Potulicki and endorsed in 1603 by King Sigismund III of Poland.

Name: Jeddingen
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in a register of the diocese of Verden between 1237 and 1246.

Name: Jeetze
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1238.

Name: Jõelähtme
Settlement_Description: A village that was first mentioned in 1241. In 1482, there was an estate.

Name: Jeggau
Settlement_Description: Probably came into the property of the hospital in Gardelegen around 1300. Mention in a name in 1429. A secure mention occurs in 1472.

Name: Jemgum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century. Before 1240 a monastery of the Knights Hospitaller was founded here, which was expanded several times in the following centuries and acquired modest property. The monastery was closed around 1528.

Name: Jena
Alternative_Name: Jani; Gene; Jene; Jenis; Jhene; Yhne
Settlement_Description: The settlement benefitted from an advantageous position at a Saale river crossing.
Town_Description: Granted town rights probably around 1230 by the lords of Loddeburg. Proven cives since 1236, granted Gotha town rights around 1332.
Toll_Description:
Toll, to be paid by wagons and carts, for the maintenance of the roads around Jena.
Further, there was a water-toll, from which we only know the fees.

Name: Jäneda
Settlement_Description: The manor and village were mentioned in 1353. The Bishop of Reval gained land from the Teutonic Order on which he built up the settlement.

Name: Jerichow
Settlement_Description: First mention as market and church village in 1144. Before that a castle and a nearby suburbium existed at the bank of the Elbe river.
Town_Description: Town rights after Magdeburg rights were probably granted between 1259 and 1336 by the lords of Jerichow. In the late Middle Ages the town lost its privileges and was demoted to borough ('Flecken').
Toll_Description: First mention of the toll of Jerichow in a liberation reord for the citizens of Magdeburg. In 1432 the villages of Wolmirstedt, Rogätz and Jerichow are mentioned as toll stations in a letter of conflict between the council of Magdeburg and the archbishop. Further mentions occur in 1460, 1480-1490 and 1492. Toll regulations remain from the 16th century.
Fair_Description: In 1650 two fairs are known.

Name: Jerstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 941.

Name: Jesewitz
Settlement_Description: First mention as Gesewitz in 1404.

Name: Jessen
Settlement_Description: Development as suburbium in the shadow of a castle at the Elster. In 1290 the castle is first mentioned, which means that hte 12th century can be seen as the time in which the settlement developed.
Town_Description: Citizens are mentioned before 1378. In 1350 referred to as civitas.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wettin in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig. The regulations heavily refer to long-distance trade goods, which gives Jessen the character of a main station of safe conduct.

Name: Jevenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the Visio Godeschalci of ca. 1190.

Name: Jõhvi
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241. A parish was probably established around 1250. Since 1491 there was a manor for a bailiff of the Teutonic Order from Narva.

Name: Joala
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1497. A manor was built at the end of the 17th century.

Name: Jõgisoo
Settlement_Description: Manor and village, which was first mentioned in 1241.

Name: Pisz
Settlement_Description: A house belonging to the Teutonic Order was built in 1342, destroyed in 1351, rebuilt and again destroyed in 1455, a fishing settlement grew close to the castle
Town_Description: A handfast exists from 1367, the first attempt at a town founding with Kulm town law by the Grand Master Ludwig von Erlichshausen in 1451 was unsuccessful, most likely because of the 13 year war in the 15th ct., the people have been called citizens in 1553 and the place was mentioned as a hamlet in 1566, new inquieries after town law were loud in 1595, but elector Friedrich Wilhelm only granted Kulm town law in 1645

Name: Joure
Alternative_Name: De Jouwer; Jeure; Heuwera; Jouwera; Opper Gyoure; Louwre
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the thirteenth century.

Name: Jübar
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1308.

Name: Jüchen
Toll_Description: The Duke of Jülich levied a road toll here in 1434/35. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Judenbach
Settlement_Description: First mention 1279.
Toll_Description: Toll station from the safe conduct by Eisfeld.

Name: Jülich
Toll_Description: In 1249, the Count of Jülich levied a land toll and a fee for safe conduct. In the same year, Flemings had to pay 12 denarii per barrel of wine. Around 1300, 12 to 15 denarii per barrel had to be paid. For more exact tariffs, see source. In 1389/93, about 557 mark a year were collected as escort fee. In 1398/99, 924¼ mark were collected as land toll.

Name: Jüterbog
Settlement_Description: A slavic settlement and castle mound existed that are mentioned in 1007, before they were conquered by archbishop Wichmann of Madgeburg in 1157, it then had a German castle with a chapel and a village, a burgward was mentioned in 1161 alongside the building of a church of our lady, which became the main church in 1173, a flemish settlement was mentioned later.
Town_Description: In 1174 a german civitas was founded with Madgeburg town law, it was destroyed in 1179 by Heinrich the lion and later rebuilt with a new market place
Toll_Description: archiepiscopal-magdeburgian toll station and safe conduct
Fair_Description: Since 1376 two big fairs are known, others were added in 1497 and 1623.

Name: Kabelitz
Settlement_Description: Probably a former Slavic settlement. Mention in the context of a "castrum Marienborch" in 946, around which a settlement "urbs Marienburg developed" (mentioned in 1145), which can probably be equated with Kabelitz, as records from 1150 and 1157 suggest. The castle district ('Burgward') seems to have consisted of several settlements in the 10th century, which mostly seem to have dissolved in the course of the 12th century. Only in the 15th century the scattered settlements seem to have bounded together in villages, one of which was Kabelitz. The settlement became property of Jerichow monastery.

Name: Kabli
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1638.

Name: Kahala
Settlement_Description: In 1560 the village was burned down by the Russians.

Name: Kahala
Settlement_Description: The village, which was first mentioned in 1241, belonged to the 'Kolk' manor.

Name: Kahla
Settlement_Description: Since the 10th/11th century Kahla was a manor with a castle that was called Leuchtenburg.
Town_Description: The expansion to town was supported by the lords of Loddeburg-Leuchtenburg since the end of the 13th century. Since 1288/99 referred to as Cives.
Bridge_Description: In 1369 the town of Kahla gains the right to pawn off rafts that damage the bridge over the Saale or the weir.

Name: Kählstorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1292.

Name: Kantküla
Settlement_Description: This village was first mentioned in 1419.

Name: Ķeipene
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1457.

Name: Kaisershagen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1301.

Name: Kaiserswerth
Toll_Description: 1) The empire levied a river toll on the Rhine here in 1174, which was often pawned. Other owners included the Archbishop of Cologne, the Count of Jülich and the Count of Berg. In 1348, 6 Turnosgroschen had to be paid for each foder of wine from ships coming from Duisburg. In 1368 it was 16 Turnosgroschen per foder of wine. For further tariffs see source. In 1400/01, approx. 5784 guilders were collected per year, in 1406/07 8460 Rhenish guilders and in 1408/09 approx. 14300 Rhenish guilders. 2) In addition, in the period from 1425 to 1431, Gerhard von Kleve levied a fee for safe river conduct. Rates and revenues are unknown. It is also questionable whether it was more of a punitive levy or whether it was collected continuously. 3) A land toll was also levied in 1424. The ownership is similar to the Rhine toll mentioned above. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Kalbe
Settlement_Description: In 983 a Benedictine convent was destroyed by Slavic rioters. In 1196 a castle is mentioned as the seat of a burgward, of which half is given to the archbishopric of Magdeburg.
Town_Description: Around 1200 town foundation, possibly planned. First referred to as town in 1324. A council is only mentioned in 1497. In the 16th and 17th century merely referred to as borough ('Flecken').
Toll_Description: The town lords of Kalbe are granted a dam toll under the condition that they use it in order to maintain the roads and grant safe conduct to travelers.
Fair_Description: In an official schedule from 1719, Kalbe held two fairs. It can be assumed that one or both of these had existed for a while to this point.

Name: Kälberfeld
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1318.

Name: Calden
Alternative_Name: Kalden; Chaldun; Chalden; Kalden; Calde; Caldin; Colden; Kaulden;
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1120.

Name: Kalisz
Staple_Description: Staple rights with precise street ordinances; Wares from Prussia to Breslau must be carried through Kalisch; Wares to other Silesian centres could also be transported via Posen.

Name: Kallenhardt
Alternative_Name: Hosteruelden; Hosterfelde; Osteruelde; Ostervelde; Callenhort; Calhard; Kalnhart; Kalenhard; Candenhart; Kallenhordt; Kaylhart; Kalhart; Calehart; Kallenhard
Settlement_Description: The place originally bore the name 'Ostervelde', which was mentioned in 1072. A settlement was founded there, which was called 'opido' around 1297 and was systematically expanded into the town of Kallenhardt.
Town_Description: Kallenhardt received Rüthen town privileges in 1543.

Name: Kalēti
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1509.

Name: Kalisz Pomorski
Alternative_Name: Kallies; Calis; Noua Calys; Nigen Kalys; Kaliz; Caliss; Calys
Settlement_Description: Excavation results suggest prehistoric settlement. A castle complex from the mid 13th ct. was the see of the starost Kenstel in the 1280s.A settlement grew close to the castle complex.
Town_Description: A document granting Brandenburg town law was given in 1303. The town was conquered by the Margraves of Brandenburg going into the 14th ct.
Staple_Description: Compulsory exchange for pitch and ash in 1303

Name: Kalitsa
Settlement_Description: The village, which was mentioned in 1558, belonged to the 'Erwita' manor.

Name: Kallmerode
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1206.

Name: Kalli
Settlement_Description: In 1560 the area was granted as fief. An estate was built between 1624 and 1638.

Name: Kalnciems
Settlement_Description: In 1567 a church was mentioned.

Name: Kaltenkirchen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1301.

Name: Zymna Voda
Alternative_Name: Kaltwasser; Zimna Woda; Symna Woda; Зимна Вода

Name: Kamen
Alternative_Name: Camine; Kamena; Camene; Kamene; Kamine; Chamene
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 11th century. Around 1243 a sovereign castle existed near the settlement.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted to the settlement between 1243 and 1248, which were expanded in 1346.

Name: Kammerbusch
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as fortified outwork ('vorwerk') of the castle of knight Heinrich von Borch, which was destroyed in 1311. First mention in a charter in the Bremervörde register of ca. 1500. At the time, it consisted of one farm.

Name: Kamień Pomorski
Alternative_Name: Kammin; Cammin; Chamin; Camina; Caminum; Kamyn; Camin
Settlement_Description: A castle was built around 800, the surrounding settlement was mainly craftsman-oriented. An outer ward with a castle mound was built in the 10th or 11th ct., it was mentioned in 1107 during a fight of the polish ruler Boleslaw against Pomerania. It was the see of the first pomeranian duke Wartislaw since 1124 and has been the residence of the later dukes until the 13th ct. After the original settlement around the castle was destroyed in 1273 by the Brandenburgs a new german settlement was built.
Town_Description: Duke Barnim I. granted Lübeck town law in 1274.

Name: Kampe
Settlement_Description: In 1473, three families are reported in the hamlet ('bauerschaft').

Name: Kampen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 9 July 1227. Archaeological finds indicate habitation from the twelfth century onward.
Town_Description: It is not known for sure whether Kampen has been granted town privileges. Possibly, those privileges may have developed from customary law, and afterwards been acknowledged and confirmed by the landlord. It is, however, likely that town privileges have been granted by Wilbrand of Oldenburg, bishop of Utrecht, between 1230 and 1233.

Name: Kampen (Holstein)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1598.

Name: Kanaküla
Settlement_Description: A village, that belonged to the Tignitz Manor.

Name: Kandava
Settlement_Description: In 1245 the old castle was conquered by the Teutonic Order. A new castle was built around 1300, where a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') developed. In the 17th century the settlement was referred to as borough ('Flecken').

Name: Kapelle-op-den-Bos
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1292.

Name: Stolzenfels
Toll_Description: A river toll on the Rhine was levied here in various periods. The toll was first documented in 1331 and was initially levied until 1349, later from 1362 to 1412. The original owner was the Archbishop of Mainz. Later, the toll went into the possession of the Archbishop of Trier. In 1345, 15 turnosgroschen were collected per foder of wine, from 1345 to 1349 7 turnosgroschen per foder, and in 1368 27 turnosgroschen per foder of wine. From 1333 to 1334, approximately 11463 pounds Heller were collected. In 1331/34 this toll was established as a secondary toll of the Kurmainzer Oberlahnsteiner toll on the Rhine. Later, the Koblenz river toll was also collected at this location. In 1412, the toll was moved to Engers.

Name: Kapellen
Toll_Description: The Duke of Guelders levied a land tariff in 1397. Exact tariffs are not known. In 1397, however, 12 guilders of lease were collected.

Name: Kapern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1360.

Name: Karksi
Settlement_Description: A castle was built in the 13th century, but was burnt down in 1297. It was the domicile of a bailiff in medieval times. A Manor was built nearby, which was owned by the Teutonic Order until 1561.

Name: Karuse
Settlement_Description: Medieval parish, first mentioned in 1240. It belonged to the Teutonic Order ('Deutscher Orden') from 1242 to 1561, making it one of the oldest parishes in Estonia.

Name: Karze
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1468.

Name: Kaseküla
Settlement_Description: There was a small village that was mentioned in 1601. Nowadays it is part of the village Selja.

Name: Kassel
Alternative_Name: Cassel; Chassella; Chassalla; Cassella; Cassele; Cassela; Cassle; Casla; Kasle
Settlement_Description: Developed from a Frankish fortification of the 10th century.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted around 1180, Kassel is first characterised as "civitas" in 1189. Town privileges were confirmed in 1239. The new town on the opposite shore of the Fulda appears in 1283, the "Freiheit" around 1330; the three parts were united in 1378.
Toll_Description: Toll on commodities, introduced by Landgrave Moritz after the Fulda river had been made navigable between Kassel and Hersfeld. In an ordinance from 1613, the toll duties were set at the rate established in 1604. At each lock in the Fulda, it was checked whether the toll had been paid.
Staple_Description: A staple in Kassel with a forced stay of three days was introduced in 1336, in a conflict about the older staple of Münden.
Fair_Description: Since 1336, three fairs are known to have taken place on the Altmarkt in Kassel: on Sunday Invocavit, St James and St Martin.

Name: Kaster
Toll_Description: The Duke of Jülich collected a road toll here from 1398/99.

Name: Kastorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1286.

Name: Kästorf
Alternative_Name: Ketesdorp; Kettesdorb; Kettesdorp; Kestorp; Kestorpe; Ketestorpe; Kesdorpe; Keystorpe; Kestorppe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1152.

Name: Katase
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1419.

Name: Katlenburg
Alternative_Name: Cadalenburg; Kathalanburg; Catelenburg; Katelenburc; Katelenburch; Catlenburg; Duhm; Katlenburg-Duhm; Dome to Kathelenborch; Dhome; Duehn; Thumb; Dohmb; Dom
Settlement_Description: The castle Katlenburg was built in the 11th century on the rivers Rhume and Katel; it was turned into an Augustinian monastery by Dietrich III of Katlenburg in 1105. The monastery was secularised after 1534. The village belonging to the monastery was originally called Duhm.
Toll_Description: A road fee is first mentioned in 1604.

Name: Katzien
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1296.

Name: Kaugurciems
Settlement_Description: The fishing village was first mentioned in 1634.

Name: Kaulille
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1345.

Name: Kaulsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1347.

Name: Kehtna
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1417. During the 15th century the village had several estates.

Name: Ķekava
Settlement_Description: Estate near the mouth of the Ķekava river. A church named after the castle Dahlen (Dole) on the river island of the same name was also built here at an unknown date, which was mentioned as being deteriorated in 1630.

Name: Keila
Settlement_Description: Originally a small village, which was sold to the 'Teutonic Order' ('Deutscher Orden') in 1433. Listed as a village until 1549. In the 15th/16th century a small settlement or a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built close to the church, which was granted city rights in 1938.

Name: Kelbra
Settlement_Description: First mention of the church in Kelbra in 1093. In the 10th century a castle was built.
Town_Description: First referral as an "oppidum" in 1351, first mention of councilmen in 1352.
Fair_Description: Kelbra besaß "seit alters" her zwei Jahrmärkte.

Name: Kellinghusen
Alternative_Name: Kerleggehuse; Kelenghusen; Schelinghusen; Tzellingchusen; Kellinghaußen; Kellinghausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1148.

Name: Kelpen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1329.

Name: Kemberg
Settlement_Description: Positioned in a former slavic settled area, Kemberg was possibly founded by Flemish colonists between 1150 and 1200. In 1332 a provost is mentioned.
Town_Description: In a record by duke Rudolf of Sachsen referred to as "our town". In 1488 the town rights were confirmed.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleit') of Wittenberg. Regulations of safe conduct remain from 1550.

Name: Kemme
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1025.

Name: Kempten
Toll_Description: The Archbishop of Mainz levied a land toll and a fee for safe conduct here from 1441. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Kerkau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1225.

Name: Zuidwolde
Alternative_Name: Zuidwolde; Suthwalda; Sudwold; Zuutwolde; Suedwolde; Zuetwoelde; Suytwolde; Suitwolde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1275.

Name: Kerkuhn
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1323.

Name: Kerpen
Toll_Description: In 1475, the lord of Kerpen levied a land toll. Per hundredweight ('Zentner') of iron 4 alb. (Albus) had to be paid. Yields are not known.

Name: Kerspleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1104.

Name: Kärbla
Settlement_Description: In 1511 there was an estate called 'Kerffel'.

Name: Kessel (Maas)
Alternative_Name: Kessel; loco Cassallo; Cassele; Caesle; Kessile; Kesselo; Keselle; Kesselle
Settlement_Description: Kessel originated in the Roman period and is first mentioned in 950; this document, however, is a forgery. The subsequent mention dates from 1107.
Town_Description: Kessel was granted town privileges some time between 1279 and 1291 by Reginald I, count of Gueldres. Kessel, however, hardly developed into a town.
Toll_Description: 1) Two tolls were levied on the river Meuse in Kessel. On the one hand, a river toll was established by the Count of Guelders in 1279, which he lent to the Lord of Kessel from 1350. On the other hand, the Duke of Brabant established a toll station in 1357, which he granted as a fief: in 1357 to Dietrich von Hornes, Lord of Perwez, in 1414 to Konrad, Lord of Schleiden and in 1480 to Count Kuno von Manderscheid. Only special tariffs are known. In 1396, for example, the people of Venlo had to pay 3 old groschen per piece of wine. The annual revenue of the Geldern toll in 1294/95 was 25 Cologne mark. 2) The Duke of Guelders also levied a fee for safe conduct on land in Kessel. The town probably served as a collection point for the Venlo fee and is therefore mentioned in 1355/61 as a secondary location. Tariffs are not known.

Name: Kestla
Settlement_Description: The village belonged to the manor of 'Alt-Isenhof'.

Name: Kettelstorf
Settlement_Description: Possibly first mentioned between 1133 and 1137. There is an earlier mention around 1006 that is uncertain.

Name: Kettwig
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in 1471. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Kiiu
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241. At the end of the 14th century, a castle was built that lasted until the 20th century.

Name: Kiel
Alternative_Name: Civitas Holsatorum; Civitati Holsatiae; Holstenstadt tom Kyle; Kyl; tom Kyle; Kilo; Kil; Kylo; Kiehl
Settlement_Description: Before the foundation of the town, there already existed a merchant settlement at this place.
Town_Description: Count Adolf IV of Holstein founded "Holstenstadt tom Kyle" as a planned town between 1238 and 1242. Johann I of Holstein granted Lübeck town privileges in 1242. Kiel was pawned to Lübeck between 1469 and 1496.
Fair_Description: The most important fair in Kiel was the one-week so-called 'Kieler Umschlag', which must date to 1431 at the latest, but was first mentioned in 1469. It became the most important international capital market for the nobility of northern Germany and Denmark in the 16th and 17th century. There are many different dates known for the fair, among others on St Martin, St Michael, the Presentation of Jesus, Easter, Ascension Day, Pentecost or Christmas. From the 16th century onwards, it usually took place in the week after Epiphany. In some years, it was also held in other towns such as Rendsburg and Oldesloe. The Umschlag was discontinued in 1911, but revived as a funfair in 1975. Next to the Umschlag, there existed three other one-week fairs in the early modern period, after Sunday Invocavit, Monday after St Peter and Paul, and on Monday after St Francis.

Name: Ķimale
Settlement_Description: The area 'Kiemala' was first mentioned in 1230. In 1253, the settlement came into the possession of the Teutonic Order.

Name: Kindelbrück
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Breviarium sancti Lulli in the 8th/9th century.
Town_Description: Albrecht from the house of Wettin bestowes civil rights upon the inhabitants of Kindelbrück.
Fair_Description: In the oldest bylaws of the town (shortly after 1400) mention fairs, their date and exact number are unknown however.
Bridge_Description: The toponym Kindelbruccun in the Breviarium sancti Lulli alludes to a bridge across the Wipper at the end of the 8th century for the road from Erfurt to the salines of Bad Frankenhausen and consequently to Magdeburg.

Name: Kinderhaus
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1333. There was possibly a leprosy house there.

Name: Kirberg
Toll_Description: The Count of Diez probably levied a land toll and later a fee for safe conduct on land before 1349. In 1349, the toll was confirmed. Tariffs from that time are not known. From 1355, Count Johann von Nassau and Daniel von Langenau levied so-called imperial surcharges ('Reichszuschläge'). This meant that 1 guilder had to be paid in addition per load. Von Langenau demanded 1 turnosgroschen extra per horse as fee for safe conduct on land.

Name: Kirch-Steinbek
Alternative_Name: Stenbeke; Steinbeeke; Sthenbeke; Kercstenbeke; Kerchstenbeke; Kerckstenbek; Stembeke; Steinbecke; Steinebeke; Steenbeck; Kirchdorf Steinbeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as 'Stenbeke' in 1212. 1239 the place was mentioned as 'Kirchsteinbek'.

Name: Kirchwelver
Alternative_Name: Welver; Weluere; Welverensis; Welvere; Welvereburg; Welveren; Welfer; Wälber

Name: Kirchboitzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1203.

Name: Kirchdorf
Alternative_Name: Kirchdorf bei Sulingen; Karcktorpe; Kerckdorpe; Karcktorpp; Kerkdorf
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 1380. According to local legend, the church goes back to a foundation of a countess of Hoya, by way of thanks for helping her free her travel wagon when it was stuck in the snow. If this is true, the countess in question could have been the wife of count Heinrich II, in which case the foundation must have taken place shortly after the middle of the 13th century.

Name: Kirchedlau
Settlement_Description: Former property of the counts of Alsleben, who sold the village to the lords of Ammendorf.

Name: Kirchgellersen
Alternative_Name: Gheldessen; Gellersen; Gelderdissen; Gelderdessen; Kerkgeldersen; Kergcheldersen; Kergeldersen
Settlement_Description: The settlement Gellersen, which consisted of three parts, was first mentioned before 1117; the village of Kirchgellersen separately after 1236. According to 17th-century registers, the village consisted of 2 farms ('plog'), 2 or 3 half farms and 4 cottages.

Name: Kirchhain
Alternative_Name: Kirchan; Werplohen; Werflohe; Werflo; Chirkhain quondam Werflo; Kyrichhagen; Kirchhagen; Kyrcheyn; Kirchheyn; Kirghan; Kirchen; Kircheyn; Kirchhayn; Kyrchayna
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1149. Called 'villa' in 1244.
Town_Description: Landgrave Heinrich II granted town charter between 1344 and 1352. First referred to in 1352 as town and 'oppidum'.

Name: Kirchhasel (Saale)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 775.
Toll_Description: In the 1530ies, merchants coming from Saalfeld are taken into schwarzburgish safe conduct at the border to Schwarza an accompanied through Rudolstadt up to the border stone at Kirchhasel/Etzelbach.

Name: Kirchhatten
Settlement_Description: Originally mentioned as "Hahtho" (Hatten) in 860, since 1260/80 called Kirchhatten.

Name: Kirchheilingen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 833.

Name: Kirchheim
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1074.

Name: Salaspils
Settlement_Description: In 1380 the Teutonic Order built a castle on the right-hand bank of the Düna. In 1577 it was destroyed by the Russians.

Name: Kirchhorst
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1368.

Name: Kirchwerder
Alternative_Name: Kercenwerder; Kercwerdir; Kercwerder; Kercwerdhere; Kyrchwerder; Kerchwerder; Kerckwerder; Karckwerder; Kerkwerdere; Karckwarder
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1217.

Name: Kirchweyhe
Alternative_Name: Wemethe; Westerwemede; Weinethe; Wynethe; Weynde; Weye; Kerkweynede; Kerkweiden; Kerckweyn; Kirchweihe
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned as 'Weinethe' in 1253.

Name: Kirchworbis
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1209.

Name: Kirumpää
Settlement_Description: In 1322 the castle was called 'castrum' and served to protect against raids from the east. In 1369 it was taken by the Russians. The nearby village was burned down. The castle was destroyed in the mid-17th century.

Name: Kissenbrück
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of possessions of the monastery of Corvey (822-836). Location of a Frankish royal court until its dissolution in the 13th century. Regularly characterised as borough ('weichbild') from 1331, although the corresponding privileges were probably older.

Name: Kittlitz
Alternative_Name: Kitlist; Kijtliste; Kettelstorpe; Kyttelste; Kittlist; Kitlisse
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230.

Name: Kitzingen
Staple_Description: In 1498 raftsmen sailing down the Main obliged to offer their wares for three days in the town.

Name: Berkeler Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Hameln (first mentioned in 1385) near the village Klein Berkel.

Name: Klein Berßen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 919.

Name: Klein Dannewerk
Alternative_Name: Klein Danewerk; Klein-Dannewerk; Danwirky; Danæwyrki; Luttekendennewerke
Settlement_Description: The settlement is named after the Danish defensive wall Danewerk, which was built between the late 7th and the late 12th century. The settlement is first mentioned in 1231, and divided into two villages Klein and Groß Dannewerk, which are first mentioned separately in 1412.

Name: Klein Engersen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1238, further mentions in the 15th and 16th century together with Groß Engersen.

Name: Klein Fullen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000 in plural, which indicates that already at that time, Fullen encompassed two distinct settlements, which developed into Groß and Klein Fullen.

Name: Klein Gladebrügge
Alternative_Name: Gladebrugge minori; Lutken Gladebrugge; Lutke Gladebrugge; Lutke Gladdenbrugge; Kleingladebruge

Name: Klein Grönau
Alternative_Name: hospitalibus Gronowe; hospitale Gronow; sunte Jurghenn vor Grounow; seken to Gronouwe; Klein-Grönau
Settlement_Description: In the 1280s, Lübeck citizens founded a hospital of St George near Grönau (the current Groß Grönau). A chapel was built in 1409. The currently still existing hospital buildings were built in 1479/1480. In modern times, the settlement at the hospital became known as Klein Grönau.

Name: Klein Hesepe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000, where a distinction between Groß and Klein Hesepe is not yet made.

Name: Mazjumpravas muiža
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1257.

Name: Klein Kummerfeld
Alternative_Name: Kummervelde; Kleinkummerfeld; Lutkenkummerfelder; Luttkummerfeldt; Lütken Kummerfeldt

Name: Klein Lafferde
Alternative_Name: Parvo Lafferde; Minori Lafforde; Osterlafforde; Lutteken Lafforde; Lutken Lafferde; Wenigen Lafferde; Kleinen Lafferd; Lutgen Lafferde; Kleinen Laffert; Kleinlafferde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1277.

Name: Klein Nenndorf
Alternative_Name: Bad Nenndorf; Niendorf; Nenthorp; Luttekendorpe; Luttiken Nendorpe; Lutteken Neyndorpe; Lutteken Neyndorppe; Lutken Nendorp; Lutken Neyndorpp
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned as a property of the monastery of Fulda in the 10th century. It consisted of two parts: Groß and Klein Nenndorf, of which the latter was first separately mentioned in 1401. Both settlements were united into Bad Nenndorf in modern times.

Name: Klein Oschersleben
Settlement_Description: Mention in a gift certificate to the bishopric of Halberstadt in 1086.

Name: Klein Rhüden
Alternative_Name: Rhüden; Ruden; Minori Ruden; Lutken Ruden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1189.

Name: Väike-Maarja
Settlement_Description: The exact foundation of the parish is unfortunately not known. This may have happened in the 13th century. The village near the church was first mentioned in 1499. At the end of the 19th century, the place grew as a borough ('Flecken').

Name: Klein Schöppenstedt
Alternative_Name: Mönche-Schöppenstedt; Parvo Schepenstide; Moneke Schepenstede; Münchescheppenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1225.

Name: Klein Sehlingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1370.

Name: Stöckheim (Braunschweig)
Alternative_Name: Stöckheim; Klein Stöckheim; Stokkem; Stokhem; Stochem; Stockheim; Capelstockem; Kapenstockem; Kapelstochem; Dreckstocken; Lütken Stöckem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1007.

Name: Klein Thurow
Settlement_Description: The oldest evidence from 1194 only mentions Thurow; a division between Groß and Klein Thurow is first made in 1332.

Name: Klein-Kreutz
Settlement_Description: Mention of Wendish- i.e. Klein Kreutz in 1275 when the Ascanians sell property to Lehnin monastery. In 1324 the settlement is given to the new town in Brandenburg.

Name: Clus
Alternative_Name: Kleine Klus; Preussische Clus; Klus; Clus; Klues up den Helwege vor dem Santfoerde
Settlement_Description: House on the border between the bishopric of Minden and the county of Schaumburg, first mentioned in 1558 as "Klues up den Helwege vor dem Santfoerde".

Name: Kleinenberg
Alternative_Name: Clenenberga; Clenenberic; Cleneberg; Clinenberge; Clenenberch; Klenenberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1220.
Town_Description: It is unknown when Kleinenberg became a town, but it is first mentioned as 'oppidum' in 1249.

Name: Kleinenbremen
Alternative_Name: curiam Lutticke Breme; parvo Bremen; Luttikenbremen; Bremam; Luckenbremen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1055 and 1080.

Name: Kleinkayna
Settlement_Description: Großkayna is first mentioned in 1286. Kleinkayna was devastated in 1966 for coal mining.

Name: Kleinkeula
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1270.

Name: Kleinringe
Settlement_Description: The settlement Ringe is first mentioned in 1329, both parts Groß- and Kleinringe separately in 1456.

Name: Kleinwechsungen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1223.

Name: Klettstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 802.

Name: Kleve
Toll_Description: The Count of Cleves levied a land toll before 1319, which he granted to Borgart van Vonderen as a fief until 1320. Tariffs are not known. In 1320, around 10 Brabant mark were collected.

Name: Klietz
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as property of the bishop of Havelberg in 1145.

Name: Klimmen
Alternative_Name: Clumam; Clumena; Clumna; Cluma; Clummene; Clemne; Climme; Clemmen; Climmen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 968, in a falsification dating from 1138. Next mention in midden of the eleventh century, in a eighteenth century copy.

Name: Klint
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1386.

Name: Kloster Zinna
Settlement_Description:
A cistercian monastery was established 1170-1171, it was finished in 1226 and became sovereign after the secularisation in 1553. In the 18th century, an attempt to revive the settlement is made by building a town, occasionally using material from the monastery.
The corresponding village Zinna was first mentioned in 1258, but probably lent its name to the monastery. It is deserted today.

Name: Klostermansfeld
Settlement_Description: Klostermansfeld is probably older than the village of Mansfeld and property in the surroundings was possibly exchanged as early as 973. The monastery may have already existed in 1042, with which the name Klostermansfeld may have emerged. Albrecht the Bear and count Hoyer IV. brought monks back with them from their pilgrimages to Jerusalem in 1158 and 1173.

Name: Klötze
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed next to a castle, first mentioned in 1311. In 1334 referred to as borough ('Flecken'). Referred to as small town ('Städtchen') in the 14th century.
Toll_Description: Mention of the toll in Klötze, owned by the dukes of Braunschweig-Lüneburg, in 1409.

Name: Klueshof
Settlement_Description: Hermitage

Name: Klus
Settlement_Description: In 1479 the inn is mentioned and is the namesake of the adjoining roadway ('Straßendamm').

Name: Knesselare
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1128, in a sixteenth century copy.

Name: Cobbel
Settlement_Description: Unclear, whether it was already mentioned in the property index of Corvey monastery in 1053, but secure mentions in 1136, 1164, 1180 and 1227.

Name: Koblenz
Alternative_Name: Confluentes; Conbulantia; covelenze; Kovelenze; Cobelenze; Covlentze
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned between the second and fourth centurie. The Franks conquered the place around 500 and a Frankish royal court was established here around 550. In 882, the settlement was destroyed by the Normans.
Town_Description: In 1276, a town council was mentioned.
Toll_Description: 1) Until 1018, the empire levied a river toll on the Rhine here. This was levied from 1000/1018 to 1302, 1309 to 1343 and from 1350 to 1362. A tarif roll from 1140 exists. The Archbishop of Trier held the toll from 1018 to 1042. From 1042 to about 1300, the monastery of St. Simeon in Trier held it. From about 1250 to 1267 and from 1300 onwards, the property went back to the Archbishop of Trier. In 1309 and 1314, 6 Turnosgroschen had to be paid for each foder of wine. From 1317 to 1321, 12 Turnosgroschen had to be paid per foder of wine, in 1345 15 Turnosgroschen and in 1358 already 17 Turnosgroschen. In 1267, 500 to 800 marks could be collected. From 1345 to 1348 the toll was leased for 655 pounds turnosgroschen (equivalent to 13100 guilders) a year. 2) The Archbishop of Trier collected a fee for safe conduct on the Rhine from 1250 to 1267. The annual revenue in 1267 was about 40 mark. 3) Parallel to the Rhine toll, there was a river toll on the Moselle, which was paid together with the river toll on the Rhine until about 1336. The owner and early tariffs are therefore identical. In 1354, 12 Turnosgroschen had to be paid per foder of wine, in 1430 1 Gulden per foder of wine. In 1336/37 and 1338/39 the annual rent was 40 pounds turnosgroschen. In 1344/46 59 pounds Turnosgroschen and in 1358/61 120 pounds Turnosgroschen could be collected. 4) In addition to the two river tolls, a land toll was also levied. Before 1000, 4 denarii per pack animal had to be paid. Annual revenues are not known. 5) The Archbishop of Trier levied bridge fee here from 1359, although the Moselle bridge was not completed until 1363. This suggests that it was already usable in 1359. In the same year, 1 heller per person and 2 heller per large animal had to be paid. In the 15th century, 6 heller per carriage had to be paid.
Staple_Description: Archbishop John II of Trier gave Koblenz staple rights between Boppard and Engers; specified in more detail in 1480. Cattle and grain from the Bonn-Wetzlar-Bingen-Wittich region and fish caught in the Rhein between Platzenborn and Oberlahnstein needed to brought to market in Koblenz.

Name: Koekelberg
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1225.

Name: Koguva
Settlement_Description: The Schmul family was provided with land and was responsible for messenger and ferry services across the 'kleine Sund' from 1532 until the 20th century.

Name: Kohala
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241 and belonged to the the 'Tolks' manor.

Name: Kohlenbissen
Settlement_Description: Kohlenbissen is possible the same settlement as "Marcolvissen", which was mentioned in 1259.

Name: Kohila
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1241. In 1438, there was an estate called Kogell, which was situated on an island in the river.

Name: Koknese
Settlement_Description: From the 11th to the 13th century there was a castle owned by Russian aristocracy that were expelled in 1208. Thereupon, Bishop Albert built a new castle (1209) around which a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') settled.
Town_Description: The fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') near the castle acquired town law by Riga in 1277 and was a member of the Hanseatic League.

Name: Kołobrzeg
Alternative_Name: Kolberg; Cholbergiensis; Colberg; Coluberch; Cholberg; Choleberch; Coluberch
Settlement_Description: During the 6th or 7th ct. two settlements grew close to the salt-works. A castle complex followed later and eventually more settlements in the 8th ct. The castle was extended during the middle of the 9th ct. In the year 1000 Boleslaw Chrobri of Poland alongside emperor Otto III. turned the area into a bishopric under the archbishopric Gnesen.
Town_Description: The german settlement was garnted Lübeck town law in 1255 by the pomeranian duke Wartislaw and the bishop of Kammin. The code of the Lübeck law was sent in 1297 by the council of Lübeck.

Name: Köln
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as the birthplace of Agrippina 50 A.D. Since the middle of the 5th century under Frankish rule.
Town_Description: Already in the Middle Ages, Cologne was a spiritual centre and town of pilgrimage. In 1388 the university was founded. A town council or regiment probably existed already in the 13th/14th century. Niemeyer does not mention the granting of town rights before 1475. Cologne was referred to as a free imperial town in 1475.
Toll_Description: 1) Cologne levied a river toll on the Rhine from 1317 to 1321. This also existed in 1363 and from 1475 to 1494. In the period between 1317 and 1321, 6 Turnosgroschen per foder of wine had to be paid. From 1475 to 1494 the tariff was 2 guilders and 2 turnosgroschen per barrel of wine. In the years 1317 to 1320, 1400 pounds 14 shillings and 5 turnosgroschen could be collected. This corresponds to about 9338 guilders a year. For other annual revenues, see Pfeiffer. 2) In 1103 a gate toll was also levied. Around 1360 1/3 of the revenue went to the town and 2/3 to the Archbishop of Cologne. In the 12th century only special tariffs are known. In 1453, 3 heller had to be paid for a loaded carriage across the Rhine. At the end of the 14th century, 4 heller had to be paid per wine carriage. For other tariffs see Pfeiffer. Annual revenues are not known. 3) Road toll was collected in 1262 parallel to the gate toll. Tariffs are therefore similar.
Staple_Description: Developed probably shortly before 1169, but original plans not always enforced. Confirmed in 1259, 1349 and 1355; revoked in 1356. Staple rights were probably not exercised after 1300. In late 1300s renewed attempts for the imposition of a staple; wood must remain in the town for one day; the Fishmonger ordinances of 1397 forced foreigners to seller their fish to the merchants of Cologne; ordinances of 1407 stipulated that wine, wood, fish, salt and iron should be offered for sale in the city; regulations regarding these matters became stricter throughout the 15th century.
