The Ordinances of the Merchant Store and the Old Market of 1486 contained new regulations for the staples for meat, oils and fats, iron, steel, lead and leather. Attempts at end of the 15th century to enforce staple rights in the trade of cattle, cloth and wool. The unloading of goods while travelling along the lower Rhine banned in 1497, but not mentioned in the imperial staple privileges for 1505. The staple after 1505 appears to decline, but is re-enforced in 1525/6. The bypassing of the staple via Neuss, Bonn and Mülheim encouraged the council in 1603 to forbid the unloading of goods along the Rhine in both directions. From 1616 there were exemptions for stone from Andernach. Staple confirmed once again by the emperor in 1635; after the Thirty Years’ War the staple was gradually transformed into a requirment to transfer wares and was finally dissolved with the Rhine Shipping act of 1831.

Name: Kölsa
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1158.

Name: Kaliningrad
Alternative_Name: Königsberg; Калининград; Conigsberg; Mons Regius; Regiomonti; civitas Regiomontana; nova civitas; Nova Kunigisberg; civitas Leybenicht; Nuwenstadt; Knyphabe; Pregormunde; nova civitas Konigisberk
Settlement_Description: The first castle of the Teutonic Order was built on the remains of an Old Prussian castle, a marketsettlement of craftsmen and farmers grew next to it, their church is documented since 1256, the first settlements were destroyed between 1262 and 1263
Town_Description: After the settlement was rebuilt, the Landmaster of Prussia, Konrad von Thierberg, granted the Kulm town law in 1286
Staple_Description: Imposition of ordinances and rules for the compulsory inspection of ash, tar, pitch and honey and also a reduced staple for wood in the 1390s. An agreement in 1466 made arrangement for a staple for ash, which must have been lost shortly after 1476. Mandate of Grandmaster Albert of Brandenburg ordered merchants from Lithuania, Maosvia, Moscow, Gdansk and Torun to offer their wares for sail when travelling through Königsberg, but was forbidden in the treaty of Krakow in 1525. Trade outside of the town forbidden in 1529, and livestock from Lithuania and Samogitia should be kept at market for three days. A mandate of 1565 ordered merchants of Bartenstein, Rastenburg, Friedland, Wehlau, Tilsit, Memel and Insterburg to bring their wares solely to market in Königsberg; repeated in 1622.

Name: Chojna
Alternative_Name: Königsberg; Königsberg in Neumark; Konigesberge; Koningesberge; Kunigsperg; Kungesberg
Settlement_Description: Most likely a pomeranian castle with a slavic settlement, the village was first mentioned in 1244
Town_Description: First mentioned as civitas in 1270, Magdeburg town law, founded either by the pomeranian dukes, the templars, the bishop of Brandenburg or the Ascanians (they are the most likely)

Name: Königsbrück
Toll_Description: The yearly income from the safe conduct was documented in 1564 (SHStA Dresden, Loc. 8634, Bl. 246–248v.).

Name: Königsdahlum
Settlement_Description: Year of first mention was 826.

Name: Königslutter
Alternative_Name: Königslutter am Elm; Luttere; Regale Luttere; Luthara; Luttera; Lutthera; Koniges Luttere; Koningeslutter; Konnigeslutter; Konigeslutter; Kenigs Lutter
Settlement_Description: Emperor Lothar III converted an early 11th-century monastery of canonesses into a Benedictine monastery in 1135, next to which the settlement Lutter developed. A ducal castle was constructed around 1200. The addition "Königs-" ('royal') to the placename first appears in the 14th century.
Town_Description: A market in Königslutter is mentioned in 1318 and the settlement is characterised as borough ('weichbild') in 1344 and 1359. Between 1400 and 1409, it received Braunschweig town privileges. More extensive privileges were granted in 1474 and 1589.
Fair_Description: In 1621, duke Friedrich Ulrich granted Königslutter a second retail and cattle fair on Sunday before St Gallus, next to the already existing one on St Peter and Paul. It is unknown how old the latter fair was, but it was probably connected to the annual pilgrimage to Königslutter on 29 June, which is first mentioned in 1291. With the pilgrimage becoming more popular in the 15th century, there were frequent complaints about fair-like situations on the monastery premises, which disturbed religious services. Thereupon trading on the grounds of the monastery was forbidden.

Name: Königstein
Alternative_Name: Königstein im Taunus; Kunegestein; Kuningestein; Cunegenstein; Kuninesteyn
Settlement_Description: A castle has been documented since 1225, which is probably a Staufer foundation. The settlement mentioned in 1276 was established here.
Town_Description: In 1313 the previous 'oppidum' received the town charter of Frankfurt.

Name: Lubniewice
Settlement_Description: A german village grew close to a fortress, but not before 1241, first mentioned in 1322
Town_Description: First mentioned as a town in 1367, a constitution didn't exist until 1808

Name: Königswinter
Toll_Description: 1) The Archbishop of Cologne levied a river toll on the Rhine in 1291/92 and 1424/25. Tariffs are unknown in 1291/92. In the 15th century Königswinter was a toll station of the Linz river toll on the Rhine. Tariffs are therefore the same - in 1424/25 6 alb. had to be paid per barrel of wine. 2) The Archbishop of Cologne levied a land toll in 1300. Tariffs are not known. In 1405 the annual yield was about 20 mark.

Name: Konju
Settlement_Description: A village is first mentioned in 1444. It was owned by the Teutonic Order in the 15th century. The manor was built in 1635 under Swedish occupation.

Name: Könnern
Settlement_Description: King Henry II. gives Könnern, former property of the county of Alsleben, to the archbishopric of Magdeburg.
Town_Description: Around 1300 the place develops to a town, an Easter and Christmas market are granted.
Fair_Description: Next to the Bartholomäimarkt there were also Easter and Christmas fairs in Könnern, it is unclear when the privilege was granted though.

Name: Kontich
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in tenth-eleventh century. Next mention in 1088, in a copy dating from 1764.

Name: Kootwijk
Alternative_Name: Coetwijc; Kaetwick; Kaitwijck; Caetwyck; Koitwyck; Koetwyck; Kootwyk; Koetwyk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1333-1334.

Name: Korbach
Alternative_Name: Curbechi; Curbyke; Curbiki; Curbeki; Corbyke; Coerbeyke; Corbecke; Corbach; Cörbach
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 980. The settlement emerged from a Saxon 'Edelhof', which later became a Carolingian street fortress and imperial court.
Town_Description: When the place received the Soest town charter in 1188 by the bishop of Paderborn, it was probably already a town. According to chroniclers of the 16th century, it was founded in 1073.

Name: Korbeek-Lo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1107, in a copy from the middle of the thirteenth century.

Name: Koorküla
Settlement_Description: The village 'Kuerkull' was granted as a fief in 1487. The manor 'Korküll' was built near the village.

Name: Karlino
Alternative_Name: Körlin; Corulin; Cornlin; Corlyn; Corlin; Cörlin
Settlement_Description: A slavic castrum and suburbium are suspected.
Town_Description: Supposedly founded as a town in 1240. Mentioned as civis in 1299 and castrum in 1308. Lübeck town law was granted by the bishop of Kammin, the date is not recorded, but the privileges were endorsed in 1500.

Name: Cornau
Settlement_Description: Originally a moated castle of the lords of Diepholz from the mid-11th century, first mentioned only in 1369. Borough ('flecken') privileges were confirmed in the mid-16th century by duke Christian Ludwig of Brunswick-Lüneburg.

Name: Kortenberg
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1095.

Name: Kortenoord
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1683.

Name: Kose
Settlement_Description: 1241 a village, 1346 a mill and a hamlet were mentioned. In 1525 there was only an Inn left. From 1642 the village belonged to the Meks manor.

Name: Bad Kösen
Alternative_Name: Kösen; Cussenti; Cusana; Cusene; Khosen; Kosin
Settlement_Description: The settlement develops from a Slavic settlement. Since the middle of the 12th century a wooden bridge led across the Saale river.
Fair_Description: Kösen was an important handling station of rafted wood. It was traded on two wood markets every year and supplied Halle, Leipzig and Allstedt, among others.

Name: Koszalin
Alternative_Name: Köslin; Cossalitz; Cussalin; Cosselin; Cößlin; Cöslin
Settlement_Description: Duke Bogislaw II. gifts the settlement to the cistercian abbey Belbuck in 1214. An earlier castle complex is to be presumed based on a mention from 1313.
Town_Description: The bishop Hermann of Gleichen grants Lübeck town law in 1266, it was later mentioned as castrum in 1281.

Name: Köthel
Alternative_Name: Cotle; Kotele; Kotle; Köetel; Kötell; Kötel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230.

Name: Köthen
Settlement_Description: 1115 mention of an "oppidum" Köthen, near which a battle against the Slavs took place. From 1180 - 1212 duke Bernhard of Saxony had coins minted with "kotene civitas", which indicates the existence of a fortified market. One can assume an earlier, slavic settlement. From 1396 a castle can be proven in Köthen.
Town_Description: Since the beginning of the 14th century, Köthen is referred to as "civitas" in the records and a sheriff, councilmen and jurymen are mentioned. Jurisdiction stays with the town lord, however.
Toll_Description: A regulation of safe conduct remains from 1563 (LHASA, DE, Z 10, Nr. 48, Amtsregister und Anschlag des Amtes Köthen.).
Fair_Description: In 1643 Leipzig prevents the establishment of two additional fairs in Köthen.

Name: Kaunas
Staple_Description: Attempts to erect a staple in the 15th century. The Hanseatic Kontor in Kaunas gained its freedom in 1441 and concentrated Lithuanian trade in the city. The mercantile ordinances of c. 1470 stipulated that that merchant wares should remain in Kaunas for three days and fobade trade with guests. In 1492 any remaining markets in Samogitia for foreign merchants were abolished; from 1541, markets allowed if they held the appropriate privilege from the king.

Name: Kraków
Staple_Description: In 1306 the town was made the staple for wares from Hungary, especially metal. After conflicts with the Hungarians, salt transported from Torun to Sandek is excepted. Citizens of Wroclaw exempt from the Krakow staple; in 1354 trade with guests forbidden. Decres of the Polish King of 1372 and 1389 making Krakow the staple market for all merchants coming to Poland (except those from Sandomir and Lublin) lead to several conflicts with Torun. In 1391 both towns removed themselves from the staple, but in 1398 merchants of Krakow forced once again to the offer their wares in the town. The important stapel for the copper trade from Hungary and for Baltic wares was confirmed in the Polish Staple law of 1565.

Name: Cracau
Settlement_Description: Settlement of Slavic origin; from 1158 and 1166 detailed accounts on the settlement of Dutch colonists remain. In 1164 it is conquered by archbishop Wichmann. Destroyed several times during the 30-year-war.

Name: Krakow
Alternative_Name: Krakow am See; Crakow; Crakowe; Crakau; Krackow; Krakow
Settlement_Description: Grew out of a wendish town close to a castle (possibly belonging to the templers), german village existed close to it
Town_Description: Became a town when Nikolaus von Werle (1235-1277) granted Schwerin-Güstrow town law, mentioned as oppidum in 1298, privileges endorsed multiple times from 1366-1375, Güstrow town law endorsed in 1437

Name: Kranenburg (Niederrhein)
Toll_Description: The Count of Cleves levied a land toll in 1381. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Kreepen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1320.

Name: Krefeld
Toll_Description: The Count of Moers and the town of Moers levied a land toll in 1373. In 1373, 1 Turnosgroschen per horse had to be paid.

Name: Kreiensen
Alternative_Name: Creyenhusen; Cregenhusen; Kregensen; Kregenszen; Kreyensen; Kreyenhusen; Kreygenhusen; Kreygenszheim; Kreinßen; Kreinsen; Kraiensen an der Gande
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1342.

Name: Kreipke
Alternative_Name: Criepan; Crepe; Krepe; Crep; Krepeche; Crephe; Krepecke; Kripk; Krepke; Kriepke; Kreipe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 976.

Name: Krelingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1195.

Name: Kremmen
Settlement_Description: Early ascanian fortress close to a wendish and a german settlement, the latter had a church and a market
Town_Description: Town founded around 1232, in 1298 the privileges of the civitas were endorsed by an ascanian margrave, mentioned as oppidum in 1459

Name: Krimulda
Settlement_Description: The castle was built as a branch castle of Treyden Castle in 1231. A manor was built near this castle.

Name: Krempelsdorf
Settlement_Description: Krempelsdorf was of Slavic origin; in the 13th century it is said that there was a Slavic and a German part. The settlement belonged to Lübeck since 1226. At the beginning of the 15th century, there were two farms, which were owned by Lübeck councillors.

Name: Krems
Alternative_Name: Krems I; Kermpetze; Crempize; Krempse; Krempz; Kremps

Name: Krensitz
Settlement_Description: First mention as Crensicz in 1350.

Name: Kluczbork
Settlement_Description: An Old Prussian fortress was built on the casltle hill with a dependant settlement, the Teutonic Order unter Otto von Braunschweig conquered the fortress in 1240, their settlement was then destroyed by the Old Prussians, in 1253 reclaimed the Teutonic Order the castle but had to give it up again in 1263 only to conquer it once more around 1270, afterwards it was the see of the Komtur of Natangen unti 1277, it was given to the bishop of Riesenburg in 1497 who let it decay, until it wasn't defensible anymore in 1507
Town_Description: A privilege from the landmaster Heinrich von Plotzke in 1315 created a town with Kulm town law

Name: Kreuzebra
Settlement_Description: First mention in 817; one of the oldest villages in the Eichsfeld.

Name: Kreyenbrück
Alternative_Name: Kreyenbrügge; Klusbrücke; Brügge bei Kreyens Hause; Kreyenbrücke; Brücke bei Krähen Hause
Settlement_Description: A farm at the bridge across the Hunte might have existed before 1428.
Bridge_Description: Bridge across the Hunte. It was originally called Klusbrücke after the family Klüsener, who lived here in 1538. Around 1630, they were replaced by the family Kreye, after whom the bridge became known as Kreyenbrück.

Name: Krimderode
Settlement_Description: First mention 1240.

Name: Krogaspe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the town register of Kiel from 1264-1289. The settlement is characterised as 'villa' in 1230 and as village ('dorp') in 1393.

Name: Krölpa
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1278.

Name: Kröpelin
Settlement_Description: Settlement existed in wendish time, church village in 1186, a mill existed since 1219, last mentioned as a settlement in 1232
Town_Description: Town law granted around 1240 by Fürst Borwin Heinrich III. von Rostock, mentioned in 1250 as oppidum, in 1280 as civitas, Lübeck town law and privileges endorsed multiple times such as 1347, 1378, 1588

Name: Kröppelshagen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1334.

Name: Krapa
Settlement_Description: The exact date of mentioning is unclear. During the 14th century, the manor belonged to the Kropfen-Family. In 1625, it was abandoned but was resettled in 1681.

Name: Kropstädt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1347 as Liesenitz, a former castle that overlooked the road leading from Treuenbritzen to Berlin. After being destroyed in 1358, it was rebuilt as Kropstädt castle in 1567. A municipality of Kröpstedt only developed after 1560.

Name: Krummesse
Alternative_Name: Cromes; Crumes; Crummess; Crumesse; Crumesce; Crummesse; Krumesse
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1194. Since the second half of the 14th century, parts of the village belonged to Lübeck.

Name: Kniazhyi Mist
Alternative_Name: Княжий Міст; Knjaschyj Mist; Księży Most

Name: Küblingen
Alternative_Name: Cugelinge; Cublinge; Cubbligge; Cublige; Kubbelinge; Cubbelingen; Kublinghe; Kubeling; Kublinge; Kubbeling
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 966.

Name: Kückhoven
Toll_Description: In 1490, a land toll was levied here. Holders, tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Kücknitz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1334.

Name: Kuddewörde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230. A monastery of Augustinian hermits was founded here in 1497, and already abolished in 1524.
Toll_Description: Because travellers circumvented the toll station in Trittau by taking the route via Kuddewörde, a toll was also levied in Kuddewörde, starting before 1558.

Name: Kuhstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1187. From the 15th century, the settlement consisted of 7 farms.

Name: Kuimetsa
Settlement_Description: In 1241 first referral to a village, which was owned by the Cistercian monastery of St. Michaelis in Reval during the 13th century. In 1345 a hamlet ('Hof') was mentioned, which was burned down in 1560.

Name: Kuinre
Alternative_Name: Cunre; Cuynre; Kuijner; Kuner; Kuynder; Kuynre
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1118.
Town_Description: On 22 March 1385, Herman, lord of Cuynre has granted town-like privileges to Cuynre. In 1407, it is mentioned that Kuinre sealed a charter with a town seal ('Stadt Segel van Kuynre').
Fair_Description: A fair was being held from at least 1385 onwards, but it is unknown when this fair took place.

Name: Kuivastu
Settlement_Description: Referred to as a village around 1645. In the Medieval times, however, it was the centre of its own administrative area.

Name: Kulna
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1219.

Name: Cumlosen
Toll_Description: A toll on the Elbe in Cumlosen is first mentioned in negotiations about reducing the tolls on the Elbe from 1476. The toll tariff was 4 Lübeck shilling, 1 loaf of bread and 3 buns for each ship. The toll is still mentioned in four travel accounts of skipper Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna from 1671-1674.

Name: Kunersdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1340; a nearby castle mound can be traced back to Slavic times.

Name: Curau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1220. The church is first mentioned in 1286. The village belonged mainly to the Hospital of the Holy Ghost in Lübeck. An inn is mentioned in 1447.

Name: Ķoniņciems
Settlement_Description: One of the villages of the 'Curonian kings' with special privileges, which it received in 1439.

Name: Kurtna
Settlement_Description: A Manor and village which was first mentioned in 1471.

Name: Kuusna
Settlement_Description: The village near an old quarry was named in 1558.

Name: Küstelberg
Alternative_Name: Kustelbergensis; Kustelberg; Questelberg; Costelberg; Custelberch; Quistelberg; Cuistelberg; Questelbergh; Custelberg; Quistelberch; Custeleberg; Kusselberg; Qwistelbergh; Cvstel; Guistesberg; Quistelburg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1177. A monastery is mentioned from 1302.

Name: Kostrzyn nad Odrą
Alternative_Name: Küstrin; Cozsterine; Custerin; Costerin; Custryn; Kostryn; Custrina; Cüstrin
Settlement_Description: The old settlement, the german and slavic villages were gone before 1417, a toll station only existed in slavic times, slavic fishing village mentioned, the german market settlement came after 1232, mentioned as oppidum in 1261
Town_Description: Magdeburg town law was likely granted by margrave Albrecht III. shortly before 1300, mentioned as civitas in 1317 and 1372, as opidum in 1323
Staple_Description: In 1424, Poles were exempted from the staple in Kostrzyn.

Name: Kyritz
Settlement_Description: The bailiff of Kyritz started the settlement close to a castle in 1232
Town_Description: Founded with Stendal town law by the lords of Plote, who organised the constitutional and legal relationships of the civitas in 1237

Name: Laage
Settlement_Description: A castle in wendish time, a priest mentioned in 1253, in 1270 a still growing village, see of the small german bailiwick that was first mentioned in 1297
Town_Description: First mentioned as oppidum in 1309, first mentioned as civitas in 1336, privileges endorsed in 1441

Name: Laag-Keppel
Alternative_Name: Keppel; Laagkeppel; Nie-Keppel; Nieuw-Keppel; Borgkeppel; Borch-Keppel; Borch Keppell; Keppel-Binnen
Settlement_Description: Origin as a settlement near the castle of Sweder van Voorst, which was probably built around 1350. Earliest mention of 'Borch Keppell' dates from 1361.
Town_Description: Market privileges are granted on 14 April 1361 by Emperor Charles IV to Sweder of Voorst for his 'opidum'. Additional town privileges granted to Laagkeppel in 1374, 1404 and 1425. It concerns a town of the type 'minderstadt'.
Toll_Description: Laag-Keppel was located near a ford where the IJssel could be crossed. This ford was part of the road between Zutphen and Emmerich; a toll was levied here. It is unknown from which moment onwards toll has been levied.

Name: Laar
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1065.

Name: Laarne
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1040, in a copy from the second half of the twelfth century.

Name: Bad Laasphe
Alternative_Name: Laasphe; Lassafa; Lasphe; Lasfa; Laspe; Lose
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as 'villa' 780 - 807.
Town_Description: The settlement had town rights from the second half of the 13th century. From 1277 'civitas', from 1295 'oppidum'. It was not until 1438 that it received the Wittgenstein town privilege.

Name: Laatzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1227.

Name: Labenz
Alternative_Name: Labbentzeke; Labenseke; Labentzeke; Lawentzeke; Lebentz; Labentz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1390.

Name: Polessk
Alternative_Name: Labiau; Полесск; Labegowe-moter; Labigowe; Labigow; Labiaw
Settlement_Description: The Teutonic Order built a fortress to protect Königsberg against the Lithuanians in 1258, it was destroyed in 1277 and rebuilt in 1280, a settlement began forming in the 13th ct. which was granted a few privileges in the 15th ct.
Town_Description: The Great Elector grants the town privilege in 1642, even though the place has already been mentioned as a 'Stadt' since 1626, the privilege called it a hamlet

Name: Ladekath
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1280.

Name: Lage (Kommende)
Settlement_Description: Probably goes back to a Frankish foundation. Since 1221 it was owned by the counts of Tecklenburg. A monastery of the Knights Hospitaller was first mentioned in 1260 (probably founded in 1245 by Count Otto von Tecklenburg). In the 14th century the monastery became an important place of pilgrimage. The monastery was closed in 1811, but a Catholic institution remained.
Fair_Description: Two fairs came into existence in the 14th century in the context of the pilgrimage to the Holy Cross in Lage, on the day of the Birth of John the Baptist, the patron saint, and on the Dedication day of the church on the Exaltation of the Holy Cross. These fairs were visited among others by merchants from Osnabrück.

Name: Lage (Werre)
Alternative_Name: Lage; Lagis; Laghe; Loghen; Layge; Lohge
Settlement_Description: In 1274 a pastor is mentioned in Lage.
Town_Description: A planned town foundation is not verifiable. After 1410 town rights were documented, the settlement is nevertheless only a grown 'Weichbild' with just some of the town privileges.

Name: Lahde
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1168.

Name: Laiuse
Settlement_Description: The parish was established in 1319. In 1406 a castle of the Teutonic Order was built nearby, which was occupied by Russians in 1558. 1622 conquered by Sweden, later destroyed.

Name: Jõgeva
Settlement_Description: Originally a manor with hamlets ('Hof'), which were mentioned in 1601. At the end of the 19th century a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built near the manor, which later received town rights.

Name: Laitse
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1219. In 1365 it was given to the Teutonic Order. Around 1800 the village was abandoned.

Name: Lamspringe
Alternative_Name: Lammespringe; Lammespringensium; Lamsprinche; Lamspringhe; Lamme; Lamspring
Settlement_Description: A monastery of canonesses in Lamspringe was first mentioned in 872, and later converted to a Benedictine nun monastery. It became Lutheran in 1568 and was closed in 1803. The connected settlement was characterised as a borough ('flecken'/'blek') from 1426 and received corresponding privileges in 1499.
Toll_Description: In 1439 the bishop of Hildesheim began to levy a wine toll, as well as in Marienburg and Bodenburg.

Name: Landegge
Settlement_Description: A castle was built here in 1178 to guard the road.
Fair_Description: A market with market toll in Landegge is first mentioned in 1238, which attracted visitors from places as far as Reiderland and Dortmund. Between 1303 and 1345, three dates for fairs are mentioned, on Pentecost, St John and the Nativity of Mary.

Name: Landen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1050. Next mention in 1080, in a middle thirteenth century copy. Next mention in 1116.

Name: Landesbergen
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned around 1200, a family von Landesbergen already in ca. 1160.

Name: Gorzów Wielkopolski
Alternative_Name: Landsberg a.d. Warthe; Landsberg an der Warthe; Landsbergk; Landisberch Nova; Nuenlandesberch; Stad tzu Nuwen landisberg
Town_Description: The knight Albert of Luge was certified as the founder of the town ‘Landisberch Nova’ by the Ascanian Margrave John I.
Staple_Description: The first mention of a staple in a charter from 1257 is probably a later addition; furthermore mentioned in 1391 and 1400. In 1424, Poles are exempted from the staple (HUB 6:533). In 1539, in favour of Frankfurt, the use of the road via Landsberg for transit traffic was prohibited, and the staple limited to commodities transported downstream from Poland. In the other direction, there existed no staple obligations.

Name: Landsberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a gift certificate from Otto I. to St. Moritz monastery in Magdeburg as "civitas holm" (MGH DD O I, nr. 231, S. 316f.). 1170 - 1186 a castle is built along which a small settlement develops.
Town_Description: 1442 the settlement is referred to as town.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct of Delitzsch

Name: Landsmeer
Alternative_Name: Lansmeer; Lantsmer; Lantsmeer; Lansmaer; Lantsmaer; Lantsmerr
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1326.

Name: Landwehrhagen
Alternative_Name: Lantgrevenhagen; Lantgrebenhayn; Lantgrafenhain; Lantgrafinhain; Lantgrebenhagen; Lantgrebenhain; Lantgreuenhaghen; Landtgrefenhagen; Landgrafenhagen; Landtwernhagen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1311-1318.

Name: Pikasilla
Settlement_Description: The bridge was built near an old castle. In 1398, it served as a place, where the Teutonic Order and the Bishop of Dorpat were negotiating. Later, a village with an Inn developed.

Name: Langeln
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1564.

Name: Langelsheim
Alternative_Name: Laggenize; Langeniz; Langesse; Langelsen; Langessem; Lanchel
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned around 1016.

Name: Langenberg (Gera)
Settlement_Description: A castle district and a nearby ribbon-built village ('Straßendorf') are proven. In 1505, when Langenberg was already a borough ('Flecken'), it was granted its first settlement-rights ('Ortsrecht'). Langenberg was only elevated to town in 1933.

Name: Langenbrügge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1330 and 1352.

Name: Langenforth
Alternative_Name: Langen Vorth; Langenforder Baurschafft; Langenförder Baurschafft; Langenvorde; Langenfohrt
Settlement_Description: Characterised as hamlet ('bauerschaft')

Name: Langenhagen
Alternative_Name: Novam Indaginem; Nova Indagine; Nyenhaghene; Nigenhagen; Niegenhagen; Nienhagen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1312.
Toll_Description: A toll station of the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg is first mentioned in 1501. A register of toll revenues exists from 1602/1603 and has been analysed by Rothe.

Name: Langenholzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1205.

Name: Langenhorn
Alternative_Name: Langenhorne; Langhenhorne; Langhen Horne; Langenhornn; Langehorn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1283.

Name: Langenlehsten
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1194.

Name: Bad Langensalza
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Breviarum sancti Lulli from the 9th century. It lay near the Dryburg of the lords of Salza, which controlled the crossing at the ford of the roads from Gotha to Mühlhausen and from Eisenach to Tennstedt.
Town_Description: The town was sieged by Kaiser Otto IV. in 1212, which probably lead to the receiving of town privileges. First referral to the town as "oppidum" in 1222. Extensive destruction of the town in 1346. In 1356 the Old city with its two suburbs, the Jacobs-town and the New town are put under one communal administration, which is corroborated by the construction of a shared town wall.
Toll_Description: The regulations of safe conduct in 1516 say: "There is no safe conduct in the department of Saltza, only the toll in town" (LHASA, MD, d. 21 A I Nr. 1 I, Amtserbbuch für Salza und Thamsbrück 1516, p. 83–84 and p. 113–116.). in 1558 the safe conduct was given to the town council with an option of repurchase, in 1663 it was ultimately given to the prince electorate.
Fair_Description: Since 1438 proof of two, since 1484 of three fairs.

Name: Langlingen
Alternative_Name: Lankelege; Langelege; Langhelege; Langlaghen; Langhleeghen; Langhelghen; Langelge; Langelinge; Langhelingh; Langelyngen; Langling
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1218/1220.

Name: Langwedel
Settlement_Description: Construction of a castle by the archbishop of Bremen around 1222; first mentioned in 1226.
Toll_Description: Toll of the archbishop of Bremen. Bremen citizens were exempted from the toll in 1226. In 1366, the castle including the toll was pawned to the town Bremen. A raise of the toll fares led to complaints from Hannover in 1427. The toll was pawned to Lüneburg in 1435 for six years. Its revenues amounted to almost 90 Taler in 1567/8. Toll revenues are also recorded in a register from 1616/1617.

Name: Lankau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1208.

Name: Laren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1294-1295.

Name: Lasfelde
Alternative_Name: Laresfelt; Larsfelde; Laresuelde; Larsuelde; Lasfelda; Laßfelde; Lassfelde
Settlement_Description: The first mention of 1174-1195 concerns a forest, but it is likely that the settlement already existed at that time as well.

Name: Lastrup
Settlement_Description: The parish of Lastrup is first mentioned in 1223, although the hamlet ('bauernschaft') existed already before that date.

Name: Latferde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 1222. A mention of the settlement "Lofurdi" in a register of the monastery Corvey from 822 probably refers to Lafferde near Peine.
Toll_Description: Road toll in the 17th century, first mentioned in 1620.

Name: Bad Lauchstädt
Alternative_Name: Lauchstädt; Lochstat; Lochtestide; Lohstedi; Lokstete; Louchstete
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the Hersfelder Zehntregister around 899. Borough ('Flecken') in 1519. In the course of the 14th and 15th century, the settlement gained several privileges, such as the privilege of jurisdicition in 1519. In 1608 borough rights ('Weichbildrechte') are confirmed by Johann Georg of Merseburg.
Toll_Description: The extensive regulations of safe conduct from 1600 confirm earlier regulations (LHASA, MD, U 10 XXIII Nr. 1.).

Name: Lauenburg
Alternative_Name: Lavenborch; Louenburch; Lowenburg; Louenborch; Lovenburg; Lauenborg; Lovenburc; Lovenborg; Lowenbogk; Lawnburg; Lauenburc; Louenborch; Lawenburg
Settlement_Description: The castle Lauenburg was built in 1181/1182 by duke Bernhard I of Ascania. After 1227, a settlement developed near the castle.
Town_Description: In the mid-13th century, the settlement probably became a town. A town council and citizens are attested at the end of the 13th century.
Toll_Description: A toll of the dukes of Saxony-Lauenburg is first mentioned in 1248, with specifications of the toll tariffs. Citizens from Hamburg were exempted from the toll in 1252. The toll in Lauenburg was especially levied on salt exported from Lüneburg towards Lübeck and towns upstream on the Elbe. According to a 1492 description, each ship had to pay 8 Gulden, 1 rye bread and a loaf of bread in Lauenburg.

Name: Lębork
Alternative_Name: Lauenburg; Lauenburg in Pommern; Lewinburg; Lowenborch; Lawenburgk; Lawenburg; Lowenburg; Lauwenburg
Settlement_Description: A slavic settlement with town-like character was mentioned in 1285. The emergence of a german settlement between 1313 and 1341 is likely but not documented.
Town_Description: Dietrich, burgrave of Altenburg and grand master of the Teutonic Order gave the town with Kulm town law to Rutcher von Emmerich. It was mentioned as a 'Stat' in 1341. A handfast dates back to 1341 and was renewed in 1507.

Name: Lauenförde
Alternative_Name: Lewevord; Lewenvorde; Lewinforde; Lawinforde; Lewenfurde; Lawenforde; Lauenford; Lawenförde; Lewenford; Lemforde
Settlement_Description: Lauenförde came into existence next to a castle, which is first mentioned in 1348. The settlement was mentioned as borough ('flecken') in 1447, but as village in the 16th century.

Name: Laiküla
Settlement_Description: The village has existed since medieval times (probably the 13th century). An estate was built in 1688.

Name: Lihula
Settlement_Description: The parish of Leal was mentioned in 1241. Beside the castle, which was built in 1211, a village/Borough ('Flecken') settled, which was destroyed again in 1298. It was rebuilt and developed itself in to a place with some churches and monasteries in the 16th century. Borough rights ('Fleckenrechte') were only granted in 1945.

Name: Lebbeke
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1003.

Name: Lebenstedt
Alternative_Name: Lövenstedt; Liuenstide; Livenstide; Lievenstede; Levenstede; Lebenstede; Levenstedde; Levenstidde; Levenstedt; Lewenstedt; Löwenstedt; Lebenstett
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1129.

Name: Lebus
Alternative_Name: Lubus; Lubusz; Lubbus; Lubbuz; terra lubusana; Episcopus lubucensis; lubusanus; lubusanusa; Lebuz
Settlement_Description: The area has been a culturally important place since the early slavic time, a polish fortress consisting of three castles is mentioned in 1109, close by is a german market settlement founded by the silesian Piast dynasty after 1225
Town_Description: Mentioned as civitas in 1226, german town law was granted in silesian times, probably earlier than 1250, mentioned as oppidum in 1354 and 1355, 1406 as Städtchen

Name: Liedikas
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1486.

Name: Leende
Alternative_Name: Lieende; Lende; Leent; Leynde; Heeze en Leend
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1253.

Name: Leer
Alternative_Name: Hleri; Lare; Lage; Lier; Lyer; Leher; Leehere
Settlement_Description: A missionary church was erected by Liudger around 790, next to which a market borough developed. Borough ('flecken') statutes are first known from 1585 and the settlement acquired urban characteristics, although formal town privileges were granted as late as in 1823.
Toll_Description: A toll of the counts of East Frisia is mentioned in 1577 complaints from Emden. In 1640, Emden merchants complain about a new toll on flax and wine in Leer.
Harbour_Description: Leer was an important harbour on the rivers Ems and Leda in the 16th century, although it suffered from the staple privileges of Emden. The importance of the harbour for the borough is indicated by the fact that the market, which originally took place at the Kaakskpütte, moved to the waterfront, where a weigh house was erected in the middle of the 16th century. In the late 16th century, a ferry with Emden is mentioned, which was privileged to skippers from Emden and Leer.

Name: Leerort
Alternative_Name: Lierortt; Lerorde; Lherorth; Leerohrt; Lieroort; Lieroorth
Settlement_Description: A castle was built by the Frisian nobleman Focko Ukena around 1420, which was destroyed in 1431. A new castle was erected by Hamburg in 1432 as protection of the trade routes against pirates. Later the castle was acquired by the Cirksena family and became the administrative centre of the region. From 1611 to 1744, the fortress was occupied by Dutch troops.
Toll_Description: During the Dutch occupation of Leerort, the admiralty of Dokkum moved the toll of Bourtange to Leerort and changed it into a toll on shipping on the Ems river in 1621. A list of toll fees from that year is still extant. The toll was finally abolished after many complaints from the count of East Frisia and the town of Emden in 1653.

Name: Leersum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the eleventh century.

Name: Leese
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1183.
Toll_Description: An insignificant toll is attested here in 1583.

Name: Leeuwarden
Alternative_Name: Ljouwert; Liunvero; Liunvert; Linvvar; Lienward; Linuuard; Linewert; Liuwerth; Lewart; Liuwerd
Settlement_Description: First mentioned on a coin from 1038-1057.
Town_Description: Leeuwarden never officially received town rights. However, Leeuwarden was recognized as a town by other cities. The earliest mention of this dates from 31 October 1285.
Harbour_Description: In the 17th century, Leeuwarden became the centre of regular barge ('trekvaart') services with Franeker and Harlingen (1646, with five departures daily in both directions), Dokkum (1647), Bolsward and Workum (1648), Groningen (1656) and Sneek (1661).

Name: Leezen
Alternative_Name: Latzinghe; Latzinge; Letcingge; Letzinghe; Leetzinghe; Lezingk; Leetzingh

Name: Lehmden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1296.

Name: Lehre
Alternative_Name: Lerin; Leri; Lerim; Lere; Lehere; Leere
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 8th or 9th century.

Name: Lehrte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as "villa Lereht" in 1147.

Name: Liebstedt
Settlement_Description: In 956 Otto I. gives property in Liebstedt to Quedlinburg monastery. In 1331 the water castle is property of the Teutonic Order.

Name: Leiden
Alternative_Name: Leithen; Leyden; Ledene; Leythen; Leda; Ledam; Leithon
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius Leiden is first mentioned in a document from 1143. Cox, however, states that Leiden was first mentioned in copy of ninth century text (tenth or late eleventh century).
Town_Description: Leiden was granted town rights on 19 December 1266 by Floris V, count of Holland. Cox argues that four grants outdate the 1266 grant, the earliest of which could have been given during the reign of Dirk VII, count of Holland (r. 1190-1203) or even Floris III, count of Holland (r. 1157-1190).

Name: Leidschendam
Alternative_Name: den Damme ofte Overtocht; Leytschendam; Leidzen Dam; Leytsendam; Leitsche Dam
Settlement_Description: Leidschendam developed near a dam in the Vliet canal, which is first mentioned in 1434. The settlement is first mentioned in 1486.
Lock_Description: A dam in the Vliet canal in Leidschendam is first mentioned in 1434. This dam was built for regulating the water levels and prevented a free passage of ships. Cargoes therefore had to be transshipped here. When the Vliet was developed as a tow canal ('trekvaart') between Leiden and Delft in 1636-1638, a passage ('duiker') for small boats was constructed as well as a slope for dragging larger ships across ('overtoom'). Passengers and cargoes would have to be unloaded first.

Name: Leimbach (Fulda)
Settlement_Description: Abandoned in the 16th century at the latest; the church is last mentioned in 1579.

Name: Leimbach (Mansfeld)
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 973 in an exchange of estates between Fulda monastery and the archbishopric of Magdeburg. (MGH OII no. 64, S. 74-77) Earlier already mentioned in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis.
Town_Description: On 10th august 1530 elevation of the marketplace to town on demand of count Hoyer VI. of Mansfeld-Vorderort.
Fair_Description: Count Hoyer IV. (1484 - 1540) obtained town-, fair-, and weekly market rights for Leimbach, which were later confirmed by emperors Ferdinand I. and Maximilian II.

Name: Leinefelde
Settlement_Description: First mention of the village in 1227. Leinefelde is only elevated to town in 1961.

Name: Leipzig
Settlement_Description: Developed from a settlement that was originally Slavic in the 10th and 11th centuries. The settlement was founded on the early trade routes of the 'Hohe Straße' and 'via imperii/Salzstraße', which gave it some meaning in trade early on. In 1050, it develops into a burgward centre.
Town_Description: Town founded by Margrave Otto of Meißen according to Halle-Magdeburg rights; city laid out according to a plan. Because of the fairs and the favorable traffic situation, Leipzig became an important mediator between Nuremberg and the Hanse towns, copper trade in Hungary and mining in the Mansfelder region. In 1409 a university was founded. Severe damage was dealt during the 30-year-war and Leipzig temporarily went to the Swedes from 1632 - 1633 and again from 1642 - 1650.
Toll_Description: A special safe conduct in Leipzig was given eight days before and after the fairs. During this time, the citizens of Leipzig had to pay the fees as well, where they would normally be excempt. In 1558 the safe conduct, including the secondary station in Taucha, is pawned off by the prince electorate to the council of the town of Leipzig. The coucil is to maintain raods, paths, dams, ditches, bridges and footbrindges from the income.
Staple_Description: The staple requirements appeared first in the market privileges of Emperor Maximilian in 1507; other records indicate that the staple existed before; e.g. citizens were forbidden to trade outside of town within a designated zone. Such prohibitions are already known from the 15th century. The staple was valid within a protected zone of 15 miles around the town; confirmed by Pope Leo X in 1514 and renewed in 1521 by Emperor Charles V. A complete enforcement of the staple was, however, not possible: conflicts with Erfurt, Halle, Magdeburg, Dresden and Prina ensued, all of whom wished to keep their staple rights. In the Seven Years’ War the Leipzig staples were combined.
Fair_Description: In a document from between 1156 and 1170 a protected zone for the yearly fair was imposed around the town of Leipzig, which must be connected to an actual yearly fair. In 1268 a document refesr to the fair at Leipzig playing host to merchants from foreign lands, which at the time was under the protected of local territorial lords. Since the 16th century the Peter-and-Paul market in Naumburg was aligned with the Leipziger calendar of markets (see Naumburg (Saale)). There was, therefore, a unique concentration of four large markets in one place.

Name: Leisnig
Toll_Description: In Leisning, safe conduct was paid in today's districts Clennen, Fischendorf and Börtewitz. A toll was due for rafts on the Mulde river.

Name: Litoměřice
Staple_Description: In 1325 King John of Bohemia recognised the right of Umschlagspflicht (compulsory exchange); in 1341 exceptions made for ships from Aussig carrying fresh fish and lead, and in 1351 for ships from Melnik, who carried grain and other wares down the Elbe or salt towards Litomerice. In 1391 staple rights confirmed, changing in 1409 to a duty on grain.

Name: Leitzkau
Settlement_Description:
In the Early Middle ages the place served as a rally point for armies marching into the East, the earliest mentions stem from records written in Leitzkau to that regard. In 1114 a stone building was erected and Leitzkau was possibly the first makeshift centre of the bishopric of Brandenburg. In 1390 the settlement is referred to as oppidum.
In 1138/39 an order of Premonstratensian Canons was established at the settlement. Beginning at the end of the 14th century, the convent, that didn't earn much property during the Middle Ages, decayed. In 1600, the convent was converted into a Renaissance castle.

Name: Lelle
Settlement_Description: A Manor and later an estate that was first mentioned in 1559.

Name: Lembeke
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1201.

Name: Lviv
Staple_Description: Beginnings are unclear. In 1379 a staple for various wares was confirmed, which were guaranteed in a treaty between Lemberg, Waldimir and Luzk. A provision of King Louis of Poland in 1380 stipulated that merchants from Hungary and Poland should offer their wares for sale for 14 days; renewed in 1387 with the addition of salt to the list of goods that should be offered for sale. A privilege of 1444 forbade foreign merchants from travelling east or west via Lemberg; confirmed in the Polish Staple Law of 1565.

Name: Lembruch
Settlement_Description: A castle was erected by the lord of Diepholz around 1275, which was first mentioned in 1305.

Name: Lemförde
Settlement_Description: A castle in Lemförde is first mentioned in 1316, but probably built around 1248. A charter from 1349 mentions Lemförde for the first time not explicitly as castle, which suggests that at that time, a significant settlement had developed. Lemförde acquired borough ('weichbild') privileges in 1427. The settlement was characterised as "wigbold" in 1457 and "flekken" (borough) in 1530, and as "Städtlein" (small town) in 1624.
Fair_Description: in 1694 it is mentioned, that a "Kirchmeße und Kramermarck" (dedication day festival and retail market) had taken place since old times before the Thirty Years' War. It is unclear how far back the fair went, possibly into the 14th century.

Name: Lemgo
Alternative_Name: Limego; Leme; Lemegowen; Lemgaw; Lemgow; Lemgovia
Settlement_Description: 'Limga' was first mentioned as a 'Flurname' in 1005, which surrounded the later settlement.
Town_Description: Around 1212 Lemgo received city rights, which were approved in 1245.
Toll_Description: A toll of the counts of Lippe is mentioned in Lemgo in 1403, 1405 and 1471.

Name: Oud-Lemiers
Alternative_Name: Lumirs; Lumires; Lummirs; Lomirs; Lommiers; Lumyers Lammers; Limmiers; Lummiers; Lemers; Lemiers; Limmers; Lemiers
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1208.

Name: Lemke
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241.

Name: Lemmer
Alternative_Name: De Lemmer; Lemmers; Lyaemmer; Liamer; Lyamer
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1309.

Name: Lemmie
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1216.

Name: Limbaži
Alternative_Name: Lemsal; Lemsel; Lemszel; Lembsell; Lembzell; Lempsell
Settlement_Description: A castle was built even before 1318. During the 14th century, a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') developed between the lake Duhnesee (today: 'Dunezers') and the medieval castle.
Town_Description: The fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') received town rights by Riga in 1385. The town was member of the Hanseatic League. The town had access to the sea due to the tributaries of the river Salis and had its own harbour.

Name: Lemsel
Alternative_Name: Lomsil; Lomsel; Lömßell; Lömsil; Lumbsel; Lömsell
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1350. 1428 mention as a knightly manor.

Name: Lengefeld
Settlement_Description: Mention in a split of property ('Gütertrennung') by monasteries Hersfeld and Fulda.

Name: Lengefeld
Alternative_Name: Lenghivelde; Lenkevelde; Lengevelt; Lengeveld; Lengefelde; Lengeuelt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned 1036.

Name: Lengenfeld
Settlement_Description: Rassow sets the first mention of the settlement in 897, when property in Lengenfeld is given in an exchange with Fulda monastery. Since 1191 a noble family of Lengefelde is known. Kahl sets the first mention in 1302, where Lengenfeld is mentioned in the record book of the Eichsfeld.

Name: Lengerich (Emsland)
Alternative_Name: Lengerich; Lengerich, Emsland; Lengreke; Lengerichi; Lengerike
Settlement_Description: A settlement was first mentioned in 891.

Name: Lengerich (Westfalen)
Alternative_Name: Lengerich; Liggerike; Lengerike; Leggerike; Lengerke; Lenkerike; Lencrike; Lengerike; Lengerick by Tegkeneburch
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1147/49.
Toll_Description: A toll station of the counts of Tecklenburg is first mentioned in 1441.

Name: Lengröden
Settlement_Description: Lengröden was a knightly manor at the time.

Name: Lennep
Toll_Description: The Count of Berg levied a land toll in 1371. In 1398, an additional 4 turnosgroschen per foder of wine and 1 turnosgroschen extra per horse had to be paid. In 1495, the annual amount was around 20 guilders.

Name: Lielvārde
Alternative_Name: Lennewarden; Lenuwart; Lenwarden; Lineward; Linwar; Lendewarden
Settlement_Description: In 1201, the already existing castle was given as a fief. In 1255, a second castle was built, which was repeatedly occupied by the Teutonic Order. In 1514 the archbishop founded a monastery of St. Anthony.

Name: Lensahn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1222/3.

Name: Lent
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1196.

Name: Lenzen
Settlement_Description: Originally a slavic castle mound where Gottschalk, the christian prince of the Obotrites was killed in 1066, a german settlement around the church existed since 1220
Town_Description: The greats of Schwerin in their function as lords of the caslte (1219-1237), granted the Salzwedel town law, it was endorsed and extended by Margrave Otto III., mentioned as civitas or town since 1373
Toll_Description: The toll in Lenzen is first mentioned in 1219, when the count of Schwerin acquired the castle as a fief. In 1237, Lübeck is exempted from the toll in Lenzen by the counts of Dannenberg, and once again in 1354 by the dukes of Mecklenburg. In 1411, the Mecklenburg part of the toll in Schnackenburg is moved to Lenzen. It is unclear if this means that a toll was also levied on shipping on the Elbe from this year, or if there was only a road toll in Lenzen. In 1558, the margrave of Brandenburg acquired the right to levy a grain toll on the Elbe as well as on the street.

Name: Lenči
Settlement_Description: The manor and village were first mentioned in 1590.

Name: Leschede
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1330.

Name: Lessien
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1624.

Name: Lethe
Settlement_Description: Archaeological excavations showed that a castle was constructed in the first half of the 15th century. Herbord von Dorgeloh is first mentioned as inhabitant in 1471.

Name: Leusden
Alternative_Name: Loesderbroec; Luesdenrebroeck; Loesdenrebroeck; Leusderbroek; Leusbroek; Nieuw-Leusden; Nieuw Leusden; Leusbroek; Oud-Leusden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1378-1379.

Name: Leuvenum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from the end of the thirteenth century.

Name: Liepāja
Settlement_Description: Originally a small fishing village 'Liwa', the harbour/port of which was first mentioned in 1253/67. In 1291 there existed 'castrum Lyva'. It was first mentioned as a settlement in 1413. After the settlement was destroyed by Lithuanians in 1418, it was rebuilt and referred to as a market place.
Town_Description: Libau gained town rights in 1625.

Name: Hessisch Lichtenau
Settlement_Description: Created by merging several villages. First mentioned in 1289.
Town_Description: Landgrave Heinrich I founded the town probably before 1289. 'Nova civitas' mentioned for 1289.

Name: Lichtenau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1326.
Town_Description: An exact award of town privileges is not documented, but it must have been a town before 1350.

Name: Niederfreden
Alternative_Name: Frethen; Fredhene; Vredene; Vreden undir Lechtenberge; Vreden under Lechtenberghe; Vredhen; Nederenvredene; Inferiori Vreden; Niddern Freden; Niedern Freden; Niedernfreden; Lichtenberg; Salzgitter-Lichtenberg
Settlement_Description: First mention of Freden around 1226. The settlement under the castle Lichtenberg consisted of two parts, Nieder- ('lower') and Ober- ('upper') Freden, of which the former is first mentioned separately around 1274. Both villages were merged with Lichtenberg under the name of the castle in 1856/57.

Name: Miłomłyn
Settlement_Description: A house of the Teutonic Order was built before 1335
Town_Description: The komtur of Christburg, Dietrich von Altenburg, founded the town in 1335 with Kulm town law, the handfast was renewed in 1438 after the old one was lost in a fire.

Name: Liebenburg
Settlement_Description: Bishop Siegfried of Hildesheim started the construction of the castle Liebenburg near the settlement Lewe in 1292. It came into the possession of the dukes of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel in 1523.
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Hildesheim in Liebenburg was cancelled in 1354.

Name: Liebenwalde
Settlement_Description: Slavic settlement and castle mound, an ascanian fortress was built in the beginning of the 13th ct., see of a margravial bailiff, a provost was mentioned in 1244, mentioned in 1449 as 'Stetichen'

Name: Lieberose
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1272, called oppidum in 1301, a castle was built early on
Town_Description: Town law was granted in 1302

Name: Liemehna
Settlement_Description: First mention as Lumene in 1238.

Name: Lienen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1088.

Name: Liepe
Settlement_Description: In 1233 the surroundings of Liepe are mentioned as former Slavic territory. In 1267 two villages of Lipa are mentioned. In 1375 only one of those villages seems to have remained.

Name: Lier
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1146.

Name: Lierop
Alternative_Name: Lirdob; Lindor; Lidorp; Liedarp; Lijedorp; Liederop
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1155.

Name: Liesborn
Alternative_Name: Lysbernen; Lisbarn; Liesbornensis; Listbarne; Lysebornensi; Lesberne; Lisefontanum; Leisbornne

Name: Limburg an der Lahn
Alternative_Name: Limburg; Lympurg; Lintburk; Lintburc; Limburc; Lympurg
Settlement_Description: Probably goes back to a Merovingian military station. The name first appears in 910.
Town_Description: The exact elevation to the city is unknown because a document is missing. 1232 'oppidum' with walls, in 1279 Frankfurt law is confirmed.
Toll_Description: In 1344, Gerlach Herr von Limburg levied a land toll and a fee for safe conduct on land. He pledged the income from an older toll to Archbishop Baldiun of Trier.

Name: Limmer
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1339.

Name: Linau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230. In the 13th and 14th century, there was a castle of the knights of Scharpenburg in Linau, who disturbed the land traffic in the region. The castle was destroyed by a coalition of Hamburg, Lübeck, the count of Holstein and the duke of Lauenburg in 1350.

Name: Lindau
Settlement_Description: Around 1322, bishop Otto II of Hildesheim erected a new castle in Lindau, where an older castle had existed before. The accompanying settlement was first characterised as borough ('flecken'/'oppidum') in 1496.
Toll_Description: A toll and safe conduct of the duke of Brunswick was mentioned in 1477, when a citizen of Schwarzburg had circumvented it. The toll might go back to the foundation of the castle around 1322. It still existed in the 17th century.

Name: Linden (Wolfenbüttel)
Alternative_Name: Lindim; Lindun; Lindem; Linder; Lindum; Lyndum; Lyndem; Lynden; Linde; Lindhem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1007. Archaeological finds suggest that a settlement existed already in the 1st to 4th century.
Toll_Description: Toll of the dukes of Brunswick. A toll collector is first mentioned in 1316; the toll was pawned in 1349. It is moved to the Gotteslager in Wolfenbüttel before 1630.

Name: Linden (Hannover)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1097.

Name: Lindena
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1234 and property of the Cistercian monastery of Dobrilugk.

Name: Lindenau
Settlement_Description: First mention of a Didericus of Lindinouwe in 1182.

Name: Lindenhayn
Settlement_Description: First mention as Lindenhoin in 1348.

Name: Lindenthal
Settlement_Description: First mention as Lindental in 1350.

Name: Lindlar
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in 1470. Tariffs are not known. In 1470/72 the toll was leased out for 20 mark a year.

Name: Lindow
Settlement_Description: A cistercian nun convent was established close to an old fortified settlement in 1230, an old fishing village nearby that grew into a market- and craftsmen settlement
Town_Description: Town law may never have been granted, mentioned as oppidum in 1375, later also called 'Städtchen', founded by the lords of Ruppin

Name: Lindow (Mark)
Settlement_Description: Foundation of a convent of Cistercian nuns in 1230 in the vicinity, which moved to Lindow around 1240. A small market- and craftsmen-village developed at the monastery.

Name: Lindtorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1431.

Name: Lingen
Settlement_Description: Lingen came into existence near a ford in the Ems near the current Altenlingen ('Old Lingen'). The settlement is first mentioned in 1150 as "Aldenlingen", which indicates that already at that time, the centre of the settlement had moved to the new Lingen further south. A first mention as "Liinga/Linga" in 975 is very questionable.
Town_Description: Lingen acquired toll, mint, market and court privileges in 1227 and was built as a planned town. In 1306, the settlement was first mentioned as 'civitas'. Town privileges were granted in 1401.

Name: Linne
Alternative_Name: Linna; Lynne; Lynde; Linden; Lijnn; Lin
Settlement_Description: Linne is first mentioned in an eleventh-century copy of a text dating from 943.
Town_Description: Linne develops into a town in the period 1180-1225. It was granted town rights some time between 1255 and 24 November 1258 by Elisabeth of Sprimont, lady of Linne. The development of Linne into a town is halted before the end of the thirteenth century.

Name: Linnepe
Alternative_Name: Linnipha; Lynpe; Lynnipe; Linepe; Lynnepe; Lynope; Lynepe; Linnepe; Lennep
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1107 and 1128.

Name: Linsburg
Settlement_Description: The settlement is characterised as "villa" in 1203. Duke Erich of Calenberg built a hunting castle in the 16th century, where there already existed a hunting lodge before.

Name: Linse
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 8th or 9th century.
Toll_Description: A toll in Linse is mentioned in toll lists of the years 1539, 1540 and 1587.

Name: Linum
Settlement_Description: Became property of the bishops of Havelberg in 1294.

Name: Lippborg
Alternative_Name: Lippeburch; Lippenburg; Lyppurc; Libborg; Leborg; Lybburch

Name: Lipiany
Settlement_Description: Pomeranian castellan castle, administrative centre of the terra, castrum was still mentioned in 1337
Town_Description: Mentioned as civitas since 1302, only named oppidum in 1337, town law likely hasn't been granted

Name: Bad Lippspringe
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1346, but goes back to a Saxon settlement. Charlemagne had 776, 780, 781 and 804 stays in this settlement. In 1312 a castle is mentioned, near which a suburbium was created, which is first mentioned in 1434.
Town_Description: In 1445 town privileges were granted.

Name: Lippstadt
Alternative_Name: Lyppia; Lippia; Lippa; Lippensis; Lippense; Stat zu der Lippe; Stadt Lippe; Lipstatt
Settlement_Description: Lippstadt was founded by the counts of Lippe around 1168 or 1184.
Town_Description: Lippstadt must have been granted town privileges after Soest model around 1220.
Toll_Description: Although an export tax on corn existed since 1366, the town acquired a privilege to levy a toll on merchant's commodities only in 1449. Moreover, in 1481 a toll was introduced on cattle sold in town and on carriages passing the bridges, to cover the maintenance of the town walls and the bridges.
Fair_Description: A confirmation of town privileges from 1244 included the right to hold a fair, including market freedom of two days before and after the fair. The oldest fair probably took place on St Martin's Day. In 1553, a fair that formerly took place on 9 September was moved to the second day of Christmas and in 1574 to Innocent's Day. In 1580, four fairs are attested: next to the two already mentioned, there were fairs on St Michael and Thursday after Sexagesima. Given the fact that the fairs took place in autumn and winter, it is likely that mainly agricultural products and cattle were traded there.

Name: Lißdorf
Settlement_Description: Mention in the record book of Hersfeld monastery.

Name: Lisse
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 918-948, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1198.

Name: Littel
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1350.

Name: Lohu
Settlement_Description: In the years 1216 and 1220 the place was a camp for soldiers from Riga. The nearby 'Lone' Castle, around which the village developed, was conquered in 1223.

Name: Löbejün
Settlement_Description: In the 10th century main settlement of a castle district ('Burgwardhauptort'), around which the village developed.
Town_Description: Elevated to town by archbishop Günther

Name: Bad Lobenstein
Settlement_Description: The castle was possibly built by the lords of Loddeburg. Borough rights ('Weichbildrechte') granted in the 13th century.
Town_Description: The exact date of the awarding of town rights is unknown. In the 14th/15h century Gera town rights were granted. In 2005 Lobenstein was given the byname "Bad".

Name: Lobmachtersen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1131.

Name: Löbstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1253.

Name: Loburg
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed near the castle and the castle district ('Burgward'), which were constructed for the control of the Ehle crossing. In 1246 the village was referred to as oppidum.
Town_Description: 1246 the town was mentioned in a record, it can be assumed it already held the status of town in 1207, when a farmstead is mentioned in its direct vicinity. In 1558 a council is mentioned.

Name: Lochem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1059, in a falsified charter of ca. 1180-1190.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted on 9 July 1233, by Otto II, count of Guelders and Zutphen.

Name: Loenen
Alternative_Name: Lona; Loenr; Loenen aan de Vecht
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 953, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 975, in a twelfth century copy.

Name: Loenen
Alternative_Name: Luona; Lona; Loene; Lo(e)nen; Luenen; Loonen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 838, in a eleventh and twelfth century copy. Next mention in 1247.

Name: Loga
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Łagów
Settlement_Description: An ascanian fortress against Poland and Silesia, first mentioned in 1258, mentioned as stedeken in 1350

Name: Koluvere
Settlement_Description: A bishop's place was built in the 13th century (around 1227) and was converted into a castle in 1424. The village developed next to the castle.

Name: Lohe
Settlement_Description: At the first mention of the settlement, seven free farmers are mentioned.

Name: Lohe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1285; characterised as "villa" in 1385.

Name: Lohne (Oldenburg)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 980.

Name: Lohne (Soest)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1231.

Name: Südlohne (Bentheim)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1160.

Name: Lohusuu
Settlement_Description: The fishing village probably already existed in the 15th century, but was only mentioned in 1601.

Name: Loitz
Settlement_Description: First settlement probably wendish with castle grounds, later garrison with a castellan or burgrave
Town_Description: Detlev of Gadebusch granted Lübeck town law, Prince Witzlaw II. ratified the privileges in 1299

Name: Lommel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1227.

Name: Löningen
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 1149 as farm of the monastery Corvey. Probably the St Vitus church already existed in the 9th century. The settlement became a borough ('wiek') or minor town ('minderstadt') in the 14th century.

Name: Loon op Zand
Alternative_Name: Lon; Vello; Venloen; Venloe; Velloen; Venlone; Venloen; Venloon; Loon op Sant; opt Sant; Veenloon op Zandt; Loon
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1233.

Name: Loobu
Settlement_Description: Village and manor, which were in the possession of the Teutonic Order from the 15th to the 16th century.

Name: Lopau
Settlement_Description: A Ludolfus from Lopau is first mentioned in a Lüneburg town register in 1293. The village consisted of three farms. It was abandoned in the 1970s to make place for a military training area.

Name: Lößnig
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1040, mention as a manor in 1156-68, mention as a knightly manor since 1445/47.

Name: Lossow
Settlement_Description: A bronze-age rampart was abandoned around 500 BC. Around 800 AD a Slavic settlement developed, at the end of the 10th century a small Polish castle was erected.

Name: Lotte
Settlement_Description: First reference from 1272.

Name: Giżycko
Settlement_Description: House of the Teutonic Order was mentioned in 1340, the first settlement from the first half of the 15th ct. grew into a 'Zinsdorf', craftsmen began settling in the 16th ct., which soon became a market-hamlet
Town_Description: Founding documents were signed by duke Johann Sigismund of Prussia in 1612, they features Kulm town law

Name: Lovendegem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1190.

Name: Leuven
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 884, in an eleventh-century copy. Next mention in 1015 is a forgery from the first quarter of the twelfth century. Next mention in circa 1050, is in a late eleventh century copy.

Name: Löwenberg
Settlement_Description: Founded in the context of the Ascanian colonisation in 1200-1250 at a road crossing, that held some meaning. The settlement was protected by a castle that was mentioned in 1375.

Name: Lübbecke
Alternative_Name: Lidbach; Hlitbeki; Hlidbeki; Lidbecki; Libbike; Lutbeke; Luybke; Libbecke
Settlement_Description: Originally a Saxon settlement, first mentioned in 775.
Town_Description: Lübbecke acquired town privileges in 1279.

Name: Lübben
Settlement_Description: Grew out of a german or wendish settlement along the big trade route to Prussia and Poland
Town_Description: The founding documents are missing, has been mentioned as urbs in 1150, under the protection of the burgrave, who was first mentioned in 1208, the Magdeburg town law was granted in 1220

Name: Lübbenau
Alternative_Name: Lübbenau/ Spreewald; Lubbenow; Lubenowe; Lobenaw; Lubenau; Liebenau
Settlement_Description: First mention around 1301.

Name: Lübberstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of the diocese of Verden from ca. 1252. According to a register from 1563/4, the village consisted of 7 farms and 1 cottage.

Name: Lübbow
Alternative_Name: Lubbowe; Lobbowe; Lubowe; Lubbow; Lobbow; Lubbouwe; Lubow; Lübbau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 956. The village consisted of 7 farms in 1450.

Name: Lübeck
Alternative_Name: Lobeke; Lubche; Lubecae; Lubece; Lubeckh; Lubeg; Lubegk; Lubek; Lubeke; Lubic; Lubicensis; Lubick; Lubik; Lubyk; Lubyke; Lupeke; Lupke; Lybch; Lübcke; Lybiku; Lybyk; Liubeke; Lybbeke; Lubice; Lubike; Lubeke; Lubek; Lubeca
Settlement_Description: Downriver from today’s old town there was a Slavic settlement called Old Lübeck, where German merchants stayed. After the destruction of Old Lübeck in 1138 the Bucu peninsular was settled, which became a town in 1143.
Town_Description: The town was founded by the Counts of Holstein in 1143 with the name of the Slavic settlement destroyed in 1138. After a town fire in 1157 a transfer of the town failed, and Duke Henry the Lion refounded the settlement with considerable privileges and mad it the seat of the bishopric. The town soon grew into one of the most important Hanseatic centres for long distance trade.
Toll_Description: According to the oldest toll regulations of the town from 1225, foreign merchants who wanted to trade in Lübeck had to pay a fare of 4 denarii each. Moreover, tolls were levied on the cargo of ships leaving the town, as well as for wagons, carts, cattle, pigs and sheep entering town at the town gates. Special regulations were made for Slavic people. In lists of town incomes from the 15th century, a "graventol" at the Holstentor and Mühlentor gates is mentioned as well, which was levied on the shipping on the Stecknitz canal ("graven"). Moreover, between 1492 and 1496, a "pound toll" for the suppression of piracy was levied on sea-going ships, of which extensive registers still exist.
Staple_Description: The Hanserecesse of 1417 and 1418 forbade the transport of grain through the Danish straits and outside of the Hanseatic towns, which guided much trade to Lübeck (HR I, 6 n 397, § 60 n 398 und 557). The banning of foreigners trading with eachother is first attested in 1472 (HUB 10:76). Hollanders were obliged to offer bacon, butter and oil from Scandinavia and wine for 4-7 days; the Peace of Utrecht (1474) confirmed these practices, but reduced the length of time to days on account of the perishable nature of the wares, with stockfish, herring, cod and seal blubber excepted. In the 16th century the east-west trade through the Sound increased, bypassing Lübeck. Negotiations with the Hollanders regarding this ended in 1532 to Lübeck’s disadvantage. The forced sale and storage of wine, fish and others wares was cause for conflict with Denmark and Hamburg, and the ordinance of 1607 modified the staple: trade with guests was forbidden, wares of Danish merchants were forbidden (except for wine), and the same for copper, iron, pelts, oil, tar and other wares from Sweden and Finland excepting wares from Russia (including leather, tallow, wax and flax, among others). After a legal decision arising from a dispute with Hamburg in 1625, Lübeck largely relaxed the compulsory sale of staple goods in the city. Renewed attempts at imposing the staple in the 18th century led once again to conflict, until the council implicitly let it fall into abeyance after 1728.

Name: Lublin
Staple_Description: The stipulation that Russians and Lithuanians could not travel via Lublin when they headed westwards is first noted in an agreement between Gdansk and Krakow in 1493; confirmed in the Polish Staple Law of 1565.

Name: Lübz
Settlement_Description: Castle 'Eldenburg' is mentioned in 1308, a church village lies close by
Town_Description: Could not have been made a town before 1456, first mention as a town in 1506 when the priviliges were endorsed

Name: Lüchow
Alternative_Name: Luchowe; Lichouwe; Lughowe; Lugowe; Luchove; Luchow; Lüchou; Lüchau; Lüchaw
Settlement_Description: Castle of unknown age. In 1144, a count of Lüchow is first mentioned, the settlement itself in 1158.
Town_Description: Lüchow acquired town privileges in 1293.
Toll_Description: Already in 1191, a water toll is mentioned in nearby Plate. In 1435, the fee for safe conduct for citizens of Salzwedel is set to the same amount of Bergen and Bodenteich. A register of the Lüchow district of 1548-1574 mentions that citizens of Lüneburg and Wustrow are exempted from toll in Lüchow, as well as those from Dannenberg partly during fairs in their home town. Toll was levied on water and road traffic, among others on wood, pots, vegetables, fish, horses and cattle. Toll fees are known from the 16th century (StAB).
Fair_Description: A market is first mentioned in 1395. According to a register of the department of Lüchow and Warpke (between 1548 and 1574), two fairs were held annually in Lüchow, on Oculi and Exaltation of the Holy Cross.

Name: Lucienvorde
Settlement_Description: The village existed since the 9th century (first mentioned between 826 and 876), but was abandoned in the 15th century. The village church, dedicated to St Stephen, remained and was renewed as St Peregrinus in 1596 and demolished in 1829.

Name: Luckau
Settlement_Description: Castle belonging to the Wettins with an attached church settlement existed around 1200, a german market settlement grew close by before 1250, a slavic settlement probably existed beforehand, one of the first documented mentions was in 1276 in a charter of margrave Heinrich
Town_Description: The town was founded before 1250 by Germans under sovereign influence, the civitas is documented in 1297 with Luckau town law adapted from Madgeburg town law
Staple_Description: In 1382 the town received staple privileges for all merchant wares, which principally served to strengthen the control the town exercised over their surroundings

Name: Luckenwalde
Settlement_Description: In the Roman imperial period, Luckenwalde lay at an important trading route between Trebbin and Jütebog. It is hard to distinguish Slavic and German settlement traces, since the Germans seem to have overtaken the Slavic structures. The German castle was first mentioned in 1216 as the centre of a burgwardium. In 1285 the castrum and oppidum of Luckenwalde become property of Zinna monastery and since then have had close connections with the monastery.
Town_Description: In the course of the Middle Ages Luckenwalde is referred to as oppidum and villa several times, sometimes village. In 1430 some town-like privileges are granted. In 1471, a mayor, a council and councilmen are mentioned, as well as a town hall in 1480. However, Luckenwalde was never granted town rights.
Fair_Description: In 1562 two fairs are granted to Luckenwalde, which probably held more regional meaning. Another fair is added in 1678.

Name: Lüdenscheid
Alternative_Name: Luidolvessceith; Luidolfesceide; Liudolvescetha; Ludolfschet; Luolfereskit; Ludolfschede; Ludenscheit
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1067.
Town_Description: Around the middle of the 13th century, the Count von der Mark granted town rights. In 1278 it is listed as an 'oppidum'. In 1517, the town rights were temporarily withdrawn because of the participation in riots.
Toll_Description: The Count of the Mark levied a land toll in 1395. In 1444, 3 denarii per draught horse and 1 denar per pack horse had to be paid. Annual revenues are not known.

Name: Lüdershausen
Settlement_Description: Castle and village, first mentioned in 1262. In the 15th and 16th century mostly pawned to Lüneburg.
Ferry_Description: A ferry across the Neetze is attested in 1352; it was replaced by a bridge in 1618.
Bridge_Description: The ferry was replaced by a bridge across the Neetze in 1618.

Name: Lüdinghausen
Settlement_Description: A church is mentioned around 800. Next to it, there grew the 'Wigbold' Lüdinghausen.
Town_Description: The actual city development took place in 1308. Before that, however, there were some attempts to fortify the settlement, against the will of the bishop, which is why it had to be torn down again. In 1314 the bishop again forced the fortifications to be destroyed, which is why Lüdinghausen is considered a city by name, but has no urban rights.

Name: Lüerdissen
Alternative_Name: Luitheressen; Liutherschen; Liuthhersen; Luderdesse; Ludershem; Luderdessen; Luderdissen; Luerdissen; Lurssen; Lirdessem; Luerdsen; Luerdtsen; Lurdissen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1155.

Name: Lüge
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1315

Name: Luhden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1253.

Name: Luhdorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1158.

Name: Lühe
Settlement_Description: Mentioned around 1400 as Luge.

Name: Lühnde
Alternative_Name: Lulende; Luuele; Liuline; Lulene; Liulinde; Lunene
Settlement_Description: The church of Lühnde was mentioned in 1117.

Name: Lüne
Settlement_Description: The Benedictine nunnery Lüne was founded in 1171 by Hildeswidis von Markboldestorp, under the supervision of the Benedictine monastery of St Michael in Lüneburg. In 1573, the monastery became a Lutheran ladies' foundation ('damenstift').

Name: Lüneburg
Alternative_Name: Hliuni; Luniburc; Lhiuniburg; Luneburg; Liuniburch; Luneborch; Lunenburg
Settlement_Description: A place called Hliuni was first mentioned in 795. In 951 a castle was founded next to the settlement. A monastery of St Michael is attested in Ottonian times before 956, in combination with the local saltworks, which would be the backbone of the local economy for centuries.
Town_Description: Henry the Lion destroyed the neighbouring settlement Bardowick in 1189, after which Lüneburg gained prominence as an important centre of trade and acquired town privileges. Duke Otto the Child confirmed the rights in 1247; from 1273 Lüneburg held the privilege of being the sole salt producer in the duchy.
Staple_Description: According to ducal privileges from 1365, 1367 and 1369 one could only ship grain and wood out of town with permission of the council; the regulation included Winsen, Harburg, Bleckede and other places in the duchy from where grain and wood was shipped. The prescription to use the roads leading through Lüneburg followed in 1392 and was extended to include the drift of cattle in 1467 and 1497. It was compulsory to offer corn, hops, wood, cattle and fish for sale on the local market for 3 days. This compulsion was extended to all commodities in the 16th century. In addition, trading between foreign merchants was prohibited. The town also sought to extend the staple claims to the trade on the Aller and Elbe river systems, with limited success. In the 16th ships on the Elbe were increasingly forced to unload their goods in Bleckede and carry them to market in Lüneburg, which led to a conflict with Hamburg and Magdeburg, and in 1574 the stopping of the traffic on the Elbe was limited to ships carrying boy salt (from the Bay of Biscay) upstream. The staple was limited to the payment of a fee in the 18th century, and finally abolished in 1843.
Fair_Description: Regulations for the cloth trade from the early 14th century show that two fairs were taking place in Lüneburg, on St Michael and on Sunday Jubilate. According to a document from 1360, the St Michael's market attracted visitors from Stade, Hamburg, Braunschweig, Hannover, the Rhineland, Hesse and Holland.

Name: Lünen
Alternative_Name: Liunon; Lunen; Luonen; Luynen; Loynen; Lühnen; Leunen; Luinen
Settlement_Description: A church is mentioned in 1018 around which the settlement grew.
Town_Description: The oldest award of town rights has not survived. However, in 1262 a market, in 1265 the court and council and in 1299 the city seal was mentioned.
Toll_Description: The Count of Dortmund levied a land toll before 1335/41. From 1347, the toll fell to the town of Dortmund. In 1347, 2 denarii per barrel of wine and 1 denar per horse had to be paid. Annual revenues are not known. In 1195, a market toll in Lünen is also mentioned.

Name: Lünzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of the diocese of Verden between 1237 and 1246.

Name: Lürschau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the Heimskringla in the 12th century.

Name: Lüsen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1360. In 1450 the village consisted of 6 farms and a cottage.

Name: Lütau
