Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1230.

Name: Lütjensee
Alternative_Name: Lüttjen See; Luttekense; Parui stagni; Lutthekense; Luttekenzee; Lutkensehe; Lutkensee

Name: Lutter am Barenberge
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1000 as "Lutterun". A castle of the bishop of Hildesheim probably already existed around this time, which was often-contested throughout the centuries between the bishop of Hildesheim and the duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg. It was finally acquired by the latter in 1523, who made it an administrative seat; the settlement became a borough ('flecken').

Name: Lutterberg
Alternative_Name: Lutzelberg; Lutzelnberge; Luttelenberg; Luttzelnberge; Luczelnberge; Lutzelnberga; Lutternberge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1297.

Name: Lützen
Settlement_Description: Originally Wendish settlement, which developed into a market borough ('Marktflecken') alongside the construction of a German castle in the 13th century. It is unclear when the village gained town rights.
Toll_Description: Regulations of safe conduct remain from the begining of the 16th century (LHASA, MD, U 10 XXIII Nr. 1, Zoll- und Geleitssachen. Geleitsordnung des Amtes Lützen).

Name: Lützschena
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1278.

Name: Lychen
Settlement_Description: A german castle settlement, a bigger slavic settlement has been destroyed before
Town_Description: The margrave Johann I granted the brother Daniel and Eberhard von Parwenitz the right to found a civitas in 1248

Name: Ełk
Alternative_Name: Lyck; Zur Likke; Lik; Lyk; Lück; Ligkau; Liccensis
Settlement_Description: The village was founded in 1425 by the Teutonic Order close to its castle

Name: Maarheeze
Alternative_Name: Marresia; Marnehese; Marnhese, Marnheeze; Marreyse; Malreheze; Marnheze; Marreys; Maerheze; Moerheeze; Maarhees; Maarheese
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1223, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Maarssen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 918-948, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1127.

Name: Maaseik
Alternative_Name: Maseyck; Eche; Eike; Ekensis; Ecke; Maaseyck
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1034.

Name: Maashees
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1521.

Name: Maasland
Alternative_Name: Masalandæ; Maseland; Masalant; Maslant; Maesland; Maeslant
Settlement_Description: Ealiest mention in 918-948, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1083, in a falsification from circa 1125.

Name: Maassluis
Alternative_Name: Mafelandersluse; Maselandersluys; Maeslandersluys; Maeslantse Sluys; Maaslandsluis; Sluis; Maassluisae
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Maassluis is first mentioned in 1367. Cox states that the first mention dates from 1573. Maassluis is elevated to town rank on 26 August 1814 by William I, king of the Netherlands.

Name: Maastricht
Alternative_Name: Traiecto; Treiectinsem urbem; Trecto; Triecto; Treiecta; Masetrieth; Masetreht; Masetrith; Traecto superiori; Traiectum superius ad Mosam; stat van Trijcht; Tricht; Trajectensem
Settlement_Description: Maastricht originated as a Roman settlement in 50 C.E. It was located on the road between Cologne and Tongeren. In the third century, Maastricht was a religious centre (as the episcopal see was moved to Maastricht, untill the eighth century). In written records, Maastricht is first mentioned in 535 (ninth-century copy). It became a trade centre in the ninth century, and in the twelfth century it developed into an important trade town.
Town_Description: In the twelfth century, Maastricht developed into an important trade town. Most likely, town rights were granted before 12 November 1204. Untill 1794, Maastricht is the condominium of the dukes of Brabant and the Prince-Bishops of Liège.

Name: Machelen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1179, in a copy form the middle of the fourteenth century. Next mention in 1125.

Name: Mackendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1150.

Name: Mackenrode
Settlement_Description: First mention in 973.

Name: Mackensen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Magdeborn
Settlement_Description:
First mention in a gift certificate by king Otto I. to the archbishopric of Merseburg as castle ('Kastell') Magdeborn.
In 1980 Magdeborn had to be deserted due to a brown coal opencast mine, after the end of operations the remains are filled with water and form the current Störmthaler lake.

Name: Magdeburg
Alternative_Name: Meideborg; Magadoburg; Megdeburch; Magdeborch; Maidburg; Megdeborch; Meyborch
Settlement_Description: Mention of a castle built by Charlemagne in 805 in the Diedenhofer Kapitular (MGH LLI 133, §7). Earlier a trading point with Slavs east of the Elbe.
Town_Description: 1188 first secure record of the Magdeburg law, which will spread to several towns. First clues to citizens. In 1295 it joins the Hanse.
Toll_Description: In 1208 Otto IV. relinquishes his right to the payment of tolls and coins in favor of the archbishop. New tolls were not to be collected without the confirmation of the archbishops. In 1309 and 1324 the archbishop relinquishes some tolls, like the wine and bridge toll. In the Hertel record book of the town of Magdeburg several tolls in the course of the Elbe river are also mentioned within the oldest fief records of the town of Magdeburg. In 1463 a settlement deal between the archbishop Frederick and Magdeburg rules that the council may collect part of the toll for the maintenance of the roads and bridges. A regulation of safe conduct remains from 1519, as well as a report on the practice of the regulations of safe conduct from 1571.
Staple_Description:
Exclusive shipping rights on grain ('Kornverschiffungsrecht') for the archbishopric of Magdeburg are granted in 1309, which leads to decade-long conflicts with the archbishop. A contract from 1463 confirms Magdeburg town rights as well as free shipping rights on grain for the prelate, the clergy and knights, which was confirmed again in 1497.
In the 16th century, the staple right was threatened by Leipzig, since Magdeburg lay in its zone of influence. This led to a contract with Hamburg concerning the protection of the staple rights of both towns in 1538. During the imperial ban 1547-1567 the staple in Magdeburg was revoked, but later re-established as a three-day depot right and mandatory turnover. In 1571 this is changed into a depot fee. Starting from 1596 it was handled as a depot and turnover right again. The destruction of the town during the 30-year war (1631) meant an end to the staple, but soon thereafter there were several attempts to re-establish it. Shipping rights on grain were confirmed in 1638. The town worked a long time to preserve the privileges, until the staple was revoked with the files on shipping on the Elbe ('Elbschiffahrtsakte') in 1821.

Name: Mahlerten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1132 and 1141.
Toll_Description: A toll in Mahlerten is first mentioned in 1371. Hildesheim complained in 1459, that a toll was levied on wagon cargoes, which had not been levied before.

Name: Mahlsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1345, it housed two knightly manors.

Name: Mahlsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1247.

Name: Mahndorf (Bremen)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1339.

Name: Mahndorf (Halberstadt)
Settlement_Description: Difference between Beffen-Mandorp and Biscopa-Mandorp in 1084.
Toll_Description: Mention of a toll station in Mahndorf district, which was supposedly situated at the route Derenburg - Halberstadt. In 1657 the station is intended to be moved to Brockenstädt mill.

Name: Mainz
Alternative_Name: Mogontiacum; Mogontia; Magancia; Maginza; Megenze; Meynce; Meintz; Meintze
Settlement_Description: By the end of the 1st century BC, Mainz was already serving as a Roman camp. First written evidence from 44 AD as 'Mogontiacum'.
Town_Description: Mainz was first referred to as a 'civitas' in 297 AD. In late Roman times, Mainz was the capital of a Roman province and served as a royal court under the Frankish rule. From 1244 to 1462 Mainz was a free imperial town.
Staple_Description: Beginnings are unclear; first documentary mention of a staple comes from the 1470s, including obligation to exchange and offer wares for sale; recognised by the emperor in 1486 and official confirmed in 1495. A tightening of the staple in 1534 led to conflict with the Count Palatine from 1542. During the Thirty Years’ War the staple was suspended, but was back in force by 1641 at the latest. The staple was dissolved in 1831 with the Rhine Shipping Act.

Name: Mainzholzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1380.

Name: Mal
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1111.

Name: Malburgen
Alternative_Name: Malberge; Maltberge; Maldberge; Malburghen; Malburgen; Malburg; Malburchen
Settlement_Description: The hamlet was first mentioned in 1118, in a possibly falsified copy from the 13th century.

Name: Malchin
Settlement_Description: Grew next to a village of the same name
Town_Description: mentioned as civitas in 1236, granted Schwerin town law, intended as a fortress against Pommern

Name: Malchow
Settlement_Description: An important military fortress in wendish time because of the convenient location, it was destroyed in 1147, then occupied by the Germans but reoccupied by the Wendish in 1164, and later that year taken over by Heinrich dem Löwen (the Lion)
Town_Description: Granted Schwerin town law in 1235, later Güstrow town law

Name: Maldegem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 930, in a copy from the middle of the eleventh century.

Name: Malden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1247.

Name: Mansfeld
Settlement_Description: Estate given to the archbishopric of Magdeburg by Fulda monastery (MGH OII no. 64, S. 74-77). This record probably refers to Klostermansfeld, which held most of the surrounding estates.
Town_Description: Mentioned as "vallis Mansfeld" in the Halberstädter Archdiakonalsmatrikel from 1400. In 1408 it is known to have been surrounded by walls. It must have owned town and market rights before that though.
Fair_Description: The counts of Mansfeld bestow a cattle- and two annual fairs upon the city.

Name: Marbach
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1216.

Name: Marburg
Settlement_Description: In 1138 the knight Ludwig de Marburg is mentioned first. The mention of a Marburg mint in 1194 presupposes that a market settlement must have existed beforehand.
Town_Description: Orders under city law by Bishop Ludwig von Münster have been documented since 1311.

Name: Mariakerke
Alternative_Name: Meron; Meran; Meren; Meeren; Meerekerke; Mariekerke; Sente Marien kercke in Meeren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in ninth century in a copy dating from 941. Next mention in 964. Next mention in 1122.

Name: Mariaweiler
Toll_Description: The Duke of Jülich levied land toll in 1571. A first mention around 1431 could be refuted. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Marienau
Alternative_Name: Ouhagen; Auhagen; Marienow; Mariaenaw; Merienowe; Marienauwe
Settlement_Description: The gamekeeper's settlement Ouhagen came into existence in the 13th century; its pilgrimage chapel acquired an indulgence in 1298. In 1310, the Carmelite monastery Marienau was founded here; abolished in 1565.

Name: Marienberg
Alternative_Name: Marien Bergk; neue Bergstadt zue Schletten

Name: Malbork
Settlement_Description: The Teutonic Order started building a castle in 1274
Town_Description: The town close to the castle was given a handfest with Kulm town law in 1276 by Conrad von Tyrbech, a second handfast followed in 1304

Name: Alūksne
Settlement_Description: The castle was built by Burkhard von Dreyleben on an island. A settlement developed soon afterwards and was referred to as a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') in 1516/34.

Name: Marienburg
Settlement_Description: A castle was constructed by the bishop of Hildesheim in 1346-1349.
Toll_Description: The bishop of Hildesheim started levying a wine toll in Marienburg around 1439.

Name: Mariendal
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1416-1417.

Name: Marienfelde
Settlement_Description: In 1375 the settlement can be found in the property of the Knights of St. John of Jerusalem, before had been in the property of the Order of the Temple. The area had been settled in the Bronze age and by Germanic peoples but remained unsettled during Slavic times. In 1435 it was given to Berlin-Cölln together with Tempelhof.

Name: Marienhafe
Settlement_Description: Marienhafe is mentioned in the law of the region Brokmerland from 1300 as 'wic', which characterised a settlement with special legal protection during market times. The church was built in the 13th century. The village had access to the sea from 1362 at the latest, although the bay silted up again later.

Name: Kwidzyn
Alternative_Name: Marienwerder; St. Mariae insula; Marjenwerder; Kwidzin; Quedune; Quidin
Town_Description: The Landmeister of the Teutonic Order Hermann Balke founded the town Marienwerder in 1233 with Kulm town law. The privileges were renewed in 1336 and 1505.

Name: Marienwohlde
Alternative_Name: Marienwolde; Marienwalde; Marienwold; Petzke; Pezeke; Petzeke
Settlement_Description: Originally called Pezeke, the Bridgettine monastery Marienwohlde was founded here in 1413, after which the settlement became known after the monastery. The nuns resided in Lübeck since 1534, the monastic properties were secularised by the duke of Saxony-Lauenburg in 1558.

Name: Märkisch Buchholz
Settlement_Description: The settlement used to be a small village next to a castle that is mentioned several times in the 14th century since 1301. The village claims to have earned town rights in 1579 but only has earned market rights and smaller town-like privileges in truth and is always referred to as little town ("Städtchen").
Town_Description: Mentioned as a town in 1449, called 'Stedlein' in 1518 and 'Flecklein' in 1554, probably remained a hamlet until the modern era
Toll_Description: In 1449 and 1494 a toll and safe conduct are mentioned in Märkisch Buchholz. The lords ('Schenken') of Landsberg, who resided on castle Teupitz, owned the land toll in Teupitz, as well as the bridge- and dam tolls in Königs-Wusterhagen and Wendisch-Buchholz.

Name: Mirosławiec
Alternative_Name: Märkisch Friedland; Nova Vredeland; Nuwe-Vredeland; Nigen-Vredeland; Vredeland; Fredlandeck; Freyland
Town_Description: A settlement before the founding of the town is not known. The brandenburg town law was most likely granted in 1303. Further privileges were granted to the civitas in 1314 by the brothers Heinrich and Johann von Wedel. These were endorsed in 1565.

Name: Markkleeberg
Settlement_Description: First mention as manor, since 1515 mention as knightly manor.

Name: Markoldendorf
Alternative_Name: Forensi Aldendorp; Forensi Oldenthorp; Margtoldendorp; Oldendorp; Market Oldendorpe; Marketaldindorpe; Markoldendorpe; Marketoldendorp; Marck Oldendorpp; Marckoldendorff; Marckoldendorf; Marckaltendorf
Settlement_Description: Near the settlement Oldendorf, of which the church is first mentioned in 1142, a market settlement was founded on the opposite shore of the Ilme river in the 13th century, which was called Markoldendorf. The regional court was moved before 1395 to the new settlement, where the courts took place until the late 16th century. Markoldendorf was made into a borough ('flecken') and fortified in 1637.

Name: Markranstädt
Settlement_Description: The village was founded near the Medieval settlement of "Altranstädt" in 1170/80.
Town_Description: In a bill of sale Markranstädt is first mentioned as little town "Städtchen".
Fair_Description: The former famous wool market in Markranstädt developed from the nearby sheep husbandry of Alt-Zelle monastery.

Name: Markröhlitz
Toll_Description: Station of safe conduct in the vicinity of Naumburg. Twin safe conduct ('Doppelgeleit') of Freyburg.

Name: Marksuhl
Settlement_Description: This borough ('Marktflecken') probably already belonged to the property of Fulda monastery before 900. It belonged to castle Altenstein, later to the district of Creuzburg. Duke Johann Ernst had a castle constructed here 1587-91.
Toll_Description: The secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Eisenach in Marksuhl was only established in 1508/1509, after a new road from Westfalia and Hessia to Frankia was built and used. The regulations of safe conduct ('Geleitsordnung') of 1535 list the fees for several wares. (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Bb 1244, Geleitsrechnung Eisenach 1553/54, p. 110.)

Name: Marl
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 900.

Name: Marlishausen
Settlement_Description: First mention in the record book of Fulda monastery in the second half of the 8th centruy.
Toll_Description: A toll regulation from 1635 remains (ThStA Rudolstadt, Kanzlei Arnstadt 1134, p. 25.).

Name: Marsum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1344.

Name: Martenshoek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1652, in a copy dating from 1768.

Name: Martinhagen
Alternative_Name: Meribodonhago; Meribodehago; Merlodenhagen; Merbodenhayn; Merbenhain; Mormelnhagen; Merdenhagen; Merdehagen; Mertenhagen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1081.

Name: Marzahna
Toll_Description:
Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleit') of Wittenberg. Regulations of safe conduct remain from 1513.
Secondary station of safe conduct of Berzig.

Name: Masbrock
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1296.

Name: Maszewo
Alternative_Name: Massow; Massowe; Mosowe; Massou; Massouwe; Matzo; Matzow
Settlement_Description: A castle hamlet with a church was mentioned in 1233. A slavic castle mound vanished before 1334. After the house of Massow have up their ancestral seat, german settlers took over the area.
Town_Description: It was already mentioned as oppidum in 1274. The new settlement was granted Magdeburg town law in 1278 by bishop Duke Hermann von Gleichen of Kammin. In 1286 Lübeck town law was granted. It has been mentioned as civitas since 1289. The privileges were endorsed in 1501 by Duke Bogislaw X.

Name: Maua
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1259.
Ferry_Description: Maua's sigil shows a ferryman, which leads to think that there used to be a ferry at this Saale ford.

Name: Maxdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1283.

Name: Mechelen
Alternative_Name: Machlines; Mechele; Machele; Machlina; Machlinenses; Mechlinia; Machlinia; Mechlene; Malines; Maghelen; Mecheln
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1131.
Staple_Description: In 1369 the Antwerp staple for fish, salt and oats was moved to Mechelen. In 1415 the staple returned to Antwerp; in compensation, Mechelen received right to hold two yearly markets.
Fair_Description: Market for fish, salt and oats, in competition with Antwerp. In 1415 emperor Sigismund gave Mechelen the privilege of holding two yearly markets in compensation for the moving of the staple to Antwerp.

Name: Mechterstädt
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Breviarium Sancti Lullii, Tab. I.

Name: Mecklenbeck
Alternative_Name: Mikelencbeke; Mykilincbike; Mikelenbeke; Mekelenbeke; Mekellenbeke; Meckelenbeck

Name: Medebach
Alternative_Name: Medebeke; Madebach; Medebyke; Medebike; Methebeke; Mekebach; Medebeka; Madebach; Meydebeke; Medebicke
Settlement_Description: Before 1144, free 'Tafelgut' of the Archbishop of Cologne. Who also made the settlement an 'oppidum' in 1144.

Name: Medingen
Alternative_Name: Zellensen; Tzelenhußen; Tzelnhußen; Medingh; Tzellensen; Tzelnsen; Cellenhusen; Medinghe; Czellensen; Novo Medinghe
Settlement_Description: The settlement was originally called Zellensen, first mentioned in 1252. After the Cistercian nun convent Medingen moved here from Altenmedingen in 1336, the settlement took over the name of the monastery. Possessions were lands primarily located near Altmedingen, as well as parts of the Lüneburg saltworks. In 1554 the monastery became a Protestant ladies' foundation.

Name: Meerane
Settlement_Description: Castle and castle village of the 12th century. In the 15th century market.
Town_Description: The village was referred to as oppidum in 1361. In 1565 Georg of Schönburg granted the town bylaws.

Name: Meerlo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1134, in a falsification from circa 1180-1190. Next mention in 1213.

Name: Meerssen
Alternative_Name: Marsna; Marsanam; Mersenam; de Mersene; Marsenen; Smarnam; Mersen; Mersem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention 847, in a ninth century copy. Next mention in 908, in a tenth century copy. Next mention in 1119.

Name: Mehle
Alternative_Name: Medeli; Medelon; Midilithe; Midele; Middelen; Medele; Mehlde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 965.

Name: Mehlem
Toll_Description: The Archbishop of Cologne levied a land toll around 1385. Tariffs are not known. From 1471 to 1472, 7½ mark and 4 shillings were collected. Mehlem was a secondary toll station of Königsdorf in 1455.

Name: Pieniężno
Settlement_Description: The Old Prussians held an older fortress and an adjoining village, a german settlement existed close by in 1282
Town_Description: The German settlement was turned into a town in 1295 by the locator Dietrich von Lichtenfeld, a town parson is mentioned in 1304, the final founding documents of the civitas with Kulm town law were given in 1312 by the territorial sovereignty, the Warmian diocesan chapter

Name: Meijel
Alternative_Name: Meyele; Meyel; Meydel; Meijel; Meille; Myl
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1303, the settlement Meijel developed around a road through the Peel high moor region and grew into a semi-independent lordship ('vrijheerlijkheid'). The original settlement, known as Luttel Meijel and later Hof, was located near a well of St Willibrord on the border with Deurne. More southerly, a parish church was built around 1425. There were one or more inns in the village.
Toll_Description: A toll of the lord of Meijel on the border between Deurne and Meijel was first mentioned as "Kijeboem" in 1483. The toll station was located a bow shot away from the well of St Willibrord in the area known as Luttel Meijel.

Name: Meimbressen
Alternative_Name: Meinbrahteshus(en); Meinbratessen; Meinbressen; Meynbrechtsen; Mmeymereßin; Meinbressen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 900.

Name: Bad Meinberg
Alternative_Name: Meinberg; Meynburghun; Meginbergen; Menberche; Meghenberg; Meinbarch; Meggenberge; Meimbergh
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 980 and 982.

Name: Meinbrexen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1222.

Name: Meine
Alternative_Name: Meynum; Mainum; Meinnem; Mejnjm; Meynem; Meynum; Meynen; Moynem; Meinem; Meinen; Meinenn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1007.

Name: Meineringhausen
Alternative_Name: Menerinchusen; Meinerinchusen; Meinrinchusen; Menrichofen; meynrinchusz; Meynrichosen; Mannerinckusen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1240.

Name: Meinerzhagen
Toll_Description: The Count of Mark levied a land toll in 1444. The toll was established on the model of the toll in Lüdenscheid. The tariff was therefore also 3 denarii per draught horse and 1 denar per pack horse.

Name: Meiningen
Settlement_Description: In the 11th century, Meiningen was royal property and royal court with a water castle.
Town_Description: Around 1200 the systematic expansion of the town began. In 1230 referred to as civitas. In 1344 awarding of Schweinfurt town rights.
Toll_Description: Bridge toll, which was taken, among others, from pilgrims to the "miracle of Grimmenthal" ('Wunder von Grimmenthal'). The toll helped finance stone bridges at the end of the Middle Ages.
Fair_Description: After their foundation the fairs were confirmed in 1565 by the counts of Henneberg and in 1612 by prince electorate Johann Georg of Saxony. By the same prince electorate two cattle and one horse market were established. While the cattle markets soon closed down, the horse market is still held today (see below). In 1662 it was decreed that all markets were to be held on the Tuesdays after the respective holidays. In 1676 another fair, the Christ fair, was granted.
Bridge_Description: At the latest an the end of the 11th century, a bridge spanned the Werra at Meiningen.

Name: Meinkot
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1145.

Name: Meißen
Alternative_Name: Misni; Missene; Missina; Meissen; Missne; Misna
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Meißen is first mentioned in 983. In the regulations of safe conduct of 1547 the fees on the water, by land and for cattle are settled (SHStA Dresden, Loc. 37997 Meißen 9f., Erbbuch des Amtes Meißen 1547, p. 338–339).

Name: Meitze
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330.

Name: Melbeck
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1296.

Name: Meldorf
Alternative_Name: Melindorp; Milinthorp; Milethorp; Melethorp; Melenthorp; Milethorp; Melthorpe; Meldorp; Meldorpe; Meldorppe; Meldorff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned by Adam of Bremen in the late 11th century as location of the mother church of Dithmarschen in ca. 814-824.
Town_Description: Town privileges probably granted by the archbishop of Bremen between 1227 and 1259; in 1265 the settlement is first characterised as town. Town privileges were repealed in 1559 after the conquest of Dithmarschen.

Name: Melle (Gent)
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 830, in a tenth century copy. Next mention end of the ninth century, in a copy dating from 941. Next mention in 964. Next mention in 1118 as 'Melle'.

Name: Melle (Osnabrück)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1169 and characterised as "oppidum" in 1350. Melle received borough ('wigbold') privileges in 1443.
Toll_Description: A toll is mentioned in the borough privileges of 1443; it is still mentioned in the 1570s.
Fair_Description: The borough ('wigbold') privileges of 1443 also contained a market privilege. A fair is explicitly mentioned in 1580. A date is not known.

Name: Mellendorf
Alternative_Name: Milinghethorp; Milingedorp; Mellinghedorpe; Melinghedorpe; Melinghdorpe; Mellingdorpe; Mellingedorpe; Melgendorf; Melligendorpe; Mellingdorp; Melliendorff; Melendorp; Mellingdorppe; Mellingendorpe; Mellingdorff
Settlement_Description: Year of first mention was 1187.

Name: Mellin
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1360; in 1375 it already is deserted, but the village is mentioned again in 1521.

Name: Mellingen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1137.

Name: Melsbroek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1123.

Lock_Description: One of seven locks in the Fulda river between Kassel and Hersfeld, which were built by landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel in a campaign to make the Fulda navigable. Regulations from 1613 specify the lock fee at 2 Alben. At each lock, it was checked whether the toll for the cargo had been paid in Kassel.

Name: Melverode
Alternative_Name: Meinoluesrode; Meinolueroht; Melveroth; Meinnolveroth; Meynelvyngerod; Melverode; Melmerode
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1007.

Name: Melzingen
Alternative_Name: Meltzinge; Meletsinge; Meltsinche; Meltinghe; Meltsinche; Meltzinghen; Melcinge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1253.

Name: Klaipėda
Staple_Description: Memel began to oblige merchants from Königsberg to staple their wares in the city from 1522. Princely mandate in 1580 forbade any exports by see; repeated in 1619 and 1622.

Name: Mengebostel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1337.

Name: Mengeringhausen
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 1234 as a 'villa', in 1239 and 1299 as an 'oppidum'. A castle was built around 1300, but it was not mentioned until 1388.
Town_Description: In 1301 the old town received town privileges, the new town in 1392. In 1500 a new privilege was granted again for both of them and in 1587 it was confirmed.

Name: Menz
Settlement_Description: In the 13th century a castle and a village were founded as a border protection.

Name: Meppel
Alternative_Name: Meppele; Mappele; Mepplo; Meppelen; Meppell; Meppelo
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1141 (in a early fifteenth-century copy, possibly a falsification). Meppel was granted city rank at 15 March 1809 by Louis Napoléon Bonaparte, king of Holland.

Name: Meppen
Settlement_Description: Missionary centre for the Emsland, in possession of the monastery Corvey in 834. It was, however, probably founded before 793. The settlement acquired toll and mint privileges in 945, and market rights in 946.
Town_Description: Fortification privileges granted by the bishop of Münster in 1360, extended in 1374. In 1387 the settlement acquired the right to have a court as well.
Fair_Description: From the early 14th century, fairs are mentioned in Meppen, for which Osnabrück merchants received safe conduct. The only consistent fair was that of St Michael, which according to a list of 1440 drew visitors mainly from Frisian territory. In 1497, the main fair is mentioned to be held at St Simon and Jude, and two additional cattle markets are added. After their importance had declined, the latter were re-founded in 1578.

Name: Merchtem
Alternative_Name: Martinas; Martines; Mercten; Marechtinis; Merchtinis; Merchten; Merchtene
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1040, in a copy dating from middle of the eleventh century. Next mention in 1117.

Name: Merheim
Toll_Description: In 1389, the Archbishop of Cologne levied a fee for safe conduct on land and a land toll. Depending on the load, 2 to 3 alb. fee for safe conduct per horse had to be paid. In 1389/93, the annual yield averaged about 250 mark a year. In 1454 up to 8 alb. per horse had to be paid as land toll. Together with the toll in Lövenich, about 200 guilders could thus be collected. In 1455 Merheim was a secondary toll station of Königsdorf.

Name: Märjamaa
Settlement_Description: The parish of Merjama probably already existed at the end of the 13th century.

Name: Meriküla
Settlement_Description: Around 1527 a hamlet ('Hof') was built near the village of Koerawerre, which was referred to as 'Merreküll' in 1533.

Name: Merschwitz
Bridge_Description: According to wagoners, the Elbe was crossed here via ferry.

Name: Merseburg
Settlement_Description: First mention of the settlement in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis (HZV A 212, HZV B 243). In the 10th cenutry, Merseburg becomes royal court and in 968 episcopal seat.
Town_Description: The royal privilige of market, coin and toll had to be granted before 981 and was confirmed in 1004. First mention of a council and burghers in 1289. Several privileges and registers are destroyed in a town fire in 1444, the "jurisdiction and freedom" of the town are restored in the same year. A more independent town constitution is achieved only after 1435, since the town was very dependent on the bishops.
Toll_Description: The safe conduct in Merseburg also had special regulations during the time of the fairs in Leipzig; during this time, every passerby had to pay a fee until the fair ended, after that, the regular fees only had to be paid once if one returned in the course of four days.
Fair_Description: A fair took place until 1323, when a fire destroyed several booths on the market and foreign traders stayed away. It was not re-established, due to the growing influence of the fairs in Leipzig.

Name: Merksem
Alternative_Name: Marcsam; Marcsem; Marshem; Merxeem; Mercsem; Merxem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1189.

Name: Merxhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1268.

Name: Merxleben
Settlement_Description: Mention in the record book of Fulda monastery.

Name: Merzen
Alternative_Name: Marsunnon; Mersene; Mersnen; Mernen; Mersenen; Kerckmerssen; Merßen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a document in 977. The settlement was possibly founded in Frankish times.

Name: Meschede
Alternative_Name: Mescedi; Meskide; Messcede; Mescide; Messcethi; Miskidi; Meskethe; Meschethe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 913 and called 'Dorp' in 1368.
Town_Description: In 1457 the place received freedom and restricted rights, but was probably not yet a city. Arnsberger law and privileges were confirmed in 1508.

Name: Międzyrzecz
Settlement_Description: One of the oldest areas of Posen, there used to be fights over the fortress with slavic settlement between Poland, Brandenburg and Silesia, an abbey was mentioned in 1005, but the cloister has most likely already been founded in 997, a church of St. Adalbert is mentioned in the mid-13th ct., possibly the relics of the cloister, Pomerania lost the castle in 1094
Town_Description: Mentioned as civitas in 1259, Magdeburg town law, the oldest town privilege was signed by the polish king Kasimir IV. in 1485

Name: Meßdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in a name in 1215; first mention of the village in 1281.

Name: Mesum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1155 and 1159.

Name: Meußließen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1296-1297. In 1450, the settlement consisted of 3 farms, 1 half farm and a cottage.

Name: Mäo
Settlement_Description: The hamlet ('Hof') of the Teutonic Order was mentioned in 1558.

Name: Meyenburg
Settlement_Description: The town is soon degraded to borough ('Flecken').
Town_Description: The town as founded intentionally around 1300, but soon lost its independence as town.

Name: Middelaar
Alternative_Name: Middelar; Middelaer; Middelair; Middeler; Midler; Middaler; Myddeler; Middellaerl Midlar
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1327.

Name: Midlum (Harlingen)
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in thirteenth century.

Name: Mildstedt
Alternative_Name: Mildtsted; Mildesect; Myldestet; Mildeset; Mylstede; Milstede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1304.

Name: Millen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1287.

Name: Miltenberg
Settlement_Description: The area was settled much earlier. However, the place was mentioned for the first time only in 1225. In the 13th century the place grew into a town.
Staple_Description: Emperor Charles IV supposedly gave the town staple privileges, but the record has been lost. Nuremberg needed to carry their goods to Miltenburg by land and there load them into ships. As the Nurembergers sometimes shipped their wares to Bamberg and Würzburg under fake marks, an agreement was reached between the Archbishop of Mainz and the city of Nuremberg, and in 1521 ships from Bamberg were held and unloaded in Miltenberg. In 1539 the staple was disestablished in return for Nuremberg credit, but was installed again in 1547. Emperor Charles V stipulated in a law of 1555 that the staple should be disestablished. In 1562 the agreement reached stipulated that Nurembergs could enjoy free shipping rights in return for a yearly payment of 200 golden gulden. The Nurembergers were only to load their goods in Bamberg, but from 1685 they could also do the same in Kitzingen and Würzburg. An ordinance of 1818 ended the market and exchange rights for Miltenberg.

Name: Minden
Alternative_Name: Mimda; Minda; Mimidona; Mindyn; Mimthum; Munthiun; Mimida; Mindonensis; Mimidomensis; Mindun; Mindunensis; Minde; Mundioborg; Mindon; Mynden
Settlement_Description: Fishing and shipping settlement near a ford on the Weser river, where a bishopric was founded by Charlemagne around 800. The settlement acquired toll, market and minting privileges in 977.
Town_Description: Minden developed into a town around 1230, with Dortmund town privileges. It is unknown on which date these privileges were exactly granted.
Toll_Description: Toll privileges were granted in 977; in 1155-1206 the toll is still mentioned, among others in a conflict about tolls with Hameln. Possibly, the toll was levied since the 13th century at the harbour (Schlagde), until it was moved to Petershagen in 1377.
Staple_Description: Staple for corn and timber. Already around 1200, citizens from Hameln were exempted from toll, if they ended their journey in Minden. Skippers on the Werre were obliged in 1457 to offer their commodities on the market in Minden. In 1530, the free transport of firewood was prohibited. In Bremen, complaints that shipments of corn were being withheld in Minden are known from 1532, which led to a centuries-long conflict between both towns. The staple privileges were confirmed by the emperor in 1627, although it was enforced relatively mildly in the 17th century. The staple was finally abolished with the "Weserschifffahrtsakte" of 1823.
Fair_Description: In the 15th century, three fairs are mentioned in Minden: on the Nativity of the Virgin and St Gorgonius, on St Martin and on Candlemas. Of these fairs, at least the fair of St Martin can probably be traced back to the market and toll privilege of 977. In 1528, the number of fairs was reduced to two. Next to the fair of St Martin, a new fair was held on St Walburga. These fairs still exist today as the Autumn and May fairs.

Name: Mingerode
Alternative_Name: Munningeroth; Mundingerod; Muningerode; Minighgerode; Mynnigerode; Müngeroda
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1184 and 1203.

Name: Mirow
Settlement_Description: Commandry of the Knights of St. John built in 1226, residency of the Duke Karl von Mecklenburg since 1587

Name: Jelgava
Settlement_Description: In 1265 a castle was built by the Teutonic Order.
Town_Description: A fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was mentioned in 1345. Town rights by Riga were granted in 1578.

Name: Mittelhausen
Settlement_Description: Mentions in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis and the Breviarium sacnti Lulli from the 9th century. Important, transregional juridical court until 1346.

Name: Mitteldorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1334.

Name: Mittenwalde
Settlement_Description: Ascanian castle, likely built on a wendish castle mound, first mentioned in 1238, a market settlement grew close by, named as a parish and the see of an archdeaconry in 1255, a wendish settlement vanished early
Town_Description: No mention of an official founding, probably some time after 1240. Mentioned as civitas and stad in 1307. Magdeburg town rights can be assumed indirectly in 1430.
Toll_Description: In 1495 a wagoner is accused of circumventing the toll in Mittenwalde. The toll therefore existed before that. Further mention in 1653.
Fair_Description: In the 15th and 16th century, three fairs and cattle markets are known in Mittenwalde.

Name: Mockau
Settlement_Description: First mention as Moccouwe (PL) in 1286.

Name: Möckern
Alternative_Name: Mocranici; Mokrianici; Mocornic; Mocorne; Mokerne; Mokern
Settlement_Description: First mention among those properties whose tithe was owed to St. Moritz' monastery in Magdeburg when the bishopric of Brandenburg was founded. Castle and castle district of the 10th cenutry, near which a rural village delevoped.
Town_Description: If and when town rights were granted is unknown. Since 1375 referred to as town. Temporarily it had a certain independence, even though it was never independent from a liege lord. In the Middle Ages there were town-like structures.

Name: Möckern
Settlement_Description: First mention as Mokeren in 1335.

Name: Madona
Settlement_Description: The manor was mentioned in 1461 as a fief.

Name: Mödrath
Toll_Description: 1) From 1389 onwards, a fee for safe conduct and a land toll were levied here. In 1389 and 1401, the Archbishop of Cologne is documented as the owner of the toll. However, the exact ownership situation is unclear. From 1470 the toll fell to the Duke of Brabant. In 1396, 2 to 3 alb. per horse had to be paid, depending on the load. The annual yield in 1389/93 averaged about 442 mark a year. In 1470/71 about 39 guilders could be collected per year, in 1498/99 about 53 guilders. 2) The Duke of Brabant also levied a road toll in 1470. Tariffs are not known. In 1470, 1 gulden 7 alb. were collected. These were used for work on the bridge over the Erft.

Name: Moerbeke
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1190.

Name: Moordrecht
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1250.

Name: Moerkapelle
Alternative_Name: Cappelle staende in de Wilderveenen onder Sevenhuysen; Moer; De Moerse Kapel; Moerkape; Moer Capel; Moercapelle-en-de-Wildeveenen; Moercapelle
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1570.

Name: Moers
Toll_Description: The Count of Moers levied a land toll here before 1317, which was, however, referred to as road toll. Rates and revenues are not known.

Name: Moryń
Settlement_Description: First mentione in 1263, a church village existed in 1265, a german castle was built into the protohistoric mound in the first half of the 13th ct., newly built in 1365 by Margrave Otto, but already in ruins in 1399
Town_Description: Based on the eagle in the crest, the town was founded by the lords of the land with german town law, mentioned in 1306 and 1360 as civitas, it was supposed to be made into a village before 1433, but the town refused

Name: Morąg
Settlement_Description: A house of the Teutonic Order was founded in 1280
Town_Description: The town was founded by the komtur of Elbing, Hermann von Öttingen, between 1320 and 1331 with Kulm town law, the founding documents were renewed in 1331 when the new municipal administrator (Erbschulz) was settled

Name: Mõigu
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1241.

Name: Mol
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1173.

Name: Molkwerum
Alternative_Name: Molkwar; Molkenhuzen; Molkenweer; Molkweer; Molcquerum; Molquerren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1398.

Name: Möllenbeck (Altmark)
Settlement_Description: First secure mention in 1238; an earlier mention in 1209 cannot be confirmed.

Name: Möllenkotten
Toll_Description: The Count of the Mark levied a land toll here in 1466. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Mölln
Alternative_Name: Möllen; Molne; Moelne; Mulne; Mølne; Mollen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1188. Mölln developed as a transshipment place on the salt route between Lüneburg and Lübeck. Originally, the settlement was located at the current street Ohlendörp. A planned town was built around the current church from ca. 1200.
Town_Description: Lübeck town privileges granted by king Valdemar II of Denmark in 1202. The town was under the jurisdiction of Lübeck between 1359 and 1683.
Toll_Description: A toll of the counts of Lauenburg was first mentioned between 1220 and 1226. During the time the town was pawned to Lübeck (1359-1683), so was the toll. The toll was especially levied on herring exported from Lübeck.

Name: Mannare
Settlement_Description: Around 1500 there was a small estate called 'Mannafer'.

Name: Mönchengladbach
Toll_Description: 1) Before 1304, a land toll and a fee for safe conduct were still levied here. In 1304, the Count of Kessel is mentioned as the owner. In 1389 the toll fell to the Duke of Jülich. In 1389/93, 2 to 3 alb. per horse had to be paid, depending on the load. In the years 1389/93, an average of 105 mark per year could be collected. 2) The Duke of Jülich levied a road toll even before 1387. Rates and revenues are not known.

Name: Monheim am Rhein
Toll_Description: 1) The Duke of Berg levied a river toll on the Rhine in 1425/26 and 1490/91. In 1425/26, 24 Turnosgroschen had to be paid for each foder of wine. The annual revenue is not known. 2) The Count of Berg levied a land toll in 1257. In 1555, 3 alb. had to be paid per foder of wine. Between 1434 and 1440 the toll was mortgaged for 60 guilders a year.

Name: Mönkenbrook
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1588.

Name: Mönkhagen
Alternative_Name: Indagine; Hagene; Monekehagenn; Mönnekenhagen; Mönckhagen; Mönchhagen; Munkenhagen

Name: Montfoort
Alternative_Name: Montfort; Munfort; Muntfort; Muntforde; Montfoerde; Montforde; Montfoirt; Montfoorde; Montphoerde
Settlement_Description: Montfoort is first mentioned in 1204. It originated as a market settlement near a castle that was built about 1163.
Town_Description: Montfoort was granted town rights at 28 May 1329 by Zweder I de Rover, Burgrave of Montfoort. By 1353, Montfoort had been fortified with a stone wall and a moat.

Name: Mook
Alternative_Name: Moldeka; Moldeke; Moldeche; Moldecke; Modike; Moldic; Moudick; Moudic; Moldick; Mouwick; Moock; Mouwyck
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1206.

Name: Liiva
Settlement_Description: Independent parish since the 13th century, which by 1200 already belonged to the 'Doppelgau' of the area with Peude.

Name: Moritz
Settlement_Description: The church was under the auspices of St. Lorenz' monastery in Magdeburg since 1275, in 1306 it was given to Plötzke monastery. Since 1307 a noble family of Moritz is mentioned.

Name: Morl
Settlement_Description: Seat of the family of Mordal.

Name: Morna
Settlement_Description: A manor, which was in the possession of the Teutonic Order until 1561.

Name: Mörse
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1301.

Name: Mörsen
Settlement_Description: Around 1280 the settlement consisted of a single farm.

Name: Mortsel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1158, in a fifteenth century copy. Next mention in 1159.

Name: Mosel
Settlement_Description: 1248 mentioned as manor, since 1552 mention of several knightly manors.

Name: Mücklingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1318.

Name: Müden (Aller)
Alternative_Name: Mutha; Mudhen; Muden; Muden upp der Alre; Müden up der Aller; Muidenn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022.
Toll_Description: A toll booth is first mentioned in 1543. Around 1800, Müden was an ancillary toll station of Celle.

Name: Müden (Örtze)
Alternative_Name: Müden an der Oertze; Müden; Muden; Mutha; Mudhen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022. According to a register from 1563/4, the village consisted of 5 farms and 3 half farms.

Name: Mühlberg
Settlement_Description: Oldest mention in 704 as Mullenberge. Mentions in the register of Mainz in 1137 and 1144, whose archbishopric owned the village and gave it away as fiefdom several times.

Name: Vecmīlgrāvis
Settlement_Description: The watercourse was dug by Cistercians in the 13th century.

Name: Mühlhausen/Thüringen
Alternative_Name: Mühlhausen i. Thür.; Mulinhuson; Mulenhusa; Mulehusen
Settlement_Description: Otto II. records in Mühlhausen in 967 (MGH DD OII, nr. 13, S. 20f.). There was a royal/imperial court in Mühlhausen, which was destroyed in 1256.
Town_Description: Imperial ministerialis and citizens of Mühlhausen live under the Mühlhausener Recht, which was recorded in ca. 1224. It is the oldest law code in the German language. Since 1348, Mühlhausen can be considered free imperial city.
Toll_Description: Konrad IV. grants the citizens of Mühlhausen the title of village mayor, toll and coin for five years.
Staple_Description: Since 1600 staple for wool trade.
Fair_Description: There are three Fairs recorded for Mühlhausen.

Name: Młynary
Settlement_Description: A yard of the Teutonic Order was founded before 1414
Town_Description: Close to the yard of the order, the komtur of Elbing, Hermann von Öttingen, founded a town between 1320 and 1329, the founding documents do not survive, but have been renewed with Kulm town law in 1338 by the komtur von Elbing, Siegfried von Sitten, and endorsed by the Grand Master Konrad von Jungingen in 1404

Name: Muiden
Alternative_Name: Amuthon; Amuson; Amuda; Muthen: Mudhen: Muden: Muijden
Settlement_Description: Van Berkel & Samplonius state that Muiden is first mentioned in an eleventh-century copy of a document dated between 918 and 948. Cox, however, claims that Muiden's earliest mention dates from the period 777-866.
Town_Description: Muiden received several town(-like) privileges from the bishops of Utrecht from 1122 onwards, but an official grant of town rights is unknown. Muiden is first mentioned as a town in 1258. On 5 June 1817 Muiden is elevated to the rank of city by Royal Decree.

Name: Muizen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1150.

Name: Mülheim (Rhein)
Toll_Description: 1) The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in 1383. In 1383 about 10 gulden, in 1388 about 30 gulden and in 1403 already 100 gulden could be collected per year. In the years 1411, 1414, 1436 and 1444, the respective annual revenue was around 100 gulden. For other revenues, see source. From 1411 to 1478, Brück, Rheindorf and Wiesdorf were secondary toll stations of Mülheim. 2) In 1489 the Duke of Berg levied transhipment toll. In 1489/90, 852 mark were collected in about six months. Mülheim was a secondary toll station of Dünnwald.

Name: Mülheim an der Ruhr
Toll_Description: The Lord of Broich probably levied a land toll from 1342 onwards. In 1588, however, the toll was confirmed directly for the first time. Earlier mentions may refer to Broich. Tariffs or revenues are not known.

Name: Müllingsen
Alternative_Name: Mulenchusen; Mullenhusen; Molinchusen; Menninckhusen; Mollinckhusen; Möllingsen; Müllingsen

Name: Müllrose
Alternative_Name: Milraze; Melraze; Melraß; Molrasen; Molleroß; Melstrase; Mölrose; Mülrose
Settlement_Description: See of the wendish close to a german village, an old slavic castle fell into ruins in the beginning of the 15th ct.
Town_Description: Founded by Margrave Otto III. around 1260 with Berlin town law, it was endorsed in 1275, mentioned as civitas mid-1275, later only called opidum, has not been a part of the immediate towns in 1325, not bigger than a village in 1405

Name: Müncheberg
Alternative_Name: Monchberg; Lubes; Leubus; Lubens; Möncheberg; Monichberch; Monychenbergk; Monkeberg; Monakaber
Settlement_Description: Duke Heinrich von Schlesien gifts land to three silesian monasteries and the templers in 1225 and 1229, many villages were found as well as a market settlement alongside a church
Town_Description: The duke gifts more land to a soon to be built civitas in 1232, he grants german towm law in 1245, still mentioned as oppidum in 1253-1352

Name: Münchehof
Settlement_Description: The settlement was probably an outpost of the monastery Walkenried.

Name: Munster
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1379. The name Munster is probably derived from Monasterium, 'monastery', but there is no evidence for the existence of a monastery in the settlement.

Name: Münster (Westfalen)
Alternative_Name: Münster; Monasterium; Mimigernaford; Mimegardevurdensis; Mimmegardeuurdensis; Mimiernevordi; Munstre; Munstere; Monastre; Monasteriensis; Monestere
Settlement_Description: The foundation of Münster was related to missionary activities of St Ludger. A monastery was founded in 793, and a diocese in 799. The settlement is first mentioned by name in 819. A market settlement developed next to the cathedral.
Town_Description: Around 1170 Münster was was first characterised as town. Town privileges were granted gradually. After the anabaptist rebellion of 1534/5, town privileges were temporarily suspended, but re-conferred in 1541 and 1553.

Name: Münsterdorf
Alternative_Name: Munsterdorp; Münsterdorff; Welanao; Welna; Wellen; Welne; Welle; Wellne
Settlement_Description: The small monastery Wellen was founded in the 9th century. The connected settlement became known as Münsterdorf, first mentioned in 1189. The names Wellen and Münsterdorf were used synonymously until the 18th century, Wellen usually in a clerical context or when referring to the manor.

Name: Müschede
Alternative_Name: Muche; Musche; Muschede; Müsche; Mussche; Muosche; Musschede; Müsscheide
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1179.

Name: Mustla
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241. In 1433 it was owned by the Teutonic Order.

Name: Mylau
Settlement_Description: The castle was erected around 1200. A settlement (suburbium) in close proximity to the castle developed in the 12th and 13th century.
Town_Description: Town priviliges were probabaly given in the middle of the 14th century. In 1367 the place was first referred to as 'town'.

Name: Naarden
Settlement_Description: Naarden is first mentioned in the tenth century.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted on 10 June 1353 by William V, count of Holland. Before that, Naarden already is mentioned as 'stede' and has several town-like features, such as a 'schepenbank' - a court of aldermen. Naarden (also) received town rank by Royal Decree in 1817.

Name: Nahlendorf - Lunstädt
Settlement_Description: Mention of Lunstedt and Nahlendorf in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis from the end of the 9th century (no. 176, 207 and 211). During the Middle Ages the villages were hardly separated and can be seen as a double-village ('Doppeldorf'). In 1937 Nahlendorf was incorporated into Lunstädt (which was in turn incorporated into Roßbach in 1950).

Name: Nahne
Settlement_Description: In Nahne, there existed a watchtower of the enclosure ('landwehr') of the Neustadt of Osnabrück, which was under construction in 1406 and 1409.

Name: Nahrendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1271.

Name: Narva
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed on an old and important trading route at the beginning of the 13th century. In 1277, a Danish castle was mentioned for the first time, which was probably built around 1256. In 1492, Ivan III built a castle called Ivangorod on the right bank of the river. Since then, it was distinguished between the Russian and Estonian part of the town.
Town_Description: At the end of the 14th century the village developed into a town and was referred to as 'civitas' in 1329. Town privileges by Lübeck and Reval were confirmed in 1345. In 1347, Narva belonged to the Teutonic Order.

Name: Natruper Turm
Alternative_Name: nye porte; Nienporte; Wartturm zur neuen Pforte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the enclosure ('landwehr') of Osnabrück. The defensive system was built around 1347, while the watchtower itself is first mentioned as "new gate" in 1383. A possible explanation for the addition "new" is that first a tower near the Bärenteich, located a little to the south, was used for defensive purposes, which was acquired by the town in 1353.

Name: Nauen
Settlement_Description: Findings from the stone age, as well as germanic and slavic times, a slavic castle mound with a german castle dissappeared early and isn't evidenced, the family lineage of the knights of Nauen are often mentioned in the 13th ct., a priest is mentioned in 1186 and 1197
Town_Description: Margraves Otto IV. and Konrad buy the land as an estate in 1292 without town law, they allow for a town hall to be built, mentioned as civitas in 1305, 1315 and 1317 some privileges regarding the markets for the new town are endorsed, Brandenburg town law is mentioned in 1429
Toll_Description: Bruns-Weczerka mentions Nauen as toll station, but cannot give a good reference. In Engel et al. Nauen is mentioned as a royal main toll station only since 1805.
Fair_Description: Two fairs were held in Nauen in the Middle Ages, after the construction of the town hall in 1302. In 1345 one fair is explicitly mentioned.

Name: Nowogard
Alternative_Name: Naugard; Nowgard; Nogart Castrum; Nevgarde; Nougarden; Novgarden; Newarten; Naugardten; Naugardt
Settlement_Description: A slavic castle mound was providing refuge. Later in 1260 a german settlement was established alongside a hamlet with slavic settlers. In 1268 it was demised to the bishopric of Kammin.
Town_Description: It was mentioned as villa sive oppidum in 1268, as 1274 as Stettlein and in 1290 as civitas. Lübeck town law was granted in 1309.

Name: Nauheim
Alternative_Name: Bad Nauheim; Neuheim; Nuweheim; Nouheim; Nuheim
Settlement_Description: The place was listed for the first time before the middle of the 12th century in the property register of the Fulda monastery, and only appears again in the 13th century.

Name: Naumburg (Saale)
Settlement_Description: A fortress of the Ekkehardiner built around 1000 and which served as the episcopal residence served as the basis for the town’s initial development.
Town_Description: In 1033, merchants who moved from Kleinjena to Naumburg were granted the freedom of trade and the inheritable posession of their homesteads. This allows for this privilege to be referred to as the oldest record of a German town foundation. Referred to as civitas in 1142. In 1432 Naumburg became member of the Hanse, but quit its membership in 1433.
Toll_Description: The extensive toll registry of Naumburg lists all the wares upon which one had to pay a fee on the market (StA Naumburg, Rep. XLVII – 2 – 1567).
Staple_Description: At several points, Naumburg held staple rights.
Ferry_Description: The ferry belonged to the council since 1354 and was due a toll.

Name: Naumburg (Hessen)
Alternative_Name: Naumburg; Nuwenburc; Nuweburch; Nuhenburg; Nuenburgen; Nuenburg; Nuenborch; Nyenborch; Nuwenburg; Numburgk; novi castri; novo castro
Settlement_Description: The place goes back to Naumburg Castle, which was first mentioned in 1182. The settlement itself is named 1206/07.
Town_Description: In 1230 'civitas' are mentioned and there is a town seal. 1256 the place is called 'oppidum'.

Name: Naunhof
Settlement_Description: Mention as castrum in 1210.
Town_Description: 1378 referred to as villa, the castle seems to have been deserted by then. In 1406 mention as a small town ('Städtchen') that was independet until 1548, when it was incorporated into the district of Grimma.

Name: Nebenhof
Alternative_Name: Pepermolen; oberste Pfeffermühle; Pfeffermolen; Oberste Pepermöle; Neue Pepermöle; Overste-Pepermöle
Settlement_Description: The Overste-Pepermöle ('upper pepper mill') near the Holsten gate was acquired by the city of Lübeck in 1310. Later, the mill disappeared and a farm with the name Nebenhof remained in the 18th century.

Name: Nederasselt
Alternative_Name: Neder Asselt; Nederassel; Inferiori Assela; Neer Asselen; Neer Asselt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1301.

Name: Nerem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1307.

Name: Nederhorst den Berg
Alternative_Name: opten Berch; ter Horst; Nederhorst; die berch ter Horst; 't Huys Horst, Den-berg; Den berch, Nederhorst; Het Dorp Den Berg ; Horsterberg
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'opten Berch and ter Horst' in 1326. Earliest mention of 'die berch ter Horst' in 1349.

Name: Nedlitz
Settlement_Description: Part of the archbishopric of Magdeburg since 963. Village and castle were completely destroyed during the 30-year war.

Name: Neer
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1204.

Name: Neerijnen
Alternative_Name: in Ine; in Hynen; Nederynen; Nederinen; Neer Ynen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 996, in a twelfth century copy. Next mention probably in circa 1200, in a fourteenth century copy.

Name: Neermoor
Alternative_Name: Edenramora; Nymramore; Eramoere; Eddermore; Neydermoer; Neddermoer
Settlement_Description: First reference from 1400.

Name: Neerwinden
Alternative_Name: UUinethe; Winede; Wines; Winedes Nederwinde; Overwinden; de Winde Superiore; Ouerwinde Middelwinden; Middelwinge
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 976. Next mention in 1139, in a middle thirteenth century copy.

Name: Neetze
Alternative_Name: Netisse; Necessen; Netesse; Netessen; Netze; Netz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1205. According to lists from 1450, 1564 and 1669, there were 8 farms and 20-30 cottages in the village.

Name: Negenborn
Alternative_Name: Nighunburni; Niganbrunnun; Nigenborne; Nigenbornen; Negenborne; Nigenborn; Neghenborne; Neghenborn; Negenbornen; Negenborne; Neurbern; Neunborn
Settlement_Description: The settlement was abandoned in the 15th century, but re-populated from 1490.

Name: Neheim
Alternative_Name: Neheim-Hüsten; Nihem; Nuohem; Niheim; Neyheim; Nyheim; Neyhym
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1202 but was probably founded in the 12th century.
Town_Description: In 1358 the town was granted the town rights of Lippstadt. 1360 a privilege for a free fair. The town rights were confirmed by archbishops of Cologne in 1369 and 1372 and re-established in the 16th century, like the rights of Arnsberg.
Toll_Description: The Count of Arnsberg levied a land toll and bridge toll even before 1314. From 1368, the Archbishop of Cologne was the owner of the toll. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Nidzica
Settlement_Description: A castle of the Teutonic Order was first mentioned in 1376 later the see of a 'Pfleger' of the Order
Town_Description: The town was founded by the Grand Master Winrich von Kniprode in 1381, after it was lost, the handfast was renewed in 1420 by Grand Master Michael Küchmeister with Kulm town law, mentioned as a 'Städtlein' in 1679 and a 'Stadt 2ter Klasse' in 1723

Name: Nereta
Alternative_Name: Nerft; stagnum nomine Nertze; Erveten; Nerfften
Settlement_Description: The 'Nerfter Moor' was mentioned in the 14th century. Later a manor was mentioned as well.

Name: Neritz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1345.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Beste is mentioned several times in the 16th century.
Lock_Description: Lock in the Beste river, which was constructed as part of the construction works for the Alster-Trave canal from 1526 onwards. It had to be renewed as early as 1530. Shipping on the canal was discontinued around 1550.

Name: Nette
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1234.

Name: Nettelkamp
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1006.

Name: Nettelstedt
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1033.

Name: Netterden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1218.

Name: Neuhardenberg
Settlement_Description: Founded in the first third of the 13th century.

Name: Kasaritsa
Settlement_Description: Before 1558 the area ('Wacke') 'Kasseritz' belonged to the Neuhausen castle.

Name: Neubrandenburg
Town_Description: Margrave Johann von Brandenburg commissioned the knight Herbord von Raven to found a town, he granted Brandenburg town law and the status of civitas in 1248

Name: Neubukow
Alternative_Name: Bukowe; Bukow; Bucoywe; Nova-Buchowe; Nien Bukow; Nigenbukow; Newenbukow
Settlement_Description: Established around 1250 close to the castle Bukow
Town_Description: First mentioned in 1260 as novum opidum Bukowe, see of the bailiwick of Bukow, Lübeck town law mentioned in 1435, no documented privilges

Name: Dębno
Alternative_Name: Neudamm; Damm; Damme; Dame; Thamme; Thamb; Neuen-Thamb
Settlement_Description: A village is mentioned in 1261, the knights there in 1337
Town_Description: Margravine Katharina of the Neumark settles tradesmen in the village and establishes it as a town in 1562, mentioned as a 'Städtlein' in 1614

Name: Neuenbau
Settlement_Description: Foundation of the village in 1775 connected to the Sattelpass.

Name: Neuendorf
Alternative_Name: Neuendorf am Damm; Niendorf am Damm
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1375.

Name: Neuengamme
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1212. A church is named for 1261.

Name: Neuenhaus
Settlement_Description: The moated castle Dinkelrode was first mentioned in 1328, next to which a settlement developed.
Town_Description: The town was founded by Count Bernd I. of Bentheim. It received the Münster town privileges in 1369.
Toll_Description: In 1370, Neuenhaus acquired the right to levy a transit toll for wagons for the maintenance of the bridges, as well as a ship toll on herring, butter, cheese and salt.

Name: Neuenkirchen (Osnabrück)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1188.

Name: Neuenkirchen (bei Bassum)
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1255.

Name: Neuenkirchen (Lüneburger Heide)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1288.

Name: Neuenkirchen (Münsterland)
Alternative_Name: Neuenkirchen; Sueduninkila; Snethwinchele; Snetwinclo; Nienkerken; Nove ecclesie
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1022 and 1032 as 'Snetwinkel'.

Name: Ādaži
Alternative_Name: Neuermühlen; Niemollenn; Nye Mole; Nighemole; Niermohlen; Nyemöhlen; Nigenmöllen
Settlement_Description: In 1297 a castle belonging to the Teutonic Order was mentioned. In 1656 it was destroyed. There was also an associated manor.

Name: Neuflemmingen
Settlement_Description: The settlement may have developed from an inn at the road.

Name: Neugattersleben
Settlement_Description: First mention of the castle in 1291.

Name: Valtaiķi
Alternative_Name: Neuhausen; Walteten; Walteiten; Waletetenn; Nova Domus; Nygenhusze; Niehus; Neugenhauss
Settlement_Description: In 1253, the region fell into the possession of the Teutonic Order. The castle already existed in 1338.

Name: Vastseliina
Alternative_Name: Neuhausen; Novum Castrum; Vrowenborgh; Nyenhus Vrowenborch
Settlement_Description: Burchard von Dreileben founded the castle in 1342, which rose to one of the strongest castles in the country by 1379. In 1702, however, it was destroyed. A manor and a suburbium were developed next to the castle.

Name: Jaunkrimulda
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1566 as a gift.

Name: Neuhof
Alternative_Name: Nuwendorp; Nova Villa; Nuendorp; Nuwenthorp; Nova Curia; Neuenhoff
Settlement_Description: The settlement was abandoned and was acquired by the monastery Walkenried in 1248, which resettled it as a folwark.

Name: Neukalen
Alternative_Name: Kalen; Kalent; Kalant; Nienkalandt; Nova Kalant; Nigen-Kaland; Nienkalen; Newenkaland; Nienkalden; Neukalden
Settlement_Description: Castle Kalen was bestowed upon the monastry Dargun in 1174, a church was mentioned in 1232, Fürst Borwin von Mecklenburg tried to establish a town in 1244 to no avail, it was relocated by Fürst Waldemar in 1281 and left the village Altkalen
Town_Description: Refounding of the town with all the old privileges in 1281, Lübeck town law was endorsed multiple times

Name: Neukammer
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1329, the settlement was already deserted in 1349. Its church became a pilgrimage site until it was demolished in the middle of the 16th century.

Name: Neukirchen
Settlement_Description: First mention as Nuenkirchen in 1350.

Name: Neukloster
Settlement_Description: In 1286 the Benedictine nun monastery in Neuenkirchen (founded in 1274) moved to Bredenbek, which was renamed after the monastery. The nuns adopted the Cistercian habit, but still lived according to the Benedictine rule. In 1499 the monastery burned down, but was rebuilt in 1519. Having remained Catholic during the Reformation, the convent died out after the Swedish occupation in 1645 until 1705.

Name: Neumünster
Alternative_Name: Niemünster; Novum Monasterium; Nyenmonstere; Niemunstere; Neygemynster; Newmunster
Settlement_Description: A monastery of Augustinian canons was founded after 1127 at the church of Wippendorf-Faldera. The monastery was moved to Bordesholm around 1330. The settlement developed into a borough ('flecken') in the late Middle Ages.
Toll_Description: Toll station of the counts of Holstein. Queen Dorothea of Denmark installed a new toll in Neumünster in 1492. Only one toll register before the 18th century is still extant, from the year 1501.

Name: Neundorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1500.

Name: Neuruppin
Settlement_Description: An early settlement at the old ferry port
Town_Description: Most likely established before 1238 by the lords of Ruppin (the Greats of Arnstein) as the economical middle of their land close to the castle Ruppin (Alt Ruppin), in 1246 there was a dominican monastery, the civitas was granted Stendal town law by Günther von Arnstein in 1256

Name: Vasknarva
Settlement_Description: The castle of the Teutonic Order was built in 1349, but was soon destroyed by Russians. This was followed by reconstruction in 1427-1442.

Name: Neuss
Alternative_Name: Neuß; Nussiam; Novaesium; Nouesium; Niuisium; Niuisi; Neusz; Nuys; Nuysse
Settlement_Description: The Roman fortress Novaesium was founded around 16 BC on the shore of the Rhine. In the vicinity, a trading settlement developed that became the old town of Neuss. In Carolingian times, a castle is mentioned here.
Town_Description: Neuss is first characterised as "oppidum" in 1170 and probably became a full town around 1200. The oldest town seal dates from 1245. Various privileges were granted in the next centuries. Among others, Neuss was granted the privileges of a Hanse town in 1475 by emperor Frederick III.
Toll_Description:
1) Already in 877, an Imperial toll for ships hauled upstream on the Rhine existed in Neuss. Pfeiffer claims that this toll was market-related. A Rhine toll of the bishop of Cologne is mentioned in 1138. The towns of Cologne and temporarily Rees were exempted from the toll. The Rhine toll was moved to Zons because of changes in the course of the river in 1372. In 1243, at least 6 denarii per ship had to be paid. In 1236 about 1200 Cologne mark were collected, in 1256 about 800 Cologne mark. For further tariffs and revenues, see Pfeiffer.
2) A market toll is mentioned in 1138 and 1169, and in 1203 a transit toll for land traffic of the bishop of Cologne. At least between 1389 and 1393, a horse toll was levied by the bishop, and a toll for safe conduct was granted by king Wenceslaus in 1396. In 1396, 2 to 3 alb. per horse had to be paid, depending on the load. In the years 1389/93, an average of about 2152 mark per year could be collected. Half of the land toll was acquired by the town of Neuss in 1455; in 1463 completely. In 1455, about 700 Rhenish guilders were collected. Elaborate details about the practice of levying the toll are known from testimonies written during a 1478-1479 conflict about the toll between Düsseldorf and Neuss. To prevent circumventing of the toll station, the toll was levied at many secondary toll stations around town as well. Detailed list of toll tariffs are known from 1601 and 1618.
3) The town of Neuss also levied a road toll in 1373. However, the Archbishop of Cologne declared this to be illegitimate, which is why its existence after 1373 is not known.
Fair_Description: It is unknown when the fairs in Neuss originated. In the 14th century, there were three fairs, on St Walpurga, St John and St Remigius. A fourth one on St Bartholomew was added before 1419. The four fairs were confirmed by emperor Frederick III in 1475, who also granted a fifth fair on St Martin. All fairs were to last four days before and after the said dates. The St Walpurga fair, which coincided with the feast on the dedication day of the church of St Quirinus, attracted most visitors, together with St John's fair in the 15th and 16th centuries.

Name: Neustadt am Rennsteig
Settlement_Description: First mention of the place in 1489.

Name: Neustadt am Rübenberge
Alternative_Name: Neustadt a. Rbge.; Nova civitas; Nyenstedt; Nyestad; Nuwenstad; Newenstatt; Nienstadt vor dem Röuwenberge; Rovenberg; Rubenberg; Ruhveberg
Settlement_Description: The counts of Wölpe founded a castle around 1215, next to which a settlement developed.
Town_Description: According to the name "nova civitas", which Neustadt was already called in 1215, the settlement possibly was already a town at the time. There exists no charter of town privileges, although the use of the Bremen town rights has been attested.
Toll_Description: In a 1389 charter, the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg proclaim that the same toll that is levied on the Aller river in Essel, will now be levied on the Leine in Neustadt, namely of each fuder grain and each fuder beer one Hannover shilling. No other tolls will be levied between Hannover and Rethem. A 1507 agreement between Hannover and Celle regulated the fares for toll and safe conduct in Essel. Toll receipts for the journey from and to Hannover were copied into a register of the town Hannover for the years 1507-1515. Likely, these refer to the the toll levied in Neustadt, as Essel is not located on the Leine.

Name: Neustadt in Holstein
Alternative_Name: Neustadt; Neustadt (Holstein); Noua Crempa; Nygenstat in dher Crempen; Nygenkrempe; Nygen Krempen; Nystadt; Neapolis; Nygestad
Settlement_Description: Before the foundation of Neustadt in 1244, there existed a small fishing settlement.
Town_Description: Founded as a planned town by Count Adolf IV of Holstein and provided with Lübeck town privileges in 1244.

Name: Neustadt (Magdeburg)
Settlement_Description: Especially the northern part of this 'old' Neustadt was intentionally erected. In 1228 Peter-and-Paul abbey, which was originally erected in Sudenburg, was moved here.
Toll_Description: Mention of a toll in the context of a quarrel between the archbishop and the town of Magdeburg in 1432.

Name: Neustadt bei Coburg
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as market in 1248, probably only qualified as such through a boardwalk erected before 1162, from Sonneberg via Hönbach.
Toll_Description: Toll station owned solely by the territorial sovereign, mentioned in 1317 in a urbarium. 1330 toll station owned by the counts of Henneberg by the route of safe conduct Coburg - Saalfeld.

Name: Neustadt-Glewe
Alternative_Name: Neustadt in Mecklenburg; De Nje Stat; Neustadt; Newstatt; Nova Civitas-Chlewa; Neustadt-Gleve
Settlement_Description: Grew close to the wendish village Glewe
Town_Description: Founded by the Duke of Schwerinin 1248 close to a castle, mentioned as civitas in thr 13th ct.

Name: Szczecinek
Alternative_Name: Neustettin; Newen Stettin; Nigen Stettin; Nien Stettin; Newestetyn; Nygenstetyn; Kleyn Stetinchen; Nygen Stetyn; Newen Stetyn; Minori Stetin, Nova Stettin; Neosedinum
Settlement_Description: Most likely grew close to a castle mound next to the Streitzigsee.
Town_Description: The town was founding in 1310 by Wratislaw IV with Lübeck town law as a precaution against Waldemar II of Brandenburg.

Name: Neuwallmoden
Alternative_Name: Wallmerhol; Wallmerhohl; Walmden; Walmede novum; Walmoden; Walmeden; castrum Novo Walmede
Settlement_Description: A castle was bought by the bishop of Hildesheim and the town of Goslar in 1307; the settlement probably developed as a consequence. The castle and the settlement were destroyed in 1368, with only the inn Wallmerhol on a border remaining. The village was resettled in the 16th century.

Name: Neuwarmbüchen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1476.

Name: Neuzelle
Settlement_Description: In 1268 a Cistercian monastery was founded, even though monks probably only resided there since 1281. The monastery has a certain Golden Age in the 15th century, after the Reformation it became protestant.

Name: Niederdehme
Alternative_Name: Dehme; Nieder Dehme; Dehem; Deheim; Thehem; Theem; Deym
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1088.

Name: Nieder Ense
Alternative_Name: Aenesi; Anasi; Enshe; Aense; Ense; Nederen Ense; Neddern enße; inferiori villa Ense
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1016 and 1020. The earlier mentions are problematic in that they do not differentiate between Ober- and Nieder-Ense.

Name: Nieder-Ingelheim
Toll_Description: In 1254, Werner IV of Bolanden probably levied a river toll on the Rhine and/or a land toll in the village of Ingelheim. The castle, which probably served as a customs post and was close to the Rhine, was destroyed in 1254. It can also be assumed that a land toll was collected on the Mainz-Bingen road. Tariffs or revenues are not known.

Name: Niederbreisig
Alternative_Name: Bad Breisig; Brisiaco; Briseche; Brisich; Brisege
Settlement_Description: A settlement possibly dates back to Celtic times and became increasingly important in the Middle Ages. In 1969, Bad Niederbreisig, Oberbreisig and Rheineck were united to form Bad Breisig, which received town rights in 1970.
Toll_Description: In 1363, the abbess of Essen levied a land toll, the so-called "schmaler Zoll". In 1397, this passed into the possession of the Duke of Jülich. In 1397 the tariff was set at 4 white pfennigs ('Weißpfennige') for 100 pigs. The annual yield is not known. A river toll on the Rhine planned for 1302 was not established.

Name: Niedereimer
Alternative_Name: Embere; Emmere; Imbere; Inferiori Embere; Nideren Emeren; Nyderen Emmere; Nederen Eymere; Niddern Eymer; Niedern Eymer; Niedern Eimer
Settlement_Description: The settlement Eimer was first mentioned in 1191. It was divided into two parts Nieder- and Obereimer, which are first mentioned separately in 1207.

Name: Niederfinow
Settlement_Description: Founded in 1258.
Town_Description: In 1308 the settlement is referred to as civitas, in 1334 it is only referred to as oppidum anymore, after the toll station and harbor at the Finow was moved to Eberswalde in 1317. In the 15th century it is steadily referred to as town or civitas, and regained some meaning in trade, but great damages during the 30-year war degraded the town to village. Its town privileges were still confirmed in 1558, 1689 and 1713, even though it is only referred to as borough ('Flecken') since 1573.
Toll_Description: The toll station is moved to Eberswalde in 1317.
Fair_Description: Two fairs were held in Niederfinow, that were later moved to Oderberg.
Bridge_Description: In 1542 Niederfinow is referred to as bridge town at the Finow. Before, in 1317, the main Finow crossing had been moved from here to Eberswalde.
Harbour_Description: In 1308 a place of transshipment from the river to land transport is established in Niederfinow.

Name: Niederheimbach
Toll_Description: The Mainz cathedral chapter levied a river toll on the Rhine in 1369. In the same year, 2½ Turnosgroschen had to be paid for each foder of wine. Annual yields are not known.

Name: Niederklobikau
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis from the end of the 9th century. Property of Wimmelburg monastery since 1215, in the 15th century the village is sold to bishop of Merseburg.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct of Merseburg

Name: Niedermarsberg
Alternative_Name: Horhusen; Horohuson; Horohusun; Horohusen; Horihusen; Horehuson; Harehusen; Horhusen; Stadtberge; Marsberg; Zum Berg; Altenstadt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 900.
Town_Description: The original award of town privileges is not known. However, there is a falsified document on the awarding of Dortmund town privileges 962. In 1104 the place is known as 'oppidum'.

Name: Niederorschel
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1152.

Name: Niedersfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1547.

Name: Niedervellmar
Alternative_Name: Filmare; Filumari; Vilemar; Vilmare; Velmari; Velmar; Nidern Velmar
Settlement_Description: Vellmar was first mentioned between 775 and 786. Since 1107 Ober- and Niedervellmar are mentioned separately for the first time, which is why it is unclear to which Vellmar early documents refer. Niedervellmar itself was mentioned in 1240.

Name: Niederzwehren
Alternative_Name: Tweron; Dwern; Twern; Twerne; Tvern; Tuern; Nieder-Zwehren; Tweren inferior; Nederen Tvern; Kyrchtzwerne
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252.

Name: Nieheim
Alternative_Name: Nihem; Nyhem; Nehem; Nyehem; Nyem; Niem; Nejm; Nieheimb
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 889.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted by Bishop Bernhard IV of Paderborn (1228-1247), extended in 1282.

Name: Niehaus
Settlement_Description: Farm, first mentioned in 1347.

Name: Niemegk
Settlement_Description: A hamlet close to the castle grew out of a burgward which was first mentiond in 1161, it grew by taking in two villages close by
Town_Description: No documentary evidence, but apparently town law and a city coat of arms were granted in 1228. Apparently Wittenberg town rights were granted in 1349. A council constitution exists since the second half of the 14th century.
Toll_Description: In 1349 and 1373 mention of a wagon toll. Secondary station of safe conduct of Berzig.

Name: Nienberge
