Settlement_Description: First mentioned 1142.

Name: Nienburg (Saale)
Settlement_Description: 975 proven as the centre of a castle district ('Burgwardmittelpunkt'). Relocation of Thankmarsfelde monastery to Nienburg in 975 as well. In the Early Middle Ages already an important leg of the road between Magdeburg and Halle.
Town_Description: Mention as "urbs", in 1035 the Hagenröder coin and the market of Staßfurt were moved here, since they were in the posession of the monastery. In 1560 secularization of the monastery.

Name: Nienburg (Weser)
Alternative_Name: Nienburg a.d. Weser; Nienburg; Nienburg; Nienborch; Nigenborch; Nyenburg; Nygenborch; Nigenborgh; Nymburg; Nyenborch
Settlement_Description: A castle of the bishop of Minden on a crossing of the Weser river is first mentioned in the 11th century; residence of the counts of Hoya in 1215-1582.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted before 1235. From 1225, Nienburg is characterised as "civitas". Attested as "villa" in 1215.
Fair_Description: In the early modern period, eleven retail fairs are mentioned, which were connected with markets for cattle, timber and shoes. Three dates are known: Friday before Laetare, Monday and Tuesday after the Exaltation of the Holy Cross (the "Krüzemarkt") and a fair for horses and cattle on Wednesday and Thursday after St Simon and Juda. It is unknown when they were founded.

Name: Niendorf I
Alternative_Name: Nienthrope; Nigendorpe; Nendorpe; Northdorpe; Nigedorp; Nygendorppe; Niendorp
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1261.

Name: Nienhof
Alternative_Name: Nienhoffe; Nigenhove; Nygenhoue; Newen Hoff; Neuenhoff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1428-1438.

Name: Nienstedt am Harz
Settlement_Description: First reference in 1055.

Name: Nieperfitz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330/52.

Name: Niersen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1335-1336.

Name: Nieste
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1293.

Name: Nieuwebrug
Settlement_Description: Nieuwebrug is first mentioned as toll station in 1391. There existed an inn, where among others the Estates of Overijssel gathered in 1496. A village developed only in the 19th century.
Toll_Description: Toll station of the bishop of Utrecht, who exempted his servants in Twente from toll payments at Nieuwebrug and Hardenberg in 1391.
Bridge_Description: The name Nieuwebrug refers to a new bridge across the Regge, which has to have existed already in 1391.

Name: Bad Nieuweschans
Alternative_Name: Lange Ackeren Schans; Langacker Schans; De Nieuwe ofte Langeacker Schans; Langacker of Nievweschans; De Lange Akker of Nieuwe Schans; Nieuweschans; Langakkerschans; Fort op Bunderland
Settlement_Description: The fortress Langakkerschans (later known as Nieuweschans) was built on the border between Groningen and East Frisia in 1628.

Name: Nieuwstadt
Alternative_Name: Nieuwstad; Novo Opido; Novum Opidum; Nyestat; Niestat; Novam Civitatem; Nuestat; Nieuwerstadt; Nustadt; Nieuwestade; Nustad; Nove ville apud Helsene
Settlement_Description: Nieuwstadt is first mentioned in 1242. It is founded on the place of an earlier settlement (called [H]elsene).
Town_Description: Nieuwstadt is first mentioned in 1242, which is also its earliest mention as town (15 July). There is no known charter of town rights, but rights were probably granted by Otto II, count of Guelders. Nieuwstadt was walled between 1277 and 1573. Its importance diminished in the sixteenth century.
Fair_Description: Two fairs of 14 days each were granted in 1312. However, it is unknown whether they were ever organized at all.

Name: Niezijl
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1579.

Name: Nijkerk
Alternative_Name: Nyenkercke; Niekircken; Nyekerc; Nykerck; Nijerkerck; Nijkercke; Nijekerck; Nijkerck; Niekercken; Nieuwkerk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1333-1334. The village was destroyed in 1412. The following year, its inhabitants received town privileges; the settlement was rebuild.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted on 27 March 1413 by Reginald IV, duke of Guelders.

Name: Mikołajki
Alternative_Name: Nikolaiken; St. Nikolas; orbis divi Nicolai; St. Niclo; St. Niclas
Settlement_Description: The church village was first mentioned in 1444 as a yard of the Teutonic Order

Name: Nymburk
Staple_Description: Staple rights for salt from northern Germany in 1401; confirmed in 1412.

Name: Nijmegen
Alternative_Name: Nimwegen; Ulpia Noviomagus; Noviomagus; Municipium Batavorum; Nieumegen; Nieumeghen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 98-117. Around 98, emperor Trajanus granted market privileges and the title Ulpia Noviomagus to the settlement. In the second century, possibly in 161, town privileges were granted. In the second half of the eight century, a palace ('palts'/ 'pfalz') was built.
Town_Description: In the second century, town privileges were granted. In 1204, Nijmegen is mentioned as 'oppidum'. 31 August 1230, town privileges similar to the town privileges granted to other free imperial cities are granted to Nijmegen by Henry VII, on behalf of his father, Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor. Most taverns and inns were located in the Grotestraat: the street between the town square and the town gate to the river Waal which was located next to the crane and called 'Kraanpoort'.
Toll_Description: Until 1228/29, the empire levied a river toll on the Waal. This was first mentioned in 1145. From 1228/29 to 1356, the Count of Cleves was the owner of the toll. After 1357, the toll was levied by the Duke of Guelders. The old toll was moved to Griethausen. No tariffs are known from the years before 1357. In 1357, 6 turnosgroschen had to be paid.
Staple_Description: Statutes from 1468 (in the 'keurboek') mention a staple on woad. It was related to the wool-dyeing which flourished in the fourteenth century, and died out in the fifteenth century. The related cloth hall is first mentioned in 1382, and lost its function at least before 1542, when it was remodeled. Gorissen suspects that this staple has been of limited importance.
Fair_Description: In Nijmegen, two fairs already existed before 1294/95. In the sixteenth century, an oxen fair was added on St. Victor's Day. Two horse fairs were instituted during the Gueldern Wars. Those fairs existed for three years only, between 1540 and 1543. In Nijmegen, three days of each fair were dedicated to cloth trade.

Name: Pyari
Settlement_Description: Manor and hamlet ('Hof') owned by the Teutonic Order. First mentioned in 1429. The farm got its name from its owner, Hans Ninigal.

Name: Nitzow
Toll_Description: In 1570 or 1580 the episcopal toll on the Havel is moved from Nitzow to Havelberg.

Name: Noordbroek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Broke' in 1273. Earliest mention of 'Nortdabrock' in 1478.

Name: Noorddijk
Alternative_Name: Northdic; Northdike; Nordike; Noordijc; Noortdycke; Nortdike; Noertdijck; Nordyck; Noordijk; Noorddyk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1299 .

Name: Noordhorn
Alternative_Name: Northorne; Noirthoren; Noorthorn; Northoren; Noerthorum; Northorm; Noerdhorn; Northorn
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1375.

Name: Noordlaren
Alternative_Name: Northlare; Northlara mare; Nordhlare; Noertlaren; Noertlare; Noertlaer; Noortlaren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in a copy dating from in 1254.

Name: Noordsleen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1365.

Name: Norden
Settlement_Description: The village of Norden developed from the merger of the two hamlets Ekel and Lintel, which are first mentioned in 785.
Town_Description: A central market place was established in the first half of the 13th century. Norden is documented in 1255 as the centre of the land of Norden and must have had a town-like character at that time. In 1455 the town had two mayors, in 1498 it had a town seal and in 1535 town regulations are known. However, a year for the acquisition of town rights is unknown.
Toll_Description: A toll of the counts of East Frisia was levied in Norden. In 1497, it was specified that commodities for which toll had already been paid in Norden were exempted from toll in Emden. For each horse or piece of cattle 1 Krummstert had to be paid. A more specific list of toll fees for various commodities is known from 1629. A toll register exists for the years 1596-1599.
Fair_Description: Fairs in Norden are first explicitly mentioned in 1440 in a letter of safe conduct. They are also mentioned in the town regulations of 1535. Dates are only known later: the fair of St James in the mid-16th century, the Pentecost market in 1598, and the large three-day autumn cattle fair ('Beestmarkt') on the day before St Martin. All of these fairs must have been older.

Name: Krylovo
Settlement_Description: A 'Wildhaus' was mentioned in 1366, a castle of the Teutonic Order in 1368, a settlement of Old Prussian farmers formed between 1370 and 1378
Town_Description: The place was intended to become a town in 1405, the founding documents with Kulm town law were signed by the Grand Master Ulrich von Jungingen in 1407

Name: Nordgoltern
Settlement_Description: The settlement Goltern, which was subdivided into Groß- and Nordgoltern, was first mentioned in 1160. Nordgoltern as a separate settlement was mentioned in 1320.

Name: Nordhastedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as "Repherstede" around 1320.

Name: Nordhausen
Settlement_Description: The first mentions of 927 and 929 refer to the liudolfing stronghold near today's dome. The Early medieval settlement was far from any natural traffic lines. Former Karolingian-Ottonian royal court. In the Middle of the 10th century, a marketplace develops nearby.
Town_Description: Nordhausen is declared free imperial city before 1220. Probably around 1180.

Name: Nordhorn
Settlement_Description: The old village Nordhorn, current Altendorf, possibly goes back to an 9th-century missionary centre. A local law court existed here since 1319.
Town_Description: The borough ('weichbild') to the southwest of the old village received the same town privileges as the town Schüttorf in 1379; they were reiterated in 1417.
Toll_Description: A privilege of the Count from 1416 permitted Nordhorn to introduce a road toll "for the utility and improvement of the town". It was levied on wagons passing through town. As the many bridges in town demanded a great deal of maintenance, a separate bridge toll was introduced in 1613.

Name: Nordshausen
Alternative_Name: Nordradeshusum; Nordradeshusun; Nordershusen; Norderteshusun; Nordishusen; Nordshausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1074.

Name: Nortmoor
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1433.

Name: Nortorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1190, but the settlement probably came into being between 500 and 800. A church was founded in the mid-12th century, after which the settlement developed into a large craftsmen village.

Name: Nossegem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1110.

Name: Nossen
Settlement_Description: A knight called Petrus de Noßin was mentioned in 1185. The village was first mentioned in 1264. The settlement surrounded the castle which came into the possession of the monastery Altzella in 1430. Town privileges were granted in 1664.

Name: Nottuln
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 834. Already in 803 an Augustinian monastery was founded.

Name: Veliky Novgorod
Alternative_Name: Velikiy Novgorod; Weliki Nowgorod; Naugard; Великий Новгород; Neugarten; Grote Valborde; Grote Naworde

Name: Nõo
Settlement_Description: Parish, which was etablished in the 14th/15th century. A Borough ('Flecken') only developed in the 19th century.

Name: Nuland
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1299, in a seventeenth century copy.

Name: Nunspeet
Alternative_Name: Nunspiet; Lonspeet; Lunsepic; Nunspit; Nuynspit; Nieuspeet
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of the church and settlement 'Nunspiet' in 1313. There is discussion whether farms were already present here before 1200, but there is consensus that habitation and cultivation of land in this area intensified during the thirteenth century. At least from the thirteenth century onwards, the centre of the settlement Nunspeet was formed by the church, the present-day 'Oude Kerk' or 'Hervormde Dorpskerk' located at Dorpsstraat 12. From the seventeenth century onwards, 'De Roskam' served as an inn on the route between Amersfoort and Zwolle.

Name: Nurmiži
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1561.

Name: Nürnberg
Alternative_Name: Nuremberg; Norenberg; Norenberc; Nuorenberc; Nourenberg; Nurinberg
Settlement_Description: The place was founded in the 11th century and had market rights from the beginning.
Town_Description: In 1219, Nuremberg was mentioned as a 'free imperial town'. In the late Middle Ages, i.e. between 1470 and 1530, the town was able to become an important trading centre due to its convenient location.

Name: Nusse
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1158.

Name: Nützen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in ca. 1520.

Name: Nüxei
Alternative_Name: Nytzenhain; Nichsehe; Nixsee; Nußhei; Nüxhei; Nixhey
Settlement_Description: At the first mention in 1420, the hamlet is mentioned as abandoned. It must have been resettled before the next mention in 1557. There existed an inn here, which became a toll station at the Thuringian border after the Thirty Years' War.

Name: Bārta
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1252. A church was situated there in 1560.

Name: Oberellen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1075.

Name: Oberhaverbeck
Settlement_Description: Haverbeck is first mentioned in a register of the diocese Verden of ca. 1252. The distinction between the two parts Ober- ('upper') and Nieder- ('lower') Haverbeck is from a later date.

Name: Oberhof
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1470.
Toll_Description: The registry of safe conduct from 1540 states that it records the policies from 1504. (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Cc 369.)

Name: Oberkirchen
Alternative_Name: Overenkerke; Overkirchin; Ouerenkirken; Ouerkirker; Ouernkerchin; Oberkerken; Oeuerenkirken; Ouerenkerken; Ouerkircken; Ouerkirchen; Obernkirchen; Vbernkirchen; Overenkercken
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1244.

Name: Oberlangen
Settlement_Description: The elongated settlement Langen, first mentioned around 1000, was divided into Ober- ('higher') and Nieder- ('lower') langen.

Name: Oberlind
Alternative_Name: Linte; ebern Lhnte; Obern Linthe; Obernlynth
Settlement_Description: The village probably already existed at a ford in the 9th century. In 1225 the village is mentioned as property of Saalfeld. Town rights were only granted in 1931.
Bridge_Description: The "Wignandesford" across the Steinach is mentioned in a record from 1162. This proves a interregional traffic route existed in the direction of Coburg since the 12th century.

Name: Oberlungwitz
Settlement_Description: This abandoned area was settled around 1100. The founder of this village built a property, which was reused as a manor until 1273. Town privileges were granted in 1936.

Name: Obermarsberg
Alternative_Name: Eresburgum; mons Eresburg; Heresburg; Heresburc; Eresberg; Eresbergensis; Heresberghe; Mons Martis; Mersberg; Stadtberge; Marsberg; Zum Berg
Settlement_Description: The existing Sachsenfest Eresburg was taken by Charlemagne in 772. Which was destroyed in 1115 by Count Friedrich von Arnsberg.
Town_Description: An exact award of town privileges is not known. However, the place was already referred to as a city around 820, 915 and 938.

Name: Obermeiser
Alternative_Name: Mesheri; Meiskere; Messere; Meschere; minus Meischere; Suthmesere; parvum Messere; Meisserde superius; Obirmezere; Obermeisser
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1015.

Name: Obermörmter
Toll_Description: The Count of Cleves levied a land toll in 1319. Tariffs and annual revenues are not known.

Name: Andervenne Oberdorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1047.

Name: Obernfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1184 and 1203.

Name: Põltsamaa
Settlement_Description: In the 13th century, a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built around the castle and church, although the origins of the settlement can be found much earlier. In the 15th and 16th centuries it had a borough rights ('Flecken').

Name: Oberreißen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1287.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct of Rudersdorf, when the proper road was circumvented.

Name: Oberröblingen
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis from the 2nd third of the 9th century. Alleged endowment of a Benedictine monastery in 1117, verified Cistercian convent in 1319. The monastery was destroyed during the Peasant's War.

Name: Oberrothenbach
Settlement_Description: First mention as Rotinbach in 1421.

Name: Obersachswerfen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1129.

Name: Selk
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1412.

Name: Obersickte
Alternative_Name: Sickte; Kikthi; Xikthi; Xicthe; Tsikthe; Zickede; Major Sickte; Ober-Tzicte; Maiori villa Tzickte; Superiori Tzikte; Superius Tzicte; Oversten Tzicte; Overentzigste; Overentzichte; Superius Tzichte; Overn Tzicte; Obern Sickte
Settlement_Description: The settlement Sickte is first mentioned in 888 and was divided into the two parts Ober- and Niedersickte, of which the former is first mentioned individually in 1308.

Name: Westuffeln
Alternative_Name: Oberuffeln; Ufelen; Ufelohun; Vfloun et altera Ufloun; Uflon; Uflahun; Ufflan; Uffeln;
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 965.

Name: Obervellmar
Alternative_Name: Filmare; Filumari; Vilemar; Vilmare; Velmari; Velmar; Ober Vilmar; Overen Velemar; Ober-Vellmar
Settlement_Description: Vellmar was first mentioned between 775 and 786. Since 1107 Ober- and Niedervellmar are mentioned separately for the first time, which is why it is unclear to which Vellmar early documents refer. Obervellmar itself was mentioned in 1299.

Name: Oberwesel
Toll_Description: From 1253 to 1269, the empire levied a river toll on the Rhine. In 1435, the Archbishop of Trier briefly established a toll. Tariffs and annual revenues are not known.

Name: Ochsenzoll
Toll_Description: Toll station on the Ochsenweg ('oxen road') on the border between Hamburg and Holstein territory. A toll was levied here between 1612 and 1867.

Name: Ochten
Alternative_Name: Ovtun; Uothen; Huth; Ofte; Hogte; Vgthen; Ugthen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention probably dates from the second half of the ninth century, in a copy dated between 1150-1158.

Name: Ochtersum
Alternative_Name: Ochtereshem; Ohtershem; Occhterseim; Hochtersem; Oghtersum; Ochtersem; Ochterszem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1132.

Name: Ochtrup
Alternative_Name: Ohthepe; Uhtepe; Ochtorpe; Ohtappen; Ochtupo; Oyttope; Ochtepe; Ohtope; Ohctepe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1134.

Name: Otepää
Settlement_Description: In 1116, an Estonian castle in Otepää was mentioned. This was conquered by Germans in the 13th century. Bishop Hermann I then built a new castle to serve as the center of the Dorpat diocese. It was destroyed at the end of the 15th century. A settlement next to the castle developed in the 13th century and gained economic importance in medieval times. However, it was completely destroyed in 1558.

Name: Oderberg
Settlement_Description: A hospital St Mary was built around 1210, the Ascanian Albrecht II. built a fortress in 1214, which soon supported a wendish village, a german castle hamlet was created and a bailiff mentioned in 1231, a Norbertines monastery was built in 1231, but it - alongside St Mary - was incorporated into the new Cistercian Monastery Mariensee, in 1258
Town_Description: Mentioned as plebanus in 1247, as plebanus civitas in 1259, as civitas in 1301, as opidum in 1317 and 1393, must have become a town before 1259, but nothing is known about that
Staple_Description: Staple rights valid only for trade upstream; merchants from Frankfurt exempted, and in 1317 merchants from Berlin-Kölln too. Confirmation in 1415 established the staple as a simple tax.

Name: Odoorn
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1327, in a copy dating from 1471.

Name: Oebisfelde
Alternative_Name: Ocisfelde; Ysfelde; Ovsfelt; Ouefsfelde; Ovesfelde; Olbisfelde
Settlement_Description: First mention presumably between 1014 and 1037. Several fortifications were erected against Slavic settlement. At the beginning of the 11th century the settlement was property of Corvey monastery.
Town_Description: Referred to as civitas in 1226, mention as oppidum in 1262. In 1448 the town privileges were confirmed.
Toll_Description: A toll was already given in 1485, further mentions occur in 1503 and 1533. In the course of the 16th century, the toll stations in Oebisfelde, Neuhaldensleben, Wolmirstedt, Dreileben, Wanzleben and Calbe complain that their income was reduced due to the toll exemption of Magdeburg.
Fair_Description: Oebisfelde owned four fairs in 1523, some were ware- and others were cattle fairs. In 1783 another ware- and cattlemarket was granted, until 1887 the number of markets was raised to 12. Some ware markets were replaced by cattle markets, however.

Name: Oedelem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1133.

Name: Oedelum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1125.

Name: Oederan
Settlement_Description: Farmers and miners settled in this area around 1180. Mining is said to have been mentioned as early as 1216.
Town_Description: Oederan gained greater economic importance due to its location on an old Bohemian street, so that there was constant growth. Several marketplaces were created and city rights were granted before 1286 (around 1250). In 1583 Mining town.
Toll_Description: Station of secondary safe conduct of Chemnitz.

Name: Oeffelt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in fourteenth century.

Name: Oegstgeest
Alternative_Name: Osgeresgest; Osgest; Oistgest; Oestgheest; Oestghest; Oestgheest; Oestgeest; Oisgeest; Oostgeest; Oestgheest
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 918-948, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1201.

Name: Oelde
Alternative_Name: Ulithi; Ulidi; Vlithi; Vlethe; Oilde; Oylde; Ölde; Olede; Ulethe; Olethe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 875. Fortified in the 14th century and characterised as borough ('wigbold') since the 16th century.

Name: Oelegem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1161.

Name: Oelsnitz
Settlement_Description: The settlement was situated around the Voitsberg castle, which was built in 1240. The settlement probably had market rights since its foundation.
Town_Description: The expansion of the town took place in the middle of the 14th century. In 1357, the town received town rights.

Name: Oerel
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 937; the church was built around 1100. Oerel was the seat of a regional court. There were 6 farms and 2 cottages here around 1500.

Name: Oerrel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1308.

Name: Oerzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1298.

Name: Oesede
Alternative_Name: Ösede; Osidi; Asithi; Esethe; Hosethe; Asedhe; Osde; Ouseten; Westerosede; Owsethen; Kerichosede; Clyozede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in documents between 836 and 891.

Name: Oettersdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1302.

Name: Oevel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention circa 1130.

Name: Ohepalu
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241 and belonged to the manor of 'Heinrichshof'.

Name: Ohof
Alternative_Name: Hove to der O; Ohove; Hove tor O; Ohoff; Mohof
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1360.

Name: Ohrsee
Alternative_Name: Ordessem; Ordeße; Ordissa; Ohrse; Orsa; Orssa

Name: Ohrum
Settlement_Description: Settlement at an important ford on the Oker river, first mentioned in Frankish royal annals of 747.

Name: Oidrema
Settlement_Description: Village and manor from the 16th century. In 1534, it was the administrative center of the area.

Name: Oisu
Settlement_Description: Manor and village that were first mentioned in the 15th or 16th century.

Name: Oisterwijk
Alternative_Name: Hosteruuic; Oesterwijc; Ostruic; Oesterwyc; Oisterwijck; Os[terw]ic
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of Oisterwijk may date from before 1167. According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, however, it is uncertain whether this is the first mention of Oisterwijk. The subsequent mention they have recorded dates from 1214 (Cox records a mention from 1212).
Town_Description: Town rights were granted on 25 November 1230 by Henry I, duke of Brabant. There might have been an earlier grant, but Cox states that no consensus exists among historians on that point.

Name: Oker
Alternative_Name: Okerturm; Frau Marien Saigerhütte; Ocker; Oveckerbugge; Ockerbruck; thorn an der Ocker; Ovecker tornhe; Ockerthurm; Okerthurmb
Settlement_Description: Already in the 10th century, mining activity took place on the Rammelsberg. The existing ironworks were united in 1527 by the Duke of Brunswick into the Frau Marien Saigerhütte, next to which a settlement of previously itinerant miners developed. A watchtower of Goslar, the Okerturm, is first mentioned in 1530.
Toll_Description: Toll was levied at the Okerturm watchtower.
Harbour_Description: The Oker was made navigable up to the Okerturm in 1577.

Name: Oldebroek
Alternative_Name: in den Broke; Hollenderbroock; Audenbroeck; Hollanderbroec; in den Oldenbroick; Hollanderbroek; Aldebroick; Oldebroeck
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1277, in a fifteenth century copy.

Name: Oldenburg (Holstein)
Alternative_Name: Antiquae civitatis; Oldenbourg; Bramione; Brandenhuse; Stargard; Aldinburg; Altenburch; Oldenburch; Aldenburc; Oldenborch
Settlement_Description: Slavic fortification, built in the second half of the 7th century. It became seat of a bishop in 968. After the destruction of the fort in 1148/49, the market settlement next to it expanded.
Town_Description: Adolf IV of Schauenburg granted Lübeck town privileges around 1233, confirmed in 1260 and 1392.

Name: Oldenburg (Oldenburg)
Settlement_Description: Residence of the counts of Oldenburg from ca. 1150.
Town_Description: Bremen town privileges were granted in 1345, but the settlement already had an urban character before: fairs and burghers are first mentioned in 1243, a magistrate court around 1300, and a council and town seal in 1307.
Toll_Description: An agreement from 1243 grants merchants from Bremen exemption from tollsin Oldenburg and free conduct. Oldenburg citizens complained in 1383 that the Count had increased the tolls to be paid by citizens from Bremen, Wildeshausen and Friesoythe. More specific toll amounts are known from the 15th century (1428) for beer, salt, oil, corn and other commodities.
Staple_Description: An agreement with Bremen limited the trade of merchants from Bremen and Westfalia in Oldenburg to the fairs on St Vitus and St Margaret. This restriction was removed in 1278, but there still existed the obligation for external merchants travelling through town to offer their commodities for sale on the market.
Fair_Description: Two fairs in Oldenburg are mentioned in an agreement between Oldenburg and Bremen from 1243, on St Vitus and St Margaret. These two markets are also mentioned in 1307, together with a fair on St Lambert (17-9), and in the town privileges from 1345, no less than seven fairs are mentioned. However, it is the question whether these were organised for a long time: in the 15th century, only St Vitus's and St Margaret's fairs are still mentioned. In the "Verordnung wegen der Oldenburger Krahmer-Marckte" from 1608, it is mentioned that there were four traditional fairs. However, older evidence for the two additional markets, on St Michael and Quasimodogeniti, is not known.

Name: Oldendorf (Zeven)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1254 in a donation to the monastery Zeven. In the 15th century, the settlement must have been abandoned; it was resettled with farmers by the monastery Zeven.

Name: Oldendorf (Luhe)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1406; a water mill is mentioned in 1511.

Name: Oldenrode
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1302.

Name: Oldenstadt
Settlement_Description: Bishop Bruno of Verden founded a house of canonesses before 973, around which a settlement developed. In 1133/37 the monastery was converted into a Benedictine monastery by monks from Corvey. Around 1260 the settlement was moved 2 km to the west bank of the Ilmenau and became the town of Uelzen. The monastery remained at the original location and became known as Oldenstadt. It owned several properties in and around Uelzen as well as shares in the Lüneburg saltworks. The monastery was abolished after the Reformation in 1529.

Name: Wöhrden
Alternative_Name: Altenwöhrden; Oldenwöhrden; Süderwöhrden; Worden; Oldenworden; Wurden
Settlement_Description: The settlement was built on an artificial mound ('wurt'), had a harbour and acquired market privileges in 1373. It was also known as Altenwöhrden to discern it from other settlements built on artificial mounds.

Name: Oldenzaal
Alternative_Name: Aldenselen; Aldensele; Oldenzeel; Aldensela; Oldenzele; Oudesael; Oudensael; Aldensael; Oldenzale; Aldenzele; Oildenzael; Oldenzall; Audenzeel; Oldensale
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 806-809. Next mention in 893, in a copy dating from 1222. Next mention in 1049 , in a twelfth century copy.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted by bishop Otto III between 1 February 1233 and 27 March 1249.

Name: Oldersum
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1381. There were two castles here, of which one was rebuilt after they were destroyed by Hamburg at the end of the 14th century.

Name: Bad Oldesloe
Settlement_Description: Oldesloe came into existence near saltworks, which are first mentioned before 1152. The church existed in 1163 at the latest.
Town_Description: Oldesloe received town privileges in the 13th century, possibly before 1249. An exact date is unknown.
Toll_Description: Toll of the counts of Holstein, first mentioned in 1175. Lübeck citizens were exempted from the toll in 1226 (confirmed in 1247), but were still required to pay a fee for safe conduct. Bremen citizens were also exempted from the toll in 1347, 1396 and 1494. Because these exemptions greatly reduced the toll revenues, a "new" toll was installed in 1474, whereby the fee for safe conduct was raised to the height of the old toll. Dutch towns complained to Lübeck in 1479 about the raise of toll tariffs from 4 to 7 shilling, equally on the Stecknitz canal. Bremen and Hamburg complained in 1511 about illegal toll levying in Oldesloe. Between 1340 and 1495, the toll was often partially or completely pawned to Lübeck.
Fair_Description: In some years, the fair Kieler Umschlag was held in Oldesloe. See Kiel for more information.

Name: Oldisleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in the records in the founding record of a Benedictine monastary by Kunigunde of Weimar-Orlamünde. The settlement is probably older, though. Occasional mention as town in the 13th century (1245, 1255), it never grew to be more than a marketplace ('Marktflecken') however.

Name: Olfen
Alternative_Name: Ulfloo; Ulfloa; Ulflaon; Ulflon; Olffen; Ulflethe; Oflen; Uflen; Olfnen; Ulphen; Olflon
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 889. In 1589, Prince-Bishop Ernst von Münster is said to have had given 'Wigbold' rights. As a 'Wicbold' mentioned again in 1592, 1601 and 1790.

Name: Olpe
Settlement_Description: The settlement goes back to a main courtyard of the Cologne church, which was first mentioned in 1120. The village itself is said to have arisen only at the beginning of the 14th century.
Town_Description: Received 1311 town rights after those of the citizens of Attendorn. Confirmation 1368.

Name: Olsberg
Alternative_Name: Olsberge; Olberge; Oelsberge; Oylßbernn; Olsbern; Olsperg; Oelsbern; Olspornn; Oelßbornn; Olsborn; Olßbern; Oilsperge; Olßbern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1280 and 1285.

Name: Olst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Holsto' in 947. Earliest mention of 'Olst' in 1235.

Name: Olvenstedt
Settlement_Description: In 826-53 Corvey monastery already owned property in Olvenstedt. The church in Olvenstedt is already mentioned in the 10th century. Since 1287 a noble family can be proven in Olvenstedt.

Name: Ommen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from before 13 June 1133. Ommen came into being around 1100 near a ford in the Overijsselse Vecht.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted by Otto III of Holland, bishop of Utrecht, on 25 August 1248.

Name: Ommerschans
Alternative_Name: Ommer Schants; Ommer Schans; d'Ommerschants; D'Ommer Schans; OmmerSchans
Settlement_Description: A fortification ('schans') in the marshes near Avereest was built by the estates of Overijssel in 1596.

Name: Ontika
Settlement_Description: Manor and village, which were property of the Teutonic Order in the 15th and 16th centuries.

Name: Oordegem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1160, in a twelfth century copy.

Name: Oosteeklo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1226.

Name: Oosterbeek
Alternative_Name: Ostarbac; Ostarbeke; Oesterbeke; Osterbeke; Osterbech; Ostrebeke; Oesterbeec
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 834 in an eleventh century copy. The next mention dates from 1028 in a copy dating from circa 1530.

Name: Oosterwolde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention at the end of the thirteenth century.

Name: Oosterzee
Alternative_Name: Eastersee; Oosterzee-Buren; Eastersea-Buorren; Osterse; Oesterze; Oisterzee; Oesterzee; Aestersee
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1132, in a falsification of the second half of the thirteenth century.

Name: Ootmarsum
Alternative_Name: Othmarshem; Otmerschem; Oetmersem; Odmersum; Oetmerssem; Otmaersen; Ootmerssum; Otmarsum; Oedtmaersheim; Oetmershem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 919-977 or 962-977 (in a fifteenth century copy).
Town_Description: On 1 July 1325, Jan III of Diest, bishop of Utrecht, granted town privileges similar to other towns in the area called Overijssel. Before 1325, Ootmarsum had 'Wigboldrecht', a limited type of town rights which is mainly found in Westphalia.

Name: Ophemert
Alternative_Name: Hamaritda; Hameritte; Hamirte; Hemerthe; Hemert; Ophemert; Op Hemert
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 800-850, in a copy dating from 1170-1175. Next mention in 1007.

Name: Opijnen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1265.

Name: Opoeteren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 952. Next mention in 1368.

Name: Oppin
Settlement_Description: Mention as early as 952 in the context of an exchange of property. A noble family of Oppin in known.

Name: Oranienburg
Alternative_Name: Bötzow; Bochzowe; Botzow; Buczow; Bötzow; Siedlung
Settlement_Description: An ascanian castle existed around 1200, a village close by is mentioned in 1217, possibly based on a slavic settlement, mentioned as stedeken in 1350
Town_Description: Possibly never made into a town, a new privilege from 1548 after a fire doesn't state town law

Name: Orlamünde
Settlement_Description: The settlement emerged in the 11th century near the castle of the lords of Weimar-Orlamünde.
Town_Description: Die awarding of town rights by landgrave Frederick II. of Thuringia can be seen between 1344 and 1349.
Toll_Description: The income from the fees of safe conduct ('Geleitseinnahmen') in Orlamünde is high enough to assume that long-distance-trade passed through here

Name: Ortrand
Settlement_Description: A sigil from the 13th century remains. Develops into a marketplace.
Town_Description: Referred to as oppidum.
Fair_Description: Since 1535 Ortrand held two fairs.

Name: Oschatz
Settlement_Description: Before 929 the settlement was situated in close proximity to a castle and its rampart, which later became the manor. Around 1150 the old market was created.
Town_Description: The expansion of the town took place in the 13th century. In 1246 the place was first mentioned as 'town' ('Stadt').
Toll_Description: Regulations of safe conduct remain from 1516 and 1552.

Name: Oschitz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1333.

Name: Osdorf
Alternative_Name: Hamburg-Osdorf; Oslevesthorpe; Osleuestorp; Oseleuestorph; Oslevesdorp; Oslevestorpe; Ostorpe; Ostorp; Ostorffe; Ostorppe; Ostorff; Osdorp; Oßdorp
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1268.

Name: Oslebshausen
Alternative_Name: Osleveshusen; Osleveshuse; Oslingeshusen; Osselveshusen; Osselckshusen; Ochselshausen; Osshusen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 860.

Name: Osnabrück
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in ca. 772. The cathedral, which belonged to the bishopric founded by Charlemagne, was probably dedicated in 787. The merchant settlement acquired market, toll and minting privileges in 1002.
Town_Description: Characterised as "civitas" since 1147. Emperor Frederick I granted town privileges to Osnabrück in 1171.
Toll_Description: The bishop of Osnabrück levied a market toll since the foundation of the market. A third part of the toll which was levied on the "new" fair on the Exaltation of the Holy Cross was ceded to the cathedral chapter in 1190. The toll of the fair on the cathedral square is mentioned in 1242 as "thelonium cimiterii". From 1359 the toll was mostly leased out, with the exception of the toll on salt. The latter was finally also leased to the burgomaster in 1487. The citizens of Osnabrück were exempted from toll payments between 1388 and 1424.
Fair_Description: The oldest fairs in Osnabrück went back to the market privilege of 1002. Before 1190, two four-day fairs are mentioned, the "Herrenmesse" of the Dedication of the cathedral on St Crispin and Crispinian, and on mid-Lent. From 1190, a third fair, the "new fair" was held on the Exaltation of the Holy Cross, which disappeared in the late 15th century. The large fairs were especially important as markets for the locally produced cloth, and attracted visitors from as far as Bremen, Lippstadt, Dortmund, Wesel, Xanten and Deventer. Smaller fairs of a single day were held on the dedication days of the churches of the Franciscan, Dominican, Augustinian and Teutonic knights' monasteries.

Name: Ossendorf
Alternative_Name: Ossenthorpe; Ossenthorp; Ossonthorp; Ossendorp; Ossindorp; Ussendorp; Ossendorpff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Ossendrecht
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1187, in a copy dating from 1277.

Name: Ostbevern
Alternative_Name: Bevern; Bervarnon; Beuerne; Ostbeveren; Ostbeueren; Osbeueren
Settlement_Description: The place originally belonged to Bevern until the parish was divided into East and West Bevern in the middle of the 13th century. Ostbevern was first mentioned in 1279.

Name: Osteel
Settlement_Description: The church in Osteel was built between 1260 and 1285. The village itself was first mentioned in 1387.

Name: Ostendorf
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1146.

Name: Ostenholz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in ca. 950.

Name: Osterburg
Settlement_Description: Former Slavic settlement. In the 10th cenutry probably castle village. In 1196 property in Osterburg is given to the archbishop of Magdeburg.
Town_Description: In 1164 the village is first referred to as "urbs".
Toll_Description: In 1287, the old city of Osterburg is referred to as toll station.
Fair_Description: In an official schedule from 1719, Osterburg, Arendsee and Bismark each held six fairs. It can be assumed that some of these had existed for a while to this point. Ware markets, fairs and cattle markets are mentioned earlier.

Name: Osterhagen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1257.

Name: Osterhausen
Settlement_Description: 772, 777, 780 übergibt Karl der Große Königskapellen in Osterhausen an das Kloster Hersfeld.

Name: Osterholz (Scharmbeck)
Settlement_Description: The Benedictine nunnery Osterholz was founded east of Scharmbeck in 1182. In 1550 the monastery became Protestant, with a short return of Catholic nuns during the Thirty Years' War. In 1650 the monastery was closed.

Name: Osterholz (Elbe)
Settlement_Description: First mention of the settlement in 1337.

Name: Ostercappeln
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1200. In the 16th century the settlement developed into a borough ('weichbild'), but is still characterised as 'villa' in 1512.

Name: Osterlinde
Alternative_Name: Lindethe; Lindedhe; Parvo Lindedhen; Parvo Lindete; Osterlyndede; Negheren Linde; Lütken Linde; Lütken Linden
Settlement_Description: The attribution of the placenames "parvo", "negheren" and "lütken" ('little') Linden to Osterlinde is not entirely certain; these could possibly refer to Westerlinde.

Name: Osternburg
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned on 6 December 1404 in a sale contract.

Name: Ostróda
Settlement_Description: A castle of the Teutonic Order was first mentioned in 1332, later the see of a 'Pfleger' of the Order and in 1341 the see of a komtur, since 1525 of a senior civil servant (Amtshauptmann)
Town_Description: Founded with Kulm town law between 1327 and 1330 by the Grand Master Luther von Braunschweig, the founding documents are lost, but a first renewal from 1335 and a second from 1348 exist

Name: Osterode am Harz
Alternative_Name: Osterode; Osterodenses; Hosterroth; Osterrothe; Osterrode; Hosterrod; Osterot; Osterroth; Osterrodh; Osteroda; Osterode (Harz)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1136; a castle is first mentioned in 1153.
Town_Description: Osterode became a town in 1239 at the latest. Goslar town privileges were granted in 1293. The town became an important centre for mining activity in the Harz mountains.
Toll_Description: A toll in Osterode is mentioned in 1334. In the 17th century, it probably did not exist anymore.

Name: Osterwieck
Settlement_Description: The name of the village points toward a higher age than the first mention. Osterwieck can possibly be equated with the foundation of Seligenstadt monastery in 781. The settlement gained market-, coin- and toll rights in 974, but these are not mentioned anymore from the 11th century on.
Toll_Description: In 1456 toll was collected illegally from a citizen of Hildesheim.

Name: Oosthuizen
Alternative_Name: Asthusa minore; Luttickoisthusen; Oesthusen; Oosthusen; Oosthuysen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the twelfth century, in a copy dating from circa 1420.

Name: Ostingersleben (Ingersleben)
Settlement_Description: First mention around 1150.

Name: Ostinghausen
Alternative_Name: Osedinchusen; Oestinch; Oystinchusen; Oistinckhausen; Oistinckhuißen; Oestinghausen

Name: Oostmalle
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1194.

Name: Ostönnen
Alternative_Name: Hostinen; Ostunnen; Tunnen; Oystune; Ostünen; Oisthonnen; Ostümmer; Ost-Tonne

Name: Ostritz
Settlement_Description: The old town, that was mentioned in 1245, was situated in close proximity to a castle. There was also a market place. The location on the road between Görlitz and Zittau favored trade.
Town_Description: In 1241 the place was first referred to as 'oppidum'.

Name: Oststeinbek
Alternative_Name: Osterstenbeke; Osterstenbek; Ostersteinbecke; Ostersteinbeck; Oster Steinbeck; Ost-Steinbek
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1255.

Name: Ottendorf-Okrilla
Toll_Description: Station of secondary safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Radeberg.

Name: Ottensen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1310.

Name: Ottergem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1108.

Name: Otterloo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 838, in a eleventh century copy.

Name: Ottersberg
Alternative_Name: Boberg; Boberge; Bocberg; Bethcamp; Bodenstedt; Otterberg; Ottersberghe; Otterberghe
Settlement_Description: The castle Boberg was built by vassals of the archbishop of Bremen around 1180. After some decades, the castle was renamed Ottersberg after the nearby village Otterstedt. A chapel was built near the castle, next to which a settlement developed. It was characterised as borough ('flecken').
Toll_Description: A toll in Ottersberg, from which Bremen citizens were exempted, is mentioned in 1562, but was probably older. In a register from 1586/7, revenues from an oxen, horses, salt and general toll are listed. The modest amounts suggest only limited traffic through Ottersberg.
Fair_Description: Three cattle and horse market were renewed after the Thirty Years' War in 1690, on Wednesday before Carnival, Wednesday before the Holy Week and Wednesday before St Michael. It is unknown whether they were held before the war as well.

Name: Otterstedt
Settlement_Description: The Lords of Otterstedt first appeared in the 12th century.

Name: Ottmarsbocholt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Otze
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1321.

Name: Oud-Alblas
Alternative_Name: Alblas; Otto de Alblas; Talblas; Alblaes; Oude-Alblaes
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1200-1214.

Name: Oud-Diemen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1126. Earliest mention of 'Diemen (Oud)' in 1874. Earliest mention of 'Oud Diemen' in 1913.

Name: Oud Reemst
Alternative_Name: Reemssche plakken; Remsterwech; Reymsche placken; Riemscher weg; Rempst; Remst; Reems; Oud-Reemst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1427.

Name: Oud-Leusen
Alternative_Name: Oudleusen; Lusne; Lusnen; Loesen; Luesne; Losene; Luesene; Leussen; Leusen; Luessen; Lussen; Old Luessen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1311.

Name: Oldeouwer
Alternative_Name: Alde Ouwer; Ouderuwer; De Ouwer; Antiqua huer; Oldenoever; Olde Huw; Oppa ower; Oudeouwer
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the thirteenth century.

Name: Ouwsterhaule
Alternative_Name: Ousterhaule; Haula; Oesterhaule; Owsterhaule; Haule; Oosterhaule
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the thirteenth century.

Name: Overasselt
Alternative_Name: Over Asselt; Asle; Assele Superioris; Assele; Ouerassel; Overassel; Averasselt; Over Asselen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the first quarter of the thirteenth century. In 1258, Overasselt is mentioned as 'de Assele Superioris'.

Name: Over-Diemen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1341.

Name: Overmere
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1307.

Name: Overpelt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1261.

Name: Overschie
Alternative_Name: Skie; Schi; Scie; Scyhe; Vetus Sciedammum; Ouder Scie; Ouwerschie
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the first half of the eleventh century .

Name: Paatna
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241 and belonged to the manor of Peuth.

Name: Pada
Settlement_Description: Manor and village (Pada-Aruküla) were first mentioned in 1241.

Name: Padelügger Baum
Alternative_Name: Pluggenbome; Plugghenbome; Schlagkbohm auf dem Stehndam; Moislinger Baum
Settlement_Description: Boom barrier in the Lübeck defensive enclosure ('landwehr'), which was named after the neighbouring manor Padelügge. The enclosure was constructed around 1300.

Name: Paderborn
Alternative_Name: Padrabrunno; Padresbrunnon; Patrisbrunna; Phadrabrunnen; Patresbrunnas; Patherbrunnen; Paderbrunno; Padrabrunnensis; Bodarbrunnensis; Paterebrunne; Boderebronnen; Patherburnensis; Paderburnensis; Parborna; Patherborne
Settlement_Description: Location of a Carolingian palace since 776; seat of a diocese since the 9th century. Around 900 the settlement was characterised as 'oppidum'.
Town_Description: The settlement received market, toll and mint privileges in 1028 at the latest. A town council is mentioned in 1238. In the 13th century, the town freed itself of the overlordship of the bishop and acquired legal freedom, which was recorded in a charter in 1327.
Toll_Description:
There were three tolls in Paderborn:
1) The market toll of the bishop, granted in 1028, was a tax on bought and sold commodities in town. Before 1301, the toll was acquired by the noble Schilder family, in the service of the bishop, and the toll became known as the Schilderzoll. It was probably levied in the Schildern alley, which might have been named after the family and the toll. In the 15th century, the toll was sold to Paderborn citizens and in 1491 to the town. Afterwards it was turned into a road toll.
2) The "small toll" belonged to the family Endehachte, who sold it to the cathedral treasurer in 1311. Further details are not known.
3) A fee for safe conduct, called "gheleyde", owned by the lords of Lippe at the beginning of the 14th century. It was sold to bishop Heinrich III in 1367. According to a 16th-century document, this toll was levied on commodities bought by foreigners in Paderborn territory and transported through town. Inhabitants of the territory were exempted from the toll. Some registers of this toll exist from the 16th century.
Fair_Description: Paderborn acquired market privileges in 1028. The oldest fair was that of St Gallus, which is mentioned in 1327 as taking place in front of the western town gate according to old custom. It was mainly used for agricultural products. A second fair of St John appears in the early 16th century; it was replaced by bishop Erich in 1521 with two new fairs, on the Chair of St Peter and on Mary Magdalene. Both fairs had three free market days before and after the fair day. In the town accounts from 1575, two other fairs, on Annunciation Day and St Nicholas, are mentioned; they might have been introduced after 1521.

Name: Padise
Settlement_Description: The monks of Dünamünde owned land here in the 13th century. A chapel was built in 1281. In 1305 a Cistercian monastery was founded, which could only be inaugurated in 1448 due to uprisings. In 1559 the monastery was closed.

Name: Paistu
Settlement_Description: End of the 13th century a church was built, which was first mentioned in 1329. The pastorate was probably established at the same time.

Name: Pala
Settlement_Description: The manor was built in 1394.

Name: Brieži
Settlement_Description: The village was mentioned in 1637 and belonged to Kokenhof.

Name: Panitzsch
Alternative_Name: Bansz; Bans; Banz; Baynsch; Bancsch; Panczsch; Bantzsch
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1267.

Name: Panten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1158.

Name: Papenburg
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the Lüneburg enclosure ('landwehr'), which was built around 1400. In 1562 an inn was also documented. Around 1830 the inn burned down and was abandoned.

Name: Rubene
Settlement_Description: The parish existed before 1208. The associated church was first mentioned in 1543.

Name: Papendrecht
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1105.

Name: Pape
Settlement_Description: In 1253 the settlement was assigned to the Teutonic Order.

Name: Parchau
Settlement_Description: Property of Berge monastery in 1191, even though St. Nicholai in Magdeburg held property here since 1188.

Name: Parchen
Settlement_Description: In 1144 property of Berge monstary. Mention of a Theodoricus of Parchen as a liege of the archbishop pf Magdeburg in 1196. A romanic church suggests an existence of the settlement in earlier times. Later construction of a castle.
Town_Description: Referred to as oppidum in 1368, in 1389 as "little town" ("Städtchen").
Fair_Description: In 1389 Archbishop Albrecht III granted the settlement two fairs.

Name: Parchim
Settlement_Description: A castle as centre of the settlement in wendish time, german merchants present even before the settlement
Town_Description: 1225 or 1226 founded by Fürst Heinrich Borwin II. von Mecklenburg with its own town law, multiple endorsements until the 18th ct., usually called civitas or town rather than oppidum

Name: Parey
Settlement_Description: Given to the bishopric of Havelberg by Otto I.

Name: Parila
Settlement_Description: Manor owned by the canons of Hapsal.

Name: Parsau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1505.

Name: Partij
Alternative_Name: Torteyde; Torteye; Tyrtei; Tey; Terty; Parthy; Partey
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1364.

Name: Pasewalk
Settlement_Description: a fortress documented in 1150
Town_Description: Magdeburg town law granted around 1250, mentioned in 1276 as a civitas

Name: Passendorf
Toll_Description: Station of safe conduct, metioned in a regulation of safe conduct from 1600.

Name: Pasym
Settlement_Description: Probably grew out of the church village Heinrichswalde
Town_Description: Founded by the Grand Master Konrad Zöllner von Rothenstein with Kulm town law in 1386

Name: Passow (Uckermark)
Settlement_Description: First mention of a castle in 1296, a village develops nearby.
Toll_Description: The castle is a toll station.

Name: Pattensen (Hannover)
Settlement_Description: A traditional first mention from 986-988 as Pathi probably refers to another settlement.
Town_Description: Pattensen probably acquired town privileges in the 13th century.

Name: Patika
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241. From 1280 it was in the possession of the "St. Johannis-Siechenhaus" (probably an old hospital) in Reval. From 1370 to 1505 there was a hamlet ('Wirtschaftshof').

Name: Paunküla
Settlement_Description: Village and Manor that were first mentioned in 1241.

Name: Paupitzsch
Alternative_Name: Pubsch; Pupitze; Pupicz; Pubsch; Puppiczsch; Paupitz
Settlement_Description: First mention of the place in a name; mentioned with a manor house since 1486 (Neuhaus). Deserted and deplaced for a brown coal opencast mine.

Name: Peckelsheim
Alternative_Name: Pykulesun; Pikelsin; Pikilissem; Pickelsen; Pikellessen; Peckelse
Settlement_Description: Originally an old peasant settlement; first mentioned in the early 11th century.
Town_Description: The town was founded with a castle in 1318 and received town rights of Borgentreich, Borgholz and Warburg. 1548 confirmation of town privileges.

Name: Peer
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1107, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Pegau
Settlement_Description: Around 1068 there was a village and a castle belonging to Wiprecht von Groitzsch. Between 1191 and 1196 a monastery was built and founded. Since the end of the 11th century there was a market place. In 1170/90 the place was expanded by a new town.
Town_Description: First referral as 'town'.
Toll_Description: A table of fees ('Geleitstafel') remains from 1619.
Fair_Description: Pegau owned two fairs of old, one of which had to be moved in 1700 due to the day of penance ('Bußtag'). In 1454 and 1561 Pegau tried for additional fairs, which were not granted due to intervention from Leipzig.

Name: Peine
Alternative_Name: Pagin; Pames; Pain; Paane; Peyne; Peino; Paine; Payne; Peina; Peinen
Settlement_Description: A comital family of Peine is first mentioned in the 12th century.
Town_Description: Gunzelin of Wolfenbüttel founded a planned town next to the castle around 1220. It received town privileges in 1223.

Name: Peitz
Settlement_Description: Started as a fishing settlement, in the middle of the 13th ct. a sovereign fortress was built and a german market- and churchvillage grew next to it
Town_Description: Mentioned as a town first in 1301, then in 1336 and 1423, usually in deeds of donation or sale

Name: Penig
Settlement_Description: The village of Altpenig settled on the northern bank. However, in today's existing urban area there was a moated castle. In 1301 Penig received market rights.
Town_Description: Between 1170 and 1329 the town was expanded by the Lords of Altenburg. In 1227 the place probably received town rights. In 1455 they were confirmed by Georg zu Leisnig.

Name: Pennigbüttel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1216.

Name: Perila
Settlement_Description: The manor and village were mentioned in 1241. The St. Michaelis monastery in Reval owned the Folwark of Pergel together with the village and mill in 1286.

Name: Perleberg
Alternative_Name: Parleberghe; Parleberg; Parleberge; Parlebergh; Berleberg; Berleberge
Settlement_Description: Used to be a Slavic settlement, a German castle was built around 1137, a small German settlement grew close to the church of St Nicholas, oldest market of the area is close by with a bigger German market settlement
Town_Description: Most likely founded around 1200 by the lords of the castle and the land, initiated by the merchants of Salzwedel
Harbour_Description: The Stepenitz was used as a waterway between Perleberg and the Elbe in Wittenberge, as is derived from the establishment of a Stepenitz toll on river transport in Wittenberge in 1337.

Name: Pärnu
Settlement_Description: From 1242 to 1263 Alt-Pernau was the episcopal centre ('Bischofssitz'). A castle of the Teutonic Order ('Deutscher Orden') was built on the left bank of the Pernau, around which Neu-Pernau settled. In the Medieval times, due to the location on the river, there was extensive trade relations with Fellin and Dorpat as far as Russia.
Town_Description: In the 14th century, the city received town rights of Riga and became a member of the Hanseatic League ('Hansebund').

Name: Liepupe
Settlement_Description: The settlement and manor were first mentioned in 1372. In 1490 an Inn is mentioned. In 1544 a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built.

Name: Petersberg (Halle)
Settlement_Description: Around 1000 a chapel was built from which Slavs were attempted to be proselitysed. The chapel had its high time in the 11th and 12th century, after that it declined in meaning but remained a popular pilgrimage site.

Name: Petershagen (Weser)
Alternative_Name: Petershagen; Petershaggen; Petershag; Hokelve; Hokeleve; Huculbi; Huculvi
Settlement_Description: Near the settlement Huculvi / Hokelve, already mentioned in 784, the bishop of Minden built the castle Petershagen in 1306; the associated settlement acquired borough ('weichbild') privileges around 1360.
Toll_Description: Emperor Charles IV granted Petershagen toll privileges in 1377. The toll is mentioned in lists of Weser tolls in 1584 and 1597. A register of toll receipts is still extant for 1565/66 (Landesarchiv NRW, KDK Minden Nr. 2607).

Name: Petkum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century

Name: Pöide
Settlement_Description: Village, which was situated around the chapel that was built in the middle of the 13th century.

Name: Peutie
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1211.

Name: Brody
Settlement_Description: The village grew out of a small castle hamlet, it was still a parish village in 1346
Town_Description: No official founding date, belonged to the 'Städtische Gerechtigkeiten' since the second half of the 16th ct., usually called town or 'Städtlein'

Name: Pikknurme
Settlement_Description: In 1560 the mill and other parts of the village burned down.

Name: Baltiysk
Alternative_Name: Pillau; Балти́йск; Seestadt Pillau; Pille; Pillaw; Königliche Stadt Pillau
Settlement_Description: During the time of the Teutonic Order, any fishing villages were founded, in 1413, 1476 and 1583, an entrenchment was built in 1625

Name: Piiumetsa
Settlement_Description: The manor and village were first mentioned in 1423. In 1593 there was also a mill.

Name: Piringen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1224.

Name: Pirna
Settlement_Description: There was a Slavic pre-settlement. In the 11./12th century a castle was built. Close to that, there were two fishermen's settlements and a market place since 1200, which was further expanded.
Town_Description: Margrave Heinrich der Erlauchte conferred 'Magdeburgisches Recht' (privileges) between 1234 and 1245.
Toll_Description: The toll on the Elbe in Pirna is first mentioned in 1269 and was closely connected to the staple. It was regulated quite minutely, as well as the duties of the ferrymen. The fee registry mentions that whatever cannot be found listed, should be looked for in the list of Königsstein (Elbe). The registry differentiates between the safe conduct on the water and by land. Returning boats were exempt from the toll. The regulations of safe-conduct do not mention rafts, which leads to believe that traffic with large transport rafts only began from Pirna. It appears to be the starting point of trade down the Elbe river.
Staple_Description: Originally only for salt and grain and for compulsory exchange of goods; later a general staple. Staple first noted in 1291 upon sale of the town; confirmed in 1325. In 1520 and 1565 merchants from Dresden partially excepted.

Name: Pißdorf
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conducht ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Köthen.

Name: Platenlaase
Settlement_Description: Originally called Lase, the addition Platen- (after the location near the settlement Plate) dates from modern times to discern the settlement from Laase. In 1450, the village consisted of 6 farms.

Name: Płoty
Settlement_Description: A wendish settlement with a castrum. Some arabic coins from the 10th ct. have been found.
Town_Description: The town was granted Lübeck town law by the knight Dubislaw von Woedtke in 1277, so it must have been founded before that point.

Name: Plathe
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1318.

Name: Plattenburg
Settlement_Description: First mention of the castle occurs in 1319 when it is sold to the bishop of Havelberg, but it was probably already constructed in the 13th century.

Name: Plau am See
Town_Description: Founded by Fürst Heinrich Borwin I. around 1225, Parchim town law granted before 1235

Name: Plaue (Gera)
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed to a village with a church and a castle.
Town_Description: Town rights were probably granted in the first half of the 14th cenutry. In 1335 market rights after of the Mühlhausen model were granted. Referred to as "town" ('stat') in 1346.
Toll_Description: Revocation of the toll in Plaue by king Louis IV, called the Bavarian.

Name: Plaue (Havel)
Settlement_Description: First mention of Plaue in a record from 1198, which means it was probably founded soon after the uprising of the Wends ('Wendenaufstand') in 1147. Mention of the castrum Plaue in 1324.
Town_Description: 1411 mention as town.
Toll_Description: Toll- and safe conduct fees proven since 1334, when the toll and safe conduct are pawned off by the archbishop of Magdeburg. After 1575 the bridge toll is abolished and the maintenance of the bridge and dam had to be paid from the income of the regular horse- and walking fee ('Pferde- und Fußzoll'). A toll registry ('Geleitstafel') remains from 1626.
Fair_Description: In 1559 a council scale and two fairs are granted to Plaue.

Name: Plauen
Settlement_Description: A castle was built before 1122. In 1244 a stone bridge over the 'Elster'.
Town_Description: Heinrich IV. of Weida founded a new town around 1230/40 which was referred to as 'civitas'.
Toll_Description: The safe conduct in Plauen controlled the road from Hof and Nürnberg to Leipzig.
Fair_Description: The fair in Plauen is mentioned in the regulation of safe conduct, in which a toll had to be paid on the day of the fair.

Name: Plaußig
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as manor in 1275; dince 1393 mentioned as knightly manor.

Name: Plön
Alternative_Name: Plunie; Plyn; Plune; Plon; Plone; Ploen
Settlement_Description: Slavic fortification, built around 900, destroyed in 1139. Around 1156, the castle was rebuilt by count Adolf II of Holstein. Around the same time, a market and church settlement came into being.
Town_Description: Lübeck town privileges granted by Count Adolf IV in 1236.

Name: Plötzkau
Settlement_Description: First mention of a count of Plötzkau in 1069, the castle changes ownership several times until the 19th century.

Name: Pogeez
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1228.
Toll_Description: In 1424, it is mentioned that a toll was levied on timber cargoes in Pogeez. It is unknown whether the toll was levied on other commodities as well.

Name: Pohnsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1295.

Name: Põlgaste
Settlement_Description: The village and the associated Manor were first mentioned in 1628.

Name: Polatsk
Alternative_Name: Polock; Polozk; Polazk; Plotzkow; Polotsk; Polatsk; Polockas; Połock; Полацк
Staple_Description: Grand Duke Witold attempted to turn Polozk into a trading centre between Riga and Smolensk. In 1406 the town aquired the right to trade beyond Riga and to supercede the rights of Riga. An actual staple was erected in 1498; Germans forbidden to engage in minor trade and to travel beyond Polozk to Smolensk and Witebsk.

Name: Połczyn-Zdrój
Settlement_Description: A wendish fishing village was demised to the knight Bartholomeus de Poliz in 1249-1254
Town_Description: Brandenburg town law was most likely granted in 1335 by the sons of Wartislaw IV. It was mentioned as a town in 1337 and was granted Lübeck town law in 1515.

Name: Pommoissel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1283.

Name: Poppenburg
Settlement_Description: Originally a royal manor at a crossing of the Leine river, which was given to the bishop of Hildesheim in 1049, who erected a castle here (first mentioned in 1227).
Toll_Description: A toll in Poppenburg is first mentioned in 1246. Hildesheim complained in 1459, that a toll was levied on wagon cargoes, where before only toll for horses had to be paid.
Ferry_Description: A ferry is mentioned in 1353, 1381 and 1389. Before 1291 and after 1522, there existed a bridge.
Bridge_Description: A bridge existed here before 1291, when it was destroyed by Hildesheim. In 1522, a bridge is mentioned again. In the meantime, the river crossing took place with a ferry.

Name: Poppenbüttel
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1336.
Harbour_Description: Harbour on the Alster river. In 1618, the Lübeck city council was informed that one should use the waterway between Bergstedt and Poppenbüttel or Fuhlsbüttel on the way to Hamburg, because of closure of the Steindamm street.

Name: Porz
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in 1477. It is possible, however, that a toll had already been levied before this. The toll from 1477 was mentioned as a "new toll". Tariffs and annual revenues are not known.

Name: Poznań
Settlement_Description: Probably a castle existed in the 8th/9th century. Since 968 Poznan was the centre of the bishopric and until 1296 the residence of the Polish dukes. Poznan was first mentioned in 970.
Staple_Description: Staple for the transport of goods from Lithuania, Masovia and the kingdom of Poland. Given in 1394, and confirmed in the Polish Staple Law of 1565.

Name: Pötrau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1158.

Name: Potzehne
Settlement_Description: In 1458 the gift of an altar in Kalvörde is confirmed, which came with income from Potzehne.

Name: Pötzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1237.

Name: Praha
Staple_Description: The privilege of King Wenzel II confirmed the staple rights of the old town, with a ban on guest trading and a stay time of five days where guests were obliged to offer their wares for sale. In 1351 trade with foreign merchants in Bohemia and Moravia was restricted to Prague. Staple for wood in Podskal in 1341; expanded to include citizens of the new town in 1356; staple for salt fish established in the new town in 1367. In 1393 further restrictions on guest trading and obligations to use certain roads; repeated in 1415. Staple rights were never complete (they never covered internal Bohemian trade), but they did include an obligation to offer wares for sale. Privileges renewed in 1497 and 1527, but proved difficult to enforce except for the fish staple in the new town which were mentioned again in 1627 and 1649.
Fair_Description: Market for grain, cattle and coal (new town)

Name: Pratau
Settlement_Description: The settlement was mentioned in a forged record as founded in 965. 1004 mentioned as "urbs", the existence of a castle is proven.

Name: Praviņas
Settlement_Description: The village was mentioned in 1494.

Name: Preetz
Settlement_Description: A church was built around 1150. In 1226, the settlement was placed under jurisdiction of the Benedictine convent, founded in 1211, which moved to the settlement in 1260. Afterwards, the settlement developed into a borough ('flecken'), as which it is characterised in 1513.

Name: Prenzlau
Alternative_Name: Prencelaw; Perenneclave; Perennecele; Printzlaw; Prinzlaw; Prinslawe; Prinzlau; Primizslaw; Primislaw; Prenzlaw; Prentslaw; Premßelow; Prempßlaw; Prempßlow; Prenßlow
Settlement_Description: First emergence of the name in 1187. Before it had already been a Slavic burgward. In 1188 it is already mentioned with a market and an inn.
Town_Description: Foundation of the town and awarding of Magdeburg town rights.

Name: Pretzetze
Alternative_Name: Bretzer; Prezetse; Pritzeze; Pressetze; Pritzecen; Pritzetze; Prytzezen; Prytzetze; Prezeze
Settlement_Description: Village and castle, first mentioned in 1328.

Name: Pretzsch
Settlement_Description: A castle controlled the Elbe crossing. Borough ('Flecken') in 1528. At the beginning of the 16th century a town-like administration existed.

Name: Bagrationovsk
Alternative_Name: Preußisch Eylau; Багратионовск; Yladia; Eylaw; Ilaw
Settlement_Description: A castle of the Teutonic Order was built by Arnolph von Eylenstein under the Grand Master Werner von Orseln (1325-1330), later the see of a 'Pfleger', a parson is mentioned in 1348
Town_Description: After a general privilege was granted in 1348 for many settlements, people asked after a town privilege, which was granted in 1585 by Duke Georg Friedrich in 1585

Name: Debrzno
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 1346 when the Teutonic Order gifted land to 'in campo Fredeland'. A member of the Order (Pfleger) was mentioned there in the same year.
Town_Description: The grand master Winrich von Kniprode granted Kulm town law in 1354, when it was called a 'Stat'.

Name: Pasłęk
Settlement_Description: A house of the Teutonic Order is mentioned in place of a Prussian castle in 1297
Town_Description: The land master of the Teutonic Order, Meinhart von Querfurt, grants a handfast with Kulm town law in 1297, the town was likely founded before that, so it's possibly the renewed founding document

Name: Preußisch Oldendorf
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed from a Carolingian parish. The St. Dionysius' church is mentioned in 996. The settlement acquired borough ('weichbild') privileges in 1692.

Name: Prisser
Alternative_Name: Prieser; Pristire; Prissir; Pritzer; Prittzer; Prißer
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330/52. In 1450, the village consisted of 8 farms, of which one was a mill.

Name: Princenhage
Alternative_Name: Vulgenhagen; Haga; in de Hage; in de Haghe; Haghe onder Nassow ende Haghe onder den Hertoghe; Prince Hage; 's Princenhage
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1198, in a fourteenth century copy.

Name: Pritzwalk
Town_Description: In 1256 the settlement has its town rights confirmed by Margraves Johann and Otto, which makes a foundation of the town in the first half of the 13th century probable.

Name: Prödel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1378. Demolished in 1971-1972 to make place for mining activities.

Name: Profen
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in a record of 1286 as Provin.

Name: Prosigk
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Köthen.

Name: Protzen
Settlement_Description: First mention 1324, probably founded at the beginning of the 13th century.

Name: Pühajõe
Settlement_Description: The manor and village were first mentioned in 1241 and belonged to the Teutonic Order from 1426.

Name: Puiatu
Settlement_Description: The village belonged to the Dünamünde monastery before 1236.

Name: Puide
Settlement_Description: A settlement is already documented in 1218, since a battle of the Germans against Liven and Latvians took place near it. In 1638 it was mentioned as a village.

Name: Pulderbos
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1273 is a copy. Next mention in 1299.

Name: Pulle
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1205

Name: Punschrau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1291.

Name: Purmerend
Alternative_Name: Purmerende; Puurmerende; Purmereynde; Purmereyndt; Purmereijnde; Purmerent; Purmereinde; Purmer
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Purmerend is first mentioned in 1342. Cox states that it was already mentioned in 1327.
Town_Description: A castle and town were founded at the site of the old village Purmered by Amsterdam banker Willem Eggert, treasurer of the count of Holland, after 1410. Between 29 December 1410 and 21 April 1484, Purmerend acquired many town-like features, but there is no single charter that describes an the official grant of town rights. The town acquired further significance as a regional market centre after the draining of the Purmer, Beemster and Wormer lakes in the first half of the 17th century.

Name: Purmerland
Alternative_Name: de Kercke van Purmer; in Purmer ban; Purmerlantsche syde; Purmerlandt; Purmerlant
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1358.

Name: Purtse
Alternative_Name: Purtz; Alt Isenhof; Purdus; Ysse; Isse
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241. In 1421, there is evidence of a manor and a mill.

Name: Pyrzyce
Settlement_Description: The beginnings as a castle are dated back to the 9th ct. Later in the 10th/11th ct. a suburbium grew which later became the wendish castrum that was mentioned in 1140. It likely had a temple. Close to the castle that was destroyed in 1283, Barnim I founded an Augustianian Sister conventual sometime before 1255. A mill existed in 1286.
Town_Description: It was likely already a civitas by 1248. In 1263 Barnim I. granted Magdeburg town law and guild privileges.

Name: Quakenbrück
Settlement_Description: The castle and settlement are first mentioned in 1188. The place was already called "oppidum" (borough) in 1261. In 1383, older borough ('weichbild') privileges were confirmed by the bishop of Osnabrück.
Town_Description: First mentioned as 'stat' (town) in 1360. The town privileges were derived from those of Osnabrück.
Toll_Description: A wine toll of the bishop of Osnabrück is mentioned in Quakenbrück between 1618 and 1620.
Fair_Description: A fair in Quakenbrück is first mentioned in 1509, but possibly older.

Name: Quarnebeck
Settlement_Description: In 1397 the settlement is sold to the lords of Plathe. This Quarnebeck probably has nothing to do with a settlement of Querenbeke which is mentioned repeatedly in 1311, since this Querenbeke is always mentioned in the context of settlements in the Harz.

Name: Quedlinburg
Settlement_Description: The place traces its roots to an old saxonian estate, which is mentioned in 922 as a ludolfing farmyard. In the 10th and 11th century Quedlinburg becomes an important palace for the saxonian kings, after Henry I. is buried here. The saxonian kings like to have their Easter celebration here.
Town_Description: In 1327 the former separated communities of the Old City (founded during 10th century) and the New City (founded during the 12th century) are put together under one council. In 1477 the city succumbs to the regency of the abbess of Quedlinburg monastery, which lets the city lose its autonomy.
Fair_Description: The exact dates of the fairs in Quedlinburg are unknown. One mention occurred in 1585, when a large flood happened during a fair. The exact date of the flood or fair is not mentioned. Because of a plague epidemic a fair on St. Martin's day was cancelled in 1598.

Name: Quelle
Alternative_Name: Cawelle; Kawellen; Kawelle; Canwelle; Nederkawell; Overkawellen; Quille; Queller
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1221.

Name: Quenstedt
Settlement_Description: In 992 king Otto II. gives the villa Quenstedi, among others, to Quedlinburg monastery.
Town_Description: According to reports from the early 19th century, Quenstedt held the privileges and appearance of a small town quite early with town walls, a town hall and even a fair. In 1636 during the 30-year-war the settlement was utterly destroyed in a fire and was deserted for 14 years, which leads to assume that it couldn't restore its former status.

Name: Querfurt
Settlement_Description: The settlement is mentioned in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis in 899. 979 the castle (Quernuordiburch) is mentioned.
Town_Description: Town rights are probably granted before 1198.
Toll_Description: In 1514 there is an escort ('Geleitsmann') in Querfurt.
Fair_Description: During the 30-year war the fair stopped, but was reopened in 1650.

Name: Quetzdölsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in a gift certificate by the margrave of Meißen to the Cistercian convent Marienkammer (register of the record-directory of the convent of St. George's of Glaucha at Halle a.S. (printed in v. Dreyhaupt).

Name: Quitzöbel
Settlement_Description: Former Slavic settlement which was occupied by the family of Quitzow after 1147.

Name: Raalte
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1123 in a falsification of the second half of the twelfth century.

Name: Rabber
Settlement_Description: Year of first reference was 1033.

Name: Räbel
Settlement_Description: A record mentions the settlement in 946, it might be forged though. First secure mention in 1150.
Ferry_Description: In 1499 the family of Kröcher was given village and ferry of Räbel as fiefdom. In 1583 the ferrymen of Räbel had established a wagon ferry, with which they had to come to an agreement with the cathedral chapter of Havelberg, on whose lands they landed.

Name: Rabenstein
Settlement_Description: The written record on Rabenstein castle begins in 1248, but it was probably founded in the 12th century. It changed owner and was destroyed several times during the Middle Ages and Early Modern times but is used until today.

Name: Raddenfort
Settlement_Description: According to the Schmettau map of Mecklenburg-Schwerin, the old village was located northeast of the current settlement.

Name: Radeburg
Settlement_Description: The origin of the place was the farming village on a ford through the 'Röder', which was built after 1150.
Town_Description: First referral as 'oppidum' in 1289.

Name: Radefeld
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1350.

Name: Radegast
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1323.

Name: Radegast (Zörbig)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in two records from 1244 (CDA 2, nr. 160 & 161), the road from Magdeburg to Leipzig crossed the Fuhne here. Since 1727 the settlement owned market rights.

Name: Radevormwald
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll around 1459. This toll station is known from a complaint by traders against this very toll. In 1555, the toll was no longer mentioned, which suggests that the toll was removed after the complaint.

Name: Radom
Staple_Description: Insignificant staple, confirmed in the Polish staple law of 1565

Name: Reiu
Settlement_Description: The village and the manor were probably built around 1200. In 1263, the area around Reidenhof was given to Pernau, in 1520 the entire village was owned by Pernau.

Name: Neman
Alternative_Name: Ragnit; Неман; Raganita; Ragneta; Rangnit; Ragain
Settlement_Description: The Teutonic Order built a castle in place of an old Prussian fortress in 1289, it was repeatedly destroyed, but between 1397-1409 fortified as one of the strongest military fortresses of the Order and kept that position of importance, a settlement existed close ot the castle, the founding of a town was planned for 1410 but took long to realise

Name: Ragösen
