Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct of Belzig.

Name: Ragow
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1468; several prehistoric finds show that the settlement existed much earlier.

Name: Rahula
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1241. During the 16th century it was temporarily in possession of the Teutonic Order ('Deutscher Orden'). In 1586 the village burned down, so that the farmers were resettled.

Name: Rahlstedt
Alternative_Name: Hamburg-Rahlstedt; Altrahlstedt; Alten Rahlstädt; Rothuluestad; Radoluestede; antiquo Radolfstede; Olden Radoluesstede; Radolfstede; Radelevestede; Radelstede; Radelefstede; Radelstorppe; Radelefstede; Ralouestede; Radelstede; Ralffstede; Alten Raleffstette
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1212.

Name: Raisdorf
Alternative_Name: Wendeschen Ratwerstorpe; Wendesche Ratwerstorp; Raderstorppe; Raystorp

Name: Ramlingen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1509.

Name: Ramsdonk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1132.

Name: Ranst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1140, in copy dating from 1265. Next mention in 1148.

Name: Rapla
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1241. In 1412 there was a church, mill and a village that were all owned by the Manor of 'Allo'. The village developed into a Borough ('Flecken').

Name: Raasiku
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1254. In 1393 it belonged to the monks of Dünamünde and later to the Padis monastery. A hamlet ('Hof') was built in 1497.

Name: Kętrzyn
Settlement_Description: A castle built by the Teutonic Order in 1329, a german settlement grew close to it, it was called oppidum in 1345, the first settlement was destroyed by Lithuanians and rebuilt as a fortified town
Town_Description: Johann Schindekopf, the komtur of Balga, granted the new town a handfast with Kulm town law in 1357, it was renewed in 1378

Name: Ratekau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1163.

Name: Rathenow
Alternative_Name: Rathenav; Ratenowe; Ratenhow; Ratinow; Rottenaw; Rathenau; Rathenow; Rathenowe; Ratinowe; Rotinow; Rotnaw
Settlement_Description: Rathenow was a castle district in 1216.
Town_Description: Since the 2nd half of the 13th century Rathenow was expanded to town, during which the village of Jederitz and the farmstead Rodewalde are incorporated. In 1288 jurisdictional rights, and in 1319 coin rights are granted. 1295 Brandenburg town rights are confirmed. Mentioned in 1288 as civitas, in 1350 as town.
Toll_Description:
A toll in Rathenow is first mentioned in the survey ('landbuch') of the Mark Brandenburg from 1375, and often mentioned in the 15th century. A shipping toll is first explicitly mentioned in 1559, when a new lock was built in Rathenow. Next to the fee for using the lock, a toll had to be paid.
Since 1536 a bridge toll was collected.
Fair_Description: During a conflict between the cobblers of Tangermünde and Rathenow, the fairs of Rathenow are mentioned.

Name: Ratzeburg
Alternative_Name: Razesburg; Raceburg; Raceborgh; Raceborg; Razispurg; Racesburch; Ratzeborg; Raceburgensis; Racezburg; Raccisburg; Rotzborg; Ratiborja
Settlement_Description: A Slavic castle is first mentioned in 1062. Ratzeburg was a bishopric from 1154 to 1554.
Town_Description: Town privileges were probably granted around 1250. The settlement is first characterised as town in 1261.

Name: Rätzlingen
Settlement_Description: In 1311 property in Retzlingen is mentioned as a fiefdom.

Name: Raudna
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241.

Name: Raukla
Settlement_Description: First referral in 1504.

Name: Rauschenburg
Toll_Description: A toll was levied on river traffic at the Rauschenburg since ca. 1600.

Name: Rebberlah
Alternative_Name: Rebberla; Retberla; Hradebodanle; Krathabodle; Rubberla; Ripperlohe; Reperlohe; Rybberlage; Repperloh; Ribberlahe; Riberloh; Ribberlow
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 990.

Name: Recklinghausen
Alternative_Name: Ricoldinchusun; Rigglenkhuson; Richelinchusen; Ricklinchusin; Recklinghusen; Riclenchusin; Rekelinchusen; Reckelinchusen; Recklinchusen; Riakelkusen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1017, but goes back to a Carolingian castle. In 1236 the place was called 'oppidum'.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted around 1230 and expanded in 1236.

Name: Reddien
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1450/51. An earlier mention from 1330/52 as Reddinghe is uncertain. In 1450, the settlement consisted of 3 farms.

Name: Reek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1510.

Name: Rees
Toll_Description: In 1372, Elector Friedrich of Cologne confirmed the right for the town of Rees to levy customs on all commodities traded in town as well as a road toll in Rees and Haltern, to fund the maintenance of the roads and the town fortifications. A market toll in Rees was levied by the Elector himself. The privilege was confirmed in 1373 and 1388.

Name: Recz
Settlement_Description: A pomeranian castle and the castle complex of the Knights of St John that was mentioned in 1269 could be identical. The castle was in ruins in 1296 and a cistercian abbey was built instead. A slavic fishing village grew close by.
Town_Description: The town was founded after 1284 by the Ascanians with Madgeburg town law. It was supposed to secure the street from Stargard eastward.

Name: Resko
Settlement_Description: A slavic castle mound was the basis for a castle from the beginning of the 13th ct.
Town_Description: Sometime after 1255 Theoderich Horn from Kolberg was supposed to start settlement in the town. The founding privilege with Lübeck town law of the Borckes from 1282 was endorsed in 1288 by Vidante and his sons.

Name: Reher
Settlement_Description: A first mention in 826-876 is not completely certain. The next mention is dated in the mid-13th century.

Name: Rehme
Settlement_Description: First reference from 751.

Name: Rezaka
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1540.

Name: Rehungen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1359.

Name: Reichenbach
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1015.

Name: Reichenbach
Settlement_Description: This small village was first mentioned in 1140.
Town_Description: The town was founded in the 1240s. In 1274 it was referred to as 'civitas'. The 'Magdeburg Law' is documented for 1367.

Name: Reinevere
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1220.

Name: Reinerbeck
Settlement_Description: The village was originally called Dudenhausen, first mentioned in 1304-1324. It was probably abandoned in the late Middle Ages. The name Reinerbeck appears first as the name for a stream in 1510. Later the name was transferred to the village.

Name: Reinickendorf
Settlement_Description: Probably first founded in 1230, the settlement is first mentioned in 1345. In 1397 it is already property of the twin city of Berlin-Cölln.

Name: Reiser
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1292.

Name: Reitwein
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1316.

Name: Remagen
Toll_Description:
1) From 1317 to 1322, the empire levied a river toll on the Rhine in the course of the 'Barach landfrieden'. In 1473, the Archbishop of Cologne is mentioned as the owner, who moved the toll from Bonn to Remagen for a few weeks. Between 1317 and 1322, 9 Turnosgroschen had to be paid for each foder of wine.
2) The Archbishop of Cologne was mentioned as the holder of the pledge of a land toll from 1421.

Name: Remkersleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1144 in records of Berge monastery.

Name: Remlingen (Wolfenbüttel)
Alternative_Name: Remlingen; Remminge; Remmelinge; Remninche; Remninge; Ramnigge
Settlement_Description: The first mention of 986 appears in a falsified charter from 1322. Remains of settlements from the 1st-7th centuries have been found.

Name: Remmels
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1200.

Name: Rendsburg
Alternative_Name: Rendsborg; Reynoldesborch; Reinoldesburch; Renolsburgh; Reyndesborgh; Rendesborch; Reinoldesborgh; Rendesborg; Rendesburgh
Settlement_Description: A Danish castle was built on an island in the Eider river at the end of the 11th century; count Adolf II of Holstein erected a border castle on the same location around 1150, which was first mentioned in 1199. Next to it a town developed.
Town_Description: First named as "civitas" in 1253; Lübeck town privileges must have been granted shortly before.
Toll_Description: Mentioned as toll station of the counts of Holstein in 1443 and 1468. Toll accounts are extant for the year 1541-1704, with lacunae in some years (Landesarchiv Schleswig-Holstein, Schleswig).
Fair_Description: In some years, the fair Kieler Umschlag was held in Rendsburg. See Kiel for further information.

Name: Renkum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 970, in a copy dating from 1480. Next mention in 1031, in a falsificaction dates from middle of the twelfth century.

Name: Rzepin
Alternative_Name: Reppen; Reppin; Ryppin; Reppen; Rewen Reppin; nyen Rhyppin; kleynen Reppin; Nyen Reppen
Settlement_Description: Was founded as a village after the polish invasion in 1326
Town_Description: The Margrave confirms borders and tolls for the town in 1329, always called town, apart from 1350, when it was mentioned as opidum

Name: Reppenstedt
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 1197. Around 1400, a watchtower of the Lüneburg enclosure ('landwehr') was built here. It was called Uhlenburg/Eulenburg. The complex consisted of a tower, a boom barrier and a bridge over a moat. An inn was mentioned in 1562.

Name: Ressen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 673-691, in a falsified copy from the twelfth century. Mentioned as 'in uilla Rexne' at the end of the eleventh century; as 'Rixne' in 1120 in a twelfth century copy.

Name: Rethem
Alternative_Name: Reeten; Rethum; Reythin; Rythum; Rettene; Richtum
Settlement_Description: The castle of Rethem was first mentioned in the 13th century; next to it, three settlements developed. The central settlement was characterised as town ('stat') in 1382 and as borough ('weichbild' or 'flecken') since 1388.
Toll_Description: Water and land toll, first mentioned in the 14th century. The oldest toll tariff, like in Celle, is known from the time around 1560. In this year, the duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg redeemed the toll from the town of Lüneburg, which had held it as a pawn since 1389. The tariffs were raised later, according to a 1576 complaint from Bremen.

Name: Rethen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1189.

Name: Rettmer
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1148.

Name: Retzin
Settlement_Description: Mention in 1489 as Lutken Retzin.

Name: Reusel
Alternative_Name: Rosole; Roselo; Rosule; Rosele; Ruexele; Roesel; Reusele; Reuzel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1173.

Name: Tallinn
Settlement_Description: From an early age, the place was a trading center with a natural harbour and a castle. 1219 possibly the first written reference.
Town_Description: The town was founded in 1230 by the settlement of German traders. However, the city consisted of the cathedral-town ('Domstadt') and the lower city ('Unterstadt'). In 1248 the lower town received the Lübeck town law and in 1252 became a member of the Hanseatic League.

Name: Rhadern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1015 and 1046. 1473, as well as in the 16th century deserted, but settled again from 1567.

Name: Rheda
Alternative_Name: Reide; Retha; Retthe; Rethe; Rithe; Rheden; Rede; Reyde
Settlement_Description: The parish of Rheda is first mentioned in 1086/88. A fortification that existed since ca. 1000 was rebuilt as a stone castle from ca. 1170. Next to the castle a borough ('flecken') was built around 1230.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted in 1355 after the Lippstadt model.

Name: Rhede (Ems)
Alternative_Name: Rhede; Hretha; Hriadi; Redan; Redun; Rhe; Rehe; Rheda; Rehee
Settlement_Description: The place was mentioned for the first time in 829.
Toll_Description: A land and water toll of the bishop of Münster is mentioned in 1564 complaints, among others of East Frisia and the town Wesel, about the levying of an unusual toll on English cloth in Rhede. The bishop responded that the toll had been levied for a long time and it continued to be levied in the 17th and 18th century.

Name: Rhee
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1381-1383.

Name: Ryn
Settlement_Description: A castle of the Teutonic Order was built in 1337 and became the see of a komtur in 1393, a mill was built in the beginning of the 15th ct. and a village grew around 1485, with craftsmen settling, the market hamlet was burned down by the Tartars in 1657

Name: Rheinbach
Toll_Description: In 1343, Beatrix von Schleiden, as Lady of Rheinbach, levied a land toll and a fee for safe conduct on land. In 1345, the toll fell to the Archbishop of Cologne. Horse toll and fee for safe conduct are recorded in 1389/93. In 1396, 2 to 3 alb. per horse had to be paid, depending on the load. In 1422, an additional 1 gulden had to be paid for each foder of wine. In 1389/93, the horse toll and the fee for safe conduct brought in an average of about 497 mark annually. For further tariffs and revenues see source. In 1457 Hilberath was a secondary toll station.

Name: Rheinberg
Toll_Description:
1) The Archbishop of Cologne owned a river toll on the Rhine here. This was levied in 1235, 1279, from 1286 to 1293, 1298 to 1302 and from 1314. In 1314, 4 Turnosgroschen had to be paid per foder of wine, in 1368 it was 10½ Turnosgroschen. For further tariffs see source. In 1368/69 about 7312 sc. (schild) were collected in the year. For other revenues see source. In the year 1279 there is only referred to a fee for safe conduct, in 1302 a river toll and a fee for safe conduct were mentioned.
2) The town of Rheinberg itself levied land toll in 1235. Tariffs are not known. In 1421/22, 33 mark 5 shillings and 9 denarii were collected. At the same time, a road toll was collected in 1290, which, together with the revenues from the land toll, were used to improve the town's fortifications. In the 15th century, the land toll fell to the Archbishop of Cologne.
3) The road toll was first mentioned in 1290.

Name: Rheindorf
Toll_Description: The Count of Berg levied a land toll in 1377. In the same year, ½ alb. per horse had to be paid. In 1411 Rheindorf was a secondary toll station of Mülheim and in 1487 of Dünnwald.

Name: Rheine
Alternative_Name: Reni; Hreini; Reyne; Reini; Rheina; Rene
Settlement_Description: The settlement, going back to a Carolingian 'villa', was first mentioned in 838.
Town_Description: Rheine received Münster town rights from bishop Ludwig II in 1327. They were partially limited in 1627 and extened again in 1632.
Fair_Description: The oldest evidence for fairs in Rheine dates from 1450, when two fairs are mentioned on Dedication Day on the Sunday after the Assumption of Mary and the "cold market" before Christmas. In 1484, two additional fairs are mentioned, on St Dionysius and All Saints' Day.

Name: Rhenen
Alternative_Name: Hreni; Renim; Reni; Rinen; Rijnen; Rienen; Renen; Rene;
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 855.
Town_Description: Rhenen was granted town privileges between 1250 and 1258. This was probably done by Henry I of Vianden, bishop of Utrecht. Rhenen was walled in 1346.

Name: Rhens
Toll_Description: In 1376, the Archbishop of Cologne levied a land toll. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Ribbesbüttel
Alternative_Name: Ricbaldesgebutle; Ricbelesbutle; Ricboldesbutle; Riboldesbutle; Ribesbutle; Rebbesbutle; Ribbeldesbutle; Reybesbuttel; Ribbesbuttel; Ribbesbutle; Rybbüttell; Rybbüttel; Ribbüttel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1007.

Name: Ribnitz
Settlement_Description: A castle and court (Gerichtsstätte) existed in wendish time, court and an inn mentioned in 1210, castle and parish mentioned in 1233
Town_Description: Founded on 1235 by Heinrich Burwyn III. von Rostock, Lübeck town law granted in1257, privileges have been endorsed multiple times, usually called civitas or town

Name: Richtenberg
Settlement_Description: Was a market settlement before it was gifted to the Monastery Neuenkamp at its founding
Town_Description: mentioned in 1297 as oppidum

Name: Riel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1310.

Name: Riemsloh
Alternative_Name: Rimeslo; Rymeslo; Rimello; Rymesloe; Rimesel; Rimslo; Riemschlege; Reineßlohe
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1160.

Name: Riemst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1066 is copy, in an eighteenth century copy. Next mention in 1096.

Name: Riesa
Settlement_Description: During the German Eastern expansion in the 12th century, the previously Slavic area was repopulated. A Benedictine monastery must have been founded shortly thereafter.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted by Johann Georg I. in 1623.
Ferry_Description: According to wagoners, the Elbe was crossed here via ferry.

Name: Riisipere
Settlement_Description: In 1394 a farm in "Rysenberge" was mentioned. In 1598 the place was divided into Old- and New-Riesenberg ('Alt- und Neu-Riesenberg').They were reunited in 1669.

Name: Prabuty
Settlement_Description: The Old Prussian castle was destroyed in 1236, a castle for the bishop of Pomesania was built between 1330 and 1340
Town_Description: The brother of the bishop of Pomesania was the locator of the new town and granted the founding documents between 1285 and 1321, bishop Rudolf himself granted a renewed handfast with Kulm town law in 1330

Name: Riestedt
Settlement_Description: In 777 Charlemagne gives Hersfeld monastery the chapel in Riestedt. Mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis (around 2nd third of 9th century).

Name: Riestedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1006.

Name: Riethoven
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1312-1350.

Name: Rietz
Toll_Description: Saxonian Toll station

Name: Rietze
Alternative_Name: Rithusen; Ridhusen; Ritze; Ruze; Rytze; Rieze
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1196-1197.

Name: Rīga
Alternative_Name: Riga; civitas tho der Righe; Rige; Ryga; Ryge; Riega
Settlement_Description: The settlement was founded in 1201 by Bishop Albert. The first episcopal palatinate was built before 1234. Shortly after 1202 a castle of the Teutonic Order was built, which was destroyed by the Rigans in 1297. A new castle was therefore built in 1330.
Town_Description: German citizens from Gotland and Germany received Gotland town rights in 1211 and Hamburg town rights in 1294/97. In 1350, however, they got their own Rigian town privileges.
Staple_Description: Staple for the trade along the River Duna. The ban on trade in the Semgaller region [?] formed the basis of the Riga staple. In 1229 all merchants given free passage along the Duna, but privilege withdrawn in the 14th century. Overseas merchants not allowed to trade with Smolensk via the Duna, while Russian and Lithuanian merchants not allowed to trade in the Baltic via the Duna. Riga reported to Lübeck in 1468 a ban on guest trading in their city (HR II, 6 n 143). From 1406 merchants from Polozk free from the Riga staple; in return (until 1498) merchants from Riga freed from the Polozk staple.

Name: Rijnsburg
Alternative_Name: Rinasburg; Rinesburch; Rinesburc; Rinesburg; Rinsburg; Rinsburch; Rinsborch; Rynsborch; Reynsburch
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 918-948, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention dates from the beginning of the eleventh century.

Name: Rijsbergen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1159.

Name: Rijssen
Alternative_Name: Risnen; Ryssen; Rysem; Risen; Rijsene; Rysen; Risne; Rijsnen; Rysne
Settlement_Description: Archaeological finds show that there has been a settlement already around the beginning of our calendar era. A permanent settlement probably exists from around 900 onward. Earliest mention in 1188 (in a late thirteenth century copy).
Town_Description: Town privileges granted by Otto III of Holland, bischop of Utrecht, in 1243.

Name: Rijswijk
Alternative_Name: Riiswiic; Risuuic; Riswic; Rysewiic; Ryswijc; Rijswijc
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention probably in the end of eleventh century, in a copy dating from circa 1420.

Name: Rillaar
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1142.

Name: Ringelheim
Alternative_Name: Ringelem; Ringhelmi; Ringilmo; Ringelenheimensis; Ringelim; Ringelen
Settlement_Description: Ringelheim was seat of a local court. In the 10th century, a monastery of canonesses was built here, which was converted to a Benedictine monastery in 1154. The Reformation was introduced in 1568, but it became Catholic again in 1643.
Toll_Description: A toll and safe conduct of the bishop of Hildesheim in Ringelheim was cancelled in 1354. In accounts of the town of Hildesheim, a new toll in Ringelheim is mentioned in 1455, where citizens of Hildesheim had been toll-free before. However, already in 1444 toll for commodities in Ringelheim had also been paid for by Hildesheim.

Name: Rõngu
Settlement_Description: In the 14th/15th century a castle was built, which was first mentioned in 1413. It was burned down in 1558, so that a new castle was built. A village was first mentioned in 1582.

Name: Ringerbrügge
Bridge_Description: On the map Comitatus Bentheim et Steinfurt, auctore Joanne Westenberg (made before 1638), Ringer brugge" is displayed near the village Ringe. It must have indicated a bridge across the Leegraben."

Name: Ringleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 802.

Name: Rinkerode
Alternative_Name: Ririxerode; Rinkenrode; Rinckenrodhe; Rinkenrothe; Rynkenrode; Rynckenrodde; Rinckenradde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 9th century.

Name: Riskau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1450/51. A register from 1684 mentioned 6 farms in the village, of which 3 had been abandoned.

Name: Ristiküla
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1442.

Name: Ritterhude
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1182.

Name: Ritterode
Settlement_Description: First mention as Rodigeresrod in 944.

Name: Ritzerau
Alternative_Name: Ricszerowe; Ritserowe; Rytzerow; Lutken Ritzerowe; Ritzerouwe

Name: Röa
Settlement_Description: The manor and village were mentioned in 1558. In 1639 there was an estate.

Name: Röbel
Settlement_Description: Castle and village were established at the beginning of the 13th ct.
Town_Description: Founded by the Fürsten von Werle in the first half of the 13th ct., record of the endorsement of the Schwerin town law for the civitas from 1261 still exists

Name: Röbbel
Alternative_Name: Röbel; Rapeldestorp; Rebbelestorpe; Robbeldestorpe; Robbelstorff; Robele; Robell
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1158.

Name: Röblingen
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis. Later a ministerial family of Röblingen is mentioned, which has nothing to do with the dynasty of Röblingen.

Name: Roklum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1159.

Name: Rodameuschel
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1227.

Name: Roodu
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241 and was abandoned since 1694. During the 15th century the place belonged to the Teuntonic Order.

Name: Rödelheim
Alternative_Name: Frankfurt-Rödelheim; Radilenheim; Rutilnheim; Rethilnhem; Redilnem; Redilnheim; Redelinheim; Reddelnheim
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 788.

Name: Rödersdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1198.

Name: Roermond
Alternative_Name: Ruremunde; Roremunt; Ruregemunde, Roremonde; Ruremonde; Rurgemunde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1130.
Town_Description: Earliest mention as a town ('oppidum') in 1224. The exact year in which town privileges have been granted is unknown, but this must have been between 16 June 1224 and 22 October 1229 by Gerard IV, count of Guelders.
Toll_Description:
1) The Count of Guelders levied a fee for safe conduct on the Meuse here from 1226/53. A special tariff of 1396 is known for people from Venloe, which determined 3 old groschen per piece of wine. In 1284, 100 mark could be collected. Parallel to this, a river toll also levied, which was probably very closely connected to the fee. Exact tariffs and revenues are therefore difficult to identify.
2) In 1226/53, the Count of Guelders also levied a fee for safe conduct on land. Tariffs are not known. In 1284, 8 mark a year were collected.
Staple_Description: Roermond was granted an eight-day staple in 1372 on goods transported through the Maas river, which was moved to Venlo in 1523. It is being questioned whether this staple right has been very effective.
Fair_Description: Roermond had three fairs: on Tuesday after Pentecost (known since 1294/5), St. Remi and St. Barbara (since 1351). A ducal charter of 1372 extended all fairs in Roermond to 16 days and introduced a fourth fair, of which the date is however unknown.

Name: Rogäsen
Settlement_Description: At the end of the 14th century mention as Ragoesen, in the property of the noble family of Werder for 500 years.

Name: Rogätz
Settlement_Description: In 1144 the village transfers from the counts of Hillersleben to the bishops of Havelberg.
Toll_Description:
In 1405 the archbishop of Magdeburg gains permission from king Wenzel to collect a toll on any ware that is carried to market there. In 1432 the villages of Wolmirstedt, Rogätz ad Jerichow are mentioned as toll stations in the record of a conflict between the council of Magdeburg and the archbishop. Further mentions of the toll in 1460 and 1492.
From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on shipping on the Elbe river.

Name: Roggel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1230.

Name: Rooküla
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241 and was located on an old winter road ('Winterstraße'). A hamlet ('Hof') was built between 1636 and 1684.

Name: Rohrberg
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1212 as a town ('civibus') with citizens ('cives'), but after that only ever referred to as village.

Name: Röhrsdorf
Toll_Description: Station of secondary safe conduct of Chemnitz

Name: Roela
Settlement_Description: Manor and hamlet ('Hof') that were both built in the middle of the 16th century.

Name: Rolde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1232, in a seventeenth century copy.

Name: Römhild
Town_Description: Count Henry IV. of Henneberg-Hartenberg founded the town between 1274 and 1317. In 1321 referred to as town.
Fair_Description: In 1498 Emperor Maximilian confirms three fairs in Römhild, whose dates are moved. A weekly market is moved to Monday.

Name: Römstedt
Alternative_Name: Rimestide; Reinstede; Remstede; Remstide; Romstede; Romste; Rembse; Römbste
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1197.

Name: Rauna
Alternative_Name: Ronneburg; Rowneborch; Runnenborch; Runenburgk; Rawneborch; Ronaeburg
Settlement_Description: The castle was probably built in 1262, but only mentioned in 1381. In 1471 a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was mentioned.
Town_Description: The fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was referred to as a minor town and received town rights of Riga later. They were confirmed in 1590.

Name: Renda
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1230/31 and fell to the Teutonic Order in 1253.

Name: Ronnenberg
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1073.

Name: Roordahuizum
Alternative_Name: Reduzum; Rorthahusum; Rowerda husum; Roerda huijsum; Raerdahusen; Rordhahwsem; Rorthuisen; Rauwerdahuizen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1389.

Name: Straupe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1221/24. The castle was probably built in 1263. 1408 Klein Roop ('Mazstraupe') was separated.
Town_Description: The fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was referred to as town in 1356 and received town rights of Riga in 1374.

Name: Roosbeek
Alternative_Name: Rosbecca; Resbais; Rosbas; Rosbais; Roshebeke; Roosbek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1136.

Name: Roosendaal
Settlement_Description: Roosendaal is first mentioned in 1268. It was elevated to city rank on 3 May 1809 by Louis Bonaparte, king of Holland. This elevation, however, lasted only untill 1814.

Name: Rorichum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Roschütz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1146.

Name: Różyny
Settlement_Description: A castlemound existed close to the town before it was founded
Town_Description: The founding documents of 1305, granted by the Pomesanian diocesan chapter, were lose and renewed with Kulm town law in 1314

Name: Rosenhof
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1480.

Name: Rosmalen
Alternative_Name: Rosmella; Rosmalla; Roesmale; Roesmalen; Rosemale; Roesmael; Roesmaelen; Roosmaelen; Roosmalen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 800-850, in a copy dating from 1170-1175. Next mention in 1295.

Name: Roßbach
Settlement_Description: First mention as 'Rozpach' in 1057. First mention of a manor house in 1196. A parish village with two churches in the Middle Ages, it became the scene of a major battle during the Seven Year's War in 1757, during which the French had to suffer a defeat.

Name: Roßla
Settlement_Description: Between 1186 and 1189 a Frederick "of Rosla" is mentioned, it is not clear if this Roßla is meant, however. In 1341 there is a secure mention, when the counts of Stolberg obtain the village

Name: Roßlau
Settlement_Description: A Slavic water castle at the banks of the Rossel is proven. The house of ministerials ('Ministerialengeschlecht') had its seat in Roßlau since about 1215.
Town_Description: First mentioned as a town in 1382. In 1685 still referred to as borough, too.
Fair_Description: In 1603 two fairs are mentioned.

Name: Roßwein
Settlement_Description: Previously Slavic fishing village, which was settled by Germans in the 12th century. At the end of the 12th century, a margravial-Meissen manor.
Town_Description: First mentioned as 'town' in 1286.

Name: Rostock
Settlement_Description: A wendish village, possibly a fisher- or boatmen-village, destroyed in 1160 after a dispute with Waldemar I. of Denmark, soon after a market settlement of german merchants
Town_Description: Fürst Heinrich Borwin I. endorses the Lübeck town law for the German town Rostock in 1218
Staple_Description: Staple for stockfish from Bergen; in 1446 members of the Hanse only allowed to export flour, malt, and other victuals to Bergen if they brought fish from Bergen back with them to Lübeck, Wismar, Rostock or Stralsund. Regulations from the 15th century indicate a ban on guest trading.

Name: Rotenburg (Wümme)
Settlement_Description: Bishop Rudolf of Verden built the castle Rotenburg around 1195, next to which a settlement developed. In the 15th century it was characterised a borough ('weichbild') as well as minor town ('städtchen'). In 1403, Bishop Conrad III von Verden granted borough rights ('weichbildrechte'), which were extended in 1427.

Name: Rotenburg an der Fulda
Alternative_Name: Rotenburg; Rodenberc; Rudenberc; Rutenberc; Rotenberg; Rothenburg
Settlement_Description: A castle was built around 1150, and an old town was laid out almost 50 years later. Mentioned in 1197 as 'villicus'.
Town_Description: The town was founded around 1200 and named as such in 1248. 1259 'civitas'.

Name: Bad Rothenfelde
Alternative_Name: Rothenfelde; up dem Rodenfelde; Aufn Rahfelde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1512.

Name: Rothenstein
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Breviarium sancti Lulli (Tab. III).

Name: Rotselaar
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1140, in a copy dating from circa 1265.

Name: Rotterdam
Alternative_Name: Rotter dam ter haluer rotte; Rotterdamme; Rotterdam ter haluer Rotte; Bokelsambacht
Settlement_Description: Rotterdam is first mentioned in the period 1280-1287. Rotterdam originates from two seperate settlements, each on either side of the River Rotte. Together, these former settlements make up Rotterdam. In the fourteenth century, Rotterdam grows into a town-like settlement.
Town_Description: Rotterdam was already granted town rights in 1299; however, this grant was soon withdrawn. In the grant of 7 June 1340, by William IV, count of Holland (William II, count of Hainaut), no mention is made of earlier town privileges. One of the smaller ‘Kamers’ (departments) of the VOC (Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie, Dutch East India Company, founded in 1602) was located in Rotterdam.

Name: Rottleberode
Settlement_Description: In Ottonian times an important royal court on the way from Wallhausen to Quedlinburg. Mention of a market in 994. Possibly castle Grasburg was moved from here to Stolberg.

Name: Rottorf
Settlement_Description: The village is first mentioned in a charter of the monastery of St Michael in Lüneburg from 1233.

Name: Rouveen
Alternative_Name: Ruenvhene; Ruwenvene; Ruveen; Ruwenveen; Ruenvene; Ruvene, Roveen; Ruwenveene; Rouvene
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1282.

Name: Roxel
Alternative_Name: Rukeslare; Rokeslere; Rokesler; Roeckslar; Roxler; Rocksler; Roxeler
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1177.

Name: Roxförde
Settlement_Description: The name already occurs in a border description from 786, but in this case a lake or a body of water is referred to. The existence of a settlement can not be ruled out. First secure mention in 1400.

Name: Rozbórz
Alternative_Name: Rozbórz Długi, es gibt daneben auch den Ort Rozbórz Okrągły

Name: Rozendaal
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1317.

Name: Rückmarsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention as Rigmarsdorff in 1250.

Name: Rucksbruch
Settlement_Description: The exact location of the toll station in Rucksbruch is unknown.
Toll_Description: The toll station in the Rucksbruch already existed in medieval times, either from 1355 or 1427. It was moved to Tanne at some point due to the bad condition of the road.

Name: Rudersdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1063.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Eckartsberga.

Name: Rudolstadt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned at the beginning of the 9th century. Emerges from a Slawic settlement. 2 castles are proven in 1264.
Town_Description: The foundation of the town probably occured at the end of the 13th century or at the beginning of the 14th century by the counts of Orlamünde. The denomitation 'town' can be found since 1326.
Toll_Description:
First mention of a street toll in 1397, which is probably collected at the old gate. Count Günther of Schwarzburg is permitted to collect two pennies from each wagon and one Meißen groschen of a heavy wagon with merchants for the protection of the roads.
A toll table from 1638 remains, when the toll was already Schwarzburgian. (ThStA Rudolstadt, Kanzlei Arnstadt 1129, p. 91 f.)
Fair_Description: Two fairs are known before 1404, another since 1465.

Name: Rucphen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1359.

Name: Rühle
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates back to 1350.

Name: Ruhrort
Settlement_Description: Around 1300, there existed a fishermen's settlement on the Rhine island Werth. A castle was constructed here between 1372 and 1380, to secure a toll station.
Town_Description: Ruhrort is first mentioned as town in 1551.
Toll_Description: Count Johann of Moers acquired the right to levy a toll of 4 Turnosen of each fuder wine on an island in the Rhine from Emperor Charles IV in 1371. The toll was shared with the count of Mark in 1572, who constructed the castle Ruhrort to secure the toll station. In 1373, the toll fee was raised to 6 Turnosen. Although the toll was cancelled 1379, the toll rights were confirmed in 1398. The Mark part of the toll was moved to Orsoy between 1405 and 1422. Citizens of Ruhrort were exempted from toll payments in 1437.

Name: Ruila
Settlement_Description: Village that was sold to the Teutonic Order ('Deutscher Orden') in 1346. In the 16th century it was an anbandoned place.

Name: Ruinen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1139, in a sixteenth century copy.

Name: Rūjiena
Settlement_Description: A castle was built between 1260 and 1270. This was about 3 km west of today's town, but was destroyed in 1560. Around the same time that the castle was built, a church was built on the northern bank of the Ruje river. In 1461 a settlement that belonged to the castle was mentioned and was referred to as 'oppidum' in 1516.
Town_Description: In 1516, Rujen was referred to as 'oppidum'.

Name: Rümpel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1342. Also named Groß Rümpel in the 15th century, to discern it from Klein Rümpel (currently Höltenklinken).

Name: Rüningen
Alternative_Name: Riungi; Runige; Runinge; Runighe; Runingen; Runigh; Runinghen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 780-802. On a hill east of the village, the watchtower Rüninger Turm was erected in 1385, which guarded the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of the town Braunschweig.

Name: Rüssel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a charter from 977.

Name: Rüssen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a charter of the monastery Corvey from the beginning of the 11th century.

Name: Rustenfelde
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1318.

Name: Rüthen
Alternative_Name: Ruthe; Ruden; Ruthen; Rüden; Ruthena; Ruien
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in the second third of the 12th century and the town was founded around 1200, which got its name from the nearby Altenrüthen.
Town_Description: After completion of the 'fundatio' and 'plantatio' of the town, the Archbishop of Cologne granted town rights, which were extended by the citizens.

Name: Rucava
Settlement_Description: In 1253 the settlement was assigned to the Teutonic Order.

Name: Ruurlo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention forged circa 1118-1127. Next mention in 1180-1190.

Name: Ruisbroek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1138.

Name: Zādzene
Alternative_Name: Saadsen; Saddesen; Satzsen; Sadeszen; Satzen; Sadsehen; Saasen hoff
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1449.

Name: Saalburg
Settlement_Description: A fortification Saalburg, which is first mentioned in 1216, was constructed at the Saale crossing at the old trade route Nuremberg - Leipzig.
Town_Description: Referred to as oppidum in 1313. Awarded Gera town rights in the 14th/15th century.

Name: Saalfeld (Altmark)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1310.

Name: Zalewo
Town_Description: The founding of the town was started by the Teutonic Order komtur of Christburg, Hinrich Zuckschwert between 1299 and 1301, the founding documents with Kulm town lw were signed by the komtur Gegehard von Schwarzburg in 1305, they were renewed in 1320 and expanded in 1334

Name: Saalfeld (Saale)
Settlement_Description: The village grew together from several districts or settlements. Among others the castle district and the so-called old Saalfeld on the right bank of the Saale. Foundation of a monastery in 1071.
Town_Description: Referred to as civitas since 1208. A sheriff is mentioned in 1282, a council in 1323. Market rights were granted in 1350, a market can be assumed already since the 12th century.
Toll_Description:
A market and a market toll are mentioned in the records.
An extensive regulation of safe conduct of 1728 remains, which also mentiones the toll on the Saale river.

Name: Saarde
Settlement_Description: In the middle of the 16th century a church was built and a pastorate was established. The church fell into disrepair in 1613-42, so a new one was built in 1642 and was called 'Saara'.

Name: Jäärja
Settlement_Description: Originally a hamlet ('Wirtschaftshof') and manor of the Teutonic Order, which was built around 1442. In 1560 this was burned down by the Russians.

Name: Saarmund
Settlement_Description: Mention of a burgward in 1217, which was probably erected on a Slavic settlement. Around the castle a settlement developed which never earned town rights (referred to as opydulum in 1375), but held some meaning as a marketplace and toll station.
Toll_Description: In 1364 and 1365 the excemption of merchants from Berlin an Cölln from the transit toll is confirmed. Sovereign toll exists in 1479, mentioned again in 1576.

Name: Sachau
Settlement_Description: The settlement of Sachau is mentioned as deserted in 1472, it may have been reconstructed by 1506, when it is not explicitly mentioned as deserted anymore.

Name: Sachsenberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned by name in 1251. The Archbishop of Cologne and the Abbot Corveys planned to build a town near Lichtenfels Castle in 1230, which can be traced to Sachsenberg.
Town_Description: In 1262 the place was called 'oppidum' and was given a town seal.

Name: Sachsenburg
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1132 (MGH DLo III 42). First mention of castle Sachsenburg in 1250, however, the place has been continously settled at since the late Bronze Age.
Toll_Description: According to the "Verzeichnis der Knechte und Tore", deliveries of salt had to be brought via the toll in Sachsenburg and Herbsleben to the Johannis gate in Erfurt. In 1394 landgrave Balthasar of Meißen gave the countess Adelheid of Beichlingen the "toll under the house of Sachsenburg" ("czoll under dem huse czu der Sachsenburg"). In 1404 the safe conduct of Sachsenburg is mentioned. Trade from Franken and Nuremberg to the seaside towns in Germany was lead via the Sachsenburg pass. The toll was paid north and south of the bridgehead. With Erfurt's economically weakened position to Leipzig, the forced usage of the road via Sachsenburg is increased.

Name: Sangaste
Settlement_Description: The manor was founded in 1287 and served as the summer residence of the bishops of Dorpat. The former St. Andreas church was built in the 14th century and was part of the parish 'Theal-Fölk'.

Name: Sint-Amands
Alternative_Name: Baesrode S. Amandi; Sinte Amants; Sint Amants; Saint-Amands
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1302

Name: Sakla
Settlement_Description: Originally a village called "Sakull" in the region 'Wacke'. Around 1750 the village became 'Kronsgut'.

Name: Salem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1197.

Name: Salacgrīva
Settlement_Description: The fishing village was first mentioned in 1215. The term 'vicus Salis' was used in 1432, but it is unclear whether it referred to Salismünde or Alt Salis (today: 'Vecsalaca').
Town_Description: 1512/16 minor town rights ('Weichbildrechte') 'thor Salcza' were granted. In 1519 the term 'oppidulum' was found. The granting of city rights has not been documented.

Name: Salmünster
Alternative_Name: Bad Soden-Salmünster; Salchenmunster; Salchmunster; Salmonster; Münster
Settlement_Description: The settlement was named as a parish at the end of the 9th century.
Town_Description: Granting of the rights and freedoms of the Wetterau imperial towns in 1320.

Name: Salzbergen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1172.

Name: Bad Salzdetfurth
Alternative_Name: Salzdetfurth; saline apud Thietvorde; solte to Detforde; Solte tho Dethforde
Settlement_Description: Because of the existence brine sources, saltworks developed in the 12th century. Around 1392 the settlement had the seal of a market borough ('marktflecken'), although is also referred to in the sources as village or town.

Name: Salzgitter-Bad
Alternative_Name: Salzgitter; Saline in Getere; Up dem Solde to Gyttere; Soltgittere; salina Gyter; Solte to Jytere; Liebenhalle; Salzliebenhall
Settlement_Description: The saltworks Salzliebenhalle near the village Gitter are first mentioned around 1125. The settlement near the saltworks is first called "Solte to Gittere"; the name Salzgitter appears in 1459.
Town_Description: Around 1400, Salzgitter became a town. In the 15th century a council and town seal are attested. However, the town lost its independent position when it became part of the duchy Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel in 1523.

Name: Salzhemmendorf
Alternative_Name: Salinarum iuxta Hemmendorpe; Salinas Hemmendorph; thome salte iuxta Hemmendorp; Salina Hemmendorpe; Solthes tho Hemmendorpe; Solte tho Hemendorpe; Salz zu Hemmendorff; Saltzhemmendorff
Settlement_Description: Saltworks near Hemmendorf are first mentioned in 1169; a settlement developed here in the 13th century.

Name: Salzkotten
Alternative_Name: Saltkoten; Salskoten; Saltkoten; Salzcoten; Saltchoten; Salcoten; Soltkoten
Settlement_Description: The origins of the settlement are not known, since the Salzkotten are boiling houses that the salters built. However, they were first mentioned in 1160. A fortified settlement is mentioned for 1247.
Town_Description: Town rights were conferred in the second half of the 13th century.

Name: Bad Salzuflen
Alternative_Name: Salzuflen; Uflen; Uflan; Uflon; Uflahon; Miduffuli; Medoffuli; Saltuflon; Ridderufflen; Quaduflen; Mitlisten-Uflen; Uffelen; Saltuffelen
Settlement_Description: The salt deposits in Salzuflen were already known in prehistoric times, but are first mentioned only in 1036.
Town_Description: In 1322 a burgomaster and town council first appears in a document, and the settlement is characterised as borough ('wygbold'). After the settlement and its surroundings were destroyed in the Soest feud in 1447, the town was reconstructed and expanded and the town privileges were reaffirmed in 1488.

Name: Bad Salzungen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was near salines. A Carolingian royal court lay in Bad Salzungen.
Town_Description: The town foundation was probably promoted by the lords of Frankenstein in the 13th century. At the beginning of the 14th century the town was subject to Fulda town rights.

Name: Salzwedel
Toll_Description: Toll and safe conduct. A toll register from 1314 shows the fees to be paid. In 1506 a dam- and bridge toll is added for the maintenance of the roads.
Fair_Description: The privileges of the cloth merchants in 1360 mention two fairs in Salzwedel

Name: Sambeek
Alternative_Name: Zannebeeke; Sambeeck; Zannebeke; Zambeke; Sint Jansbeck; Sambeke; Sandebecke; Zantbeeck; Sandbeek; Santbeeck; St. Jansbeek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1294.

Name: Sandau
Settlement_Description: In the 10th century a village-like settlement probably aready existed. In 1272 the village was granted ferry rights and other privileges, which were confirmed in 1325. No referral as town, however. In 1632 the old privileges were revoked.
Toll_Description: In 1425 archbishop Günther pawns Sandau and its tolls and safe conduct off to the bishop of Havelberg. Mention of the toll in a quarrel between the town of Magdeburg and the archbishop in 1432. Further mention in the context of the negotiations of the tolls of Kietznick, Jerichow and Sandau on the diet of princes in 1480-1490.

Name: Sandershausen
Alternative_Name: Sandrateshusen; Sandardeshusun; Sanderachteshusen; Sandershusen; Zandershusen; Sangershausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1167.

Name: Sandersleben
Settlement_Description: 1046 Mention in a gift certificate by Henry III. to Meißen monastery (MGH DD H III, nr. 157, S. 198f.). Controls the gateway to the mountainous area of Mansfeld.
Town_Description: Town rights since the beginning of the 14th century, a new town privilege was given in 1497 after Sandersleben's complete destruction after a fire.

Name: Sandesneben
Alternative_Name: Zanzegnewe; Sanctzkeneue; Santzkeneue; Santzegnewe; Santskenneue; Sandisneben
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230.

Name: Sandhatten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as "Westhathen" in 1240; mentioned as "Sandhatten" since 1324.

Name: Sandkrug (Oldenburg)
Settlement_Description: The hamlet ('bauerschaft') was originally called Streek and first mentioned in 1526. In the 18th century, the inn and post station Sandkrug on the post road Oldenburg-Bremen was erected here, which later became the official name for the settlement.

Name: Sandomierz
Staple_Description: Unimportant staple, confirmed in the Polish Staple Law of 1565

Name: Sandrup
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1022 and 1023. The road crossed the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Münster here, which was closed with a boom barrier.

Name: Sangerhausen
Settlement_Description: Most probably already a settlement of the 6th/7th century, in the 8th century develoment of an "oppidum". Mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis in the 2nd third of the 9th century. Mention in the records in 991 when abbot Unger of Memleben gives tithes to empress Adelheid.
Town_Description: According to Niemeyer town privileges were given in 1194. Referral to the settlement as "oppidum" in 1204. A town wall must have existed before the 1260ies.
Toll_Description: The fees of the safe conduct in Sangerhausen can be derived from the regulations of safe conduct ('Geleitsordnung') from 1517 (LHASA, MD, d. 40 A I Nr. 1, Amt Sangerhausen 1517).

Name: Sankt Georgsberg
Alternative_Name: St. Georg auf dem Berge; sancti Georgii in Raceburg; sancti Georgii prope Raceburg; sancti Georgii in monte iuxta Raceborgh; ecclesia sancti Georgii apud Raceborg; Sunte Jurigens to Razeborch
Settlement_Description: A Benedictine monastery was founded around 1044, destroyed by a Slavic revolt in 1066, and refounded around or before 1143. The parish church became the regional centre of the christianisation.

Name: Sint Gerlach
Alternative_Name: Sanctum Gerlacum; Sancto Gerlaco; Sancti Gerlaci; Sankt Gerlach
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1217.

Name: Sankt Goar
Toll_Description: The Count of Katzenelnbogen probably levied a river toll on the Rhine even before 1219 until 1235. In 1245, the toll was established again. From the year 1368 it is known that 10 turnosgroschen had to be paid per foder of wine. In 1480/81 about 1822 gulden were collected, in 1481/82 about 1051 gulden, in 1482/83 about 3209 gulden and in 1485 about 3017 gulden. For further revenues see source.

Name: Pärnu-Jaagupi
Settlement_Description: A church was mentioned in 1325. A settlement developed around the St. Jakobi church at the end of the 19th century.

Name: Järva-Jaani
Settlement_Description: In 1221/23 the Danes started building a church in the village of 'Kettis' (now Keika). They completed the building by the end of the 13th century. A parish was established.

Name: Harju Jaani
Settlement_Description: The church was built in the early 14th century. The associated pastorate was established at the same time. The place where the church is today is called Raasiku.

Name: Sankt Jürgen
Settlement_Description: In 1392 an infirmary on the road between Groß Salze and Frohse at the street to Schönebeck. Its exact location cannot be reconstructed today.

Name: Katrinas
Settlement_Description: The place belonged to the parish of the same name. It had a church that was built in 1624.

Name: Kadrina
Settlement_Description: The parish was established in the 13th or 14th century. The borough ('Flecken') developed in the 19th century.

Name: Maarja-Magdaleena
Settlement_Description: The parish was first mentioned in 1443. In the 19th century, a borough ('Flecken') developed around the church.

Name: Koeru
Settlement_Description: The parish was founded in the second half of the 13th century.

Name: Skulte
Settlement_Description: The church itself was built even before 1646. It is known that it was rebuilt in 1646. The village and manor 'Skulte' ('Adjamünde') was first mentioned in 1540.

Name: Järva-Madise
Settlement_Description: St. Matthäi is a parish that has been mentioned regularly since the 15th century. However, it appears under other names, such as 'Goldenberge' (1467) or 'Kullenbeck'. Baptisms have already been documented for 1220. The St. Matthäi church was built in the 14th century and was first mentioned in 1427.

Name: Sankt Mauritz
Settlement_Description: St. Mauritz Abbey was founded in 1080, probably on an older farming ground.

Name: Pēterupe
Settlement_Description: The originally wooden church was built in 1641. Today, it belongs to 'Saulkrasti' ('Neubad').

Name: Peetri
Settlement_Description: The village and the parish of the same name already existed at the beginning of the 13th century. The church was probably built in 1221-23.

Name: Sappemeer
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1660.
Harbour_Description: In the 1620s, the Schuitendiep canal was extended to Zuidbroek, where the first ship from Groningen arrived in 1628. Regular barge ('trekschuit') services were offered since 1654 at the latest.

Name: Saraiķi
Settlement_Description: The village and manor of the Teutonic Order was named in 1291 together with the stream of the same name.

Name: Sarstedt
Alternative_Name: Scharzstede; Zerstede; Cherstette; Schirstede; Zchiarstide; Chyarstede; Tserstede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1046 and 1056 and mentioned in 1216 as farm of the bishop of Hildesheim. Bishop Conrad II built a castle in Sarstedt in 1221-1225.
Town_Description: Before 1296, the settlement was reconstructed and expanded and acquired town privileges from bishop Siegfried II of Hildesheim. From 1319, the settlement is called "civitas". Citizens of Sarstedt were exempted from all taxes to the bishop's bailiff by bishop Heinrich III in 1350.
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Hildesheim in Sarstedt is mentioned among others in 1388 and 1441. It is unclear whether this is the same toll as the one on the "Bruch vor Sarstedt" (Bierbruch) mentioned in 1384.

Name: Bad Sassendorf
Alternative_Name: Sassendorf; Sassendorp; Sassendorpe; Sassenthorp; Sassenthorpe; Sassindorp; Zassendarpe; Sassendorff; Sassentrop; Sastrop; Sastrup
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1169-1179. Saltworks already existed at that time.

Name: Sassenheim
Alternative_Name: UUestsagnem; Hostsagnem; Sasheim; Saxheim; Saxnem; Sasnem; Sassenem; Zassenem; Sassem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 918-948, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention dates from the beginning of the eleventh century.

Name: Sattelpaß
Settlement_Description: Location of a guardsman, no record of a settlement. Until the 19th century location of a toll bar.
Toll_Description: End of range of the safe conduct granted by Coburg on the Sattelpass-road.

Name: Sättelstädt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 936.

Name: Saula
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1241. The place was owned by the Manor 'Kosch'.

Name: Sayda
Town_Description: Already mentioned as 'oppidum' in 1250. Referred to as 'civitas' in 1289. A 'town letter' ('Stadtbrief') was issued in 1442, but town regulations ('Städteordnung') were only adopted in 1834.
Toll_Description: The regulations of safe conduct state that if a wagon with garlic passes, it has to pay some garlic (LHASA, MD, d. 45, A Nr. 146 II, Amt Seyda 1550.).

Name: Schaafhausen
Alternative_Name: Scaphusen; Scaphuse; Schaphus; Schaphuse; Schapphußen; Schaafhusen; Schaphausen; Schaffhausen; Schaphusen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1360. According to a 1684 register, the settlement consisted of 4 half farms, of which one was abandoned.

Name: Schaarbeek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1120, in a copy from the end of thirteenth century.

Name: Schackenthal
Settlement_Description: First mention in the Codex Diplomaticus Anhaltinus in 1019

Name: Schafstädt
Settlement_Description: Settlement from ancient Thuringian ('altthüringisch') times, mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis from the end of the 9th century.
Town_Description: Town rights were probably granted in 1539 and confirmed in 1558.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conducht ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Lauchstädt.
Fair_Description: Two fairs are mentioned in 1539.

Name: Schafwedel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1202.

Name: Schaijk
Alternative_Name: Scaeywijc; Schayck; Scheyk; Schayk; Schaik; Scheik; Osser-schayk; Herper-Schayk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1383.

Name: Schalkau
Settlement_Description: First mention in the register of decrees of Schaumberg I, 21.
Town_Description: As early as 1317 Schalkau is referred to as town. In 1441 also referred to as borough ('Flecken'). In 1362 landgrave Frederick the Stern granted Schalkau town- and market rights modelled after Rodach and Neustadt rights.

Name: Schapdetten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1022 and 1032.

Name: Schardam
Alternative_Name: Scaderdam; Schaderdam; Schaerdam; Schaderdamme; Schardam; Schaerdam; Scaerdam
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1319.

Name: Scharfoldendorf
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1146.

Name: Scharlibbe
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1351 as the property of a Johann of Buch.

Name: Scharn
Alternative_Name: Scarne; Scharnen; Scarnia; Scarnen; Scharen; Schaarn; Schaan
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1145, in a forgery shortly after 1145. Next mention probably falsification in 1151. Next mention in circa 1179-1180 [1152].

Name: Scharnhop
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1307. In the 14th century, it was a village with 7 farms; in 1568 there was only a farm of a manor ('meyerhof') left.

Name: Scharwoude
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1312.

Name: Scharzfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 952, in a falsified document from the 13th century.

Name: Schauen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 973, when Schauen is confirmed as property of the chathedral chapter of Magdeburg. In the 13th century, a ministerial family of Schauen is known.

Name: Scheemda
Alternative_Name: Senieda; Schemede; Schemte; Sceempte; Schemda; Scheemte
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1282, in a sixteenth - seventeenth century copy.

Name: Scheeren
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1345, it is deserted in 1521. In 1686 an inn and sheep farms are mentioned.

Name: Scheerhorn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1209.

Name: Schellerten
Settlement_Description: Between 1235 and 1261 the settlement was first mentioned.

Name: Schenefeld (Steinburg)
Alternative_Name: Schenefeld; Scanafeld; Sconeuelde; Scheneuelde; Schonefelde; Schenefelde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned by Adam of Bremen in the late 11th century, who described the foundation of a missionary church here in ca. 825. Although it always remained a village, Schenefeld developed into a significant political and economic centre for the region.

Name: Schenefeld (Pinneberg)
Settlement_Description: Around 1070, Schenfeld was the centre of the Saxonian Holstengau. The place was first mentioned in a charter in 1256.

Name: Schepsdorf
Settlement_Description: The name of the village is derived from the ferry (schep = 'ship') across the Ems.

Name: Scherfede
Alternative_Name: Scerua, Scherua; Scerve; Skerve; Scherve; Scerue; Scerven
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 822 and 826.

Name: Schermbeck
Toll_Description: The Count of Cleves levied a land toll in 1362.

Name: Schernikau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1292; mention of an innkeep in 1375.

Name: Scherpenheuvel
Alternative_Name: Mons Acutus; Collis Aspera; Montaigu; Scherpenheuvel-Zichem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1066. Next mention in 1099-1138.

Name: Scheulder
Alternative_Name: Scoler; Schuerle; Schuler; Schuller; Schuiler; Schulder
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1421.

Name: Schevenbrügge
Settlement_Description: Hamlet near a bridge, first mentioned in 1633/34.

Name: Schiedam
Alternative_Name: dicho de Scie; Scheidam; Novum Sciedammum; Nuwen Sciedamme; Niewendamme; Sciedam; Nieuwendamme; Scyedamme; Nuwer Scie
Settlement_Description: Schiedam is first mentioned in 1204, according to Van Berkel & Samplonius. Cox mentions a later date, 1264. In the river Schie, a dam was built in 1250. Schiedam was a small port town on the trade routes over the rivers Meuse and Schie. However, the port suffered from sedimentation. The importance of the port diminished in the fourteenth century, when Rotterdam en Delft got a connection to the Meuse.
Town_Description: Schiedam was granted town rights on 18 March 1275 by Adelaide of Holland (lady of Schiedam).

Name: Schiffbek
Alternative_Name: Schiffbecke; Schibeke; Scibeke; Scipbeke; Scibbeke; Schipbeke; Schibbeke; Schippbecke; Schibecke; Schiffbegke; Schifbek; Schiffbeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1212.

Name: Schinditz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1378, mention of a manor in 1491/2.

Name: Schipborg
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Borc' in 1298-1304. Earliest mention of 'Schipbork' in 1634.

Name: Schipluiden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the twelfth century, in a copy dating from circa 1420.

Name: Sępopol
Settlement_Description: A castle of the Teutonic Order was built in 1319 in place of an old Old Prussian castle
Town_Description: The grand master Heinrich Dusemer granted the founding documents of the town in 1351 with Kulm town law, it was mentioned as opidum in 1485

Name: Świdwin
Alternative_Name: Schivelbein; Schiuelbein; Schibilbeyn; Scheibelbeyn; Schiefelbein; Cchiuelbin; Scyulbein; Schiuelbin; Schiuelbeen
Settlement_Description: At first a wendish castle mound and settlement. The ascanian margraves were holding the castle from 1266 onward. German settlers were first mentioned in 1280.
Town_Description: The Brandenburg town law was likely granted by the Margraves Otto IV and Conrad in 1296, but fortification was already in place in 1292. It was mentioned as civitas in 1371 and he privileges were renewed in 1278 by Hans von Wedel.

Name: Schkeuditz
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 849 as limes Sorabicus, first mention of the castle in 941. In the 10th century, Schkeuditz was a castle district centre ('Burgwardhauptort') of the Slavs and later taken over by the Germans.
Town_Description: In 1200 the expansion to town began. In 1210 referred to as oppidum, however, certain privileges and rights were only granted in 1436 by bishop Johannes II. In 1557 the town rights were confirmed.
Toll_Description: The regulations of safe conduct were renewed and copied in 1535, which means they existed earlier.

Name: Schkopau
Settlement_Description: Founded in the 9th century, imperial ministerials named themselves after Schokpau since 1177 at the latest and died out in 1480.
Toll_Description: The income from land and ferry tolls are recurring in the records of the Trotha family on castle Schkopau.

Name: Ostrov
Alternative_Name: Schlackenwerth; Ostrov nad Ohří; Schlakenwerth; Schlaccowerdt

Name: Schladen
Settlement_Description: Originally a farm of the royal palace Werla, it was reconstructed as a castle by bishop Udo of Hildesheim before 1110.

Name: Schlangen
Alternative_Name: Lengi; Lanchel; Ostlangen; Westlanghen; Austlangen; Ouslangen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Sławno
Alternative_Name: Schlawe; Slavena; Slawe; nova Zlawna; nien Slawe; Slage; Zlauinie
Settlement_Description: The settlement was ideally located close to the castle at a river (Wipperfluss). Many suburbians were formed and a castellan is mentioned in 1223 as well as a church of St Adalbert. In 1230 Duke Swantopolk expanded a castrum.
Town_Description: The location was likely done in 1311, it was mentioned as civitas in 1317 and was granted Lübeck town law by the swiencan Jesko.

Name: Schleibnitz
Settlement_Description: Property of Berge monastery in 1144.

Name: Schleiz
Settlement_Description: The village originated from a Slavic settlement. Next to the old settlement, a new town with a castle developed in 1284.
Town_Description: In 1297 one finds the denomination as oppidum. The exact year of the awarding of the town rights is unknown, but it probably occured at the end of the 13th century. In the 14th/15th century, Gera town rights were granted.

Name: Schleswig
Alternative_Name: Slesvig; Sliesthorp; Sliaswich; Slesuuic; Sliaswig; Sleswich; Sleswic; Slésvík; Sleswyk; Slesvic; Slæswich; Sleswig
Settlement_Description: The 9th-century merchant settlement Haithabu on the opposite shore of the Schlei was moved to Schleswig in the 11th century. Bishopric since 1026. The settlement was the main transshipment point in long-distance trade between the North Sea and the Baltic Sea.
Town_Description: First mentioned as a 'civitas' in 1196; The Schleswig town law developed in the late 12th century.

Name: Schleusingen
Settlement_Description: A castle Berthold was built in the 12th century. In 1533 market rights and four markets were granted.
Town_Description: Between 1406 and 1415 Schleusingen was granted town rights by countess Rechthild.
Toll_Description: End of the Coburg safe conduct according to the Coburg charter of safe conduct ('Coburger Geleitstafel') from 1492.

Name: Schleusingerneundorf
Settlement_Description: First mention 1332.

Name: Schlewecke
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1642.

Name: Schlieben
Alternative_Name: Sleben; Zlowin; Sliwne; Scliuven; Zluwen; Slyben

Name: Schloburg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1652.

Name: Człuchów
Settlement_Description: Wendish refugees were granted the right to settle in 1200 by the duke Sambor I. of eastern Pomerania. The Teutonic Order bought the lands surrounding it in 1312 and built a castle and in 1332 a Komtur.
Town_Description: A handfast with Kulm town law was granted by the Grand master Heinrich Dusemer in 1348 and was endorsed later by the polish King Sigismund II.

Name: Człopa
Alternative_Name: Schloppe; Slopa; Schlopp; Sczloppa; Szlopa; Sczlopa
Town_Description: The town law was likely granted at the end of the 13th ct., the town itself was first mentioned in 1350. The town privileges with Magdeburg town law were renewed in 1614.

Name: Schlotheim
Settlement_Description: 974 mention of castle Schlotheim with neighboring village.
Town_Description: Referral to the town as "civitas", the town's layout is obviously planned. The bylaws of Schlotheim have to be recorded before 1408, at the beginning of the 14th century councilmen, sheriffs and jurymen are mentioned.

Name: Schlüchtern
Alternative_Name: Sluchderin; Sluchterin; Sluderin; Solitaria; Sluhteren; Sluthere; Schluchter
Settlement_Description: Originated near a monastery founded around 880. The settlement is called in 993. In 1278 already an independent place, in 1550 and 1572 still mentioned as 'Flecken'.
Town_Description: First mentioned as a town in 1562.

Name: Schlutup
Alternative_Name: Sluckup; Vretup; Scluckup; Slukop; Sluckuppe; Slutrup; Schlukip
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1225. In the fishing village, there was a guarded crossing of the Lübeck border ('landwehr') with Mecklenburg, with an inn and a boom barrier. The watchtower was demolished in 1673, its stones used for the mill gate (Mühlentor) in Lübeck.

Name: Schmarsau
Alternative_Name: Smersowe; Smarzeve; Smarsowe; Smerseve; Schmarsow; Schmersow; Smarsow
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330/52. In 1450, the settlement consisted of 3 farms, a mill and a cottage.

Name: Süderschmedeby
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1421.

Name: Schmerlecke
Alternative_Name: Ismereleke; Smerlecco; Smerlachen; Smerlike; Smirlachen; Smerlake; Smerleken

Name: Schmithausen
Toll_Description: From 1062/76 until around 1318, there was a river toll on the Rhine in Schmithausen. This was moved to Emmerich after 1318. The Bishop of Utrecht was the owner of the toll, with the monasteries of St. Johannes (1076 to 1085) and St. Maria (since 1085) listed as owners as well. The toll was frequently leased out: before 1228 to the Lord of Schmithausen, since 1228 to the Lord of Lek and since 1351 to the Lord of Culembourg. In 1319, 4 denarii per barrel had to be paid.

Name: Schmilau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1093.

Name: Schmira
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1243; property of the thuringian-schwarzburgian counts, who gave the village away as fiefdom on several occasions.

Name: Schmölau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1330. In 1375 it is mentioned as deserted, mentioned again in 1458 but it is unclear whether it is active. Surely reconstructed by 1542.

Name: Schnakenbek
Settlement_Description: First written reference from 1230.

Name: Piła
Settlement_Description: Originally a slavic fishing village.
Town_Description: The town privileges were granted in 1380 by Queen Hedwig, but were destroyed in 1824 in a fire. Snydemole was first mentioned in 1456 and called a Stadt in 1506 and 1511. In 1513 Sigismund I of Poland granted the Madgeburg town law.

Name: Schneverdingen
Alternative_Name: Snewordinge; Snewerdinge; Schneverdingk; Sneverding; Schneverdinge; Schnäverding
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1231.

Name: Scholen
Settlement_Description: In a 1203 charter, a "Dietrich von Sconenla" appears, around 1370 the settlement itself is first mentioned.

Name: Schönau (Hörsel)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1293.

Name: Schönau (Leipzig)
Settlement_Description: First mention as Schonowe in 1285.

Name: Schönberg (Mecklenburg)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1219. Bishop Ulrich of Ratzeburg built a fortified house between 1257 and 1284, which was made into the residence of bishop Marquard in the early 14th century. The settlement was characterised as borough ('oppidum') in the early 16th century, but only received town rights in 1822.

Name: Schönberg (Lauenburg)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1389. The settlement was abandoned after 1554. The current village Schönberg is located more to the north.

Name: Schönböcken
Settlement_Description: The area around Schönböcken belongs since 1226 to the town of Lübeck, and the village must have been founded not long after. It is first mentioned in 1262.

Name: Schönebeck
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1375.

Name: Schönebeck
Settlement_Description: The beginnings of the settlements go back to a family in Magdeburg that derives its name from this village since 1244. The settlement was first mentioned in 1194. 1372 a castle is mentioned in the position of the former saline. Even though the settlement was planned, it was never granted town rights and was always ruled by a town lord.
Toll_Description: Announcement of a toll on the Elbe during a dispute between the Archbishop of Magdeburg and the town council of Magdeburg in 1432.
Staple_Description: In a treaty between Archbishop Sigismund and Magdeburg in 1562, rafters were not allowed to remain in Schönebeck longer than a day.
Fair_Description: In 1555 Schönebeck is granted the privilege for two fairs and one weekly market, which leads to several conflicts with the town of Magdeburg.

Name: Trzcińsko Zdrój
Alternative_Name: Schönfließ; Schowen; Scawen; Schouwenfliet; Schouwenflite; Sconevlith; Schonevliet; Schonfliete; Schönenfließ; Bad Schönfließ
Settlement_Description: Paved castle mound, no settlement before the town was founded
Town_Description: First mentioned in 1248, possibly a german town that was founded in 1266 by a Margrave, mentioned as civitas in 1281 and from then on, mentioned as oppidum only in 1350, called a town in 1445

Name: Schönhausen (Elbe)
Settlement_Description: First mention of the church in Schönhausen in 1212; sources, which claim a mention in 1202 cannot be proven. Mention as a little town ('Stedtchen') in the 16th centruy, in 1600 referred to as borough ('Flecken'). Mention of a monastery in 1608.

Name: Schöningen
Alternative_Name: Scahaningi; Scieninge; Sceninghe; Schanigge; Sceningh; Sceningen; Scheningk
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 747. There was probably a royal court here, since Pippin, Charlemagne and Otto III. held court in 747, 784, 994 and 995.
Town_Description: Duke Magnus of Brunswick granted town privileges in 1346-48. However, the settlement was already mentioned as 'oppidum' in 1332 and 'civitas' in 1338. The town was fortified in the first half of the 14th century and a ducal castle was built in 1348.

Name: Schönstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 780.

Name: Schoonhoven
Alternative_Name: Sconhouen; Schoenhove; Sconehoven; Scoenhouen; Schoenhouen; 'tScoenhoven; Schonehoue; Scoenhove
Settlement_Description: Schoonhoven is first mentioned in 1247. A castle was built nearby in the mid-thirteenth century.
Town_Description: Schoonhoven was granted town(-like) privileges in several steps. It developed into a town from especially 1280 onward, when Floris V, count of Holland, granted town privileges on 3 May 1280. These rights were supplemented with additional rights over the years.

Name: Schoonloo
Alternative_Name: Sconelo; Schoenloe; Scoenlo; Scoenloe; Scheloe; Scholoe; Schonerlo; Schonlo; Scharlo; Schraallo; Scholo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Sconelo' in 1328. Earliest mention of 'Schoonloo' in 1847.

Name: Schöppenstedt
Alternative_Name: Sciphinstete; Scyppenstide; Schipenstede; Scheppestede; Scheppenstedt; Scheppenstidde; Schepenstidde
Settlement_Description: The church was founded in 827. The settlement is first mentioned in a charter in 1051 and characterised as "villa" until 1332.
Town_Description: Schöppenstedt is characterised as borough ('weichbild') from 1345, and as town in the 16th century.
Toll_Description: One of the five toll stations in the Amt Wolfenbüttel, first mentioned in 1492.

Name: Schöppingen
Settlement_Description: The church of St Brictus was built before 838, when it was first mentioned.
Town_Description: A planned town was founded in the 14th century, first mentioned as borough ('wigbold') in 1396. It is characterised as town between 1435 and 1658, but after 1659 it is usually called 'wigbold' again.

Name: Schöps
Settlement_Description: First mention 1293.

Name: Schopsdorf
Settlement_Description: Schopsdorf was a residence of the bishop of Brandenburg was 1327 - 1347. The correlating village was probably already deserted in the 13th century. A new settlement developed around a barbican in 1763.

Name: Schoten
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 868, in a eighteenth century copy. Next mention in 1152.

Name: Schreufa
Alternative_Name: Ober-Schreufa; Scroufi; Scrûfi; Scruffi; Scroufin; Scroife; Scoufe; Scrophe; Schrofe; Obirschroyffe; ObernSchreuffe; Schroyffe; Schreuff; Schrefe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 850.

Name: Skrunda
Settlement_Description: In 1253 the wooded region fell to the Teutonic Order, that built a castle in 1368. In 1429 there was a manor.

Name: Schuilenburg
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1229.

Name: Schulendorf
Settlement_Description: Year of first mention was 1230.

Name: Schulenhof
Settlement_Description: The village called Schulendorf was abandoned between 1444 and 1620, a farm ('hof') remained.

Name: Schüttorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1154 in the foundation charter Wietmarschen monastery. In 1184 it was called "curia" and in 1288 "oppidum".
Town_Description: Schüttorf became the first urban settlement in the county of Bentheim in 1295, when it received the town rights of Münster.
Toll_Description: According to privileges from 1465, the town levied a road toll at the town gates and on the bridge.
Fair_Description: Four six-day fairs are mentioned in Schüttorf in 1465, which were doubtlessly older. Dates are not mentioned.

Name: Schwaan
Settlement_Description: A Slavic castle is mentioned in 1170. Next to it a German village developed; a parish priest is first mentioned in 1232.
Town_Description: Founded by the lords of Werle, mentioned as oppidum in 1276, privileges endorsed in 1308, 1526 and 1532.

Name: Alt Schwagstorf
Alternative_Name: Schwagstorf; Schwagsdorf; Svavasthorp; Suasthorpe; Swaghestorpe; Zwagestorppe; Swastorpf; Schwastrup
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1090.

Name: Schwagstorf
Alternative_Name: Swavesdorr; Svavesdorphe; Svaghestorp; Swegestorpe; Swavestorppe; Swaestrup; Schwagstrupff; Schwaigstorf
Settlement_Description: Fist mentioned around 1000.

Name: Schwalbach
Alternative_Name: Schwalbach am Taunus; Langinswalbach; Swalbach; Langenschwalbach
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1352. Was a comparatively large settlement in the Middle Ages and therefore rose to become a town without any official granting of privileges. Called 'Flecken' around 1600. 1643 granting of the 'Burgfrieden' and confirmation of old rights.

Name: Schwallungen
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 788 in a register of Fulda monastery.

Name: Gulbene
Settlement_Description: Around 1340 a castle and church were built. The first written reference dated back to 1416. A fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') developed close to the castle and appeared under the name 'vicus Svaneburgensis' in 1489. The settlement and castle were destroyed by Ivan IV in 1577.

Name: Zvārde
Settlement_Description: The district of 'Schwarden' was first mentioned in 1628.

Name: Bad Schwartau
Settlement_Description: Settlement at the Schwartau river. A mill is mentioned in 1215, a hospital in 1258.

Name: Schwarza
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1074.
Toll_Description: In the 1530ies, merchants coming from Saalfeld are taken into schwarzburgish safe conduct at the border to Schwarza an accompanied through Rudolstadt up to the border stone at Kirchhasel/Etzelbach.
Fair_Description: 1495 Schwarza is granted the privilege to hold three fairs and to fortify the town by Emperor Maximilian.
Bridge_Description: In 1689 first mention of an event connected to a bridge (destroyed by a flood), it can be assumed there was a stone bridge earlier.

Name: Ādams
Settlement_Description: The manor existed before 1625. However, the ownership is only known from 1625.

Name: Schwarzenbek
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1291.

Name: Schwedt
Town_Description: First secure mention of a castle and town of Scwet in 1265. Confirmation of town rights in 1515, market rights only in 1548.
Toll_Description: The town held the land- and water toll, later a bridge- and dam toll were added.

Name: Schweimke
Alternative_Name: Swenbeke; Svembeke; Swembeke; Sweymbeke; Swemeke; Smemeke; Swemcke; Sweymeke; Swemke; Schwencke; Schwemike; Schweimcke
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1244.

Name: Schweinitz
Settlement_Description: Ersterwähnung 1182.
Town_Description: Referred to as civitas in 1350.
Fair_Description: 1484 a fair and a weekly market are granted.

Name: Schwelm
Alternative_Name: Suelmin; Suelmiu; Swelme; Swelhem; Swelm; Suelme
Settlement_Description: Mentioned around 900. Called 'villa' or 'curtis' around 950. The settlement grew up at the church, mentioned in 1085, and was granted market privileges in 1493.
Town_Description: The town rights were first granted in 1496, but were withdrawn in 1501 after complaints from the peasantry. In 1590 town rights were granted again.

Name: Schwemlitz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1360.

Name: Schwerin
Alternative_Name: Zuarin; Zverin; Zuerin; Zwerin; Cwerin; Swerin
Settlement_Description: A wendish castle mentioned in 1018, most likely a trading post, basis of christian missions since 1155, see of the bishop of Schwerin in 1160
Town_Description: Town law granted by Duke Heinrich der Löwe (the Lion) in 1160, mentioned as civitas that same year

Name: Schwerte
Alternative_Name: Sverte; Swerte; Swerthe; Swerthene; Swirte; Swirthe; Swierte; Sweirte; Sweyrte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 962 and 971.
Town_Description: In 1367 the town was given expanded city rights, but was fortified as early as 1242.

Name: Schwerz
Settlement_Description: First mention in the Chronicon Montis Sereni, the Wettin chronicle of the Petersberg (MGH SS. 23, ed. E. Ehrenfeuchter, Hannover 1874, S. 172).

Name: Świebodzin
