Alternative_Name: Schwiebus; Sweboffin; Swebofin; Swebozin; Swebessin; Swebussin; Swebusin; Swebyssen; Swebissen; Swibessin; Swibissin; Swibissen; Schwebossin
Settlement_Description: A castle was built in 1228, mentioned in 1247 and 1303, mention of an earlier market settlement
Town_Description: Mentioned as a town first in 1319, full town law was granted in 1469

Name: Sebexen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1139.

Name: Seboldshausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1148.

Name: Secklendorf
Alternative_Name: Sekerthorpe; Syggerdorp; Zekerdorpe; Sekeldorppe; Seckerdorp; Szekeldorpe; Segeldorff; Seckelndörf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned after 1236.

Name: Seedorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252.

Name: Seega
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1227.

Name: Seehausen (Leipzig)
Settlement_Description: First mention as Sehusen in 1359.

Name: Seehausen (Altmark)
Settlement_Description: In the 10th century, a border castle probably already existed as protection against the Slavs. Around 1150 the Old city was constructed, around 1170 a New town was established.
Town_Description: Referred to as oppidum in 1196. The town was probably under Magdeburg town rights, while "Seehausen town rights" were given to Pritzwalk in 1256. Member of the Hanse in 1358.
Fair_Description: In an official schedule from 1719, Seehausen, Werben and Arneburg each held three fairs. It can be assumed that some of these had existed for a while to this point.

Name: Seehausen (Wanzleben)
Settlement_Description: Important place on the road from Magdeburg to the west (Werla). First record mention 966 in a gift certificate by Otto I to his familiar Mamaco (MGH DD O I, nr. 327, S. 441), it probably existed before that though and was an im portant waypoint on the way to Magdeburg. With the shift of royal courts from Werla to Goslar, Seehausen looses its importance for traffic.
Town_Description: In 1197 Seehausen had the status of a town, in 1563 it is only referred to as borough ('Flecken').

Name: Seelow
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1252, probably founded in the first half of the 13th century. Mention as borough ('Flecken') in 1278 and as little town ('Städtchen') in 1308 and 1317.

Name: Seesen
Settlement_Description: The settlement, consisting of a royal court and castle, is first mentioned in 973/4 in an imperial charter of Otto II. In the 13th century, a merchant settlement came into existence around the St Andrew's church next to the old settlement.
Town_Description: Seesen is characterised from 1360 as town or borough ('stad', 'blek' or 'oppidum'). A council is attested in 1407, and the settlement received borough ('weichbild') privileges in 1428. Only in 1532, however, Seesen is first counted among the towns in the duchy of Brunswick.
Toll_Description: A toll of the dukes of Brunswick is first mentioned in Seesen in 1405, when it was pawned. Toll revenues were limited. According to an overview of tolls in the duchy of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel from 1582, the toll was calculated according to the weight of the cargo.
Fair_Description: A fair in Seesen is first mentioned in 1434. In 1640, there were three fairs, to which a cattle fair was added.

Name: Bad Segeberg
Alternative_Name: Siegeburg; Segeberg; Szegebarge; Segebergch; Segheberghe; Sigeberg; Sigeberch
Settlement_Description: A castle and a monastery of Augustinian canons were founded in 1134. Next to it, a market settlement developed.
Town_Description: Lübeck town privileges granted by Adolf IV. of Holstein in 1244(?), confirmed by the counts Johann and Gerhard in 1260. The town was pawned to Lübeck between 1342 and 1366.
Toll_Description: Already in 1400, it is ordained that merchants from Lübeck to Neumünster and Rendsburg are obliged to travel via Segeberg. An actual toll station of the counts of Holstein is first mentioned in 1479 in a Lübeck complaint. However, toll revenues were only modest in the 16th century.

Name: Sigulda
Alternative_Name: Segewold; Segewald; Seghewold; Zeghewold; Zegewolt; Zygvuld
Settlement_Description: Around 1207/10 a knightly order built a castle, which was one centre of the Teutonic Order in the 14th and 15th centuries. The decay of the castle began around 1600. In 1434 the fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') near the castle was first mentioned. It was probably destroyed by Ivan IV in 1577. A church was first mentioned in 1483 - it was probably built in 1225.

Name: Sehnde
Alternative_Name: Senethe; Seynede; Senede; Senedhe; Sende; Zeynde
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1147.

Name: Seidfeld
Alternative_Name: Setvelde; Zetvelte; Zetwelde; Zetvelde; Seetfelde; Setzuelde; Setuelde; Seytfelde; Sietueld; Seitueld; Zetfelde; Seedfeld; Siedfelde; Seidtfelde; Siedtfelt; Setfelde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1242.

Name: Vecsēlpils
Alternative_Name: Selburg; Alt Selburg; castrum Selonum; castrum Selen; Seelborch
Settlement_Description: In 1208, Germans conquered the existing castle ('castrum Selonum'), which became the bishopric from 1218. Another castle of the Teutonic Order was built in 1373. Before 1596 a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built, which was referred to as 'Städtlein'. In 1621, it received market rights.

Name: Seligenstadt
Alternative_Name: superiori Mulinheim; Seliginstat; Saligenstatt; Saligstat; Selgenstat; Saliginstad
Settlement_Description: Emerges from a monastery settlement that merged with the town of Obermühlheim. The monastery is first mentioned in 847.
Town_Description: From 1175 called 'cives' and 'civitas'.

Name: Seljaküla
Settlement_Description: Village with a manor was mentioned in 1517.

Name: Zeltiņi
Settlement_Description: The manor was probably built in the 13th century.

Name: Silla
Settlement_Description: The village was mentioned in 1489 and belonged to the lands of the 'Uchten' manor.

Name: Ziemeri
Settlement_Description: The Manor was built even before 1550.

Name: Semmenstedt
Alternative_Name: Scemmenstede; Simmenstede; Symmenstidde; Zemmenstide; Chemenstede; Tsemmenstede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022.

Name: Sendenhorst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned 875.
Town_Description: The place was elevated to a town in 1315.

Name: Sensenstein
Settlement_Description: The castle was mentioned 1373, but an older watch tower is said to have stood in its place.

Name: Sārnate
Settlement_Description: The latvian region 'Sarnitus' was first mentioned in 1230.

Name: Cesvaine
Alternative_Name: Sesswegen; Seßwegen; Zcessowe; Cessowe; Cesweghen; Czeswegen; Zeszwegen; Seszwegen; Zieswegen
Settlement_Description: In the early 14th century, the archbishop built a castle, which was mentioned in 1426. The castle may not have been built until the end of the 14th century.
Town_Description: A fortified borough ('Hakelwerk'), which was referred to as 'oppidum' in 1441 was built near the castle. The castle and the settlement were both destroyed by the Russians in 1577.

Name: Sece
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1556 and was burned down by Russians in 1559.

Name: Sibbesse
Alternative_Name: Sibesse; Sighebrechthusen; Sibechteseim; Sibbichtissen; Zibbetessen; Sebbechtessen; Sybbetze; Sibbeszen; Sibbeßen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 989.

Name: Siebeneichen
Alternative_Name: Seveneken; Seueneken; Soveneken; Septem Quercus; Souen Eken; Szoueneken; Sovenecken
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1211.

Name: Siebigerode
Settlement_Description: In 1040 Siebigerode is given as part of a dowry. In 1273 it was noticed that the village was deserted. In between the village must have been reconstructed, but by 1646 it had been deserted again. In 1651 it was attempted to be rebuilt again.

Name: Sieden
Settlement_Description: Settlement near a ford in the stream Siede. The stream is first mentioned in 1241, the settlement in ca. 1380. On the "Kurhannoversche Landesaufnahme" (1764-1784), a toll house is depicted here. However, there is no evidence for a toll in the period before 1650.

Name: Siegburg
Alternative_Name: Siburgh; Sigeburch; Sigeberg; Sigeburgh; Siberch; Siberg; Sigeberch; Siegeberga; Sigiberch; Sygeberg; Segeberg; Sigeberc; Siburg; Siburgh; Syberch; Sygeberch; Syberg; Seyberch; Ziberg; Ziberti; Siegberg; Sijburg; Siborgh; Seybergkch; Sijberch; Sijbergh; Ziberge; Sigberch; Syburgen; Ziberghen; Sibbergh; Siburch; Siegbourg; Sybourg; Sibourg
Settlement_Description: Archbishop Anno II of Cologne founded a Benedictine monastery on the Siegberg around 1064; a small settlement already existed at the site at this time. The monastery received market, toll and mint privileges in 1069.
Town_Description: Siegburg is first mentioned as 'oppidum', 'stat' or 'civitas' in the 1180s and can be considered a town at this point, although town privileges were not granted. The town was fortified in 1220-40.
Toll_Description:
1) The monastery of Siegburg received toll privileges in 1069; this probably concerned a market toll. Moreover, according to complaints from Cologne in 1438, a "new toll" on land and water, especially for wine, was levied by the Duke of Berg. It was abolished around 1442.
2) In 1357, a bridge toll was levied by the town itself. A fee of 4 old heller per horse had to be paid.
Fair_Description: The monastery Siegburg received market privileges in 1069; the oldest market is mentioned in 1183-85 to take place on Ascension Day, which was well visited, among others by merchants from Cologne. A second fair of St Servatius is mentioned in 1461, which was moved to Corpus Christi in that year. A third fair, on St Matthew's Day, might have existed since 1491 and was confirmed in 1521/22. A fourth fair, on St Nicholas, was granted in 1600.

Name: Siegen
Alternative_Name: Sigena; Sige; Sigin; Sygin; Sygen; Segen; Segin; Syghene; Zeghen; Seje
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1079 and 1089.
Town_Description: Since around 1170 coins were minted with the inscription "Sigenensis civitas", town rights had to exist before. In 1224 a new Siegen was founded around 700 m to the east, next to a castle, into which the citizens of the old town moved.

Name: Siek
Alternative_Name: Wlensike; Wlensich; Vulensyke; Vulenzych; Zike; Zyke; Syke; Sike; Sieck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1273.

Name: Sierße
Alternative_Name: Sigerdeshusen; Siegehardishusen; Sihardeshusen; Sigerdissem; Syerdissen; Sierdissen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1141.

Name: Sievershausen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1234.

Name: Sijsele
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1116.

Name: Sillamäe
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1502.

Name: Silvolde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 838, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention dates from 1200.

Name: Simpelveld
Alternative_Name: Semplouei; Senplouoir; Simplevei; Simplei; Saintplouoir; Zemplenege; Zempleveghe; Zemplevoer; Simplenoel; Semple; Simpel; Simpelvi; Simpelvelt; Sainplovoir; Sympelvelt; Simpelfelt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1155, in a thirteenth century copy

Name: Sinsleben
Settlement_Description: In 964 Gernrode monastery held property in Sinsleben, in following years it was owned by Quedlinburg monastery and the counts of Falkenstein.

Name: Sint-Michielsgestel
Alternative_Name: Gestele; Gestel; Ghestel; S. Michiel Gestel; Michiels Gestel; St. MichielsgesteI; St. Michelsgestel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1173.

Name: Sint-Oedenrode
Alternative_Name: A. Rodae Comitis; Rodae S. Odae; Rode; Sinte Oeden Rode; Rode ane Sinte Oedekerke; Sint Oeyenrode; Rode Sanctae Odae; St. Oedenrode; St. Oidenrode; St. Oeden Rode; Sa Oderode
Settlement_Description: Sint-Oedenrode is first mentioned in the twelfth century.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted some time between 9 April 1232 and 2 April 1233 by Henry I, duke of Brabant.

Name: Sint-Truiden
Alternative_Name: S. Trudonis; Sancti Trvdonis; Sancti Trudonis; Sent Truden; Sintruden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention 784-791. Next mention in 1133.

Name: Sint-Job-in-'t-Goor
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1560.

Name: Sint-Kruis-Winkel
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1150.

Name: Sint-Lenaarts
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1560.

Name: Sint-Odiliënberg
Alternative_Name: Mons Petri; Berg; Heriberc; Berga; Berche; Vodeberg; Hudelberg; Vodellenbergh; Mons Odilie; Sente Petersberge; Ulenberge; Sunte Odilien Berghe; Olenbergh;
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in probably the first half of the ninth century, in a seventeenth century copy. Next mention in 858 and 943, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1057 in a twelfth century copy.

Name: Sint-Pauwels
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1239.

Name: Sint-Stevens-Woluwe
Alternative_Name: UUiluua; UUille(uua); Wleuue; Wlewe; Wolewe; Wolua; Woluwe ten vorde; Sent Stevens Woluwe;
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1040, in a copy of the middle of the eleventh century. Next mention in 1046.

Name: Sinzig
Toll_Description: From 1452, a land toll was levied in Sinzig. The Archbishop of Cologne was mentioend as the pledgee. It is probable that there was already a market toll in Sinzig before 1452. In 1490, an additional 1 gold gulden had to be paid for each foder of wine. Annual revenues are not known.

Name: Sittard
Alternative_Name: Siter; Sittert; Zittert; Sithert; Zittaert; Zittart; Sittaert
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1157.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted between 10 and 30 April 1243 by Walram II 'de Goede', lord of Monschau, and his mother Elisabeth van Bar.
Toll_Description: The Duke of Jülich levied a land toll in 1494. Exact tariffs are not known. Between 1494 and 1495, 24 gulden were collected.

Name: Sittendorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1059 in the record book of Hersfeld monastery. Confirmation in 1128 by archbishop Adalbert of Mainz to Jechaburg monastery over the tithe from the village of "Sidendorph", among others.

Name: Preedi
Settlement_Description: The manor and the associated hamlets ('Hof') belonged to the cathedral in Reval in 1442.

Name: Džūkste
Settlement_Description: The manor of the Teutonic Order was mentioned in 1442.

Name: Sliedrecht
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1203, in a copy dating from 1704.

Name: Slijk-Ewijk
Alternative_Name: Euuic Silec; SlijckEwick; Slijck-Ewijck; Slyckewick; Slyk-Ewyk
Settlement_Description: Some identify 'Euuic Silec' as Slijk-Ewijk, but Van Berkel and Samplonius (2018) consider this identification unlikely. According to them, the place is first mentioned in 1573 as 'SlijckEwick'. The tower of the church (Hervormde Kerk, Dorpsstraat 70), however, dates from the twelfth century; the nave from the fifteenth century.

Name: Slochteren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the eleventh century.

Name: Sloten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned 26 March 1384.
Town_Description: First mentioned as a town on 27 April 1422. Sloten was walled during the Middle Ages. Further fortifications were added in 1672.

Name: Sluis
Alternative_Name: Sluse; Lamminsvliet; Laminsvliete; Lecluse; Sluus; Sluys; Sluyse; Sluijs; Leclusa; Lamminsvliete
Settlement_Description: The settlement of Sluis probably came into existence during the second half of the thirteenth century; Cox suspects around 1270. According to Cox, the earliest mention of the name 'Leclusa' dates from around 1241. Until 1324, Sluis was mainly known as 'Lamminsvliet'. The earliest mention of 'Sluse' and 'Laminsvliete' dates, according to Van Berkel and Samplonius, from 1290.
Town_Description: The earliest mention of Sluis as a town dates from 30 November 1290. Town privileges were granted by Guy of Dampierre, count of Flanders, between 1278 and 1290. As early as 1382, Sluis was a fortified town. From 1387 onwards, it functioned as a navy port of the Burgundian dukes.

Name: Smiltene
Settlement_Description: In 1224, a castle was mentioned, which fell to the Teutonic Order in 1556. In 1428, a fortified borough developed, which was referred to as a 'minor town' ('Weichbild') oder 'oppidulum' in 1553/37.

Name: Sneek
Alternative_Name: Snits; Snek; Snaken; Snake; Snitze; Sneke; Sneeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned on 15 August 1296.
Town_Description: Sneek was first mentioned as a town on 9 October 1317. In 1492, an earthen wall was built and a moat was added.

Name: Söder
Settlement_Description: Castle of the bishop of Hildesheim, first mentioned as enfeoffed to the lords of Hagen around 1200. Reconstructed as baroque castle in 1740/42.

Name: Soderstorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1241.

Name: Soeren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention as Laag Soeren in 1830-1855.

Name: Soest (Westfalen)
Alternative_Name: Soest; Sosat; Suosaz; Susacium; Sosatio; Schuschit; Suesacen; Sosaziensis; Susati; Zoest; Soist; Sost; Susa; Zust; Zoyst; Sosacium; Zusatum; Susatum; Sosatum; Sosa
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 836; a Merovingian cemetery in the urban area indicates earlier habitation of the area. Soest was allegedly already a well populated town in the 9th century.
Town_Description: Soester town law first appeared in 1144, which was awarded to Lübeck in 1158. However, its origins probably date back to around 1100.
Toll_Description: From 1306/08, the Archbishop of Cologne was the owner of a land toll and a fee for safe conduct on land. In 1444, the toll fell to the Duke of Kleve-Mark. In 1360, 4 denarii per foder of wine had to be paid. In 1306/08, 30 mark were collected.

Name: Soest (Amersfoort)
Alternative_Name: Soys; Zoys; Suys; Sus; Sose; Zoes; Zoest; Zoystwarts; Zoeswarts; Zoess; Zoest
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1028, in a copy dating from circa 1530.

Name: Soestdijk
Alternative_Name: Zoesdijck; Zoestdijck; Soest dyck; Soesdyk; Zoestdyk
Settlement_Description: The Soestdijk, a raised causeway through wet territory, was built shortly after 1350 by the bishop of Utrecht to improve the road between Utrecht and Ter Eem. A country house was built at the dike around 1650, which was later transformed into palace Soestdijk.

Name: Sooniste
Settlement_Description: The village was mentioned in 1525.

Name: Myślibórz
Settlement_Description: A slavic castle mound close to a slavic settlement, later a small fishing settlement, a farmyard of the templers is mentioned in 1260, which later became a sovereign castle, but it was destroyed in 1349
Town_Description: Founded by the Margraves between 1262 and 1270, mentioned as a fortified civitas in 1271

Name: Sollstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1221 in a record over grain tolls that are given to Walkenried monastery.

Name: Solpke
Settlement_Description: In 1473 Solpke is mentioned as the pertinence of Calbe
Toll_Description: A royal secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleitsstelle') of Gardelegen is mentioned in Solpke in 1743.

Name: Soltau
Settlement_Description: 937 mentioned in a donation charter from King Otto I. In 1304, a moated castle was built at the mouth of the river Soltau, to where the village of Soltau was relocated in 1383. In 1388, this settlement received borough ('weichbild') privileges and market rights after Celle model.
Toll_Description: A toll of the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg is mentioned in 1409.

Name: Sõmeru
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1615 as possession of the Manor of Noistfer (Purdi).

Name: Sommerfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1220.

Name: Sõmerpalu
Settlement_Description: Originally a castle, mentioned in 1555 and 1561. However, this has not been preserved. A manor was built in the early 16th century.

Name: Son
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1107, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Sondershausen
Settlement_Description: First mention in the records in 1125, the beginnings of the settlement are probably much older with Frankish roots. Situated above Sondershausen lies the Spatenburg, which was probably built during a program in 1075 by Henry IV.
Town_Description: In 1304 there's a first referral as "oppidum". 1347 was the first time the town's crest was used in a record and the town was referred to as "stat", with its inhabitants as "Borger". Oldest recorded town right from 1555, it is mentioned within that the first bylaws developed in the first half of the 15th century. Main traffic route within the town was the "Hauptstraße", which was merely known as "Straße" until at least the 16th century. The castle within the town received the functions of the Spatenburg during the 14th centruy.
Fair_Description: In 1550 two fairs are mentioned.

Name: Sunākste
Settlement_Description: The pastorate and the associated church were first mentioned in 1567.

Name: Maasilinna
Settlement_Description: A castle, which was built in 1345. The former castle in Peude was destroyed in an uprising, so that the residents had to build the new castle as an atonement ('Soneburg = Sühneburg').

Name: Sonnewalde
Settlement_Description: A sovereignty of Sonnewalde appears in 1255, the castle in Sonnewalde is mentioned in 1301 and was probably built upon a former slavic settlement. A village develops at the foot of the castle.

Name: Sonsbeck
Toll_Description: The Count of Cleves levied a land toll in 1319. In 1365, about 14 mark were collected per year, and from 1371 to 1395 about 16 mark.

Name: Sontra
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1232 and still called a village in 1358.
Town_Description: Was granted town privileges in 1368.

Name: Allendorf (Werra)
Alternative_Name: Allendorf; Bad Sooden-Allendorf; Oldendorp; Aldendorf; Aldendorp
Settlement_Description: Allendorf is first mentioned in 1229 and was at that time already a town, founded between 1212 and 1218.
Town_Description: Allendorf was founded between 1212 and 1218 near the saltworks of Sooden by the landgrave of Thuringia.

Name: Soeva
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1442.

Name: Żary
Alternative_Name: Sorau; Gau Sara; Sarow; Sarovia; Sarowe; Soraw; Saraw; Zaraw
Settlement_Description: Was probably the castle mound of a wendish castle
Town_Description: Burgrave Albrecht von Dewin likely granted the Madgeburg town law in 1260, mentioned as oppidum and civitas in 1329

Name: Sorgbrück
Settlement_Description: Ann inn at the river Sorge is first mentioned in 1470.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Sorge river is mentioned in 1587.

Name: Spaarndam
Alternative_Name: dammo apud Sparnam; Spernedam; Sparnedam; Sparendamme; Spaerndamme; Sparendam; Sperendam; Sparedam; Spaarendam
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1253, in a eighteenth century copy.
Lock_Description: A dam that closed off the Spaarne from the IJ already existed in 1253, when count Willem II of Holland announced the plan to build a lock for ships. The plan was not realised and the entire dam destroyed by floods before 1286. A new dam with a lock was mentioned in 1305, and the lock fees were set in 1316 to the same tariff as in 1253.

Name: Spalbeek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1253.

Name: Spandau
Alternative_Name: Berlin-Spandau; Spandow; Spandowe; Zpandow; Zpandowe; Spandaw; Spandawe
Settlement_Description: First traces of settlement have been dated to the 8th century and a Slavic castle existed into the 12th century. In 1197 the German castle is first mentioned and first traces of a German settlement could be dated to the beginning of the 13th century. Around 1200 the settlement around the castle mound in Spandau was abandoned and moved further north, where it became a market settlement around the church St. Nikolai.
Town_Description: The record, which grants the settlement next to the castle Brandenburg town rights in 1232 was interpolated, the actual awarding of said town rights presumably occurred around 1240 after a town fire.
Toll_Description: Wagoners had to pay a toll as early as 1320 as well as a street toll ('Deichselpfennig') later on.
Staple_Description: A temporary staple in Spandau is mentioned in a complaint of the Elector in 1450.

Name: Spangenberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1235.
Town_Description: 1261 'civitas'. 1309 Lippstadt law is confirmed.

Name: Pangodi
Settlement_Description: Manor, which was owned by King Gustav Adolf.

Name: Spechtsbrunn
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1414.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Gräfenthal (1728).

Name: Speulde
Alternative_Name: Spelde; Spuelde; Spaelde; Spolde; Gespoold; Spuel; Speuld; Speult
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1313.

Name: Spielberg
Settlement_Description: Mention in the record book of Hersfeld monastery.

Name: Spithal
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1350. The name of the settlement is possibly derived from a leprosy. The ruined church on the graveyard probably dates from the 12th century. In 1450, the village consisted of 8 farms and a cottage.

Name: Sprakensehl
Alternative_Name: Sprakensele; Sprakense; Sprakensen; Sprakensole; Sprakenzol; Sprakensol; Sprakenzel; Sprakensel; Sprakelsen; Sprakenslo; Sprakensten; Sprakenßelle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1246.

Name: Spremberg
Settlement_Description: In 1272 a family of Spremberg appears, who founds a castle and town in 1301.
Town_Description: An entry in a chronicle of the town founding in 893 is most likely untrue, town law was first mentioned in a 1397 sovereign document

Name: Springe
Alternative_Name: Helereisprig; Eleraegiesprig; Halresprige; Hallerspring; Sprincge; Halrespringhe; Halresprig; Halrespring; Halrespringhe; Halresringe; Sprinck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned before 1007. The St Andrew's church is mentioned in 1264.
Town_Description: The nearby castle of Hallermund was lost to the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg in 1282, whereupon the counts of Hallermund retreated to Springe. Possibly, the settlement was raised to a town soon afterwards. It is first mentioned as "oppidum" in 1324; town privileges exist from 1415.
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Hildesheim in Springe is mentioned when it was pawned to Reineke Holtgreve in 1388.

Name: Sprotta
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1314 as Sprotav.

Name: Sprundel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 992, in a falsification of circa 1610. Next mention in 1282.

Name: Staaken
Settlement_Description: First mention in the records in 1273, noble residence after it was sold to Spandau in 1295.

Name: Stabroek
Settlement_Description: First mention in a copy from 1244.

Name: Stade
Settlement_Description: The fortress and settlement was first mentioned when it was destroyed by Vikings in 994. Around 1000 the settlement became the seat of the counts of Stade.
Town_Description: King Otto IV granted town privileges in 1209; they were confirmed in 1236.
Toll_Description: The Archbishop of Bremen introduced a market toll in 1038, and in connection to the 1259 staple privilege a toll on the Elbe traffic at the mouth of the Schwinge (see there). Moreover, a toll existed on cattle driven through town, as well as a wine toll (mentioned 1487 and 1530).
Staple_Description: In 1259, Archbishop Hildebrand of Bremen founded the Stade staple, which forced all ships coming from the sea to stay in Stade for 3 tides. The staple led to conflicts with Hamburg, which managed to acquire exemption from the staple in Stade in 1340. In the long run, it proved to be impossible to enforce the staple for other seafarers as well. Next to Hamburg and Buxtehude, Stade was a staple market for grain along the Elbe, as confirmed in a treaty from 1487. Staple of the English Merchant Adventurers in 1577-1597 and 1602-1611.
Fair_Description: Stade acquired the market privilege in 1038; the oldest fair took place on St James's Day. A second fair on Tuesday after Easter is first mentioned in 1593, as well as a horse market on Letare Sunday. A second horse market eight days before Lent was renewed in 1670, but it is unknown when it was first organised. In 1692, St James's fair had a duration of 14 days, the Easter fair 8 days.

Name: Stadthagen
Alternative_Name: Indago Comitis; Grevenalveshaghen; Indago Comitis Adolphi; Haghen
Settlement_Description: Founded in ca. 1220 by count Adolf III or Adolf IV of Holstein-Schaumburg. A moated castle is first mentioned in 1224, a church in 1230.
Town_Description: Mentioned as "civitas" in a 1244 charter. The town acquired market privileges, among others the right of free trade with Minden and other towns, in 1322. Lippstadt town privileges were confirmed in 1344.

Name: Stadtlohn
Alternative_Name: Laon; Loen; Lon; Northlon; Nortlon; Nortloon
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1085.
Town_Description: The town rights were probably granted in the 13th century. 1411 Award of 'Wigboldsrechten', which were later confirmed by Bishop Otto IV of Münster.

Name: Stadtoldendorf
Alternative_Name: Aldenthorp; Aldendorp; Oldendorp; Oldendorpe; Aldendorpe; Oldendorppe; Stadtoldendorpe; Stadt Oldendorf; Stadtaltendorf; Stadtoldendorff; Stadt Oldendorf
Settlement_Description: A settlement must have existed long before the foundation of the town, possibly since the 5th century.
Town_Description: The foundation of the town was closely related to the nearby castle Homburg. Holzminden town privileges were granted by Heinrich of Homburg in 1255. Since 1281, the addition "stadt" (town) was part of the place name.
Toll_Description: A toll station is mentioned in toll lists of the years 1539, 1540 and 1587, but probably originated with the lords of Homburg.

Name: Stammen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 997 and 1000.

Name: Stramproy
Alternative_Name: Stramprode; Stramproede; Strampraide; Stramproyde; Stramproijen; Stamprai; Stampray; Stramproyen; Stamproy
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1299.

Name: Stapelfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1288.

Name: Stapelmoor
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1424, but the village church is dated to c. 1300.

Name: Staphorst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in copies from 1217, 1263, 1283 and 1346. Next mention in 1355.

Name: Stargard
Settlement_Description: The old wendish castle was acquired by the Margraves of Brandenburg in 1236, they built a fortress where a german village developed close by
Town_Description: Margrave Otto III. von Brandenburg grants the brandenburger town law in 1259

Name: Staßfurt
Settlement_Description: Staßfurt develops with the discovery of salines at the southern bank of the Bode.
Town_Description: Staßfurt gains town rights sometime before 1276 - probably around 1265. First mention of a castle in the records in 1278, it must have existed before that however and may have been destroyed during a conflict between emperor Frederick II. and Otto IV. Important economic role of the place due to its trade with salt, it did always have the problem that there was almost no wood in its surroundings. Wood had to be brought to Staßfurt via rivers in Calbe or Nienburg.

Name: Stauffenburg
Alternative_Name: Stouphenburch; Stovfenburch; Stauffenburgk; Stouphenburch; Stofeburg; Staufenberch
Settlement_Description: A castle was probably founded in the 11th century, first mentioned in 1130. It became an administrative centre for the region.

Name: Stavoren
Alternative_Name: Starum; Staveren; Stavron; Stavervn; Staurienses; Staurensis; Stauero; Stauern
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from the tenth or early eleventh century.
Town_Description: Cox states that town rights were granted by Egbert I of Brunswijk and Margrave of Friesland, before 1068. Van Berkel & Samplonius, however, state that town rights were granted before 1077 by Egbert's son and successor, Egbert II, Margrave of Meissen and Friesland.
Harbour_Description: A harbour is known to have existed in the tenth century, functioning as export port for salt. It gained real importance in the eleventh century, when Stavoren participated in trade on the Rhine and IJssel. Stavoren flourished in the fourteenth century, but as the Zuiderzee expanded, the harbor became shallow. As a result, it declined in importance.

Name: Steddorf
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 1306 in the context of damaged property of the monastery Zeven in Steddorf. In 1390 the entire village was sold to the monastery.

Name: Steelhoven
Alternative_Name: Sthenlo; Steello: te Steenloe; Steelo; Steloe; Stelo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1213.

Name: Steenderen
Alternative_Name: Stenere; Stenhere; Stenre; Steinre; Stenhare; Steenre; Steender; Seender
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1046, in a twelfth century copy.

Name: Steensel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1124.

Name: Steenwijk
Alternative_Name: Steenwijc; Steenwijck; Steynwich; Stenwic; Steenwic; Stenwyc; Steynwik; Steenwyck
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1141 (in a fifteenth century copy, which might be a falsification).
Town_Description: Earliest mention as 'opidum' in 1296. Probably, town privileges were granted by John II of Sierck (Jan II van Sierck), bishop of Utrecht before 29 February 1296.

Name: Stegen
Harbour_Description: First attempts to build a canal between Alster and Trave started in 1448. Although construction work was discontinued in 1452 without success, the section Hamburg-Stegen was kept navigable for the transport of lime from Segeberg, which was transferred from wagon to ship in Stegen. Transshipment in Stegen is still attested in 1557.
Lock_Description: Lock between the Alster and the Alster-Trave canal, which was constructed in 1527. Already in 1550, shipping on the canal was discontinued.

Name: Steimke
Alternative_Name: Stenbeke; Stembeke; Steynbeke; Steinbeke; Steymbeke; Stenebeke; Steenbeke; Stembecke; Stemke; Stemcke; Steimbk; Stemeke; Steinbeck; Steimbcke
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1196/97.

Name: Steinau an der Straße
Alternative_Name: Steinau; Steina; Steinahe; Steyna an der Strasze gegin Fulde; Stena; Steynauwe; Steynau; Stena an der Straze; Stäne
Settlement_Description: A castle might have been built around 900. Called 'castrum' in 1287. The settlement is only mentioned in the course of the granting of city rights in 1290.
Town_Description: In 1290 the settlement received town rights and a weekly market. 1401 and 1404 it is mentioned that the town has Frankfurt and Gelnhausen rights.

Name: Steinbach (Schleusingen)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1305.

Name: Steinbergen
Settlement_Description: Steinberg was characterised as "villa" in 1285.

Name: Steinbrück
Settlement_Description: Castle on the border of Hildesheim territory, which was erected in 1370-1383 by bishop Gerhard vom Berge of Hildesheim. It was first mentioned in 1391. The fortifications were demolished in 1643 and the site was turned into a manor.
Bridge_Description: Stone bridge across the Fuhse river, after which the castle was called.

Name: Steinbrücken
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1128.

Name: Steinburg
Settlement_Description: Moated castle of the counts of Holstein, first mentioned in 1307. The castle was demolished in 1640. A sconce remained; the last remains were demolished in 1763.

Name: Steinfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a charter of the monastery Amorbach of ca. 1000. However, the charter is interpreted as a falsification. In 1548, four farms are mentioned in Steinfeld.

Name: Steinförde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 990.

Name: Steinfurt
Toll_Description: Border toll station

Name: Steinheim am Main
Settlement_Description: The settlement is named 1223 and goes back to a castle that dates back to the 10th century.
Town_Description: In 1320 Frankfurt freedoms and rights were granted.

Name: Steinheim (Westfalen)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 963. Village in the 12th and 13th centuries.
Town_Description: Fortified in 1275 and raised to town.

Name: Steinkuhle
Settlement_Description: Toll house and inn. On the border between the princedoms a bit to the north, there was also a watchtower, where the town of Einbeck stationed a guard. The toll house was burnt down in the Thirty Years' War and not rebuilt afterwards.
Toll_Description: The toll was pawned by duke Eric I of Brunswick-Calenberg in 1514.

Name: Stelle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330.

Name: Stendal
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022. In the 10th century there already existed a small village settlement.
Town_Description: The settlement received market and town rights in 1160 according to the Magdeburg Law. In the 13th century the Stendaler Seefarer guild was created. Between 1350 and 1515 Stendal was a member of the Hanse.
Staple_Description: Removal of the market and staple rights of Magdeburg between 1547-1554 to Tangermünde, Stendal and Brandenburg, on account of the siege of Magdeburg.
Fair_Description: Stendal had three fairs, their dates and durations are unknown. During the siege of Magdeburg between 1547 and 1554, the Magdeburg market and staple was moved to Tangermünde, Stendal and Brandenburg.Since 1563 it was allowed to hold cattle and horse markets on two of the Stendal fair days.

Name: Stenderup
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1452.

Name: Sternberg
Settlement_Description: The town was founded without a pre-existing settlement between 1238 and 1256.
Town_Description: Fürst Pribislaw I of Mecklenburg founded the town with Parchim town privileges between 1238 and 1256. The settlement is mentioned as civitas in the early 14th century.

Name: Szczecin
Alternative_Name: Stettin; Stettyn; Stetin; Stetyn; Stityn; Stityn; Stitinum; Olden Stettin
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1091 as a castrum, at that point it was a ducal castle. It was given to the Danish in 1173 as a castellan castle. Two germen market settlements were growing in 1124-1129. After 1190 Knut IV of Danmark rebuilt the 'Burstaburg'.
Town_Description: In 1243 the Magdeburg town law was granted by Duke Barnim I of Pomerania after both market settlements were merged.
Toll_Description: A toll erected in 1311 for citizens of the Mark of Brandeburg, which the inhabitants of Stettin wished to avoid.
Staple_Description: First regulations restricting the grain trade in Pomerania to Stettin in 1253 and 1281; staple rights followed in 1283, with obligation to exchange wares and the forbidding of transports on the tributaries of the Oder and the banning of guest trading. Loosening of the staple in the 14th century for citizens of Gartz and Greifenhagen, who themselves claimed staple rights, and also for citizens from the Mark of Brandenburg, who after payment of toll were allowed to pass through Stettin in the same ship. Expansion of staple privileges in 1312: ban on the export of grain between Stettin and Ückermunde and on timber and coal between Stettin, Ziegenort, Crampe, and Altdamm, with imports into Stettin excepted. Around the middle of the 15th century a dispute between Stettin and Stargard over the bypassing of the Stettin stapel by shipping on the river on Ihna was settled in favour of Stettin. Confirmation of the staple followed in 1467, including the stipulation that all wares on ships coming from the sea into the Stettin lagoon and wares entering Stettin overland from the Oder basin should be stapled in Stettin. In 1475 merchants obliged to store herring in Stettin for three days. In the 16th century conflicts with Frankfurt over passage along the Oder. Abolition of the staple in 1752, after which Stettin enjoyed only a monopoly over the linseed trade.

Name: Steudnitz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1173.

Name: Haus Steuerwald
Settlement_Description: Around 1510/13, an inn was built by the bishop of Hildesheim, which was later called Haus Steuerwald after the nearby castle Steuerwald, which is first mentioned in 1310. The bailiff of the castle erected a boom barrier here in 1586, which was removed by the town of Hildesheim again afterwards.

Name: Stickhausen
Settlement_Description: The castle Stickhausen was erected around 1432 by Ulrich Cirksena, the later count of East Frisia.
Toll_Description: Around 1589, Count Johann II of East Frisia introduced a toll in Stickhausen. In 1599, a bridge and water toll is mentioned in connection to the fair in Detern. It was discontinued after a conflict with Oldenburg in 1641 at the latest. See Detern for further details.

Name: Stiddien
Alternative_Name: Stidegem; Striedegem; Stedehem; Stidiem; Stedium; Stydium; Styddium; Styddyem; Stiddeum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1172.

Name: Stiege
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as a castle and residence, slowly develops into a village until 1599 at the latest.

Name: Stockelsdorf
Settlement_Description: Manor belonging to Lübeck citizens, first mentioned in 1303. An inn is mentioned in Stockelsdorf in 1447.

Name: Stöcken (Uelzen)
Alternative_Name: Stöcken; Stokhem; Stockem; Stochen; Stokken; Stochym
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1142.

Name: Stöcken (Hannover)
Alternative_Name: Stöcken; Stockim; Stochem; Sthochem; Stokhem; Stockem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1185.
Toll_Description: The registers of the Amt Neustadt am Rübenberge from 1425 and 1426 list revenues from the toll in Stöcken.

Name: Stöcken (Wittingen)
Alternative_Name: Stöcken; Stockem; Stokkem apud Witingen; Stochem; Stokkedhe; Stokem; Stocken; Stockem uppe der Yzen; Stocheym in dem Lande to Witinge; Stöckhem; Stöckheim
Settlement_Description: First mentioned after 1209.

Name: Stockhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1246.

Name: Stokkem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1181.

Name: Stöckheim (Einbeck)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 826-876.

Name: Stalbe
Settlement_Description: The manor was mentioned in 1350 in the course of granting fief.

Name: Stolberg
Settlement_Description: First appearance of the settlement in the records in 1210, even though it most probably existed before that and must have been an important resting station on the way from Braunschweig to Erfurt via the Harz.
Town_Description: Gains town rights around 1300.

Name: Słupsk
Settlement_Description: Archaeological finds date back to the 7th ct. A castellan was mentioned since 1236. The castle probably stood where the current catholic church was built.
Town_Description: Duke Swantopolk II granted Lübeck town law in 1265 or 1278. Later in 1310 the Margrave Waldemar von Brandenburg granted the Lübeck town law again to the german market settlement.

Name: Stommeln
Toll_Description:
1) In 1389, the Duke of Jülich levied a land toll and a fee for safe conduct on land. For 1389/93 there is evidence of both horse toll and escort fee. Depending on the load, 2 to 3 alb. per horse had to be paid. On average, about 771 mark were collected per year. In 1398/99 it was about 283 mark. Later, this collection point was only referred to as a toll station.
2) The duke also levied a road toll in 1434/35. Tariffs are not known. In 1500/01, 20 mark were collected.

Name: Storkau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1209 in a name; mention of the village and farmstead in 1337.
Ferry_Description: Storkau maintained a small passenger ferry.

Name: Stötterlingenburg
Alternative_Name: Lüttgenrode; Stötterlingen; Stoterlingeborch; Stutirligburg; Stoterlingenborch; Stetterlingkburgk
Settlement_Description: Mention of a settlement of Stötterlingen in the 10th century; in 992 a monastery is founded within the castle of Stötterlingenburg, but the castle buildings were already gone by 1106 and the monastery was in lamentable condition in 1108. It was newly renovated, after which it gained some prosperity. The monastery was secularised in 1555.

Name: Straelen
Toll_Description: The Duke of Guelders levied a road toll in 1395. Tariffs and revenues are not known. A market toll was also mentioned from 1326.

Name: Stralsund
Settlement_Description: Fishingsettlement in slawic times, german colonists since around 1200
Town_Description: Prince Wistzlaw I. of Rügen grants the same town law as Rostock had, a civitas with Lübeck town law
Staple_Description: Staple for stockfish from Bergen; in 1446 members of the Hanse only allowed to export flour, malt, and other victuals to Bergen if they brought fish from Bergen back with them to Lübeck, Wismar, Rostock or Stralsund.

Name: Strasburg
Settlement_Description: The 'Straßenburg' with a castle settlement and historic district vanished early, two villages were incorporated so Germans and Slavs mixed in the castle settlement
Town_Description: Couldn't have been founded before 1250, the old village mayor was mentioned in 1267, granted Magdeburg town law, has been called civitas or town since 1328

Name: Stratum
Alternative_Name: Straethem; Straethom; Straten; Strathem; Straten; Stratem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1312-1350.

Name: Straupitz
Settlement_Description: First mention of a sovereignty of Straupitz in 1294.

Name: Strausberg
Settlement_Description: Foundation possibly around 1230, emergence of the German settlement in the first half of the 13th century.
Town_Description: Mention of a district ('Gemeyne') in 1337, mention of a mayor in 1373.

Name: Straußfurt
Settlement_Description: The settlement's name which alludes to a ford seems to be in direct contradicition to the name of the opposite Vehra, which alludes to a ferry. It is possible that the villages were founded at different times of the year, when the Unstrut had different water levels.

Name: Strecknitz
Settlement_Description: The manor Strecknitz, belonging to Lübeck, was first mentioned in 1248. Shortly after 1316, the "Grönauer Baum", a boom barrier across the street, was mentioned here. At the end of the 17th century, the fee for opening the barrier was 6 pfennig for wagons. There existed an inn at the barrier as well.

Name: Strehla
Settlement_Description: At the end of the 10th century a castle was built in the middle of a castle guard. A suburb developed around this castle.
Town_Description: Mentioned as 'civitas' 1210.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Oschatz.
Ferry_Description: According to wagoners, the Elbe was crossed here via ferry.

Name: Strelitz
Settlement_Description: First a wendish, then a german village, a castle was built which promoted the development of the village, mentioned as Strelitz in 1278
Town_Description: Neubrandenburg town law granted in 1349 by the Dukes Otto and Ulrich von Fürstenberg

Name: Ströbeck
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1004, referred to as borough ('Fleck') in 1470. Within Ströbeck, a watchtower can be found.

Name: Stroobos
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention is probably from circa 1660.

Name: Stromberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned either 1158 or 1159.

Name: Strukdorf
Alternative_Name: Structorpe; Strucktorp; Struktorpe; Strucktorppe; Struckstorpe; Struckdorpp; Strucktorff; Struckdorff

Name: Stubbendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned after 1324.

Name: Ulbroka
Settlement_Description: In 1528 the area was given as a fief. Thereupon, a manor was built, which was given to the Mayor of Riga in 1562.

Name: Sztum
Settlement_Description: An Old Prussian castle was destroyed in 1236 and a castle of the Teutonic Order was built between 1326 und 1335, it became the see of a komtur in 1331, then in 1333 the see of a bailiff and a chapel in 1413, later it was mentioned as a yard of the Teutonic Order
Town_Description: Founding documents with Kulm town law were given in 1416 by the Grand master Michael Küchmeister von Sternberg, endorsed in 1754

Name: Suchsdorf
Settlement_Description: Since the 14th century, the village belonged to the Hospital of the Holy Ghost in Kiel.

Name: Sudenburg
Settlement_Description: Formerly a suburbium south of the cathedral that was always closely related to the cathedral immunity. Foundation of the Peter-and-Paul abbey in 1202, which was moved to the Neustadt in 1228. In 1213 destroyed by Otto IV., Sudenburg had an own council and town hall after reconstruction, as well as own guilds.

Name: Suderburg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1004.

Name: Süderlügum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 15th century.

Name: Suderwittingen
Alternative_Name: Suderwitinge; Suderwittinghe; Suderwitinghe; Sauer Wytynge; Suderwieting; Sunderwetteghen; Surwiting; Suderwytinghen; Surewitingen; Szuder Wytinge; Surewyttingk; Szurewitingk; Saurwieting; Sauwrewieting
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1226.

Name: Südkampen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1255.

Name: Südlohne (Oldenburg)
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1291.

Name: Suhl
Settlement_Description: Salt and natural resource deposits facilitated early settlement in the region. In 1445 Suhl became a borough ('Flecken').
Town_Description: Granted town rights by William VI., count of Henneberg.
Toll_Description: Toll registries show the tolls that had to be paid in Suhl in 1502 and 1524. (ThStA Meiningen, Sekt. III Nr. 510 (1502); ThStA Meiningen, Sekt. III 510 (A 14b) Nr. 3).)
Fair_Description: In 1544 Wilhelm IV. of Henneberg Schleusingen is given three fair privileges by emperor Karl V. Another is added in 1599. In 1661 the fairs were moved from Sundays to Tuesdays.

Name: Suislepa
Settlement_Description: Village and crown land that was first mentioned in 1583. At the end of the 18th century Neu Suislep (Uue Suislepa) was created, but is now merged with Alt Suislep (Vana Suislepa).

Name: Sülbeck (Leine)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1174-1194.
Toll_Description: A toll in Sülbeck is mentioned in 1619 and 1629.

Name: Sülfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1017.

Name: Sülfeld
Lock_Description: Lock between the river Beste and the Alster-Trave canal, which was constructed in 1527. Already in 1550, the shipping on the canal was discontinued.

Name: Sulingen
Alternative_Name: Sulegon; Sulegen; Sulighen; Sulgen; Sülgen; Sülleghe
Settlement_Description: Around 800, a missionary parish ('urpfarrei') was founded by the diocese of Minden. The settlement is first mentioned in 1029 and is characterised as borough ('flecken') in 1519.
Town_Description: The settlement was first mentioned as town in 1558. A town seal is attested as well. However, formal town rights were first granted in 1929.

Name: Bad Sülze
Alternative_Name: Sülze; Sulta; Sulten; to der Sulten; Sulte; salina iexta Marlow; Sulta iexta Marlow; Sultze; Sülz
Settlement_Description: The settlement grew close to the saline that was first mentioned in 1229, although most likely older than that, settlement itself was first mentioned in 1243
Town_Description: Founded with Lübeck town law by the lords of Rostock, which is provable since 1298, founding likely encouraged by Rostock merchants, mentioned as consules in 1262, as civitas in 1278, privileges have been endorsed multiple times

Name: Sundern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1310.

Name: Suntaži
Settlement_Description: The manor was mentioned in 1318 and was owned by the Archbishop of Riga. A castle was built at the same time.

Name: Süpplingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 888.

Name: Süpplingenburg
Settlement_Description: The castle was built in the 10th or 11th century on a river island west of the current settlement. The settlement was first mentioned in 1106.

Name: Süstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1296.

Name: Susteren
Alternative_Name: Svestra; Suestera; Sustrensi; Sostra; Sustra; Suestrensis; Suestrense
Settlement_Description: Susteren is first mentioned in a 1191-copy of a document dated 714.
Town_Description: Susteren is first mentioned as a town on 26 April 1276. An official charter of town grants is not known to exist (or have existed). It is possible that town privileges were granted by Reginald I, count of Guelders.

Name: Sustrum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1000.

Name: Tabivere
Settlement_Description: In the middle of the 16th century a hamlet ('Hof') emerged around which a small village settled (mentioned in 1582).

Name: Tahkuranna
Settlement_Description: Around 1500, the hamlet ('Hof'), probably owned by the Teutonic Order, was set up. In 1620 the court was fief.

Name: Puurmani
Settlement_Description: Before 1561 the farm belonged to the Falkenau monastery. The manor was crownland property until 1645.

Name: Tammiste
Settlement_Description: Manor and estate were first mentioned in 1560.

Name: Tangeln
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1348.

Name: Tangermünde
Settlement_Description: First mention between 1012 and 1018. The settlement was the centre of a castle district ('Burgwardmittelpunkt') in the 10th to 12th century. In 1196 property in Tangermünde was given to the archbishop of Magdeburg.
Town_Description: The margraves of Brandenburg promoted the town's development, which was mostly finished around 1200. In 1436 Tangermünde joined the Hanse.
Toll_Description: In 1345 the exception of toll and safe conduct for the citizens of Stendal in Salzwedel, Osterburg, Tangermünde, Seehausen, Werben, Havelberg and Arneburg. Mentions of the toll in 1373, 1377 and 1385, it is differentiated between the land (town) toll and the water (Elbe) toll. Further mentions in 1414, 1428 and 1458 when the excemption of toll of the citizens of Tangermünde is mentioned.
Staple_Description: From 1547 to 1554 the staple and market from Magdeburg are moved to Tangermünde, Stendal and Brandenburg, due to the siege on Magdeburg.
Fair_Description:
From 1547 to 1554 the staple and market from Magdeburg are moved to Tangermünde, Stendal and Brandenburg, due to the siege on Magdeburg.
Through complaints by Magdeburg in 1668, four fairs are known, two of which take place during autumn. A fair in August and a fair on St. Martin's day are mentioned. In 1686, fairs on Carnival and St. Johannis' day are mentioned.

Name: Tanne
Toll_Description: The toll station in Rucksbruch was moved to Tanne in the 1720s.

Name: Gvardeysk
Settlement_Description: An Old Prussian castle was given to the Teutonic Order in 1265 and subsequently extended, the castle was moved between 1280-1290 and later became the see of a komtur and then of a 'Pfleger', for a while it was the residence of Duk Albrecht, who died there in 1567, the castle was given to the sovereign authority in 1794 by Friedrich Wilhelm II.

Name: Tarnów
Staple_Description: Unimportant staple, confirmed in the Polish Staple Law of 1565

Name: Tarvastu
Settlement_Description: The parish was mentioned in 1225 and 1234, making it one of the oldest. The first church was built in the 14th century. In addition, there was a castle of the Teutonic Order in Tarwast, which was built at the beginning of the 14th century. It was destroyed at the end of the 16th century.

Name: Taucha
Settlement_Description: The settlement was mentioned in 979.
Town_Description: The town was founded in the middle of the 12th century. The town presumably had 'Magdeburg law'.
Toll_Description: Seconday station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Leipzig.

Name: Taurupe
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1492 and was owned by the Pahlen-Family.

Name: Tecklenburg
Alternative_Name: Titkelenburg; Tekeneburc; Tikkeneburg; Tiegneburg; Tyclenburch; Tegkeneburch; Techeneburg; Tekeneburg; Tikeneburgensis; Tikkeneborg; Ticillenburch; Thekeneborig; Tiäkenbuorg
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1150. In 1226 it is referred to as 'suburbium'.
Town_Description: In 1388 the place was already designated as a town, but only received town privileges in the 17th century.

Name: Tegau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1071.

Name: Teglingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 9th century. The name goes back to a court, which was mentioned regularly until the 18th century.

Name: Telgt
Alternative_Name: Telgud; Tellechte; Telghit; Telgit; Telghede; Tellicht; Telcht
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 806, in a tenth century copy.

Name: Telgte
Alternative_Name: Telgoht; Telgit; Telghet; Suttelghet; Telleghet; Telgtt; Telgot; Telget; Telgith; Telged; Teelget; Telleghot; Theliget; Telgott; Telgget; Telgelt; Tellichte; Telligt; Tellechte; Telgite
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1090.
Town_Description: In 1238 Telgte was granted 'Wigboldsrechte' and was later called a town.

Name: Tellingstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned ca. 1140.

Name: Teltow
Settlement_Description: Probably founded before 1230, 1232 granted Spandau rights.
Town_Description: The first mention in the records occurs in 1265, when Teltow is granted the same rights and privileges as other towns such as Spandau, Brandenburg or Berlin. It never develops, already in 1300 it only appears as oppidum
Fair_Description: Three fairs are mentioned before 1700, especially flax markets.

Name: Tempelberg
Settlement_Description: In 1244 the settlement's tithe is given to the Order of the Temple.

Name: Czaplinek
Settlement_Description: Originally an old slavic settlement called Czaplin, the oldest documents call the area a 'desertum'.
Town_Description: The town was founded with Magdeburg town law between 1281 and 1334. The area was given to the Order of the Templars in 1286 who built a castle there around 1291, which later became a catholic church. In 1312 the area was given to the Order of the Knights of St John. It later belonged to the Ascanians, the margraves of Brandenburg, who gave it to two knights. They were called the owners of the town in 1334. The by King Stephan.

Name: Tempelhof
Settlement_Description: First mention in the records in 1247, no records of the foundation remain. The settlement first was the property of the Order of the Temple, from which it derived its name. In 1435 the Knights of St. John of Jerusalem, who had gained property of the settlement, sell it to the towns of Berlin-Cölln.

Name: Templin
Settlement_Description: A pomeranian castle that became ascanian in 1230
Town_Description: The date of the towns founding is unknown, probably founded in 1250 by the Ascanians, first mentioned in 1270, usually called civitas around 1314 and 1320

Name: Ten Boer
Alternative_Name: De Bure; vanden Bueren; vanden Buer; Buerum; Tembuer; Ten Buir
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in a copy dating from 1301.

Name: Bad Tennstedt
Settlement_Description: Mention in the times of Charlemagne in a gift certificate. The foundation of the settlement were two castles. In the 12th century, the settlement developed into a market borough ('Marktflecken').
Town_Description: Referred to as town (civitas) in 1275, a town constitution exists since the 13th century.

Name: Eembrugge
Alternative_Name: Ter Eem; Ema; Emebrucge; Eme; Eembrugghe; Emebruggen; Eem brug; Ter-Eem
Settlement_Description: Eembrugge is first mentioned in 1254, the near-by castle 'Huis ter Eem' in 1252. The settlement was located near a ford in the river Eem. A bridge was built there in the late twelfth century. Eembrugge is located on the road between Baarn and Bunschoten.
Town_Description: Eembrugge was granted town privileges sometime between 1336 and 1340 by John ('Jan') III van Diest, bisshop of Utrecht. According to Cox it never fully developed into a town and was destroyed in 1527 by people from Guelders. Van Berkel & Samplonius argue that it was an important town untill its destruction in 1527. The castle was destroyed as well in 1527. After the destruction, habitation moved to the west side of the river Eem.

Name: Terborg (Gelderland)
Alternative_Name: Burch; Ter Borch; Ter Borch; Terborch; Borg (Ter); Burg; Ter-Burg; Ter-Borgh; Ter-Borch; Terborg
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1325.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted on 23 April 1419, by Dirk and Hendrik, lords of Wissche (Wisch).

Name: Terborg (Ostfriesland)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1357.

Name: Terherne
Alternative_Name: Terhorne; ter Herna; Terhorna; toer Herna; Herne
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1491.

Name: Terkaple
Alternative_Name: Cappelghe; Capella; Caple; Ter Capla; Cappelle; Ter Kappel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in thirteenth century.

Name: Terschuur
Alternative_Name: Terschuer; ther schueren; bij der Schuir; ter Schuer; Ter Schuur; ter Schuren; Ter Schuir
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention around 1400.

Name: Terwolde
Alternative_Name: Ter Wolde; Wolde; van der Woelde; Twoelde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1295.

Name: Tessin
Settlement_Description: A castle existed in wendish time, german castrum mentioned in 1301, bailiwick mentioned in 1333
Town_Description: Mecklenburg acquired the land in 1323, town first mentioned in 1325, mentioned as oppidum in 1343 evidence of Schwerin town law from 1364, no verifiable priviliges, usually called civitas

Name: Teterow
Alternative_Name: Thiterow; Thiterowe;Teterouwe; Teterowe; Tetrow; Thetherow; Theterow; Tetherow
Settlement_Description: In wendish times a castle in circipania with a wendish village close by, conquered by the Danes in 1171
Town_Description: Nikolaus von Werle granted Schwerin-Güstrow town law shortly before 1272, privileges have often been endorsed, usually called oppidum or civitas

Name: Tettenborn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1237.

Name: Teupitz
Settlement_Description: First mention of a castle and settlement in 1307.
Toll_Description: The lords ('Schenken') of Landsberg, who resided on castle Teupitz, owned the land toll in Teupitz, as well as the bridge- and dam tolls in Königs-Wusterhagen and Wendisch-Buchholz.

Name: Teutleben
Settlement_Description: First mention at the end of the 8th or the beginning of the 9th century.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Tenneberg, the table of fees ('Zolltafel') was written and valid for both places.

Name: Theal
Settlement_Description: The parish of Theal was mentioned in 1379.

Name: Kloster Thedinga
Settlement_Description: The Benedictine monastery was allegedly founded by the holy Hatebrand, who was abbot of Feldwirth around 1190. However, it is first mentioned in a charter only in 1338. The last time the monastery was mentioned in documents was in 1616, after which the monastery seems to have been closed.

Name: Themar
Settlement_Description: First mention in the record book of Fulda monastery in 796.
Town_Description: The referral as civitas and oppidum can be found in 1317 and 1319. The settlement is referred to as borough ('Flecken') in 1452 and as market borough ('Marktflecken') in 1491. After that the term "town" is established.

Name: Thiede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 780 and 802.
Toll_Description: A toll of the duke of Brunswick in Thiede is mentioned in 1347, but not anymore in descriptions of tolls in the Amt Wolfenbüttel from the 16th and 17th centuries.

Name: Thienbüttel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1200.

Name: Thiene
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1037.

Name: Thiensen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1349.

Name: Thölstedt
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1211.

Name: Tome
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1434. In 1442, a manor was built by the Teutonic Order.

Name: Toruń
Staple_Description: In the late 14th century, the city attempted to create a staple market, which led to conflicts with Cracow. Both cities gave up their staples in 1391, but as Cracow started to force merchants to offer their wares on the market in 1398, Toruń received new rights from the Grand Master, which included a staple with limitations to the streets to be used for commodities exported from Poland (wax, furs, metals and spices) and imported cloth from England. When the staple lost importance after the peace of Thorn in 1411, it was reinstated in 1428 and now included corn; confirmed in 1448 with the inclusion of river transport, and again by King Casimir in 1457 after Toruń became Polish. The staple was cancelled after 1466, with the exception of the obligation to travel only on roads leading through town. Attempts to reinstate the staple led to many conflicts with other cities, until all obligations were annulled in 1496. There were renewed attempts to establish a staple in the 16th century, which was confirmed by the Pope in 1516. The King decided in 1533 that ships on the Vistula heading upstream had to unload in Toruń, although the full staple was not acknowledged. A renewed obligation to travel via Toruń from Danzig to Poland was instated, but cancelled in 1537 again, with the exemption of fish. In the 17th century, only the fish staple still existed.

Name: Thräna
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1181, 1243 mention as manor.

Name: Thuine
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention from 836.

Name: Mittelsten Thüle
Settlement_Description: The hamlet ('bauerschaft') Thüle, first mentioned in 1270, was stretched out along 6 km and was divided into three parts. The middle part was first mentioned separately in 1411.

Name: Thüste
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022.

Name: Tiddische
Alternative_Name: Didghesche; Terxsen; Tudesche; Tydisen; Tiddeschke; Diedisch; Tyddisch; Thidisch
Settlement_Description: Mentions of the settlement before 1366 (among others as "Didighessen" in 1315) are very uncertain.

Name: Thiedenwiese
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th or 11th century as Tiadikasheim, abandoned probably before 1412. In the 18th century, a post station named Thiedenwiese was installed south of the former settlement.

Name: Tiefthal
Alternative_Name: Tiefental; Diffentale; Tifental; Tyffentayl; Diefenthale; Diefedal
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1074. The settlement was probably founded by St. Peter's monastery in Erfurt, later it became property of the town of Erfurt.

Name: Tiel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 850-865 (possibly 855), in a copy of 1170-1175. In 893, Tiel is mentioned as an 'oppidum'.
Town_Description: Tiel was probably granted town privileges by Holy Roman Emperor Henry VI between 1191 and 1197. It is first mentioned as a town in 1195.
Fair_Description: At least from 1447 onward, an unknown number of fairs were held in Tiel. From a source probably dating from the fifteenth century, it is known that four fairs were held in Tiel. One horse fair, a cattle fair, and two cloth fairs.

Name: Tienen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 872, a falsification from the twelfth century . Next mention in 1146.

Name: Tytsjerk
Alternative_Name: Tietjerk; Thiatzerckera; Tyetzerka; Tyeetzerke; Tyetzerck; Tijetzerck; Tziekech; Tjetjerck; Tjetjerk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1392.

Name: Tilburg
Alternative_Name: Tilliburgis; Tilborg; Tilburch; Tilbvrg; Tylburg; Thilborhc; Tilborh; Tilebort; Tilborch
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of Tilburg can be found in an 1191 copy of an document dated 709. Tilburg was elevated to town rank on 18 April 1809 by Louis Bonaparte, king of Holland.

Name: Tildonk
Alternative_Name: Tieldunch; Tieldonc; Tildunc; Tildunch; Thyldunch; Tieldunc
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1107.

Name: Tielenbrücke
Bridge_Description: Bridge across the Tielenau, first mentioned in the 16th century.

Name: Sovetsk
Alternative_Name: Tilsit; Sowetsk; Sowjetsk; Tilse; Tillsit; Tilsa; Tilshele
Settlement_Description: A castle was built in 1365, another in 1406 with an adjoining Old Prussian settlement, towards the end of the Teutonic Order, a market hamlet grew, a Franciscan monastery was built
Town_Description: Duke Albrecht grants town law in 1552
Staple_Description: In 1543 grain barges travelling through Tilsit obliged to offer their goods for sale for three days

Name: Timmaspe
Settlement_Description: Characterised as 'villa' in 1320, and as village ('dorp') in 1538.

Name: Timmeitz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1450/51. It consisted of 3 farms at the time.

Name: Timmerhorn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1331.

Name: Tirza
Settlement_Description: The church, that belonged to to parish of Tirsen-Wellan, was built by the brothers Johann and Fabian von Tiesenhausen in 1589.

Name: Titz
Toll_Description: In 1389, the Duke of Jülich levied a land toll and a fee for safe conduct on land. In 1389/93, both horse toll and escort fees are recorded. Depending on the load, 2 to 3 alb. had to be paid per horse. On average, about 5 mark could be collected per year. In 1398/99 it was 20 mark.

Name: Tödwensche Brücke
Bridge_Description: The bridge was first mentioned in 1438 and belonged to the village Tödwen (Tõdva), which was first mentioned in 1241. There existed inns on both sides of the bridge.

Name: Toldijk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1506.

Name: Tolkmicko
Settlement_Description: An Old Prussian castle sat next to where the town would be, a castle of the Teutonic Order was destroyed in 1454, where a castle of the starost would be built after 1466, with a village adjoining
Town_Description: Founded by a locator and given the founding documentsby the komtur of Elbing, Ludwig von Schippen (1296-1300), a handfast with Kulm town law was granted in 1351 by Grand master Heinrich Dusemer and renewed in 1444 by Grand master Konrad von Erlichhasen

Name: Tollendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330/52. In 1450, the village consisted of 2 farms, 2 half farms and a mill; in 1564 of 6 farms.

Name: Tõlluste
Settlement_Description: In 1528 an estate was called Arries. Before that, the place was probably a manor.

Name: Tongeren
Alternative_Name: Tungris; Tungros; Tungrorum; Tungrus; Tongrensis; Tongren; Tongern; Tongres
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 390, in a sixth century and ninth century copy. Next mention in sixth century copy. Next mention in circa 575, in end seventh century copy. Next mention in 980. Next mention in 1049.

Name: Töpingen
Settlement_Description: A "Holt de Tobinghe" is mentioned as a new citizen in the Lüneburg town register in 1302, which is the first written reference to the village of Töpingen.

Name: Torgau
Toll_Description: A transit toll on the Elbe in Torgau is first mentioned in 1386, a salt and wine toll in 1432. The regulations of safe conduct in Torgau from 1510 give the exact fees for bulk wares ('Zentnergut') LHASA, MD, d. 49, Nr. 2, Amt Torgau 1510, p. 348–354.)
Fair_Description: The fairs in Torgau were confirmed in 1575 and 1641.

Name: Torma
Settlement_Description: Manor and the associated village and hamlet ('Hof') were mentioned in 1493.

Name: Tornau (Stendal)
Settlement_Description: First mention in a name; first mention of the village in 1238.

Name: Töttleben
Settlement_Description: Mention in the record book of Fulda monastery.

Name: Tramm
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330/52. In 1450 the settlement consisted of 2 farms.

Name: Travemünde
Settlement_Description: Count Adolf III of Holstein built a tower here in 1187 to secure the mouth of the Trave river. The settlement was first called Travemünde in 1219, and a fire beacon for navigation is mentioned in 1226. The tower was acquired by Lübeck in 1247, and in 1329 the entire settlement. It was reconstructed as a fortress after 1559.

Name: Trebatsch
Settlement_Description: First mention of the name in 1324, further mention of the settlement in 1495.
Toll_Description: The family of Trebatsch held a toll on rafted lumber on the Trebatsh Fließ.

Name: Trebbin
Settlement_Description: First mention of Trebbin in a name, which proves the existence of the castle. The settlement and market that went with the castle are only mentioned in 1373.
Town_Description: Awarding of town rights is unknown, they can first be proven in the 15th century.
Toll_Description: Station of safe conduct and toll known for 1375. In 1560 income from the dam toll is still known.

Name: Treben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1200.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Altenburg.

Name: Trebitz
Settlement_Description: First (real) mention in 1004 as a castle district ('Burgward'). Temporalily the place was mentioned as a borough ('Flecken') or a little town ('Städtlein').

Name: Trebnitz
Settlement_Description: In 1252 the manor Trebnitz is bought.

Name: Trechtingshausen
Toll_Description: A river toll on the Rhine was levied here for several years. The Lord of Hohenfels was the owner of the toll in the periods 1260 to 1269 and 1278 to 1282. Possibly a toll was also levied by the Mainz cathedral chapter in 1369. However, it is unclear whether the imperial grant of toll rights in the same year applied to Trechtingshausen or Niederheimbach. Tariffs from the 13th century are not known. In 1369, a charge of 2½ Turnosgroschen per barrel of wine is recorded.

Name: Turaida
Alternative_Name: Treiden; Treyden; Thoraida; Thoredia; Thoreyda; Threiden; Treygdenn; Dreiden
Settlement_Description: In 1214, Bishop Philipp von Ratzeburg built a castle that was the residence of the Teutonic Order in the 15th century. Only a ruin can be seen since the 18th century. The parish of Treyden was mentioned in 1248 and 1457.

Name: Trems
Alternative_Name: Trems-Mühle; molendinum Premnize; Premesce; Premece; Premze; Premscen; Tremsmol
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1215. At the mill and settlement Trems, there was a crossing of the Lübeck enclosure ('landwehr'), which was constructed around 1300. It consisted of a boom barrier and a watchtower with a guard.

Name: Trendelburg
Alternative_Name: Trindirberg; Drendeneburg; Dreyndeneborch; Dreyndeburg; Treyndeneborg; Tryndenborg; Drenderborg; Trindenburgk; Drengilburg; Drendelberg; Trindelnburgk; Trendelburgk; Drenterborch
Settlement_Description: Comes from the village of Trende, 1 km upstream and mentioned in 1203. In 1303 the village was relocated to Trendelburg. Called a city in 1304, but it is unclear whether town privileges were officially granted.

Name: Trzebiatów
Alternative_Name: Treptow an der Rega; Trybethowe; Trebutowe; Tribetowe; Treptowe
Settlement_Description: A first settlement grew close to a slavic castle and a church was mentioned in 1175. A Benedictine Convent was founded at the end of the 12. ct., but was soon relocated.
Town_Description: The founding date is not known, but it was mentioned as civitas in 1245. The town law was confirmed in 1540.

Name: Treuenbrietzen
Alternative_Name: Bricene; Bryzna; Briessen; Truwenbriessen; Trewen Briezen
Settlement_Description: A local noble family is proven since 1209, a castle since 1217. In the shelter of the castle a settlement develops, that is soon granted market privileges. It merges with another settlement that began around St. Nikolai church.
Town_Description: In 1290 the civitas is granted a larger area and furhter privileges, which means it must have reached town status earlier. Since 1324 Magdeburg town rights can be proven.
Toll_Description: In the district of Treuenbrietzen, the fee of safe conduct on wagons with centerloas ('Zentnerwagen') was 6, beyond the border 8 pennies.
Fair_Description: In 1521 a cattle market is granted that is merged into a cattle and flax market in 1606. In 1671 five fairs are granted or confirmed, four of which have a preceding cattle-, horse- and flax market.

Name: Treysa
Alternative_Name: Treise; Trese; Treyse; Treiss; Treisa; Dreysa; Treyßa; Dreis; Drees; Trres
Settlement_Description: A settlement is mentioned in the 8th century. Mentioned as a 'villa' in 1229 and as a village in 1233.
Town_Description: 1270 referred to as 'oppidum' and given a town seal. The settlement was probably previously raised to a town under Count Friedrich I. von Ziegenhain (1186-1229). However, the privileges were not confirmed until 1445.

Name: Tribsees
Settlement_Description: first documented in 1136, see of the slawic castellans, see of the stewardship of Tribsees, town grew out of the fortress of the princes of Rügen
Town_Description: town law granted between 1218 and 1267, 1285 Lübeck town law in the style of Rostock ratified by Prince Witzlaw II.

Name: Trzebiel
Town_Description: First mentioned as town in 1301, a castle is mentioned in 1319 and 1336, probably founded by the owner of the feoff of the castle

Name: Trittau
Alternative_Name: Trittouwe; Truttowe; Trutowe; Trittowe; Trittou; Trittow
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1239. A castle was built in Trittau by count Johann of Holstein in 1326. It was pawned to Lübeck in 1375, 1504-1515, and 1524. It was conquered by Lübeck troops in 1534, but returned to Holstein the following year. The castle was demolished in 1775.
Toll_Description: The toll of the counts of Holstein in Trittau is first mentioned in 1457. According to a register of toll revenues from the early 1540s, the toll receipts were usually around 600 Lübeck mark per year.

Name: Troisdorf
Toll_Description: Toll station of the dukes of Berg, first mentioned in 1387. It was abolished in 1389, but re-installed around 1400.

Name: Trotha
Settlement_Description: In Trotha finds of the Thuringians were recovered, probably a settlement existed since then. During the middle ages a noble family of Trotha existed. In 1900 Trotha was incorporated into Halle.

Name: Trügleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1267.

Name: Mustvee
Settlement_Description: During the 14th century the settlement was a fishing village. It received town rights in 1938.

Name: Tuchtfeld
Alternative_Name: Ducfelden; Tufelte; Tuckfelde; Tuffelde; Tugfelde; Duchfelde; Zuchtfeld; Tuchtfeldte; Tofell; Tuckfeldt; Tuchtfeldt; Tuchtfelde; Tuchfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 8th or 9th century.

Name: Tukums
Alternative_Name: Tuckum; Tuckemen; Thuckem; Tuckheym; Thuckem; Tuckheym; Tockheym; Tuckumb
Settlement_Description: The area fell to the Teutonic Order in 1253, that built a castle in 1299. A manor was mentioned since 1442. In 1445 a fortified borough was stated.

Name: Tungeln
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1160 by biship Philipp of Osnabrück.

Name: Türi
Settlement_Description: Around 1300 there was a church in whose surroundings a village developed.

Name: Turnhout
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1186.

Name: Tüttleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 822.

Name: Tuczno
Alternative_Name: Tütz; Thuetz; Tuitz; Thucz; Tietz; Tenczik
Settlement_Description: Originally a bailiwick and slavic settlement. A sword from the 7th ct. was found. Then area later belonged to the ascanian Margraves of Brandenburg and the House of Wedell were its patrons.
Town_Description: The town privileges were attested in 1306 and the Magdeburg town law was granted in 1331 by the brothers von Wedell.

Name: Twello
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from the end of thirteenth century.

Name: Twijzel
Alternative_Name: Twizel; Twislum; Opwysel; Up-twyzel; Opt Wysel; Twysel; Twijel; Optwijzel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from the thirteenth century, probably from circa 1240.

Name: Twillingen
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1301.

Name: Twiste
Alternative_Name: Tuistai; Zuisla; Twista; Teuiste; Suiste; Twist; Thuiste; Tuiste; Duiste; Twyste; Twisten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 820 and 876.

Name: Twistringen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the list of donors to the construction of the Weser bridge in Bremen, ca. 1250. The settlement is doubtlessly older; a parish was possibly already founded before 850.

Name: Ubbakal
Settlement_Description: The small village, which was first mentioned in 1564 belongs to the Manor of Koigi.

Name: Ubbergen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1277.

Name: Uebigau
