Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Liebenwerda.

Name: Uhti
Settlement_Description: Village that was first mentioned in 1299.

Name: Uchte
Settlement_Description: A castle of the count of Hoya is built in 1284. Next to it, a settlement developed, which had a burgomaster and council in 1459 and was characterised as borough ('flecken') in 1520.

Name: Uckerath
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll from 1440. Tariffs are not known. In the years 1440/41 and 1441/42 a lease of 12 mark can be recorded.

Name: Ückermünde
Alternative_Name: Ueckermünde; Ucramund; Ucremunde; Ukeremunde; Ukirmunde; Uckermünde
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in regard to a state parliament assembly in 1178, also in 1223
Town_Description: Lübeck town law granted around 1260, first mentioned as a town in 1276

Name: Uden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1190.

Name: Uudeküla
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1564.

Name: Udria
Settlement_Description: The village belonged to the Lagena manor since 1623.

Name: Uelsen
Settlement_Description: The church of St Willibrord already existed in 1131, and there was a regional court in the village.

Name: Uelzen
Alternative_Name: Ullishusun; Vlleshusen; Vlessen; Hullisheim; Ullesen; Vlseln; Ultzen; Lewenwolde; Leowenwolde; Ülzen; Ulyssaea
Settlement_Description: Around 1260, the settlement at the monastery Uelzen (the current Oldenstadt) was moved to the western shore of the Ilmenau river as a result of a conflict between the dukes of Lüneburg and the counts of Schwerin.
Town_Description: The "new town" Uelzen acquired Lüneburg town privileges from duke Johann of Brunswick in 1270, under the name Lewenwolde.
Toll_Description: A toll at the monastery in the old town (Oldenstadt) is first mentioned around 1133/37, when it was given to the monastery by the bishop of Verden. After the foundation of the new town of Uelzen, the toll was owned by the duke of Brunswick, who sold it to the town in 1370. The toll was levied at the town gates from travellers from outside of the principality of Lüneburg, who carried commodities with them.
Fair_Description: Fairs in Uelzen are first mentioned in 1448, on Letare Sunday (mid-Lent) and the Day of St John. In the late 16th century, two additional fairs are mentioned: dedication day, on the Nativity of Mary, and on Invocavit Sunday.

Name: Uerdingen
Toll_Description:
1) The Archbishop of Cologne levied a fee for safe conduct on the Rhine even before 1279. Tariffs and revenues have not been preserved. The levy was abolished in the same year.
2) The archbishop levied a land toll in 1449/53. The annual revenue around the years 1454/60 amounted to about 80 mark.

Name: Uetze
Alternative_Name: Utisson; Utissen; Vtesseim; Uttessem; Uttesse; Utze; Vtze
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022.

Name: Ikšķile
Settlement_Description: The village where Bishop Meinhard started the Liven mission was first mentioned in 1184. A castle and a church were therefore built in 1185. In 1202 the castle lost its importance and the live began several riots. The Teutonic Order was able to regain the castle in the 14th and 15th centuries. The village was mentioned in 1405. In 1507 there was a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk').

Name: Üffeln
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1240.

Name: Ufhoven
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1047.

Name: Ugchelen
Alternative_Name: Uchtelerberg; Uggelremere; Uchtelen; Oechelen; Uchgelen; Uchelen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1243.

Name: Uulu
Settlement_Description: Village and manor house, which originated around 1500. A courtyard was mentioned in 1601.

Name: Uhlstädt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1084.

Name: Ulmale
Settlement_Description: In 1350, the settlement was mentioned as fief. In 1442, a manor of the Teutonic Order is documented.

Name: Ulzburg
Alternative_Name: Henstedt-Ulzburg; Olzeborch; Oltzeborch; Oltzeborg; Ultezeborch; Olseborch; Olßeborgh; Oltzeburgh; Vlzeburch; Olseborg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1339.

Name: Vaabina
Settlement_Description: Since only the remains of the wall have survived from the earlier castle, it is not possible to date the exact year of construction. 1405, however, possible owners of the castle are mentioned. 1522 a manor was mentioned.

Name: Uenglingen
Settlement_Description: Mention as property of St. Ludgeri monastery in Helmstedt in 1238. In 1247 mention of a warden.

Name: Unna
Alternative_Name: Unha; Unnha; Unneha; Unnay; Onna; Unnaw; Unnauwe
Settlement_Description: A church is mentioned in 1019. However, the settlement dates back to the Merovingian period.
Town_Description: 1243 and 1278 called 'villa'. In the course of disputes between the Counts of the Mark and the Archbishops of Cologne at the end of the 13th century elevated to a country town. Awarded the 'Wigboldsrecht' in 1243 and urban privileges in 1290.
Toll_Description: A land toll was first mentioned in 1470. The property realtions are not clear. Presumably the toll was owned by the Count of the Mark or the town of Unna itself. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Unsen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 856.

Name: Uphusen (Bremen)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1219.

Name: Uppen
Settlement_Description: At the pass of Uppen a watchtower of the Hildesheim enclosure ('landwehr') was built. Since 1664, the settlement is joined with Achtum.

Name: Uppenberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1022 and 1032.

Name: Urbach
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in Urbach for the first time in 1411. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Ursel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1147, in a copy from the end of the thirteenth century.

Name: Usingen
Alternative_Name: Oasunge; Ohsingeheim; Osinga; Osanga; Osungen; Otsingen; Uosunge; Othsingen; Uotingen; Osinga; Usungin; Usungen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 8th century.
Town_Description: The transition from village to town is fluid. In 1326 the place was last called a village, in 1362 citizens were mentioned for the first time. Accordingly, the place developed into a town during this period. It is first mentioned as a town in documents in 1377, a city seal before 1394.

Name: Uetersen
Settlement_Description: Developed out of a 12th-century castle of the knights of Barmstede and a Cistercian nun convent that was founded around 1234.

Name: Utrecht
Alternative_Name: Traiecto; Treiecto; Vttrecht; Ulterius Traectum; loco Vultaburch dicto qui nun Vultraiectum dicitur; Inferius Traectum; Utreth
Settlement_Description: The first mention of Utrecht dates from 300 (in seventh-, eight- and tenth-century copies of the document). Settlement history, however, dates back to the Roman period, when a 'castellum' (fort) was built at the location of the present-day Domplein. Later, it became an episcopal see and a religious centre.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted between 1114 and 2 June 1122 by Godblad ('Godebald'), bishop of Utrecht, and developed further in the twelfth and thirteenth century.

Name: Vaals
Alternative_Name: Vals; Uals; Vails; Valis; Vayls; Voyls prope Aquis; Vaels
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1041.

Name: Vaassen
Alternative_Name: Fasna; Vasnon; Fassen; Vasyn; Vaessen; Vasen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from around 800-850, in a copy dating from 1170-1175. Next mention in 1118-1127 was forged in 1180-1190, in a fourteenth century copy.

Name: Vacha
Alternative_Name: Vaccha; Fahhonoro marca; Vache; Fahche; Fache
Settlement_Description: The settlement developed at an important Werra crossing.
Town_Description: The elevation to town occurred in 1186 at the latest by abbot Konrad of Fulda. It was subject to Fulda town rights. Around 1260 ditches, ramparts and walls, as well as the town castle Mendelstein were constructed.
Toll_Description: Trade caravans that were meant for Frankfurt were taken into Hessian safe conduct in Vacha.
Fair_Description: In 1508 two, in 1576 seven fairs are known.

Name: Vahrenwald
Alternative_Name: Voranwalde; Vorenwalde; Vorenwolde; Vornwold; Vormwoldt; Varenwolt; Vorenwalt; Varenwalt; Varenwaldt; Vahremwald
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1183.

Name: Valdorf
Alternative_Name: Valethorpe; Valendorpe; Valldorpe; Waltorpe; Vaddorfe; Faldorpe; Vallendorp; Valdorff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1055.

Name: Valkenburg (Geul)
Alternative_Name: Valkenburg; castello de Falcomonte; Mons Falconis; Falkenburg; Valckenburg vel Faucqmont; Valckenburgh; Fauquemont; Valkenberg; Valkinburch
Settlement_Description: The name 'Falchenberg' is first mentioned in 1041, concerning present-day Oud-Valkenburg, east of present-day Valkenburg. According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, the location of present-day Valkenburg is first mentioned as Valkenburg in 1121. An urban trade settlement developed in the thirteenth century near a castle.
Town_Description: Valkenburg is first mentioned as a town before 1 May 1353. It was already surrounded by a stone wall in the thirteenth century. A charter has not survived. Possibly, town privileges were granted by Reinald, lord of Monschau and Valkenburg.

Name: Valkenburg (Rijn)
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 918-948, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1064, in a falsification of the first half of the twelfth century copy.

Name: Valkenswaard
Alternative_Name: Wederde; Wederze; Wederde; Waerde; Wedert; Weerd; Verckensweerde; Valkenswaardt; Valkensweerd; Verkensweerd; Valkensweert
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the first quarter of the thirteenth century.

Name: Valaste
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241 and belonged to the Teutonic Order from 1444. From 1624 it was property of the manor of Ontika.

Name: Varrel
Settlement_Description: A hamlet ('bauernschaft') was first mentioned in 1289. In 1381, the monastery Heiligenrode founded the manor Varrel, which came to the count of Oldenburg after the Reformation in 1581.
Toll_Description: A toll station in Varrel is mentioned in the first half of the 17th century. It might have gone back to the acquisition of the manor Varrel by the counts of Oldenburg in 1581, possibly as a subsidiary toll station of Delmenhorst, which was circumvented by the road through Varrel. Some undated toll tariffs still exist.

Name: Varrelbusch
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1463.

Name: Varrigsen
Alternative_Name: Verthelekessen; Verdelikesem; Verdelexen; Verdelasten; Ferdessen; Vardiessen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1180.

Name: Vastorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1238.

Name: Veghel
Alternative_Name: Vehchele; Vechel; Vegghele; Vechle; Vechghel; Vechgel; Vehchel; Vecchel; Veghel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the beginning of the thirteenth century.

Name: Vechelde
Settlement_Description: The settlement was fortified by the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg in 1382. Between 1392 and 1671, the castle was pawned to the town of Brunswick.

Name: Vechta
Alternative_Name: Vechtam; Vechte; Vegte; Vecthe; Vetha; Wectha
Settlement_Description: The counts of Ravensberg constructed a castle "prope Vechtam" at the crossing of the Moorbach in the 12th century.
Town_Description: Acquisition of town privileges unknown, possibly before 1252. In ca. 1180/81, mint and toll rights were granted to the settlement. A charter from 1269 suggests that Vechta had (limited) town privileges at that moment, although it is later still characterised only as borough ('wicbold'); first mentioned as 'civitas' in 1351, the town privileges were confirmed by the bishop of Münster in 1372. In the 15th century, Vechta had the Osnabrück town rights.

Name: Veckenstedt
Settlement_Description: In the 9th century, a family of Veckenstedt is mentioned, which presumably held residence in a castle in Veckenstedt.

Name: Veenhusen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1283.

Name: Veessen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1217.

Name: Vehra
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1208 as property of Pforta monastery. The settlement's name which alludes to a ferry seems to be in direct contradicition to the name of the opposite Straußfurt, which alludes to a ford. It is possible that the villages were founded at different times of the year, when the Unstrut had different water levels.

Name: Vehrte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1050.

Name: Vejle
Town_Description: From the early middle ages Vejle was a royal town, but the oldest known town privileges are from 1327. Already around the middle of the 12th century and perhaps even earlier Vejle had an urban character. In the first half of the 14th century a Dominican monastery was established in the town.

Name: Velbert
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in 1471. The first mention results from a lawsuit. In 1555 the toll station is no longer mentioned. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Velden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1334.

Name: Veldhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1300. The church in the hamlet ('bauerschaft') Veldhausen was moved to Neuenhaus in 1370, but because the new location was difficult to reach, it was moved back to Veldhausen in 1410-1411.

Name: Veldwezelt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1157.

Name: Velgen
Alternative_Name: Velinge; Veldinge; Velinghen; Veling; Fallingen; Velynghe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1231.

Name: Veldhoven
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1294, in a fifteenth century copy.

Name: Vellern
Settlement_Description: First mentioned at the end of the 11th century.

Name: Velp
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from the beginning of the ninth century, in a copy dating from 1170-1175. Next mention is in 893, in a copy dating from 1122.

Name: Velpke
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1150.

Name: Velstove
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1505.

Name: Venlo
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention around 1000.
Town_Description: Earliest mention as 'oppidum' in 1272, and in 1339 Venlo is called 'stede'. Town privileges were granted by Reginald II, duke of Guelders, on 1 September 1343.
Toll_Description:
1) In 1284, an fee for safe conduct was mentioned for the first time. It is unclear whether this applied to land or water traffic. In 1294/95, in addition to the fee, a river toll on the Maas is also mentioned, which was of great importance especially in the 14th century. The Count of Guelders and later the Lord of Millen (before 1328/39) were holders of the toll. In 1339 the toll fell to the Duke of Guelders. In the 14th century, Blerick and Kessel were additional toll stations for the fee for safe conduct. In 1284, 20 mark were collected as fee. In 1295, the toll and the escort fee were leased for 150 old Brabant mark. For more detailed rates and revenues, see Pfeiffer.
2) Around 1271, a land toll was also levied. The Count of Jülich leased the toll to the knight Wilhelm von Broekhuisen. Tariffs are not known. The annual revenue amounted to less than 80 mark. The toll was later no longer mentioned, so that the transit through Venlo was free.
3) A transhipment toll is mentioned in 1355/61. The holder was the Duke of Guelders. It had to be paid 5½ denarii per carriage of wine.
4) The town of Venlo levied a road toll in 1366. Rates and revenues are not known.
Staple_Description: Venlo acquired limited staple privileges in the town privileges of 1343. In 1523, the full eight-day staple of Roermond was moved to Venlo.
Fair_Description: Venlo probably had one fair from at least 1294/95 onward: a fair of sixteen days on Sunday after Invocavit. When Venlo received town privileges in 1343, it received the right to held three fairs of sixteen days: the one on Sunday after Invocavit, one on St. Albinus, and one on Sunday after St. Lambert.
Harbour_Description: Over the course of the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries, Venlo became a transshipment port. From Holland to Venlo, the river Meuse was well navigable for deep-drawing ships, but upstream, the use of smaller ships with a more shallow draught was necessary.

Name: Venebrugge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1253. The name refers to a causeway through the moor on the border between the county Bentheim and the diocese Utrecht (Oversticht). On the Utrecht side, there was a fortification, on the Bentheim side there was an inn.

Name: Verden
Alternative_Name: Ferdun; Ferdi; Feride; Verdi; Ferdiun; Werduun; Verden (Aller); Vehrde
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 782. A royal court of Charlemagne existed here, as well as a bishopric. A cathedral church is attested in ca. 814.
Town_Description: Emperor Otto III granted Verden market, toll and minting privileges in 985. A town council is mentioned in 1235 and town privileges were granted in 1259. Since 1405 at the latest, the town was a Free Imperial City.
Fair_Description: The oldest fair in Verden, on the Dedication day of the cathedral, can be linked to the market privilege of 985. In 1491, two other fairs are mentioned as well, on 14 and 8 days before St Bartholomew.

Name: Vetschau
Alternative_Name: Vetschau/ Spreewald; Veczicz: Fetzschow: Fetscho: Fetschow; Vetscho; Vetschow
Settlement_Description: Parish village is mentioned in 1346, later a market hamlet, most likely wendish
Town_Description: After the initiative of the lord of the land, King Ferdinand creates a town between 1548-1549

Name: Vienenburg
Alternative_Name: Vineburch; Vineborch; Finenburg; Vynenborch; Vinenburg; Fynenborch; Vienenburgk
Settlement_Description: The castle Vienenburg was built around 1300 by the count of Wernigerode, first mentioned in 1306. It was sold to the bishop of Hildesheim in 1367 and came to the duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel in 1523.
Toll_Description: The privilege of levying a toll was granted in 1323. In 1396, Goslar butchers complained that they had to pay a toll on cattle driven through Vienenburg, of which they claimed to be exempted.

Name: Vierde
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1337.

Name: Vierhouten
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1418 as 'Vierholten', but a small settlement probably already existed before. Veen et. al. (2016) presume permanent habitation from ca. 1250 onwards. Neefjes and Bleumink (2015) consider earlier habitation a possiblity, possibly from the tenth century onwards. There is consensus that habitation and cultivation of land intensified during the thirteenth century.

Name: Vierlingsbeek
Alternative_Name: Vierlinxbeke; Vyrlinckbeecke; VerlinghBeeck; Virlincxbeeck; Vierlinksbeek; Virlingsbeck
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1428.

Name: Vierraden
Settlement_Description: A mill is mentioned in 1265, in the beginning of the 14th ct. a pomeranian castle was built, first mentioned in 1321, a castle hamlet is mentioned in 1450
Town_Description: Mentioned as a town when the castle is impawned to the Szczecins, Duke of Hohenstein, the feoffee of the castle since 1478, founded a 'Stetlin' across from it in 1515 with electoral permission
Toll_Description: The sovereignty (later department) of Schwedt owned a bridge- and dam toll in Vierraden.

Name: Viesebeck
Alternative_Name: Visbike; Vissebeck; Visbecke; Visbeke; Visbecke; Visebeck; Fischbegke; Fysbecke; Fisebeck; Fiesebeck; Viesebeck; Fisebecki
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1107 and 1127.

Name: Viesen
Settlement_Description: Written mention in 1282 as Visene.

Name: Witnica
Settlement_Description: An old village with german farmers, used to be a slavic fishing village

Name: Vijlen
Alternative_Name: Uillam; Vilarus; Vile; Vilen; Vylen; Villen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1016.

Name: Bad Vilbel
Alternative_Name: Vilbel; Felwila; Velawilre; Felawila; Velwila; Velewilo; Filwil; Filbil; Vilbel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 774. Developed on the traces of Roman and Germanic settlements.

Name: Willah
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of the castle Bremervörde between 1498 and 1500. The settlement consisted of a single farm.

Name: Vilvoorde
Alternative_Name: Filfurdo; Fillofort; Filfurt; Viluort; Filuardia; Viluorden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 779, in a copy from around 1191. Next entry in 974, in a copy also from around 1191. Next entry in 1122

Name: Vinte
Alternative_Name: Wienethe; Vinnithi; Vinnethe; Vinnete; Vynnete; Vyntte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in ca. 1150.

Name: Visbek
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 819.

Name: Visselhövede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1258. Seat of a bailiff ('vogt') of the diocese of Verden. Around 1450, the settlement acquired borough ('weichbild') privileges from bishop Johann von Asel of Verden.

Name: Visvliet
Alternative_Name: Visvleeth; Fliethuzum; Ffischvliedt; Visvleete; Visfleet; Vissflete
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1476.

Name: Vlaardingen
Alternative_Name: Flardingis; Flardingun; Flerethinga; Flardinge; Vlerdinge; Flardinghen; Vlaerdinghen; Vlerdinghen; Vlaerdinge; Flardingen; Vlardinghe
Settlement_Description: Vlaardingen is first mentioned in a mid-fourteenth-century copy of a document dating from about 1018. Van Berkel & Samplonius mention archeological findings from Merovingian and Carolingian times.
Town_Description: Vlaardingen is granted town rights on 14 May 1273 by Floris V, count of Holland.

Name: Vlagtwedde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1316.

Name: Vlodrop
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 943, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1277.
Toll_Description: The Count of Guelders levied a bridge toll in Vlodrop for the first time in 1294/95. Rates are not known. 3 shillings and 6 denarii were collected in 1294/95.

Name: Vlotho
Alternative_Name: Flutowe; Flaute; Vlotow; Vlotowe; Flotuwe; Vlotouwe; Flotowe; Vlotov; Vlote; Vlothowe
Settlement_Description: An early settlement close to the castle at a ford in the Weser river can be dated back to the 12th century.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted around 1250. After 1368, the town was degraded into a market borough ('marktflecken'), and received new town privileges in 1719.
Toll_Description: A toll on the Weser river in Vlotho was levied since 1224. It is mentioned in a complaint by the town Bremen in 1584 and in a document from the Hardehausen monastery in 1597.

Name: Rannajõe
Settlement_Description: In the Middle Ages, this area was part of the church's benefices. 1564 an estate was mentioned.

Name: Vöhrum
Alternative_Name: Vordem; Vortheim; Vorden; Worden; Voorden; Lutteken Vordem; Kerchvoerden; Kirchvorden; olden Vördum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022.

Name: Voigtsberg
Toll_Description: The regulations of safe conduct in Voigtsberg mention a bridge toll, as well as fees that were due on the fairs.
Fair_Description: The regulations of safe conduct in Voigtsberg mention fees that were due on the fairs.

Name: Völkenrode
Alternative_Name: Volklingerode; Wollenrode; Volkingeroide; Volckemerot; Volckengerodt; Wölkenrode; Völckingroda; Volkenrode
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1344.

Name: Volkmarsen
Alternative_Name: Folcmeressen; Volkmaressen; Volcmerssen; Wolcmersen; Volkmarsen; Volcmersen; Volkmarsheim; Volkemissen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1155.
Town_Description: The settlement was raised to a town by the Corvey Monastery. 1233 called 'oppidum'.

Name: Vollenhove
Alternative_Name: Fulnaho; Fullenho; Vullenho; Volnho; Fulhowe; Vollenhoe; Vollenhoue
Settlement_Description: Vollenhove developed as a settlement near Vollenhove castle. The earliest mention of ‘Fulnaho’ as the name of a forest dates from 944 (in a copy from the second half of the twelfth century). The castle was built in 1165. Possibly since the end of the thirteenth century, but at least before town privileges were officially granted in 1354, a market was held in Vollenhove.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted by Jan IV of Arkel, bishop of Utrecht, on 13 July 1354. In the beginning of the fourteenth century, there was at least one inn in Vollenhove.

Name: Völlinghausen (Möhne)
Alternative_Name: Völlinghausen; Volkelinchusen; Volckhlinghuesen; Vollingkhuißen; Fullinghaußen; Follinckhausen

Name: Völlinghausen (Erwitte)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 978.

Name: Voort
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1386.

Name: Voorst
Alternative_Name: Vuorst; Worst; Forste; Vorste; Uorste; Upvoerst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 893 in a copy from 1222. Over time, the river IJssel moved away from Voorst.

Name: Voorthuizen
Alternative_Name: Voirthusen; Voerthusun; Vorthusin; Voerthuisen; Vorthusen; Voorthusen; Vorthuijsen; Voorthuysen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 970 in a copy from 1480.

Name: Vorchten
Alternative_Name: Vorichten; Vorethen; Varachtermate; Varachtermerssche; Vorachten; Vorgten; Voiraften
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1176, in a seventeenth century copy.

Name: Vorden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1121, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Vörden
Alternative_Name: Dreckförde; Dreckforde; Treckforden; Vörden up den witten velde
Settlement_Description: Vörden developed near a ford, which was paved by the bishop of Osnabrück already in 1081. The settlement itself is first mentioned in 1341, and a castle in 1370. After the conquest by the bishop of the settlement by the bishop of Osnabrück in 1387, the settlement became a borough ('weichbild'). Characterised as 'oppidum' around 1391.

Name: Vordersten Thüle
Settlement_Description: The hamlet ('bauerschaft') Thüle, first mentioned in 1270, was stretched out along 6 km and was divided into three parts. The northernmost part was called Vordersten Thüle.

Name: Vorselaar
Alternative_Name: Furisclare; Furisclarus; Forsellara; Forlaria; Forlare; Forslare
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 726, in a copy dating from 1191 and circa 1222. Next mention in 1117.

Name: Vorsfelde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1145.

Name: Vorwerk
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1262.

Name: Vorwohle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1400.

Name: Voskuil
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1378.

Name: Vrasene
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a circa 1175 copy from a document from 1149-1166.

Name: Vreden
Alternative_Name: Fredenna; Frethunensis; Fretheni; Frethenna; Fredena; Fredenensis; Frethene; Vrethene; Vrethen; Wredene; Fredene
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 839.
Town_Description: 'Wigboldsrechte' were granted at the latest in 1241. According to a document, the place received 1252 town rights at the latest.

Name: Vreeland
Settlement_Description: Vreeland is first mentioned in 1265 as an 'oppidum'. It received town privileges in 1265, but these were withdrawn in 1560 by the States of Utrecht.
Town_Description: Vreeland is first mentioned in 1265 as an 'oppidum', when it is founded and granted town privileges by Henry I van Vianden, bishop of Utrecht. Henry has a castle (Kasteel Vreeland) built between 1258 and 1260 for military/strategic purposes. It is situated on the intersection between the river Vecht and a land route. Vreeland was also founded for military and economic reasons, but never fully developped into a town. The town priliveges of Vreeland were withdrawn by the States of Utrecht in 1560.

Name: Vries
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1139, in a sixteenth century copy.

Name: Vught
Alternative_Name: Fughte; Uuchte; Vuothe; Wtte; Vugde; Vuhcte; Vucht; Vuchte; Vuechte
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1028, in a copy dating from circa 1530.

Name: Vuren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1200.

Name: Vynen
Toll_Description: The Count of Cleves levied a land toll duty in 1319. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Vyshniy Volochëk
Alternative_Name: Вышний Волочёк; Vyšnij Voločok; Wyschni-Wolotschek; Wyschni Wolotschok; Vysnij Volocek; Vyshny Volochyok

Name: Waardenburg
Alternative_Name: Werden; Weerdenberch; Wardenberch; Wardenburch; Weerdenborch; Wairdenburch; Waerdenburg; Weerenburg; Werdenburg; Hiern
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1108, in a twelfth-century copy

Name: Waarloos
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1188, in a copy dating from circa 1243. Next mention in 1218 is a copy.

Name: Wachholderbaum
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1653.

Name: Wachsdorf
Bridge_Description: In 1640 a damaged bridge in Wachsdorf is repaired.

Name: Wachtebeke
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1198.

Name: Wachtum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1381-1383.

Name: Waddinxveen
Alternative_Name: Waddinxuene; Waddincsvena; Waddinghe vene; Waddinsvene; Waddijnsvene; Waddijnxveen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1233, in a copy dating from 1340.

Name: Waffenrod
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1332.

Name: Wageningen
Alternative_Name: Wachoningon; Wagenunge; Wageninge; Neowageningen; Wagennunge; Waginnunge; Wagenonghe; Wagenongh; Waghanonge
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1125, but is possibly a forgery. In 1240, Otto II, count of Guelders, fortified Wageningen with walls and double moats.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted on 12 June 1263, by Otto II, count of Guelders, to oppidum Wageningen. Confirmation of town privileges on 4 December 1312 by Reginald I, count of Guelders, and elevation from oppidum to civitas.
Fair_Description: From at least 1294/95 onward, Wageningen had one fair.

Name: Taagepera
Settlement_Description: The Manor was first mentioned in 1509.

Name: Vahastu
Settlement_Description: The village and a manor were first mentioned in 1534. An old castle on a hill near Vahastu hints at an earlier settlement.

Name: Vahuküla
Settlement_Description: In 1253 the Teutonic Order left the village 'Wawe' to the bishop of Reval. The village belonged to the manor 'Sitz'.

Name: Wahlitz
Settlement_Description: Settlements on the nearby Taubenberg go as far back as the Nelolithic and is constantly settled through the ages. Written mention in 1015, when it is given to St. Mary's church in Magdeburg.

Name: Wahn (Emsland)
Settlement_Description: It is uncertain if the settlement Walinoon, mentioned around 1000, is the same as Wahn. The village was demolished in 1941 to make place for an extension of a firing range.

Name: Wahrburg
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1339.

Name: Wahren
Settlement_Description: First mention as Vuarim in 1004.

Name: Wahrstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1264.

Name: Vaimastvere
Settlement_Description: Village and manor were first mentioned in 1527.

Name: Vaida
Settlement_Description: A village, that came into the possession of the Teutonic Order ('Deutscher Orden'), was first mentioned in 1241.

Name: Walchum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1280.
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Münster in Walchum is mentioned in 1576, when it could not be leased. Likewise, a toll collector could not be found in 1645 because revenues were low because of the Thirty Years' War.

Name: Waldau (Bernburg)
Settlement_Description: Charlemagne gathers his troops in Waladala in 806 in order to cross the Saale. First mention of Waldau 1049 as the property of Gernrode monastery.

Name: Waldau (Eisfeld)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1299.

Name: Waldfisch
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1259.

Name: Waldkappel
Alternative_Name: Kapel; Koppel; Cappel; Capella; Kapile; Waldkappil; Waltcappele; Waldcappel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1226.

Name: Walem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1183.

Name: Valga
Settlement_Description: The settlement probably already existed in the 13th century. A priest was mentioned there in 1286. The settlement was destroyed by Lithuanians in 1345.
Town_Description: In 1387 the place was already referred to as 'oppidum'. It received town rights from Riga and Dorpat only in 1584.

Name: Walkenried
Settlement_Description: A Cistercian monastery was founded in Walkenried in 1127/29. In 1556 it changed to the Protestant denomination, and was secularised in 1648.

Name: Walle (Bremen)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1139. On a hill in Walle, the gallows of the town of Bremen were located.

Name: Walle (Celle)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1304.

Name: Wallendorf
Settlement_Description: St. Peter's monastery had property here since 1091.

Name: Wallenhorst
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 851.

Name: Wallensen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1068.

Name: Wallhausen
Settlement_Description: Important ottonian an saxonian imperial palace, several royal stays are documented, such as the wedding of Otto, father of Henry I., and Mathilde in 909. Mentioned in 1028 as castle district ('Burgwardbezirk'). Duting the Late Middle Ages temporary residence of the Teutonic Order, after that several pawnings, until the family of the Asseburg have their residence here from 1414 until 1945.

Name: Valle
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1542 and was crownland.

Name: Valkla
Settlement_Description: Manor and village, which were mentioned in 1241. In 1400 the area was occupied by the Teutonic Order.

Name: Walschleben
Alternative_Name: Wahochleben; Ualichsleben; Walcheslebe; Walslebe; Walcheslebin; Walahesleba; Walesleubi
Settlement_Description: First mention in 822. Formerly the settlement was given to the archbishopric of Magdeburg by Otto I., then became property of Fulda monastery and in the end of the counts of Gleichen.

Name: Walsrode
Settlement_Description: Around 986 Count Wala founded a monastery of canonesses (from 1225: Benedictine nuns), next to which a market settlement developed. The settlement received borough ('weichbild') privileges after the Brunswick law in 1383/88.

Name: Walstedde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 875.

Name: Waltersleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1227.

Name: Waltrop
Settlement_Description: First known mention in 1147. Previously said to have been in the 9th century but not secured.

Name: Waltrup
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1042 and 1063.

Name: Wandsbek
Alternative_Name: Hamburg-Wandsbek; Wantesbeke; Wandeßbeke; Wandesbek; Wandeszbecke; Wandisbeck; Wandesbegke; Wandesbeck
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in a document in 1296 as a village with five farms ('Hufen') that developed into estates. The moated castle Wandesburg was built in 1568.

Name: Wanfried
Alternative_Name: Wanevreodum; Vanofriedem; Wanifredun; Wonefryde; Wenefriden; Wenefrydin; Wanfrede; Wannfried
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 9th century. In the 13th century as a 'villa', later called 'Flecken'.
Town_Description: In 1608, Landgrave Moritz granted town rights.

Name: Wange
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 742. Next mention in 1070.

Name: Wanssum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1242.

Name: Wanzleben
Settlement_Description: One of the earliest settlements in the environs of Magdeburg that probably exited before 877. Earliest mention of a castle in 968 that controlled the crossing across the Sarre by the road from Magdeburg to Halberstadt.
Town_Description: After the settlement as grown considerably through influx from the surrounding areas, archbishop Peter raises its status to that of town. It is considered immediately responsible to the crown.
Toll_Description: Complaint in the 16th century, when it is stated that the toll stations of Oebisfelde, Neuhaldensleben, Wolmirstedt, Dreileben, Wanzleben and Calbe collect less toll because of Magdeburg's toll excemption.
Fair_Description: With its town privileges, Wanzleben was granted a fair. While Keyser has it held on Thursday before Ascension day, Bergner cites it as being granted on the first Sunday after "meynden".

Name: Warburg
Alternative_Name: Vuartberch; Warperg; Uuardbergi; Vuartberch; Wartberge; Wartberg; Wartborg; Wartburgum
Settlement_Description: A castle is first mentioned in 1017. A charter from 1036 first mentions a settlement near the castle.
Town_Description: Warburg originally consisted of two towns: the old and new town. The granting of town privileges is unknown for both. The old town was mentioned as "civitas" in 1195 and had a burgomaster and council by 1245. For the new town, a burgomaster and council are mentioned in 1239. Both towns were united in 1436.
Fair_Description: On 15-7-1366, Bishop Henry III of Paderborn granted the towntwo fairs of three days, and on 31 October in the same year another two. These alternated between the old and new town. In 1372, he permitted both towns each to organise a church consecration fest. Moreover, for the old town the fair of St Michael is mentioned, which was the old grain market. Tolls and fares for safe conduct were connected to the fairs, which were pawned to the city by the bishop in 1446.

Name: Varbuse
Settlement_Description: Manor and village that were mentioned in 1627.

Name: Wardenburg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1218. A castle was built by the count of Oldenburg around 1268, after which the settlement was named, as well as a chapel. The castle was destroyed by troops of the bishop of Münster in 1342.

Name: Varudi
Settlement_Description: Manor and village were first mentioned in 1241.

Name: Waren
Alternative_Name: Waren/Müritz; Waren (Müritz); Warne; Wahrden; Wahrn; Waaren; Wahren
Settlement_Description: A village in wendish times, a castle as the administrative centre of the terra Warne since 1218
Town_Description: Nikolaus I. von Werle founded the town with Schwerin town law between 1260 and 1270, mentioned as civitas in 1292 and as oppidum in 1331

Name: Warendorf
Alternative_Name: Warantharpa; Waranthorpae; Warenthorpe; Warendhorp; Warendorppe; Warntorf; Varenthorpe; Varandohrpe; Varendorpen; Warendhorp
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 11th century.
Town_Description: Was granted town privileges around 1200.

Name: Warin
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in forged documents in the late 12th ct., in genuine documents first mentioned in 1229, usually as a see of the bishops of Schwerin, a church mentioned in 1233, bishop Hermann builts a castle at the end of the 13th ct. that is still in the making in 1284, the castle was the impulse to create a town
Town_Description: First mentioned as a town in 1306, no written privileges, usually called an oppidum

Name: Varja
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1241. It was owned by the Teutonic Order since 1472.

Name: Warken
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1059 in a falsified copy dating from ca 1180-1190.

Name: Warmsdorf
Settlement_Description: Mention in a record of bishop Burchard of Halberstadt, who gives estates to Ilsenburg monastary during their renovations (Codex Diplomaticus Anhaltinus I, 101). 1347 mention of castle Warmsdorf in the records, which controls the Wipper crossing.
Toll_Description: In 1496 the toll from Warmsdorf is moved to Neundorf (Anhalt). The toll house is repoted to have been right next to the castle's bridge until 1724.

Name: Warnsveld
Alternative_Name: Warnesvelt; Warnesfelde; Warnesvelde; Wernsfelt; Wernsvelde; Warnsfelt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1121, in a thirteenth century copy. The Saint Martinus Church (Sint Martinuskerk) was probably founded in the eleventh century; it is first mentioned in 1121. The oldes buildings were primarily located south and east of the church. Archaelogical evidence suggests settlement since the ninth century: dendrochronology dates a well around 841.

Name: Varangu
Settlement_Description: Manor and village were first mentioned in the 16th century.

Name: Warszawa
Staple_Description: Merchants started to be forced to offer their commodities on the Warsaw market around 1440.

Name: Warstein
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1072.
Town_Description: Archbishop Siegfried of Cologne founded the town in 1276. 1287 Warstein is named as 'oppidum'.

Name: Vasalemma
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1241. In 1364 it came into the possession of the Padis monastery.

Name: Wassenaar
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1200, in a copy dating from 1305.

Name: Wassenberg
Toll_Description:
1) The lord of Wassenberg probably levied a land toll in 1237 or before 1354/55. Among others, the Archbishop of Cologne (1283 to 1296), the Lord of Heinsberg (1310 to 1448/53) and Count Vinzenz of Moers (1453 to 1480/94) were pledge holders. In 1494, the toll fell to the Duke of Jülich. In 1389, 2 shillings per barrel of wine had to be paid. The annual yield in 1354/55 was about 11 mark.
2) The Duke of Brabant-Limburg also levied a fee for safe conduct on land in 1389. 2 shillings per horse had to be paid. The fee was later merged with the land toll.

Name: Vastemõisa
Settlement_Description: In 1559 the Teutonic Order owned a hamlet ('Hof') in this place. At the end of the 16th century this hamlet belonged to the fief of the castle in Fellin.

Name: Wasungen
Settlement_Description: A castle is mentioned in 1189-90. Around that a castle borough ('Burgflecken') developed, that is mentioned in 1337.
Town_Description: Already in 1301 the term oppidum can be found. The awarding of Schweinfurt town rights can be located in 1308.

Name: Webbekom
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1107, in a copy from the middle of the thirteenth century

Name: Wedde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1316. Around 1360, the noble family Addinga constructed a fortified manor here.

Name: Weddingen
Settlement_Description: In 1399, Weddingen became the seat of a monastery of the Teutonic Order, which moved here from Goslar. The church in Weddingen was already in their possession in 1287.

Name: Wedel
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1212 as a ferry landing.
Fair_Description: Wedel was the most prominent market for oxen driven south from Denmark. First indications for the market date from 1465, when Hamburg attempted to stop oxen from being driven to Wedel, which suggests that Wedel had started to take over the function of main hub for oxen from Hamburg around this time. The market took place from mid-March to mid-April.

Name: Weener
Alternative_Name: Uuianheri; Uuenari; Weinere; Wianderi; Wenari; Weenere; Wyanere; Wener
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century, although a manor of the monastery Werden an der Ruhr existed already in the 9th century. A church is mentioned around 1000.
Fair_Description: Weener acquired market privileges in 1508.

Name: Weert (Maastricht)
Alternative_Name: Weert; Werde; Weerde; Weirt; Weerdt; Wert; Werd
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1335.

Name: Weert
Alternative_Name: Werta; Werd; Wertha; Weirta; Weerth; Wirt
Settlement_Description: Weert originated on the crossroad of several trade routes. It is first mentioned in 1062, but this document is a forgery from the late eleventh century. Its subsequent mention dates from 1155. However, both Cox and Van Berkel & Samplonius mention political development around Weert in the late eleventh century.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted on 5 May 1414 by William VI of Horne (Huis Horne). Further town privileges were added in 1563. During the fifteenth century, Weert flourished socio-economically.

Name: Weesp
Settlement_Description: Weesp is first mentioned in 1131. It is located at the river Vecht and was a village/town of military-strategic importance.
Town_Description: Weesp was granted town rights on 20 May 1355 by William V, count of Holland. In 1355 military defences were added to the city, and later the town was surrounded by a stone defence wall.

Name: Weferlingen
Settlement_Description: Referred to as borough ('Flecken') in 1239. The place was part of the bishopric of Halberstadt, which had to defend its claims against Magdeburg, Braunschweig and Brandenburg.

Name: Wegenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1311 in the fiefdom register of Halberstadt. The exact date of foundation is not known.
Toll_Description: In 1533 a secondary station of safe conduct of the toll in Gardelegen is established in Wegenstedt, so travellers could choose between the routes via Oebisfelde or Gardelegen.

Name: Veģi
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1560.

Name: Znamensk
Alternative_Name: Wehlau; Знаменск; Wetau; Wetalo; Velowe; Wilaw
Settlement_Description: The Old Prussian built a fortress against the Teutonic Order in 1255, but it was soon conquered by the Order and then in 1280 destroyed during a siege along with the settlement surrounding it
Town_Description: The teutonic Order granted Gottfried Hundertmark the privilege to found the civitas in 1336 with Kulm town law

Name: Wehnde
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1238.

Name: Wehrbergen
Alternative_Name: Wederbergon; Wereberg; Werberge; Wederberge; Wederberg; Wederberch; Wederberhe; Wederberche; Werbergen; Werberghe; Wedderberghe; Wederberghe
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1042.

Name: Wehre
Settlement_Description: The settlement Wehre consisted of two parts: Ost- or Klein-Wehre and West- or Groß-Wehre. Groß-Wehre, the current village Wehre, is first mentioned separately in the 13th century. Klein-Wehre seems to have been abandoned in the 16th century.

Name: Wehrendorf
Alternative_Name: Werinctorp; Wirinctorpe; Weeringdorpe; Wernickterpe; Werrinchdorpe; Weringktorp; Werentorppe; Wirinctorff; Weyrnicktorppe; Werintorpe; Werendorpe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1052.

Name: Wehrstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention as villa, formerly it lay a little furhter away from Halberstadt at a nowadays detached church.

Name: Weiden
Toll_Description: The Duke of Brabant-Limburg levied a land toll in 1312/15. Tariffs are not known. In 1312/15 about 20 pounds were collected, in 1356/57 142 Aachen mark.

Name: Weimar (Kassel)
Alternative_Name: Weimar; Wimar; Winmare; Wimare; Wimmare; Winmar; Weinmar
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1097.

Name: Weißenberg
Settlement_Description: It was probably an estate in the 12th century.
Town_Description: Referral as 'oppidum'.

Name: Weißenfels
Settlement_Description: Due to several town fires, most sources on the settlement are lost to us. The settlement was probably founded in 1185 at the bottom of the Wettins' castle.
Town_Description: First mention of a town council in 1280, a town hall and the consecration of the town church are mentioned in 1303.
Staple_Description: A staple is mentioned in 1185 and possibly in 1075.
Fair_Description: In the confirmation of the fair of 1500 an earlier fair is mentioned whose record was lost in a city fire.

Name: Weißensee
Settlement_Description: The settlement was probably first founded in 1230, and first mentioned in 1313. Over time, four noble manors were established in Weißensee.

Name: Weißensee
Settlement_Description: The castle as the nucleus of the town was built as a resting point between the Wartburg and the Neuenburg near Freyburg. In the 12th/13th century it played an important role in conflicts between rulers as a roadblock. The market places of the old market settlement and the planned city were not situated on the axis of the main traffic, which were defined by geographic circumstances.
Town_Description: A systematic foundation of the town can be seen architecturally around the castle at the beginning of the 13th century. Since 1198 there are market officials, followed by jurymen, a district court and the citizen's rights of the citizens of Eisenach and Gotha in 1265 by landgrave Balthasar.
Toll_Description: A document from 1430 mentions that safe conduct has been given 'since olden times'. Toll station for the main safe conduct by Sachsenburg. In 1558 prince electorate August pawnes off the safe conduct to the council of Weißensee for three years, so that they may maintain paths, roads, dams, footbridges, ditches and bridges.
Fair_Description: In 1646 a chronicler mentiones three fairs in Weißensee, which had been there 'since olden times': Laetare Sunday, Sunday after St. Margaret and the third Sunday after Galli. The fairs are confirmed in 1693 and another fair is added on wednesday and thursday after the third advent. The fairs are still mentioned in 1863.

Name: Paide
Settlement_Description: In 1265/66 a castle of the Teutonic Order was built, which served as a residence for the bailiffs. A fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built near the castle. The expansion and reconstruction of the castle began in the 14th century.
Town_Description: The fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') received town rights of Riga in 1291.

Name: Weißig
Toll_Description: Secondary station safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Radeberg.

Name: Well
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1135-1180.

Name: Welplage
Settlement_Description: Hamlet ('bauerschaft'), which probably came into existence in the context of securing of the border between Minden and Osnabrück, possibly not much older than Huntebrück (1324).

Name: Welsede
Alternative_Name: Welsethe; Welzethe; Velzede; Welsedhe; Velsethe; Veltstede; Velstede
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1224.

Name: Welsum (Dalfsen)
Alternative_Name: Welsem; Welsne; Wilsne; Welsene; Welseme; Welsen; Welsum; Welssem; Welssen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1315.

Name: Welsum (IJssel)
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1213.

Name: Wendeburg
Alternative_Name: Winetheburg; Wenedeburch; Winedeburg; Wenetheborch; Wendeborch; Wendeborg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1196.

Name: Wenden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1031.

Name: Cēsis
Settlement_Description: The mission of the pagans who settled there began in 1206. Therefore a castle of a knightly order was built in 1207-1210, soon after that a second one was built. It became the main castle of the Teutonic Order. A village developed around the two castles, which burned down in 1221. In 1224/27 a new settlement came into being, which is mentioned as a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk').
Town_Description: Wenden was referred to as a town in 1323. It received town rights of Riga during the first half of the 14th century. It was member of the Hanseatic League. In the 16th century, staple for trade via Marienburg to Pleskau and Novgorod.

Name: Wendezelle
Alternative_Name: Wendenzelle; Wendeselle; Wendecelle; Wendetzelle; Wendelfelde; Wendezell
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1362.

Name: Wendessen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1170.

Name: Wendhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 826 and 876.

Name: Wennebostel
Alternative_Name: Weneborstle; Weyemborstolde; Weneborstele; Wendevorstelde; Weneborstell; Wendenbostel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1330.

Name: Wennigsen (Melle)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1200.

Name: Wennigsen (Deister)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned at the end of the 12th century or the beginning of the 13th century.

Name: Vendzavas
Settlement_Description: The area 'Venelis' was first mentioned in a contract in 1230. Later, a manor was built.

Name: Wensebrock
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1540.

Name: Wentorf
Alternative_Name: Wentorf bei Hamburg; Wenetdorp; Wenedorp; Wentorpe
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1217.

Name: Wenum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1335.

Name: Wenzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022.

Name: Werben
Alternative_Name: Werben (Elbe); Hansestadt Werben (Elbe); Wiribeni; Wirbene; Werbene
Settlement_Description: Former Wendish settlement. A border castle for the protection against Slavs was erected in the 10th century.
Town_Description: Referred to as oppidum in 1196, civitas only in 1225. The town used Magdeburg town rights. Since 1358 member of the Hanse.
Toll_Description: In 1429 margrave Johann commands that the toll in Werben is to be preserved. In 1440 the toll is described more closely as a toll on land and on water, ship tolls and ware tolls follow. In 1487 and 1541 only the road toll in Werben is mentioned, the water toll was possibly abandoned in 1492.
Fair_Description: In an official schedule from 1719, Seehausen, Werben and Arneburg each held three fairs. It can be assumed that some of these had existed for a while to this point.

Name: Virtsu
Settlement_Description: An estate was mentioned in 1459. A castle was built in 1465 to keep a watch on the sea route. It was destroyed in 1533/34. The current village around the harbour was only created at the end of the 19th century.

Name: Werdohl
Alternative_Name: Werthol; Werdole; Werthole; Werhole; Werdohle; Werdole
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as 'Kirchdorf' in 1101.

Name: Werkel
Alternative_Name: Werkele; Wercle; Werckeln; Werkeln; Werkle; Wergkel; Werhkil; Vergkel; Werkil; Werckel; Werckil; Werckell
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1219.

Name: Werl
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1024.
Town_Description: In 1246 it was mentioned as an 'oppidum'. Archbishop Engelbert II of Cologne confirmed the town rights of Werl in 1271.
Toll_Description: The archbishop levied a land toll here for the first time around 1238/61. In the years there were also several pledge holders. From 1306/08, half the toll fell to the Count of Arnsberg. Tariffs are not known. There was probably a cattle and market toll in Werl. Together with the land toll, the annual revenue in 1306/08 amounted to about 20 mark.

Name: Wermelskirchen
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in 1398. Tariffs and annual revenues are not known.

Name: Werne
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 834. A market place had developed in the late 12th century.
Town_Description: Werne received borough ('wigbold') privileges in 1385 and was fortified after 1400.
Fair_Description: A fair on St Simon and Jude was granted in 1362.

Name: Werneuchen
Alternative_Name: Warnow; Warnowe; Wernow; Wernowe; Barnow; Bernowa nova; Nyenbernowe; Bernowiken; Bernöwichen; Wernöwichen; Klein-Bernau
Settlement_Description: A parson is named in 1247, mentioned as oppidum in 1300
Town_Description: Founded as a town, but never fully developed as one, older documents never mention it as a town, own document of 1315 calls it a civitas, generally just oppidum, Städtlein or hamlet, royal statute elevates it to a town in 1865

Name: Wernigerode
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1121. The settlement was preceded by a village from the 9th century, probably a new foundation of Corvey monastery around 836.
Town_Description: In 1229 Wernigerode was granted town rights. Around 1265-1279 a new town developed, which was affiliated with the old town, but which were joined only in 1528.
Toll_Description: The count of Wernigerode Konrad sells the toll in the old and new city to the town of Wernigerode, so that the town defenses may be financed through it.

Name: Werntrop
Alternative_Name: Werhincdors; Wernincthorp; Werntorf; Werenttorpe; Werentorp; Werntrop; Werentorff
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1072.

Name: Werste
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1176.

Name: Werth
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1260. 'Castrum' in 1318, castle in 1369.
Town_Description: In 1426 the place was called a town according to a statute, but was not granted its rights. In 1547 it was named as a 'Wigbold' and in 1574 as a 'Städtlein'.

Name: Wesel
Settlement_Description: First uncertain mention in a note of the monastery Echternach, which can be dated to 719-739. The foundation of a church around 800 and the finds of a grave field from the 8th and 9th century indicate that there existed a large settlement at this time already.
Town_Description: Wesel acquired town privileges in 1241.
Toll_Description:
1) The Count of Cleves levied a land toll in 1300. In 1319, 120 mark were collected together with the transhipment toll in Wesel.
2) In 1319, a road toll was also mentioned, which was levied by the town itself. The Count of Cleves granted the privilege for this fee.

Name: Rakvere
Settlement_Description: In 1220 the area and the Estonian castle 'Tarwanpe' was conquered by Danes, who built the castle 'Wesenbergh' in the same place in 1252. The city developed alongside the castle.
Town_Description: The city received 'Lübeck town law' in 1302 and was governed by the Teutonic Order in 1346. In the 16th century, the city came under Russian and later Swedish conquership.

Name: Wesenberg
Town_Description: Founded around 1250 by Fürst Nikolaus von Werle-Güstrow without a former settlement, founding privileges have not survived, Schwerin town law endorsed in 1278, mentioned as civitas in 1300

Name: Wesendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1543. It is very uncertain whether the "Vesendorpe" mentioned in 1278 can be identified with Wesendorf.

Name: Wesloe
Alternative_Name: Wiscenlo; Wisselo; Wizelo; Wiscelo; Wysselo; Wislo
Settlement_Description: In 1256, the village is mentioned as "recently founded". It was in possession of Lübeck, from the middle of the 14th century privately owned.

Name: Wespelaar
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1154, in a copy from the middle of fourteenth century.

Name: Wesseln
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1146.

Name: Veselava
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1602.

Name: Wessenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230.

Name: Westenholz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1237.

Name: Wester-Celle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned before 1007.

Name: Westergellersen
Alternative_Name: Gheldessen; Gellersen; Gelderdissen; Gelderdessen; Westergeldersen; Westerghelderdessen
Settlement_Description: The settlement Gellersen, which consisted of three parts, was first mentioned in 1117; Westergellersen separately in 1276. According to 17th-century registers, the village consisted of 4 farms ('plog') and 2 half farms or 3 farms and 3 half farms.

Name: Westerhüsen
Settlement_Description: The settlement of Westeros is counted to the Northern Thuringian areas (Nordthüringgau) in the founding letter ('Fundationsbrief') by emperor Louis the Pious. Further mention in 840 in the records of Corvey monastery.

Name: Westerlinde
Alternative_Name: Linnithe; Linnethe; Lyndethe; Lindethe; Kerklindede; Verneren Linde; Westerlynde; Kercklinde; Westerlinda; Groten Linden
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1022.

Name: Westervoort
Alternative_Name: Westerwrd; Westerwort; Westerwurt; Westerwoert; Westervoert; Westervoirt; Westerfoert
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1025, in a eighteenth century copy.

Name: Westhausen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1146, when property in Westhausen is given to Lippoldsberge monastery. A family of Westhausen is known.

Name: Westhofen
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 1255.
Town_Description: The privileges were confirmed in 1401. The place was previously mentioned as freedom and fortified around 1300.

Name: Westmalle
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1233 is copy.

Name: Westönnen
Alternative_Name: Westthunen; Tunne; Westunnen; Vestunen; Westhoenen; Westonnen Dorff

Name: Westrem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1087, in a copy dating from 1775.

Name: Wesuwe
Settlement_Description: From the 1379 charter in which Wesuwe was first mentioned, it can be inferred that there existed a parish church already around 1200.

Name: Wettbergen
Alternative_Name: Wetberga; Watberge; Wetberghe; Wethberge; Wetberge; Wetbergen; Wethbergen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1055 and 1080.

Name: Wetter (Hessen)
Alternative_Name: Wetter; Werer; Wetrehen; Wettera; Wettere; Wettre
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 850.
Town_Description: Town ready since the end of the 12th century, citizens are mentioned from 1223. A council constitution before the oldest wisdom is documented in 1239. 1309 called 'oppidani'.

Name: Wetter (Ruhr)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1214. Nearby, the sovereign castle of the Counts of the Mark was built between 1243 and 1273.
Town_Description: In 1355, urban privileges, which probably existed earlier, were first documented.

Name: Wettringen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 838.

Name: Wetzlar
Alternative_Name: Wetflar; Wetzflar; Witflaria; Wetflaria; Wetzler; Wetzloa
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1141/42.
Town_Description: In 1180 the settlement was raised to an imperial town by Friedrich I. 'Civitas' in 1225.

Name: Wezup
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1284.

Name: Wichtringhausen
Alternative_Name: Wichmereghusen; Wichmeringehusen; Wicmeringehusen; Wicherdingehusen; Wichmerinchusen; Vichteringehusen; Withringhausen; Wichmeringhausen; Wichrichusen; Wittringhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1200

Name: Wickensen
Settlement_Description: Originally a folwark of the castle Homburg, which goes back to the Middle Ages. After it came in possession of the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg, the administrative centre was moved from the Homburg to Wickensen in 1542.
Toll_Description: A toll station of the dukes of Brunswick in Wickensen is mentioned in toll lists of the years 1539-1544 and 1587.

Name: Widdersdorf
Toll_Description: In 1389, the Archbishop of Cologne levied a fee for safe conduct on land and a land toll. At first there is only the fee mentioned, later also the land toll. In 1389/93 there is evidence of both horse toll and escort fee. Depending on the load, 2 to 3 alb. per horse had to be paid. The annual revenue amounted to an average of about 667 mark. In 1455 Widdersdorf was a secondary toll station of Königsdorf.

Name: Wiebrechtshausen
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1015. Around 1230 a Cistercian nun convent was founded. It was closed shortly before 1612.

Name: Wiedelah
Settlement_Description: The moated castle Wiedelah was built between 1292 and 1297 by the knights von der Gowische; in the 14th century it became property of the bishop of Hildesheim. The castle was acquired by the Brandenburg noble family of Quitzow in 1569, who rebuilt it as renaissance palace around 1600.

Name: Wiedenbrück
Alternative_Name: Witunbruca; Widenbrugga; Widenbrugge; Widdenbrukke; Widenbruge; Widenbrucge; Widenbruche; Wienbrügge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 952 and from then on the mint and market place of the Bishop of Osnabrück.
Town_Description: The old town was founded around 1200, the new town started in 1249.

Name: Wiederitzsch
Alternative_Name: Groß Wiederitzsch; Wideriz; Wederaz; Großen Wederiß;Großwetteritzsch
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1091, first mention as "Großwiederitzsch" ('Großen Wederiß') in 1475. Incorporated into one municipal of Wiederitzsch together with Kleinwiederitzsch in 1904.

Name: Wiedersbach
Settlement_Description: Given to the archbishop of Mainz as a fiefdom in 1311.

Name: Wiepke
Settlement_Description: First mention in damage accounts from 1420, in which damages from 1412 and 1418 are recorded.

Name: Wierden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1298-1304.

Name: Wieren
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252.

Name: Wiesbaden
Alternative_Name: Aquae Mattiacorum; Mattiacum; Aquae Mattiacae; Mattium; Wisibada; Wisibadun; Wisebadon; Wisibad; Wisibadin; Wysebadin; Wiesebaden Wysbaden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as early as 50 AD when it was inhabited by the Romans. Around 500 there was a settlement by the Franks. In 1022 the place is mentioned as a 'villa'.
Town_Description: Is mentioned in 1241 as 'civitas' and in 1242 as 'civitas imperatoria'. Still referred to as 'oppidum' in 1344, it was first mentioned as a town in 1348. In 1393 the town received a letter of freedom confirming the old freedoms and rights. These were partly repealed by the peasant uprising in 1525, but awarded again in 1566.

Name: Wiesdorf
Toll_Description: The Duke of Berg levied a land toll in 1411. Tariffs and revenues are not known. Wiesdorf was a secondary toll of Mülheim, at the end of the 15th century also temporarily of Büchel.

Name: Wietmarschen
Settlement_Description: The Benedictine monastery Marienrode was founded in 1154 by Bishop Frederick of Münster, next to which a settlement developed. The monastery was in operation until 1811.

Name: Wijchmaal
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1161.

Name: Wijhe
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 960, in a sixteenth century copy.

Name: Wildenburg
Toll_Description: The lord of Wildenburg levied a land toll before 1396. 2 Turnosgroschen per horse had to be paid.

Name: Wildeshausen
Settlement_Description: A monastery of secular canons was founded in the 9th century, an "oppidum" is mentioned at the same time. A castle was built around 1150. In 1270, the archbishop of Bremen acquired the power in the town and administrative region of Wildeshausen. The monastery had minting rights in the 13th and 14th centuries.
Town_Description: In 1270, the archbishop of Bremen granted Bremen town privileges to Wildeshausen.
Toll_Description: Originally owned by the counts of Oldenburg. In 1271, citizens of Bremen were freed from toll in Wildeshausen by the bishop. A part of the toll was owned by the counts of Hoya in the 14th century, who sold it to the town of Wildeshausen in 1441. The toll was often leased, from 1541 onwards by Münster, which had acquired the toll. In the 17th century, an additional toll on oxen was levied on Easter.
Fair_Description: The most important fair in Wildeshausen was on St Ulrich, which is first mentioned in 1298 and is the only fair which can be attested through the centuries. For Ulrich's fair and for that on St Simon and Jude, invitations were sent to Osnabrück in the 14th century. In 1507, three three-day fairs were installed, because the old ones were not visited any more. Next to the renewed fair on St Ulrich, these took place on St George and on the day of the Eleven Thousand Virgins. The latter two must have disappeared soon after, because in 1529, only two fairs are still mentioned, on St Ulrich and St Dionysius.

Name: Vilksala
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned 1422.

Name: Wilmersdorf
Settlement_Description: The village was founded in the second quarter of the 13th ct., it was first mentioned in 1295, Joachim I purchased half of it in 1506

Name: Vilnius
Staple_Description: In negotiations between Gdanks and Krakow in 1493 it is noted for the first time that Russians and Lithuanians wishing to trade in the west were obliged to travel via Vilnius.

Name: Wilp
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 840-849, in a copy dating from circa 1000. Next mention in 840-864, in a fifteenth century.copy.

Name: Wolder
Alternative_Name: Villara; Wilre; Wylre; Wolre; Wilderen; Wilder; Wijler; Wiler; Wilré; Wilree
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 930. Next mention in 1316.

Name: Wilsche
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1152.

Name: Bad Wilsnack
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as a church village in 1300, destroyed during a fight in 1383, became a pilgrimage site through a miracle of the host, mentioned as oppidum in 1398, a council and merchants house names in 1424
Town_Description: The Wittstock town law and market rights were granted in 1513 by the bishop of Havelberg

Name: Wilsum
Settlement_Description: According to Cox, the earliest mention of Wilsum dates from 1213; according to Jager, the earliest mention dates from 1170. Its church was built around the mid-eleventh century.
Town_Description: It is assumed that Wilsum was granted town privileges by the bishop of Utrecht before 1321. On 24 February 1321, its town privileges were codified.

Name: Ventspils
Settlement_Description: The area fell to the Teutonic Order in 1253, after which a castle was built in the 13th century. The castle was first mentioned in 1290. In 1244 a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built.
Town_Description: Town right were granted in 1378. In 1440 the town joined the Hanseatic League.

Name: Windeby
Settlement_Description: Manor

Name: Windesheim
Alternative_Name: Wendesheim; Windeshem; Windesim; Wijndessem; Wijndesem; Winssem; Windsheim
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1028, in a copy dating from 1530.

Name: Windheim
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 12th century.

Name: Wingerode
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1146.

Name: Westendorf
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1383.

Name: Winksele
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1133.

Name: Winnenthal
Toll_Description: The Duke of Cleves levied a land toll around 1450. Records about tariffs or revenues have not survived.

Name: Winschoten
Alternative_Name: Windschoter; Winsewida; Wynschote; Wynschoten; Wynschotten; Wynscote; Winschate; Winschote; Winschoot
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the thirteenth century. Winschoten was granted town rights at 7 May 1819 by William I of the Netherlands.

Name: Winsen (Aller)
Alternative_Name: Winsen a.d. Aller; Winsen an der Aller; Winsen; Winusen; Wensen; Wynsen; Wynsen vppe der Alre; Weensen vp der Alre; Winsen uppe der Alre; Winszen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1107-1128. The castle is first mentioned in 1312.
Toll_Description: The toll of the Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg is first mentioned in 1409. In a 1507 agreement between Hannover and Celle, it is stipulated that citizens of Hannover have to pay tolls for shipping on the Aller river in Celle, like the toll levied on the land route in Winsen. A toll tariff is known from the 16th century (StAB).

Name: Winsen (Luhe)
Alternative_Name: Winhusen; Winsen an der Luhe; Winsene up der Lu; Wynssen
Settlement_Description: Winsen was mentioned for the first time in 1158. A church was mentioned in 1233. The settlement was referred to as borough ('oppidum') in 1293. In 1299, a moated castle is first mentioned.
Town_Description: In 1322, Winsen received Lüneburg town privileges. The town was often pawned to Lüneburg in the following centuries.
Toll_Description: A charter from 1333 attests a herring toll of the dukes of Brunswick for citizens from Hannover: for each last herring 25 pennies. The toll is still mentioned in 1388.

Name: Winterberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1276.
Town_Description: Around 1250 the town received town rights and was fortified. These rights were confirmed in 1357.

Name: Winterswijk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the eleventh century, in a copy dating from 1493.
Fair_Description: Even though Winterswijk did not have town privileges, it was being granted a one-day fair in 1531 by Charles, duke of Guelders. The day of this fair is unknown.

Name: Wintzingerode
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1204.

Name: Winzenburg
Settlement_Description: The settlement was originally called Hasekenhusen; a chapel is mentioned in 1140. After the nearby castle Winzenburg was destroyed in 1522, the administrative centre was moved to the folwark Hasekenhusen and the village restructured. It thereupon became known after the former castle.

Name: Winzerla
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1317.
Toll_Description: Station of secondary safe conduct of Jena-Burgau.

Name: Wipperfürth
Toll_Description: In 1398, the Duke of Berg levied a land toll in Wipperfürth. 4 Turnosgroschen had to be paid for each foder of wine. A charge of 1 Turnosgroschen was levied per horse. In 1470/72 the toll was leased out for 68 guilders a year.

Name: Wippringsen
Alternative_Name: Witmarenchusen; Wicmarinchusen; Wytmarinckhusen; Wypperinchusen; Wopperynckhusen; Vytmarinchusen; Wypperingkhuißen; Wiprinckhausen

Name: Wipshausen
Alternative_Name: Wipteshusen; Wppedeshusen; Wibdeshusen; Wypteshusen; Wipteshusen; Wybbedeshusen; Wiptzhusen; Wipshußen; Wippeshaußen; Wibßhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1357.

Name: Wirdum
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in the 8th or 9th century.

Name: Wismar
Alternative_Name: Wißmar; Wissemara; Wismaraa; Wissemar; Widmar; Wismer
Settlement_Description: Small Slavic fishing village, where a settlement of german farmers and merchants developed with a church of St Nicholas around 1200.
Town_Description: First mentioned as town in 1229, it was most likely founded in 1226 but the charter has not survived. Lübeck town privileges were extended in 1250.
Staple_Description: Staple for stockfish from Bergen; in 1446 members of the Hanse were only allowed to export flour, malt, and other victuals to Bergen if they brought fish from Bergen back with them to Lübeck, Wismar, Rostock or Stralsund. Regulations from 1435 and 1480 refer to a staple for grain.

Name: Wispenstein
Settlement_Description: The family of Steinberg constructed a moated castle here between 1445 and 1451, probably next to an older water mill of the monastery Lamspringe.

Name: Wissinghausen
Alternative_Name: Werzinchosen; Wircenhosen; Wersenchusen; Wirtsinkusin; Wirtzenhusen; Wirtzenchusen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1266.

Name: Wittem
Alternative_Name: Witham; Witam; Witheim; Wecham; Wittham; Withem; Wytem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1125.

Name: Witten
Settlement_Description: Goes back to a Carolingian settlement, where a church village emerged. First mentioned in 1016.

Name: Lutherstadt Wittenberg
Settlement_Description: Originally a fisher village from the 11th and 12th century.
Town_Description: Herzog Albrecht II. grants town rights in 1293. Additionally, Wittenberg was the residence of the Ascanian dukes in the 14th century. In 1317 coucil members, a mayor and a municipality appear in the records.
Toll_Description: First mention of a toll in 1423 in a certificate from duke Friedrich the strident to duchess Barbara, widow of elector Rudolf III. The safe conduct in Wittenberg shows the high amount of trade traffic from north to south and east to west. The regulations of safe conduct also settle the tolls on the Elbe and the bridge toll, while the account books from 1444 to 1545 further mention income from the ferry and cattle tolls. Regulations of safe conduct remain from 1513.
Staple_Description: In 1415 King Sigismund gave Duke Rudolf of Saxony staple privileges in his castle and city of Wittenberg; this privilege was confirmed by King Friedrich II for the Dukes Friedrich and Wilhem in 1444. Staple rights were again confirmed in 1478, but proved difficult to enforce.

Name: Wittenberge
Settlement_Description: A wendish settlement with a castle mound, the castle was likely built after 1136, traces of older mounds, the village and its ferry were first mentioned in 1226
Town_Description: A founding by the lineage of the Gans, the old privileges have been reinstated between 1300 and 1365, mentioned as civitas in 1312 and 1321, as oppidum in 1407 and stedeken in 1531
Toll_Description: A toll on river transport on the Stepenitz was installed by margrave Ludwig in 1337, in return for his support of the improvement of the river for shipping. Perleberg citizens were exempted from the toll in 1348. A toll on shipping on the Elbe river is first mentioned in negotiations about the reduction of tolls on the Elbe in 1476. It was pawned to the family Gans of Putlitz, who claimed to have received the right of levying a toll from the emperor in 1208, a statement that is impossible to verify. The toll fee on the Elbe was 7 Gulden, 1 loaf of bread and 1 bun for every ship in 1492. The toll on the Elbe is also attested in four travel accounts of Pirna skipper Gottfried Kleeditz from 1671-1674.

Name: Wittenburg
Settlement_Description: In wendish time, one of three castle grounds in the region of the Polabians, most likely a german castle garrison since the middle of the 12th ct., mentioned as provincia Wittenburg in 1154, a church village closeby mentioned in 1194
Town_Description: Founded by the Dukes of Schwerin with Lübeck town law, first mentioned as civitas in 1230, privileges have been endorsed multiple times

Name: Wittenwater
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1312.

Name: Witterda
Settlement_Description: First mention in the records 1143.

Name: Wittingen
Settlement_Description: The place 'Wittingen' is mentioned for the first time in 1014. However, a referral to 'Wittingau' dates back to the 8th century.
Town_Description: Characterised as "civitas" in 1267 and "oppidum" in 1293. In 1369 at the latest, Wittingen had a council, judges and burghers as well as a town seal. However, the settlement was also regularly characterised as borough ('weichbild').
Toll_Description: Wasmod von dem Knesebeck sold a part of the toll in Wittingen to the duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg in 1410. Johann von dem Knesebeck was pawned with a sixth part of the toll in 1444; later a sixth part of the toll was owned by the von dem Knesebeck family as well.

Name: Wittlage
Settlement_Description: A moated castle was built here between 1309 and 1313 by Osnabrück bishop Engelbert von Weihe.

Name: Wittmar
Settlement_Description: The charter with the first mention of 965 appears to be a falsification from the 12th century.

Name: Wittstock
Settlement_Description: A burgward is mentioned 948, 1150 and 1179, has been an episcopal fortreess since the mid-12th ct.
Town_Description: Bishop Heinrich I. van Havelberg raises the village to a town in 1245, the Stendal town right was granted in 1248 and endorsed many times after 1275, mentioned as civitas since 1248

Name: Witzenhausen
Alternative_Name: Wizzanhuson; Witczenhusin; Wezenhusen; Wizinhusen; Wittinhusin; Wyssenhusen; Witzenhusen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 850.
Town_Description: Witzenhausen acquired market and town privileges in 1225. It was characterised as "oppidum" in 1232 and "civitas" in 1247.

Name: Witzhave
Alternative_Name: Wytteshave; Witteshoue; Witeshoue; Witeshof; Wytshaue; Witteßhaue; Witzhaue
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1248.

Name: Wobeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1118.

Name: Võhma
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1583.

Name: Woensdrecht
Alternative_Name: Wunsdrecht; Gunsdrecht; Wonsdrech; Honsdreecht; Honcsdreecht; Ghonsdrecht; Wonsdrecht
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1249, in a copy dating from 1669.

Name: Woensel
Alternative_Name: Gunsela; Gunsella; Wnsela; Woncele; Woenssel; Wonsel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1107, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Woffleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 927 in a gift certificate by Henry I.

Name: Wohlde
Alternative_Name: Wolde; Bergerwold; Bergerwolde; Bergherwolde; Wolt; Wooldt; Woldt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1381-1382.

Name: Wohldenberg
Alternative_Name: Woldenberghe; Waldeberg; Waldeberch; Woldenberch; Woldenbergk; Waltrenbroch; Woldenborch; Woldenberc
Settlement_Description: Castle of the counts of Wöltingerode, who started naming themselves after the new castle in 1172 or 1153/78.

Name: Ēvele
Settlement_Description: The parish and manor were first mentioned in 1562. In 1660, 'Neu-Wohlfahrt' ('Vecjērcēni') was separated.

Name: Woldegk
Town_Description: Original privileges have not survived, founded between 1236 and 1250 by the Margraves of Brandenburg alongside the castle

Name: Dobiegniew
Alternative_Name: Woldenberg; Dubiegniewo; Dubgenew; Dubbegenek; Dubegnev; Stobegnewa; Dobyegnyeg; Waldinborg; Waldinberg; Woldenberghe
