Settlement_Description: A slavic settlement and manor. It was gifted to the convent Ovsink close ot Posen in 1250, which was endorsed in 1280.
Town_Description: Founded by the Ascanians around 1298 with Brandenburg town law. First mentioned as civitas in 1313.

Name: Wolfen
Settlement_Description: Until the 19th century a farmer and linen-weaver village with a resident manor, whose owners changed often.

Name: Wolfenbüttel
Settlement_Description: The castle Wolfenbüttel is first mentioned in 1118. First indications about a settlement near the castle date from the early 14th century. From 1432, the castle was the main residence of the dukes of Brunswick and was reconstructed as a fortress.
Town_Description: Wolfenbüttel acquired market privileges in 1570 and acquired its final form as a renaissance fortress between 1570 and 1626, which consisted of the Heinrichstadt around the castle, the civic settlement Neustadt, and the suburb Gotteslager east of it. Duke Julius attempted to develop the town into the major trading hub Gotteslager from 1582, but the project failed.
Fair_Description: Wolfenbüttel acquired market privileges in 1570 with two fairs, on 9 May and 4 November. When duke Julius tried to raise the town to the major trade hub Gotteslager, he granted four fairs of twelve days, on 14 January, 14 April, 14 July and 14 November. After the failure of the project, the fairs were reduced to two eight-day fairs in spring and autumn again, taking place on 5 May and 5 November.

Name: Wolfhagen
Settlement_Description: The settlement emerged from seven deserted villages and was first mentioned in 1231.

Name: Wolfshagen
Settlement_Description: Mention of the castle in Wolfshagen in 1375.

Name: Wolgast
Alternative_Name: Hologost; Ologost; Wologost; Walegost; Wolegost; Wolgast; Walgust; Wolegast; Wolgust; Valagust
Settlement_Description: first mentioned in Heinrich I. time
Town_Description: Duke Wartislaw I. of Pomerania conquers the wendish settlement and grants it town law, german law granted in 1259, Lübeck town law since 1282

Name: Valgunde
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1413.

Name: Wolkenstein
Settlement_Description: In 1323 the place was already called 'oppidum' and probably arose from a 'suburbium', which was situated next to the castle.
Town_Description: In 1434 the place was referred to as 'town'.
Toll_Description: A table of fees ('Geleitstafel') remains from 1591 (SHStA Dresden, Loc. 40099, Wolkenstein Nr. 40b, Erbbuch des Amtes Wolkenstein 1591, p. 477–481).

Name: Wolin
Alternative_Name: Wollin; Jomsburg; Hynnisburg; Julin; Jumne; Jumine; Jumneta; Helmold; Vineta; Wulin; Wolin; Wolyn
Settlement_Description: Prehistorical findings of a pre-german settlement. A merchant town of wendish and viking origin since the 10th ct. Mostly wendish settlement until the german town founding.
Town_Description: Duke Barnim I of Pomerania granted Lübeck town law to the market settlement in the 13th ct. First mentioned as a town in 1279, when the privileges were renewed.

Name: Valmiera
Alternative_Name: Wolmar; Wollar; Wollmer; Wollmahr; Walmar; Wolmaria; Volmar; Woldemar
Settlement_Description: In 1224, the area came to a knightly order who built a fortress out of wood. In 1283/87 there was a castle and a church, around which a settlement developed.
Town_Description: Wolmar was already referred to as a town before 1323. In 1328, the town received town rights of Riga and in 1365 became a member of the Hanseatic League. In 1684, town privileges were revoked.

Name: Kõo
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1583. A hamlet ('Hof') was built in the 17th century.

Name: Wolmirstedt
Settlement_Description: In 1109 a German castle of the counts of Walbeck is mentioned, a rural settlement developed nearby.
Town_Description: First town bylaws around 1390. Before, it is already counted among the towns of the wood district ('Holzkreis') in 1362 and referred to as little town ('stedeken') in 1382.
Toll_Description: A toll and safe conduct can be proven in Wolmirstedt since 1368. In 1405 the archbishop of Magdeburg is granted permission by king Wenzel to collect toll on any ware that is carried to the market in his towns. In a letter of conflict between the council of Magdeburg and the archbishop from 1432, the villages of Wolmirstedt, Rogätz and Jerichow are mentioned as toll stations, the toll in Wolmirstedt is mentioned as being collected on an (old) Elbe crossing. The toll in Wolmirstedt is further mentioned in the 16th century, when a complaint is filed that the toll stations of Oebisfelde, Neuhaldensleben, Wolmirstedt, Dreileben, Wanzleben and Calbe collect less toll because of Magdeburg's toll excemption.

Name: Woltersdorf
Settlement_Description: Mention in 1562 as Woltirstorff, property of the lords of Wedel since olden times.

Name: Wolthausen
Alternative_Name: Wlethusen; Wllethusen; Wulthusen; Wolthusen; Wulthuszen; Walthusen; Walhusen; Wuldthusenn; Wulthausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1235.

Name: Wöltingerode
Settlement_Description: A monastery was founded in 1174. According to a document from 1188, it was a Cistercian nun monastery, which was converted into an Evangelical women's convent after the Reformation. It was closed in 1809.

Name: Woltrup
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1240.

Name: Wolvertem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1086.

Name: Vooreküla
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 1627.

Name: Worbis
Settlement_Description: In 1238 the castle village is already a market village (Forense Worueze).
Town_Description: Around 1255 already civitas. The awarding of the town rights possibly already occurred before 1255. Through a pawn lordship ('Pfandherrschaft') between 1381 and 1574 the town rights were distincly restricted, which made the town lose much of its independence.
Toll_Description: Worbis has been a tollstation and station of safe conduct since the 13th century.
Fair_Description: Archbishop Daniel Brendel of Homburg grants the town two fairs and a cattle fair in 1576. In 1660 the town is granted another fair on Sunday after St. Margaret's day.

Name: Workum
Alternative_Name: Warkum; Waltercom; Waldricheim; Woldrichem; Wolderchem; Waerkum; Worckum; Wolderkum; Woudrichem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1327.
Town_Description: According to Cox, Workum became a town before 1385. Van Berkel & Samplonius mention 1350.
Harbour_Description: Regular barge ('trekschuit') services were offered on the route Workum-Bolsward-Leeuwarden from 1648 onwards.

Name: Wormbach
Alternative_Name: Worunbach; Worbeche; Wormbike; Wormbeke; Wormeke; Wormecke; Wormicke; Wormecken; Wormbacensen; Wormbecke; Wurmbecke
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1072.

Name: Orneta
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as a German settlement in 1308, as a parish community in 1312
Town_Description: Bishop Eberhard von Neitze grants Kulm town law in 1312, mentioned as a town in 1313, the handfast was renewed in 1359

Name: Worringen
Toll_Description:
1) The archbishop levied a fee for safe conduct on water before 1279. Presumably this toll was abolished in the same year in the course of the landfrieden. Revenues and tariffs are not known.
2) In 1287/88, a land toll of the Archbishop of Cologne was also mentioned.

Name: Voose
Settlement_Description: The village of the Manor 'Pallfer' was mentioned in 1241.

Name: Wöstendöllen
Settlement_Description: The settlement 'Duliun' is first mentioned around 1000. Since the 11th century, it was divided into Ostdöllen ('Astulini') and Norddöllen ('Nordulini'). In 1383 'Wostendolne' is first mentioned.

Name: Wrestedt
Alternative_Name: Uuersteti; Vurestedi; Wrestide; Wrestede; Wristede; Freistedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 892.

Name: Wriezen
Alternative_Name: Writzen an der Oder; Wrezene; Wricenne; Wriczen; Wrecen; Wrezzin; Wryssen; Wrissen; Wrietzen
Settlement_Description: Probably a slavic trading place, around 1250 there existed a german market settlement with two small wendish fishing villages
Town_Description: An official town founding is unknown, mentioned as civitas in 1303, but as oppidum in 1320, the Magrave Ludiwg grants the Magdeburg town law in 1337

Name: Wrisbergholzen
Alternative_Name: Thiederikingehusen; Wrissberg; Wristberg; Wrysberch; Wryßbarge; Wrisbarges; Wrißberg
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1125.

Name: Wülfel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1234.

Name: Wülfingerode
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1154.
Toll_Description: Wülfingerode is mentioned in a registry of safe conduct from 1610.

Name: Wulfsode
Alternative_Name: Wulfersode; Wolferßrade; Wulfersothe; Vulfersrode; Wulfeszoden; Vulphersrode; Wulversrode; Wolffersow
Settlement_Description: First mentioned after 1236.

Name: Wulften (Osnabrück)
Alternative_Name: Wulften; Wulfem; Wulfhem; Wulfamen; Wulhamen; Wulfham; Wolfhemen; Wlfhem; Wulphemen; Wulfhammen; Vulfham; Vulpham; Vulfhem; Vulveten; Wulveten; Wulffhem; Wulffhamen; Wulffam; Wulffem; Volffem; Wulffheym; Wulffen; Wulfften; Wulffman
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1188.

Name: Wulften am Harz
Alternative_Name: Wulften; Wolfenni; Uolftune; Wolfften; Wlftene; Volften
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 889.

Name: Wundersleben
Settlement_Description: First mention at the end of the 8th or the beginning of the 9th cenutry.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleistsstelle') of Weißensee.

Name: Wunstorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 871. Bishop Dietrich I of Minden founded a nunnery here.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted in 1261 by bishop Cuno of Minden.

Name: Würzburg
Alternative_Name: Uburzis; castello Virteburch; Wirzaburg; Uuirziburg; Wirciburg; Wirzburch; Werzebvrc; Wrztburg; Marcoburgum; Peapolis; Mustoburgum; Marcopolim
Settlement_Description: Duchy in the 7th century. Saint Kilian suffered his martyrium in Würzburg in 689. In 742 the bishopric was founded. The place was first mentioned around 700 in a copy of a document. Around the same time, the settlement centre was moved to the right side of the river Main.

Name: Wurzen
Settlement_Description: The place emerges from a Slavic settlement with castle. In the middle of the 10th century a German castle was built.
Town_Description: Around 1300 the market settlement was fortified.
Toll_Description: Extensive regulations of safe conduct remain from the 16th century (SStA Leipzig, Stadt Wurzen Nr. 932).
Fair_Description: In 1670, Wurzen requested two fairs, which seem to have been granted despite protests from Leipzig.

Name: Wust
Settlement_Description: First mention as Wostitz in 1240.

Name: Wusterhausen
Alternative_Name: Wusterhausen/ Dosse; Wendisch-Wusterhausen; Wusterhuse slavica; Königs-Wusterhausen; Königswusterhausen
Settlement_Description: A Fortress of Brandenburg, a mill is mentioned in 1366, Wusterhausen as castrum is mentioned in 1375, usually mentioned as a slavic settlement, not always called village
Toll_Description: The lords ('Schenken') of Landsberg, who resided on castle Teupitz, owned the land toll in Teupitz, as well as the bridge- and dam tolls in Königs-Wusterhagen and Wendisch-Buchholz.

Name: Wustermark
Settlement_Description: First mention of the settlement in 1212. A castle may have existed, two inns are proven in 1355.
Toll_Description: In 1424, 1446 and 1458 the seigneural toll on the road to Wustermark is pawned off to the town of Magdeburg.

Name: Wustrow
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1217. In the 13th century, the lords of Wustrow built a castle, next to which the settlement developed. It was characterised as borough ('weichbild') in 1352 and 1369.
Town_Description: The settlement was first mentioned as town in 1377, although the town privileges were only confirmed in 1654.

Name: Wuustwezel
Alternative_Name: Wesella; Wlte Wesel; Wesele; Woestwesel; Wuestwesele
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1250.

Name: Wymeer
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1319 together with the monastery Dünebroek west of it.

Name: Xanten
Toll_Description: In 1142, there is evidence of a ship or river toll in Xanten, which was market-related. In 1314, this was merged into a river toll on the Rhine in Rheinberg. In 1336, a toll privilege was issued to the town of Xanten, granting a land toll that had been levied "since time immemorial". The revenue was to be used for road construction. In 1353 and 1372 the toll rights were confirmed. In 1392, the toll presumably fell to the Count of Cleves.

Name: Sabile
Settlement_Description: An old castle already existed in the 9th to the 13th century. In 1253 the land fell to the Teutonic Order that built a new castle around 1282. In 1462/64 there is evidence of a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') which was referred to as a 'town'. When this fell into disrepair in 1563, the borough ('Flecken') was rebuilt in the 17th century.

Name: Zahna
Settlement_Description: Slavic settlement at first and in 1198 main castle district settlement ('Burgwardhauptort').
Town_Description: Erhard and Heinrich of Wederden granted town- and toll rights in 1326. These were confirmed in 1361 and 1484.

Name: Zahrensen
Settlement_Description: The village probably goes back to the Zahrenhusen family; a Lippold of Zahrenhusen is first mentioned in 1231.

Name: Zalk
Alternative_Name: Santlike; Zantlike; Zallic; Zalijc; Zalliker-weerde; Salnic; Zalincke; Zallik
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1213. The predecessor of the St. Nicolaaskerk (St Nicholas Church) possibly dated from the eleventh century. The current tower dates from the end of the twelfth century.

Name: Zaltbommel
Alternative_Name: Bomala; Bomele; Bomala; Bomele; Bomilo; Bumele; Sautbomel; Zoutbomel; Saltbomme; Zoutebommele; Zautbomel; Zaltbommel(l); Salt Bommel; Bommel; Saltbommel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 850 (in a copy dating from the end of the eleventh century).
Town_Description: In 999, Zaltbommel received toll, mintage and ‘gruit’ privileges. In 1195, it is first mentioned as a town. Possibly, Otto II, count of Guelders, granted Zaltbommel town privileges in 1231. Reginald II, count of Guelders, granted Zaltbommel town privileges on 13 December 1315. More extensive town privileges were granted by Reginald II on 19 October 1316.
Fair_Description: In Zaltbommel, two fairs came into existence before 1494/95. In 1492, two additional horse and cattle fairs were granted.

Name: Zandhoven
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1183.

Name: Zangenberg
Settlement_Description: Mention 1301 as Czangenberg.

Name: Sianów
Settlement_Description: A castle belonged to the descendants of the Palatin Swenzo early in the 14th ct.
Town_Description: Peter von Pollnow founded the town 1343 with Lübeck town law. The first of many endorsement was made in 1348 by the bishop of Kammin.

Name: Carnikava
Alternative_Name: Zarnikau; Czernekow; Sernekow; Sarnekow; Zernkow; Zarnicko
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1463.

Name: Zaunröden
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1378.

Name: Zeddam
Alternative_Name: Sydehem; Seheim; Sedehem; Zedem; Zeedem; Zedam; Zedum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1139-1148, in a copy dating from 1211, maybe falsification. The next mention in 1200.

Name: Zedtlitz
Settlement_Description: First mention as manor in 1190, in 1303 referred to as castrum, since 1548 knightly manor.

Name: Zeeland
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1376, in a copy dating from 1677.

Name: Zehdenick
Settlement_Description: First a slavic, later in 1200 a german castle, slavic settlements mentioned towards the end of the 13th ct. as well as a german market settlement, a parson is named in 1211, a Cistercian nun monastery is founded in 1250
Town_Description: First mentioned as civitas in 1281

Name: Zeist
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 838, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1028, in a copy dating from circa 1530.

Name: Zeitz
Settlement_Description: First mention of Zeitz during the foundation of suffragan bishoprics according to the resolutions of the Synod of Ravenna in 967, the settlement is probably older though.
Town_Description: Since 1147 the settlement is referred to as town, there's proof of a council constitution in 1322 that, however, has to be older.
Staple_Description: In 1278 staple rights were established.

Name: Zeldert
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1363.

Name: Zele
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1149, in a copy from the second quart of the thirteenth century. Next mention in 1183.

Name: Zellerfeld
Settlement_Description: Foundation of the monastery Cella in the mid-12th century. It is first mentioned as "ecclesia de Cella" in 1191. After mining activities stopped around 1350, the monastery was abolished in 1432. Mining started again in 1526.
Town_Description: Mentioned as mining town ('freie Bergstadt') in 1532, merged with Clausthal in 1924.
Fair_Description: A fair on the Sunday before St Michael existed since 1613.

Name: Zellik
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 974. Next mention in 1003.

Name: Zemst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1150.

Name: Zerben
Settlement_Description: Mention in 1311 as Cerwen.

Name: Zerbst
Settlement_Description: Slavic predecessing settlement, which fell into the missionary area of margrave Gero. Castle district ('Burgward') since 1196.
Town_Description: Around 1200 during the German east migration ('Ostsiedlung') the town was fortified and granted Magdeburg town rights.
Fair_Description: Zerbst presumably had two fairs of some renown in the 14th and 15th century. Their exact length cannot be determined for their early stages. In 1502, 1503, 1545, 1546 and 1595 the fairs were confrimed. In 1514 Zerbst tries for a third fair, which is prevented by Leipzig. Both fairs are held together with cattle markets.

Name: Zernien
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1360. In 1450, the setttlement consisted of 2 farms.

Name: Zeutsch
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1084.

Name: Zeven
Alternative_Name: Kiviana; Cyvena; Quivena; Sxhevena; Zevena; Neu-Heeslingen
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 986. In 1141 the Benedictine monastery of Heeslingen was moved to Zeven. In 1158, the monastery was granted market, mint and toll privileges by Emperor Frederick I. It was abolished in 1647.
Fair_Description: Zeven acquired market privileges in 1158, but a fair 14 days after Pentecost ist first mentioned only in 1740. Older dates are unknown.

Name: Zevenaar
Alternative_Name: Subenhara; Subenhari; Sevenharen; Sivenharen; Sovenharen; Siuenar; Seuener; Zeuener; Zevenar; Sevenar; Out Zeventer, Nieu-Zeventer
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from ca. 1047.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted on 24 January 1487 by John II, duke of Cleves and count of Mark. Zevenaar is considered a town of the type 'minderstad'.
Toll_Description: The oldest reference for a toll of the count of Cleves in Zevenaar dates from ca. 1355. In the town privileges from 1487, the Duke of Cleves donated revenues from the land and road toll in Zevenaar for the fortification of the town.

Name: Ziegenhain
Alternative_Name: Cigenhagen; Czegenhagen; Ciginhan; Czigenhain; Zichenhan; Ziegenhayn
Settlement_Description: Around 1050 there was a castle at which a settlement developed.
Town_Description: Around 1240 the settlement was mentioned as 'urbs' and 'oppidani' . 1274 mentioned as 'oppidum'.

Name: Sulęcin
Alternative_Name: Zielenzig; Zulenche; Zeulenzcik; Sulenzec; Sulenzhit; Zolenceke; Tzullenzk; Sczulenzik; Czelentzick
Settlement_Description: A polish castle and settlement, whose owner, Duke Mrochko or Mrotsek, allowed german settlers to settle in 1241, the german and slavic settlements grew together
Town_Description: Founded by the Templars, was already a civitas in 1244, called opidum in 1286 and 1351 and villa in 1289, throughout the 14th ct. usually mentioned as civitas or town, called Städtchen in 1460

Name: Ziepel
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in 992 as property given to Memleben monastery.

Name: Ziesar
Settlement_Description: Castle district centre ('Burgwardmittelpunkt') in Slavic times, mentioned in 949 as property for the newly founded bishopric of Brandenburg. Since 1214 mentioned as residence of the bishop.
Town_Description: In 1337 bishop Dietrich grants Magdeburg town rights.
Fair_Description: Since the 17th century, four fairs are known. In 1697 two cattle fairs are granted.

Name: Ziethen
Alternative_Name: Ziethene; Cithene; Citene maius; Cythene Mairorem; Theutonica Cythene; Cythane Theutonica; Siten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1158.

Name: Zilly
Settlement_Description: First mentions of the place since 1172 as property of Ilsenburg monastery. First mention of the noble family of Zilly in 1211. First mention of the castle in 1334.

Name: Zittau
Settlement_Description: Originally a Slavic settlement, which was located on the long-distance route between the Baltic Sea and Bohemia. Later, a German castle with the associated borough close to the castle ('Burgflecken').
Town_Description: The city was founded before 1230. In 1255 the town wall was built. In 1275 the term 'civitas' was used.
Staple_Description: In 1351 the city secured a ban on the use of an ancillary road bypassing the city via Friedland; revoked in 1383. In 1425 staple for lead from Frauenburg; in 1469 staple for fish.

Name: Zöbigker
Alternative_Name: Czebeker; Czebekor; Czebekur; Zebicker; Zibiger; Zcewicker
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1378.

Name: Zöblitz
Settlement_Description: Probably a farming settlement that developed into a market place by 1323.

Name: Zoetermeer
Alternative_Name: Soetermere; Zutermere; Soetermeer; Zoetermere; Soermerse meer; Soetermeersse Meer
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1269.

Name: Code
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in 1543.

Name: Zollenspieker
Alternative_Name: Eislingen; Tollenspiker; Zoln Spiker; Toln Spicker; Tollenspiker; Tollenspicker; Zollenspeicher
Settlement_Description: The new toll station Zollenspieker/Eislingen was possibly built with the stones of the castle Riepenburg, the previous location of the toll station, which was demolished in 1512. According to a drawing from ca. 1600, there existed a double building with a ferry landing pier and boardwalk.
Toll_Description: The Hamburg toll station Eislingen on the Elbe river, also called Zollenspieker, was moved in the early 16th century from Riepenburg to the current Zollenspieker because of changes in the mouth of the Ilmenau river (see Riepenburg). From 1584, the toll was levied in cooperation with Lübeck. At the end of the 16th century, Lüneburg negotiated reduced toll fees with Hamburg. The toll was abolished with the Elbschifffahrtsakte of 1821.
Ferry_Description: Ferry across the Elbe to Hoopte.

Name: Zollgrün
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1342. The inn in Zollgrün is already proven as such since 1501.

Name: Zomergem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the ninth century in a copy dating from 941. Next mention in 964. Next mention in 1122.

Name: Zons
Toll_Description:
1) In 1372 a river toll on the Rhine was mentioned in Zons, which was levied by the Archbishop of Cologne. In the 15th century, 1½ 'oberländische Gulden' and 2 alb. per foder of wine are established as the fee. From 1475 to 1495, an additional 1 turnosgroschen per foder of wine had to be paid. In 1419 to 1420 the annual yield amounted to 7520 guilders, in 1421 to 1422 to 7987 guilders.
2) Around 1425, the Archbishop of Cologne also levied a fee for safe conduct on water, which was collected together with the river toll.
3) Around the same time, the Archbishop of Cologne levied a road toll.

Name: Sopot
Settlement_Description: A castle dates back to around 1000. The surrounding villages were given to the monastery of Oliva in 1283 by Duke Mestwin II. of Pommerelia.

Name: Zörbig
Settlement_Description: Founded in the 10th century as a German castle as the centre of a castle district ('Burgward'). A rural settlement developed in the surroundings.
Town_Description: Prince electorate Ernst and count Albrecht of Saxony granted town rights in 1470.

Name: Zorge
Settlement_Description: The foundation of the settlement goes back into the 13th century. In the 16th century, ironworks were constructed.

Name: Zöschen
Alternative_Name: Zeseme; Zcesme; Ceseme; Cisme; Aldindorph; Zössen
Settlement_Description: In the 13th century, a ministerial family of Zössen in mentioned. The former Aldindorph is today part of Zöschen and encompassed the church, the upper village and the corresponding buildings.

Name: Zschaschelwitz
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1181.

Name: Zschopau
Settlement_Description: A castle had stood there since the mid-12th century to protect the 'Salzstraße' and its ford near Zschopau from Halle to Bohemia.The town was expanded after 1200.
Toll_Description: Station of secondary safe conduct of Chemnitz

Name: Zuchau
Settlement_Description: Mention of the settlement in a gift certificate by Otto II from 979 (RI II, 2 n. 784).

Name: Zuidbroek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Broke' in 1273. Earliest mention of 'Suthabroke' in 1283, in a sixteenth- seventeenth century copy.

Name: Zuidhorn
Alternative_Name: Hurum; Zuuthorm; Suythorm; Suedhorn; Northorn zuydt; Suidhorn
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Hurum' in 1338. Earliest mention of 'Zuuthorm' in 1466.

Name: Zuidlaren
Alternative_Name: Lare; Suethlare; Suthlare; Suthlaren; Zuytlaren; Zuutlaer; Zuydtlaren; Suidlaren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Lare' in 1232-1233. Earliest mention of 'Suethlare' in 1262.

Name: Sleen
Alternative_Name: Zuidsleen; Slene; Sle; Scleen; Slen; Zuetsleen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Slene' probably in the 12th century. Earliest mention of 'Zuetsleen' in 1381-1383.

Name: Oud-Zuilen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention is probably from 1169. Next mention of 'Sulen' in 1200. Zuilen became known as Oud-Zuilen after the settlement Nieuw Zuilen was founded in the mid-20th century.

Name: Sulechów
Alternative_Name: Züllichau; Tzulchou; Zulchow; Czullich; Czolch; Züllich; Züllichow
Settlement_Description: Began as a castle settlement
Town_Description: The town was established around 1250 by the silesian dukes during their colonisation efforts, mentioned as 'Haus und Stadt' in 1319

Name: Zundert
Alternative_Name: Deae Sandravdigae; Sunderda; Sunderde; in zondert; Sundert; Groot Sundert; Groot Zundert
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in first-fourth century. Next mention in a falsification from 1157.

Name: Züschen
Alternative_Name: Zuschinum; Tzuschene; Thuseana; Scussene; Scuskene; Tuisgana; Tuschena; Zwischene; Thuschen; Zcuschene; Zuschen; Czuschene
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1100.
Town_Description: The exact founding of the town is not known, but in 1322 the place was called 'oppidum'. A town seal can be proven in 1363.

Name: Züschen
Alternative_Name: Thuskena; Tuschena; Zuschene; Zuschena; Tzuschen; Tuschen; Tzusschena; Tusschene; Tusschen; Czuschenna; Thuschen; Zuschen; Zvsche; Tüschen; Zuschenau; Züschen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1243.

Name: Zutphen
Alternative_Name: Sutphem; Sutpheni; Sutfene; Sutuene; Sutfenna; Sutphania; Sutfen; Sutphen; Sutfenne; Sutphaniense
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1101, but archeological research shows that the place where Zutphen is located has at least been permanently inhabited from the sixth or seventh century onwards. From circa 900 onwards, Zutphen was walled and functioned as a central place for a duke or lord. Oldest mention as 'oppidum' Zutphen dates from 1059. Between 1120 and 1138, the county of Zutphen was inherited by the count of Guelders.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted between 15 April 1191 and 30 March 1196, by Otto I, count of Guelders and Zutphen. In the thirteenth century, the first stone town wall was finished. From 1339 onwards, Guelders became a duchy. From the fourteenth century onwards, four administrative units (quarters) were distinguished in Guelders; Zutphen functioned as the capital in the Quarter of Zutphen ('Kwartier van Zutphen'). Het Stuvennest or Stuvenest, in the Melatensteeg, was one of the inns in town. It is being named between 1468 and 1531. Already before 1268, a hospital was located just outside the Spitaalpoort along the road towards Emmerich. The course of the river IJssel near Zutphen was influenced by human activity several times. In 1357, the river was changed by cutting the southern meander. Unintentionally, this activated the old IJssel at Empe again. As a result, the town risked to lose its location close to the main stem. In 1406/1407, the meander directly west of the town was being canalized until the Polbeek estuary. As a result, the branch at Empe and the northern meander across the Mars were cut off. The canalized river was located between short banks. From the fifteenth century onwards, the navigability of the river IJssel was being threatened by silting.
Toll_Description: A land road toll ('weggeld') was levied at three town gates. At the Laarpoort (road towards the east: towards Lochem, Twente and Westphalia), the Spittaalpoort or Hospitaalpoort (road towards the south: towards Doetinchem, Emmerich and Cleves), and the Nieuwstadspoort (road towards Deventer). The gates Olypoort and Veerpoort had become redundant after the course of the river IJssel had been altered in the fourteenth century. Sources from the fourteenth century show that the Laarpoort brought in more than the other gates combined.
Fair_Description: Zutphen had one fair at least from 1294/1295 onwards. Fair trading in Zutphen decreased from the beginning of the fifteenth century onwards, despite an ongoing increase in the number of fairs. The Saint Walpurgis fair (1st of May) was the only fair in Guelders with a limited supraregional function. Competition of Zutphen with the town of Deventer was constant.

Name: Zwartsluis
Alternative_Name: Swarte Sluys; Zwartensluis; Swarte Sluse; Swaertesluys; Swartesluijs; Swartesluis
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1398.

Name: Zwätzen
Settlement_Description: First mention 1182.

Name: Zweeloo
Alternative_Name: Suele; Swele; Swelle; Zwele; Zwelle; Sweel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1298-1304.

Name: Zwenkau
Settlement_Description: Originally a Slavic settlement. In the 10th century a German castle was built, which was surrounded by a settlement. In 1195 the settlement was mentioned as a market place.
Town_Description: The place was metioned as a town in 1288. However, Bishop Thilo of Merseburg confirmed or renewed 'borough' ('Weichbild') and town rights in 1475.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Pegau.

Name: Zwickau
Settlement_Description: A castle and a market probably existed since the 11th century. The area was previously inhabited by Slavs. The place settled near an old river crossing.
Town_Description: Market and city rights were probably given between 1198 and 1221.
Toll_Description: The Ernestinian safe conduct in Zwickau is influenced by mining products.

Name: Zwijndrecht
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a thirteenth century copy from a document from 847. Next mention in 1114.

Name: Bad Zwischenahn
Alternative_Name: Zwischenahn; Tuschenan; Tuiskena; Tusghenan; Twiischenan; Twysschenan; Twuschena; Twischen Ahn; Tuschenaem; Twischena
Settlement_Description: The area has been settled since the 9th century. The place was first mentioned in 1134.

Name: Zwolle
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 1129 (in a fourteenth century copy).
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted by Wilbrand of Oldenburg, bishop of Utrecht, on 31 August 1230. These town privileges were renewed and extended in 1346.

Name: Eschebrügge
Settlement_Description: On the map Comitatus Bentheim et Steinfurt, auctore Joanne Westenberg (made before 1638), Escherbrug" is displayed as a fortification on the border between the county Bentheim and the Dutch province of Overijssel. The name must refer to a causeway through marshy terrain rather than an actual bridge."

Name: Haelen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1224.

Name: Darłowo
Alternative_Name: Rügenwalde; Ruyenwolde; Rugenwolt; Ruigenwolt; Rugenwolde; Ruwemwolt; Ruwemwolde
Settlement_Description: Archaeological finds from the 8th to 12th ct., partly viking. A castle is mentioned in 1285 and there are traces of settlement from the 11th to the 12th ct.
Town_Description: 1271 first mentioned as civitas. Location was likely done by Wizlaw II of Rügen in 1270. The town was destroyed in 1283. The privilege of 1312 by the dukes Peter of Neuenburg and Jesko of Schlawe offers the town to five new settlers. The privilege inlcuded Lübeck town law.
Staple_Description: Not a real staple, but a forced stay for skippers of two days

Name: Middelburg
Settlement_Description: Middelburg originated as a Caroligian castle, built as a defence against attacks from Norsemen. In the late tenth century, it is already said to have been a port.
Town_Description: In May 1217, town privileges of Middelburg are confirmed by Joan, countess of Flanders, and William I, count of Holland. Possibly, earlier town rights were granted by Floris III, count of Holland. The 'Kamer' (department) of Zeeland, the second largest of the six 'Kamers' of the VOC (Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie, Dutch East India Company, founded in 1602), was located in Middelburg.
Toll_Description: See staple below
Staple_Description: 1347-48 saw the establishment of English and Scottish merchants, with privileges for English merchants following in 1383-88. Privileges for merchants from Portugal in 1390. From 1405 efforts made to secure a staple for the entire island of Walcheren that seems to have been merely an obligation to travel through Middelburg for the payment of the pound toll due there. The staple was given up in 1445. In the 16th century new attempts to erect a staple; in 1521 imperial staple privileges for wine, oil, fruit and iron coming from the west over see; in 1522 staple treaty with Scotland for 14 years, after which there were attempts to extend the staple. 1558 saw the establishment of English merchants.

Name: Buren
Alternative_Name: Buria; Burion; Buram; Büren; Bueren; Buyren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 772 (mentioned in a copy from around 1183-1195).
Town_Description: Town privileges granted on 27 June 1395 by Alart, lord of Buren and Beusichem. Buren was located near the castle Buren. The oldest known privileges of Buren concern family rights dating from 1368 and heritage rights dating from 1383.

Name: Beusichem
Alternative_Name: Beuzekom; Buosinhem; Bosenchem; Bosenkem; Busenchem; Busenghem; Bosincheym; Bosiken; Boesinchem; Beusecum; Boesechem; Bosinghem; Bosinchem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 777-866.

Name: Adavere
Settlement_Description: The manor was first mentioned in a document by Wolter von Plettenberg in 1510.

Name: Bockenheim
Alternative_Name: Frankfurt-Bockenheim; Bochinheim; Boenheim; Bukkinheim; Buchenheim; Buckenheim; Bockinheim
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 767.

Name: Rinteln
Alternative_Name: Rintelen; Renthene; Rinthelen; Rynthelen; Rentellen; Rintelensi; Rintillen
Settlement_Description: The village Rentene (old Rinteln) is attested at the northern shore of the Weser from the late 11th century. Around 1230, count Adolf IV of Holstein and Schaumburg founded the planned town new Rinteln at the southern shore. The church is first mentioned in 1235.
Town_Description: Rinteln is characterised as civitas in 1238, and acquired Lippstadt town privileges the following year.
Toll_Description: Rinteln acquired the right to levy a road toll in 1391: of each wagon 4, of each cart 2, of each horse and cow 1 penny, and of each pig, sheep or goat 1 Heller. The toll collector for the water toll on the Weser river was also responsible for collecting the road toll. Revenues are included in the Rinteln toll registers from 1571 (NLA Bückeburg, see Rothe).
Fair_Description: Rinteln acquired market privileges in 1392 and was allowed to hold two seven-day fairs, before and after the second Sunday after Easter and before and after St James's Day.

Name: Großenwieden
Alternative_Name: Withen; Widen; Wyda; Wydhen; Wyden; Wieden; Widun; Wydun; Within; Widhen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 825. A market is attested in the 13th century.
Toll_Description: A toll booth on the Weser river in Großenwieden is first attested as early as 1287.The toll station was moved to Oldendorf in 1588. Toll registers from 1548 are kept in the Niedersächsisches Landesarchiv Bückeburg, L1 Nr. 6358-6373.

Lock_Description: One of seven locks in the Fulda river between Kassel and Hersfeld, which were built by landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel in a campaign to make the Fulda navigable. Regulations from 1613 specify the lock fee at 2 Alben. At each lock, it was checked whether the toll for the cargo had been paid in Kassel.

One of seven locks in the Fulda river between Kassel and Hersfeld, which were built by landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel in a campaign to make the Fulda navigable. Regulations from 1613 specify the lock fee at 2 Alben. At each lock, it was checked whether the toll for the cargo had been paid in Kassel.

One of seven locks in the Fulda river between Kassel and Hersfeld, which were built by landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel in a campaign to make the Fulda navigable. Regulations from 1613 specify the lock fee at 2 Alben. At each lock, it was checked whether the toll for the cargo had been paid in Kassel.

One of seven locks in the Fulda river between Kassel and Hersfeld, which were built by landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel in a campaign to make the Fulda navigable. Regulations from 1613 specify the lock fee at 2 Alben. At each lock, it was checked whether the toll for the cargo had been paid in Kassel.

One of seven locks in the Fulda river between Kassel and Hersfeld, which were built by landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel in a campaign to make the Fulda navigable. Regulations from 1613 specify the lock fee at 2 Alben. At each lock, it was checked whether the toll for the cargo had been paid in Kassel.
Fish and mill weir near Spiekershausen with a passage for ships on the left side of the river.
Fish and mill weir near Speele with a passage for ships on the left side of the river.

Name: Obernkirchen
Settlement_Description: The monastery of Augustinian canonesses Obernkirchen is first mentioned in an 1167 charter. An earlier history since the 9th century is legendary and cannot be proven. The settlement that developed near the monastery is first mentioned in 1171. It received imperial market privileges and limited borough ('weichbild') rights in 1181. A further development of the settlement took place after the secularisation of the monastery by count Otto IV of Schaumburg in 1565, when the settlement received a borough ('flecken') council after the Bückeburg model.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted by count Ernst of Holstein-Schaumburg.

Name: Rumbeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1031.
Toll_Description: The Weser toll station of Oldendorf was moved to Rumbeck in 1616 because of damming of the old river arm near Oldendorf. After 1621, it was moved back to Oldendorf during the Thirty Years' War. Toll registers are extant in the Niedersächsisches Landesarchiv Bückeburg, L1 Nr. 6380-6385.

Name: Vlissingen
Alternative_Name: Flushing; Vlissinghe; Vlissinghen; Nyevlissinghen; Vlijssingen; Vlijssinghen; Veteri Vlissnghe; oude Vlissinghen; Vlissigghen; Vlissiniensi
Settlement_Description: Vlissingen is first mentioned in 1235 (in a copy from 1324). This first mention of the name Vlissingen (then spelled as 'Vlissinghe') refers to what would later be called Oud-Vlissingen ('Old Vlissingen'). The present-day town came into being near a newly founded harbour at the end of the thirteenth century. Oud-Vlissingen disappeared in the French period, when defence structures were built. Old-Vlissingen was located west of Vlissingen, within the borders of the present-day town.
Town_Description: Vlissingen was granted town rights on 2 April 1315 by William III, count of Holland. Fortifications were added after 1485.
Staple_Description: Around 1500 staple rights for herring. Conflict with Middelburg led to the compromise whereby wine and fruit from the Walcheren region was taken to Middelburg and fish to Vlissingen.

Name: Veere
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Veere is first mentioned in 1305. Cox states that Veere was already mentioned in 1283-1284, and that before 1296 international wool trade took place in the settlement. Veere originated around the location of the ferry to Kampen (Noord-Beverland).
Town_Description: On 31 May 1355, Veere is mentioned as a town when it receives the right to pursue the manufacturing of cloth, together with various other towns on Walcheren. Furthermore, a statute from the same period contains regulations not unsimilar to town rights.
Harbour_Description: Important settlement for Scottish merchants from 1444, but a real staple right was never achieved.

Name: Lubrza
Alternative_Name: Liebenau; Lubynn; Lubenow; Lübenau; Libenau; Liebenow
Town_Description: Mentioned as 'hus und stat' in 1319 and 1322, called civitas in the beginning of the 16th ct., made a hamlet after a war in 1615, town law wasn't granted until 1857

Name: Brückfeldwarte
Settlement_Description: Boom barrier and watchtower in the enclosure ('landwehr') of Höxter

Name: Bosseborner Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the enclosure ('landwehr') of Höxter. The tower proper was located on a hill 200m south of the street. In its place the Bismarckturm was built in 1900.

Toll_Description: Bridge toll; it was leased to the monastery Willebadessen in 1300.
Bridge_Description: Located near the monastery of Corvey on the crossing of two important long-distance routes, Höxter was an important point to cross the river Weser. A ferry is first mentioned in 836, and from 1115 onwards a bridge, which was the first bridge known to have been built across the Weser. The original bridge was probably constructed from wood, replaced in 1249 at the latest by a stone bridge with seven arches and a wooden central part, which could be removed in case of ice drift in winter. The bridge was destroyed in 1673 and only rebuilt in 1831.

Name: Gieselwerder
Settlement_Description: The lords of Gieselwerder are first mentioned in 1093, who inhabited a castle on a former island ('werder') in the Weser river. A ferry is mentioned here in 1409. The castle was already dilapidated in 1583/87 and consequently almost entirely demolished.
Toll_Description: Water, land and ferry toll, which was leased by the archbishop of Mainz to the landgrave of Hesse in 1462. The toll was also listed in a 1584 complaint from Bremen about the tolls on the Weser. Toll registers exist among others for the years 1637-9 and 1645-6; for the 16th century, only entries for the land and ferry toll are known. Toll tariffs are known only from 1543-45 (analysed by Demandt).

Name: Bodenfelde
Alternative_Name: Budinifelde; Budinifeld; Budinefeldun; Budinisvelt; Budinoveldun; Budinueldun; Budineveldon; Budineveld; Budeneuelde; Budenevelde; Bodenvelt; Bodeneuelde; Bodenvelde; Bodinfelde; Bodennfelde; Bödenfel
Settlement_Description: The settlement originally existed as two separate settlements on both sides of the Reiherbach. Economically significant were the saltworks in the village. Attempts to raise the village to a town in 1437 failed due to destructions during feuds.
Toll_Description: In 1270, the duke of Brunswick acquired the toll in Wahmbeck and half of the toll in Bodenfelde. The river toll was moved to Lauenförde in 1534, because ships sailing upstream on the Weser increasingly transshipped their cargo onto the land route in Herstelle. The land toll in Bodenfelde remained.

Name: Polle
Settlement_Description: It can be assumed that the place was already settled during the 9th and 10th century. The borough ('flecken') that exists today originated from the castle that was first mentioned in 1285.
Toll_Description: In the first mention of the castle in 1285, a toll of the Counts of Everstein on the Weser is mentioned, which is confirmed in a Bremen complaint of 1584, as well as a charter of the monastery Hardehausen from 1597.

Name: Burg Ohsen
Settlement_Description: Castle on the right shore of the Weser, first mentioned in 1259, but probably built around 1200.
Toll_Description: Toll station for the river traffic, mentioned in a 1584 complaint from Bremen, as well as in a 1597 charter of the monastery Hardehausen. The beginnings of the toll are unclear; it is not known whether a toll was already levied here before the castle came to the dukes of Brunswick in 1422. When Ohsen was pawned to Oberhofmarschall Franz Ernst Graf v. Platen in 1681, both a land and a river toll were mentioned.

In 1510, citizens of Bodenwerder were exempted from the Weser toll in Grohnde, which was levied by Evert von Münchhausen, who had been enfeoffed with the toll, before. The Weser toll is further mentioned in a 1584 complaint from Bremen, but not in a list of Weser tolls in a charter of the monastery Hardehausen from 1597.

Name: Hamelner Loch
Toll_Description: Conflict about tolls between Hameln and Minden around 1200; bishop Dietmar of Minden arbitrated and declared that citizens of both towns were mutually exempted from toll payments. Hameln acquired the right to levy a ship and bridge toll from duke Albrecht of Brunswick in 1277. The toll is still mentioned in a Bremen complaint from 1584, but not in a Weser toll list in a charter of the monastery of Hardehausen from 1597.
Lock_Description: A weir in the Weser river, the so-called Hamelner Loch, which was first mentioned in 1314 but might have been built at the beginning of the 11th century, provided a considerable barrier for shipping on the river. The 6,30m wide passage for ships in the form of a wooden slipway, the Fiehre, was only passable when the cargo of the ships was unloaded first, which promoted a staple-like situation.

Name: Hausberge
Alternative_Name: Porta Westfalica; Hus tom Berge; Monte; Hauß zum Berg; Schalksburg; castellum Scalcaburg; Schalkesberge; de monte; Montis; Husbage
Settlement_Description: The castle Schalksburg was first mentioned in 1020, later referred to as Hausberge and demolished in 1723. Next to it, a settlement developed that was characterised as town in 1548 and received market privileges in 1613, but remained a borough ('flecken').

Name: Stolzenau
Settlement_Description: A castle was built in 1346 by the count of Hoya during a border conflict between Hoya and Minden. The corresponding settlement is characterised as borough ('flecken') from 1459 onwards.
Toll_Description: Toll on land and on the Weser river, which was pawned in 1553. Furthermore, it is mentioned in 1576, in a 1584 complaint from Bremen, and in a 1597 charter of the monastery Hardehausen. The toll station probably went back to the founding of the castle. Toll revenues are known for some years around 1600.
Fair_Description: Three fairs were granted in 1590, on the Mondays after Reminiscere, St John the Baptist and St Lawrence.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Weser is mentioned in 1573. It was destroyed by floods in 1582 and rebuilt in 1587.

Name: Schlüsselburg
Settlement_Description: A castle was built by the bishop of Minden in 1335 during border disputes with Hoya. A planned settlement was built in the second half of the 14th century, which received borough ('weichbild') privileges in 1400.
Toll_Description: A toll on the Weser river in Schlüsselburg is mentioned in a 1584 complaint from Bremen, as well as a 1597 list of Weser tolls from the monastery Hardehausen. It probably went back to the foundation of the castle.

Name: Hoya
Settlement_Description: Possibly a settlement of the Angrivarii before, it is first mentioned in the 11th century. A castle is first mentioned in 1213. From 1233, it is characterised as town ('urbs', 'civitas', 'stadt') or borough ('weichbild', 'flecken'). It acquired borough ('weichbild') privileges probably in 1368.
Toll_Description: In a 1335 treaty between Bremen and Hoya, it is agreed that Bremen skippers enjoy free shipping on the Weser river in return for the payment of a transit toll in Hoya. The toll was pawned in 1543, and mentioned in a 1584 complaint from Bremen and in a charter of the monastery Hardehausen from 1597. Toll revenues are known from the late 16th century.

Name: Dreye
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1158.
Toll_Description: Toll of the counts of Hoya, later the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg. The monastery of Schinna was exempted from toll payments in Weyhe in 1258. Later - probably before 1370 - the toll was moved to Dreye, where it is mentioned again in the 16th century. It was leased to Dr. jur. Gideon Eggeling in 1571, and to the wife of count Simon of Lippe in 1582. The toll collector in 1574 is named Johann von Redessen (Bodeßen?), who was responsible for collecting the land and water toll. The river toll in Dreye is mentioned in a 1597 charter of the monastery of Hardehausen, but not in a list of Weser toll stations in a 1584 complaint from Bremen; a toll in Schlieme, just a few kilometres upstream, is mentioned instead. Probably both tolls were merged between these years, as accounts from the administrative region of Syke list both tolls separately in 1572, but combined in 1586.

Name: Schlieme
Alternative_Name: Schlimme; Slime; Schlime; Slym; Schlim; Slyem
Settlement_Description: In the 13th century, Brun von Hagen received the farm Schlieme as a fief from the count of Bruchhausen. In 1563, it is referred to as noble farm ('meierhof').
Toll_Description: A toll in Schlieme is leased to Dietrich Behr in 1563 and mentioned in a 1584 complaint from Bremen, but not any more in a list of Weser tolls in a 1597 charter of the monastery of Hardehausen. Probably, the river tolls in Schlieme and nearby Dreye were merged in the meantime, as accounts of the administrative region of Syke list incomes from these tolls separately in 1572, but combined in 1586. According to the 1572 account, the toll in Schlieme had higher revenues than the one in Dreye.

Name: Wetenkamp
Toll_Description: A toll of the archbishop of Bremen at the confluence of the Weser and Aller rivers near Thedinghausen already existed in the 14th century. Half of the toll was leased to Bremen burgomaster Dirick Hoyer in the 16th century, and returned to the Bremen cathedral chapter after Hoyer's death in 1569. The toll was moved to Intschede in 1607 because of changes in the course of the Aller. Toll tariffs are known for the early 15th century and 1545; for the years after 1567, toll registers are extant (Niedersächsisches Landesarchiv Stade, analysed by Peters 1913).

Bridge_Description: The only bridge across the Weser river between Höxter and Minden, which was constructed shortly after 1000. At first it was a wooden bridge, which had to be renovated multiple times. It was replaced by a bridge with stone pillars between 1380 and 1390. A bridge toll is attested in the 14th century.

Name: Bremer Schlagd
Toll_Description: A toll on the Weser river in Münden is mentioned in a 1584 complaint from Bremen. Probably, it refers to the harbours fees that were introduced two years earlier.
Harbour_Description: At the confluence of the Fulda and Werra, the harbour for traffic on the Weser was located, which was named Bremer Schlagd after the sea port at the other end of the river. The harbour quays were extended in 1582; at the occasion harbour fees ('Schlachtgeld') were introduced.

Name: Varenholz
Alternative_Name: Vorenholte; Fornholte; Vorneholte; Vorenholthe; Varenholte; Voremholte; Varnholte; Fernholte; Wornholte; Vorhenholthe; Vornholtthe; Varenholtz; Vornholdt; Varenholtz; Varnholz; Vorenholtz; Furenholt; Varnhold
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1176. A castle was built around this time, and is first mentioned in 1323, when it was sold to the lords of Lippe. The settlement developed into a borough ('flecken') in the 16th century.

Name: Kleine Schlachte
Harbour_Description: The so-called "kleine" ('small') Schlachte was located east of the Weser bridge. It served as a harbour for river traffic, contrary to the Schlachte, located west of the bridge, which was the sea port of Bremen. The river harbour appears for the first time on the map of Bremen by Braun/Hogenberg (1588/9) and was constructed from stone shortly before. However, a landing place for timber rafts was probably already existing on this spot in the 13th century.

Toll_Description: In Rinteln a shipping toll was levied on the Weser river by the count of Schaumburg. The toll registers, which are available from the year 1571 (NLA Bückeburg), give an extraordinary insight in traffic on the river in the late 16th century.
Harbour_Description: The harbour was of minor importance for the town Rinteln. According to Merian's town view of 1647, it was located on the northern shore of the Weser, which was unpaved.

Ferry_Description: A ferry is first mentioned in 1319, but was probably much older. It seems that it operated next to the bridge, which was not usable for heavier traffic before its construction from stone. Afterwards, a ferry was deployed as well in the frequent cases of damage to the bridge.
Bridge_Description: A ferry across the Weser river was probably replaced by a wooden bridge in the 11th century. A bridge toll for foreigners is mentioned in 1232. Around 1340, the bridge rested on stone pillars, until it was replaced by a bridge completely constructed from stone in 1463.

Name: Vegesack
Settlement_Description: An inn "Zum Vegesack" is mentioned around 1500. At the end of the 16th century, a settlement developed around the harbour basin.
Harbour_Description: Because large ships had ever greater trouble reaching the harbour of Bremen due to the silting up of the river Weser, a new harbour basin in Vegesack was planned in 1618. The plans were realised between 1619 and 1622. However, travel accounts of the Utrecht antiquarian Aernout van Buchel from 1587 and 1591 attest that the harbour of Vegesack was used as a landing place for sea-going ships on the way to Bremen already before the construction of the harbour basin.

Name: Schlachte
Harbour_Description: The port activities at the Balge, the original harbour of Bremen, expanded to include the bank of the Weser river in the course of the 13th century, which developed into Bremen's harbour for sea-going traffic under the name "Schlachte". Originally, landing facilities were made of wooden pile work (from which the name "Schlachte" was derived), but stone quays were built in the 16th century.

Name: Balge
Harbour_Description: The Balge, a river arm of the Weser that was located directly next to the market square, was the oldest harbour of Bremen. Due to the limited place, building activities and silting up of the river arm, it gradually lost its significance to the new sea-going harbour at the river front, the Schlachte. However, the Balge regulations of 1399 indicate a still lively traffic at that time, though it must have remained limited to lighter boats. In the 16th century, it had largely lost its importance as a harbour and was closed for regular traffic in 1602.

Toll_Description: In 1379, a bridge toll is first mentioned. Until the 16th century, it was owned by the counts of Neubruchhausen and Hoya, from whose lands multiple villages had paid for the construction of the bridge. Still in 1533, the toll was owned by the count of Hoya, but by the 18th century, it was in the hands of the cathedral and six Bremen families.
Bridge_Description: Bridge over both arms of the Weser river, the "kleine" ('little') and "große" ('large') Weser. A wooden bridge is first mentioned in 1244. Between 1522 and 1531, a large tower, called the "Braut" ('bride'), was constructed on the peninsula between both river arms to guard the bridge. At the occasion, the bridge over the little Weser, which was presumably originally a straight continuation of the large bridge, was reconstructed as a draw bridge a little upstream on the Teerhof peninsula.

Name: Intschede
Toll_Description: In 1607, the toll at the mouth of the river Aller in the Weser near Wetenkamp (Thedinghausen) was moved to Intschede because of changes in the course of the river. Toll registers are available in the Niedersächsisches Landesarchiv Stade; for the year 1610/11, they have been analysed by Peters (1913).

Name: Afferdsche Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower at the crossing of the Hamel river in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Hameln, first mentioned in 1385. The tower is mentioned in 1415 as a stone building.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the river Hamel is mentioned in 1356 and 1394.

Name: Wehrberger Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Hameln, which is first mentioned in 1385. The tower was located in such a way that both land and river traffic could be watched over.

Harbour_Description: Important transshipment point between water and land traffic between Bremen and Braunschweig. On a view of Celle by Merian (1654), we can see that the harbour was located next to the water mill near the castle.

Lock_Description: In 1390, the town of Hannover and the owner of the Bordenau mill weir agreed that the weir should be opened to shipping on the Leine at all times.

Name: Bothmer Mühle
Lock_Description: In 1389 the town Hannover agreed with Eberhard von Mahrenholz, the owner of the Bothmer mill, that he would construct a passage for ships on the Leine river in the mill weir. After the establishment of the shipping monopoly of Celle in 1516, the weir was barricaded by Celle. This led to conflicts with the towns Neustadt am Rübenberge and Hannover in 1546-8, which would last until the end of the 16th century.
In 1389 the town Hannover arranged with the owner of the mill weir in Grindau, that it had to be opened for ships on the Leine river at all times.
In 1390 the town Hannover and the owner of the Dinstorf mill weir agreed that the weir should be opened to ships on the Leine river at all times.

In 1390 the town Hannover arranged with the monastery Mariensee, the owner of the mill in Wulfelade, that the mill weir had to be opened to ships on the Leine river at any time. Moreover, the town promised to repair any damage inflicted to the mill weir by passing ships within four weeks.
A lock near Veltenhof was built between 1442 and 1444 as part of construction works to increase the navigability of the Oker river between Braunschweig and the castle Neubrück.

Name: Ölper
Alternative_Name: Elbere; Elber; Olber; Olbere; Ölber; Oelver; Oelper
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1251. In Ölper stood a watchtower of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Braunschweig, which was erected around 1390.

Lock_Description: Between 1442 and 1444, locks were constructed in Veltenhof, Ölper and Watenbüttel, so that the Oker was navigable between Braunschweig and the castle Neubrück.
Between 1442 and 1444, a lock was constructed near Watenbüttel in order to increase the navigability of the Oker river between Braunschweig and the castle Neubrück.

Toll_Description: The town acquired toll privileges in 985. According to 1460 complaints from the towns Brunswick and Celle, the toll tariff on the Aller river in Verden had at that time been increased to a sixfold of the previous tariff. Three years later, the toll was reduced again to 50 percent.

Lock_Description: To make the Oker river navigable, the town of Braunschweig made an arrangement with the miller Lütkens in Hillerse to construct a lock in the mill weir. The lock was finalised in 1460.
Lock near Wienhausen, built between 1459 and 1461 by the town of Braunschweig to facilitate shipping on the Oker and Aller rivers.

Lock in the Aller river in Celle, which was built before 1461 to facilitate shipping between Braunschweig and Celle. Both towns paid half of the construction costs. The lock is displayed on an engraving by Merian from 1654.

Name: Lohnde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1209.

Lock_Description: A lock in the Leine in Neustadt was built in 1506.

Name: Marienwerder
Alternative_Name: Insula sancte Marie; Insula beate Marie; Insula iuxta Honovere; sancte Marie de Insula; Werdere; Werder; Marrienwerder; Marienwehrder
Settlement_Description: Foundation of a monastery of Augustinian canons in ca. 1196; the monks were replaced by nuns from the monastery Obernkirchen in 1216. It became a pilgrimage destination. In 1543, the monastery became a Lutheran Ladies' convent. The buildings were destroyed and plunedered during the Thirty Years' War in 1632, and rebuilt after a fire in 1687.

Name: Ahlden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1160. The castle of Ahlden was confiscated by the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg in 1431. Around this time, the settlement acquired the character of a borough ('flecken').
Toll_Description: With the acquisition of Ahlden by Lüneburg, it became one of the toll stations on the Aller river. An agreement between Hannover and Celle from 1507 defines that for ships sailing from Bremen to Hannover, half of the tolls in the duchy of Celle have to be paid in Ahlden. After changes in the course of the river between 1618 and 1630, the toll was levied in Hudemühlen. Toll revenues are known for the 18th and 19th century.

Bridge_Description: The bridge across the Aller near Essel became a hindrance for traffic on the river in the 16th century. Plans from 1586 to construct a higher bridge that could be passed by ships were never realised, according to a Bremen complaints from 1608. Instead there existed a hatch, for which one had to get the key from the bailiff ('vogt') in Essel. In order to get there, the marshy terrain separating the river and the settlement had to be crossed, which was difficult especially in winter when the marshes were flooded.
Harbour_Description: Essel was a transshipment point for the land and water traffic, predominantly between Bremen and Braunschweig. Around 1587 the Duke of Brunswick tried to stimulate the settlement as transshipment point, which led to complaints from Celle.

Name: Haren (Ems)
Settlement_Description: The settlement, originally a fishing village, adopted the name of the current village Altharen. In the 13th century, the settlement had a church, and a castle of the bishop of Münster is mentioned in 1304.
Toll_Description: A toll in Haren is first mentioned as a fief of the count of Tecklenburg in 1236; later it belonged to the bishop of Münster. A list of toll fees for various commodities exists for the year 1631. In the 17th century, half of the toll was owned by the town Meppen.
Fair_Description: Various fairs are mentioned in Haren in the early 14th century, for which merchants from Osnabrück received safe conduct. Of these fairs, the fairs at Pentecost and St John are still mentioned in the late 15th century, together with a new fair on St Giles.

Name: Klapperturm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Einbeck on the street to Dassel, built in 1446. It is the only watchtower of Einbeck that still exists.

Name: Bartshäuser Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Einbeck, which is first mentioned in 1431. The tower itself is mentioned in 1439. Demolished in 1795.

Name: Leineturm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower on the crossing of the river Leine near Northeim, which was built in 1399. Since the late 16th century, there was an inn next to the tower. The tower was demolished in 1717.
Bridge_Description: An older wooden bridge was replaced by a stone one in 1497. It was located 100m north of the current river crossing.

Name: Stau
Harbour_Description: The "Stau" at the mouth of the Haaren in the Hunte was the harbour of Oldenburg. Shipping traffic is first attested in the 14th century. An additional loading place for the river traffic was located in Donnerschwee, where a toll for ships loading timber is mentioned in 1428, and where pottery was loaded as well. In the course of the 15th century, shipping activity was moved from Donnerschwee to the Stau.

Name: Bäckerstraße
Toll_Description: Toll of the dukes of Lüneburg on road traffic in the Bäckerstraße, first mentioned in 1383. Lüneburg citizens were exempted from toll payments. A toll register of ca. 1500 in a town account gives an impression of the traffic through the street.

Already in 1396 Lüneburg had attempted in vain to levy a toll on traffic on the Ilmenau river. According to complaints from Hamburg, a toll was levied again in 1465, which was legalised by the emperor in a 1471 privilege. After conflicts with other Hanseatic towns, Lüneburg had to cancel the levying of the toll in 1476.
Harbour_Description: River harbour at the Ilmenau, of which the shores were stabilised with stone quays since the 16th century at the latest. On the eastern side of the harbour, a crane existed since 1346 as well as a storage building ('kaufhaus'), which was enlarged in 1574. A new storage building was erected in 1622. The harbour basin could be closed off with a barrier; additionally a bastion was built to guard the harbour entrance in 1534, which had to be reconstructed after an explosion in 1537.

Name: Krapendorf
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1185. In 1279 the castle Cloppenburg was built near the settlement, which developed into a town that converged with Krapendorf. However, both settlements remained independent until 1855.

Harbour_Description: In the 17th century, Haren was the centre of the transport with barges ('pünten') on the Ems.
The Vechte was navigable up to Schüttorf with barges until the 20th century. The town was an important transshipment point for sandstone from the Bentheim quarries on its way to the Dutch cities.
Nordhorn was a transshipment harbour for sandstone from the Bentheim quarries on its way to the Dutch cities. The current street Steinmaate is a reminder of this.
The Ems river was navigable with larger ships downstream from Meppen, which made the town a transshipment point for water transport.

Toll_Description: It is mentioned in 1482 that the town of Meppen would share the profits from the bridge toll, levied by the town alone before, with the bishop. The entire toll income was returned to the town in 1569.
Ferry_Description: A ferry existed here until construction of a bridge in 1385.
Bridge_Description: A bridge over the Ems was built by the bishop of Münster in 1385. In 1569, it was acquired by the town.

Toll_Description: It is mentioned in 1482 that the town of Meppen would share the profits from the bridge toll, levied by the town alone before, with the bishop. The entire toll income was returned to the town in 1569.
Bridge_Description: The bridge over the Hase was first mentioned in 1398, when Bishop Otto of Münster bought half of the bridge. In the next year, the other half was acquired by the town of Meppen; In 1569, it was owned completely by the town.
Bridge over the Hase. An extraordinary bridge toll is mentioned here in a complaint from Deventer, Kampen and Zwolle in 1569.

Harbour_Description: The Hase was navigable up to Haselünne

Name: Schlagde
Harbour_Description: The construction of a city wall in the 13th century separated the old market, located on the shore of a river arm, from the water. Consequently a harbour at the shore of the Weser was established, which received the name "Schlagde". The harbour was located outside of town; possibly, the Weser toll was levied here before the toll in Petershagen was granted (1377).

It is unknown where the harbour for shipping on the Oker river in Braunschweig was located. For the shipping to Celle and Bremen in the late Middle Ages, a location in the northern part of town is assumed, probably around the former river island Werder in the borough Hagen, with an additional landing place on the opposite shore in the borough Neustadt around the former street Nickelnkulk. However, there is no written or archaeological evidence for a harbour in Braunschweig. The (un)loading of ships might also have taken place outside the town.

Name: Schöppenstedter Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Braunschweig. The oldest evidence for this part of the landwehr dates from 1387.

Harbour_Description: The Oker was made navigable between Wolfenbüttel and Schladen in 1575, and up to Oker in 1577.

Lock_Description: A lock near Dorstadt was constructed in 1575 as part of a project to make the Oker navigable between Wolfenbüttel and Schladen. The basin was 20 feet deep.

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Oker was first mentioned in 1527.

Lock_Description: Flash lock at the mill in Ohrum, built to regulate the shipping on the Oker in 1577.
The Nette (Altenau) was made navigable in 1575, at which occasion a lock was constructed near Wendessen. Shipping on the stream must have stopped around 1610.

Name: Donnerburgbrücke
Settlement_Description: Stables for draught horses are mentioned in 1584. Since the 17th century, there existed an inn at the bridge.
Bridge_Description: The bridge is first mentioned in 1385 in a peace agreement between the town Braunschweig and Cordt van der Assenburg. A draw bridge is mentioned in 1584. The current still existing stone bridge dates from 1708 and is called Donnerburgbrücke, after a former inn at the bridge, which came into the possession of Hans Jürgen Donner in 1705.
Harbour_Description: A place for loading stones from the Ösel was created next to the bridge in 1575.
Lock_Description: A lock was built here in the context of making the Nette (Altenau) navigable in 1575.

Harbour_Description: The Nette (Altenau) was made navigable in 1575, mainly for the transport of stones from the Elm. According to a 1578 source, in which duke Julius promised the transport of building material by ship for the reconstruction of houses after the town of Schöppenstedt had burned down, the Nette was navigable up to Schöppenstedt. Shipping on the stream must have stopped around 1610.

Toll_Description: A toll of the archbishop of Bremen on the crossing of the river Lesum is already mentioned in 1062. A bridge toll was levied from 1387 onwards, to cover the expenses of the construction of the new bridge. At first, this toll was levied by the town of Bremen, later it was shared with the archbishop.
Ferry_Description: In the charter about the reconstruction of the castle from 1350, a ferry is mentioned. This ferry must have existed until the construction of the bridge in 1388.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Lesum was built by the town of Bremen around 1388 for the sum of 6000 Mark.

Name: Lesum
Alternative_Name: Liastmona; Liestmunde; Liesmunde; Liesmund; Lesmona; Lesmund; Lestmona; Lessimona; Lesmene; Lessmonia
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 860.

Name: Sulberger Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Duderstadt on the Sulberg, first mentioned in annals of the year 1400. In the vicinity, the gallows of Duderstadt were located as well.

Name: Wehnder Warte
Alternative_Name: Nige warde; Nyge warde by Wende; Feuerhaken-Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Duderstadt near Wehnde, built in 1413.

Name: Giehlermühlen
Settlement_Description: Water mill, farm and inn, mentioned in a tax register of 1535.

Name: Gotteslager
Toll_Description: The toll in Linden was moved before 1630 into the suburb Gotteslager in Wolfenbüttel. According to a description of 1630, the toll in Gotteslager had the highest revenues of the five toll stations in the Amt Wolfenbüttel.

Name: Thiedebach
Settlement_Description: Toll station with inn at the stream Thiedebach, which was built by duke Julius of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel after 1586.
Toll_Description: A toll station was installed here by duke Julius of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel after 1586.

Name: Hessendamm
Toll_Description: Toll of the bishop of Halberstadt at the Hessendamm, which was built in 1343.

Name: Mattierzoll
Alternative_Name: Hessem Tam; Hessendamm; Hessen-Zoldham; berchvrede by Hesnum
Settlement_Description: The town of Brunswick erected a guardtower on the northern side of the causeway that bridged the Große Bruch (Hessendamm) in 1375.
Toll_Description: Toll station of the dukes of Brunswick at the Hessemdamm, which was built in 1343. Since the 19th century, the toll station is known as Mattierzoll, because the toll had to be paid in Mattier (Matthiasgroschen), a coin minted in Goslar since 1471. Detailed toll tariffs and regulations are recorded in an overview of tolls in the duchy of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel from 1582.

Name: Bungenstedter Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower on the border between Brunswick and Hildesheim territory, first mentioned in 1461. In the second half of the 16th century, lumberjack Albrecht Gillies constructed a house next to the tower.

Name: Sankt Hülfe
Alternative_Name: Nutlo; Nuttlo; Notlo; Nuttele; Zunt-Hulpe; Zunte Hulpe; Sent Hulpe
Settlement_Description: The village was originally called Nutlo. A first mention as "Stuttele" between 1238 and 1250 is believed to be a writing error. A chapel dedicated to the Holy Wilgefortis is first mentioned in 1378, and became a pilgrimage centre. This resulted in the village becoming known as Sankt Hülfe. The chapel burned down after 1519 and was not rebuilt.

Harbour_Description: Due to changes in the course of the Ems, the Mühlenbach was enlarged in 1541 to keep allowing smaller ships to anchor near the town. In this area, the former landing place at the bank of the Ems is to be presumed as well.

Name: Warturm
Alternative_Name: Wartorne; Warthorn; torn to der Warebrughen
Settlement_Description: Watchtower to guard the border between Bremen and Oldenburg at the Ochtum river, built in the early 14th century. The name is derived from the settlement War(e), which was abandoned in the 14th century. A new toll house and inn was built in 1577, the "Storchennest" (stork's nest). The tower was demolished in 1661, but rebuilt in 1669. After its destruction in 1813, the remains were removed in 1820. The toll house still exists.
Toll_Description: The road toll is first mentioned in 1449, when it was leased to several citizens for 12 years, but it probably existed from the time the road between Delmenhorst and Bremen via Huchting was constructed, as was agreed upon by the counts of Oldenburg and the town of Bremen in 1311. Oldenburg citizens acquired exemption of the toll at the Warturm in 1461. A new toll house was erected in 1577.
Bridge_Description: Bridge across the Ochtum (Warbrücke), first mentioned in 1390.

Name: Mittelshuchting
Alternative_Name: Huchting; Huhthinge; Huginke; Huchtinge; Huchtingen; Hoychtiggen; Huchtigen; Huchtyghe; Huctinge; Myddelshuchtinghe; Myddelsthuchtinghe
Settlement_Description: The settlement Huchting was divided in three parts: Kirch-, Mittels- and Brokhuchting, of which the former two are the oldest parts. Mittelshuchting is first mentioned separately in 1384.

Name: Kattenturm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower of Bremen, built in 1390 to control the crossing of the Ochtum river near Kattenesch, after which village the tower was named. Next to the tower, there was a toll house and an inn. Demolished in 1803. The current settlement, a quarter of Bremen, was later named after the former tower.
Toll_Description: At the Kattenturm, a toll was levied by the town of Bremen.
Bridge_Description: Bridge over the river Ochtum. In 1799, the draw bridge was replaced by a fixed bridge.

Name: Stumpfer Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower Dörshelf with an inn on a pass on a trade route, first mentioned in the first half of the 15th century. Possibly, it belonged to the town Alfeld to secure the street, later to the noble family of Steinberg-Wispenstein. The tower became known as Stumpfer Turm in the 18th century because of the missing spire.

Name: Nobiskrug
Settlement_Description: The Inn was first mentioned in 1582.

Name: Glanerbrug
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1773.

Harbour_Description: The significance of the Elbe harbour in Lauenburg grew considerably after the opening of the Stecknitz canal in 1398, as cargoes had to be transshipped here because of the different ship sizes on the canal and on the Elbe. Skippers of Lauenburg acquired a transport monopoly for all commodities being transported on the canal that were to be transported further on the Elbe in 1417.

The harbour of Emden was located in a bend of the river Ems, which was cut across 4 km south during a flooding in 1509, creating the island Nesserland. As a result the harbour, now located on a river arm, started to silt up. The town tried to prevent the silting of its harbour and the bypassing of its staple between 1585 and the Thirty Years' War with a pile barrier in the main stream. The harbour in the town was extended in 1538 by raising and reinforcing the peninsula Butvenne between the Ratsdelft and the Falderndelft. Countess Anna ordered the construction of a loading crane on the Bonesse, the eastern shore of the Falderndelft, in 1544.

Name: Dörverden
Settlement_Description: Possibly, Dörverden is identical to the "Tulifurdon" mentioned by Ptolemy in 150. This possibility is supported by archaeological finds of graves from pre-Christian times. It was an old regional court ('gogericht'), which was acquired by the bishop of Verden in 1288. The court existed until ca. 1650. The local church is first mentioned in 1340.

Harbour_Description: Ems harbour in Rheine, which could be reached with the Ems barges ('pünten'). With the development of shipping to Greven after 1550, the significance of Rheine as transshipment point and skipper town grew.

Lock_Description: A wooden mill weir in the Ems is first mentioned in 1362, and replaced by a construction of stone in 1550. The existence of the weir forced the transshipment of cargoes on river barges. For this reason, a wooden chamber lock ('verlaat') was constructed in the weir in 1579/80.

Bridge_Description: Construction of a bridge over the Dinkel was started when the settlement received town privileges in 1369; the next year, the citizens acquired the right to fetch timber in the surroundings and to levy a toll for the maintenance of the bridge.

Name: Mühlenkolk
Harbour_Description: The harbour was located at the current Mühlenkolk, which was connected to the Vechte and Dinkel via the Mühlenbecke.

Name: Heger Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the enclosure ('landwehr') of Osnabrück, constructed around 1347.

Name: Victorbur
Settlement_Description: Victorbur is mentioned in the law of the region Brokmerland from 1300 as 'wic', which indicates a settlement with special legal protection during market times. The oldest predecessor of the local church was possibly built in the 11th century.

Name: Rotenburger Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of the town Braunschweig, which was erected between 1381 and 1385.

Name: Raffturm
Alternative_Name: Rafhove; Raffhove; torn uppe deme Raffhove
