Settlement_Description: Watchtower of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Braunschweig, erected between 1384 and 1388.

Name: Wendenturm
Alternative_Name: berchfrede to Wenden; torn to Wenden
Settlement_Description: Watchtower of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Braunschweig. The oldest evidence for this part of the enclosure dates from 1387.

Name: Döhrener Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the enclosure ('landwehr') of Hannover.

Name: Roter Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower at the bridge across an arm of the Leine river, constructed in 1440, demolished in 1646.

Name: Landwehrschenke
Settlement_Description: Watchtower and inn of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Hannover.

Name: Schlagd
Harbour_Description: Wanfried was the end of shipping on the Werra and therefore an important transshipment station between land- and rivertransport.

Name: Zum Dicken Weib
Alternative_Name: thom dicken wyve; Emmer Brücke; Dickes Weib

Bridge_Description: The bridge in Bodenteich is mentioned in 1393, when wagons toppled over there.

Name: Eigenroder Warte
Alternative_Name: Hüpstedter Warte; Eigenröder Warte; Schalkeröder Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower north of Mühlhausen.

Name: Rüdigershagen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1148.

Name: Fahre
Settlement_Description: At the ferry, there existed an inn and a chapel

Name: Harzburg
Settlement_Description: The castle Harzburg, which actually consisted of two castles on mountain tops, was built by emperor Henry II in 1065-1068. The castle was demolished after the Thirty Years' War.

Name: Dambeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1450/51. An earlier mention from 1330/52 as Dannenbeke is uncertain. In 1450, the village consisted of 3 farms.

Name: Hitzacker
Alternative_Name: Hidesaker; Hideshakere; Hiddesacker; Hyddesackere; Hidzakere; Hidzackere; Hiddesakere; Hidzaker; Hizger; Hidesacher; Hedesackere; Hitzger
Settlement_Description: Slavic fortification from the 8th century, later a castle of Henry the Lion and the dukes of Saxony-Lauenburg, which is first mentioned in a charter from 1162.
Town_Description: Hitzacker was already mentioned as "urbs" in 1203, but received the Lüneburg town privileges in 1258.
Toll_Description: Toll on the Elbe river traffic of the dukes of Saxony-Lauenburg, first mentioned in 1248 with references to the toll fees. In the 14th century, the toll often changes hands or was pawned. At the division of the duchy of Brunswick-Lüneburg in 1428, the toll was divided by the dukes of Brunswick and Lüneburg; it came completely to Lüneburg in 1491. In 1492, the toll fees were indicated as 4 Gulden, 1 "pärchin", 1 loaf of bread and 2 buns for each ship. The toll was discontinued in 1872.
Harbour_Description: The harbour of Hitzacker was important for shipping on the Jeetzel river. Commodities that were transported further onto the Elbe sometimes had to be transferred to other ships here.

Name: Schnackenburg
Alternative_Name: Snakenburg; Snakenburch; Snakenborch; Snakenborgh; Schnakenborch; Snackeburg; Godegord; Schnakenburg
Settlement_Description: The settlement came into existence next to a castle, which was possibly built in the 11th century and first mentioned in 1218. The settlement was characterised as borough ('weichbild') in 1351 and as town in 1373, although it remained a borough or minor town.
Toll_Description: Toll on the Elbe of the margraves of Brandenburg, shared with the lord of Mecklenburg in 1321. It was acquired by the dukes of Mecklenburg in 1373 and by the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg in 1390/91. Levying of the Mecklenburg part of the toll was moved to Lenzen before 1411. The Lüneburg part of the toll in Schnackenburg was divided between the dukes of Brunswick and Lüneburg after the partition of the duchy in 1409; it came completely to Lüneburg in 1491, but was often pawned to the lords of Bülow. The dukes tried to raise the toll tariffs in 1576, after which various towns complained that the fees had already been doubled. A new raise of the fees was confirmed in 1613.
Harbour_Description: Trade relations with Hamburg in Schackenburg are attested from 1288.

Name: Kasseler Schlagd
Harbour_Description: The quay at the shore of the Fulda in Münden was the harbour for the traffic on the Fulda river, and it was named Kasseler Schlagd after its most important destination Kassel. In 1582, the landing bridges were extended and harbour fees were introduced.

Name: Wanfrieder Schlagd
Harbour_Description: The harbour at the shore of the Werra in Münden was destined for handling shipping on the Werra; it was named Wanfrieder Schlagd after the Werra town where the cargoes were transshipped to land traffic. In 1582, the harbour quays were extended and harbour fees were introduced.

Ferry_Description: The Weser near Nienburg could be crossed at a ford. Before the construction of a bridge, ferrymen were also active here.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Weser is first mentioned in 1569 as "Lembker bruggen" ('bridge to Lemke'). The bridge was destroyed by Danish troops in 1625 during the Thirty Years' War, temporarily replaced by a pontoon bridge, and rebuilt in 1663.

Name: Rohrsen (Weser)
Alternative_Name: Rohrsen; Roschem; Roschum; Rotsem; Roszem; Rossem; Rorhsem
Settlement_Description: The settlement consisted of 3-5 households in the 15th and 16th century.

Name: Rohrsener Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Hameln, first mentioned in 1385.

Toll_Description: A bridge fee is mentioned in 1400 and 1548. In 1582, an additional toll is established.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Leine is first mentioned in 1062.

Name: Lobith
Alternative_Name: Lobedhe; Lobedde; Lobede; Lobeth; Lobedde, Lobedde; Loebede; Lobet
Toll_Description: This toll for sailing transport was owned by the Duchy of Guelders. In 1307, a new toll house was built a bit more to the west, because of changes in the course of the Rhine. In 1479, the toll became property of Cleves (Kleve). Toll administration 1306 - 1459 (1550) is preserved in Gelders Archief, 0001 Graven en hertogen van Gelre, graven van Zutphen and 0012 Gelderse Rekenkamer. Until at least 1556 (Map Jacob van Deventer), the toll of Lobith was at the bifurcation of the River Rhine into Waal and (Neder-)Rijn. But already in 1540, it was concluded that the bifurcation moved more south to the place where from 1586 on the Schenkenschans divided the Rhine into the two branches. After 1473, the levying of the toll was temporarily moved by Karel van Gelre to Arnhem (Rhine), Nijmegen (Waal) and IJsseloord (IJssel). Willem van Kleef annulated this, but from 1543 on this Grote Gelderse Tol was levied for every of the three branches of the Rhine in: Arnhem (Rhine), Nijmegen (Waal) and IJsseloord (IJssel).
Ferry_Description: This ferry, known as the 'Tolhuisveer' ('Toll house ferry'), is first mentioned in 1394. From at least the fifteenth century onward, the ferry had three owners: half of it was owned by the Chapter of Elten, a quarter by the lords of Grondstein, and a quarter by the lords of Bergh. Around 1660, the ferry was impeded by the 'Gelderse Rekenkamer', after which it ceased to exist after a couple of years.

Harbour_Description: The harbour on the Este river in Buxtehude was in connection with Hamburg and Wedel an important transshipment point for the crossing of the Elbe river on the road between Flanders and Lübeck and for the transport of oxen between Denmark and the Low Countries.

Name: Bad Bevensen
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 1162, but possibly originated in the Lombard period and seems to have been an important trading place before it lost its significance to Lüneburg and Uelzen around 1200. The settlement was usually referred to as borough ('wicbeld').

Harbour_Description: In the 16th century, there existed a skippers' guild in Winsen, which was obliged to keep the Luhe navigable.

The Ilmenau river was occasionally used as a transport route upstream from Lüneburg, mainly for the shipping of firewood for the Lüneburg saltworks. The Ilmenau privilege of 1348 granted Lüneburg the right to make the Ilmenau navigable between Lüneburg and Uelzen; the section between Medingen and Uelzen was given up in 1562.

Name: Leszno
Alternative_Name: Lissa; Polnisch Lissa; Lissa in Posen

Name: Lengefelder Warte
Settlement_Description: Erected around 1360, this watchtower controlled the Northwest of Mühlhausen, controlling the passage through the Mühlhäuser Landgraben.

Harbour_Description: Although the river harbour of Kassel was located on the Schlagd in the old town, the towns maps of Michael Müller from 1547 and of Merian from 1646 show a loading place for river barges at the eastern shore of the Fulda just outside of the walls of the new town.

Toll_Description: In order to pay for the construction of a new bridge in 1346, a bridge toll was introduced for many commodities. The toll also had to be paid by wagons crossing the river at the ford.
Bridge_Description: A wooden bridge across the Fulda existed since the building of the new town on the eastern shore of the Fulda, which was first mentioned in 1283. In 1346, it was complained that the bridge was in a bad state, probably as a result of flooding in 1342, and had to be renewed. Next to the bridge, there also existed a ford at the time. The new bridge was a wooden construction on stone pillars, which was replaced with a massive stone bridge by Landgrave Philipp in 1509-1512, and finally demolished around 1790, with a new bridge constructed on a different site.

Toll_Description: Collection of the gate- and road toll can be derived from the instructions of the guards in the bills of the chamberlain in 1407 and 1409.

Name: Wangersen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1105. According to a register from Bremervörde from ca. 1500, the settlement consisted of five farms.

Toll_Description: The town acquired the right to levy a bridge toll in 1571: for pedestrians one Pfennig, for a horseback rider one Verden Schwar, for a pig or a sheep one Pfennig, and for a wagon one Witten.
Bridge_Description: Verden took its name from a ford or a ferry across the Aller river. However, from 1220 a bridge is attested as well. On a view of the town by Merian from 1653, we can see that this was a summer bridge, which could be partly deconstructed to protect the structure from flood and ice in winter. At these times, the bridge was replaced by a ferry.

Name: Stintbrücke
Toll_Description: The Stint toll was called after the place where it was levied, the bridge Stintbrücke across the Balge. This toll of the archbishop was leased to Bremen citizen Johann Uppenhus in 1346. In 1371 it was sold to the inn of St George ('St. Jürgengasthaus') and the hospital of St Rembert.

Name: Thüsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1223. The settlement burned down in 1635 and was only rebuilt in 1652.

Name: Dinaburgas pils
Settlement_Description: Castle of the Livonian order, destroyed by the Russians in 1577, who founded a new town 20km downstream (modern Daugavpils).

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Weser in Rinteln is first mentioned in 1223.

Name: Vehlen
Alternative_Name: Velden; Velde; Veldent; Velderen; Veldhen; Vhelden; Velthem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1055-1080.

Name: Sülbeck (Schaumburg)
Alternative_Name: Sülbeck; Sullethe; Sulbike; Sulbicke; Sulbeke; Szulbeke; Sulbecke; Sülpke
Settlement_Description: A first mention as "Sullethe" in 1055-1085 might refer to another settlement. First mentioned as "Sulbike" in 1153-1170.

Name: Pötritz
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in a document from 1363. It is deserted around 1500 but later in 1664 an inn is founded in the same place.

Toll_Description: From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.
Harbour_Description: Mention of a St. Nicolas-church which was demolished in 1775. It was supposed to belong to a fishing and boatmen-settlement near the Schönebecker Elbe-gate.

Bridge_Description: Bridge over the Eder in Fritzlar. The bridge was guarded by a watchtower.

Name: Barby
Settlement_Description: First mention in a gift certificate of the tithe of the Slavs in the castles Frohse, Calbe and Barby to the monastary of St. Mauritius in Magdeburg from Otto I 961 (MGH DD OI, nr. 222, S. 304.). The place's name may allude to an earlier, nordic settlement. In the 12th century a small territorial lordship is established with a castle (located at today's castle), which is in direct competition with the principality of Anhalt and the archbishopric of Magdeburg. The shire of Arnstein-Barby goes extinct in 1659.
Town_Description: 1407 a coucil is mentioned. The town had more of an impact through agriculture and brewing, less so than with the ferry over the Elbe.
Ferry_Description: A Elbe ferry is mentioned, doesn't seem to have any further meaning though.

Name: Rothenhaus
Settlement_Description: The "route house" Rothenhaus was constructed by Duke Franz II of Lauenburg as toll station in 1609.

Name: Palmschleuse
Bridge_Description: In 1613, a bridge over the Delvenau was constructed, because the previous ford had been too problematic to cross.

Name: Neumühle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1482.

Name: Belsen
Alternative_Name: Bellensen; Bellenszen; Bellenhusen; Bellenzen; Belssen; Belletzen; Bellessen; Bolsenn; Belsingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1235.

Name: Neuekrug
Settlement_Description: The Neue Krug is first mentioned in 1745.

Name: Schenkenschanz
Toll_Description: This toll for sailing transport is the continuation of the toll of Esserden (before 1062) that moved to Schmithausen (1085) and then to Emmerich (1142). Ca. 1635 it moved to Fort 's Gravenweerd /Schenken-schans.Through the years the tollhouse was located at at least two spots. Because the toll was levied at the bifurcation of the river Rhine into the branches Nederrijn and Waal, the registers of this toll are the best source to get an idea of total Dutch-German trade and transport on the Rhine in 17th and 18th century. From 1800-1803 the levying of the toll took place in Arnhem and Nijmegen. Toll administration 1635 (1630) - 1810 is preserved in Utrechts Archief, 221 Kapittel van Sint Marie te Utrecht inv.no. 1630 - 1712 f.e. 1666-1666 (registers)

Name: Badenhauser Landwehr
Settlement_Description: Crossing of the border ('landwehr') between Osterode and Staufenburg, first mentioned in 1438. In 1536, a watchtower and boom barrier are mentioned here; a house for the guard at the barrier was built in 1579.

Name: Alte Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Osterode, built in the 14th century. The remains were rediscovered in 1965.

Toll_Description: With the staple privilege of Stade from 1259, a cargo toll was introduced for commodities on ships that passed the town, as well as a "Ruderzoll", measured by the size of the ship. This led to conflicts with Hamburg, which was exempted from the toll in 1340, as well as Lübeck, Bremen and Lüneburg. In case that circumstances prohibited anchoring of the ship in the mouth of the Schwinge, the toll could also be paid at the archepiscopal toll collector in Hamburg. The cargo toll was cancelled in 1862, the "Ruderzoll" already in 1844.

Harbour_Description: Because of the bad condition of the roads, transport in East Frisia up to Apen often took place over the water, especially in winter.
Harbour at the Elbe river. In the 16th century, passing ships were often forced to unload their cargo and to bring it to the Lüneburg staple market.

Toll_Description: The toll in Boizenburg had to be paid by ships on the Elbe river as well as the Schaale canal from 1564. Because Boizenburg was not located directly on those rivers, a toll station must have existed in the vicinity of the ferry. For further details, see Boizenburg.

Ferry_Description: At times when the bridge could not be used and after its destruction in 1622, a ferry was in service.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Weser in Petershagen is first mentioned in 1407. It is shown as a wooden bridge on an engraving of Merian from 1645; this was a summer bridge, which could be partially deconstructed in winter to protect the construction from damage by floods and ice. Nevertheless, the bridge was destroyed by floods and rebuilt in 1565 and 1596. After a renewed destruction in 1622, the bridge was not rebuilt. This means that the bridge that Merian depicted did not exist at that time anymore.
Harbour_Description: Skippers from Petershagen regularly appear in the toll register of Rinteln.

Name: Goldener Pflug
Settlement_Description: Inn, first mentioned 1791.

Name: Friedberger Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Frankfurt, built in 1476.

Name: Reichmannsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1418.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conducht ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Gräfenthal (1728).

Name: Hjørring
Settlement_Description: Place name known from the 12th century. In the middle of the 12th century the Danish king Svend Grathe (1146-1157) produced coins in Hjørring, which by then was a settlement with some level of urban activity. The settlement belonged to the crown.
Town_Description: Hjørring was listed as a town in King Valdemars Cadastre about 1231. In 1243 Hjørring was granted town privileges by the Danish king Erik Plovpenning (1241-1250), and hereby became the first official town in the region of Vendsyssel. In 1408 a mayor and citizens were mentioned.

Name: Angeren
Alternative_Name: Angrina; Angram; Angerhem; Angheren; Angere; Angerem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the beginning of the ninth century in a copy dated between 1170 and 1175. Mentioned as 'apud Angram' at the end of the eleventh century.
Toll_Description: The toll for sailing transport is mentioned for the first time in 1074 and for the last time in 1226. After 1226, it moved to Huissen, where ownership of the toll changed to the Count of Cleves.

Name: Ribbeck
Settlement_Description: First mention of the name in 1282, first mention of the settlement in 1335.

Name: Findenwirunshier
Alternative_Name: Neu Kaliß; Mühle 'Finden wir uns hier'; Findenwirunshier Mühle

Name: Fährkrug
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1721 as a ferry inn, in the 19th century a secondary toll station of Werben.

Name: Voorde
Settlement_Description: The settlement was named after a ford in the Eider river.

Name: Sarau
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1197.

Name: Steinfelderhude
Settlement_Description: Inn, first mentioned in 1650.

Name: Fleischgaffel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1327.

Name: Keller
Alternative_Name: Imkeller; Lindhorst; Lindthorst; Eddiksee; Edicksehe; Meddeck ßee; Medicsehe; Meddicksee; Meddickseh
Settlement_Description: In the 14th century, a fortification was constructed on the border between Schauenburg and Dithmarschen, which became known as (M)eddiksee, after a nearby lake. In the second half of the 16th century, the Rantzau family built the manor Lindhorst here, a dependency of the castle Hanerau. The manor was demolished between 1614 and 1620. Since 1642, the settlement is known as Keller.
Toll_Description: The toll of Hanerau, which was levied since the middle of the 15th century, was also levied at Lindhorst (Keller).

Name: Bad Münder
Alternative_Name: Bad Münder am Deister; Munere; Mundere; Mündere; Munder; Munimeri; Munnere; Munderen
Settlement_Description: Settlement first mentioned between 856 and 869.
Town_Description: Raised to a market town in an early stage; civic court and council present in the first half of the 13th century. Mentioned as "oppidum" in 1260 and "civitas" in 1302.

Name: Sæby
Settlement_Description: Around 1400 Sæby seems to have been a relatively small fishing village located at a river mount on the Eastern coast of Vendsyssel. The settlement belonged to the bishop of Børglum.
Town_Description: Sæby developed into a town during the 15th century. In the 1460ties a Carmelite abbey was established and in the same decade a mayor and a town bailiff (Danish: byfoged) also appeared in textual sources. A town hall, which was placed at the town square west of the parish church, is mentioned in 1597. The oldest known town privileges were given by king Frederik 1. in 1524. The year after the town was granted a town law by bishop Stygge Krumpen of Børglum. The close relationship between the town and the dioceses of Børglum is reflected in the alternative name of the town “Mariested” (Mary's Place) until the Reformation in 1536.
Harbour_Description: From the late medieval period onwards Sæby functioned as a harbour in Eastern Vendsyssel as a small river, Sæby Å, mouth was the only natural harbour between Skagen and Limfjorden. The harbour was plagued by storms, currents and high tides as well as ice during winter. This ment repairs were often needed. The king financed harbour repairs multiple times during the 1500s.

Name: Skagen
Settlement_Description: Founded before 1300 on the top of the peninsula of Jutland as a fishing community. A hard and changing climate prevented a coherent structure of the settlement and later also the town.
Town_Description: Skagen was given town privileges in 1413 by king Erik the Pomeranian. In 1460 a mayor of Skagen appeared in the sources for the first time. King Hans of Denmark granted the first town law in 1507. In the 15th and 16th centuries Skagen was a relatively dynamic but also unusual town, as it was scattered and there were no streets and no town square. The permanent settlement appears to have been concentrated in two areas, modern day Skagen and Højen (modern day Gl. Skagen).
Toll_Description: The royal toll appears in sources from the 15th century onwards. A toll station is mentioned in 1514. The royal customs officer in Skagen was responsible for a lighthouse built in 1560. From the 15th century onwards the royal toll of Skagen was one of the most important in Jutland.
Harbour_Description: The character of the medieval harbour is unknown. But the harbour was important, especially for the trade with Norway. In 1327, for example, Skagen was mentioned as part of the route to either England or Norway from Poland. The harbour was used by Hanseatic ships, for example from Lübeck in 1399.

Ferry_Description: The ferry is replaced by a wooden bridge in 1422.
Bridge_Description: Since 1422 the ferry across the larger, Eastern river branch is replaced by a wooden bridge.

Name: Børglum
Settlement_Description: An important royal manor in the viking age and a Premonstratensian abbey and the diocese of Børglum or Vendsyssel in the middle ages. It is uncertain when the abbey and later the diocese was established. The abbey is probably from around 1200, perhaps some decades earlier, and prior to 1220 the bishopric of Vendsyssel was also placed in Børglum. Throughout the Middle Ages, Børglum was a religious, political and economical center in Northern Jutland.
Fair_Description: A annual fair was held at Børglum in the middle of June.

Name: Nibe
Settlement_Description: In the 13th century and the early 14th century Nibe was a fishing village with a certain level of trading activity, which benefited from rich fishing banks in Limfjorden. Herring from Nibe was imported and sold in Hanseatic towns. Nibe was a royal settlement, and the king granted Nibe certain trading rights, which normally belonged to towns. Hereby Nibe was in opposition to the town of Aalborg a bit further west. In 1536 Nibe was described as a town. In 1545 Nibe was granted the right to a law (Danish: Birkeret) and a bailiff (Danish: foged). In 1570 Aalborg resisted Nibe’s desire to have permanent craftsmen living. This was however granted in 1587. The ongoing conflict with Aalborg is probably the reason why Nibe was not officially granted town privileges before the 18th century.

Toll_Description: In 1650, Salzwedel was allowed to take a bridge- and dam toll from shipments of grain in order to maintain the bridges and dams. The rising trade with lumber and working stones made the bridges and dams fall into disrepair, so it was allowed that the council collected the bridge and dam toll from such wares as well.
Harbour_Description: The river Jeetze connected Salzwedel with the Elbe and Hamburg, and shipping on the river was significant for the economic development of the town. It is first mentioned in 1248.

Name: Hovsør
Settlement_Description: Hovsør is first mentioned in 1374, but probably an older fishing village.
Town_Description: A borough around 1530, probably in 1532. This year the king promised tax exemption for a period of five years to Hovsør as well as freedom from toll in Denmark, expect for the Scania Market. Hovsør hereby appears to have been considered as a town, but in 1542 the privileges were lost. Hovsør benefited from rich fishing banks in Limfjorden, but also the export of oxen was important.
Harbour_Description: The character of the medieval harbour is not known. Probably a natural harbour within the bay. During the 15th and 16th century some people moved from the neighboring town of Thisted to Hovsør because of the harbour.

Name: Alt Wallmoden
Alternative_Name: Wallmode; Walmonthem; Walmontheim; Walmoden; Walmeden; Walmodhe; Antiquo Walmede; Olden Walmode; Walmde Antiquum; Alten Wallmoden; Altenwalm; Alten Walm
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 941. There existed a farm of bishop Meinwerk of Paderborn. A noble family of Wallmoden is first mentioned in 1154; around 1500 the place is mentioned as castle in the diocese of Hildesheim. In the 14th century, the addition "Alt" ('old') appears, to discern the settlement from the castle Neuwallmoden.

Bridge_Description: Mentioned as stone bridge (pons lapidus) in 1161.

Name: Klietznick
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as belonging to the castle district of Jerichow.
Toll_Description: Mention in the context of the negotiations of the tolls of Kietznick, Jerichow and Sandau on the diet of princes in 1480-1490.

Name: Weetzen
Alternative_Name: Wetzenedhe; Wetzcende; Wettesen; Wetsende; Wecce; Wetessen; Wetse; Wetzende; Weczende; Wetscende; Wetzen; Wetzenne; Wessende; Wetzem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1269.

Harbour_Description: Important harbour for salt from the local saltworks

Lock_Description: The weir for the water mill contained a passage for ships. Ships built in Wanfried could pass this downstream without problems, upstream however with great difficulty. A drawing of the passage from 1610 is kept in the Hessian State Archive in Marburg, 4 a Nr. 39/54.

Name: Sooden
Alternative_Name: Bad Sooden-Allendorf; Sothen; Sothe; Soden; Westera; Westren; Westrun; Westra; Westari
Settlement_Description: The salt deposits in Sooden were already mentioned in the 8th century under the name "Westera". The name Sooden ist known from 1093 onwards. The village was united with Allendorf in 1929.

Name: Jever
Alternative_Name: Gefri; Givers; Gevere; Geffer; Jeverden; Jevesanda; Gevesand; Geferen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1011 and 1062. Originally possibly a fishing settlement of the Chauki, in the 10th or 11th century fortified with earthworks. In 1039 mentioned as mint of the House of Billung.
Town_Description: Jever was already mentioned as 'oppidum' in 1347 and had a seal. In 1536, the town was re-founded and fortified. The oldest town rights date from 1572.
Fair_Description: Around 1350, Jever is already mentioned as a market settlement. In the following period, its importance must have declined, as the fairs on the old market place are first mentioned again in 1535. In the town rights of 1572, fairs are mentioned on eleven Tuesdays each year and import tolls for these fairs are set. Next to these, there existed two horse fairs and fairs on Carnival and Christmas. In 1602, three additional horse fairs were added. Exact dates are only known from 1729.

Name: Esens
Settlement_Description: A church was probably built around 1100, but the settlement is first mentioned only in 1300.
Town_Description: Town rights were probably granted between 1537 and 1540.
Fair_Description: The markets of Esens were provided with safe-conduct in 1440. In the description of Harlingerland by Balthasar Arends, the dates are specified on 14 days after Pentecost and St Bartholomew (called Magnus's fair). In 1572, a third fair was granted and in 1610 another four fairs. However, these disappeared again after a while.

Name: Wittmund
Settlement_Description: A missionary church is mentioned in 884, which was demolished in 1164.
Town_Description: In 1567, the market settlement received town rights from the Countess Agnes von Rietberg, which it lost again in the 17th century.
Fair_Description: Market regulations for Wittmund are first known from 1607. Later, the most important markets are defined as the fairs of St John and Our Lady.

Name: Dreileben
Settlement_Description: Mention in 996 in the properties that are given to St. Moritz' monastery in Magdeburg by Otto I. Since 1304 center of a small jurisdiction.
Toll_Description: In the course of the 16th century, the toll stations in Oebisfelde, Neuhaldensleben, Wolmirstedt, Dreileben, Wanzleben and Calbe complain that their income was reduced due to the toll exemption of Magdeburg.

Name: Blumenthal (Elbe)
Harbour_Description: The town of Burg establishes a harbour ('Schifsstätte') here, from which the citizens of Magdeburg violently force a ship to Magdeburg in order to scare boatmen of coming ashore in Burg in 1632.

Name: Uslar
Alternative_Name: Husleri; Huslere; Uslaria; Uslir; Uslere; Huslaria; Usler; Uszler; Ueslar; Üslär
Settlement_Description: Possibly already settled in prehistoric times. First mentioned as village in 1006-1007. It became a borough ('flecken') in the early 13th century.
Town_Description: First mentioned as "civitas" in 1269. The Göttingen town privileges were granted at an unknown date; reiterated in 1345.

Name: Hardegsen
Alternative_Name: Herdegessen; Herdessen; Hardegsenn; Hardegedissen; Hiridechessun; Herdeghessen
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned between 1015 and 1036. In 1310, a castle is mentioned.
Town_Description: Town rights were allegedly granted by Duke Otto I the Evil of Brunswick-Lüneburg in 1383, although a charter is not known. Already two years before, Hardegsen is characterised as town. Burgomaster and town council are mentioned in 1409.
Toll_Description: A toll in Hardegsen is first mentioned in 1559.
Fair_Description: A charter of the baker's guild from 1390 mentions two fairs in Hardegsen, on Sunday before the Ascension of Our Lady and Sunday before St Martin. On these days, bakers from other towns were allowed to offer their produce for sale in Hardegsen.

Toll_Description: Records from 1441 and 1515 show that traffic from Langensalza and Mühlhausen was forced to use the Andreas gate.

With Erfurt's economically weakened position to Leipzig, the forced usage of certain roads is raised. According to the "Verzeichnis der Knechte und Tore", deliveries of salt had to be brought via the toll in Sachsenburg and Herbsleben to the Johannis gate in Erfurt.
Roads lead to the Löber-gate, from where there were to roads with safe conduct to Coburg.

Name: Krummesser Baum
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the Lübeck enclosure ('landwehr'), which was completed around 1300. It existed of a tower with three floors, a palisade, a boom barrier, and an inn. The tower was still existing in 1785.

Toll_Description: The toll on the Weser in Dörverden is first mentioned in the 1360s. In 1575, it is confirmed that Dörverden belongs to the Bishopric of Verden, although the toll is owned by the Count of Hoya. However, the toll is not mentioned in lists of Weser tolls from 1584 and 1597.
The toll in Nienburg is mentioned in 1390 and 1563, in a Bremen complaint from 1584 and in a charter of the monastery Hardehausen from 1597. It was leased out in 1574 for 1000 Joachimsthaler.

Harbour_Description: Although the road was the main artery for Höxter's trade, skippers from Höxter were active in transport on the Weser, as can be seen from the toll accounts of Rinteln.
Vlotho developed into an important skippers' town on the Weser in the 17th century. Harbour structures were however first built in the 18th century.

Name: Ry
Alternative_Name: Rye; Rythe; Gammel Ry; Gl. Ry

Name: Groß Nenndorf
Alternative_Name: Bad Nenndorf; Niendorf; Nenthorp; Groten Nendorpe; Groten Neyndorpe; Grotennendorpe; Grossentorpe; Grotenneudorppe; Groten Negendorpe; Groten Nendorphe
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned as a property of the monastery of Fulda in the 10th century. It consisted of two parts: Groß and Klein Nenndorf, of which the former was first separately mentioned in 1374. Both settlements were united into Bad Nenndorf in modern times.

Name: Hohenwarthe
Settlement_Description: Between 1309 and 1314 archbishop Burchardt III. founded a castle in Hohenwarthe and extraced toll on the Elbe, which led to the citizens of Magdeburg attacking and destroying the castle.
Toll_Description: Between 1309 and 1314 archbishop Burchardt III. founded a castle in Hohenwarthe and extraced toll on the Elbe, which led to the citizens of Magdeburg attacking and destroying the castle. In 1391 a toll on the Elbe in Neuhof, near Hohenwarthe, is mentioned. It is unclear whether this is still the same toll.

Name: Altona
Alternative_Name: Hamburg-Altona; Altena, Altenah, Altonah, Altonahe, Altenawe, Altonavia; Altonahe; Altenah
Settlement_Description: The settlement probably originated in the early 16th century as a fishermen's and craftsmen's settlement. The inn Altona was first mentioned in 1537. The settlement became a borough ('flecken') in 1604.

Name: Dockenhuden
Settlement_Description: Farming village, merged with Blankenese in 1919

Name: Neundorf (Anhalt)
Toll_Description: The toll from Warmsdorf is moved to Neundorf in 1496. In 1537 the toll is moved again to Bernburg.

Ferry_Description: Already at the first mention of Wedel in 1212, a ferry is mentioned. It became an important crossing point for oxen from Denmark on the river Elbe. The transport of oxen through Wedel is attested from the mid-15th century. The shipping took place in the flood plain near the manor Haseldorf, to which the ferry belonged, at the current Fährmannssand. Around 1500, the owner of Haseldorf received 6 shilling for every 20 ferried oxen. The remaining revenues were belonged to the count of Schauenburg, who deployed 7-8 barges here in the 16th century. However, often the ferry in Zollenspieker was preferred by the oxen traders, due to high hay prices in Wedel and Blankenese and frequent complaints about the ill-treatment of the oxen by the Wedel ferrymen.

Harbour_Description: Connections with Bremen can be attested from the 13th century onwards. The existence of the "Hamelner Loch" upstream could have stimulated the shipping from Oldendorf.

Ferry_Description: Crossing of the Old Street across the Saale
Bridge_Description: In the 14th to 15th century crossing the Saale was possible via a bridge. In 1456 the council of Zerbst supports the construction of a bridge at Calbe at the request of the archbishop of Magdeburg.
Lock_Description: In the middle of the 12th century the mill weir in Calbe was dammed up and could be used as a lock for a fee.

Name: Kloster Gröningen
Settlement_Description: Endowed by count Siegfried in 936. The monastary was run by monks from Corvey. Gröningen monastary belonged to Corvey monastary until the 17th century, even if the monastery proper was dissolved in 1550.

Name: Engerhafe
Settlement_Description: Engerhafe was mentioned in the 1300 law of the region Brokmerland as 'wic', a settlement with special legal protection during market times. The village church dates from the 13th century.

Name: Uphusen (Emden)
Settlement_Description: The village is first mentioned in 1325, but its church dates from the second half of the 13th century.

Name: Riepe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Westerende Kirchloog
Settlement_Description: This place was first mentioned in 1408.

Name: Brockzetel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1497.

Name: Rispel
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1475.
Toll_Description: According to a 1640 complaint from Emden merchants visiting the fairs in Jever, the count of East Frisia had started to levy a toll on commodities in Rispel during the eleven market times in Jever about three years earlier. In 1648, renewed complaints attest that the fees had been raised and the toll was now also levied on cattle.

Name: Friedeburg
Alternative_Name: Fredeborch; Endel; Endell; Friedeburgh; Fridenburgk; Vredeberch; Vredenborg
Settlement_Description: Castle of the chieftain Fredo, later of the counts of East Frisia, which was built in 1359 and demolished in 1763. The attached settlement was originally called Endel.
Toll_Description: A transit toll was introduced by countess Theda of East Frisia at the Friedeburg in 1480; the inhabitants of Dornum were exempted from toll payments. A list of toll fees for various transported commodities from 1637 still exists.

Name: Marx
Settlement_Description: The village church, dedicated to St Mark, dates from the 13th century.

Name: Neuenburg
Settlement_Description: Castle, erected in 1462 by Count Gerd of Oldenburg to control the road to East Frisia.
Toll_Description: A toll station of the county of Oldenburg was installed in Neuenburg in 1613.

Name: Bockhorn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1220, and developed into a market borough in the 14th century.

Name: Dringenburg
Settlement_Description: The settlement is preceded by a castle built in the first half of the 14th century. It was built by Count Konrad I of Oldenburg as a defence against the Frisians.

Name: Wiefelstede
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 1059 and has the oldest Romanic church of Ammerland.

Name: Sandhorst
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 822 and 872. Former summer residence of the Counts of East Frisia.

Name: Hoym
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a record by Otto I. in 961, in which the villa Hoym (Hahem) ist confirmed as the property of Quedlinburg monastary (MGH DD OI nr. 228, S. 312f.). First mention of Castle Hoym in 1301, which guards the crossing of the trade road from Braunschweig to Leipzig over the Selke.
Town_Description: In 1543, the place receives full town rights by duke Wolfgang of Anhalt.
Toll_Description: There's no mention of a road toll in pawn records, even though the village was pawned several times. However, it can be assumed that there had to be some kind of toll, especially at the Selke crossing.

Name: Cappel
Alternative_Name: Kappel; Capella; Capelle; Capellis; Kapellensis; Cappelen; Nortcapele; Nortcappele; Kappela; Kappele; Capel
Settlement_Description: The Premonstrensian nunnery Cappel was founded in 1139 at the latest by counts Bernhard and Hermann zur Lippe. It was turned into a protestant ladies' house in the 16th century.

Name: Brockenstedter Mühle
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in a record in 937. During the Late Middle ages the settlement is abandoned, while the village's mill still runs until the 1970s.
Toll_Description: In 1657 the toll station of the district of Mahndorf is supposed to be moved here.

Name: Nordborg
Settlement_Description: Around 1150 the Danish king Svend Grathe build a castle on a small peninsula in Nordborg lake. In the following century a settlement with an urban character developed around the castle. The settlement was known as “Købing” until the 17th century, when both the castle and the settlement was called Nordborg. The name reflects, how the settlement is located on the northern part of the island of Als. Traders and craftsmen lived in the settlement, but Nordborg was not given official trading privileges before 1680.

Bridge_Description: A stone bridge across the Saale is constructed by the city council ("High Bridge" or "Klaustorbridge"), in order to connect to western trade. It lay slightly more to the south of today's bridge and was demolished in 1840 and replaced by the more modern Elisabethbrücke.

Toll_Description: The council of Halle had a toll gate on the Magdeburg road. In 1499 an escort ('Geleitsmann') is attested at the Steintor.
A regulation of safe conduct from 1563 settles the bridge and road toll.
Bridge_Description: In 1239 the usage and the custom-free passage of a bridge in Bernburg (not localized) is settled (Codex Diplomaticus Anhaltinus II, Nr. 145).

Name: Hesel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Bagband
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1454, although the village church dates from the middle of the 13th century.

Name: Aurich-Oldendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1431, but the village church dates from the middle of the 13th century.

Name: Filsum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 10th century.

Name: Booneschans
Alternative_Name: Booner Schans; Booner schans; Boner Schans; Boonerschans; Boonenschans; Bonerschans
Settlement_Description: Small fortress ('schans') on the border between Groningen and East Frisia. There is unclarity about the date of its construction: 1587 according to some authors, but more likely is a construction around 1593, at the same time as Oudeschans and Bourtange.

Name: Winschoterhogebrug
Settlement_Description: A fortress ('schans') was constructed near the bridge across the Pekel-Aa around 1625.
Bridge_Description: The fortress was constructed near the high (=fixed) bridge across the Pekel-Aa. It is unknown how old it was.

Name: Ditfurt
Settlement_Description: Former Saxon stronghold above the Bode ford. To the South, a Karolingian royal residence was established.
Toll_Description: Quedlinburg monastery profits from the toll at the Bode crossing in its village of Ditfurt.

Bridge_Description: Bridge built in the 12th century which connected the Old City of Quedlinburg with its territories in the East. Made the detour via Ditfurt unnecessary.

Name: Dötlingen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1203.

Name: Donnerschleuse
Alternative_Name: Niedern Schleuse; Niederschleuse; Tonnerschleuse; nye nedder stausluze
Lock_Description: The new Niederschleuse was constructed around 1451 (the old Niederschleuse was located near Anker). The lock was later known as Donnerschleuse, after multiple generations of lock keepers from the Donner family in the 17th century. A second lock, the lower Donnerschleuse, was built 200m downstream in the 18th century. Between both locks, the ford on the street between Hamburg and Lübeck was located.

Name: Andisleben
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Breviarium Sancti Lulli Tab. III. Seat of the nobles of Andisleben.

Name: Görmar
Settlement_Description: First mention in 897.

Toll_Description:
Until about 1810 Arnhem was the location for some tolls:

    The first toll for sailing transport is the Great Guelders toll of Arnhem. It is the continuation of the Lobith toll after this toll was deprived for the Guelders duke and became Clevish in 1473. In or after 1492 the Duke of Guelders founded a new toll station in Arnhem. In combination with the tolls of Nijmegen, Tiel, Zaltbommel, IJsseloord and Zutphen and the tolls on river Meuse, these were the Great Guelders tolls. Toll administration 1543 - 1567, 1574-75, 1586-1604, 1617/18, 1623/24, 1626/28,1636/40, 1655/63, 1663/79, 1688/90 and 1739/41 is preserved in Gelders Archief, 0012 Gelderse Rekenkamer. Toll administration 1801- 1810 is preserved in: Gelders Archief, 0016 Gewestelijke besturen in de Bataafs-Franse tijd.
    The second toll for sailing transport is the Anholt toll, "Anholtse tol". It was situated in Arnhem from 1618. This toll was the result of the temporarily removal of the toll of the Duchy of Guelders from Lobith to IJsseloord in the war time between 1372 -1379. 1384 the Duke of Guelders recieved permission from the Holy roman emperor to levy this toll in addition to the one of Lobith permanently. The toll moved temporarily for a short while to Huissen. In 1434 Duke Arnold gave the toll over in pledge (and in 1472 in property) to his brother Willem van Egmond, reason that the name was during many years Arnoldian or Egmondian toll. From 1561 the toll was owned by the Lord of Anholt, so it became the name Anholt toll. In 1816 the toll was transferred to the Kingdom of the Netherlands. Because the toll house at IJsseloord was permanently threatened by the river, from 1618 the levying of the toll took place from the tower above the guardhouse near the Sabelspoort bridge in the town of Arnhem. Toll administration (registers from 1688 - 1756) is preserved in Fürstlich Salm-Salmsche Archiv (FSSA), Schloss Anholt, Anholt, Germany, In: Archiv Arnheimer Zoll: III Zollrechnungen und Zollbücher, Tolregisters van de ontvangers van de Arnheimer Zoll, inv.nrs. 31, 36-40, 43-59.
    The Market toll, 'Merckttol'', this toll for sailing transport was founded before 1249, the year is was levied for the Hospital of St. John. In 1782 is noted that the market toll was levied three times a year for a period of 21 days. the fist time from 11/12 March, the second time the 7th September and the third time the 10th November. The toll was collected then in combination with the Anholt toll.
Harbour_Description: In front of the gate named 'Sabelspoort', a jetty is visible on the map printed by Joan Blaeu in 1649. Blaeu's map is based on a map drawn ten years earlier by Nicolaas van Geelkercken.

Name: Huissen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 850-865, in a copy dated between 1170-1175.
Toll_Description: 1) The Count of Kleve levied a river toll on the Rhine here in 1242. In 1405, approx. 0.92 guilders ('Gulden') had to be paid for each foder of wine, then 1 guilder ('Gulden') per foder of wine in 1486. The annual yield was 1208½ schild in 1419, 980 schild in 1420 and 1398 schild in 1421. For other annual revenues see source. 2) The Count of Kleve also levied a land toll in 1312, which was loaned until 1418. Originally, the land toll referred to grain, which was brought to the market in Arnhem. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Holten (Overijssel)
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1237.

Toll_Description: Toll collection point at the church of St. Aegidien for the usage of the road or bridge.
Bridge_Description: Krämer-bridge, today the bridge with the longest house-façade in Europe. Used to connect the palatine district with the Wenigermarkt on either sides of the Gera.

Name: Altengottern
Settlement_Description: In 802/17 one of the villages of Gottern is referred to as 'in Thuringia' and mentioned as the property of a count Erpfol. In 997, Altengottern is referred to as a part of the 'Natergau' (MGH DO III 251). Since the end of the 10th century, the prefix "Alten-" is used for this part of the village on the left bank of the Unstrut.
Toll_Description: More precise mention of the toll point in Gottern by Quad (1602).

Name: Herbsleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in the record book of Fulda monastery. Even though the village is referred to as 'town' several times during the 16th century, it was never actually granted town rights and by the end of the century is only called borogh ('Flecken').
Toll_Description:
In 1375 the castle and its corresponding belongings, except the safe conduct are pawned off. In 1424 an escort ('Geleitsmann') is mentioned. Toll station at an important Unstrut-crossing. In 1545 renewal of the requirement that wagoners who go to Herbsleben, Weißensee and continue on and who arrive via the forest, have to go via Erfurt.
Regulations of safe conduct ('Geleitsordnung') and a table of fees ('Geleitstafel') remain from 1554.
Fair_Description: On 15th June 1331 emperor Ludwig grants permission to hold a fair and a weekly market in Herbsleben.

Harbour_Description: After the Schuitendiep canal had been extended to Zuidbroek, the first ship from Groningen arrived here in 1628. In the 1630s, the canal was extended to Winschoten. Regular barge ('trekschuit') services were offered in 1654 at the latest.

Name: Bredstedt
Alternative_Name: Bredsted; Bräist; Brethæstath; Breest; Breste; Brestede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1231, but archaeological finds indicate that the settlement is much older. The settlement developed into a borough ('flecken') and received market privileges in 1530.

Harbour_Description: After the construction of a weir in the Ems in Rheine in 1550, the river became navigable until Greven, where cargo was transshipped onto the land route to Münster.

Name: Tilleda
Settlement_Description: First mention in the register of property of Hersfeld monastery where it is mentioned as a gift from Charlemagne. In 972 the ottonian imperial court ('Kaiserpfalz') is mentioned there. The court is gradually abandoned around 1200, the residents settle down in the village at the foot of the plateau. Following nobles resided within the village.

Name: Soerel
Settlement_Description: According to seventeenth century maps, there was one farm in Soerel. This farm served as an inn, possibly at least from 1418 onwards. It was located on the intersection of two roads: the 'Amersfoortse Weg' between Zwolle and Amersfoort, and the 'Arnhemseweg' between Arnhem and Elburg. The map of the Veluwe by De Man from ca. 1810 shows an additional post house. From 1634 onwards, postillions made use of the land route between the inns 'De Zwarte Boer' and 'Het Soerel'.

Name: Miłakowo
Settlement_Description: The place has first been mentioned in 1314, the castle of the Teutonic Order was first mentioned in 1354, but has to be older than that
Town_Description: First called a town in 1323, the first handfast with Kulm town law was burned and thus replaced in 1490 by Grand Master Hans von Tieffen

Name: Nakskov
Town_Description: Nakskov is listed as an established town in King Valdemar’s Cadastre in a text within the manuscript originally written around 1240. In 1266 a royal privilege was given to the villani (Danish: bymænd) in Nakskov. In 1274 king Erik 5 of Denmark the same town laws and privileges as the town of Næstved and other towns on the island of Sealand. The privileges were confirmed and extended in 1288, 1293 and 1320. A town council is mentioned for the first time in 1351. The town benefited from a rich agricultural hinterland and fishing, and dynamic trade with towns around the western Baltic Sea, especially Lübeck.

Name: Bad Frankenhausen
Settlement_Description: First mention before 900 as a Frankish settlement. Mention in a record by Otto III. (MGH DO III 305). Throughout the medieval ages exploitation of salt salines around the place, starting from 1074.
Town_Description: Mention as a town in 1282.

Name: Artern
Settlement_Description: Mention in the Breviarii Sancti Lulli, tab. I from the last third of the 8th century: In 776 the Wigiberti chapter owns property in Artern.
Town_Description: Granted town rights around 1346 by Ludwig the Bavarian. 1430 civitas; 'Königstuhl' (place of trial) north of the city.

Name: Memleben
Alternative_Name: Mimelebo; Immunleba; Mimilebo; Mimeleve; Imenlevo; Miminlevo
Settlement_Description: Mention in list A of the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis. Popular residency of the early Saxonian kings, dying place of Henry I in 936. In between 976 and 979 foundation of a Benedictine monastery with market-, toll- and coinage rights. In 1015 all privileges and gifts were revoked and Memleben monastery was put under the jurisdiction of Hersfeld monastary. The monastery's history ends in the 16th century during the Peasant's war, when it is looted and in consequence given to the Fürstenschule in Pforta.

Name: Rødby
Settlement_Description: Rødby was probably established as a village during the Viking Age, c. 800-1050.

Name: Almrich
Settlement_Description: First written mention in a border description of Pforte monastery. A description of a castle from 1010 probably refers to Altenburg.

Name: Ollendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the Codex Eberhardi of the imperial abbey Fulda, between 822 and 842. At the end of the Middle Ages it served as an important crossing of roads and held several instances of traffic infrastructure, such as an inn, a wagoner, a blacksmith and a toll house.
Toll_Description: The water castle held a secondary station of safe conduct at the end of the Middle Ages or even after.

Bridge_Description: In 1589 the wooden bridge across the Unstrut is renewed.

Toll_Description: Records of a toll on the Elsterbridge in 1152.
Bridge_Description: In 1535 the former wooden bridge (mentioned in the records in 1364) was converted to a stone bridge, which was demolished and rebuilt into today's bridge in 1886 century.

Name: Thüringer Pforte
Bridge_Description: The toll in Sachsenburg was paid north and south of the bridgehead.

Name: Roßleben
Settlement_Description:
First mention in the record book of Hersfeld monastery from 830 - 850. It was granted town rights only in 1999.
In 1140 an Augustinian monastery was founded and gained some meaning during the middle ages, it was converted into a convent of Cistercian nuns before 1263 until it slowly declined in the 16th century. The remaining monastery buildings were destroyed during a fire in 1686.

Name: Eigenrieder Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower to the West of Mühlhausen, controlling the passage through the Mühlhäuser Landgraben, erected in the 14th century.

Name: Sollstedter Warte
Settlement_Description: Established during the construction of the Mühlhäuser Landgraben.

Name: Horsmarer Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower, established during the construction of the Mühlhäuser Landgraben.

Name: Wietzendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1231, when Wietzendorf became its own parish. According to a 1438 register, there were 20 farms in the village.

Name: Ohrdruf
Settlement_Description: Foundation of a monastery in 725. Mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis.
Town_Description: Mention of the settlement as town (on the sigil). Elevated to town by the counts of Gleichen, town in 1399, marketplace in 1375.

Name: Bad Bibra
Settlement_Description: Early demesne in the 8th/9th century. Mention in the Breviarium Sancti Lulli as Bibaraho. A castle is proven to exist since the 14th century at the latest. In 1486 market-, toll-, safe conduct- and fortification rights are granted to the lords of Bibra.

Name: Bienstädter Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower north of Erfurt.

Name: Wartenberg/Niederzimmern
Settlement_Description: Watchtower East of Erfurt.

Name: Nödaer Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower north of Erfurt.

Name: Wartberg/Windischholzhausen
Settlement_Description: Watchtower Southeast of Erfurt.

Name: Lexkesveer
Alternative_Name: den veer tot lexkenshuys; Leexken aen 't veerstat; Leksensveer
Toll_Description: The Market toll "Markt- or Mercktol" or "Springtol" of Lexkesveer, a toll for sailing transport was levied every year from July 25th (St. Jacob) during 21 days by the toll employee from the Great Gueldres toll in Arnhem. The origin of this toll is not quite clear. Probably, it is the continuation of tolls near the Medieval ferriage or ferry of Lexkes where toll was levied for the Wageningen market tolls. About 1450 and about 1500 these tolls are documented in two 'Tolboucxkens' in which the tarifs of a lot of Rhine tolls are noted. The first period the toll was levied from 14 days before until 14 days after St Johns day, Midsummer. The second period the toll was levied from 10 days before St Jacobs day until 10 days after. In 1538 a part of the income of this tolls was donated by Duke Willem van Gulik to the town of Wageningen. In 1782 only the second period is still mentioned. Toll registers of this toll are saved in Gelders Archief, 0012 Gelderse Rekenkamer for the years 1739-1774, 1790, 1793 and 0016 Gewestelijke besturen in de Bataafs-Franse tijd for the years 1794 - 1797.
Ferry_Description: A ferry across the Rijn is first mentioned in 1426.

Bridge_Description: In the early and high middle ages the only fortified corssing across the Werra in between Vacha and Kreuzberg.

Name: Rengelröder Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower west of Heiligenstadt, controlling traffic in the Leine valley.

Bridge_Description: Crossing can be proven since 1186, it was situated further to the West than the current bridge (under the mouth of the Oechse). In 1346 a stone bridge was constructed, after a wooden bridge was carried away by floods.

Name: Poitzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the first half of the 15th century. An earlier mention as Pochedissen from 1252 is uncertain.

Name: Trauen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of the diocese of Verden of ca. 1252.

Name: Offen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1336.

Name: Pattensen (Winsen)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1197.

Name: Toppenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of the diocese of Verden of ca. 1252.

Name: Garlstorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1192.

Name: Sahrendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a tithe register of Verden from ca. 1252. In 1275, the settlement consisted of 4 farms and a cottage. In the late 15th century, the village was deserted and resettled by the monastery of St Michael in Lüneburg.

Name: Hanstedt I
Alternative_Name: Hanstedt; Haanstedihusun; Hanstede; Honstede; Honsted; Honstete; Hantstede; Hansted uppe de smalen owe; Hanstede uppe der Swinouwe; Hanstede uppe der Swynouwe; Hanstede prope Swynouwe; Hanstede uppe der Swinawe
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in the register of possessions of the monastery of Corvey between 822 and 876. It was also called Hansted on the Schwienau ('Hanstede uppe der Swynouwe') to discern it from other Hanstedts in the region.

Name: Oberohe
Settlement_Description: The settlement Ohe is first mentioned in 1450; the part Oberohe ('upper Ohe') in 1668.

Name: Brockhöfe
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1321.

Name: Wettenbostel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252.

Name: Tellmer
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in 866.

Name: Thamsbrück
Settlement_Description: The name of the settlement already occurs in the 8th/9th century, which leads to believe there has been a former settlement. It was either deserted before the foundation of the town or was assimilated into the new town. The town's immediate predecessor would have been Thamsbrück castle in the late 13th century.
Town_Description: Around 1193 landgrave Herman I. of Thuringia grants Thamsbrück market- and town rights. In the late 13th century, a town council is well-proven (it consisted mostly of knights).

Name: Bollstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention around 750 in the record book of Fulda monastery.

Name: Katze
Settlement_Description: In the Early Middle Ages probably already a Crossroads for traffic at the Saale river.

Toll_Description: At the Coburger Gate, the fee for safe conduct and tolls for wagons, cattle and people with wheelbarrows or carriers had to be paid.

Name: Mālpils
Settlement_Description: A castle was first mentioned in 1413. It was probably built in 1386.

Name: Irmelsberg (Crock)
Settlement_Description: St. Veit's church on the Irmelsberg has been a popular destination of pilgrimage since the early medieval ages. Construction of a late Gothic church in 1489.

Name: Engenstein
Settlement_Description: Castle which controlled the "High Road" in the Thuringian Forest since the 14th century. End of the area of horse-hitching-services ('Vorspanndienst') from Eisfeld. Location of one of the oldest heritage inns within the department of Eisfeld (surviving date on the building: 1587).

Toll_Description: end of the Coburg safe conduct according to the Coburg charter of safe conduct ('Coburger Geleitstafel') from 1492.

Name: Köppelsdorf
Settlement_Description: Foundation at the road of safe conduct from Nuremberg to Saalfeld ('Sattelpassstraße'), first Thuringian vertical mining place ('Saigerhütte).

Name: Untersuhl
Settlement_Description: Former watchtower that controlled the Werra crossing. In 1615 the village church is built inside.

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Sieg river is first mentioned in 1343.

Name: Laeva
Settlement_Description: Manor and village were mentioned in 1295, a hamlet ('Hof') in 1645.

Name: Lõimetsa
Settlement_Description: The Manor and the belonging hamlet ('Hof') were mentioned in 1583.

Name: Anna
Settlement_Description: The oldest church in whose proximity the village settled can be dated to the 17th century.

Name: Ojaküla
Settlement_Description: The village was mentioned in 1586.

Name: Toolse
Settlement_Description: The Teutonic Order built a castle ('Vredeborch') here in 1471 to protect the harbour against pirates.

Name: Piltene
Alternative_Name: Pilten; Vense; Venetis; Pylthena; Pilta; Pylthene
Settlement_Description: The castle was first mentioned in 1309. In 1329, a fortified borough ('Hakelwerk') was built.
Town_Description: Piltene received town rights by Riga in the 15th century.

Name: Køge
Town_Description: Køge was founded on the marsh north from Køge å. It was still a new settlement when Erik Menved in 1288 gave tax-excemption to build on uninhabited parcels in Køge town. The settlement was structured around Nørregade/Brogade, which runs almost north-south and crosses the stream with a bridge, and Vestergade which leads vest into the country. The settlement was carefully planned in a grid pattern.
Fair_Description: On Zealand it was decreed in 1516 by Christian, that only 4 years markets was alloved, from Roskilde, Slangerup, Ringsted and Køge.
Harbour_Description: The first harbour was placed inside the semi circle rampart surrounding the earliest settlement, near the street Fænnediget just before the bridge across the stream. In the late middle ages it was moved to where the stream enters from the sea, due to bigger ships and sand filling up the stream.

Name: Oberschleuse
Lock_Description: The (little) Oberschleuse ('upper lock') between the Mölln lake and the Stecknitz river was also known as Erichschleuse, probably after Duke Erich I (1296-1361) of Lauenburg. It is first mentioned in 1336 and therefore the oldest of the three locks in the Stecknitz. A second lock, the "large" Oberschleuse, located ca. 420m from this one, the year of construction is unknown, but it was reconstructed in 1614.

Name: Zienburger Schleuse
Alternative_Name: Ziehnburger Schleuse; Siedenburger Schleuse; Göttiner Schleuse

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Stecknitz near Krummesse is first mentioned in 1469; it was repaired in 1614. During reconstructions of the road from 1650, the bridge was temporarily replaced by a ferry. A bridge is attested again in 1655.

Name: Hohenstiege
Settlement_Description: A brick kiln was founded in 1597 and disappeared in 1807. Moreoever, an inn is mentioned at this place, belonging to the manor Padelügge.

Name: Kuhmühlenbrücke
Alternative_Name: molendinum domini Hartwici; molendini vaccarum; Komolen; Kuhe Mühle; Kuhmühle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1247 as "the mill of lord Hartwic", which was known as the Kuhmühle from the middle of the 15th century.
Bridge_Description: In relation to the mill mentioned in 1247, a "new bridge" across the Eilbeck is mentioned as well. Before there was a ford here. The Eilbeck also formed part of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Hamburg.

Name: Georgenthal
Settlement_Description: Foundation of a monastary on the hight of the Georgenberg, in between 1160 and 1190 it is moved to the valley instead. During the Peasant's war the convent flees to Gotha and the monastary is used as a quarry. In 1531 the monastarial belongings are given to the administration ('Kammer') and a sovereign department is formed.
Toll_Description: In 1637 the safe conduct from Tambach is moved to the village of Georgenthal.

Name: Tambach-Dietharz
Settlement_Description: Mention of the settlement of Dietharz in 1246. The roads that joined in Tambach and Dietharz were controlled by several castles, whose exact location are not verified in all cases. Evidence of markets in the year 1500. In 1919 Tambach and Dietharz are merged into one town.
Toll_Description:
Important station of safe conduct on the way between Erfurt ans Schmalkalden. A table of safe conduct ('Geleitstafel') shows the fees due. (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Bb 171, Capitalrechnung der Ämter zu Thüringen, Vogtland und Franken 1535/36.)
In 1637 the safe conduct of Tambach is moved to Georgenthal.

Name: Nesselhof
Settlement_Description: Foundation of the hospital Nesselhof by the Lazarite Gottfried Walldorf.

Name: Osterberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1251.

Toll_Description: A bridge toll is introduced in 1588. The first two years, the revenues were used to cover the construction costs of the bridge; afterwards, half of the toll was paid to the duke of Saxony-Lauenburg, the other half was used for maintenance of the bridge. Toll tariffs are known from 1592 and 1627.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Ratzeburg lake is already mentioned in connection to the castle in documents from the 13th century. This was a narrow bridge for pedestrians; wagons with cargo had to go around the lake or be carried across with ships. In 1588-91, a new wider bridge was constructed, which allowed two horse-drawn wagons to pass each other. The bridge was replaced by a stone causeway in 1847.

Name: Schmalkalden
Settlement_Description: The settlement of Smalacalta is given to Fulda monastery in 874.
Town_Description: First mention as a town in 1227, however one can assume it to have been a town earlier already. Mentioned as civitas in 1272, in 1335 the town rights of Gelnhausen are granted by count Berthold VII. The sovereign interests were represented by the sheriff, of which one was appointed by Henneberg and one by Hessia since 1396.
Toll_Description: The toll registry of Schmalkalden remains from 1489 (ThStA Meiningen, III A, 14).

Name: Hammbrücke
Bridge_Description: The bridge across the Schmalfelder Au is first mentioned in 1650.
The bridge across the Krückau in Elmshorn was first mentioned in 1386.
The stone bridge and causeway at the mill in Schwartau are mentioned in 1475 and were mended on various occasions in the 17th century.

Name: Großenbroderfähre
Ferry_Description: Ferry to Fehmarn, first mentioned in 1361.

Name: Herrenfähre
Ferry_Description: A ferry owned by the count of Holstein was first mentioned in 1190; it could be acquired by Lübeck temporarily in 1247, and definitively in 1329.

Name: Wijk bij Duurstede
Alternative_Name: Wijk; villa, quondam Doresteti nunc autem UUik nominata; nostra villa dicta Wijc; Wycke bi Duersteden; Wiic bi Duersteden; Duyerstede ende onse stadt van Wijck; Wyck, off Duerstede; Wijck tot Duerstede; Wyk te Duurstede; Dorestad; Dorestate; Dorestati; Dorestates; Duristate; Dorestadum; Dorstado
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a eleventh-century copy from a document from 948. Settlement history in this region goes back to Roman times, however. Romans built a 'castellum' (fort) in the region. In the Caroligian era an international trade hub, called Dorestad, was located in the area. An enormous amount of archeological evidence from the Dorestad period has been found. Dorestad was first mentioned on paper in 695 and dissappeared from the map in the ninth century (after 843). In 948 a 'villa' is indicated as having been known as 'Dorestad' but now being called 'Wijk'.
Town_Description: Wijk bij Duurstede was granted town privileges on 12 March 1300 by Gijsbrecht II, lord of Abcoude and Wijk.

Toll_Description: The Wijk bij Duurstede toll for sailing transport was the continuation of the toll of Rhenen. The Rhenen toll moved to Wijk bij Duurstede around 1470 on behalf of Bishop David of Burgundy. A long term conflict about the location of the toll resulted in a temporary displacement of the toll back to Rhenen from 1546-1557. But after the last year the toll definitely was levied in Wijk bij Duurstede. Toll administration (1623,1770-1799, 1800-1805) is preserved in Utrechts Archief, 37 Financiële instellingen van de landsheer en van de Staten van Utrecht en daarop volgende gewestelijke besturen, inv. no. 324, 1471-1501 and 2858-2865. And 218-1 Bisschoppen van Utrecht, inv.no. 10, fo. 235v-237. Tariff lists (1486, 1545) are published.

Name: Holbæk
Harbour_Description: Holbæk wharf was mentioned in 1328, it was made longer in 1582.

Name: Tårnborg
Town_Description: The castle Tårnborg was built in the 1100 by Valdemar The Great, in order to protect the crossing across Storebælt, and to earn a toll for this. Southeast of the castle a town grew forth, which was ended in 1425 when Eric of Pommern ordered Tårnborg demolished. Tårnborg was prosperous from 12-1300, and thousands of coins found near the castle as well as tax markers in lead from Skåne market tell us of vibrant trading. The trading stopped around 1399, where custom lists from Lübeck show Korsør instead of Tårnborg. The reason for the change is most likely that the bigger ships of the time, couldn't sail into Korsør Nor.
Toll_Description: The castle Tårnborg was built in the 1100 by Valdemar The Great, in order to protect the crossing across Storebælt, and to earn a toll for this

Name: Hauröden
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1206.

Toll_Description: After the reconstriction of the bridge, the builder, knight Jürgen of Waldenfels is granted the former ferry fee as bridge toll in 1459. After 1575 the bridge toll is abolished and the maintenance of the bridge and dam had to be paid from the income of the regular horse- and walking fee ('Pferd- und Fußzoll').
Ferry_Description: After the destruction of the bridge in 1244, a ferry was used as replacement.
Bridge_Description: A crossing of the Havel existed since Slavic times. In 1244 the bridge near Plaue was destroyed during an attack of Magdeburg on Brandenburg and not reconstructed until 1459.

Toll_Description: Until 1529 one Bohemian heller was paid for a bushel of grain. The price was afterwards raised to one Bohemian penny. From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfried Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.
Ferry_Description: The Elbe ferry near Roßlau is mentioned in 1349. In 1407 the archbishop of Magdeburg has the mill, the bridge across the Mulde river and the ferry across the Elbe river destroyed.
Bridge_Description: In 1437 there was a first attempt to build a bridge, however, Zerbst refused to help with the build, which is why the ferry remained. Since 1583 the Elbe was spanned by a bridge near Roßlau. It was destroyed during the 30-year war in 1631 and only rebuilt in 1680.

Ferry_Description: Since 1362 the ferry across the Elbe can be proven, it would have existed before though. In 1447 the castle and town of Aken are pawned off including the toll and ferry. As the result of flooding, the Elbe couldn't be crossed at Aken in 1433.

Name: Magdeburger Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Helmstedt, built before 1252.

Name: Bad Sachsa
Alternative_Name: Sachsa; Saxahu; Sassa; Saxa; die Sachßa
Settlement_Description: The settlement came into being next to the castle Sachsenstein, which was destroyed in 1074. The settlement is first mentioned in 1219.
Town_Description: An exact year in which the settlement became a town is not known. It was mentioned as a borough ('flecken') in 1432; a first town seal is known from 1525.

Name: Bad Lauterberg
Alternative_Name: Bad Lauterberg im Harz; Lutterberg; Luterberch; Lutherberch; Lutterberge; Lutterberc; Luthirberg; Lutterinberc; Luterinberg; Lutherberck; Luterberche; Lutterberghe; Lutterbergk; Lautterberg; Lauterbergk; Lauterberg
Settlement_Description: The settlement acquired its name from a castle that is first mentioned in 1183. However, the settlement only developed in the second half of the 15th century with the growth of mining activities. Lauterberg acquired mining privileges ('bergfreiheit') in 1521, but never developed into a mining town ('bergstadt'). In the 17th century, it was a borough ('flecken') with various privileges.
Fair_Description: Lauterberg acquired the right to organise two fairs in 1619.

Name: Scharzfels
Settlement_Description: The castle Scharzfels was first mentioned in 1131 and belonged to the Dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg. It was destroyed by French troops in 1761.
Toll_Description: Below the Scharzfels castle, a toll was levied by the lords of Hohnstein. Citizens from Osterode were exempted from toll payments in 1465, and in 1521 all persons who worked in the Count's mines. The toll was discontinued in 1851. According to Herbst, there was also a toll station in the neighbouring village Scharzfeld, but he does not provide a source for this statement.
Bridge_Description: A bridge over the Oder existed presumably already in the 13th century.

Name: Riepenburg
Alternative_Name: Eslingen; Eislingen; Esslingen; Eyslinghe; Eßlingen; Eytzlinghe; Ribenborg; Rybenborch; Rybemborch; Ripenborch; Ribenborgh; Rybenborch; Rypenborch; Ribenborgh; Ripemborch; Riepenborg;
Settlement_Description: The toll station and the ferry of Eislingen were protected by the castle Riepenburg, which was consrtucted in the mid-13th century. Since 1455, it is also known as Zollenspieker after the toll station. Because of relocation of the mouth of the Ilmenau, Riepenburg castle was demolished in 1512; possibly, its stones were used for the construction of the new toll station.
Toll_Description: Toll on the Elbe river of the dukes of Lauenburg, first mentioned in Krauel in 1216; the toll station Eyslinghe is first mentioned in 1252, from 1455 it is also known as Zollenspieker. According to a list of toll fees from 1278, Lüneburg was partially exempted from toll payments. The toll was acquired by Hamburg and Lübeck in 1420, who did not acknowledge the privileges of Lüneburg. Subsequently, a project was started by Lüneburg to dig a canal between the Ilmenau and the Elbe near Laßrönne to circumvent the toll station, with limited success. The toll station was moved west in the 16th century after a relocation of the mouth of the Ilmenau river (see Zollenspieker).
Ferry_Description: A ferry at the toll station Eislingen to Stöckte is first mentioned in 1252. It was moved to Zollenspieker/Hoopte when the toll station was relocated in the 16th century.

Name: Stöckte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of the diocese of Verden from ca. 1252.
Ferry_Description: Ferry to Riepenburg that was first mentioned in 1252. In the 16th century it was moved to Hoopte / Zollenspieker due to the relocation of the Ilmenau estuary.

Name: Gronau (Leine)
Alternative_Name: Gronau; Emne; Emna; Emnam; Empna; Empne; Empne; Gronowe; Gronow; Grunouwe; Gronaw
Settlement_Description: Originally there existed a castle of the bishop of Hildesheim and a settlement (Empne) on the shore of the Leine, which was destroyed during a feud in 1279. The settlement was moved to a river island and reconstructed as the planned town Gronau, first mentioned as such in 1298.
Town_Description: In 1298, bishop Siegfried II of Hildesheim founded the new planned settlement Gronau. The settlement is characterised as town from the start. Its predecessor Empne had already been characterised as "civitas" around 1228.
Fair_Description: According to a 1593 register of the house of Gronau, a fair took place on Sunday Oculi. On this day, a toll was levied of one Goslar penny for all who bought commodities at the market, with the exception of nobles.

Name: Ilsenburg
Settlement_Description: A castle in Ilsenburg is given to the bishop of Halberstadt in 998, which is converted to a Benedictine monastery in 1003 and 1018. After its destruction during the peasant's war, the monastery is reconstructed and used as a residence by lords and officials.

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Rhume is already mentioned in 1260.
A contract between Nienburg monastery and the Ascanians proves the existence of a bridge across the Mulde as early as 1239. Around 1400 there was a firm bridge crossing the Mulde in Dessau.
Construction of a firm bridge across the Mulde in between Roßlau and Dessau. It was destroyed during the 30-year war in 1642 and only rebuilt in 1680.

Toll_Description: The toll guard was to collect toll at the Untertor in Worbis, as stated in the toll regulations of 1661.

Name: Lukaszoll
Toll_Description: According to 18th-century maps, the toll station in Vienenburg was located at the crossing of the "high street" between Harzburg and Vienenburg and the "old street" between Oker and Stapelburg. The toll privilege was granted in 1323 (see Vienenburg).

Name: Stapelburg
Settlement_Description: A castle was constructed in 1360 by the counts of Wernigerode as toll station and protection of the road above the former village of Wendelburgerode. In the 16th century a village developed underneath the castle.
Toll_Description: The castle was built as a toll station and for the safety of the road.

Name: Gohlis
Settlement_Description: First mention as Goluz in 1317.

Ferry_Description: The ferry was held by castle Schkopau

Name: Ammendorf
Settlement_Description: 1155 mention of the lords of Ammendorf, the existence of a lowland castle is known. In 1264 a Heinrich of Ammendorf endows a monastery in Ammendorf.
Bridge_Description: In the 30-year's war the toll bridge at Ammersdorf is destroyed and replaced by a wooden construction in 1653. In 1733 it is replaced again by a stone bridge that is preserved until today.

Name: Kleinsteinrade
Alternative_Name: Lutke Steinrad; Lutke Stenrade; Steinraderbaum; Steinraderhof
Settlement_Description: Manor at the enclosure ('landwehr') of Lübeck, which must have been founded around 1247. There existed a boom barrier to secure the border here.

Name: Stockelsdorfer Baum
Settlement_Description: Crossing of the enclosure ('landwehr') of Lübeck - completed around 1300 - with a boom barrier.

Name: Rade
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1320.
Lock_Description: A lock in the Alster river was constructed in 1527 as part of construction work for the Alster-Trave canal.

Name: Wohldorfer Schleuse
Toll_Description: A toll was levied by Hamburg, who had acquired Wohldorf in 1437, on wood floated down the Alster. The Hamburg town accounts (Kämmereirechnungen) register revenues from this toll from 1461 onwards.
Lock_Description: Lock in the Alster river, which was constructed in 1527 as part of the construction works for the Alster-Trave canal.

Harbour_Description: In 1618, the Lübeck council was informed, that travellers to Hamburg should use the waterway between Bergstedt and Poppenbüttel or Fuhlsbüttel because of closure of the Steindamm street.

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Trave river was first mentioned in 1188.

Harbour_Description: The Trave was navigable until Oldesloe, and the town was therefore an important transshipment point for the traffic between the North and the Baltic Sea.

Name: Roßbach
Settlement_Description: First mention in the records in 1256 with a knight of Roßbach.
