Ferry_Description: In 1300 the ferry is bought by Pforte monastery. It is mentioned again in 1303. In the description of safe conduct from 1736 the ferry near Roßbach is mentioned but it can be assumed it existed before. The escort from Freyburg stretched to the middle of the Saale river.
Bridge_Description: In the description of safe conduct from 1736 a small wooden bridge near the ferry at Roßbach is mentioned. It can be assumed it existed before.

Name: Buttstädt
Settlement_Description: Referred to as villa in 1067. Village and market place since 1199.
Town_Description: Referred to as town since 1331, in 1392 town rights of Weißensee were granted.
Fair_Description: The cattle fairs in Buttstädt count to the largest in middle Germany.

Name: Gerstenberg
Toll_Description: Station of safe conduct of Altenburg. The street to Naumburg led through there. Mainly crops were transported through here.

Name: Sömmerda
Settlement_Description: As property of Fulda monastery, Sömmerda probably already existed in the 9th century. It is mentioned in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis in 876. It is first mentioned in the records in 1268, when it is given as a fiefdom. The castle was destroyed in 1312, its location is unknown. Until the 15th century, Sömmerda is referred to as village.
Town_Description: In 1459 it is referred to as borough ('Flecken') and since then a market borough with a kind of town constitution. A town council is known for 1433, a first town hall was first built between 1529 and 1539.
Fair_Description: The first fair privilege for the fair on St. Michael's day was granted in 1546, further privileges followed in 1591, 1684 and 1778.

Name: Guthmannshausen
Settlement_Description: First mention in the Breviarium Sancti Lulli, Tab. II.
Toll_Description: Point of safe conduct from Erfurt. It lost significance duting the end of the 14th century and the beginning of the 15th century due to the Wettin separation ('Wettinische Teilung') in 1485, in which the department of Sachsenburg went to the Albertines. In the aftermath, traffic could be forced on the road via Sachsenburg, thus neglecting Guthmannshausen and Vogelsberg.

Name: Harras
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1252. Seat of the family of Harras.
Toll_Description: After 1570, the toll in Harras is moved to Oberheldrungen.

Name: Nebra
Alternative_Name: Neveri; Nebrue; Neuiri; Nevereheim; Nebre; Nebraw
Settlement_Description: First mention in the records of Fulda monastery from before 900. Former Wendisch village, later carolingian royal court. Borough ('Marktflecken') in the 11th century.
Town_Description: 1254 town; First mention as "oppidanus" in 1351.
Toll_Description: One of the oldest secondary stations of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') for Freyburg.

Name: Reppel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 726, in a copy dating from circa 1222. Next mention in 855-856, in a copy dating from circa 1222. Next mention in thirteenth century.

Name: Weimar
Alternative_Name: Wehmare; Weihmari; Wimares; Wimeri; Wimar; Wymar
Settlement_Description: First mention of a count of Weimar in 975.
Town_Description: Foundation of the town around 1250 by the counts of Orlamünde. In 1254 first mention as civitas. In 1410 granted town rights of Weißensee.
Toll_Description: The safe conduct in Weimar was occasionally used to bypass the safe conduct in Erfurt, a registry shows the fees from 1580. The records of safe conduct suggest that Weimar was as important a station of safe conduct as Coburg (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. B 24444 (1573)).
Fair_Description: In 1456 the two three-day fairs were confirmed, so they had existed earlier. Three days before the fairs a cattle market took place. In 1729 a third fair was granted.

Name: Mihla
Settlement_Description: Old royal tenurial and part of the first properties of Hersfeld monastery. Construction of a Renaissance castle in the 16th century.
Toll_Description: Secondary safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of the station of safe conduct in Eisenach.
Ferry_Description: 1349/1350 mention of a ferry across the Werra.

Name: Schweina
Settlement_Description: First mention (of the brook Schweina?) in MGH DH I 35.
Toll_Description: Since the safe conduct in Eisnach was avoided by some by taking the route Vacha – Salzungen – Schweina – Waltershausen, a station of safe conduct was established in Schweina.

Name: Kloster Allendorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1272, monastery of Cistercian nuns. In 1525 secularization of the monastery, after the great fire of Salzungen in 1786 the monastery was used as a quarry.

Name: Witzelroda
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1259 in the register of Henneberg II N. 38.

Name: Hetlinger Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the enclosure ('landwehr') of the Neustadt in Osnabrück, which was constructed in 1406/09. The tower itself is mentioned in 1493.

Name: Brochterbeck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1150.

Name: Steinigerturm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower on the border between Osnabrück and Iburg

Bridge_Description: A bridge over the Wipperau was first mentioned in 1142, and a bridge toll was possibly levied here.

Name: Unterlauter
Toll_Description: Station of secondary safe conduct of Eisfeld, its importance is not clear. At least the fee for copper and lead had to be paid here (ThHStA W, Reg. Cc 1105).

Name: Osthausen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1271, it probably already existed in the 8th and 9th century.

Name: Alteburg
Settlement_Description: Probably bronze- to ironage hilltop settlement, not unlike a celtic oppidum.

Name: Wiegendorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 876.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle) of Weimar, which, deriving from the records of safe conduct, was frequented by long-distance trade. (regulation of safe conduct: ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Bb 171, Capitalrechnung der Ämter zu Thüringen, Vogtland und Franken 1535/36.)

Name: Burgau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1216; in 1486 the districts of Burgau and Jena are joined.
Toll_Description: The safe conduct in Burgau had some meaning due to wood transport. There's also a clear connection to the fairs in Leipzig and Naumburg. In Burgau, a toll on rafting on the Saale river was due, which benefitted both the district of Burgau and the district of Jena.
Bridge_Description: In 1544 the bridge in Burgau collapses and traffic is redirected via Camsdorf.

Name: Niederschleuse
Lock_Description: The Niederschleuse is one of three flash locks in the Stecknitz river that already existed before the construction of the Stecknitz-Delvenau canal from 1391. It is first mentioned in 1409. A new lock called Niederschleuse was constructed near Lankau in 1451, later known as Donnerschleuse.

Name: Thierschneck
Toll_Description: Lesser known station of safe conduct with an uncommonly high transfer of wares. Several conflicts between Ernestingian and Albertingian escorts are recorded. A registry of safe conduct ('Geleitstafel') from 1535/36 is preserved (ThHStA Weimar, Reg. Bb 171, Capitalrechnung der Ämter zu Thüringen, Vogtland und Franken 1535/36.).

Name: Leutenberg
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1187.
Town_Description: The town was probably founded in the 13th century by the lords of Schwarzburg, mention as town in 1326 (ThSTA Rudolstadt, A.C. 35). Almost exact adaptation of Saalfeld town rights in 1496.
Toll_Description: Toll station en route of Nürnberg and Leipzig via Saalfeld. It is known through a complaint of an escort from Lehesten, there are no further record on it.

Name: Lehesten
Settlement_Description: The hamlet was property of Saalfeld monastery.
Town_Description: In 1651 town rights were granted.
Toll_Description: Through a writ by an escort from Lehesten we know that transport form Leipzig to Nürnberg passed through. It may have been a station of explicit long-distnace safe-conduct. A list of fees ('Zolltafel') remains from 1579. In 1728 secondary station of safe conduct of Zella.

Harbour_Description: The Stör river was navigable until Itzehoe, which made the town an important transshipment point between river and sea trade (via the Elbe and the North Sea) and land transport.

Name: Hermsdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1256.

Name: Lentföhrden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1479.

Name: Trotz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1833 in August Schumann's "Vollständiges Staats-, Post- und Zeitungslexikon von Sachsen".

Name: Wilster
Settlement_Description: Settlement on the shore of the Wilsterau, where a church belonging to the Hamburg cathedral chapter is first mentioned in 1164.
Town_Description: Count Gerhard II of Holstein granted Lübeck town law in 1282. The town became a significant sea trade centre in the 16th century.

Name: Eutin
Alternative_Name: Utine; Uthine; Utin; Oytin; Oithin; Ewthin; Ewtyn; Euthin
Settlement_Description: Slavic fortification, where Hollanders settled after 1143. It became a market settlement and a residence of the bishop of Lübeck in 1156/57.
Town_Description: Lübeck town privileges were granted by Lübeck Bishop Johann II of Diest in 1257.

Name: Burg auf Fehmarn
Alternative_Name: Burghaeby; Borch; thor de Borch; Borg uppe Vemeren; Castro
Settlement_Description: Market settlement next to a castle. The church of St Nicholas was founded in the 13th century.
Town_Description: Lübeck town privileges granted in 1329.

Name: Garding
Alternative_Name: Getthing; Gerthing; Giaerthning; Gerdinghe; Gerdingen; Gardingk; Giæthningheret; Gardinge
Settlement_Description: The church was founded in 1109; the settlement was first mentioned in 1187.
Town_Description: Borough ('flecken') with market privileges in 1575, town privileges granted in 1590.

Name: Tönning
Alternative_Name: Tønning; Tunnighen; Tunnige; Thunnigheret; Thynnynghen; Tunnyngen; Tunning; Tonnigen
Settlement_Description: Originally a terp settlement, going back to Carolingian times or earlier, first mentioned in 1187 as central place of Eiderstedt. A church existed around this time as well.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted in 1590 by Duke Johann Adolf of Holstein-Gottorf.

Name: Glückstadt
Town_Description: Built as a planned town by the Danish King Christian IV as a stronghold and trade centre as competition for Hamburg. The 'Fundationsbrief' of 1617 granted Lübeck and Hamburg town privileges.
Staple_Description: The Danish king tried to establish Glückstadt as a staple for Icelandic products in competition with Hamburg. In 1623, a branch of the Copenhagen Icelandic trade company was established in the town, and in 1645, it was ordained that all Icelandic products had to be stored in Glückstadt first and sold there. Despite further limitations in the 17th and 18th centuries, the staple was often circumvented.

Name: Krempe
Alternative_Name: Crimpa; Crimpe; Crempe; Crimpen; Krempa; Krempen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1234, grew out of a settlement at the Krempau river.
Town_Description: Lübeck town privileges were granted in 1240-1250. They were confirmed by count Gerhard I in 1271.

Name: Lütjenburg
Alternative_Name: Liutchaburg; Laxo; Lutilinburg; Lutilenburg; Lutelenburg; Luttelinburg; Luttekenburg; Luttelenburg; Lutekenborgh; Luetekenborch; Lutkenborch
Settlement_Description: St Michael's Church was built around 1165. The older Slavic settlement Liucha / Lutilinburg was located nearby, but not directly related.
Town_Description: First mentioned as town in 1271. Lübeck town privileges were confirmed in 1275 by count Gerhard of Schauenburg.

Name: Pößneck
Settlement_Description: The oldest parts of the town are based on an earlier settlement.
Town_Description: Planned town foundation, since 1351 town rights of Saalfeld. Loss of those rights in 1525 due to the peasant's war, re-admission of the rights in 1527.
Toll_Description: Safe conduct in the district of Pößneck is handled under the same regulations as in the district of Saalfeld in 1728.
Fair_Description: Pößneck is granted fair privileges by King Ruprecht of Bohemia in 1409. In 1660, Pößneck is granted a Christmas fair.

Name: Roge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1312.

Name: Terlinden
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1545.

Name: Eckmannsdorf
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wittenberg in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig. Regulations of safe conduct remain from 1550.

Name: Mellnsdorf
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wittenberg in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig. Regulations of safe conduct remain from 1550.

Name: Bad Liebenwerda
Settlement_Description: In the course of the 11th century, a castle is built at the Elster river, around which the settlement develops in the course of the 12th century.
Town_Description: Referred to as civitas in 1304.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wettin in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig. Easternmost Ernestinian safe condct, situated far from any important trade roads.

Name: Langennaundorf
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wettin (Liebenwerda) in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig.

Name: Wahrenbrück
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wettin in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig.
Bridge_Description: A bridge in Wahrenbrück is mentioned in the records.

Name: Dobra
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wettin (Liebenwerda) in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig.

Name: Hohenleipisch
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Nebengeleit') of Wettin (Liebenwerda) in the system of safe conduct around Leipzig.

Name: Wöllmen
Settlement_Description: First mention of a manor in 1347
Toll_Description: Station of secondary safe conduct of Eilenburg.

Name: Funkenburg (Leipzig)
Settlement_Description: Funkenburg castle was destroyed in 1547.

Name: Staverden
Alternative_Name: Staveren; Stavera; Staveren; Staueren; Staver; Staefferden; Steveren
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'apud Staveren' in 1290. On 3 June 1291, Reginald I, duke of Guelders, is granted permission by King Rudolf I of Habsburg to found the town of 'Stavera'.
Town_Description: 25 March 1298, Reginald I, duke of Guelders, granted town privileges to Staverden. Staverden, however, never grew into an actual town, but remained a castle with several farms.

Name: Bredevoort
Alternative_Name: Breideruord; Brederuorht; Bredervorth; Bredervoert; Bredervoert; Bredevoert; Brevoort; Bredevoort; Breidervort
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1188. In the 13th century, Bredevoort is walled and has a moat.
Town_Description: In 1388, Bredevoort is named as a town ('stat'). Possibly, William of Jülich, duke of Guelders (1371-1402), has granted town privileges. Bredevoort is a town of the type 'Borgmannenstad': privileges were granted to the 'borgmannen' (D: Burgmanschaft).

Name: Gendt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 790-793.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted in 1233, by Otto II, count of Guelders and Zutphen.

Name: Batenburg
Alternative_Name: Battenburg; Batenburch; Batenborg; Batembork; Batinburg; Batenborch
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1076-1081, in a possibly falsified copy dating from the second half of the twelfth century.
Town_Description: The earliest mention of Batenburg as a town dates from 1349. By then, Batenburg has been granted toll, mintage, and weekly market rights. The earliest preserved privilege dates from 1389, and enables the installation of a 'schepenbank'.

Name: Culemborg
Alternative_Name: Kulenburg; Culenburgh; Kulenborch; Culenborgh; Colemborch; Culemborch
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention on 4 July 1281. The origin and development of Culemborg as a town-like place are being dated around 1300.
Town_Description: Town privileges granted to the burghers (‘poorters’) at Culemborg by Johan van Bosinchem, lord of Culemborg, on 6 December 1318.

Name: Asperen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 893 (in a copy from 1222).
Town_Description: Earliest mention as a town (‘die porte tot Asperen’) on 11 January 1314. It is presumed that Otto of Heukelum, lord of Asperen, had the town build around 1314, and granted town privileges. Asperen was being walled before 1377.

Name: Heukelum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention dates from 996 (copy from the second half of the twelfth century).
Town_Description: Descriptions as a town date from 1070 (‘stedeken’), 1329 (‘stadt’), and 1393 (‘poerte van Huekelem’). It is presumed that Heukelum has been granted town privileges by Otto, lord of Heukelum, before July 1393.

Name: Maasbommel
Alternative_Name: Bumele; Masebomel; Maeseboemel; Maesbomel; Maessboemel: Maes bommel; Maesbommel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1144.
Town_Description: On 15 August 1312, Reginald I, count of Guelders, confirms the town privileges of Maasbommel.

Harbour_Description: The Hoendiep canal was not directly connected with the other canals in Groningen. A mooring place for ships was located outside the Aa gate, as can be seen on old maps of the town.
Kellinghusen is mentioned as a harbour in 1260.

Toll_Description: King Christian IV of Denmark started to levy a toll from all passing ships on the Elbe in Glückstadt in 1630: for each mast 1 Rosenobel, from each Schiffspfund of the cargo 1 Thaler, and 1.5 percent of the entire value. After complaints of Hamburg, the toll was discontinued in 1645, although the Danish king tried to re-introduce it in 1675.

Name: Hittfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1004. A wooden predecessor of the current church might have been constructed in the 9th century.

Name: Marxen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1239.

Name: Helmstorf (Harburg)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of the diocese of Verden from ca. 1277-1295.

Name: Nindorf am Walde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1162.

Name: Wellsee
Settlement_Description: The village was first mentioned in the Kiel town register of 1264-1289, in an entry dated ca. 1275. The settlement took its name from the nearby lake.

Harbour_Description: Originally the harbour was located on the shore of the Eider river. In 1613, the harbour was enlarged and dug directly into the town.

As the only town on the Eider river until the foundation of Friedrichstadt, Rendsburg was an important transshipment point on the transit trade between the North and Baltic Sea. Especially the role of transit harbour for Eckernförde gained prominence in the 15th and 16th centuries. Moreover, Rendsburg was the central harbour for the export of wood from the regional forests. A fee had to paid for (un)loading the Eider barges at the quays. Around 1600, a causeway was constructed, which forced the transshipment of cargoes which were further transported on the Eider.

Name: Ameide
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1266.
Toll_Description: The history of this toll for sailing transport is rather unknown. In 1400 there is struggle against Lord Jan van Arkel who levies toll on river Lek in Ameide. We know some other details from the lawsuit between Utrecht and the Lord of Brederode that was finished in 1534. The Lord of Brederode claimed that his family owned the toll for more than 60 years before 1516. Verkerk mentiones the 'market toll' in 1784, it was also called 'silent toll'. The toll was levied from 18th of June to July 20th another souce says from 20th of June to July 20th.

Name: IJsselbrug
Toll_Description: Toll had to be paid to cross the bridge. A toll plate with tariffs from 1628 has been preserved in the Stedelijk Museum Kampen.
Bridge_Description: The town of Kampen built the a wooden bridge over the river IJssel in 1448. It was destroyed and rebuild several times. From 1598 onward, it became a pontoon bridge. In 1638, it changed to again to a bridge with a permanent cross-river connection.

Name: Ammerstol
Alternative_Name: Theloneo de Ambers; Theloneo suo de Ammers; Thelonio nostro Ambers; Ammers; tolne van Ammers; Ammers Tol; tolhuus tAmmers; Klein-Ammers
Settlement_Description: Ammerstol is first mentioned in a 1320 copy of a document from 1221.
Town_Description: Ammerstol was granted town rights on 16 May 1320. Economically, Ammerstol relied on the salmon fishery.
Toll_Description: This toll for sailing transport is first mentioned in 1221. It was owned by the Duke of Holland. The tollhouse was situated just opposite of the outlet of the river Ammers in the river Lek. In 1398, the Duke of Holland relocated the toll to the town of Schoonhoven which is situated about 4 km upstream. From 1397 onward Schoonhoven fell under his jurisdiction. In the previous years Schoonhoven had developed into a serious town and although Ammerstol received town rights, it stayed a rather small village. A tariff list written between 1355 and 1358 is published in Bronnen voor de economische geschiedenis van het Beneden-Maasgebied.

Name: Schönhagen
Settlement_Description: Schönhagen is mentioned in 1588 as a "new village, built only 18 years ago". This should probably be interpreted as a reconstruction of large parts of the village after a fire or other disaster, as the village is first mentioned in 1418.

Name: Beverungen
Alternative_Name: Beuerungen; Ovoronbeverungen; Beberuggen; Beverunge; Beueringen; Beveruggen; Beverungun
Settlement_Description: Beverungen is first mentioned between in a donation to the monastery of Corvey around the middle of the 9th century. Around 1330, the bishop of Paderborn erected a castle here.
Town_Description: A town and bridge were planned around the time that the castle was built, ca. 1330. However, town privileges were first granted in 1417, although the settlement was mostly referred to as borough ('wikbold') afterwards. The bridge was only built in 1902.

Harbour_Description: Together with Lauenförde on the opposite side of the Weser, Beverungen profited from its location on a river crossing, and became a transshipment point, especially for iron towards Bremen in the 16th and 17th centuries.

Toll_Description: Toll station at the castle of Lauenförde, which was moved here from Bodenfelde in 1534, because skippers increasingly transshipped their cargo on the land route in Herstelle.

Name: Küheturm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Northeim, built in 1442. The remains became part of the hotel Rücking.
Bridge_Description: The bridge over the Rhume in Northeim was constructed in 1285 as a joint enterprise by the town and the Benedictine monastery. In 1395, the bridge is mentioned as "pontem longum", and was reconstructed shortly before 1432. A cross was placed on the bridge in 1424, where donations for the maintenance of the bridge were collected. In 1568, the bridge was reconstructed in stone.

Name: Helmarshausen
Alternative_Name: Helmerateshusa; Helmwardeshusun; Helmundeshusen; Helmwordessen; Helwardeshusen; Helmwerzhusen; Helwarzhusen; Helmershausen
Settlement_Description: 944 mentioned for the first time in a deed of gift. At the end of the 10th century a Benedictine monastery was founded, at which a settlement developed. Shortly after its foundation, the abbey of Helmarshausen received market, mint and toll privileges. In the early 12th century, the settlement is characterised as 'oppidum'.
Town_Description: The settlement became a town in the first half of the 13th century, probably in competition with nearby Herstelle, which was owned by the bishop of Paderborn. Town privileges were confirmed in 1241 by the archbishop of Cologne.
Fair_Description: A fair at St. John the Baptist was established in 1223. In 1254 there were three fairs mentioned.

Ferry_Description: A ferry across the Weser near Lippoldsberg is first mentioned in 1409. Earlier, there existed a ferry near Bodenfelde, which was mentioned already in 1120 and was owned by the monastery of Helmarshausen.

Name: Lippoldsberg
Settlement_Description: The count of Northeim returned the fief of Lippoldsberg to the archbishop of Mainz in 1090 for the foundation of a monastery of Benedictine nuns.

Name: Haarbrück
Alternative_Name: Horbruche; Horebrucke; Horbruge; Hornbruge; Horebrughe; Horbrugen; Harbrukke; Harbrugge; Arbrocke; Horbrück; Häbrugh
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1253.

Name: Corvey
Settlement_Description: The Benedictine abbey of Corvey was founded on the place of a former Saxon manor in 822. It received imperial mint and toll privileges in 833 and a settlement developed south of it. Because the nearby town of Höxter developed rapidly and became ever more independent, the abbots tried to stimulate the monastery settlement as a competitor at the end of the 12th century. It was fortified and a bridge across the Weser was built in 1229. Regularly referred to as "civitas", there existed a civic court and a council. The town was destroyed by citizens from Höxter in 1265, last mentioned as "oppidum" in 1348 and must have been abandoned shortly after 1400. The monastery was destroyed in 1634, but rebuilt after the Thirty Years' War.

Bridge_Description: Since 1306 there seems to have been a wooden bridge at this Werra-crossing, which was damaged often and destroyed by a flood in 1496. From 1549-1551 a stone bridge was built, from which the keystone is still intact. In 1552 massive floods forced the re-construction of two of the vaults. In 1881 an iron bridge was constructed.

Name: Borgentreich
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1280 but previously grown together from older villages.
Town_Description: In 1283 and 1312 mentioned as 'civitas'. The town privileges got renewed in 1330.

Name: Bad Grund
Alternative_Name: Bad Grund (Harz); Fundo; Grunt; Grunde; Grundt; Bergstadt Grund
Settlement_Description: First mentioned on 26-9-1317 as forester's settlement of lumberjack Reinecke de Fundo. Later it became a miner's settlement.
Town_Description: Bad Grund acquired mining privileges ('bergfreiheit') in 1532, and a first town seal in 1535. A judge and council are mentioned in 1553. It owned the privileges of a miner's town ('freie bergstadt'), which were reiterated until the 18th century.

Name: Lautenthal
Alternative_Name: Lautenthal (Oberharz); Ludandal; Ludendal; Luttenthall; Lutendael; Lautentall; Lautendhal; Lautenthall
Settlement_Description: Mining activity in the valley of the Laute is first attested in 1330. After iron ore was discovered at the Kranichsberg in 1538, the miner's settlement Lautenthal developed.
Town_Description: Lautenthal presumable acquired mining privileges ('bergfreiheit') in the 1560s, as it is listed as a mining town ('bergstadt') in 1568. In 1613, the town privileges were extended.
Fair_Description: With the market privilege of 1613, a weekly market and a fair on St Simon and Jude were founded.

Name: Wildemann
Alternative_Name: Wildeman; Willdeman; Wildenman; Wildenmann; Willeman; Wilteman
Settlement_Description: After mining activity had taken place in the area around 1200 and declined afterwards, the old mine shafts were reopened in 1524 and 1529. Between 1529 and 1532, the area was probably settled.
Town_Description: A mining town was founded that received mining privileges ('bergfreiheit') and a council in 1534. The privileges were confirmed in 1550.

Name: Sankt Andreasberg
Alternative_Name: St. Andreasberg; Sanct Andrews berges; Sancti Andreas berge; Sanct Andreszberge; Andreas bergstadt; Sankt Annerschbarg
Settlement_Description: A first miner's settlement in this region existed in the late 13th century, but disappeared after the Black Death in the mid-14th century. In 1487, there are first indications of mining again, and the settlement acquired mining privileges ('bergfreiheit') in 1521.
Town_Description: Sankt Andreasberg acquired the privileges of a mining town ('bergstadt') in 1537.

Name: Altenau
Settlement_Description: Ironworks in Altenau are mentioned in 1298 and 1311. Increased activity in silver mining led to the development of a settlement in the late 16th century.
Town_Description: A judge and council are mentioned in 1594. The settlement acquired a seal in 1617, and received mining town ('bergstadt') privileges in 1636.

Name: Siebleben
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in the Breviarium Sancti Lulli, Tab. II

Name: Hausen
Settlement_Description: First mention in the record book of Mainz II 38.

Name: Tauhardt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1346.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Eckartsberga.

Name: Rohnstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in MGH DO II 201

Name: Schwerstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 780.

Name: Eldagsen
Alternative_Name: Eldaghessen; Eyldaghessen; Eildagensis; Eildagessen; Eildagissen; Eyldasen; Eldassen; Eyldagsen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned at the end of the 11th century. An often-cited earlier mention of 826-876 is a falsification and cannot be linked to Eldagsen on linguistic grounds.
Town_Description: Eldagsen was mentioned as 'civitas' around 1300, in 1302 as 'oppidum' and in 1320 as borough ('weichbild'). It received town privileges from the counts of Hallermund with permission of the dukes of Brunswick in 1355.

Name: Alferde
Alternative_Name: Alacfurdi; Alecfurde; Alecforde; Alcforde; Alecvordhe; Alforde; Alkvorde; Alferte
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1022.

Name: Hedemünden
Alternative_Name: Hademinni; Hedeminni; Hedeminne; Hedemunde; Heddemyn; Hedemunt; Hedemen; Hatheminne; Hedeminden; Hedemunde; Hedemynden; Heidemünde; Heidemunden; Heddemünden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as royal farm in a 1017 donation charter. The settlement is listed as borough ('flecken') in 1460 and 1493-1494.
Town_Description: The town privileges of Hedemünden were confirmed in 1645.

Bridge_Description: Homeien (Homeyen)-bridge; First mention in 1216, probably already in 1187.

Lock_Description: In 1232 the citizens of Spandau are allowed the construction of a flood channel ('Flutrinne'), which they could use without payment of a toll. In 1556 a chamber lock is built during the construction of the citadel.

Toll_Description: At places along the Havel and Spree in which locks had been constructed, a lock toll was collected for the maintenance of the locks. However, they were as high as other tolls which generated purely financial income.
Lock_Description: From 1548 to 50 a pound lock was erected at the Stone gate in Brandenburg. A re-construction of "ship traffic" ('Schiffahrt') and lock in Brandenburg is already mentioned in 1455, however, the nature of the constructions is unknown. They were probably connected to the staple in Brandenburg.

Name: Cölln (Berlin)
Settlement_Description: In the 13th century, increased trade seems to have increased the meaning of the settlements of Berlin and Cölln at the Spree crossing. There is no secure proof of a Slavic predecessor settlement.
Town_Description: The first written indication of Cölln is given in the mention of its provost in 1237. Since its first mention, Cölln can be seen as a town, it is referred to as civitas in 1261. The exact date of the awarding of town rights has not survived, as well as earlier mentions, which may have been destroyed during a town fire in 1380. In 1244, the provost of Berlin is first mentioned, who is also referred to as provost of Cölln in 1247, which may be seen as proof that both towns can be seen as twin towns at the time. Participation at the Hanseatic Diets 1359, 1430 and lastly 1443, in 1518 they were forced by their territorial lord to quit the alliance.

Name: Rodenberg
Alternative_Name: Rothenberge; Roenberg; Räonbare; Rodenberge; Rodenberghe; Redenberghen
Settlement_Description: A castle is mentioned around 930, which was located on the "alter Rodenberg" and belonged to the counts of Roden-Wunstorf. At the end of the 13th or beginning of the 14th century, Count Adolf of Holstein-Schaumburg erected a moated castle, next to which a settlement developed, that acquired borough ('flecken') privileges before 1375.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted in 1615 by Count Ernst of Schaumburg.
Fair_Description: In the town privileges of 1615, Rodenberg received the right to organise three fairs, on the days of St Philip and James, St James and All Saints.

Name: Lauenau
Alternative_Name: Lauwenauwe; Lawennawe; Lauenawe; Louwenaw; Lauwenow; Louenowe; Lawenaw; Lauenaw; Schwedesdorf; Sundesdorf; Sindesdorf; Suidesdorf; Svedhestorpe; Swedestorpe; Zuedesdorpe; Suedestorpe; Swydestorpe; Zwydestorpe; Swetingtorpe; Swedestorpp; Swederstorpe; Schwedertorpe; Schwedestorff
Settlement_Description: The village Schwedestorf is first mentioned in 973/1059. Next to it, the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg built the castle Lauenau, which is first mentioned in 1307. It was usually pawned to the counts of Schaumburg. The castle was destroyed in 1519, but rebuilt in 1568-72. The settlement next to the castle was first mentioned as borough ('bleck'/'flecken') in 1527. In 1575 it received borough privileges, which were renewed in 1649.

Name: Otterndorf
Settlement_Description: Around 1100, duke Lothar of Saxony is said to have raised the settlement, which probably existed before the 11th century, to a borough ('flecken'). A church is first mentioned around 1261. The settlement functioned as central market place for the Hadeln region.
Town_Description: The settlement acquired Stade town privileges around 1400, which were modified in 1541.
Fair_Description: Fairs in Otterndorf are already mentioned in the town privileges of 1541, but were probably older. They were specified in 1567 as two three-day fairs, which were held in the churchyard on 8 days before St Vitus and 8 days before St Michael. A cattle market was connected to the latter. In 1570, a horse fair on the Dispersion of the Apostles was added. The venue for the fairs was moved to the town hall, the current Marktstraße, in 1582.

Name: Brunkau
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned in 1238, but had been deserted for a long time by 1375. In 1538 the land was first used again for animal hubandry, an outlying estate ('Vorwerk') was established in 1544, and in 1608 a village is mentioned again.

Name: Freiburg (Elbe)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as castle of the bishop of Bremen in 1154. The moated castle was destroyed by Henry the Lion in 1177.
Town_Description: Archbishop Hildebold of Bremen granted the settlement town privileges in 1271.

Name: Neuhaus (Oste)
Alternative_Name: Neuhaus; Neuhaus an der Oste; Nigehus; Nyenhus
Settlement_Description: A castle built in 1404 by the archbishop of Bremen Otto von Braunschweig. It was destroyed in 1420, but rebuilt in 1435 by archbishop Balduin. The settlement developed into a borough ('flecken') by the 16th century.

Name: Geversdorf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1230. The church is first mentioned in 1233.

Name: Lamstedt
Settlement_Description: The parish of Lamstedt is first mentioned in 1115, but was much older.

Name: Ebersdorf (Saale)
Settlement_Description: The settlement was first mentioned in 1272.

Name: Kranenburg (Oste)
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1375.

Name: Cadenberge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1146/48. A church is first mentioned in 1337.
Fair_Description: Fairs in Cadenberge are first mentioned in 1448, but further details before the 18th century are not known.

Name: Belum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1230. The St Vitus church was probably built in the 14th century. However, the settlement seems to have existed since early Saxon times.

Name: Lehe
Settlement_Description: Settled by Frisians around 1000. In 1200 a stone church was built and the settlement developed into a market borough ('marktflecken').
Fair_Description: The Bremen council granted the right to hold two three-day fairs in Lehe in 1588, on Sunday Cantate and Sunday after St Bartholomew. In 1620, three fairs are mentioned, on Sunday after St George, Sunday after Trinity Sunday and Sunday before All Saints' Day.

Name: Stotel
Settlement_Description: Around 1220 a castle was constructed in Stotel; an older one was destroyed in 1213. It was seat of the counts of Stotel until ca. 1350.
Toll_Description: A toll of the archbishop of Bremen was pawned to the town Bremen in 1362. In 1365, citizens of Bremen were exempted from toll payments.

Name: Bad Bederkesa
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1159 in connection with the Lords of Bederkesa. Around 1200 a wooden castle was built and in 1287 the settlement was characterised as a borough ('flecken'). The settlement came into possession of Bremen in 1421,
Fair_Description: A fair for commodities and wood took place on Tuesday before St Michael. It is first attested in 1724, but probably it was granted around 1588, when the settlement belonged to Bremen, similar to the fairs in Lehe and Neuenkirchen.

Name: Ritzebüttel
Settlement_Description: The terp settlement Hardewiek existed already before the area was diked in the 11th century. Around 1300, the lords Lappe erected the castle Steenborg. It was conquered by Hamburg in 1393, as a means to control the mouth of the Elbe river. Ritzebüttel was merged with Cuxhaven in 1872.

Name: Altenbruch
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1280. The double-towered church of St. Nicholas was built in the 13th century.
Fair_Description: In 1632, the fair on Good Friday, which had been organised for some years, was moved to Thursday after Easter. In 1640, it was mentioned to have a duration of 14 days.

Name: Schnöggersburg
Settlement_Description: Founded in 1694 and named after the forester. In following years inn, forester's office and sheep farm until it was bought by the state in 1931 and integrated into a military training area.

Name: Midlum (Wursten)
Settlement_Description: The church of Midlum was built in the 12th and expanded in the 13th century. In 1219, a Benedictine nunnery was founded here, but moved to Altenwalde in 1282.

Name: Blumenthal (Bremen)
Alternative_Name: Blumenthal; Bremen-Blumenthal; Blomendal; Blomendale; Blomendall; Blomenthall
Settlement_Description: The knights of Oumund built the Blomendal castle in the 13th century, which was destroyed in 1305 and rebuilt at another location in 1354. The castle belonged to the town of Bremen since 1430.

Name: Neuenkirchen (Weser)
Settlement_Description: A new church was built around 1100, which gave the settlement its name. It is shown on a map of the 12th century; a priest is first mentioned in 1240.
Fair_Description: A fair on the second Sunday before St Michael's Day was granted in 1588.

Name: Schwanewede
Settlement_Description: A Borchardus de Svanewede is first mentioned in 1203. The family owned a castle in the village, which was destroyed in a feud with Bremen around 1300, but rebuilt later.

Name: Meyenburg
Settlement_Description: A moated castle was first mentioned in 1309. Next to it, a village developed.

Name: Elsfleth
Settlement_Description: The settlement is first mentioned as meeting place of representatives of the Bremen council and the Frisian land of Rüstringen in 1220 and 1291. A church was built in 1285 at the latest.
Toll_Description: Toll on the Weser river, which was levied by the Count of Oldenburg from 1623 onwards, initially in Brake. In 1624, the toll was moved to Elsfleth. The toll led to many conflicts between the County of Oldenburg and the town of Bremen.

Name: Klüden
Settlement_Description: First secure mention in 1472; earlier mentions might refer to Kläden.

Name: Blätz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1359, but the settlement was probably deserted after 1366. In 1562 it is used as an outlying agricultural and animal hubandry estate, a village only re-emerges in 1794.

Name: Montfort
Alternative_Name: Montem circumfossatum qui Miemekar nuncupator; Montfoirt; Monforth
Settlement_Description: Montfort is first mentioned in 1258. According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, it is not certain that this document refers to Montfort. The subsequent mention they register, dates from 1272. Montfort originated near a castle built around 1260.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted between 1277 and 1294 by Reginald I, count of Guelders. These rights were granted to stimulate the development of the town, but Montfort never fully developed into a town. In 1310, Montfort lost its town privileges, but these were re-granted in 1312. Montfort is last mentioned as a town in written sources in 1421. However, Jacob van Deventer drew a map of Montfort for his series of town maps in 1545. The castle of Montfort last served military purposes in the 1630s.
Fair_Description: In 1312, Reginald (Reinald) I, count of Guelders, granted a fair to Montfort. Most likely, however, this fair has never become effective.

Toll_Description: The Schoonhoven toll for sailing transport was relocated from Ammerstol to Schoonhoven in 1398. It was owned by the Duke of Holland. The Provisional Representantives of Holland decided to abolish the toll in 1795. Toll administration (1432-1433, 1478-1481, 1481-1483, 1483-1484, 1483-1484, 1484-1486, 1487, 1518) is published in Bronnen voor de economische geschiedenis van het Beneden-Maasgebied. Administration for later years (1770 - 1793) is preserved in the National Archives, 3.01.28 Rekenkamer ter Auditie en Opvolgende Colleges, inv. no. 5419 - 5434.

Name: Hulshorst
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1294/95. Archeological evidence suggests habitation from the eleventh/twelfth century onward. In the period 1350-1650, Hulshorst consisted of a scattered number of farms, mainly along the roads Oudeweg and Harderwijkerweg (former Bovenweg).

Harbour_Description: The Berkel was navigable up to Coesfeld until 1890

Name: Eibergen
Alternative_Name: Eiberghen; Ecberghe; Ecberghen; Hegberghe; Eyberghe; Eyberch
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1188, in a thirteenth century document. Another mention dates from 1246.

Harbour_Description: On the maps of Zutphen of Jacob van Deventer (mid-16th century) and from the Atlas van Loon (1649), a harbour crane is drawn next to the bridge on the IJssel river front.

Name: Brennersgrün
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1187.

Name: Rodacherbrunn
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1540.

Harbour_Description: The grain market of Arnhem was moved to a new location outside the Rijnpoort (Rhine gate), near the river. Earliest mention of the grain market on this location in 1428. The quay was broadened; in 1440, decisions were made for a new harbour here, and paving the road. In 1449, a crane was being build. Cranage had to be paid if one used the crane. This crane was out of use between 1499-1525 because it had been destroyed. Officially, Arnhem had no grain staple, but around the mid-fifteenth century, from 1437-1439 onward, the town de facto forced people to offer their load of grain for sale in Arnhem when passing by on the river Rhine. In 1603, the harbour was made safer.

Name: Blankenstein (Saale)
Settlement_Description: First uncertain mention in 1392, first certain mention in 1444.

Name: Syke
Alternative_Name: Sieke; Syk; Sicken; Zike; Sicke; Zyke; Zicke; Sike
Settlement_Description: Archaeological excavations have shown that a refuge castle must have existed around 800. First mentioned around 1250. At the end of the 13th century, a castle is built. The settlement is characterised as borough ('flecken') in 1520, but only acquired the corresponding privileges in 1718.

Name: Bruchhausen(-Vilsen)
Alternative_Name: Bruchhausen; Bruchhausen-Vilsen; Altbruchhausen; Altenbruchhausen; Bruchusen; Brokhusen; Bruchaußen; Alt Bruchhausen; Brughusen; Oldenbruchusen; Olden Brochhusen; Oldenbrockhusenn
Settlement_Description: The castle of Bruchhausen, first mentioned in 1189, was residence of the lords of Bruchhausen, later inherited by the counts of Oldenburg, and sold to the count of Hoya in 1326. The settlement developed into a borough ('flecken') at the beginning of the 15th century. It merged with nearby Vilsen in 1929.
Toll_Description: A toll of the counts of Hoya in Bruchhausen was pawned to Heinrich Starke in 1545. After complaints from Bremen in the 1590s, it was mentioned that the toll had existed for a long time.

Name: Vilsen
Alternative_Name: Bruchhausen-Vilsen; Villesen; Vilhusen; Vilszen; Viltzen; Vylsen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1227. The settlement acquired borough ('flecken') privileges in the 15th century, which were confirmed in 1577. It merged with nearby Bruchhausen in 1929.

Ferry_Description: The ferry in front of the town gate called 'Veerpoort' ('Ferry gate') is mentioned from at least 1389 onward. Probably because of silting up of the river IJssel and consequential attempts to replace the river's course, the ferry was - at least during the third quarter of the sixteenth century - located more downstream. In 1583, it was moved to a location in front of the town gate 'Koepoort' ('Cow gate'). The ferry was owned by the land lord.

Toll_Description: At least from 1487 onward, a toll was levied for crossing the bridge.
Ferry_Description: During the Eighty Years' War, the bridge was replaced by a ferry for several years.
Bridge_Description: In front of the gate called 'Waterpoort' a bridge crossed the river. During the Eighty Years' War, the bridge was removed for several years and replaced by a ferry.
Harbour_Description: Shipping on the Oude IJssel was made possible in 1582, when the water mill in Keppel was demolished. According to a document from 1590, shipping took place at that time between Doesburg and Doetinchem. Shipping in the other direction, to Bocholt and Anholt, was made possible with construction works in 1592.
The Bocholter Aa was made navigable in 1592. This allowed shipping between Bocholt and Doesburg via the Oude IJssel.
The Issel river was cleaned of obstacles in 1592; this allowed shipping between Anholt and Doesburg via the Oude IJssel.

Name: Ramsdorf
Alternative_Name: Hramastorpe; Ramasdorpe; Ramestorpe; Rambstorpe; Nortramesdorpe; Ransdorp; Ranstrop; Ranstrup
Settlement_Description: In the 11th century there was an episcopal official court and shortly before 1200 a parish church was founded, where the settlement originated. In 1319 this is called 'villa'.
Town_Description: In 1319 'Wigboldrechte' were granted. In 1384 the place was run as an 'oppidum' and town, in 1427 also called town.

Toll_Description: A toll on the Weser river in Landesbergen is mentioned in a Bremen complaint from 1584, as well as in a 1597 charter of the monastery Hardehausen.

Ferry_Description: The Ruhr river could be crossed with a ford near Mülheim. A ferry is first mentioned here in 1408, which belonged to the Count of Broich, but was usually pawned. It was planned to replace the ferry by a bridge as early as 1443, but an actual bridge is only attested in ca. 1750.

Harbour_Description: A harbour in Ruhrort is already attested in the Middle Ages, but was no ideal loading point. Ships had to anchor on the Rhine or Ruhr until the construction of harbour quays in the 18th century.

Name: Bohmte
Alternative_Name: Bamwide; Bomwide; Bamwida; Bonwide; Bomwede; Bomethe; Bombte; Bomde; Boemwede; Bomede; Boembte; Baempte; Baumte; Bomwedde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1068-70.

Name: Diepenau
Settlement_Description: A castle was built by the count of Hoya at the border with the diocese of Minden around 1380. Next to it a settlement developed, which was first mentioned in 1462 and received borough ('flecken') privileges in 1486.
Toll_Description: A toll in Diepenau is mentioned in 1581 as existing since old times. It probably goes back to the foundation of the castle around 1380.

Name: Müsleringen
Alternative_Name: Musleringe; Muslerinche; Muszleringe; Musseleringe; Musseler; Mueslerynge
Settlement_Description: The place was first mentioned in 1235.

Ferry_Description: A ferry across the Rhin river was the reason for the addition 'fehr' (ferry) to the name of Bellin. The ferry is first attested in 1402.
Bridge_Description: The ferry was replaced by a bridge in 1616.

Lock_Description: A new lock was constructed near Marienwerder in 1506.

Name: Gehrden
Alternative_Name: Gerdene; Geredene; Gherdene; Geherdene; Gerden; Cherdene
Settlement_Description: Mentioned as borough ('oppidum') in 1298; the settlement acquired borough ('flecken') privileges in 1647.

Name: Rötha
Alternative_Name: Rothowe; Rotowe; Rowe; Rotaw; Rothau; Rotov; Rotow; Rotwe; Rodewa
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1127.
Town_Description: First mentioned as town in 1291, usually referred to as borough ('städtlein', 'flecken') afterwards.

Name: Halte
Settlement_Description: Originally a folwark of the monastery of Knights Hospitalers Muhde. It was secularised in 1561.
Toll_Description: The count of Eastern Frisia installed a toll station in Halte around 1581, which led to complaints from the bishop of Münster, who claimed that it conflicted with a toll treaty from 1572. After a verdict of the Imperial Chamber Court in 1582, levying of the toll for Münster ships was discontinued. According to complaints from Emden from 1594, 1611, 1640 and 1647, the levying of the toll either never completely stopped, or was re-introduced in several years.

Harbour_Description: In Kösen temporarily existed a raft harbor ('Floßrechen') in order to ship logs of wood.

Bridge_Description: The "long bridge" and causeway across the Aue are first mentioned in 1303. They were part of the defence system ('landwehr') of the town of Braunschweig.

Name: Woeste Hoeve
Alternative_Name: Wueste Hoeue; Woeste Hoef; Woest Hoef; De Woeste Hoeve
Settlement_Description: The inn 'Woeste Hoeve' is presumably one of the oldest inns on the Veluwe. It was located on the crossroad of the road between Arnhem and Deventer, and the Hesseroad between Steenderen and Barneveld.

Ferry_Description:
In 1409 the citizens of Belgern hand over their share of the ferry to Buch monastery.
In 1474 Buch monastery loans half the ferry to ferryman Wenzel for life. In the following time, the ferry seems to only have been passed over to private persons. There was a large raft ferry and a small boat ferry.

Bridge_Description: A bridge in Freden is mentioned in 1413.
A bridge and causeway across the Schunter near Lehre is mentioned in 1488.
According to the travel diary of Henning Brandis from 1495, the Fuhse valley was crossed with a causeway and a bridge.

Ferry_Description: A ferry was in function until the construction of a ponton bridge in 1603. From 1287 onward, the ferry was owned by the chapter of Sain-Peter (Sint-Pieter) in Utrecht. In 1601, it was acquired by the town of Arnhem. A land toll owned by the landlord, the duke of Guelders, linked up to the ferry, stimulating trade-related traffic to enter Arnhem.
Bridge_Description: 'Schipbrug', a ponton bridge which has functioned since 1603.

Name: Schwarzer Kater
Settlement_Description: Inn at a crossing west of Dahlen. Crossing of the 'Hohe Straße' and the 'Hainstraße', here called 'Heustraße'.

Bridge_Description: A wooden bridge is first mentioned in 1577.

Toll_Description: A bridge and ferry toll were due in Torgau, as well as a toll on wares that were shipped on the Elbe river (LHASA, MD, d. 49, Nr. 2, Amt Torgau 1510, p. 348–354.). From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.
Bridge_Description: Between 1422 and 1428 a wodden bridge across the Elbe was constructed in Torgau by the order of prince electorate Friedrich I.

Toll_Description: Important toll station for goods on the Elbe. From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.

The regulations of safe conduct settle the tolls on the Elbe and the bridge toll, while the account books from 1444 to 1545 further mention income from the ferry and cattle tolls. (LHASA, MD, d. 54, Wittenberg Nr. 1, Erbbuch des Amtes Wittenberg 1513, p. 100v – 106v.). Returning and loaded boats were exempt from the toll in Wittenberg. Furthermore, the regulations of safe conduct do not mention rafts, which gives Wittenberg the impression of being a starting- or ending point for trade within the electorate of Saxony. From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.

The safe conduct in Wittenberg shows the high amount of trade traffic from north to south and east to west. The regulations of safe conduct also settle the tolls on the Elbe and the bridge toll, while the account books from 1444 to 1545 further mention income from the ferry and cattle tolls. The high incomes from the bridge toll probably show the close relations between Wittenberg and the surrounding agricultural settlements. (LHASA, MD, d. 54, Wittenberg Nr. 1, Erbbuch des Amtes Wittenberg 1513, p. 100v – 106v.).
Ferry_Description: Mentioned in a certificate for a jointress ('Leibgedingsurkunde') to duchess Barbara, widow of prince electorate Rudolf III., from Friedrich the Strident. The account books from 1444 - 1545 still mention income from the ferry.
Bridge_Description: In 1428, prince electorate Friedrich has the Elbe-bridge constructed.

Toll_Description: The regulation of safe conduct settles the fees taken from rafts as well as boats. From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.
Ferry_Description: In the regulations of safe conduct, the ferry fees are mentioned as well.

Toll_Description: In the Dessau regulations of safe conduct from 1549, the fees for rafts and ships on the Elbe were fixed. From four travel accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on shipping on the Elbe river.

Harbour_Description: The Winschoterdiep canal was dug in the 1630s, which allowed water traffic with Groningen. Regular barge ('trekschuit') services were offered in 1654 at the latest.
In the 1630s the Winschoterdiep canal was dug, which allowed river traffic between Groningen and Winschoten. Regular barge ('trekschuit') services were offered since 1654 at the latest.

Toll_Description: A regulation of safe conduct from the 16th century lists the fees due on the Elbe river. From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.
From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.

The toll on the Elbe was already established with Jerichow castle in 1144.
From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.

Mentions of the toll in 1373, 1377 and 1385, it is differentiated between the land (town) toll and the water (Elbe) toll. Further mentions in 1414, 1428 and 1458 when the excemption of toll of the citizens of Tangermünde is mentioned. From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.
Ferry_Description: In 1376 riders crossed the Elbe on the ferry at Tangermünde.

Toll_Description: From four traveling accounts by the river merchant Gottfired Kleeditz from Pirna in 1671 to 1674 there is proof for a toll on the Elbe river on transport boats.
In 1499 an escort ('Geleitsmann') is attested at the Galgtor in Halle.

Name: Wellaune
Settlement_Description: First mention around 1340 as Welin.

Name: Oschersleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in 814. Since the 12th century a castle and market place ('Marktflecken'), since 1376 borough ('Weichbild').
Town_Description: In 1235 referred to as civitas. Since the end of the 12th century probably owned town rights. The first record of a council remains from 1322. It remained under the authority of Brandenburg.
Fair_Description: Three fairs and cattle markets are confirmed in Oschersleben in 1650 and two cattle markets are added before the fair after Reminiscere and another on St. Bartholomew's day.
Bridge_Description: Even though the lowland-crossing dam and the corresponding bridges are mentioned several times since 1287, the more important roads led either via Hadmersleben or via Neudamm – Neuwegersleben.

Name: Ranis
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1169, Frankish castle with suburbium.
Town_Description: The exact date of of when Ranis was granted town rights is not known. Probably during the reign of the counts of Schwarzburg (1206 - 1389).

Bridge_Description: A drawbridge across the Unstrut is destroyed by mercenaries in 1631.

Name: Kottmann
Settlement_Description: Crossing of the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Vreden near the farm Kottmann. The boom barrier was first mentioned as "Lewer Hecke" in 1543.

Name: Salmer
Settlement_Description: Near the farm Volmer, the road crossed the 16th-century defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Vreden.

Bridge_Description: In the 14th century, a stone bridge is known which led from the Brücktor across the Elbe on the town side to the marsh. In 1440 a wooden bridge is constructed, which had only little openenings for ships to pass through.

Name: Westochtersum
Alternative_Name: West-Ochtersum; Ochtersum; Orten; Ochterszem; Ochtsem; Ochterßum; Westerochtersumb
Settlement_Description: The settlement Ochtersum is first mentioned in 1237, the church was built around 1260.

Name: Westerholt
Settlement_Description: A village was first mentioned in 1420.

Name: Arle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the early 12th century.

Name: Hage
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1400, but there already existed a wooden church here in ca. 1200.

Name: Issersheilingen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1279.
Toll_Description: Station of secondary safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Gottern (LHASA, MD, d. 21 A I Nr. 1 I, Amtserbbuch für Salza und Thamsbrück 1516, p. 83–84 and p. 113–116).
"Beyod the toll station at the Rußningsbach in direction of Bila" a traveler had to pay for safe conduct.

Ferry_Description: The town was named after the ferry that was situated here.

Toll_Description: After the Aller river had changed its course between 1618 and 1630, the toll levied on river traffic in Ahlden was now levied in Hudemühlen.

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Innerste near Marienburg is mentioned in 1571.

Lock_Description: The mouth of the Wilster Au river in the Stör was closed with a flood gate in 1438. It was replaced by a chamber lock in 1925.
The mouth of the river Kremper Au in the Stör was closed with a flood gate in 1636. The barrier was moved to the dike in Borsfleth in 1756.

Name: Wiehe
Alternative_Name: Wihe; Roßleben-Wiehe; Uuihe; Wiha; Wie; Wy
Settlement_Description: Probably a Frankish castle or homestead around which a village developed. Mention around 998 in the Breviarium Sancti Lulli. It is referred to as civitas as early as the 10th century, which doesn't make it a town at this time, but may show its importance and possible fortification.
Town_Description: In 1297 mention of citizens of Wiehe, in 1320 market- and other town-like privileges are granted. In 1394 the town rights are confirmed by landgrave Balthasar, so they may have existed as early as the beginning of the 14th century. The town was granted town rights of Eisenach.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Eckartsberga.

Name: Bothenheilingen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1143.

Name: Welsbach
Settlement_Description: Großwelsbach is first mentioned in 1216, Kleinwelsbach in 1285.
Toll_Description: Station of secondary safe conduct ('Beigeleitsstelle') of Gottern (LHASA, MD, d. 21 A I Nr. 1 I, Amtserbbuch für Salza und Thamsbrück 1516, p. 83–84 and p. 113–116).

Name: Wethau
Settlement_Description: The name of the settlement is first mentioned in 1146, the name of the district as early as 976.

Bridge_Description: In the regulation of safe conduct of Eckartsberga, the bridge across the Wethau in the village of Wethau is mentioned as the ending station of the safe conduct of Eckartsberga and the beginning of the safe conduct of Weißenburg. It was to be maintained by the council of Naumburg, and its annals mention that it had to be rebuilt or repaired multiple times.
The name of the hamlet Schevenbrügge indicates that a "crooked" bridge crossing the Kattbeck stream must have existed in 1633/34 at the latest.

Harbour_Description: In Kampen, ships and boats could tie up along the IJsselkade (IJssel Quay) and the Burgwal (the quay of the Burgel canal). In 1456, the area now called 'Oude Buitenhaven' was indicated as the 'harbour'. The IJsselkade was indicated as the 'shipyard'. The IJsselkade, also known as the 'Welle', was the main location for loading and unloading. The crane is first mentioned in 1342, replaced in 1475 by a new one, and was probably located near the Stadsbrugplein (the square near the bridge over the IJssel). The crane was pulled down in 1851. Perpendicular to the quay were jetties. North of the harbour was the quay of 'de Hagen'. 'De Hagen' was a district of Kampen laying outside the town wall. In the sixteenth century, there was a shipbuilding yard in De Hagen.

Name: Brunnepe
Alternative_Name: Bronepe; Bronope; Bronpe; Broenpe; Bronnep; Broneppe; Oerd; Oord; Oerde
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1329, but the settlement has been inhabited before. The inhabitants of the village were scattered around several centers. The diked core of the village was called 'Oerd', 'Oord' or 'Oerde'. In 1672-73, the village was destroyed by the French army.
Toll_Description: Merchants from other places had to pay 'paalgeld' in order to unload goods in Brunnepe.
Harbour_Description: In the fourteenth and fifteenth century, Bruneppe had a harbour with a 'lastasie', a shipbuilding yard. Probably, it was only used for repairs; not for building seegoing ships.

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Eider must have existed in 1220 at the latest, as the village Brügge was named after the bridge.

Toll_Description: The regulations of safe conduct mention a bridge toll that had to be paid by wagons and cattle herders.

Bridge_Description: Saalebridge, first mentioned in 1445. In 1547 the bridge was moved to the current position at the end of the Ludwigsstraße.

Name: Seehausen (Bad Frankenhausen)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1101.

Name: Reinfeld
Alternative_Name: Reyneuelt; Reineuelde; Rineuelde; Reyneuelde; Reynenvelde; Reynevuelde; Reinfeldt
Settlement_Description: Cistercian monastery, founded in 1186. After its abolition, a castle was built. The associated settlement developed into a borough ('flecken') around 1600.

Name: Oberheldrungen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1229.
Toll_Description: After 1570, the toll in Harras is moved to Oberheldrungen.

Name: Vogelsberg
Settlement_Description: First mention in MGH DLdDt 170.
Toll_Description: Secondary station of safe conduct of Erfurt. Mainly rural goods passed thorugh here, even though it gained some meaning with the rising copper trade from Mansfeld.

Name: Schönewerda
Settlement_Description: The oldest part of the village, Eßmannsdorf, is mentioned in 786. The settlement of Schönewerda is founded on an island in the Unstrut in the 12th century. Mention in the record book of Donndorf monastery in 1311.
Town_Description: It isn't quite clear if Schönewerda was granted town- and market rights in 1310 and lost them again in a lawsuit for labour services in 1628.

Name: Hardisleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in the book of records of Pforte monastery.

Name: Neunheilingen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1150.

Name: Blaue Warte
Settlement_Description: In 1438 archbishop Günther promises the council of Wanzleben that he will erect and man watchtowers around the town.

Name: Friedrichstadt
Alternative_Name: Friedrichstadt (Eider); Friedrichstadt an der Eider; Frederiksstad; Fredericopolis; Frederikstat
Settlement_Description: Friedrichstadt was founded by duke Friedrich III of Holstein-Gottorf in 1621. Settlers were drawn with economic privileges and freedom of religion, which attracted a community of predominantly Dutch religious refugees.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted in 1635.

Bridge_Description: A bridge across two arms of the Leine river, consisting of a "short" and a "long" bridge, is first mentioned in 1445. Before, there existed a ford here.

Name: Moritzberg
Alternative_Name: Bergflecken St. Mauritii; Bergdorf; Blek up dem Berge
Settlement_Description: A chapel was founded in 1025 and devoted to St Maurice in 1028; connected to it was a nunnery, which was turned into a collegiate church with 16 canons in 1068. Around the monastery a settlement developed in the 11th century. It developed into a borough ('flecken') in the 15th century.

Name: Siechenhof (Mühlhausen)
Settlement_Description: The infirmary near the Lengenfeld watchtower is already mentioned in 1283. It is still mentioned in the descirption of the proper road of safe conduct from 1609. In 1802 it is referred to as a popular resting station for wagoners.

Name: Heilig-Geist-Spital Eisleben
Settlement_Description: The Holy-Ghost infirmary is proven since 1373 bur probably reaches back until the 13th century.
Bridge_Description: A letter from 1594 mentiones a bridge near the infirmary.

Name: Henne (Naumburg)
Ferry_Description: The ferry to Halle ('Hallesche Fähre') in Naumburg was situated at the inn "Zur Henne".
A Rhine ferry between Düsseldorf and Neuss at Hamm is first mentioned in 1262. On the Hamm side, it was located at "auf den Steinen" (on the stones).

Name: Hohenschemsbrücke
Bridge_Description: Bridge across the Werse, first mentioned in 1280.

Name: Broskov
Bridge_Description: Medieval road placed above road from Roman Iron age (dated about 250 AD).

Name: Onsild
Bridge_Description: Crossing of Onsild stream, dirt roads (hulveje) and a stone paved road from around 1300 AD.

Name: Vester Immervad
Bridge_Description: 21m long stepping stone path. Late Viking age to early medieval.

Name: Løvel Bro
Bridge_Description: Inscription stone mentions King Eric Plovpenning or King Eric Glipping, placing the bridge in the period 1241-1286. The inscription leads us to believe an older wooden construction was replaced with a stone bridge. First mentioned in wrinting 1454, we know of wooden bridges from middle 1500s.

Name: Skjern å
Bridge_Description: Medieval bridge placed near present “Kong Hans Bro”, dendro dates places the bridge construction in 1105. It was maintained and repaired until 1350 after which it was abandoned. After this Kongevejsbroen is known, it was ordered constructed in 1632. Other bridges or ways of crossing most likely was used in the period without known bridges.

Name: Gamle Skæremølle Bro
Bridge_Description: Presumed constructed around 1600.

Name: Sundhausen
Settlement_Description: Mention in 775/786 in the Breviarium sancti Lullii of Hersfeld monastery (Tab. I).

Bridge_Description: A water mill at the river Neetze is first mentioned in 1314. At this time at the latest, a bridge and causeway must have existed as well. Before there was a ford.

Harbour_Description: The raftwood station in Zwenkau is proof for the significance of the village for rafting on the Elster river.

Name: Lübscherbaum
Alternative_Name: Lubeschen bome; Lubeschem bome; Lubischen Boem; Lübschenbaum
Settlement_Description: Boom barrier in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Hamburg on the road to Lübeck, first mentioned in the 15th century.

Name: Schlagd
Harbour_Description: The river harbour of Kassel was located at the Schlagd, the shore of the Fulda near the old market place. In the 1570s, storage houses were built here.

Around 1600, landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel launched construction works to make the Fulda river navigable between Kassel and Hersfeld, which was realised in 1601. Later ordinances secured the navigability.

Bridge_Description: A wooden bridge across the Werra existed from the 13th century. It was replaced by a stone bridge in 1606.
A bridge across the Werra is first mentioned in 1326. According to an engraving of Merian from 1655, it consisted of three stone arched bridges across three arms of the river.

Name: Schweinitz (Herzberg)
Toll_Description: Tables of fees ('Geleitstafeln') remain from 1510 and 1531/32.

Ferry_Description: Werben held ferry privileges since 1360.

Name: Deetzer Warte
Settlement_Description: The Deetz overland trench ('Landwehr') was already mentioned in 1238. The watchtower was erected in 1409. Since 1703 an inn existed, from which toll was collected at least since 1745.

Bridge_Description: The bridge across the Hörsel in Eisenach was probably constructed during the 12th century.

Name: Oderbrück
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Oder is first displayed on a map of the Harz area from 1530.
A bridge is mentioned in 1626.

Name: Hubeturm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Einbeck, first mentioned in 1436. It was demolished in 1800.

Name: Wiebrechtshauser Turm
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the defensive enclosure ('landwehr') of Northeim, built around 1400. It was demolished in 1829.

Name: Barnum
Toll_Description: In 1277, Wesel was exempted from payment of the toll on river traffic in Barnum, which was levied by the duke of Cleves.

Harbour_Description: Haltern was transit point for many commodities between Münsterland and the Rhine river system. A harbour crane is attested in 1597.

Name: Haus Ostendorf
Toll_Description: Toll on river traffic of the lords of Ostendorf as vassals of the bishop of Münster. Since 1494 in possession of the lords of Raesfeld. There are many records of attacks on skippers from Wesel here.

Name: Haus Vogelsang
Toll_Description: Toll on the Lippe river at the house Vogelsang, which was only levied on ships that moored there.

A transit toll in Wesel is first mentioned in 1188/1193 in complaints from the monastery Cappenberg that its exemption from the toll in Wesel was being disregarded, upon which the count of Cleves forbade the levying of toll on ships and wagons from Cappenberg. Later sources indicate that the toll was only levied on the transshipment ("upslach") of cargoes between ships and land vehicles. In the 16th century, this was only applied on commodities that left the town after having been transshipped. Wesel citizens were exempted from toll payments. Despite protests from the town, the duke of Cleves enforced the levying of the toll on commodities that stayed in Wesel in the 1580s as well; a new toll regulation from 1586 only mentions commodities which were transported further on the land route, however.
Harbour_Description: Wesel was an important transshipment point on the Rhine and Lippe rivers. Harbour infrastructure is attested from 1355, when a crane was brought from Neuss to Wesel. A harbour basin was built in an old Lippe arm in 1525, but had silted up again by 1600. A crane ship to facilitate loading and unloading of ships on the waterfront of the Rhine was built in 1524, but burnt down in 1535. A new crane from 1537 was destroyed by Spanish troops in 1588. It was rebuilt in 1590/91. A register of crane fees is extant for 1623.

Name: Aardenburg
Alternative_Name: Rodenburgh; Rodenburg; Rodanburg; Redenburg; Redanburg; Reddenburg; Erdenburg; Ardenburg; Ardenburg; Ardenborch; Aerdenburg; Rodenburch
Settlement_Description: In 170, a Roman castellum was situated at the site of the modern-day town of Aardenburg. The first mention in written records dates from 966.
Town_Description: In the eleventh and twelfth century, Aardenburg developped into a town. It was granted town privileges before 1187 by Philip of Alsace, count of Flanders. The charter has not survived. By 1299, Aardenburg had a earth wall, a moat and four town gates.

Harbour_Description: The Oker river was made navigable between Schladen and Wolfenbüttel in 1575, and between Schladen and Oker in 1577.

Name: Lengde
Alternative_Name: Leggithe; Lengethe; Lengithe; Lengedhe; Leggethe; Lengede; Lengethe; Lenghede; Lenge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1131.

Based on archaeological evidence, an inn may be located just outside the core of Hees and about a thirty minutes' walk from Nijmegen, along the 'Hooge Weg', the road between Nijmegen and Wijchen. It existed from the end of the fourteenth century until it probably burned down around the middle of the fifteenth century - possibly during the siege of Nijmegen in 1473.

Name: Hees
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1196 in relation to the foundation of St Jans Hospital. A wooden chapel, belonging to St Stephen's Church (Stevenskerk) in Nijmegen, already existed around 800. Around 1250, a chapel of stone was built on the current location of the Church of St Peter (Petruskerk, Schependomlaan 85), which was replaced by a new one around 1430, and by a church around 1550.

Name: Hennigsdorf
Settlement_Description: The settlement was probably founded by Spandau or tranferred to German jurisdiction.

Ferry_Description: The ferry between Nijmegen and Lent has existed from at least the beginning of the eight century onward. Originally, it was owned by the land lord. During the Middle Ages, it was owned by a partnership of ecclesiastical and secular lords, among which the provisors of the Holy Spirit. In 1592, the town council of Nijmegen became the ferry's owner. The ferry was leased out to multiple leaseholders. Due to war, the ferry's exploitation was very limited between 1585 and 1591. In 1657, the ferry was replaced by a cable ferry, invented, and exploited as well, by Hendrick Heuck. In 1563, the ferrymen and town council of Nijmegen complain about multiple illegal ferry activities upstream near Ooij, and downstream near Oosterhout.

Harbour_Description: A wharf with a crane was situated just outside the town gate called 'Kraanpoort', at the end of the main street from the river Waal into town, the 'Grotestraat'. The Grotestraat is one of the oldest streets of the town. Archeological research shows the presence of a wharf or harbour in the tenth and eleventh century. In 1420, the wharf was extended from 170 to 400 metre. The 'Kraanpoort' gate is first mentioned in 1382, just as the crane. The ferry bridge was located near the 'Kraanpoort' as well. Before 1422, the ferry bridge was probably located a little more eastward. A small harbour was located west of the town, perpendicular to the river Waal, between the river and the town gate called 'Hezelpoort'. Between 1601 and 1604, this harbour was moved and enlarged inside the town walls, parallel to the river Waal.

Name: Tannroda
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1115, the castle around which the village developed was probably erected in the 12th century.
Town_Description: The settlement that developed across the castle on the other bank of the Schwarza is mentioned as town in 1403 and as borough ('Flecken') in the 16th century. The council only held administrative privileges, no jurisdiction.

Ferry_Description: A "new" ferry across the Oste in Geversdorf is first mentioned in 1423. It connected Geversdorf with Itzwörden.

Harbour_Description: The river Oste was navigable for larger ships until Bremervörde, although due to shallow waters near Bremervörde, some cargoes had to be transshipped onto smaller vessels at landing places downstream before being transported to Bremervörde.

Name: Bevern (Bremervörde)
Settlement_Description: Bevern was first mentioned as a farm of the monastery Heeslingen in 986. Around 1500, ten farms and seven cottages in the village belonged to the monastery Zeven. One remaining farm was acquired by the monastery later as well.
Fair_Description: A fair on Ascension day took place in Bevern before 1582, when it was moved to Bremervörde.

Name: Hezelpoort
Harbour_Description: A small harbour was located between the river Waal and the town gate named Hezelpoort. Between 1601 and 1604, this harbour was moved and enlarged inside the town walls, parallel to the river Waal.

Name: Plötzky
Alternative_Name: Plotzka; Plocke; Plozzeke; Plozich; Plotzck, Plosk; Plotzke
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as the residence of an Ascanian ministerial family. Between 1220 and 1230 a cistercian convent is founded. It is given up in 1538.

Lock_Description: The chamber lock in Calbe was first built in 1564.

Toll_Description: The toll in Lenzen was - at least from 1558 onwards - also levied on traffic on the Elbe river. According to 18th-century maps, the toll house was located on an old river arm. For more details, see Lenzen.

Name: Wijchen
Alternative_Name: Wichine; Wigene; Wigen; Wighen; Wychene; Wichene; Wichen
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1155. Wijchen was a small, agrarian village. The castle is first mentioned in 1392, but probably dates from the fourteenth century.

Name: Wehningen
Toll_Description: A river toll on the Elbe in Wehningen was first mentioned in 1372 when the castle came into the possession of the duke of Mecklenburg. In 1492, the toll fees are specified at 4 Gulden and 1 loaf of bread for each passing ship.

Harbour_Description: Geesthacht was a harbour for produce of the Vierlanden, as well as wood from the Sachsenwald.

Lock_Description: The chamber lock in Bernburg was built in 1560.
The chamber lock in Alsleben was built around 1560.

Name: Süderstapel
Toll_Description: Toll of the dukes of Schleswig-Gottorf on the Eider river. In 1506, the toll tariffs were raised for commodities transported by Rendsburg citizens, except for wood. Still extant toll registers from the early 16th century show that mainly grain from Rendsburg was transported over the river.

Lock_Description: The chamber lock in Rothenburg was renewed in 1694, which indicates that it existed before.

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Eider river was already part of the castle when it was constructed around 1150, and is often mentioned in sources from the second half of the 12th century. A bridge is still depicted on the view of the town by Braun and Hogenberg from 1584, but around 1600 it was replaced by a causeway with a lock.
Harbour_Description: After the construction of a causeway in front of the castle around 1600, commodities transported on the Eider river were forced to be transshipped in Rendsburg.

Name: Mooksche veer
Alternative_Name: Katwijksche veer; Mookse veer; Katwijkse veer

Bridge_Description: In 1450, a copper (?) bear is cast for the construction of the bridge across the Mulde. In a depiction of Eilenburg of 1550, the bridge is shown as a bridge on poles ('Pfahlbrücke').

Toll_Description: Since the existence of a lock, half a lock toll was granted by prince electorate Joachim II.
Lock_Description: In 1561 a round lock was constructed, which was replaced by a pound lock in 1610 - 1741.

Bridge_Description: The Stresow bridge is mentioned in 1433.
Former ford, earliest connection between the twin towns of Berlin and Cölln.
Second oldest Spree crossing, the construction of the bridge (Lange Brücke, today: Rathausbrücke) began in the 13th century.
