Toll_Description: At places along the Havel and Spree in which locks had been constructed, a lock toll was collected for the maintenance of the locks. However, they were as high as other tolls which generated purely financial income.
Lock_Description: Around 1550 the first lock is constructed in the city moat of Cölln.

Name: Berlikum
Alternative_Name: Berltsum; Berlichem; Barlichem; Berlikim; Berltjem; Berlkum; Verlingum [Berlingum]; Belkum; Berlekum; Berlicum
Settlement_Description: Berlikum is known to have existed around 900, located near the Middelzee (a former estuary of the Wadden sea).
Town_Description: Berlikum is first mentioned as a town in 1355 and is known to have had city-like features in the fourteenth-century.

Name: Burg Heimburg
Settlement_Description: Only certain castle foundation around 1070 by emperor Heinrich IV. next to the Harzburg. Property of the lords of Heimburg in the 12th century, changes owenership to the lords of Blankenburg-Regenstein in the last third of the 13th century, until only a steward resides on the castle since 1344. Beneath the castle the settlement of Heimburg develops, which is referred to as "borough" ('Fleck') in 1434.
Toll_Description: In a pawn record of 1434 the toll on the Heimburg is mentioned.

Harbour_Description: Before ca. 1200, Bevensen seems to have been an important trading site at the Ilmenau river. Afterwards, the Ilmenau was used upstream from Lüneburg until Bevensen, occasionally also until Uelzen, mostly for the transport of firewood for the Lüneburg saltworks.

The Ilmenau river upstream from Lüneburg was used as a waterway, mainly for transporting wood. In 1348, the town received the privilege to make the river navigable until Uelzen. The landing place for the vessels must have been located in the vicinity of the water mill, since the mill weir prevented ships from reaching the main harbour of the town.

Toll_Description: In the context of making the Ilmenau river navigable for wood transports to Lüneburg, a draw bridge was to be built near Medingen in 1343. In return, the monastery was allowed to levy a toll on the wood transported on the river.

Harbour_Description: The harbour of Harburg was used to ship corn and wood, but due to the constant attempts of Hamburg to prevent shipping on the southern Elbe because of the Hamburg staple from the 15th century onwards, it never gained prominence.

Toll_Description: A toll on shipping on the Oste was levied at Kranenburg, of which it is unknown when it started. In the late 17th century, a chain across the river forced ships to halt for toll payment. Before 1627, the bridge must have fulfilled the same function.
Ferry_Description: Before construction of the bridge and after it was burned down in 1627, a ferry must have existed near Kranenburg. It must have been replaced by the new river crossing at Hechthausen in 1659 at the latest.
Bridge_Description: A draw bridge across the Oste, which allowed passage to larger ships, was destroyed by imperial troops in 1627. It is unknown when it was built. A new bridge was built in 1659 further downstream near Hechthausen.

Toll_Description: The town Werden acquired the right to levy a bridge toll to pay for the maintenance of the bridge in 1426. After 1479, the duke of Mark introduced a bridge toll for citizens of the town as well, who had been exempted before.
Ferry_Description: A ferry replaced the bridge during its reconstruction in 1533-1538 and after its final destruction in 1642.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Ruhr is first mentioned in 1065. It was destroyed by floods in 1399 and 1533. At the latter occasion, it was replaced by a ferry for five years. According to a view of town by Braun and Hogeberg from 1572, the bridge was made from stone and had seven arches. Above the second pillar on the town side, there was a gate building, where the bridge toll was probably levied. The bridge was again destroyed by floods in 1642 and replaced for a ferry for the following two centuries.
Harbour_Description: In 1033, it is mentioned that the Ruhr river is navigable until Werden abbey. Probably, this was true for later centuries as well.

Name: Wiedensahl
Alternative_Name: Widensole; Wydensole; Widensadel; Wyndesolen; Wydensal; Wiedensaele; Weidensaell; Widensehle
Settlement_Description: An old Saxon manor existed around 500. A settlement was founded in the 13th century and first mentioned in 1253, which developed into a market borough ('flecken').

Harbour_Description: Duisburg had been an important harbour on the Rhine river in the Early and High Middle Ages. After 1200, the Rhine changed its course and Duisburg was now located on an old Rhine arm that silted up, leading to a decline of the harbour. On a 1566 view of the town, boats are still shown at the Dickelsbach (the former Rhine arm) in front of the Schwanentor, which indicate that the harbour could at this time still be reached with small vessels via the Ruhr river.

Name: Kloster Neuendorf
Settlement_Description: Founded not long before 1232 as a Cistercian convent. It was prosperous until the 15th century, in the aftermath of the Reformation it became protestant. In 1579 the monastery is officially dissolved but a convent of nuns is established, which was dissolved in 1810.

Name: Aakerfähr
Ferry_Description: The existence of a Ruhr ferry at this place is attested in a 1359 Duisburg town account, but it is likely to have been much older. Due to frequent changes in the course of the river, the ferry was frequently moved, changing hands between Meiderich and Duisburg, who kept half of the ferry fees. The other half of the revenues belonged to the duke of Cleves.

Name: Bierbruch
Alternative_Name: uppe deme broke vor Tzerstede; Bruch vor Sarstedt
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Hildesheim on the "Bruch vor Sarstedt" is first mentioned in 1384. The bishop cancelled levying of the toll in favour of Hildesheim citizens in 1393.

Harbour_Description: After the construction of the Schaale waterway in 1564, Dutzow on the northern shore of the lake Schaalsee became a transshipment point for transport, mainly of salt, between the Baltic Sea harbour of Wismar and the Elbe river.
The town of Rostock maintained a barge service with Bützow, which was rented out in 1433.

Name: Drübeck
Settlement_Description: Founded as a Benedictine convent in 877, the monastery remains as a protestant convent until today.

Lock_Description: A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed in Grabow on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.
A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed in Neustadt on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.

Name: Walbeck
Settlement_Description: First mention in a record from 959. In 992 a monastery of Benedictine nuns is endowed in Walbeck. The monastery is dissolved in 1525.

Name: Wiederstedt
Settlement_Description:
First mention of the village in 944.
Formerly a hospital in Hettstedt which was converted into a convent of Augistinian sisters, consecrated to the Holy Virgin Mary, before 1248. It was moved to Wiederstedt before 1259.

Name: Vianen
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Vianen is first mentioned about 1270. Cox states this more specifically as 1 December 1271.
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted on 22 September 1336 by Willem of Duivenvoorde, lord of Oosterhout, and Heilwich of Duivenvoorde, lady of Vianen and Oosterhout.

Name: Wenzendorfer Brücke
Bridge_Description: Boardwalk that had to be maintained by Pforte monastery.
A bridge across the Saale is known since the middle of the 12th century. In 1393 a wooden bridge is proven to have crossed the Saale. In 1404 a stone bridge was built to replace the wooden bridge.

Name: Oudewater
Alternative_Name: Ovdewatere; Oldewater; Heldwater; tOudewatre; Oudewatre; Thynoudewater; Tynoudewater; Ouwatere; Oudewateram; Oudewatere
Settlement_Description: The first mention of Oudewater dates from 1239. It gains importance as a fortified border settlement/town.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted by Henry I, count of Vianden. Neither the grant itself, nor any copies, have survived; therefore, the exact date of the grant is unknown. Based on source material from the seventeenth and eighteenth century, Cox states that these privileges may have been granted in 1257.

Name: Steinholzwarte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower built in the 14th/15th century.

Name: Seweckenwarte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower built in the 14th century.

Name: Neue Turmwarte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower; mentioned in 1461. The name alludes to an older predecessor.

Name: Horstbergwarte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower, part of the ditch system that stretched all the way to the Neue Turmwarte.

Name: Austbergwarte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower, in the 15th century it was a watchtower for Blankenburg.

Name: Sargstedter Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower built in the 15th century by Halberstadt monastery.

Toll_Description: At places along the Havel and Spree in which locks had been constructed, a lock toll was collected for the maintenance of the locks. However, they were as high as other tolls which generated purely financial income.
Lock_Description: In 1588 the first lock is constructed for trade with Frankfurt/Oder.

Name: Monnickendam
Alternative_Name: Monikendamme; Monekedamme; Monekiindamme; Monikedamme; Monicdam; Monekendam; Monickedamme; Monickedam; Monekdam; Monickendamme; Munnekedam
Settlement_Description: Monnickendam is first mentioned in 1288.
Town_Description: Monnickendam is granted town rights on 27 March 1356 by William V, count of Holland.

Name: Zaandam
Alternative_Name: Zaenderdam; Zaneredam; Zaenredam; Zanerdam; Saerdam; Zaardamme; Sanerdam; Saenredam; Sardam
Settlement_Description: Zaandam came into existence when the Hogendam or Zaanderdam was built not long before 1288, which closed off the Zaan river from the IJ. It is first mentioned in 1316. Around the dam and its locks, a village developed with inns that boomed in the 16th and 17th centuries due to the growth of shipping and industry along the Zaan river. In the 17th century, Zaandam became divided in Oost-Zaandam and West-Zaandam, which were merged into a single village Zaandam only in 1811. Zaandam was elevated to a town on 1 January 1812 by Emperor Napoleon.
Toll_Description: A toll at the Hogendam, presumably on beer, is first mentioned in 1349.
Ferry_Description: Ferry services between Zaandam and Amsterdam were regulated in 1631: four skippers for each settlement were allowed to operate on the route and tariffs were fixed. In 1683, ferry services were extended to 12 skippers.
Harbour_Description: A harbour developed on the western side of the dam in the 16th and 17th century during the economic boom of Zaandam. It served as transit harbour for regional as well as international ships. Extensive harbour structures on the IJ side of the dam were built in 1636 and 1650, which were connected with the sea. Larger sea-going vessels could not anchor in the harbour and had to use the mouth of the Zaan river as roadstead.
Lock_Description: When the Hogendam was constructed around 1288, two wooden sluices were built for draining purposes. Probably, these were passable for smaller vessels. From 1544 to 1547, one of them was replaced with a pound lock from stone, which allowed larger vessels to pass, which made the Zaan the main waterway from Amsterdam to northern Holland. However, the lock was bridged and built over, so that its capacity remained limited. The fee for use of this large lock was 10 stuiver; the town of Alkmaar enjoyed the right of free passage. The second "Wormer Sluis" or "Kleine sluis" was renewed in 1549, and protests from various villages in 1588 after it was announced that the lock would be closed show that there was a high demand for two passages for ships in the dam. In 1608, an "overtoom" (a construction for dragging ships across a barrier) was constructed to allow sea-going ships built at the Zaan shipyards to enter the IJ. A third sluice was built in 1612 in connection with the draining of the Schermer and Beemster lakes.

Name: Beverwijk
Alternative_Name: Beuorhem; Beuerhem; Agathenkiricha; Agathenkyricha; Agathenkerka; Sinte Agheten dorpe; parrogia Sancte Agathe virginis; parrochia de Wijc; Beverwijc; Wyck; Beverwyc; ter Wyc; Aghetskerke; sinte Aechtendorpe; Aagtendorp; Aagtenkerk; Sint Aagtendorp
Settlement_Description: Beverwijk is first mentioned in an eleventh-century copy of a document dated 918-948. In the thirteenth-century it gains some importance as a place for transhipment.
Town_Description: Beverwijk was granted town rights on 11 November 1298 by John I, count of Holland and Zeeland.

Name: Edam
Alternative_Name: Aedamme; Adam; Yedamme; Yedam; Edamum; Eedam
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Edam is first mentioned in 1342-1343. Cox states that there is an earlier mention dating from 1310.
Town_Description: Edam was granted town privileges on 19 November 1357 by William V, count of Holland.
Harbour_Description: In the town privileges of 1357, Edam acquired the right to construct a new harbour, that connected the Purmer lake with the Zuiderzee. It became an important sea harbour for the hinterland of northern Holland.

Name: Alkmaar
Alternative_Name: Almere; Alcmere; Allecmere; Alkmer; Alcmare; Alcmar; Alcmaer; Alcmair;
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Alkmaar is first mentioned in the first half of the eleventh century. Cox, however, claims that the earliest mention dates from 922-939. A market is mentioned in 1132, and Alkmaar is called an 'oppidum' in 1166.
Town_Description: Alkmaar is granted town rights on 11 June 1254 by William II, count of Holland. However, in 1426, Alkmaar lost its town privileges (and its military defences). The defences were re-established in 1451. In 1456, the town rights were re-granted, but these (and the city gates and walls) were lost again in 1491. The town rigts were again restored in the sixteenth century.

Name: Schellinkhout
Alternative_Name: Scellinchout; Scillinchout; Schellinckhout; Scellinchout; Schellink hout; Schellincxhout; Schellingshout
Settlement_Description: Schellinkhout is first mentioned around 1311/1312. Schellinkhout was granted town privileges on 21 December 1402 by Albert (‘Albrecht’) of Bavaria, count of Holland. In 1414, the villages Wijdenes and Oosterleek were added to the ‘stede’ Schellinkhout. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. In 1429, the town privileges were withdrawn and on 6 January 1430, Wijdenes and Oosterleek were separated from the ‘stede’ Schellinkhout (and were granted their own town privileges). The town rights of Schellinkhout itself were restored sometime between 1442 and 1450.

Name: Hem
Settlement_Description: Hem is first mentioned around 1312. On 2 February 1414 Hem, together with Venhuizen, was granted town privileges by William (‘Willem’) VI, count of Holland. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments.

Name: Spanbroek
Alternative_Name: Spanbroech; Spanbroec; Spanbroke; Spambroek; Spanbrouck; Spanbroeck
Settlement_Description: According to Cox, Spanbroek is first mentioned in a 1300-copy of a 1256 document. Van Berkel and Samplonius take a slightly later date, 1290 (in a thirteenth- or fourteenth-century copy). In 1414, the settlements Spanbroek, Opmeer, Obdam and Hensbroek were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Spanbroek. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. For political reasons, the 'stede' lost its privileges in 1426. By 1434, the territory was divided between several lords. In 1456, 'stede' Spanbroek received its own town privileges, separate from the 'stede' Obdam-Hensbroek.

Name: Hoogwoud
Alternative_Name: Officii de Alta Silua; Hogerholtwal; Houchoucwoude; Hoichhoutwoude; Hogoutwoude; Hoichtwoude; Hoochwoude; Hooghwoude
Settlement_Description: The name Hoogwoud is first mentioned in a copy of a document dating from 1289. This, however, concerns the 'ambacht' Hoogwoud. The first mention of the settlement dates from from c.1312. On 2 February 1414, Hoogwoud, together with Aartswoud, was granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Hoogwoud and Aartswoud combined formed the ‘stede’ Hoogwoud. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The town privileges of the 'stede' were withdrawn on 13 August 1426, but were re-granted on 29 March 1450.

Name: Sijbekarspel
Alternative_Name: Siboutskerspel; Zyboudskerspel; Syboutskerspel; Sybekarspel; Zibekerspel; Zybenkerspil; Zybenkerspel; Zybekerspel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1312. In 1414, Sijbekarspel and Benningbroek were granted town rights by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Sijbekarspel. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. For political reasons, the town rights were withdrawn in 1426. The privileges were temporarily regranted in 1428 and 1452, before they were permanently restored in 1456.

Name: Abbekerk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1312. In 1414, Abbekerk, Lambertschaag, Twisk and Midwoud were granted town rights by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Abbekerk. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The stede lost its town privileges in 1426. These were temporarily restored in 1436 and 1452. In 1456, the restoration of the privileges was made permanent.

Name: Grootebroek
Alternative_Name: Groote broec; Groetbroec; Grotebroec; Groetebroeck; Grootebroeck; Groete Brouck; Groten Broek
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Grootebroek is first mentioned in 1288. Cox chooses a slightly later date, c1312. Grootebroek, together with Bovenkarspel, was granted town privileges on 2 August 1364 by Albert ('Albrecht'), governor ('ruwaard') of Holland. Grootebroek and Bovenkarspel combined formed the 'stede' Broek. The settlements Lutjebroek and Hoogkarspel were added to this 'stede' in 1402 and 1403, respectively. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The 'stede' lost its privileges in 1426, but these were partly regranted in 1429, and fully restored in 1436.

Name: Medemblik
Alternative_Name: Medemolaca; Medemelacha; Medenblec; Medemelake; Medemleke; Medenbliec; Medenblijck; Memelick
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of Medemblik in writing occurs in the eleventh-century copy of a document dated 918-948. Cox states that Medemblik originated in the late seventh or early eighth century. It gained governmental and economic importance as it was located on the shipping route through the Vlie between Dorestad and Almere. Furthermore, there were royal and episcopal residences in the area.
Town_Description: Medemblik was granted town rights on 25 March 1289 by Floris V, count of Holland.

Name: Nedlitz
Settlement_Description: The Havel-passage between lakes Lehnitz- and Jungfern has been guarded since the Bronze Age. Later, a Slavic settlement is formed, which is then absorbed into a German village.
Ferry_Description: First mention of the ferry in Nedlitz in 1323; it was the only direct connection between Potsam and Spandau. The ferry existed well into the 19th century.

Name: Potsdam
Settlement_Description: First mention 993 in a gift certificate by Otto III. to Quedlinburg monastery. A Slavic settlement and a Kietz existed next to each other, the castle warden first took residence in the Slavic castle rampart in the 12th century. Before 1237 a stone castle was erected at the bank of the Havel river.
Town_Description: In 1345 mention as civitas with a council constitution. In 1404 referred to as 'Stedeken', the date of the awarding of town rights is unknown.
Toll_Description: The castle was the seat of the custums office. The toll station is first mentioned in 1370.

Bridge_Description: A bridge, the "Lange Brücke", across the Havel existed since 1317.

Name: Mühlberg (Elbe)
Settlement_Description: Foundation of a Cistercian nunnery which was mentioned in 1228, but a settlement was probably founded in 1200.
Town_Description: Referred to as oppidum in 1230, in 1295 as civitas, when old and New town were still differentiated. 1363 town rights were granted by Karl IV.
Toll_Description: The Elbe toll in Mühlberg only entered the possession of the electorate in Sachsen at the end of the 15th century. A registry of safe conduct from 1555 merely lists the toll due on mill-, cut-, and limestones, as well as grain. Wood is only mentioned indirectly in the fee for rafts.
A land toll was being levied at the bridge. From 1602 onward, a water toll was being levied at Eembrugge for ships going from and to Amersfoort.
Bridge_Description: A bridge was built in the late twelfth century. A toll had to be paid to cross the bridge.

Name: Schagen
Alternative_Name: Scagha; Scagon; Scagan; Scagen; Scaghen; Schaegen
Settlement_Description: Schagen is first mentioned in a ca. 1420 copy of a document dated at the end of the eleventh century. Schagen was granted town rights on 12 May 1415 by William VI, count of Holland. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws').

Name: Winkel
Settlement_Description: Winkel is first mentioned in 1289. Winkel was granted town rights on 12 May 1415 by William VI, count of Holland. The settlement, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). Winkel lost its town privileges as a consequence of the Hook and Cod wars, but these rights were regranted on 8 May 1452 by Philip the Good, count of Holland.

Name: Burghorn
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention dates from 1456. Burghorn is founded as a polder. Burghorn is granted town privileges between 1 January and 18 November 1462 by Willem van Schagen, lord of Burghorn. The settlement never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). Burghorn eventually merged into Schagen.

Name: Texel
Alternative_Name: Tesla; Thesla; Tysele; insulae Texlae; Tlex; Texle; Texla; Tessele; Texsel; Texalie
Settlement_Description: Texel is a Dutch Wadden Island on which several settlements are located. Texel is first mentioned in a 1183-1195 copy from a document dating from 772 or 776.
Town_Description: Texel is a Dutch Wadden Island on which several settlements are located. The island in its entirety was granted town privileges on 26 March 1415 by William VI, count of Holland. Texel lost its town rights in 1426 (for joining the Hook side in the Hook and Cod wars). The privileges were re-granted in 1434, and were lost again in 1491. The town rights were once again restored in 1494.

Name: Wieringen
Alternative_Name: Wirense; Wirensi; Uvira; Wironi (Wirom); Wiron; Wireon; UUiron; Wieringerlant; Wieringherlant; Wieringhen; Wyeringen; Wiring
Settlement_Description: Wieringen is a former island in the Dutch province of Noord-Holland. It is first mentioned in a the 1150-1158 copy of manuscript dating from the late eighth century - 817. Wieringen remained an island until the first half of the twentieth century.
Town_Description: Wieringen is a former island in the Dutch province of Noord-Holland. Several settlements were located on the island. The island in its entirety was granted town rights on 10 August 1432. Wieringen lost its town rights in 1492, but later these were restored.

Name: Noordwijk
Alternative_Name: Nordcha; Norhtgo; Northgo; Nothungon; Northico; Nordeke; Nordeka; Norghe; Noertijc; Nortwyck; Nortik; Nordwige; Nortic; Nortdijc; Northeke; Noirtich; Noertich
Settlement_Description: Noordwijk is first mentioned in a 1520 copy from a document dating from 889.
Town_Description: Noordwijk was granted town rights on 1 April 1398 by Albert (Dutch: Albrecht) I of Bavaria, count of Holland. However, these town privileges were withdrawn again on 12 March 1399.

Name: Kammerhof
Settlement_Description: In 1409 margrave Jost grants Seeburg the Kammerhof as fiefdom.
Ferry_Description: The establishment of a ferry in Kammerhof led to a conflict with Werben, which had held ferry privileges since 1360. Since Seeburg and Werben could not reconcile themselves, the margrave decided in 1448 that the ferry operation in Kammerhof had to be stopped. It was continued at a later date.

Name: Haastrecht
Alternative_Name: Havekesdret; Hauekesdrecht; Hauekesdreht; Hauestrecht; Haestrecht; Haesdrecht
Settlement_Description: Haastdrecht is first mentioned in a twelfth-century copy of a 1108 text. The settlement originated around 1100 at the point were the river Vlist flows into the river Hollandse IJssel.
Town_Description: Cox argues that Haastrecht must have been granted town privileges before 24 May 1301. Possibly, this grant was received from Willem (II) Berthout, bishop of Utrecht.

Name: 's-Gravenzande
Alternative_Name: Harena comitis; Arenam sive vulgariter Zande; Grauenzande; Grauenzande, super Zande; sGravensande; tGravesande; Grauezande; Zande
Settlement_Description: 's-Gravenzande is first mentioned in 1200. The settlement originated on a sandbank. The counts of Holland built a house there.
Town_Description: 's-Gravenzande was granted town rights in May 1246 by Willem II, count of Holland, on the request of his widowed mother Mathilda ('Machteld') of Brabant. She also founded a beguinage in 's-Gravenzande (before 1255). 's-Gravenzande, however, did never really developed into a town.

Name: Goedereede
Alternative_Name: Goederreede; Goederede; Goerede; Goeree; Goede Reede
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of Goedereede is in 1312, when it was granted town rights.
Town_Description: Goedereede was granted town rights on 1 May 1312 by Gerard, lord of Voorne. The original charter has been lost; thanks to copies, the town rights are known.

Name: Heenvliet
Settlement_Description: Heenvliet is first mentioned in a fourteenth-century copy of a 1254 text.
Town_Description: Heenvliet was granted town rights on 20 March 1469 by Adriaan, lord of Cruyningen, of Heenvliet and of Woensdrecht. However, Heenvliet never really developed into a town.

Name: Geervliet
Settlement_Description: Geervliet is first mentioned in 1195. In the thirteenth century, the lords of Putten situated their court there.
Town_Description: Geervliet is granted town priviliges on 4 April 1381 by Sweder, lord of Abcoude-Gaesbeek, Putten and Strijen. During the reign of his successor and son, the town was surrounded by a stone wall.
Toll_Description: The Geervliet tol for sailing transport has its origin in the Carolingian period. It is the successor to a royal toll that was dependant of the former Dorestad toll. Originally the Geervliet tol was situated in Geervliet near the Bernisse river. It controlled the trafic coming from the North Sea towards the Netherlands going to Flanders, Brabant and Dordrecht via the rivers Meuse and Scheldt, moreover it controlled the traffic from the rivers Meuse, Waal and Rhine to Dordrecht, Flanders, Brabant and the North Sea. Because skippers tried to avoid the toll, outposts were situated in Sloecketers, Niervaert (Klundert), den Broeck, Hannekijnswairt, Rillant, Borsselshaec, Texel and Vlieland, and Enkhuizen. In the 16th century the toll was relocated to Dordrecht (the office was in the Joppens or Toll tower) because the Bernisse silted. Outposts werd situated then in Geervliet, on the Spui river near Hekelingen, and in Delfshaven, Schiedam, Geertruidenberg, Steenbergen, 's-Grevelduin-Kapelle, Leur, Strijen, Gastel, Oudenbosch, Rosendaal, Brielle, Maassluis, Zwartewaal, Goeree and Breda. The toll was founded and owned by (a predecessor of) the Count of Holland and after the Rebellion against Spain it was owned by the States of Holland and West-Friesland. Registers from the Geervliet toll are preserved for the years 1454, 1500, 1506, 1511, 1516, 1531-34, 1553, 1724 and 1769, 1780-1805 (complete toll), 1389 (branch Strienemonde, fragment),1771- 1795 (branch Rotterdam), 1729 – 1761 (branch Maassluis), 1621 (branch Pietershoek/land van Bonaventure), 1544-46 (for grain transports)

Bridge_Description: In 1723 the wooden bridges at the Seehäuser gate were exchanged for stone bridges.

Name: Woerden
Alternative_Name: Wirda; Uurdin; Worthen; Wrthen; Wourden; Worden; Wurdin
Settlement_Description: Woerden is first mentioned in a fifteenth-century copy of a documented written after 786. Settlement history, however, dates back to the Roman period. The remains of a Roman Limes fortress have been found. In 1159 a castle is built at that spot by the bishop of Utrecht, Godfrey van Rhenen.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted on 12 March 1372 by Albert I, duke of Bavaria, governor ('ruwaard') of Holland. Woerden had been fortified with stone town walls and a moat before 1372.

Name: Nieuwpoort
Alternative_Name: Nove Ville; Nova Villa; Nyewe poirt; Nyepoort; Niipoirt; Nuweport; Nieuw-poort; Nierporte; Nyeupoort; Nijepoort; Niupoort; Nypoort; Novae [portae]; Nieupoort
Settlement_Description: Nieuwpoort is first mentioned in a 1449 copy of a 1283 document.
Town_Description: Nieuwpoort was granted town rights in 1283, by Arnoud, lord of Liesveld, and Gijsbrecht, lord of Langerak. It thus became a codominium of the barons of Liesveld and the lords of Langerak. Possibly, earlier grants were made by their fathers. In 1489, the town walls and gates were destroyed. After have been besieged and burnt several times, Nieuwpoort is transformed into a fortress in 1672.

Name: Woudrichem
Alternative_Name: UUalderinghe[m]; Waldrichem; Woldrekem; Woldrichem; Woudrikem; Woirckum; Woerchem; Worcum; Worcom; Workum
Settlement_Description: The first mention of Woudrichem dates from the tenth to eleventh century.
Town_Description: Woudrichem was granted town rights before 28 March 1283. Most likely, this grant took place in the period between 1272 and 1283 and was issued by William II of Horne (Huis Horne), lord of Altena.

Name: Leerdam
Alternative_Name: Lerdamme; Lederdamme; Lederdam; Leyerdam; Leyderdam; Lyrdamme; Leijderdam
Settlement_Description: Leerdam is first mentioned in 1265.
Town_Description: Leerdam is mentioned as a town ('stede') in 1371, but was granted town rights on 11 November 1382 by Otto, lord of Arkel.

Name: Heusden
Settlement_Description: The name Heusden is first mentioned in 1108-1122, then spelled as 'Hysdene'. This, however, refers to present-day Oud-Heusden. In the thirteenth century, a new settlement originated near the local castle, which by 1250 had acquired the right of a fish market.
Town_Description: Heusden was probably granted town rights between 1286 (when it is mentioned as a 'oppidulum') and 1296 (when it is described as a 'civitatem'). These rights may have been granted by Jan (John) III of Heusden.

Name: Tholen
Settlement_Description: Tholen is first mentioned in 1261. It originates near a toll. In the early fourteenth century fortifications are added.
Town_Description: Tholen was granted town rights on 7 December 1366 by John of Blois, lord of Beaumont, Schoonhoven and Tholen. On 16 May 1452, a large fire swept through Tholen.

Name: Reimerswaal
Alternative_Name: Reimarswal; Reimerswala; Reimarswale; Remerswale; Rinmaswale; Remmerzwaelle; Remburswale; Rymerzwale; Reijmerwale; Remerswale
Settlement_Description: Reimerswaal is first mentioned in 1204.
Town_Description: Reimerswaal was granted town rights on 1 April 1375 by Albert ('Albrecht') of Bavaria, regent ('ruwaard') of Holland. In the sixteenth century Reimerswaal suffered from several storm surges, most notably the St. Felix's flood of 1530. Jacob van Deventer still drew the town as part of his town atlas around 1555, but in 1631, the remains of the city were deserted and claimed by the water.

Name: Hulst
Settlement_Description: Hulst is first mentioned in a fourteenth-century copy of document dated 1108.
Town_Description: Hulst was granted town privileges circa 1180.

Name: Oostburg
Alternative_Name: Osborch; Osburg; Ostburg; Ostburh; Oistburg; Oostburgh
Settlement_Description: In the period 879-918, a castle ('burcht') was built at the site of Oostburg as a defence against attacks by Norsemen. The first mention in written records dates from 949.
Town_Description: According to Cox, Oostburg was granted town rights before 1187 by Philip of Alsace, count of Flanders. The first mention as 'stad' (town) dates from 1174.

Name: Westkapelle
Alternative_Name: Westcapella; Westcappelam; Westcappalle; Weest Cappel; Weest Cappele; Westcappel; Westcapplen
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of Westkapelle dates from a twelfth-century copy of a document dated between 1102-1105, but it is known that a church was built in Westkapelle before 1050. Economically, the early settlement relied on agriculture and fishery.
Town_Description: Westkapelle was granted town rights in May 1223, but never fully developed into a town.

Name: Goes
Alternative_Name: Curtagosum; Cortagosum; Curtagosu; Gous; Gos; Goys; Gois
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Goes is first mentioned in 976. Cox seems to consider the subsequent mention in 1216 more trustworthy as a first mention.
Town_Description: From a juridical perspective, Goes became a town on 7 July 1405, via a statement of Willem VI, count of Holland en Zeeland. From a social-economic point of view, Goes may already be considered a town before that date. In 1417, Goes was granted the right to built fortifications.

Name: Sint Maartensdijk
Alternative_Name: Sint-Maartensdijk; St. Martendijk; Sinte Martijnsdike; Sente Mertinsdijcke; Sente Martensdijck; Sinte Martinsdijck; St. Maartensdijk; Sinte Martensdijck; Haestingen; Haestinghe; Aggeris D'Mar; Agger Sancti Martini; Sinte Martyns dike; Sente-Martijnsdijch; Sente Mairtyns dyc; Zinte Martynsdyc; Sinte Martynsdyc; Sinte Martyns dyke; Sinte Martynsdyck; Sinte Mertyns dyck; S. Martensdijck; Smeerdiek; St. Maartens dyk; Maartensdijk (St); Smeerdijk
Settlement_Description: Sint Maartensdijk is first mentioned in 1304.
Town_Description: Sint Maartensdijk was probably granted town privileges between 24 February and 9 June 1485 by Alienora van Borssele, lady of Sint Maartensdijk.

Name: Zierikzee
Alternative_Name: Siricasha; Sirikese; Zierikshe; Sirixe; Zirixe; Zierixzee; Zierick zee; Ziericzee; Zircxzee; De Stad Zierikzee; Ziricse
Settlement_Description: Zierikzee is first mentioned in a thirteenth-century copy of a document dated 1156. Zierikzee developped into a governmental centre of the count, and became a port and trading place.
Town_Description: Zierikzee was granted town privileges some time around 1220 (before May 1217, or May 1220- February 1222) by William I, count of Holland. The charter, however, has not survived. The earliest surviving charter dates from 11 March 1248.

Name: Brouwershaven
Alternative_Name: Brijdorpersluis; Brouwershavene; Dorp van Brouwershavene; Brouwerschaven; Brouwershaeven; Brouwershaue; Brouwershaviae
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, the first mention of Brouwershaven as 'Brijdorpersluis' dates from around 1305. Cox considers 1318 it's earliest mention, when the village is first called 'Brouwershavene'. Brouwershaven was founded on the initiative of the count of Holland and Zeeland from 1286 onward, in the 'ambacht' Brijdorp.
Town_Description: Brouwershaven was granted town privileges on 7 February 1403 by Albert I, duke of Bavaria, count of Holland and Zeeland. The charter mentions an earlier statute that must probably be dated before 1351.
Staple_Description: Brijdorp had a staple for beer from Holland.
Harbour_Description: Possibly, a harbour was already located here before 1286, but from 1286 onward, it was further developed.
Lock_Description: Possibly, a lock was already located here before 1286, but from 1286, it was further developed.

Name: Zevenbergen
Alternative_Name: Zeuenbercg; Zeuenberhg; Zeuenberghe; Zeuenberghen; Sevenbergen; Zevenberghen; Sevenberghen
Settlement_Description: Zevenbergen is first mentioned in 1288.
Town_Description: In 1369, Zevenbergen is still mentioned as a village. The first mention of Zevenbergen as a town dates from 14 september 1396. Town rights were thus granted some time between 1369 and 14 September 1396. Possibly, these rights were granted by Hugeman of Strijen, lord of Zevenbergen.

Name: Helmond
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of Helmond can be found in a twelfth-century copy of a documents dated 1108. Archaeological evidence indicates that a new settlement came into being east of the river Aa near the castle 't Oude Huys around 1225.
Town_Description: According to Cox, Helmond probably received town rights between 1225 and 28 May 1241. He states that it is most likely that this happened some time around 1232. Around 1400 stone town walls and a castle were built.

Name: Winsum
Alternative_Name: Uinchem; UUinkhem; Wincheim; VVinshem; Winzhem; Winchium; Wintzhamerhemme; Winzum; Wintzum; Winsem
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in tenth-eleventh century.

Name: Wachtendonk
Toll_Description: The Duke of Guelders levied a land toll for the first time around 1430. From 1473 to 1543, the Duke of Cleves held the toll. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Delfshaven
Alternative_Name: die nuwe haven van Delf; horer nieuwer haven; Nieuwe Have; Nyewe Haven; Delfschehave; Delfsche Haven; Delfschehavene; Delfshauen; Haven der Stadt Delf
Settlement_Description: Delfshaven is first mentioned at the end of the fourteenth century. The settlement originated near the canal Delfshavense Schie from Delft to the river Meuse that was meant to facilitate the transport of Delft's ale, that was dug in 1389. By Royal Decree of 31 July 1825 (issued by William I of the Netherlands), it was decided that Delfshaven would be allowed to call itself a town.

Name: Hagestein
Alternative_Name: Gaspewerde; Gaspward; Hagesteine; Hagesteyn; Gaspaarde; Haghensteyne; Hagensteyn; Gasperde; Hagesteijn; Hagesteyne
Settlement_Description: Hagestein is first mentioned in 1228. A castle was located in the village. After this castle and the town were demolished in 1405, a new castle was build from around 1546. It was accompanied by a modest settlement.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted to Hagestein on 11 November 1382 by Otto, lord of Arkel. In 1405 the town and castle were sieged, captured, and demolished.

Name: Sint Anna ter Muiden
Alternative_Name: Muda; Mude; Anna-ter-Mu; St. Anna ter Muiden
Settlement_Description: Sint Anna ter Muiden is first mentioned in 1242.
Town_Description: Sint Anna ter Muiden was granted town privileges in March 1242 by Thomas (II) of Savoye, count of Flanders, and Joan of Constantinople, countess of Flanders. Sint Anna ter Muiden was an outport of Brugges. In the thirteenth century, the port was troubled by progressive silting of the Zwin. Furthermore, it experienced growing competition from Sluis.

Name: Biervliet
Settlement_Description: In the years around 1180, Philip of Alsace, count of Flanders, initiated a settlement called Damme. According to Cox, it is quite possible that he was also involved in setting up Biervliet at the same time. In written records, Biervliet is first mentioned in a thirteenth-century copy of a document dated 1183.
Town_Description: According to Cox, town rights were granted before 1183 by Philip of Alsace, count of Flanders. Van Berkel & Samplonius state that town rights were granted in 1183. Biervliet was located at the Braakman, which made it into a prosperous trading town. The town, however, was also fulnarable to floodings and storm surges. J. Buisman describes that severe land loss occured in the fifteenth century, reducing it to a tiny island. In the sixteenth and seventeenth century, land reclaimations began. In 1702, a dike to IJzendijke, reconnected Biervliet to the mainland.

Name: Lathen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the possession of the monastery Corvey in 884.
Toll_Description: A toll of the bishop of Münster in Lathen is mentioned in 1613.

Name: Ihrhove
Settlement_Description: The church was built in the mid-13th century.

Name: Wiltshausen
Settlement_Description: A ferry house was built in 1562.
Ferry_Description: Ferry across the Leda river. A ferry house was built in 1562.

Name: Terneuzen
Alternative_Name: Nose; Terneuse; Terneusen; Noesen; Neusen; ter Neuze; Stadt Neuze
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Terneuzen is first mentioned in 1340. Cox adheres to a slightly earlier date, 1325. The settlement originated near a waterway to Gent. During the Eighty Years War, Terneuzen became an important fortified town.
Town_Description: On 23 April 1584, Terneuzen was granted town privileges by William I, prince of Orange. Many of these privileges were granted because the inhabitants of Terneuzen could no longer go to the city of Axel for commerce and juridical matters, as Axel had become Spanish property. Afterwards, Terneuzen kept these privileges. Terneuzen was elevated to city rank by Royal Decree in 1816.

Name: Axel
Alternative_Name: Axla; villa Axala; Axele; Acsla; Acselle; Axellen
Settlement_Description: Axel is first mentioned in a eleventh-century copy of a document dated between 987 and 994.
Town_Description: According to Cox, Axel was granted town privileges in 1183 by Philip of Alsace, count of Flanders. The charter, however, has not survived. A later charter (dated 1532) refers to another grant of town rights, in 1213 by Ferdinand, count of Flanders, and Joan (of Constantinople), countess of Flanders.

Name: Sas van Gent
Alternative_Name: Tzas; t Zas van Gendt; 't Sas van Gendt; 't Sas van Gent; Tsasensis
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Sas van Gent is first mentioned in 1573. Cox chooses a later date, 1583. The Heemkundige Kring Sas van Gent (the local history association), however, states that the settlement came into being about the same time that building works on the lock were finished, in 1563. In 1572, the settlement and the lock were destroyed after they were conquered by Watergeuzen. This, however, was not the end of the settlement. Although Sas van Gent was not granted town privileges before the nineteenth century, its position and legal behaviour were town-like (leading to complaints of the States of Zeeland). Sas van Gent was elevated to town rank in 1816 by William I, king of the Netherlands.
Harbour_Description: With the construction of the Sassevaart in 1549, Sas van Gent became the sea harbour of Gent.

Name: Philippine
Alternative_Name: Philippijne; Philippijnen; Filippine; Sainct Philippine; Phillipijne
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1505.
Town_Description: The earliest mention of Philippine dates from 1505/1506. In this period the walled town was founded in a newly constructed polder. At its foundation, Philippine was granted town rights. In the 1630s, it became a fortified town. From 1635 onwards, it also became a traders' town of some importance.

Name: Kortgene
Alternative_Name: Cortkeen; Cortekene; Kortekine; Cortekine; Coirtkene; Cortkene; De Stadt Kortgeen
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Kortgene is first mentioned in 1247. Cox argues for a slightly earlier date, 1217. In 1413 town walls and gates were built.
Town_Description: Kortgene is first mentioned as a town on 6 December 1421. An official charter granting town rights has not survived. However, town privileges were probably granted by Philip of Borselen ('Filips van Borselen'), lord of Kortgene. During a flood in 1532, Kortgene was drowned. In 1681, the town was again reclaimed from the sea.

Name: Domburg
Alternative_Name: Dumburch; Domburch infra castellum; Cumburgh infra castellum; Dumborgh extra castellum; Comburgh
Settlement_Description: In the vicinity of the modern town Domburg, another traders' settlement was located in the years around 200. This settlement, however, dissappeared into the sea. Archeological remains of a castle ('ringburcht') have been found. This castle was built shortly after 885. The first mention of Domburg in written records dates from the period 1181-1210.
Town_Description: 'Dumburgh infra castellum' (located in the east) was granted town rights between 25 December 1222 and 24 December 1223 by Floris IV, count of Holland, and Dirk, lord of Voorne and burgrave of Zeeland. 'Dumburgh extra castellum' (located in the west) was excluded from these town rights. Domburg never fully developed into a town.

Name: Arnemuiden
Alternative_Name: Arnemuda; Arnemeuden; Aernemuden; Arnemuden; Armuden; Armuijden; Armuyen; Armuyden
Settlement_Description: Arnemuiden is first mentioned in 1223.
Town_Description: Arnemuiden was granted town privileges by William I, Prince of Orange, on 15 June 1574. In 1816, Arnemuiden was also elevated to city rank.

Name: Hughevliet
Settlement_Description: The exact location of the settlement is unknown, as it ceased to exist in 1404 when it drowned due to a storm surge.
Town_Description: According to Cox, town rights were granted in the thirteenth century. The exact location of the town is unknown, as it ceased to exist in 1404 when it drowned due to a storm surge.

Name: Steenbergen
Alternative_Name: Steinberghe; Stenberghe; Steenberghen; Steemberghen; Stenberghen; Stienberghe; Steenbergensis
Settlement_Description: Steenbergen is first mentioned in 1267. The settlement is granted various privileges in the late thirteenth and early fourteenth century. The inhabitants also gain the right to built a stone wall around their settlement. However, in 1337, Steenbergen is still called a 'dorp' (village).
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted between 1337 and 1345 by Mathilde ('Machtild'') of Wezemaal, lady of Bergen op Zoom, and John III, duke of Brabant and lord of Breda. A charter has not survived. 1345 is the first mention of Steenbergen as a town.

Name: Willemstad
Alternative_Name: Willems stad; De Ruigenhil; Willemstat; Wilm stat
Settlement_Description: The first mention of Willemstad dates from 2 March 1584. However, the settlement originated in 1565. Then, it was called De Ruigenhil. Later, it was transformed into a fortified town and became known as Willemstad.
Town_Description: On 12 August 1586, Willemstad is granted town rights by Maurice, prince of Orange, and Marquess of Bergen op Zoom.

Name: Klundert
Alternative_Name: die Clunder; den noordt clundert; zuytclundert; opte Clundert; de Clundert; den Cleundairt; den Clundert;
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of Klundert dates from 1537 (according to Van Berkel & Samplonius; Cox takes 1525 as the earliest mention). However, this mention is probably related to the building of a dike in a polder, rather than an actual settlement. Cox states that in 1561 some families were living there.
Town_Description: Although no official grant of town privileges is known to have existed, Klundert developped into a town in the period 1578-1582 during the reign of William, prince of Oranje, lord of Niervaart. In 1582, the town is walled.

Name: Oosterhout
Alternative_Name: Hosterholte; Osterholt; Hosterhout; Hoesterhout; Oesterhout; Ostrout; Oestrout; Oesterhoudt; Ostorol
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Oosterhout is first mentioined in 1156. Cox takes 815 as the earliest mention (in a 1170 copy). In the seventeenth century, Oosterhout tried to claim town status. To this end, town grants from the 1100s-1300s were forged. These attempts, however, did not succeed. Oosterhout, was elevated to town rank on 3 May 1809 by Louis Bonaparte, king of Holland.

Name: Waalwijk
Alternative_Name: Walwic; Walewich; Walewyc; Wallewyc; Waelwyc; Walewyck; Waelwyck; Waelwijc; Waelwiic
Settlement_Description: The first mention of Waalwijk dates from 1200 (in a 1305 copy of the document).
Town_Description: Town privileges were granted on 17 December 1303 by John II, duke of Brabant. However, it never fully developed into a town.

Name: Oss
Settlement_Description: Oss is first mentioned in a twelfth-century copy of a document dated 6 May 1069. This document also mentions a church in the settlement.
Town_Description: Oss was granted town privileges on 14 October 1399 by Joanna, duchess of Brabant.

Name: Megen
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of Megen is a 1191 copy of a document dated 721-722. Archeological findings, however, indicate habitation during the Roman era.
Town_Description: Megen is already mentioned as a town in the period 1325-1350, but the earliest known grant of town rights dates from January 1357. These were granted by William, count of Megen, and Helwige, countess of Megen. Megen was surround by earth and stone walls.

Name: Ravenstein
Settlement_Description: Ravenstein originates near a castle built around 1360.
Town_Description: Ravenstein was granted town rights on 4 May 1380 by Reinoud of Valkenburg, lord of Ravenstein.

Name: Wessem
Alternative_Name: Wisheim; Wesheim; Wishem; Wissen; Weshem; Wysheim; Wishem; Wesshem
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of Wessem can be found in an eleventh- to twelfth-century copy of a document dated 965. By 1119 a toll and a port are mentioned.
Town_Description: Wessem was never officially granted town rights, but slowly developed into a town. It received several town(-like) privileges from the lords of Horne (Huis Horne) before 1329. On 27 April 1329, Wessem is first mentioned as a town.

Name: Malburgse veer
Ferry_Description: Ferry near Malburgen ('Malburgse veer').

Bridge_Description: In 1547 the bridge was moved to the current position at the end of the Ludwigsstraße in order to better defend the town during the Schmalkalden war.

Name: Tauschwitz
Settlement_Description: In 1313 Pforta monastery gains full jurisdiction over the village, but Tauschwitz is deserted today. The date of its desertion is unknown. There used to be extensive viniculture.
Ferry_Description: A ferry in Tauschwitz is mentioned in 1323.

Name: Eijsden
Alternative_Name: In procaspide [in loco Aspide]; Espede; Espide; Espithe; Espethe; Esde; Espde; Eessden; Esdem; Eisden; Eesden; Haspere; Aspre; Eysden in den Dael; Asple
Settlement_Description: The first mention of Eijsden probably dates from 870 (in a sixteenth-century copy of the document). Its subsequent mention dates from 1168-1174. From the eleventh until thirteenth century, Eijsden and neighbouring settlement Breust were central to the cultivation of the Plateau of Margraten. The history of several villages there, can be traced back to either Eijsden or Breust.
Town_Description: Whether Eijsden was officially granted town rights, remains a matter of historical debate. Eijsden itself was never called a 'stad' (town), but has always been refered to as a 'vrijheid'. On the other hand, Eijsden did have a town-like character. The 'vrijheidsboek', the source that contained the rights of Eijsden, is seen by some as a town rights charter. Hans van Hall dates this book to 1321, Jan Hartmann states that it originated in the middle of the thirteenth century. In 2011, Van Hall argued that Eijsden should be seen as a 'dwergstadje' (dwarf town) or borough ('Minderstadt'). Eijsden did have an earth wall as fortifications and a moat. In 1632, a castle was built.

Harbour_Description: River harbour on the Rhine. A ship crane is mentioned in 1585, which was replaced by a fixed crane before 1626.

Bridge_Description: Oldest Ilm crossing in Weimar, a wooden bridge was erected before 1430. In 1613 the wooden bridge was destroyed and replaced by a stone bridge in 1618, which was destroyed again in 1689, until it was re-erected in 1749.
The bridge Bolbrugge across the Mühlenteich connected the town with the mainland. It is first mentioned in 1340.

Lock_Description: A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed near Plate on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.
A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed in Banzkow on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.
A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed as "Stuken sluse" near Stuck on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.
A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed as "Foien kercker sluse" near Maliß on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.
A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed as "Gam sluse" on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.
A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed as "Spitz sluse" on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.
A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed as "Heit sluse" on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.

A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed as "Finde wi uns hir sluse" near the mill Findenwirunshier on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.
A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed as "Snaken sluse" on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.
A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed as "Walck sluse" on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.

Settlement_Description: A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed as "Holt sluse" on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.

Lock_Description: A lock in the canal between the Elbe and the Schwerin lake, which was built between 1568 and 1572, is displayed as "Steinsluse von Döms" ('stone lock of Dömitz') on a map of the canal by Daniel Frese from 1605.

Bridge_Description: A fixed crossing of the Unstrut is mentioned in 1288, before a ferry or ford can be assumed.

Name: Kloster Homburg
Settlement_Description: The monastery was given property around 1100 and was probably founded before. Near the monastery, a battle between rebelling Thuringians and Saxonians and king Henry IV. took place in 1075. After that, the former convent of nuns was converted into a monastery of Benedictine monks in 1136. It was destroyed during the Peasant's war and finally sold and demolished in 1544.

Toll_Description: On the Merxleben bridge a bridge toll had been collected "for a long time" by the town of Langensalza until it was given to the town lord in 1668. A bridge house and a bridge tower existed.

Harbour_Description: According to a falsified charter from 1188, Lübeck had the privilege of shipping on the Wakenitz and the Ratzeburg lake until Ratzeburg. These privileges were confirmed in 1226. A document from 1439 mentions the harbour to have been located west of the cathedral island; a view of the town from 1588, however, displays boats near the long bridge east of town.
Shipping on the Wakenitz between Lübeck and Ratzeburg has been attested since 1188. The Wakenitz harbour in Lübeck must have been located near the Hüxter gate.

Name: Grieth
Toll_Description: The Duke of Kleve levied a river toll on the Rhine here from 1472 to 1485. The toll was in Büderich before and after that. The same tariffs therefore apply as in Büderich. In 1481, 5200 guilders were collected. Actually, the toll was to be moved to Grieth as early as 1336 - but this did not happen. The transfer of the customs in 1472 was justified by the fact that toll evasions were increasing in Büderich.

Name: Kloster Donndorf
Settlement_Description: Convent of Cistercian nuns. It was badly damaged during the Peasant's War and dissolved in 1540. The last abbess is said to have died in 1561.

Name: Burg Wendelstein
Settlement_Description: The castle was inherited in 1322. Reports, which see its erection in 1332 are likely to have been extensions. It suffered some damages in the 30-year-war and after some time of lesser meaning, it mostly decayed until 1958. Some parts are being restored today.

Bridge_Description: In 1207 there's already mention of a bridge built on stone pillars.

Harbour_Description: As seen on a map from Braun and Hogeberg of 1590, the harbour place "Zu den Stiegen" was accessible directly from the market place. Due to its location on small old Rhine arms, it was only usable for smaller boats.

In front of the Rhine gate, the large harbour place of the town Neuss was located. The town map of Braun and Hogeberg from 1590 shows a ship crane here, which is first attested in 1400. According to a description from 1670, larger Rhine barges could not get closer to town on this Rhine arm.

Ferry_Description: A ferry between Neuss and Düsseldorf is first mentioned in 1262. On the Neuss side, it was connected to the farm Kothausen at the Heerdter Busch. Since 1315 the ferry was owned by the Clarist monastery in Neuss.
Harbour_Description: Due to changes in the course of the Rhine in the Middle Ages, Neuss became located on old Rhine arms that slowly silted up, making it ever more difficult for ships to get close to the town. In situations with low water levels, the ship crane of Neuss, normally located near the Rhine gate, was even moved to the Rhine shore near the ferry to Hamm, as is for example shown on a drawing from 1621.

Bridge_Description: A wooden bridge is renewed in 1573, which had to be renovated again in 1589 and built in oak wood. It was destroyed during the 30-year war in 1636 but rebuilt almost immediately.

Ferry_Description: The ferry privileges of Neuss were divided in two parts by the end of the 13th century. Next to the ferry in Hamm, another ferry was connected to the farm Hüchelheim near Grimlinghausen.

Bridge_Description: A stone Saale bridge was erected in the 13th century.

Toll_Description: Hermann of Gommern and his sons give the cistercian convent Plötzky property, as well as a toll on the Elbe river since it "had been like this since old times" in 1330. The toll therefore probably existed for longer.

Name: Enumatil
Alternative_Name: Enematil; Enema tylle; Eenematijll; Emonis pontem; Eemetil; Eme Til; Eem-til; Ema-Til
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1456.
Bridge_Description: The settlement developed next to a bridge ('til') across the Hoendiep, from which the name was derived.

Name: Crossen (Elster)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 995

Bridge_Description: The first evidence for a bridge near the mill weir, the place of an old ford in the Ems, dates from 1362. With the extension of the town walls around 1450, the bridge must have been moved to the current location at the Emsstraße. The wooden bridge had to be repaired or rebuilt numerous times in the 17th century.

Name: Spier
Alternative_Name: Spehoerne; Spehorne; Spehoren; Spehoern; Spirhoern; Spirhoren; Spyrhoren; Spijr; Spyer; Spyr; Spyerhoerne
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1212.

Name: Merkwitz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1266.

Name: Sint Servaasbrug
Bridge_Description: A bridge crossing the Meuse River in Maastricht existed from the Roman period onwards. This bridge, however, was located slightly further south than the present-day Sint Servaasbrug. In 1267, it was destructed in warfare; the bridge was restored, but this was not done properly. In 1275, the restored wooden bridge collapsed during a religious procession, causing many people to drown in the Meuse. After this, a new, stone bridge was built: the present-day Sint Servaasbrug. Construction works started in 1281 and were finished before 1300.

Lock_Description: The map of Mecklenburg included in the atlas of Janssonius from 1622 shows a lock near Blücher in the Schaale canal, which was built in 1564.
The map of Mecklenburg included in the atlas of Janssonius from 1622 shows a lock near Bennin in the Schaale canal, which was built in 1564.
The map of Mecklenburg included in the atlas of Janssonius from 1622 shows a lock south of Vietow in the Schaale canal, which was built in 1564.
The map of Mecklenburg included in the atlas of Janssonius from 1622 shows a lock north of Vietow in the Schaale canal, which was built in 1564.
The map of Mecklenburg included in the atlas of Janssonius from 1622 shows a lock near Kogel in the Schaale canal, which was built in 1564.
The map of Mecklenburg included in the atlas of Janssonius from 1622 shows a lock near Pamprin in the Schaale canal, which was built in 1564.

Name: Yerseke
Alternative_Name: Gersake; Gersicha; Gersecha; Gerseca; Jheersic; Yersicken
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention 966 has been added ca. 1000 in a fifteenth century copy. Next mention in 980, in a fifteenth century copy. The next mention is in 1186.

Name: Varrelgraben
Alternative_Name: Verlgraven; Verlergraven; Varlgrafen; Verthelgraben; Varlegraven; Verlegraven; Ferlegraven
Settlement_Description: Settlement at the stream Varrelgraben on the border between Bremen and Delmenhorst territory, first mentioned in 1338. It often functioned as a meeting place for negotiations between Bremen and Oldenburg.
Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Varrelgraben must have been built at the latest around 1311, when Bremen and the count of Delmenhorst agreed that the road between Delmenhorst and Bremen was to be maintained for traffic.

Name: Limmen
Alternative_Name: Limbon; Limben; Limban; Linbon; Lymmen; Lijmmen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 918-948, in an 11th-century copy.

Name: Krommenie
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1317. The name is derived from the water Krommenie, which is first mentioned in 1276.

Name: Molletjesveer
Ferry_Description: A ferry crossing at this point became required after the canal Nauernasche Vaart was dug. The licence for the ferry was granted in 1634.

Name: Schloß Broich
Toll_Description: The settlement of Broich itself probably had a land toll, which is documented in 1250. This was probably levied by the Lord of Broich. Tariffs and revenues are not known. It is possible that it was a land toll at the Ruhr crossing, but its existence after 1250 can no longer be proven. It was not until the 18th century that a land toll was again established in Broich.

Name: Santpoort
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1389.

Name: Bockenheimer Warte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the enclosure ('landwehr') of Frankfurt, built in 1434/5.

Name: Galluswarte
Settlement_Description: Watchtower in the enclosure ('landwehr') of Frankfurt, built in 1396.

Name: Buiksloot
Alternative_Name: Bukesloot; Bueke Sloot; Buyck sloot; Boekesloot; Beuckelssloot; Boekelsloot
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1544.

Name: Oudshoorn
Alternative_Name: Ousthorne; Houtshorne; Outshorne; Outshoerne; Outhooren; Outshoorn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1305.

Toll_Description: Hausberge was a toll station at the Weser river, mentioned in a 1584 complaint from Bremen and in a 1597 charter of the monastery Hardehausen.

Name: Niervaart
Settlement_Description: The exact location of the former village and town of Niervaart is unknown. Generally, it is assumed to have been located about 2 kilometers east of Klundert. Klundert arose after Niervaart had ceased to exist. Niervaart is first mentioned in 1290.
Town_Description: Niervaart was granted town(-like) privileges on 7 September 1357 by Aleid (Adelaide), lady of Putten en Strijen. Between 1421-1450, Niervaart ceased to exist as a consequence of several floods.

Name: Langenholzhausen
Alternative_Name: Holthusen; Langenholthusen; Langen Holthosen; Langen Holthusen; Langhenholthusen; Langhe Holthusenn; Langennholthusenn; Holdthusen; Langennholtzhaußenn; Langenholdtzhausen; Langennholtzhausen; Langenholtzhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as Holthusen in 1244. The settlement consisted of three parts: Langen-, Overen- and Nederenholthusen, of which the latter two later merged with the former.

Name: Möllenbeck (Schaumburg)
Alternative_Name: Möllenbeck; Mulinpeche; Mulinbechi; Mulinbeche; Mulenbeche; Molenbecke; Mollenbecke; Mulenbike; Molenbek; Mollenbeke; Mollenbeck
Settlement_Description: A monastery of Augustianian Canonesses was founded shortly before 896. After having become Lutheran, the monastery was converted into a manor in 1649. An accompanying settlement, which is characterised as borough ('oppidum') in 1353 and 1355 and as village in 1361, seems to have been abandoned at multiple points in time in the late 14th and 15th centuries. The market church was demolished in 1448.

Name: Bösingfeld
Alternative_Name: Bosincvelde; Bosinguelde; Bozinckffelde; Bozincvelt; Bozingeuelde; Bossinguelde; Bosingvelden; Bosingkfelde; Bosingfelt; Boßingesuelde; Bosinckueldt; Bösinckfelde; Böesingfelde; Bosinghfelde
Settlement_Description: The first mention of 1224 indicates the existence of a castle of the count of Sternberg. A planned town was built around 1300, but it remained a borough ('flecken'). The settlement was destroyed and abandoned in a feud in 1424, and only resettled in 1492.

Name: Barntrup
Settlement_Description: The original settlement was located southeast of the current centre. Between 1225 and 1317, a new planned settlement was built by the count of Sternberg at the current location, where it is first mentioned in 1317 as "oppidum".
Town_Description: First characterised as town in 1366, Barntrup received Lemgo town privileges in 1376. However, it retained the character of a borough.

Name: Humfeld
Alternative_Name: Humuelde; Honvelde; Luttekenhunvelde; Luttyckenhontvelde; Hunvelde; Hunevelde; Obernhumfelde; superiori Hunvelde; inferiori Hunvelde; Overenhunvelde; Nederenhunvelde; Overenhummelvelde; Nedderenhummelvelde; Humvelde; Overenhumveld; Nederenhumvelde; Hundtfeldt; Hunfeldt; Hunefeld; Hümfeld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1259, the settlement consisted of two parts: Overen- and Nederenhumvelde. It was partly abandoned in the 15th century, and resettled in 1467.

Ferry_Description: As a consequence of war activities, the location of the ferry moved from a more upstream location to a location in front of the town gate called 'Koepoort' ('Cow gate'). The ferry was owned by the land lord. In 1583, the ferry right was leased out on a long lease to the town of Doesburg.

The ferry near Dieren is one of the oldest ferries in the region. It is first mentioned in 1269. At least in the thirteenth century, it is owned by the Teutonic Order. Over the centuries, the Teutonic Order preserves ownership of half of the ferry rights. Originally, the ferry served long distance traffic, but after the establishment of a ferry in front of Doesburg in the fourteenth century, it must have lost this position and probably mainly served farmers.

Bridge_Description: The land between Doesburg and Ellecom-Dieren went through wetlands. Before the end of the sixteenth century, there was a ford between Doesburg and Ellecom. At high water levels, a bridge located next to it could be used. Around 1597, this ford was no longer usable. The maintenance of the bridge was a cause of conflict for several years, but traffic managed to find a temporary route around it. The bridge was replaced by a ferry in 1672. In 1698, it was replaced by a bridge again. The chosen location of the ford/bridge on the map may not be exactly right for the period 1350-1650.

Toll_Description: A toll ('bruggeld'/'weggeld') had to be paid to pass the bridge.
Bridge_Description: The bridge was maintained by the lord of Keppel.

Toll_Description: Toll on the Elbe river in Dömitz. For details, see Dömitz main node.

Name: Tiefenort
Settlement_Description: First mention in the record book of Henneberg.
Bridge_Description: The bridge is mentioned since 1330.

Name: Furth (Neuss)
Toll_Description: Secondary toll station of the land toll of Neuss, first mentioned in 1386. It is last mentioned in 1789. 4 alb. per horse had to be paid.

Name: Derikum
Toll_Description: Secondary toll station of the land toll of Neuss, which is attested for the period 1560-1793. It was also often called Norf after the neighbouring village.

Lock_Description: One of seven locks in the Fulda river between Kassel and Hersfeld, which were built by landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel in a campaign to make the Fulda navigable. Regulations from 1613 specify the lock fee at 2 Alben. At each lock, it was checked whether the toll for the cargo had been paid in Kassel.

Name: Melsungen
Alternative_Name: Elesenga in pago Hassim; Milisunge; major Milsungen; Milsungen
Settlement_Description: There is evidence of a settlement dating back to the 10th century, perhaps 973.
Town_Description: The town was founded in the 13th century. 1267 'civitas' and 'burgenses'.

Toll_Description: A bridge toll was levied at the bridge from the 14th century.
Ferry_Description: After the destruction of the bridge in 1635, it was replaced by a ferry.
Bridge_Description: A wooden bridge across the Ruhr was first mentioned in 1282. It was replaced by a stone construction in the 14th century. The bridge was destroyed by the archbishop of Cologne in 1583, but restored before 1591. During the Thirty Years' War, the bridge was destroyed in 1635 and replaced by a ferry. A new bridge was only built in the 19th century.
A bridge across the Ruhr in Wetter is first mentioned in 1605. This was a wooden construction on ten pillars.

Toll_Description: In 1421, toll rights were granted to Herdecke, which according to the document had existed "since time immemorial". The aforementioned bridge toll was presumably levied as early as 1392. In 1421, Duke Adolf of Kleve-Mark transferred the bridge toll to Herdecke Hospital. Tariffs and revenues are not known.
Bridge_Description: Written evidence for the existence of a Ruhr bridge in Herdecke first appears in the 13th century, when it became property of the Herdecke monastery. At the end of the 14th century, the bridge belonged to the counts of Cleves-Mark. In 1410, the bridge was apparently destroyed, since a new bridge with stone pillars was to be built, which only happened in 1421. The bridge was destroyed by floods in 1514 and rebuilt afterwards.

Name: Jägerbrücke
Bridge_Description: A stone bridge in Arnsberg was built by Elector Salentin in 1575. It was destroyed by floods in 1619. A new wooden bridge was only built in 1655.

Name: Struth
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1125.

Toll_Description: Toll on the Weser river, which is mentioned in a 1584 complaint from Bremen. Toll accounts exist from the year 1565 onwards (Landesarchiv NRW, Detmold). These have been analysed by Korinth.

Name: Heyerode
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1363.

Name: Dronrijp
Alternative_Name: Dronryp; Dennigrip; Drenningrip; Drunryp; Op die Ryp
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1132 in a falsification of the second half of the thirteenth century. The next mention dates probably from 1243.

Name: Marssum
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in the thirteenth century.

Name: Easterwierrum
Alternative_Name: Oosterwierum; Aesterwerum; Werum; Aesterwerim; Osterwerum; Oesterwerum; Eesterwerum
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1319.

Name: Waltershausen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1209, when landgrave Hermann I. protested aginst the market in Friedrichsroda. A foundation in Frankish times seems possible.
Town_Description: First mention as town in 1357, town rights were granted in the 14th century. In 1441 the town privileges are confirmed.
Toll_Description: 1410 Waltershausen in granted safe conduct and toll privileges like Gotha.

Name: Haskerhorne
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1333.

Name: Oudehaske
Alternative_Name: Hasca; Haschera munkam; Aelde Hascha; Olde Haske; Althasck; Olde Hassche
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1315.

Name: Sint Nicolaasga
Alternative_Name: Sint NikAd sanctum Nycolaum; Sanctonicolao; Sinte Nyclaesga; Sanct Nyclaes gae
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 13th century.

Name: Oudeschoot
Alternative_Name: Aldskoat; Scoeten; Schote; Scote; Scoten; Schoten;Aldeschot
Settlement_Description: In 1299, a women's monastery of the Teutonic Order was founded in Oudeschoot. The monastery was abolished in 1580.

Name: Donkerbroek
Alternative_Name: Dombroek; Duncbrueck; Dumbraech; Dongbroec; Dumbroeck; Dunckerbroeck; Dombroeck; Donckerbrouck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1408.

Name: Stiens
Alternative_Name: Steninge; Steynsinghum; Stienzede; Steenzede; Stenze; Steens; Stienze; Steenze; Steensse; Steninge; Steens
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in thirteenth century.

Name: Tjerkwerd
Alternative_Name: Tsjerkwert; Kercwere; Kercwerve; Kerkwerc; Kerkwert; Kercward; Karcwarde; Kercwaerd; Kercweer; Tzerckwert; Iterwert; 'tZerkwert; Tjerckwert
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 13th century.

Bridge_Description: The bridge across the Ifta marked the border of safe conduct between Hessia and Saxonia.

Name: Apolda
Alternative_Name: Appolde; Appoltre; Apold; Apoldia; Apollo; Apoldau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1119. Castle and corresponding village (seat of the county lords).
Town_Description: First referred to as civitas in 1308. Elevation to town by the cupbearers of Apolda, who died out in the 14th century. Since then the Wettins were the de facto town lords, even if Mainz held some claims to it until 1666.

Name: Berga (Elster)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1267. The settlement or its mill respectively are mentioned in 1306.
Town_Description: Referred to as opidum in 1378, in 1386 as town ('stat'). Town rights developed in the 14th century, which were confirmed in 1427 by Henry of Weida. Market settlement.
Fair_Description: In 1427 three fairs and a weekly market are known in Berka, a fourth fair followed in 1653.

Name: Bad Berka
Settlement_Description: First mention as a church village, 1300 referred to as villa, in 1367 as village. At the end of the 13th century a castle is built that is seat of the family of Witzleben, but it is destroyed between 1608 and 1633.
Town_Description: 1414 first mention as town, but it is also still called a village and a borough ('Flecken') until the 18th century. In 1592 the town was granted bylaws.

Name: Bad Blankenburg
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1208 in a record in which the surrounding area is given to the counts of Schwarzburg by Otto IV. First mention of the castle in 1280.
Town_Description: First mention of the town in 1323, but it probably already developed in the middle of the 13th century. A council constitution is known since the end of the 14th century.

Name: Bürgel
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1133 as the foundation of a Benedictine monastery.
Town_Description: The town of Bürgel, which was founded by the monastery, is first mentioned 1234 and lay on the right bank of the Gleiße. In 1307 it is referred to as civitas. A council is first mentioned in 1360. The monastery is dissolved in 1526 and its property as well as the town are made a electoral-saxonian district.

Name: Eisenberg (Thüringen)
Settlement_Description: In 1171 the construction of town fortifications is reported (at the same time as Leipzig and Freiberg).
Town_Description: Before 1219 a new town is founded, in 1256 the citizens own the town sigil. The first recording of town rights stems from 1563 but they were probably adapted in the 15th century.

Name: Friedrichroda
Settlement_Description: Mention in 1209 when landgrave Hermann I. wanted to destroy the market in Friedrichroda, because it allegedly damaged his own towns.
Town_Description: In 1597 the settlement was granted townrights.

Name: Geisa
Settlement_Description: Abbot Bertho II. of Fulda founded the market settlement next to the old settlement and had it fortified.
Town_Description: Elevated to town in the first half of the 14th century. The town rights were probably similar to the town rights in Fulda.

Name: Greiz
Alternative_Name: Grouz; Grewcz; Groucze; Grewtz; Greutz; Groytz
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1209, first mention of the castle and church in Greiz in 1225.
Town_Description: First mention of the town in 1359. The oldest town privileges stem from 1527, the oldest town rights only from 1672.

Toll_Description: There was a toll on the lower bridge.
Bridge_Description: Two bridges led across the Weiße Elster.

Name: Großbreitenbach
