Settlement_Description: First mention in 1399
Town_Description: Since the 16th century, the settlement was a market borough, by the end of the 16th century it was also referred to as town borough. It was only granted town rights in 1855 though.
Fair_Description: In 1586 three fairs and cattle markets are mentioned.

Name: Großenehrich
Alternative_Name: Ehrriche; Erichi; Heriki; Erick; Ericha; Irrichen
Settlement_Description: Mention in a gift certificate to Fulda monastery. Mention as borough ('Flecken') in 1469, as market borough in 1500.
Town_Description: Referred to as town in 1521, until the end of the 16th century simultaneous mention as market borough. Since 1521 a council is known.

Name: Heldburg
Settlement_Description: Mention in a gift certificate to Fulda monastery.
Town_Description: The foundadtion of the town goes back to 1390, in 1396 a council constitution ('Ratsverfassung') is known. Until the middle of the 15th century it is referred to as borough ('Flecken') and little town ('Städtchen') interchangibly. In 1423 Hildburghausen town rights, in 1457 Coburg town rights are known.

Name: Königsee
Alternative_Name: Kunigesse; Kunegesse; Cungesse; Koningisse; Kongeßee; Konigsehe
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1199 as owning parish rights.
Town_Description: Probably earned town rights in the first half of the 13th century by the counts of Schwarzburg. In 1257 citizens (cives) are mentioned, in 1287 town rights are mentioned. In 1365 town rights are based on the bylaws of Stadtilm from 1350. Since 1342 a council is known.
Fair_Description: Since 1365 fairs are proven.

Name: Lobeda
Settlement_Description: Mention of a noble of Louede in 1156, but his ties to Lobeda aren't entirely sure. Since 1213 a clergyman of Lobeda is known.
Town_Description: First mention of a town (civitas) in 1284, founded by the lords of Lobdeburg. In 1404 two mayors are mentioned, in 1407 the bylaws are confirmed (this record is lost, other bylaws remain from 1456).

Name: Lucka
Settlement_Description: Mention in 1307 as a village, raised to marketplace between 1307 and 1320. Referred to as oppidum in 1320.
Town_Description: In 1409 the settlement is granted the privileges, bylaws and municipal court, which it asks to have renewed in 1474.
Toll_Description: In 1347 the "house of Breitenhain, the small town of Lucka with their toll" are sold by the Wettins to the counts of Starkenberg. Even before it can be assumed that the settlement was a toll station for the castle of Breitenhain.

Name: Magdala
Settlement_Description: First mention in 874.
Town_Description: The town foundation occurred between 1284 and 1288 by the counts of Orlamünde. It is referred to as civitas in 1288 and has a council constitution in 1290. The town is destroyed in 1452 and only recovers badly.

Name: Neustadt (Orla)
Settlement_Description: First mention in the records as nova civitas in 1287.
Town_Description: The town was founded without a direct predecessor by Otto IV. of Loddeburg-Arnshaugk in 1287, even though there may have been earlier Slavic settlements.

Name: Rastenberg
Settlement_Description: First mention of the castle of Rastenberg in 1282, the residing family is already mentioned in 1252. The village of Rastenberg is first mentioned in 1333.
Town_Description: The village is elevated to town by the Wettins in 1378, but in the 15th century it was probably no more than a market borough (referred to as borough ('Flecken') in 1464). It started to thrive in the 16th century, but was hit hard by the 30-year war.

Name: Remda
Settlement_Description: First mention in the beginning of the 9th century in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis.
Town_Description: First mention as civitas in 1286.

Name: Ronneburg
Settlement_Description: First mention as property of the lords of Weida.
Town_Description: The town was a planned foundation in the north-east of the castle in the second half of the 13th century. The first citizen is mentioned in 1301. It was granted probably Gera town rights in the beginning of the 14th century, which were confirmed in 1380.
Fair_Description: Since 1594 several fairs, especially cattle markets are known.

Name: Schmölln
Settlement_Description: Even before 1066 a Benedictine monastery existed, possibly the oldest outside of the Ottonian bishop's see. It had market, coin and toll privileges.
Town_Description: Town and church are founded in 1238, there may have been first beginnings on the right bank of the Sprotte. In the 14th century Gera town rights are granted. In 1412 the town rights and privileges of the citizens are first confirmed.
Fair_Description: Fairs are first mentioned in 1524.

Name: Jaunjelgava
Settlement_Description: The place was probably built at the end of the 16th century, but was destroyed around 1600 during the Swedish-Polish wars. It served as a transshipment port from land to water.
Town_Description: The place received town rights for the first time around 1630. In 1647 these were confirmed.

Name: Sonneberg
Settlement_Description: Around 1200 castle Sonneberg is founded, at the foot of the castle a settlement Altenröthen already existed, which was soon replaced by the settlement of Röthen, which is first mentioned in 1260.
Town_Description: First mention as little town ("Städtchen") in 1317, it is elevated to town in 1349.
Fair_Description: In 1601 two fairs and a weekly market are mentioned.

Name: Stadtilm
Settlement_Description: First mention in a forged record from the middle of the 12th century that is dated to 1114.
Town_Description: The village developed into a town around 1280 - 1300. In 1350 the village is granted bylaws whose core goes back to the 13th century. It was granted new bylawes in 1596.

Name: Stadtlengsfeld
Settlement_Description: Mention of the castle of Lengsfeld as a fiefdom of Fulda in 1235.
Town_Description: In 1359 the town was granted market rights, it was probably elevated to town at the end of the 14th century.

Name: Stadtroda
Settlement_Description: A Cistercian nun convent was founded between 1228 and 1247.
Town_Description: The village is first referred to as town in 1333. It is granted town rights in 1340. The common law was recorded in the 15th century. A second market developed on the left bank of the Roda and became equal with the first foundation in 1523.

Name: Bad Sulza
Settlement_Description: First mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis. Further mention in 1046, when a market is founded, which slowly developed into a town.
Town_Description: In 1353 referred to as oppidum, but until the 16th century referred to as borough ('Flecken') and little town ('Städtchen'). A council constitution is only known since 1540.

Name: Tanna
Alternative_Name: Thanna; zu der Tannen; zur Tanne
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1232, when a clergyman is mentioned.
Town_Description: In 1495 town rights are granted, which are probably based on Schleiz town rights. Town bylaways remain from 1566 with references to earlier versions.

Name: Teichel
Settlement_Description: First mention in a gift certificate in 1076.
Town_Description: First mention as town in 1417, it was expanded and elevated to town by the counts of Schwarzburg before. In 1535 bylaws are mentioned which refer to older bylaws, which are based on those of Rudolstadt. Despite the town rights, Teichel always had a village-like character.

Name: Triptis
Settlement_Description: First mention in the context of a nunnery which was moved from Triptis to Zwickau. The counts of Lobdeburg-Arnshaugk can be seen as the founders of the market settlement which developed along with the castle.
Town_Description: First mention as civitas in 1378, the counts of Lobdeburg-Arnshaugk probably elevated the village to town at the end of the 13th century.
Toll_Description: From 1568 until 1688 the town owned rights to safe conduct.

Name: Ummerstadt
Settlement_Description: In 837 Fulda monastery was given property which could be interpreted as Ummerstadt.
Town_Description: In 1290 a citizen (civis) is mentioned and the settlement is referred to as town (opidum) since 1317, which leads to assume that it was elevated to town at the end of the 13th century.

Name: Weida
Settlement_Description: First mention in a record in the name of a witness.
Town_Description: First mention as a town in 1209, but it was probably elevated in the middle of the 12th century. Town rights remain from 1377 by Heinrich XV., but there may have been older ones.

Name: Zeulenroda
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1325, but the settlement probably developed in the middle of the 13th century.
Town_Description: Zeulenroda is granted town- and marketrights in 1438, probably due to its beneficial location at a traffic line.

Name: Bleicherode
Settlement_Description: Developed at the foot of the Löwenburg and the Wallburg.
Town_Description: Referred to as oppidum in 1326, as town in 1395. Town rights were probably granted in the first half of the 14th century, but they were lost and renewed in 1572.

Name: Cochstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in a gift certificate by Otto I. in 941, but it is probably older and emerged from two villages.
Town_Description: Cochstedt was granted town rights in 1535, market rights were probably granted earlier.

Name: Neuenkrug
Settlement_Description: Mentioned in several travel accounts on the main route from Stade to Bremen. An Inn where travellers could spend the night. Commendone and Ruggieri mentioned in 1561 that there were only two beds.

Name: Gerbstedt
Settlement_Description: Foundation of a nunnery in 985, which was later turned into a convent of Benedictine nuns. The nunnery converted to Protestantism in 1564 and existed until 1805. Since 1404 the settlement near the nunnery is referred to as a borough but it already owns a town hall.
Town_Description: Mentioned as oppidum in 1520. In 1530 town rights are granted by Karl V.
Toll_Description: At the beginning of the 16th century the income from safe conduct is recorded.
Fair_Description: With the awarding of town rights a fair is mentioned that is moved from its former location near the chapel at the Welfenholz.

Name: Stadt Gernrode
Alternative_Name: Rode; Gerenrode; Geronisroth; Geronrod; Gerenrodun; Gerenroht; Gernrode
Settlement_Description: First known through the castle of margrave Gero, but since his family died out, his seat was changed into a house of canonesses in 959. In 1604 the property was assimilated into imperial property.
Town_Description: The settlement near the nunnery is granted town rights by Abbess Anna of Plauen in 1549.

Name: Gouwsluis
Alternative_Name: ter Goude jnder sluyze op den Riin; Goutsluyse; Gouslus; Goudsluse; Goude-sluus; Goudersluys; Goutse Sluys; Goutsche Sluys
Lock_Description: The connection between the Gouwe and Rijn rivers is first mentioned in 1244. A flash lock must have existed here around the middle of the 13th century and is first mentioned in 1284. A second pound lock was built next to the old one in 1562 to increase the capacity of the system.

Name: Gröbzig
Settlement_Description: The castle of Gröbzig is first mentioned in 1291, the archbishopric of Magdeburg possibly held rights Gröbzig as early as 1176.
Town_Description: The settlement was referred to as town in 1401, in 1465 it gained borough rights ('Weichbildrechte').
Fair_Description: In 1587 the town was granted the privilege to hold two fairs.

Harbour_Description: In 1225, a canal was dug between the rivers Gouwe and Oude Rijn, and a harbour was constructed on the shores of the canal. On a map of town by Joan Blaeu from 1652, we can see that there was a crane next to the lock.
Lock_Description: A lock in Gouda is first mentioned in 1358 when it was complained that the lock was too small. It must have existed from the time that the Gouwe became a navigable waterway in the 13th century.

Name: IJzendijke
Alternative_Name: Isendica; Isendike; Ysendyk; Ysendica; Isendic; Ysendic; Isendika; Ysendonck; Ysendijcke; Isendique
Settlement_Description: The earliest mention of IJzendijk dates from 1046, this document, however, is a forgery made in the secund quarter of the twelfth century. The subsequent mentions dates from 1127.
Town_Description: Town rights were probably granted around 1238 by Joan of Constantinople, countess of Flanders. After an uproar of Flemish towns, IJzendijke lost its privileges in 1328, but these were regranted by 1330. According to Cox, IJzendijke ceased to exist due to floods and storm surges, especially in the years 1375/76, 1408 and 1437. J. Buisman gives a more precise date for this event, namely 1404. Present-day IJzendijke originated near a fortress built in 1587 and was elevated to town rank by Royal Decree in 1816.

Harbour_Description: The harbour in Gouda stretched between the market place and the Hollandse IJssel. On a map of town by Joan Blaeu (1652), we can see that the shores of the IJssel in front of the town walls were used as landing places for ships as well.

Name: Vreeswijk
Alternative_Name: Niewervart; Fresionouuic; Vresewik; Vresewike; Vrieswijc; Vreeswijc; Vrieswijc; Vreeswijck
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 918-948 (in an 11th-century copy).
Toll_Description: The toll of the bishop of Utrecht on shipping on the Vaartsche Rijn was partially moved from Oudegein to Vreeswijk when the "nieuwe vaart" was built around 1288 and the connection between the Lek and the Hollandse IJssel was closed with a dike.
Lock_Description: The "nieuwe vaart" between the Lek and the Vaartsche Rijn was dug around 1288. A dam prevented direct passage for ships, which had to be dragged over it. An opening in the dam and two wooden locks were built in 1373.

Name: Apenburg
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1264, but this early settlement was destroyed before 1344.
Town_Description: The new settlement is moved and referred to as civitas, later it is usually called little town ('stedtchen'). In 1402 town rights are recorded.
Fair_Description: In 1445 three fairs with cattle trade are known.

Lock_Description: The lock was located at the end of the Sasse Vaart, which ensured a connection with the sea for the town of Gent. Permission for digging the Sasse Vaart was granted in 1547, by Emporer Charles V. In 1549, permission for building the lock followed. Construction works on the lock were completed in 1563.

Name: Güsten
Alternative_Name: Gusthen; Gutstein; Gozene; Ghozsten; Güzsten; Goztene
Settlement_Description: First mention as property of the archbishopric of Magdeburg through a gift by Otto I.
Town_Description: Granted town rights in 1373, which were confirmed in 1459 and 1551, but it never elevated to be more than a farming town.

Name: Harzgerode
Settlement_Description: In 993 Otto III. grants market-, coin and toll rights to the settlement of Hagenrode. At the end of the 13th century the dukes of Anhalt construct a castle in Harzgerode.
Town_Description: In 1338 Harzgerode is the first Anhaltinian village to be elevated to town.

Name: Heldrungen
Settlement_Description: First mention in 847, this settlement was deserted though. After the construction of the water castle people settled near it.
Town_Description: Town rights were granted in 1530 by emperor Karl V.
Fair_Description: One fair is known in 1516.

Name: Oudegein
Toll_Description: A toll levied by the bishop of Utrecht on shipping on the Vaartsche Rijn at Gein was first mentioned in 1200. A source from 1244 specifies this toll as a fee for the cargoes that were transshipped here with a crane and the ships that were dragged across the dike. Citizens from Utrecht were exempted from the toll in 1305. After the Hollandse IJssel was closed off from the Lek river and a "nieuwe vaart" was dug to connect the Vaartsche Rijn and the Lek river in ca. 1288, the toll was also levied in Vreeswijk.
Lock_Description: The Vaartsche Rijn canal met with the dike Randijk at Oudegein. Originally, ships and their cargoes had to be dragged over the dike here. After the Hollandse IJssel had been closed off from the Lek river, minimising the risk of inundations, a lock was built in the Randijk, which gave the canal its current name Doorslag.

Name: Heringen (Helme)
Settlement_Description: Mention in a record by Ludwig the German together with Nordhausen.
Town_Description: In 1339 a castle is erected and the settlement is elevated to town by Dietrich IV. von Honstein.
Fair_Description: Since the 14th century two fairs are known.

Name: Lutjebroek
Settlement_Description: Lutjebroek is first mentioned c1312. On 14 October 1402, Lutjebroek was added to the ‘stede’ Broek, which already consisted of Grootebroek and Bovenkarspel. These two settlements had been granted town privileges on 2 August 1364 by Albert ('Albrecht'), governor ('ruwaard') of Holland. In 1403, Hoogkarspel was also added to this ‘stede’. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The 'stede' lost its privileges in 1426, but these were partly regranted in 1429, and fully restored in 1436.

Name: Venhuizen
Alternative_Name: Veinhusen; Veenhusen; Veen husen; Venhuise; Venhuysen
Settlement_Description: Venhuizen is first mentioned around 1312. On 2 February 1414 Venhuizen, together with the village Hem, was granted town privileges by William (‘Willem’) VI, count of Holland. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments.

Name: Oudkarspel
Alternative_Name: Aldenkercha; Outkerspel; Oudekerspel; Oude Carspel; Oudtkarspel; Oudt Carspel
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Oudkarpsel is first mentioned in 1094 (then spelled as ‘Aldenkercha’). The subsequent mention dates from 1289. On 12 May 1415, Oudkarspel, together with the villages Noord-Scharwoude, Zuid-Scharwoude, and Broek op Langedijk, was granted town privileges by William (‘Willem’) VI, count of Holland. Oudkarspel, Noord-Scharwoude, Zuid-Scharwoude and Broek op Langedijk combined formed the ‘stede’ Langedijk. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The town privileges were withdrawn on 13 and 20 August 1426.

Name: Noord-Scharwoude
Alternative_Name: Bernardeskercha; Norscorwoude; Norsscherwoude; Nortscerwoude; Noertscherwoude; Nortscherwoude; N. Schermwou; Noordt Scherwoude; Noordscharwoude
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Noord-Scharwoude is first mentioned in 1094 (then spelled as ‘Bernardeskercha’). The subsequent mention dates from 1289. On 12 May 1415, Noord-Scharwoude, together with the villages Oudkarspel, Zuid-Scharwoude, and Broek op Langedijk, was granted town privileges by William (‘Willem’) VI, count of Holland. Noord-Scharwoude, Zuid-Scharwoude, Oudkarspel and Broek op Langedijk combined formed the ‘stede’ Langedijk. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The town privileges were withdrawn on 13 and 20 August 1426.

Name: Zuid-Scharwoude
Alternative_Name: Sudrekercha; Suscerwoude; Zuusscherwoude; Suutscerwoude; Zuutscerwoude; Suytscherwoude; Suijder Woude; Z. Schermwou; Suydt Scherwou; Zuid-Scherwoude; Susscherwoude; St. Pieterskarspel; Zuidscharwoude
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Zuid-Scharwoude is first mentioned in 1094 (then spelled as ‘Sudrekercha’). The subsequent mention dates from 1289. On 12 May 1415, Zuid-Scharwoude, together with the villages Oudkarspel, Noord-Scharwoude, and Broek op Langedijk, was granted town privileges by William (‘Willem’) VI, count of Holland. Zuid-Scharwoude, Noord-Scharwoude, Oudkarspel and Broek op Langedijk combined formed the ‘stede’ Langedijk. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The town privileges were withdrawn on 13 and 20 August 1426.

Name: Broek op Langedijk
Alternative_Name: Broec; Franlorebroech; Broeck opten dijck; Brock; Langhendyck; Broeck; Broek op Langendijk
Settlement_Description: According to Van Berkel & Samplonius, Broek op Langedijk is first mentioned in the 1420 copy of a document dating from the twelfth century. The subsequent mention dates from 1216. On 12 May 1415, Broek op Langedijk, together with the villages Oudkarspel, Noord-Scharwoude, and Zuid-Scharwoude, was granted town privileges by William (‘Willem’) VI, count of Holland. Broek op Langedijk, Noord-Scharwoude, Zuid-Scharwoude and Oudkarspel combined formed the ‘stede’ Langedijk. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The town privileges were withdrawn on 13 and 20 August 1426.

Name: Wijdenes
Alternative_Name: Widenesse; Wiedenesse; Wijdenesse; Widenisse; Wyd Nes
Settlement_Description: Wijdenes is first mentioned around 1312. Together with the village Oosterleek, the settlement was added to the ‘stede’ Schellinkhout in 1414. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. Wijdenes and Oosterleek were separated from the ‘stede’ Schellinkhout on 6 January 1430 and were granted their own town privileges.

Name: Oosterleek
Settlement_Description: Oosterleek is first mentioned in1311. Together with the village Wijdenes, the settlement was added to the ‘stede’ Schellinkhout in 1414. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. Oosterleek and Wijdenes were separated from the ‘stede’ Schellinkhout on 6 January 1430 and were granted their own town privileges.

Name: Aartswoud
Alternative_Name: Nedartswoude; Ederswoude; Edaertswoude; Edairtswoude; Eertswoude; Aertswout; Aertswoude
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1312. Next mention in circa 1338. On 2 February 1414, Aartswoud, together with Hoogwoud, was granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Aartswoud and Hoogwoud combined formed the ‘stede’ Hoogwoud. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The stede lost its town privileges on 13 August 1426, but these were re-granted on 29 March 1450.

Name: Oude-Niedorp
Alternative_Name: Nienthorp; Nethorp; Oudeniedorp; Oudenyedorp; Ouden Nyedorp; Oude Nyedorp; Oud Nierop
Settlement_Description: The first mention of Oude-Niedorp occurs in a circa 1420 copy of a document that probably dates from the end of the eleventh century. The subsequent mention dates from 1180 (in a twelfth century copy). Oude-Niedorp, together with Nieuwe-Niedorp, was granted town privileges on 12 May 1415 by William VI, count of Holland. The original document has not survived. Oude-Niedorp and Nieuwe-Niedorp combined formed the ‘stede’ Niedorp. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. As a result of the Hook and Cod wars, the ‘stede’ lost its town privileges in August 1426. The town rights were re-granted on 8 May 1452.

Name: Nieuwe-Niedorp
Alternative_Name: Niewenniedorp; Nyenyedorp; Nuwen Nyedorp; Nyerop; Nierip
Settlement_Description: Nieuwe-Niedorp is first mentioned in 1289. Nieuwe-Niedorp, together with Oude-Niedorp, was granted town privileges on 12 May 1415 by William VI, count of Holland. The original document has not survived. Nieuwe-Niedorp and Oude-Niedorp combined formed the ‘stede’ Niedorp. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. As a result of the Hook and Cod wars, the ‘stede’ lost its town privileges in August 1426. The town rights were re-granted on 8 May 1452.

Name: Kölleda
Settlement_Description: First mention in 802.
Town_Description: Granted town rights in 1392, before it already owned market rights.

Name: Opmeer
Settlement_Description: Opmeer is first mentioned around 1312. In 1414, the settlements Opmeer, Hensbroek, Spanbroek and Obdam were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Spanbroek. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. For political reasons, the ‘stede’ lost its privileges in 1426. By 1434, the territory was divided between several lords.

Name: Kroppenstedt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 934, when it is given by Heinrich I.
Town_Description: In 1254 a council constitution can be proven, so it can be assumed that Kroppenstedt was given town rights when it was given to the bishopric of Halberstadt in 1253.

Name: Obdam
Settlement_Description: According to Cox, Obdam is first mentioned around 1312. Van Berkel and Samplonius take a slightly later early date, referring to a 1420-copy of an early thirteenth century text. In 1414, the settlements Obdam, Opmeer, Spanbroek and Hensbroek were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Spanbroek. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. For political reasons, the ‘stede’ lost its privileges in 1426. By 1434, the territory was divided between several lords. In 1456, Obdam and Hensbroek received their own town privileges as ‘stede’ Obdam-Hensbroek, separate from the ‘stede’ Spanbroek.

Name: Hensbroek
Alternative_Name: Hensbroec; Heensbroke; Heynsbrouck; Hensbroeck; Hemsbrouck; Hijnsbrouk
Settlement_Description: Hensbroek is first mentioned around 1312. In 1414, the settlements Hensbroek, Opmeer, Spanbroek and Obdam were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Spanbroek. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. For political reasons, the ‘stede’ lost its privileges in 1426. By 1434, the territory was divided between several lords. In 1456, Hensbroek and Obdam received their own town privileges as ‘stede’ Obdam-Hensbroek, separate from the ‘stede’ Spanbroek.

Name: Benningbroek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1338. In 1414, Benningbroek and Sijbekarspel were granted town rights by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Sijbekarspel. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. For political reasons, the town rights were withdrawn in 1426. The privileges were temporarily regranted in 1428 and 1452, before they were permanently restored in 1456.

Name: Laucha (Unstrut)
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1124.
Town_Description: Granted town- or at least borough rights in 1344. Definitely granted town rights in 1409 by margrave Friedrich of Meißen.
Fair_Description: In 1419 Friedrich the Silly granted two fairs.

Name: Oosterblokker
Alternative_Name: Oesterbloecwere; Oisterblocwer; Oosterblocweer; Oister Bloicker; Ooster Blocker; Ooster blocker
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1312. In 1414, Oosterblokker, Westwoud and Westerblokker were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements became the ‘stede’ Westwoud. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments.

Name: Westwoud
Alternative_Name: Westenwoude; Westen woude; Westwoude; Westewoud; West Wout
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1312. In 1414, Westwoud, Oosterblokker and Westerblokker were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements became the ‘stede’ Westwoud. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. In 1493, the administrative region (‘banne’) Westwoud was split into Westwoud and Binnenwijzend. Binnenwijzend then got its own village government and representatives within the ‘stede’ Westwoud.

Name: Wadway
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1256, in a copy dating from circa 1300. In 1414, the settlements Wadway, Hauwert, Nibbixwoud and Wognum were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Wognum. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The ‘stede’ Wognum lost its town rights in 1426 and is permanently added to the jurisdiction of Hoorn in 1436. On the level of village government, they kept their independence.

Name: Wognum
Alternative_Name: Wokgunge; Woggungen; Wognem; Wogghenem; Woggenom; Woggenum
Settlement_Description: Wognum is first mentioned in the first half of the eleventh century. In 1414, the settlements Wognum, Hauwert, Nibbixwoud and Wadway were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Wognum. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The ‘stede’ Wognum lost its town rights in 1426 and is permanently added to the jurisdiction of Hoorn in 1436. On the level of village government, they kept their independence.

Name: Nibbixwoud
Alternative_Name: Nuweboxwoude; Nieweboxwoude; Nyeboxwoude; Nubodwoude; Nibikswout; Nubucxwoude
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1312. In 1414, the settlements Nibbixwoud, Hauwert, Wognum and Wadway were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Wognum. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The ‘stede’ Wognum lost its town rights in 1426 and is permanently added to the jurisdiction of Hoorn in 1436. On the level of village government, they kept their independence.

Name: Hauwert
Alternative_Name: Oudeboxwoude; Oudebocxwoude; Hauwaert; Hauwerden; Obexwoude; Hauwart
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention of 'Oudeboxwoude" in circa 1312. Earliest mention of 'Hauwaert' in 1494. In 1414, the settlements Hauwert, Wognum, Nibbixwoud and Wadway were granted town privileges by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Wognum. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The ‘stede’ Wognum lost its town rights in 1426 and is permanently added to the jurisdiction of Hoorn in 1436. On the level of village government, they kept their independence.

Name: Lambertschaag
Alternative_Name: Lambrechtscoch; Lambrechtscaghe; Lambrechtscoich; Lambrechtkage; Lammerskage; Lambertscagen; LambertSchage; Lammerschage
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1312. In 1414, Lambertschaag, Abbekerk, Twisk and Midwoud were granted town rights by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Abbekerk. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The stede lost its town privileges in 1426. These were temporarily restored in 1436 and 1452. In 1456, the restoration of the privileges was made permanent.

Name: Twisk
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention probably in 1243-1245. The subsequent mention dates from 1311. In 1414, Twisk, Lambertschaag, Abbekerk and Midwoud were granted town rights by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Abbekerk. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The stede lost its town privileges in 1426. These were temporarily restored in 1436 and 1452. In 1456, the restoration of the privileges was made permanent.

Name: Mücheln
Alternative_Name: Muchileburg; Muchilacha; Mochenleiuaburg; Mucheln; Muchil; Muhchele
Settlement_Description: First mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis.
Town_Description: Friedrich the Stern elevated the settlement to town in 1350.

Name: Midwoud
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in circa 1312. In 1414, Midwoud, Lambertschaag, Twisk and Abbekerk were granted town rights by William VI, count of Holland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Abbekerk. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. The stede lost its town privileges in 1426. These were temporarily restored in 1436 and 1452. In 1456, the restoration of the privileges was made permanent.

Name: Barsingerhorn
Alternative_Name: Bersincshorne; Bersinghehorne; Bersingherhoirne; Bersingerhorne; Barsingherhoirne; Barsinghehorne; Bersingerhorn; Barsinger Horn
Settlement_Description: Barsingerhorn is first mentioned in 1289. Barsingerhorn and Haringhuizen were granted town rights on 12 May 1415 by William VI, count of Holland and Zeeland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Barsingerhorn. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. Many of the town privileges granted in the West-Friesland area (in which Barsingerhorn and Haringhuizen are situated) were withdrawn in 1426. New town privileges were granted to Barsingerhorn in 1427. However, as the lord granted these rights did not have the authority to do so, the privileges were again withdrawn in 1436.

Name: Haringhuizen
Alternative_Name: Die Niewekerc; Heringhehusen; Herinchuzen; Harinchuysen; Harinckhuyse
Settlement_Description: Haringhuizen is first mentioned in 1338, then called 'Die Niewekerc'. It is first mentioned as Haringhuizen in 1344. Haringhuizen and Barsingerhorn were granted town rights on 12 May 1415 by William VI, count of Holland and Zeeland. Together, these settlements formed the ‘stede’ Barsingerhorn. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments. Many of the town privileges granted in the West-Friesland area (in which Haringhuizen and Barsingerhorn are situated) were withdrawn in 1426. New town privileges were granted to Barsingerhorn in 1427. However, as the lord granted these rights did not have the authority to do so, the privileges were again withdrawn in 1436.

Name: Prettin
Settlement_Description: It appears as burgward in the 11th century, in 1012 Prettin goes to the archbishopic of Magdeburg.
Town_Description: In 1523 probably Magdeburg town rights are confirmed, it is unclear when they were first granted (possibly in the middle of the 12th century). Market rights were granted in 1565

Name: Raguhn
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1285.
Town_Description: First referred to as town in 1395, granted an own jurisdiction. Town rights may have been granted as early as 1259.

Name: Hoornbrug
Settlement_Description: A chapel of the Holy Cross was built south of the bridge in 1502 by Comen Gheryt van Leyden as gratitude for the safe return from his pilgrimage to Jerusalem. The chapel was probably destroyed during acts of war in 1572-1575.
Bridge_Description: The bridge is first mentioned in 1340. Probably this was a wooden bridge with a foundation of bricks. A new bridge with two arches was built entirely from bricks in 1601-2.

Name: Schildau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1184 in the Petersberg chronicle.
Town_Description: Town rights were possibly granted in the 15th century, 1445 the settlement has an own sigil. In 1528 citizens are mentioned.
Fair_Description: In the 17th century the town gains some wealth through three fairs.

Name: Bad Schmiedeberg
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1332.
Town_Description: First referred to as civitas in 1350, mention of a town hall in 1379.

Name: Schraplau
Settlement_Description: First mention in the Hersfelder Zehntverzeichnis. The castle was constructed around 1200.
Town_Description: In 1497 referred to as oppidum, soon after that administrated by a mayor and a council. Town rights were probably only granted in the 1740s.

Name: Teuchern
Settlement_Description: First mention in 933, in 981 mentioned as a district ('Gau'), 1140 referred to as villa.
Town_Description: In 1480 fairs and weekly markets are granted probably town rights as well.
Fair_Description: In 1480 two fairs are granted.

Name: Treffurt
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1104, former rural village in the 11th century, the construction of a castle facilitated an economic upswing. Develops into a market borough ('Marktflecken').
Town_Description: In 1532 extended market rights granted by Karl V, but not granted town rights.

Name: Wegeleben
Settlement_Description: First mention in a family name, who probably constructed the castle in the 12th century.
Town_Description: Settlement counts as town since 1267, when it already has a wall. It is referred to as civitas in 1288. In 1354 a mayor and a council are mentioned, but Wegeleben is still referred to as borough ('Flecken') most of the time.
Fair_Description: In 1651 a fair is confirmed.

Toll_Description: A toll was collected in Wegeleben in order to maintain the stone bridge, it was confirmed in 1651.
Bridge_Description: At some point there was a stone bridge across the Bode in Wegeleben.

Name: Wörlitz
Settlement_Description: First secure mention in 1004, possibly as early as 965, but the authenticity of the record is contested. Possibly a burgward centre, which would make Wörlitz one of the earliest burgwards.
Town_Description: In 1440 referred to as town, but after that also mentioned several times as borough ('Flecken'), market borough, little town ('Städtlein') or town.

Name: Ziegenrück
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1327, when the gift of property in Ziegenrück is confirmed. It may have been in noble property since the 13th century. According to legend, Charlemagne built the castle in order to defend against the Sorbs, but there are no remains of this castle.
Town_Description: In 1328 house and town of Ziegenrück are first mentioned, town rights were possibly granted at the beginning of the 13th century. In 1527 all town privileges are revoked due to participation in the Peasant's War. After that it is referred to as borough ('Flecken'). It only earns new bylaws in 1853.

Name: Großlöbichau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1001 (MGH DO II 393).

Lock_Description: A dam closed off the Delf from the Ems river in 1272, in which three sluices ('zijlen') were constructed.

Name: Oudeschans
Alternative_Name: Oude Schans; Bellingwolster Schans; Bellingwolder-Schans; Bellingwolderschans; De Oude Bellingewolder Schans; Bellingwolderzijl
Settlement_Description: The fortress ('schans') Bellingwolderschans was constructed in 1593. Later it became known as Oude Schans.

Name: Voorburg
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 918-948, in a eleventh century copy. Next mention in 1198.

Name: Göttern
Settlement_Description: First mention in 822 - 842.

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Dinkel "near Spechtholte" is first mentioned in 1365.

Harbour_Description: The Sieg river was navigable until Siegburg until the 19th century and reached town via the Mühlengraben, which is first mentioned in 1183-85. A small harbour is known in front of the Cologne gate in the 16th century.

Name: Aggerbrücke
Toll_Description: A bridge toll at the bridge across the Agger of the Dukes of Berg is first mentioned in 1357. They promised to abolish the toll, but in later times it still exists. In the 16th century, the abbot of the monastery of Siegburg was responsable for the levying of the toll. A toll house still existed in 1805.
Bridge_Description: Bridge across the Agger between Troisdorf and Siegburg, first mentioned in 1357 in connection with the bridge toll.

Name: Hellevoetsluis
Settlement_Description: The fortress ('vesting') Hellevoetsluis was built in the early 17th century as a navy harbour.
Harbour_Description: Around the lock Hellevoetsluis, a harbour for the surrounding region developed.
Lock_Description: A sluice was built in the dike around the polder Struijten (1533) for the water management of the polder Nieuw Helvoet (1394).

Ferry_Description: According to Horsten, the ferry was located on the site of the former 'Veerbrug', a bridge first mentioned in 1752.
According to Horsten, the ferry was located on the site of the former 'Veerbrug', a bridge first mentioned in 1752.

Name: Reifenstein
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1123.

Name: Damme (Brugge)
Alternative_Name: Dam; in den Dam; ten Damme
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1180.

Name: Drie Fonteinen
Lock_Description: The locks of Drie Fonteinen south of Vilvoorde were constructed in the canal Brussel-Willebroek between July 1560 and September 1561.

Name: Willebroek
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1189.

Name: Oudenbosch
Alternative_Name: Barlebosche; Berlebosse; Berlebosch; Oudenbossche; Vetusbuscum; Baerlebossche; Baerlebosch
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1275 as a settlement in the Baerlebosch forest. When another settlement Nieuwenbosch was founded in the 14th century, the older settlement became known as Oudenbosch.

Name: Kruisstraat
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1565. The hamlet is named after its location on the crossing of two roads.

Name: IJsselmonde
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1125-1130 (in a copy of ca. 1420).

Name: Obergebra
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1221.

Harbour_Description: The Schuitendiep was dug around 1400 and extended to Zuidbroek in 1628 and Winschoten in the 1630s. The Damsterdiep was dug in 1424 and connected Groningen with Appingedam and Delfzijl. Regular barge ('trekvaart') services took place on both canals from the middle of the 17th century; the barges moored in Groningen in the vicinity of the Steentil bridge, as can be seen on 17th-century maps of the city.

Name: Beek (Xanten)
Toll_Description: The Count of Kleve levied a river toll on the Rhine from 1385 to 1400/01. Furthermore, a transshipment toll was levied by him in 1366.

Name: Strümp
Toll_Description: In Stümp, a land toll was levied from 1294 until about 1454/60. After that, the toll was transferred to the Brühl. The Count of Kleve held the toll until 1392, after which the toll fell to the Electorate of Cologne ('Kurköln').

Name: Alphen aan den Rijn
Settlement_Description: Alphen goes back to the Roman castellum Albaniana, located opposite the mouth of the Aar in the Rhine. It was first mentioned around 300, in a 7th-century copy. The castellum developed into the settlement Alphen in the Middle Ages.

Name: Harmelen
Alternative_Name: Hermale; Harmalen; Hermalen; Ermale; Heermalen; Heremael
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1202 is a falsification. Next mention is from circa 1220.

Name: Hazerswoude-Dorp
Alternative_Name: Hadewartswoude; Hadewertswoude; Haduardswoud; Haesairdwoude; Hasartswoude; Haserswoude; Hasertswoude
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1280-1287.

Name: Pausa
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1263, it is unclear whether it was based on a Slavic settlement.
Town_Description: In 1350 mention as civitas, but it was always a rather uninportant rural town.

Name: Naitschau
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1444.

Name: Hochdorf
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1143.

Name: Roringer Warte
Settlement_Description: The watchtower ('Warte') was part of the enclosure ('Landwehr') of Göttingen, which was probably completed in 1407/08.
Bridge_Description: Next to the tower there was a bridge across a moat.

Name: Seulinger Warte
Alternative_Name: Mägdebergswarte; megedeberchwarde; warde boven Sulingen; warthus boven Sulingen
Settlement_Description: The so-called Mägdebergswarte, first mentioned in 1437, was a watchtower ('Warte') of the enclosure ('Landwehr') of Duderstadt. In the same year a barrier ('Schlagbaum') was set up next to the tower. In the 16th century the name Sulinger Warte caught on. In 1535 a guard house ('Warthus boven Sulingen') was built. In 1589 a new one was erected. It is possible that the watchtower was already in ruins by then.

Name: Meerkerk
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1266.

Name: Nikolausberg
Alternative_Name: ecclesie sancti Nycolai in monte qui dicitur Wlrideshusen; Ulradeshusen; ecclesie sancti Nicolai in Adelradeshusen; Uthelradeshusen; Olredeshusen; Holredeshusen; Ulrideshusen; Olerdeshusen; up dem berghe to sinte Nycolaus; Ulrichishusen zcu S. Nycolao; sinthe Nicolawes berche to Olrikeshusen; Sinte Nicolaes berge; Olrickeshusen; Mons Sancti Nicolai; Clauweßberge; Sanct Nicolas; Claußberge; Nicolausberg
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1162, the settlement was originally called Olredeshusen or Adelradeshusen. The church of St Nicholas became a pilgrimage destination and thus the name Nikolausberg gradually replaced the old name of the village in the 16th century.

Name: Zwammerdam
Alternative_Name: Steckede sive Suadenburg; dammum in Suadenburch; Suademburgdam; Suadenborchdam; Swadenborchdam; Zwadenburgerdamme; Zwademardam; Zwamerdam; Zwaden-burgerdam
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1165. Zwammerdam is named after a dam that the count of Holland built in the Rhine in the 12th century.

Harbour_Description: Outer harbour of Schiedam

Name: Strienemonde
Toll_Description: A toll of the counts of Holland on the Striene river at Strienemonde is first mentioned in 1247 and last mentioned in 1398.

Harbour_Description: Geertruidenberg was a booming harbour town until the Maas was closed of near Heusden in 1271. After the flood of St Elisabeth in 1421, however, Geertruidenberg regained direct access to the Rhine and Meuse delta.

Name: Lügde
Alternative_Name: Liuhidi; Liuithi; Lugethe; Ludhe; Lugede; Luthen; Luthe; Luden; Ludge; Lugda; Lude; Lugede; Lugde; Lugdunum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 784. After the town Lügde developed on the opposite shore of the Emmer, the old settlement became known as Oldenlude and was abandoned in the 14th century.
Town_Description: Opposite the original settlement, a town developed, which is characterised as "civitas" in 1195. Around 1240, it became a town with Lippstadt town privileges.

Name: Kemnade
Alternative_Name: Keminetan; Keminata; Kimenaden; Keminada; Keminade; Kaminade; Kaminata; Caminata; Kemenadhen; Kemenaden; Kempnade; Kemmennaden; Kemnaw
Settlement_Description: The monastery of canonesses Kemnade was founded between 959 and 965. The monastery became part of the Benedictine order in 1147. Abolished in 1584.

Name: Hehlen
Alternative_Name: Heli; Heloon; Helen; Helenen; Heylen; Helem; Heelen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a register of possessions of the monastery Fulda from the 8th or 9th century.

Name: Ottenstein
Settlement_Description: Castle of the counts of Everstein and adjacent settlement, first mentioned in 1319. An earlier mention of 1192 cannot be verified.

Name: Bodenwerder
Alternative_Name: Werdere; Insula; Werthere; Insulam; Bodenwerdhere; Bodenwerdere; insulam Bodonis; Bodenverdere; Bodinwerder; Badenwerder
Settlement_Description: Bodenwerder came into existence as a trading place on a river island ('werder') in the Weser river. It was first mentioned in 1150.
Town_Description: Bodenwerder acquired town privileges after Holzminden model in 1287.

Harbour_Description: Harbour for the regular passenger barge services ('trekvaart') to Haarlem, dug in 1631.
Harbour for the the barge services ('trekschuit') to Amsterdam; the tow canal was dug in 1631.

Name: Grohnde
Alternative_Name: Gronede; Grone; Grouede; Grovede; Gronde; Groene; Groinde
Settlement_Description: A settlement is first mentioned in 1237-1247, a castle in 1395.

Toll_Description: The toll for sailing transport on the river Lek in Rhenen is probably the continuation of the early medieval (Carolingian) toll of Dorestad. It is first mentioned in Rhenen in 1220, but it is plausible that is was established there already earlier.The toll was owned by the Bishop of Utrecht who was the worldly ruler of the diocese Utrecht. Around ca. 1470 Utrecht Bishop David of Burgundy moved the toll to his residency Wijk bij Duurstede. A long term conflict about the location of the toll resulted in a temporary displacement of the toll back to Rhenen from 1546-1557. But after the last year the toll definitely was levied in Wijk bij Duurstede.

Bridge_Description: Imperial chancellor Dietrich von Portitz (1361 - 1367) had a bridge built across the Saale at Castle Giebichenstein and had the castle itself be rebuilt.

Name: Bottrop
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 1092.
Fair_Description: Bottrop was granted a retail and cattle fair on St Michael's Day in 1423.

Name: Gerstungen
Settlement_Description: In 1065, king Heinrich IV. writes records in Gerstungen. An existense of a market is assumed since the first half of the 11th century, the triangle shape of the market seems to confirm an early foundation. Gerstungen was a royal court in the 11th century. In 1311 a water castle can be proven in Gerstungen.

Harbour_Description: With the establishment of a trekvaart (tow-canal) on the Vliet canal between Leiden and Delft in 1636-1638, the Vliet was extended to the Galgenwater at the west side of the city.

Name: Assendelft
Alternative_Name: Asmedelf; Ascmannedelf; Eskmadelf; Eskendelf; Esknemendelf; Ascendelf; Ascamannasdelf; Assendelf
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the first half of the 11th century, in a copy from 1063.

Name: Rustenburg
Settlement_Description: The house Rustenburg is first mentioned in 1573. According to some authors, the name was derived from an inn.

Name: Kerkrade
Alternative_Name: Ecclesiam Rode; Kirchrode; Kerkrode; Kirchraede; Kerkenraede; Kerkrat; Kirchrode
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1108 or shortly after. Next mention in 1241.

Name: Bovenste Locht
Settlement_Description: First mentioned as toll station in 1356. Locht was divided into two settlements, Bovenste ('highest') and Onderste ('lowest') Locht, according to their place in the landscape.
Toll_Description: A toll station of the duke of Brabant-Limburg was first mentioned in 1356. In that year, the revenues were 15 Aachen mark, in 1374-1384 and 1389/90 10 mark, and in 1390/91 5 mark.

Name: Kunrade
Alternative_Name: Konnenrade; Kungenroide; Kongeroide; Conraedt; Cunroot; Kunraede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the 14th century.

Name: Sint Maarten
Alternative_Name: Niwelant; Ste Maertijn; Ecclesia beati Martini; Sinte Maertens; Sunte Meerten; Sunte Merten; Sunte Mertyns; Tnyeuwelant van Sente Mertin; S. Marten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1289. The settlement was originally called Nieuwland, but soon became known as Sint Maarten, after the patron saint of the local church St Martin.

Name: Saka
Settlement_Description: The area 'Saccze' was mentioned in a treaty ('Kurenvetrag') in 1230. In 1253 it fell to the Teutonic Order. At the end of the 14th century, Sacken was given as a fief several times. Sackenhausen was a complex of goods made up of several farms and an inn.

Bridge_Description: A "grote brugge" ('large bridge') across the Venta is mentioned in 1438, when it was restored.

Name: Stockum (Sauerland)
Alternative_Name: Stockum; Stochem; Stocheim; Stocheym; Stoicheym; Stockheim; Stuckhem; Stockheimb
Settlement_Description: First mentioned around 985.

Name: Beegden
Alternative_Name: Beegedem; Bekede; Beket; Beegde; Beecde; Beicden; Beecdem; Begden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1202.

Name: Ool
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1293.
Toll_Description: A toll on the Maas river in Ool is mentioned in 1393, when Reinald of Valkenburg gave his part in the toll to his half-brother Godfried II. The toll is mentioned again in 1545, but seems to have lost its significance by the 18th century.
Ferry_Description: A ferry across the Maas river in Ool is already mentioned in 1293.

Name: Rimburg
Alternative_Name: Rimbourg; Rincberge; Ringberg; Rengelberg; Rengelborg; Rynckburg; Remberg; Rimborgh; Rimborch
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1278.

Name: Binnenwijzend
Alternative_Name: Binnenwisen; Binnenwysen; Binnewijsen; Binnen Wiesen; Binne wysent; Binne Wysendt
Settlement_Description: Binnenwijzend is first mentioned around 1312. It was part of the administrative region (‘banne’) of Westwoud until 1493, when this administrative region (‘banne’) was split into Westwoud and Binnenwijzend. Binnenwijzend then got its own village government and representatives within the ‘stede’ Westwoud. This 'stede' (consisting of Westwoud, Oosterblokker and Westerblokker) had been granted town privileges in 1414 by William VI, count of Holland. These settlements, however, never developed an urban character. The granting of town rights was part of an administrative reorganization in which a number of smaller settlements were granted town rights in order to provide them with a certain degree of self-government which replaced the need for the count of Holland's bailiffs ('baljuws'). The settlements kept their own separate settlement governments.

Name: Knollendam
Alternative_Name: Oost-Knollendam; West-Knollendam; Cnollendam; Noord-Dam van de Zaenden
Settlement_Description: A dam that closed off the Zaan river from the Starnmeer lake was built in the late 13th century. It was first mentioned in 1347. A village developed around it. After the dam was demolished around 1635, the settlement was divided into Oost- and West-Knollendam on both shores of the Zaan.
Ferry_Description: After the dam was demolished around 1635, a ferry connected both shores of the river.
Lock_Description: A lock in the dam was constructed in 1374 and a second one in 1560. Around 1635, the entire dam was removed.

Harbour_Description: Harbour of Oudenbosch; the canal connecting Oudenbosch with the Mark river was dug in 1300. The harbour predominantly as transshipment harbour for peat transports.

Name: Oude veer
Ferry_Description: According to Horsten, a ferry over the river Mark, called the Oude veer (Old ferry), is mentioned on a 1656 map of Brabant by C.J. Visscher.

Name: Ginneken
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1246.

Name: Goirle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1215.

Name: Hedel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 815-816, in a copy from 1170-1175.

Name: Drunen
Alternative_Name: Hunen; Drone; Ter Unen; Vnen; Druenen; Druynen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the first quarter of the 13th century.

Name: Elshout
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1312-1350.

Name: Capelle
Alternative_Name: Capella; in der capelle tSprange; De Capel; 's Grevelduin-Cappel; Capelle Schrevelduin
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1257.

Name: Welleringhausen
Alternative_Name: Walberinchusen; Weldricheshusen; Walterinchusen; Walderzkenkusz; Weltersinchusz; Weltzerinchusen; Welderskusen; Welderickhausen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1194. It was characterised as village ('dorf') in 1382.

Name: Oberschledorn
Alternative_Name: Slethere; Scledere; Sledere; Slederen; Ouerenschleydern; Overnschleder; Obbernn Schleder; Oberschleidern
Settlement_Description: The settlement Sledere is first mentioned in 1245, but is impossible to discern if it concerns Oberschledorn or neighbouring Niederschleidern. First certain mention of Oberschledorn in 1386.

Name: Heel
Alternative_Name: Catualium; Catualivm; Hethele; Hedel; Hedele; Hedell
Settlement_Description: The settlement goes back to the Roman settlement Catualium, first mentioned in ca. 365 (in a 13th-century copy).

Name: Thorn
Alternative_Name: Tornensi monasterio; Torna; Turnis; Turne; Thoren
Settlement_Description: Thorn developed around a Benedictine nunnery that was founded in 992. In the 13th century, it developed into a secular ladies' convent with far-reaching autonomy.

Name: Panheel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned between 1417 and 1518.

Harbour_Description: A harbour in Wessem is first mentioned in 1119.

Name: Houten
Alternative_Name: Haltna; Haltnon; Altene; Halten; Alten; Hauten; Holten; Houtem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in a eleventh-century copy from a document from 918-948. Next mention in the tenth- eleventh century.

Name: Nettesheim
Toll_Description: In 1386, the Archbishop of Cologne levied a land toll and/or road toll ('viaticum'). In 1386/87, 1392/93 and 1398/99, 8 mark were collected each year. In 1442/43 the annual revenue was 16 mark, in 1444/45 24 mark.

Name: Pulheim
Toll_Description: The Duke of Jülich levied a road toll in 1500. Tariffs and revenues are not known.

Name: Geyen
Toll_Description: 1) From 1389, the Duke of Jülich levied a fee for safe conduct and a land toll here. Depending on the load, 2 to 3 white pfennigs ('Weißpfennige'/Albus) per horse had to be paid as escort fee. In 1389/93 the annual amount averaged about 316 mark per year, in 1398/99 about 192 mark. 2) In addition, the duke levied a road toll in 1500. Unfortunately, tariffs have not been preserved.

Name: Lövenich
Toll_Description: The Archbishop of Cologne levied a land toll in 1449. Tariffs are not known. The annual revenue amounted to about 200 guilders with the toll in Merheim. In 1455 Lövenich was a secondary toll station of Königsdorf.

Name: Lunteren
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1334.

Name: Scherpenzeel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1229

Name: Merum
Alternative_Name: Merehem; Merheim; Merheym; Meren; Mehrum; Memer; Meerem
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1101.
Fair_Description: A fair on the first Tuesday of September was held in Merum until the 19th century; first evidence for this fair comes from a toll regulation from Roermond that probably dates from the 15th century.

Name: Neuhaus (Wolfsburg)
Alternative_Name: Neuhaus; Novum Castrum; Novo Castro; Nyenhus; Nye Hus; Nigenhus bii Helingh; Nigehus; Nigehuß; Newenhus; Neuhauß
Settlement_Description: The castle Neuhaus was first mentioned in 1354.

Bridge_Description: A bridge across the Ilme between Einbeck and Salzderhelden is mentioned in 1463 and 1494.

Name: Salzderhelden
Alternative_Name: Salehelden; Sale iuxta castrum Helden; Sale; castrum dictum Solth; Helden; Salis; Solde; Sold; Salt; Salcze zur Helden; Solte der Helden; Solthe tor Helden; Szolte der Hellen; Solte thor Helle; Saltzderhelden; Saltz der Hellen; Soltz der Hellen; Salz tor Helde; Saltz der Helden
Settlement_Description: The saltworks in Salzderhelden are first mentioned in 1305, the castle in 1306, but it was possibly built in the 13th century. The settlement was characterised as borough ('blek' / 'flecken') since 1480, which received market privileges in 1509.
Toll_Description: A toll in Salzderhelden is first mentioned in 1422.

Bridge_Description: The bridge across the Leine river in Salzderhelden was first mentioned in 1482. Next to the bridge was a watchtower of the town of Einbeck.

Toll_Description: A toll on shipping on the Oste river at Neuhaus is mentioned in 1502.

Name: Greetsiel
Toll_Description: A toll was introduced in Greetsiel by count Johann II of East Frisia around 1576, which led to complaints from merchants from Emden and abroad. Cargo for which toll in Greetsiel already had been paid was exempted from toll in Emden.

Name: Stekene
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1296.

Name: Sint-Gillis-Waas
Settlement_Description: First mention in 1239.

Lock_Description: Steenkensrabot
Dorekensrabot
Blockerabot

Toll_Description: In the regulations of safe conduct of 1519 the fees for boats and ships are set as well.

Name: Krimpen aan de Lek
Alternative_Name: Crempene; Crenpene; Crimpen; Crimpen op de Merwede; Crimpen up die Merwede; Crympen op die Merwede; Crimpen upte Lecke
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1064 (in a falsification from the first half of the 12th century).

Name: Krimpen aan den IJssel
Alternative_Name: Crimpen super Yssel; Crimpen op die Ysele; Crimpen up die Ysele; Crimpen up d' Ysel; Crympen vp die Ysel; Crimpen upte IJsel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1277 (in a copy from 1329).

Name: Beetsterzwaag
Alternative_Name: Beetstersweach; Suagh; Beexterswage; Bexterszwaege; Betzerswaech; Beetsterswaegh
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1315.

Name: Akkrum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1315.

Name: Aldeboarn
Alternative_Name: Oldeboorn; Bornde; Borne; Boern; Alda Boern; Auwenborn; Oldenborn; Aldeboren; Oudeboorn
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1243.

Name: Oldenzijl
Lock_Description: A sluice ('zijl') between the Winsumer- and Reitdiep was first mentioned here in 1323. After a new connection was dug between both waterways more to the west in 1458-9, with a new sluice in Shaphalsterzijl, it became known as the old sluice (Oldenzijl). The sluice was demolished in 1636 after the Reitdiep was straightened.

Name: Schaphalsterzijl
Lock_Description: Sluice ('zijl') near Schapehals, built in 1458-9.

Name: Norg
Alternative_Name: Nurch; Norich; Niurech; Norech; Norch; Norgh
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1139 (in a 16th-century copy).

Name: Wolvega
Alternative_Name: Wolvegea; Wluegho; Wolvegae; Vuluega; Woluegae; Woluega
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1320.

Name: Heino
Alternative_Name: Heyna; Heyne; Heijn; Heijnen; Heyno; Heijno; Heijne
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1245.

Name: Wijthmen
Alternative_Name: Wytmen; Widmen; Wijtman; Wiitmen; Wijtmen; Wiitman; Wijthmen; Wijtman
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1207.

Name: Den Ham
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1333.

Name: Losser
Alternative_Name: Lutheri; Luithere; Lothere; Luthere; Ludere; Lotthere; Lotsere; Lossere
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the late 10th century.

Name: Hooge Mierde
Alternative_Name: Myrtha; Mirde; Myrta; Myrde; Hoghe Myerde; Hoge Mierde
Settlement_Description: The settlement Mierde (Myrtha) is first mentioned in ca. 1200. The addition "Hooge" was added later to discern it from neighbouring Lage Mierde.

Name: Poppel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1211.

Name: Budel
Alternative_Name: Budilio; Bodilio; Budil; Budela; Budele; Buedel; Buel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 779, in a 12th-century copy.

Name: Hamont
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1257.

Name: Achel
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1139.

Name: Bergeijk
Alternative_Name: Echa; Eka; Eyke; Bercheyck; Eycke; Bergh eyck; Bergeik
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1137, in a 13th-century copy.

Name: Kinrooi
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 1345.

Name: Neerpelt
Settlement_Description: Earliest mention in 815, in a copy dating from circa 1170. Next mention in 1107, in a thirteenth century copy.

Name: Haarle
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1367.

Name: Elsen
Alternative_Name: Elnse; Elnsen; Elsnem; Elsene; Elssen; Elzen
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1252.

Name: Aalten
Alternative_Name: Aladna; Alethnin; Aladon; Alethim; Alethen; Aelten
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 828, in a 11th-century copy.

Ferry_Description: Before the construction of the bridge in 1485, a ferry crossing must have existed at this place.
Bridge_Description: A bridge was constructed across the IJssel in Zutphen in 1485.

Lock_Description: After the water mill in Keppel had been demolished in 1582 to facilitate shipping on the Oude IJssel, the Lord of Keppel constructed a new mill in the southern arm of the river in 1537. The construction did not contain a lock, but the weir was built in such a way that ships could pass it with normal water levels. However, since the weir changed the water levels, it hindered shipping nevertheless. A court case between Doesburg and Keppel at the Guelders court did nothing to change the situation.
After the mouth of the Oude IJssel into the IJssel was moved south of town in 1605, a new pound lock complex was constructed to regulate the shipping on both rivers.

Name: 's Hertogenmolens
Lock_Description: Duke Willem II of Croÿ, lord of Aarschot, ordered the construction of new water mills in the Demer near the beguinage before 1520. Between the two mills, there was a lock through which ships could be dragged.

Name: Oldemarkt
Alternative_Name: Olden markt; Oldemarct; Oldemerct; Oldenmerckt; Olde Markt
Settlement_Description: Originally called Dodovene, first mentioned in 1336. The name Oldemarkt is first attested in 1448.

Name: Achterveld
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1309

Name: Woudenberg
Alternative_Name: Waldenberg; Woudenberghe; Woudenberch; Wouwenberg; Wouwenbergh; Woudenborch
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1327.

Name: Gronsveld
Alternative_Name: Groslas; Gruosles; Grule; Grunesele; Gronselt; Grueles; Grunselt; Grunsfilt; Gronsfelt; Gronsfeld; Grules
Settlement_Description: Gronsveld is first mentioned in a 673-690 document, then named Groslas. This document, however, is a twelfth-century copy of a falsification dated 1024-1031. The subsequent mention dates from around 1089 in a thirteenth-century copy.

Name: Rijckholt
Alternative_Name: Rykilt; Rikilt; Ryckelt; Rickholt; Ricquelt; Ricken; Ryckholt
Settlement_Description: The first mention of Ryckholt dates from 1330.

Name: Breust
Alternative_Name: villam Brusti; Brosten; Broiste; Broeste; Bruest in den Dael; Bruist; Bruyst
Settlement_Description: Breust is first mentioned in a seventeenth-century copy of a manuscript from 965. From the eleventh until thirteenth century, Breust and neighbouring settlement Eijsden were central to the cultivation of the Plateau of Margraten. The history of several villages there, can be traced back to either Breust or Eijsden.

Lock_Description: The count of Holland built a dam in the Rhine in the 12th century, in order to regulate water levels in Holland, but it led to water problems in Utrecht. Emperor Fredrick Barbarossa ordered the demolition of the dam in 1165, but to no avail: the dam remained, with an opening for ships to pass.

Harbour_Description: Due to the existence of three sluices between the Haarlem Lake and the IJ, the tow canal ('trekvaart') between Amsterdam and Haarlem, which was built in 1631, was interrupted in Halfweg. Passengers had to change barges here.

Name: Ouderkerk aan de Amstel
Alternative_Name: Ouderkerk; Ouder Amstel; Ouderkerken; Ouwerkerck; Oudekerck; Ouderkerck; Ouderamstel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1308.

Name: Baambrugge
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1394.
Bridge_Description: Baambrugge is named after a bridge across the Angstel.

Lock_Description: The Hinderdam, a dam with locks, was built in the Vecht river by the bishop of Utrecht in 1437, to protect the land from floods from the Zuiderzee. It replaced the Otterspoor dam near Breukelen. The dam was demolished around 1672, when new locks were built in Muiden.
The Otterspoor dam with locks, which served to protect Utrecht from high tides from the Zuiderzee, was replaced by the Hinderdam in 1437.

Name: Amstelveen
Alternative_Name: Amestelrevene; Aemstelreveen; Aemsterveen; tAmsterveen; Amsterveen; Nieuwer-Amstel
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1308.

Name: Leimuiden
Alternative_Name: Leymuiden; Leijmuiden; Letthemutha; Leithemutha; Leithemuthon; Leithemuthe; Leyemuyden
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in the first half of the 11th century.

Name: Castricum
Alternative_Name: Castrichem; Casterkem; Kasterkem; Castringhem; Castrikem; Castrichem; Castricom; Kastrikum
Settlement_Description: First mentioned probably in the late 11th century, in a copy from ca. 1420.

Name: Neer-Andel
Alternative_Name: Andel; Uutandele; Uutandels; Neerael; Neer Ael
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 1382.

Name: Ede
Settlement_Description: First mentioned in 838, in an 11th-century copy.
